Subject: input needed on custom short stroke 911 motor...please

 
hi, i could use any input from anyone out there, what i have is
3.0 turbo case
2.2s crank and rods
complete 77s 911 motor core
set of like new 3.3 turbo cly
 
what my plans are is to put the 2.2s crank in the 3.0 liter case
using the 66mm s rods and my 3.3 97mm turbo liners, have some
hi compresion pistons like 9.8-10.3 /1 made up to fit 
the 97mm turbo liners,and use all the stuff off the
2.7 motor..i.e layshaft,cam towers,sheetmetal,oil cooler
chain cases..ect...ect. i think that would make a nice
short stroke 2.9 liter motor
 
what would you recommend for...
 
 1. heads to use, i was thinking on 79 3.0 sc heads or 3.2 liter
 
 2. internal oil pump, like the 3.0 or 3.3 turbo
 
 3. cam selection, im going to use this mainly as a "street racer", so i was thinking
    of the mfi s or e grind
 
 4. the best/easiest fuel system either carbs or if not that great then getting
    a modified mech. fuel injection system

 and...

    or any other input from you would again be "GREATLY" APPRICIATED

Date: Tue, 31 Jan 1995 19:54:54 -0800
From: TIMC1@ix.netcom.com (Timothy Collins)
Subject: RE: Porsche Hood Shocks

>Does any one know where you can get some
>good aftermarket ones that will last at least 1 year.
>Steve Magown
Steve, 
Do not be discouraged by this experience. Hood shocks are
gas filled and, unlike Bilstein shocks, are shipped loose and
fully extended in cartons of up to 500 pcs from the manufacturer
in Germany. This sometimes causes the shafts to become pitted,
bent and for the seals to leak prematurely. This is not real common,
but not unheard of. You should find that your dealer knows about
this and will replace them. If not, get 'em from your friendly
Porsche mail order house from Pano. Nothing wrong with the product.

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 95 01:45:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Hot 951 wheel/brake


Sounds like you have a frozen brake calliper piston.  If that is the case,
you probably want to have a mechanic rebuild it and its three siblings.
The rebuild kits themselves are obscenely expensive.  You should
hope that disassembly, cleaning, and reassembly is sufficient.  But
don't count on it.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 95 08:18:52 +0100
From: Magnus Ottenstrom <magot@weald.air.saab.se>
Subject: 911 oil scum


It has been stated that the 911 can get this yellowish scum at the top
of the oil tank and in the hose that goes from the tank to the engine
(breather hose?). 

That's very true and if the car has been abused alot (short trips
which does not allow the oil to get warm) this scum gets collected
at the bottom of the oil tank.

The scum that owned my car before me appearantly collected a lot
of the oil scum in the tank. The problem is to get the tank clean
without removing it... You can get a piece of cloth on a wire up
through the drain hole but it's tricky. The breather hose can
easily be detached from the oil tank and cleaned (partially).

The bottom line is as stated before: get the oil really warm and
change oil regulary.

Magnus Ottentrom
'82 911 SC

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 09:39:41 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: CARS FOR SALE/ PARTS FOR SALE/WANTED


someone wrote:

| Contact Gary Stratton or  George Valerio @ 916.925.0911
| Tell them you got this from my post and maybe they'll cut me a deal on those 
| RSR wheels! (cough, choke)

| 6X16 & 7X16 alloys, $700

| 9X15 & 11X15 Factory RSR alloys, polished $4500

I know that a genuine set of RSR 15" are very rare, I don't know
what a good street price is. I have a vague memory of a pair of 11X15 
at 1000GBP (~1500 USD). I *DO* know that a set of 6X16 & 7X16
are as common as muck, in the UK you would be lucky to get 
350 GBP for these if they were in good shape, so I would consider
that in the US one would pay even less. So if the RSR set is as
overpriced as the 6X16 & 7X16 then don't cut a deal, just walk.

Further, we find:

- --------------------------

| 1984 Porsche Cab.  Roller, has all body parts, 6X16 & 7X16 factory alloys, 
| windshield cut for speedster glass, $4500

| 1989 speedster windshield, new in box, $4500

| 3.2 motor w/ all wiring, oil lines, brain, ready to bolt in, 40,000 miles 
| $6500

| 5 speed G50 for 911, $1000

- --------------------------

Given that significantly modified Porsche are depreciated rather than
appreciated, would you pay 16500 USD for a flat-pack speedster? Add
the cost of putting it together and painting it, and one would be
better off buying a factory Speedster. These prices look high in GBP
let alone USD? Is it just me, or is someone flying a kite?

Regards

Ben

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 95 08:45 EST

Depends on what you mean by "good".  I gave the Bazooka tubes a bye, since I
really couldn't see any place to put them.  If you really want some good bass,
consider a 10" free-air woofer in one of the back corner pockets.

	speaker for moderate power (30 or 40 watts)?  A lot of people talked 
	about Infinity speakers in the archived messages.  Andy?

I know Polk makes a decent one, haven't heard the Infinity.  I'm seriously
considering the Boston Acoustics separates, they're the best car audio speakers
I've ever heard (that I could afford!)  I'm also considering building some kind
of floor plate to slope from the bottom of the back seats to the back of the
front seats, I'm hoping there's enough room there to mount my BA 6x9s.  If not,
I'll probably have to mount them in my wife's car.

Mike, thanks for giving me the chance to set the record straight, as I 
screwed-up and deleted Arthur's post before it sunk in that I was being 
misquoted.  BFD you say, (and you're right. BFD indeed...)

What I said was that galvanization (NOT partial) started in '75 with the '76 
model, and that, given Porsche's proclivity to make running changes, some
'75s may have gotten the benefit.  But who cares? 

For the record.  My body is not galvanized.  And it shows!  (but, OTOH, my 
p-car's is...)

available for replacement of blade plus backing strip. I found out the hard way 
by getting a set which was too wide also but the store told me about the narrow 
configuration and changed my wide or standard version to the narrow.

I've seen specific information, too probably in a late
'70's Panorama. It might also be in Paul Frere's 911
book. I heard that Porsche has one of the first galvanized
bodies "in the zinc" on display outside the factory, so 
maybe Peter can answer this one.

As a point of reference, my '73 911 was partially 
galvanized. I'm not sure how much, but the whole
underside, fenders and wells and the rear valance
appeared to be galvanized. The only part that ever 
rusted was under the chrome kick-plates (at the top
of the rocker panels) and I think that was just because
water could get in there and take forever to dry out.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 09:45:49 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: '73 914 2.0 fuel injection


Dear Bart and everyone,

All 914 2.0 fuel injected engines start, run rough and die three times before
running smoothly when they are cold. the auxillary air valve, open when cold
adds more air for smoother idle when cold. After about five minutes, it heats
and closes. The problem with these valves (shaped like a barrel with a 90
degree hose fitting on top and a red wire exiting the bottom), is that over
the years, water vapor collects in them and rusts the valve shut. To repair,
pry off the top then sand and clean the valve until it slides smoothly and
then recrimp the top.

We have to fix these valves because new ones are totally unavailable and used
ones are expensive ($125.00). These companies you mentioned have varying
prices because they are all not selling the same thing. Bosch has superceded
the 1.7, 2.0 valve with the 1.8 variety and that is what Performance and
Stoddard are selling. And call Automobile Atlanta or AJ Racing. I'm sure at
that price it is the real thing, but I bet neither has stock to sell you! At
least Tweeks knows they are no longer available.

You definitely need an auxiliary air valve for smooth cold running, so fix
yours!

Three different head temp sensors were used on the 914 and some are more
expensive than others, but all will work. Order a generic cheap one or more
expensive matched one. These sensors provide increased resistance when cold
for a richer mixture and when not, almost no resistance for lean mixture.
Sometimes 914s become too lean when hot, so the factory trick is to add a 270
ohm resistor in line with the head sensor. this guarantees some residual
enrichment throughout the temperature range.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 09:40:56 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Driving Lts.


Dear Bryan(and all),

It's easy to independently wire the driving light! They were originally wired
to the low beams for US Federal regulations, but now, who cares?

Two wires need to be switched and the they are as follows:
     1. The white with blue striped wire exiting the 85 terminal on the
foglight relay has to be connected to a hot source. (The wire goes to the
high low beam relay on 70/71 and to the low beam on the fuseblock (fuse No.1)
on the '72 and later vehicles).
     2. The black with blue wire on the driving light switch terminal 15
needs to be connected to a hot source. It is originally connected to terminal
58b on the early 70/71 914s or terminal 56 on the 72 and up 914s on the
headlight switch.

Number one originally allows the lights to be operated only in the low beam
position while No.2 originally allows the driving lights to be operated only
when the headlamps are on. Sourcing differently switched hot sources for
these two wires will give you the driving light action you prefer.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 09:40:45 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 suspenion adjustment


Dear Nick,

You can easily lower the front of your 914 as long as it is not any lower
than the rear and the camber will adjust to at least 30 minutes negative and
preferably 0 degrees. Don't adjust the height by wheel well. Measure on a
level surface, from the center of the rear torsion bar to the ground on each
side and make sure they are even.

George Hussey

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 95 07:56:17 PST
From: radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
Subject: 914 Speakers and Airheads

          Greetings,

          Regarding the discussion on Porsche 914 stereo systems: I
          was always disappointed with the bass response from those
          dinky front speakers in the 914.  On the other hand, I
          didn't want to hack away at my car to install bigger
          speakers in a non-stock location.  So, I designed a
          subwoofer box with an 8" woofer -- it fits right in-between
          the two passenger seats (where the "third" seat used to be.)
          I designed the box to be removable, so that if I ever feel
          like having a stock 914, I just un-plug it (removing the
          crossover from the speaker loop) and put the pad back in.  I
          actually like having a raised box on the left -- it's the
          perfect arm rest height.  Also, I upholstered it in black
          vinyl to fit in the decor.  If anyone is interrested,  I
          could try to relate the basic design to you and tell you
          which woofers and crossover components to use.  (I used to
          have a speaker company I ran as a hobby before I got called
          up on my active duty Air Force assignment.)

          Regarding the flying discussion:  I am a current (student)
          pilot with 48 hours.  I take my FAA practical test in a week
          or two.  Wish me luck!

          -Tim

Date: 01 Feb 95 11:22:01 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: K&N filter concern

 
Hi, Larry.
 
The cloud of gas you describe is sometimes called "fuel standoff." You can
run a VW or 356 without an air cleaner, but you have to rejet the thing to
compensate for the leaning out at high rpm without the filter. For example,
with a two-barrel Solex, each barrel "robs" some fuel from the cloud, in
other words some of the fuel kicked up by the other barrel, giving
an enriching effect. If you could contain all of each barrel's cloud in
velocity stacks, you wouldn't get this effect, but you would need very long
stacks to do it.
 
I once saw a guy struggling to get his 356 to run without misfiring at a
slalom. I looked down inside his carburetors and noticed that he had very
neatly cut a thin sheet of rubber to form a gasket to his nifty velocity
stacks. The rubber gasket did not have any holes for the air correction
jets. When somebody pointed this out to him, he took off his stacks and gasket
and ran it again, and it misfired just as before. Reason: his air correction
jets were working again, but without the stacks he was still leaning it out
due to blown away standoff. Once he cut holes in the gasket and put the stacks
back on, the misfiring was considerably reduced. It still needs rejetting.
 
I found some stacks at a swap meet and began to fool with them on my car.
As expected, and just as everybody had told me, switching to stacks made the
engine go lean at high rpm. I went to smaller air correction jets, and that
helped, but I also had to go to bigger mains. I tested by putting my German time
 -speed-distance test rig on the car and measuring time intervals for every 5
mph in full-throttle 2nd gear acceleration. The funny thing is, with all that
induction noise coming from the back, you think "yeah, I'm really moving now"
but the test printout shows that the car is actually LOTS slower unless you do
a lot of rejetting -- and have an effective means to measure the performance
difference (dyno or road test gear; lots of stopwatch timing and averaging
otherwise).
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 01 Feb 95 11:22:09 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Tail happy 911s

 
Bill Elwell's response is the only one so far that emphasises the effects of
weight transfer, is the most cogent and I feel the only correct one so
far. Thanks for blowing away the smoke, Bill.
 
It is possible to spin just about any car by unloading the rear end. I have
even spun a VW GTI by braking hard in a turn. The GTI is more forgiving than
the 911 in this but the laws of physics remain the same.
 
Getting off the gas as the first action in a spin is just basically wrong,
especially in a 911 but in most cars. POWER STABILIZES THE REAR END. If it's
starting to go, there's a good chance it is doing so because you backed off
or braked, unloading the rear. Load it up again. Steer. This may not always
be possible because you are running out of road, etc. and the spin is going
to be inevitable. Given unlimited space to recover, most spins can be caught
again. Given you are trying to recover AND make the next cone/guardrail/etc.
recovery may no longer be possible. Try to keep as much power on the back, or
stay off the brakes as much as possible, while steering out of it.
 
Once you've lost the car completely, both feet in, steer as best you can, and
wait.
 
And yes, I do spin at slaloms.
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 95 09:27:57 MST
From: hrubin@nyx.cs.du.edu (Howard Rubin)
Subject: short shift

When I bought my 82 911SC it had the Automotion short shift, which I found
too short. I changed over to the factory kit and like it much better. It all
depends on how short a shift you want. The internal quality of the factory
kit seems a little better too. Both kits are easy to install. 
If you're interested in the Automotion kit, I'd be willing to sell it...

>with installing on this late 915 trans version? What would I expect? Any 
>difference between the factory version and say the Automotion version with

Try 2 or even 3 hood shocks on each side of your hood

>Does any one know where you can get some
>good aftermarket ones that will last at least 1 year.
>Steve Magown

Date: Wed,  1 Feb 95 08:44:05 TZ
From: Jim Harriger <jimharr@microsoft.com>
Subject: Porsche bike?

someone recently speculated here about a possible Porsche motorcycle.

in the Cycle World that came in the mailbox yesterday, there is a full page
speculation, with two artists renderings, about what the bike might be, and
when it might be available. the high points:

 -single-sided front suspension, with shock located behind the steering axis
 -140hp, 4-cyl, with variable valve timing (variomatic?), FI w/DME
 -shaft drive, w/seperate control arm to minimize shaft effect.
 -6-speed with electronic control, shifting by std. lever, or rocker sw. 
on handlebar
					(tiptronic on a bike?)
 -available '96 or '97

 -no price speculated on, but they did note that Porsche technical excellence is
	not cheap!

(this information is attributed to Motorrrad Reisen & Sport, a german m/c
magazine)

if this is for real, and i don't have to sell my house to buy one, i could have
two porsches in my garage, and still have room for the pickup! I WANT ONE!


anybody have any REAL(tm) information? are these guys smoking old
air filters (paper or otherwise :-) ) ?


						jim harriger

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 12:14:39 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Converting to Euro-driving lights on 951

If anyone breaks a lense, they can get a pair of euro-driving lights
for $129.

1) Remove the relector assy from the broken lense

2) Replace the blank assy on the good lense with the reflector assy
from the broken

3) Buy a euro fog-light assy.


You'lll find the euro and USA assy's are identiocal with the exception
of the replacement of the blamnk-plate with a driving light reflector,
which is identiacl to the fog reflector.

FYI,
	Steve

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 95 12:48:37 EST
From: weltyc@cs.vassar.edu (Chris Welty)
Subject: February Porsching Column


Porsching by Chris Welty, Hudson-Champlain Region

When You Wish Upon a Star - Part II

Some time later, sitting in La Guardia Airport, the magnitude of the
moment had yet to smash its way into my head.  My entire body was
tingling, my stomach twisted with an odd combination of excitement and
dread.  After all, I was embarking on a mission the successful
completion of which would transform a lifetime dream into reality.  In
addition, I was about to spend more money than I'd ever spent in my
life on something that many people would call frivolous and
self-indulgent.  Visions of poor, starving children in drought-ridden
Ethiopia and, for that matter, on the Park Avenue median, flashed
through my mind.  Unable to withstand the burden of guilt weighing on
my conscience, I quickly jumped up and ran down the terminal.  John
and Karl, babbling about some kind of pressure chain fed update
tensioner, were oblivious to my action.  I had no idea where I was
going, but I was clearly being driven by some benevolent force, for
there, in front of me, was a small, thin, pathetic looking child - the
word orphan written all over him.

"Hey kid," I huffed, realizing that I'd run about two
miles. "Why do you have `orphan' written all over you like
that?'

"Huh?" the kid responded, suspiciously turning towards me.

"Never mind, you poor child," I said.  "Is it tough being an
orphan?"

"Orphan?  I'm no..."

"Parents killed in an auto accident?"  I figured that seemed the most
likely cause, these days. 

"They were???" he responded, wildly searching the Airport with his
eyes.

"That's just terrible.  I'm sure they never meant for you to be
alone in the world," I said, reaching into my wallet.  The poor kid
had become frantic, and had started to cry.  I figured he was calling
up memories of his parents death, which was probably a good thing for
him to face up to. In fact I remembered that "hail hail fire and
snow" episode of Star Trek where McCoy told Kirk that it was
unhealthy for a bunch of children whose parents had just died not to
be crying.

"Mooooooommmmmmeeeeeee," he cried.

"There there," I comforted.  "I know it's hard to accept, but
crying is good, you should let it out.  Here's a few bucks for you.
I'll bet your parents would have wanted you to go to college, so put
that in the bank and with interest it'll be ten dollars one day."

By now the kid was hysterical, and I figured he needed to be left
alone, so I headed back to the terminal, my conscience clear after
having done my good deed.  I was now ready to be self indulgent, and
as I approached John and Karl (who were still unaware of my absence) I
couldn't help but notice a faint, shimmering haze which seemed to
surround them.  Although I dismissed it as a slight misting in my eyes
(the result of my recent emotional experience with that poor orphaned
boy), in the back of my mind things were beginning to click together,
and I was becoming dimly aware that other forces were at play here,
forces that would not allow me to fail in my quest.

We boarded the plane, found our seats, and unloaded the 200 pounds of
Porsche literature John had brought for our perusal.  I was amazed at
the amount of material that had been written on these cars.  By the
end of the flight, I already felt I was an expert on all aspects of
the 911.  I learned that the topic of the discussion in the terminal
had been the carrera pressure fed chain tensioner update, and why it
was so important.  I learned the likely rust spots on older 911s, how
to check for the original paint and crashes, and read about a million
articles on how improve performance.  Each step in my Porschezation
was more astonishing than the previous.

We landed in LA, and went to get our bags.  To our surprise, they
actually check your baggage claim ticket before you are allowed to
leave the baggage pickup area with luggage.  This singular experience
caused a surge of anxiety until I found my claim ticket, which for
some reason I hadn't thrown out as I usually do.  However, I was
still resisting the truth, and chose to attribute even this startling
stroke of luck to chance.

The next shocker was waiting for us at the luggage pickup area.  Every
single piece of luggage we had checked in at LaGuardia had NOT ended
up in Cleveland.  Through some miracle, not only had they reached LA,
but they were undamaged AND they came out rather quickly.  Even John
and Karl were starting to wonder how we could be so lucky.  Karl's
bag was the last of our bunch to show up, and I spotted it and elbowed
my way into position to grab it as it was conveyed by.  I reached out
my hand, grasped the handle, and was immediately pulled onto the
conveyor belt, past the rubber curtain thingy, and into the mystical
other dimension that no one ever sees.

For some reason, Karl's bag had gotten stuck to the conveyor belt,
which I hadn't accounted for when I grabbed the handle.  The
unexpected jolt had me temporarily dazed; I slowly recovered and tried
to gauge my surroundings.  The conveyor belt was traveling in a dense
fog, through which I could barely make out huge piles, of unknown
composition, up ahead.  As I approached I was able to discern the
contents of each pile, and I was taken aback.  One pile contained only
unmatched socks, another pile was of hammers and screwdrivers, another
contained pencils and pens, then a pile of keys, followed by wallets,
tire valve stem caps, hockey pucks, every superball ever made, and old
game show hosts.  The fog began to thin ever so slightly, and I could
see other piles, and thousands of other luggage conveyor belts, all
moving as if they would converge ahead.  I strained my eyes to see
through the fog, and slowly it became clear that I was approaching a
city of some sort, where all the baggage conveyor belts were indeed
converging.  I saw, to my horror, that all the thousands of belts were
merging into one belt that was of the same width.  The point of
convergence was a deafening chaos of baggage, colliding and bouncing
in all directions.  Very few pieces of luggage were actually staying
on the new conveyor belt, most were ricocheting off into the
surrounding city (which I recognized almost immediately as Cleveland,
thanks to the sign reading "Welcome to Cleveland - City of Lost
Luggage").  The speed of my conveyor belt was increasing
dramatically as it neared the city, and before I knew it I was
hurtling towards the baggage vortex.  Not having any time to react, I
just held on tight to Karl's suitcase and closed my eyes as we
plunged into the swirling maelstrom of luggage.  I'm not sure what
happened next, but when I opened my eyes, I was just coming back
through the dimensional barrier into the LAX baggage claim area.  John
and Karl were standing there, smiling.

"I forgot to tell you," Karl said, in addition to his German
accent, he tended to draw trailing vowels out for hours.  "I brought
all my tools with me." With this he heaved his suitcase off the
conveyor belt, plopping it on the floor beside him.  Still in a daze
from my visit to the land of the lost, I summonned the will to move
and rolled off the belt myself.

"I thought it was stuck," I mumbled.

"Not stuck, just heavy," he replied.  "How was it back there?"

"I'm just happy to be alive," I said, pocketing the housekeys I
had lost in sixth grade (at least my trip hadn't been a total loss).

With a deep breath, we proceeded out of the building, John and I
carrying, and Karl dragging, our respective luggage.  We were greeted
with a blast of blistering LA smog, and all collapsed onto the
pavement, gasping for air.

"Welcome to LA, mang!" someone said, with a chuckle.

We slowly regained our composure and climbed to our feet.  The sun
blared at through the greyish air, and I squinted up at the sky.  Not
a cloud to be seen.  There was a bright flash as a plane dipped its
wing and reflected the sunlight.  Had I taken the time to think about
it, I would have realized that the plane could not possibly have
reflected the sun, the angles were all wrong.

The search was about to begin.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 95 09:51:29 -0800
From: keith_watson@MENTORG.COM (Keith Watson)
Subject: Re: 911 SC Rear speaker size WITH AMP ?

>        Funny you should said this, I actually brought the car with *3*
amps in
>the car, the previous owner had a BIG system with a whole subwoffer box
over the
>back seat, the head unit and subwoffers were stolen but the amps and box was
>still in the car when I brought it...I removed the 2 amps under the front
seats
>but lefted the Alpine amp in the trunk, I also removed the subwoffer box (I
>hated the way it looks)...I thought about hooking up the amp, do you really
>think it'll make alot of difference with my system ?? (100 watt amps into 4
>channels, 5.25 speakers in front, 6x4 speakers in back (not yet installed),
>*Tagra top* so LOT's of interior noise....).
>
>        Thanks again.
>
>G.E.

I used to have a simple system in my Targa - Alpine tape deck, Nakamichi
amp run as 90w x 2, and Nakamichi separates (3 inch tweeters, 5.25 inch
mids) in the doors.  The system never had lower end bass but it still
sounded nice.  There was no problem hearing it with the top off up to
80mph.  Over 80mph the noise of having the top off drastically increases.
The only other thing I would have added to that system was another amp
and a subwoofer.

Keith Watson
'81 911 SC Targa

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 95 09:52:27 -0800

>How many of those fly airplanes with engines, how many fly those
>where the designer forgot the engine

I fly one with an engine, a Mooney 201, which is the a/c that came with a 
Porsche engine as an option a few years ago. Unfortunately because they 
still cost major $$$$, mine isn't this version. The PFM (Porsche engined 
version) is not as fast as some of the others but is renowned for its 
smoothness. Too bad the program didn't continue because today's piston a/c 
engines still use decades old designs.

Date: 01 Feb 95 12:50:42 EST
From: Ray Khorram <70524.3012@compuserve.com>
Subject: Questions about '82 euro 930

Hi,
I am the proud new owner of a european '82 930. It has adjustable turbo
boost, and boy is it fast. Yes, I have read Bruce Anderson's excellent
book, and I have seen the picture of the melted piston and cylinder. So
I am trying to restrain myself and only go to 1.5 bar for a few memorable
seconds per month. Based on Bruce's advice I called up Callaway to get
details on the "Microfueler" fuel enrichment device for overboosted
turbos, but it is no longer available. Callaway now specializes in
domestic non-turbo V8s. So I guess that if I intend to run at higher boost
settings for more than a few seconds I should get an oversized 
intercooler, but first I need to take care of other items.

I have lots of questions. Sorry if these are stupid ones but after 
spending over $ 300 on books and manuals I still don't have any place I 
can look up the answers. There is no Porsche dealer in southern New 
Hampshire, and this is a euro model so dealers aren't paricularly
helpful anyway. Besides, dealers want to fix problems, not to tell me how
I can fix it myself.

1) Does anyone know where to get the service manual for the euro turbos ?
I bought the (expensive!) manual from Performance Products but it only has
the US versions, and skips the model years where no turbo was officially 
imported in the US. I can read German ('cause I grew up there).
I know that the turbo manual is only supposed to cover those items that
are different from the regular 911, and that I would haver to buy the 
other two volumes to be complete, but because of the US / Euro difference
I want to locate the correct versions before I pay another $250 per volume. 

2) In my front trunk, there is a cylindrical item with two hoses
 connected, labelled Purolator (nothing else is legible due to rust on
 this item). Since there are little black things falling out of holes,
 and since it smells a little bit like fuel, two mechanics I have shown
 this to think that it is a charcoal canister for the fuel tank breather,
 but everyone believes this is a nonstandard item perhaps added by the
 importers of the car. Question: Should a '82 930 have a charcoal canister
 installed by the factory ? Where would it be installed and what does it
 look like ? As I was checking out my car, I have seen many items I can't
 figure out. In the left front wheel well, there seems to be a plastic
 tank like object above what appears to be the windshield washer fluid 
 container. Could that possibly be the original fuel tank breather box ?

3) I found that my windshield washer pump was disconnected and appeared 
 dead, so I opened it up, removed some sand that was stuck between the 
 gears, and the pump spins now. I connected the hoses, but it didn't 
 pump the fluid. I figured out that it needs a T-style check valve, 
 and ordered it from Automotion, but I am confused by the fact that 
 there are three hoses to hook up to the pump. One goes up to the 
 windshield nozzles, and two apparently come from the tank. I
 tried every logical way of using the T connector but the pump still 
 only pulls water out of the tank only for as long as the tank is 
 completely full (i.e. water level is up to the filler) So why are 
 there two hoses from the tank ? Is one for priming the pump and the
 other for pulling water out of the bottom ? How exactly should they
 be connected to the T valve and the pump ?

4) My headlight washer pump doesn't work. After ordering the factory
 owner's manual, I found that it is only supposed to work when the
 headlight is on. OK, so I tried it. I hear a relay clicking, and the
 relay is located close to the windshield washer pump. But I can't find
 the actual headlight washer pump, or any location where any loose hoses
 and electrical cables would suggest that it should be installed there.
 So where should I be able to find the headlight washer pump ?

5) Everything I have read about the 930 suggests that I should have truly
 amazing brake performance. My brakes work, but they are not at all
 impressive. My '83 Toyota stops better. Three local mechanics have 
 taken a quick look at the pads and rotors and suggested that they 
 "pass inspection" and don't need replacement any time soon. Oh yeah,
 sometimes the brake failure light comes on (and stays on until the 
 battery is disconnected). I wonder if the brake booster could be at
 fault, and if there is an easy way for me to check it out ?

6) It is missing the rear anti-roll bar. I only intend to drive on 
regular streets, and mostly at legal speeds. (So what if I go from 
30mph to 60mph in 1.5 seconds... there is no acceleration limit!)
Should I bother to get an anti-roll bar ? If so, factory or Weltmeister ?
Handling currently is not good, but I don't know if there are other 
suspension problems, or if 930s are supposed to handle this way, or
if it is all related to the lack of the rear anti-roll bar. It would be
so great if I could find a buddy with a similar car within driving 
distance!

7) With great interest I read the recent item about optimal jacking
 points. In fact I had just bought one of those little hydraulic jacks
 with two jack stands ($35 at Walmart). Unfortunately, the description
 "front cross support beam" and "Engine with wood blocks" is still a 
 little vague for me. I am horrified at the thought of damaging the car
 by jacking it up wrong, so I would appreciate more details.

Thanks! Ray

'82 Porsche 930	(fun car)
'83 Celica GTS	(car for parking in Boston and towing boat)
'88 Celica Turbo(daily runner)
'92 Harley 883 (which I converted to 1200)

Porschephiles #1125                         Wed Feb 1 19:29:05 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 17:37:33 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: spinning



There is a great deal of similarity spinning P-cars and aircraft

As an unwritten rule, regardless of ability spin and you will crash

Sure practice spinning with plenty of space (H ov V) will help you 
recognise the onset of a spin, and hopefully allow you to back off, in 
each case releasing applied pressure to the pointing device will unload 
the surfaces and re-attach wheels to road or air to wing. So the advise 
is generally sound.

If you make a habit of driving beyond the limit of adhesion, eventually 
you will come to grief, think about what happens when you are doing a 
progressive power slide and you hit a nice patch of diesel whoops!!

As they say - very chuckable - not very catchable.

All the above of course does not apply if your name is Pete - if you've 
got it - thrash it!! 

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 17:55:41 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Roundabouts

On Tue, 31 Jan 1995, Larry Wilson wrote:

> 
> > If you really want to have fun try L'Etoile at rush (or any other) 
> > hour, where the priority a` droite gets you on fast but then .........
> 
> In 1961, with my wife and two kids, we picked up our new 356B Coupe at
> Sonauto dealership in Paris. None of us had ever been in a Porsche before
> (except to see if the kids fit in the back), much less driven one. We made
> two wrong turns and immediately found ourselves in L'Etoile at lunch hour.

Some years ago - lost in Paris - ended up driving round the Arc de 
Triuphe, must have looked bemused.

Next lights frenchman draws alongside, and explained the insurance 
position of driving around the arc-

he explains in perfect english - if you have a bump at the arc, french 
insurance will not pay out - they reason that you don't have to drive 
round the arc - if you want to avoid crunches, go some other route.

I thought that was marvelous gallic logic - perhaps if US courts applied 
the same logic to product liability, some of the stupid court decisions 
may have been avoided I am thinking particularly about woman who have 
breast implants that go wrong, people who roll jeeps etc.

Whats the verdict?
	 is some product liability a pudding pullers charter.

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 95 11:32:04 -0700
From: Jan Bjernfalk <bjernfal@olin.dsd.ES.COM>
Subject: Re: 911 or MR2 

>From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
>
>A friend of mine wants a 911, but can't afford one.  He has heard a lot of good
> things about the '91 and later Toyota MR2 Turbos.  Does anyone have experience
> with these cars?  How do they compare to Porsche handling?  He said that there
> was a suspension problem with the MR2 that would cause the tail to swing out
> do a nose plow (sounds 911-ish!) during  hard driving.  But, that otherwise,
>the car is a mid engine pocket rocket (and a great deal $).  Any responses are
>welcome!  Sean  '80 928


Well, I can't comment directly on the 911 vs. the MR2, but I did own a '91
MR2 Turbo before "moving up" to my 944 Turbo.

MR2 Pros:  It's fast (but don't even consider the non-turbo).  Front end
feels nimble and responsive, thanks to mid-engine layout.  Great view out the
front, as hood drops off sharply.  Feels like driving a toy Ferrari.
It's very much a true "sports car", and quite fun to drive.

MR2 Cons:  Engine is loud, and the noises are not especially endearing.
Handling is very unbalanced;  lift-throttle oversteer is a real problem.
(I suppose the 911 has much the same behavior -- this either is good or bad,
depending on your point of view)  Handling is improved on '93 and later models.
It was surprisingly maintenance intensive (for a Toyota) -- don't expect it
to be like a put-gas-in-it-and-go-100K-miles Corolla.  The build quality
was not up to what I expect from Toyota;  little things would break, and the
interior seemed cheesy.  The car is very small, both in seating area and
storage, which became more annoying to me as time went by.
Finally (and I can't explain this well), the car lacks "character".  It seemed
anonymous and neutral -- no personality!.  Of course my Porsche has tons 
of character, my Toyota LandCruiser has character, even my Taurus SHO had 
some character.

In retrospect, I found that with the MR2, I initially loved it, and then, over
a year, got more and more annoyed with the thing -- finally I was happy to
let it go.  Whereas with the 944, I was at first unsure about the thing, but
as I drove it and got used to it, I got to appreciate it more and more. Now,
I won't give it up for anything.

In comparison, I think the 944 Turbo is clearly in a class above the MR2, in
performance, quality, and driver appeal.  I'm sure the same is true of the 911.
I've noticed that there are always *many* MR2's for sale in the local paper, 
whereas I know that there were not very many built.  That tells me people 
don't hang on to them very long, and neither did I.

A '91-'92 MR2 Turbo probably costs about $10-12K.  For the same money, your
friend could get a nice '86-'87 944 Turbo, or even an '80-'82 911sc for not
much more (??).  BTW, my '89 944 w/ 50Kmi feels alot newer, tighter, and less 
worn than my '91 MR2 did w/ 50Kmi.

I predict that if your friend goes for the MR2, he'll be back knocking on our
door before long.  Just my (admittedly biased) opinion.

Jan Bjernfalk
'89 951 White
'92 BMW 525i  (for the wife)
'89 LandCruiser  (for the dog)

------------------------------

My $0.02 for the flying thread...
I am the proud owner of a currently disabled euro 356SC (Stan, Maestro and

owner of a lovely '68 Glasfugel Libelle H301B sailplane.  The 356's plate
is "GO SOAR"
and she gets driven to the gliderport most every week during the soaring
season.  Another glider pilot, Carol Hines (LL) has a 356 coupe as well
(and a gorgeous ASW24 that she can fly the wings off!)
Anyone have any experience with the porsche flugmotor in the  Mooney PFM?

why but that's what the book said.

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  1 Feb 95 12:00:53 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Hot 951 wheel/brake

One other thing to check is the parking brake cable. If it clogs up 
with dirt/rust,
it could cause the parking brake shoes to stay extended against
their drums (which are, btw, in the hubs of the rear disk rotors).

Although if the rotor is turning blue, then it is probably a frozen
piston holding a pad againt the rotor, as others have mentioned.

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  1 Feb 95 13:31:38 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; missing sway bar on 930

From: Ray Khorram <70524.3012@compuserve.com>
Subject: Questions about '82 euro 930

Hi,
I am the proud new owner of a european '82 930.....
  (snip)

>6) It is missing the rear anti-roll bar. I only intend to drive on
>regular streets, and mostly at legal speeds. (So what if I go from
>30mph to 60mph in 1.5 seconds... there is no acceleration limit!)
>Should I bother to get an anti-roll bar ? If so, factory or Weltmeister ?
>Handling currently is not good, but I don't know if there are other
>suspension problems, or if 930s are supposed to handle this way, or
>if it is all related to the lack of the rear anti-roll bar. It would be
>so great if I could find a buddy with a similar car within driving
>distance!
  (snip)

    The rear sway bar will tighten up the rear end and in my experience
  will increase the dreaded "trailing throttle oversteer" which tends to swap
  911 ends...Without the bar at all your car will tend to understeer more, but
  may make it more like a "regular car" in terms of handling.
    If you aren't going to track the car I'd certainly avoid anything stiff 
  (a big bar or poly bushings) if possible and stick to stock. You don't 
  mention what you don't like about the handling (and I am certainly not a 
  talented driver who knows that much about setting up cars) but make sure
  that everything is working the way it -should- (shocks, bearings, ball
  joints). In stock form your 930 should be thoroughly awesome, unless you
  have a lot of 911 time on the track and are really good.  A friend (a
  talented 944 pilot) lost his stiffly sprung 911 after lifting the throttle
  during a lane change (spun his car backwards over the curb, into a tree, 
  caught on fire and burned his flared, 3 liter, Recaroed car to cinders)...
  Stiff isn't always better....

    For fun I used lift on sharp corners just to swing the rear around,
  I did this so much on old bushings that it broke the end of the up link
  loose from the trailing arm; after which the car just wouldn't
  swing around any more.

       -Lee A.  ex 911520119 Silver Anniversary edition coupe
               





------------------------------

Date: Wed,  1 Feb 95 13:34:54 CST
From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: RE: 944 faq...

Dennis:

With regards to doing a 9X4/968 FAQ,

YEA, GO FOR IT!!!

Why should the air heads be the only ones with a FAQ.  The 944 is the best 
car Porsche ever made!  In my opinion, it's the best car around.  I'd be 
happy to help.  I'm not a 944 super tech but I do some of my own 
maintenance and I *ENJOY* studying the car.

One area I'd like to see addressed are the later models, specifically the 
88/89 951 S.  Again, one of the best cars ever made but so few people know 
about them.  They're rare but *FUN* to drive and almost bullet proof.

I'd be happy to contribute my 951 S experiences to the FAQ.  I've also 
owned a '86 944 and an '88 944 S.  There are plenty of people here who own 
one or more 924/944/968/derivatives.  

So, GO FOR IT!!!!

Bert
'88 951S, Black

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 95 16:26 EST
From: tnelson@telesciences.com (Tracy M Nelson)
Subject: Re: Porsche bike?

Seems to me it was Jim Harriger <jimharr@microsoft.com> who said:
	someone recently speculated here about a possible Porsche motorcycle.
	
	in the Cycle World that came in the mailbox yesterday, there is a full page
	speculation, with two artists renderings, about what the bike might be, and
	when it might be available. the high points:
	
	-single-sided front suspension, with shock located behind the steering axis

What, no center-hub steering?  C'mon, Yamaha can't have *all* the fun...

	-140hp, 4-cyl, with variable valve timing (variomatic?), FI w/DME

This is a more powerful motor than I have in my pickup.  More power than the
original 944!  Hmmm, a two-wheel 944, hmmmm....  BTW, anybody know how much HP
the Yamaha V-Max puts out?

	-shaft drive, w/seperate control arm to minimize shaft effect.
	-6-speed with electronic control, shifting by std. lever, or rocker sw. 
	on handlebar
						(tiptronic on a bike?)

Are both shifter styles going to be provided, or will you have to choose one?
I know on my old bike (Kawasaki 750 two-stroke) the *last* thing I wanted to
do was shift my grip (so to speak) during hard acceleration!  Of course, I
haven't seen where they propose to put the switch, maybe they've figured out a
good placement for it.
	-available '96 or '97
	
	-no price speculated on, but they did note that Porsche technical excellence is
		not cheap!

Guess that's not a problem for anyone on *this* list! :)

- -- Tracy Nelson (t.nelson@telesciences.com)
'87 944S


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 13:37:08 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: re; missing sway bar on 930

>  have a lot of 911 time on the track and are really good.  A friend (a
>  talented 944 pilot) lost his stiffly sprung 911 after lifting the throttle
>  during a lane change (spun his car backwards over the curb, into a tree,
>  caught on fire and burned his flared, 3 liter, Recaroed car to cinders)...
>  Stiff isn't always better....

Lee, et al:

I find it very hard to believe that anyone could spin a 911 by lifting
the throttle during a lane change. Please describe to us what kind of
lane change this person was making. There has to be some other reason
he lost control of the car. This sounds like someone trying to blame the
car for his own stupid mistake.

This "lift throttle oversteer" stuff is getting way blown out of preportion
here. I am not saying that the characteristic does not exists, because it
does. But a 911, even a "stiffly sprung 911", does not magically spin out
of control without some help from the driver. And certainly not when making
a lane change. If you understand what the 911 does and why it does it, you
are half way there. The other half is learning how to control your 911 at
edge. Go autocrossing! This will teach you more about your 911's handling
than anything else.

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Scott said:

>the throttle during a lane change. Please describe to us what kind of

I've seen a couple *almost* happen when people are trying to do 90mph
"lane surfing" through 70mph traffic. Eventually, stuff happens and a
lane slows down unexpectedly - another Mallox moment!.  Of course none
of us porschephiles would do anything like that.


Funny how even I get some perverse satisfaction when it's a Porsche or 
other supercar that screws up. I guess it's like when I got my bright 
yellow 911 and a friend of mine said "you'll have to be really careful 
now because this thing puts you pretty high on the yahoo index"

------------------------------

Date: Wed,  1 Feb 95 16:46:12 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re: spinning 911s/rear sway bars

>>   A friend (a talented 944 pilot) lost his stiffly sprung 911 after
>>  lifting the throttle during a lane change (spun his car backwards over
>>  the curb, into a tree, caught on fire and burned his flared, 3 liter,
>>  Recaroed car to cinders)... Stiff isn't always better....

>Lee, et al:

>I find it very hard to believe that anyone could spin a 911 by lifting
>the throttle during a lane change. Please describe to us what kind of
>lane change this person was making. There has to be some other reason
>he lost control of the car. This sounds like someone trying to blame the
>car for his own stupid mistake.

>Scott Winders

    In fact, said friend was coming BACK from an autocross when the accident
 occurred ! The lane change was an aggressive one between 2 cars; as he
 started the change, he got nervous about his (closing) distance to the car
 in front of him and let off the gas as he twitched the wheel.....he never
 had a chance to recover.
    His car was a '72 with flares, 7/8" wheels, and adjustable Weltmeister
 bars front and rear. He was new to the 911 (lost it something like 2
 months after he got it) but was a moderately experienced and talented
 944 autocrosser, around cars and racing all his life.
  
  I'd agree, the 911 is at least a consistent car and won't just spin out
 of nowhere. But they aren't forgiving to heavy-handling and stiffening
 them up exacerbates the situation. I'd bet most people would be just
 as happy without a rear sway bar at all.
 
  If you remember the video game shaped like a motorcycle, that you sit
 on and push the thing back and forth to steer ? I could never beat a
 friend who'd never driven a bike; he didn't KNOW he couldn't just throw
 the thing over, or be careful coming back off the "grass", or let off the
 gas in a corner...and unlike real life, the game didn't care either !
 My driving expertise is limited to knowing you can't upset the dynamics
 of a machine without expecting a result; in my Friends case, too much
 throttle change AND too much steering did him in. In his 944, it certainly
 wouldn't have happened (as he put it, a move he'd made "thousands of times").
 In my experience, a 911 can wag its tail all day long where a 928 just 
 never will.  And a stiffer rear bar means more oversteer. 

   And no, said Friend didn't blame the car for his driving ! And the
 people in the car he crashed and burned in front of (not to mention his
 wife, who nixed another purchase of a road-going Porsche) probably wasted 
 no word to impress on him their impression of his driving...!

            -Lee A.

Subject: Re: quick "airhead" survey

Martin Walker sez:

|> Since it's come up a few times recently:

|> How many current pfiles are also *CURRENT* pilots ?  Aircraft owners ?

	Well, I guess it depends on the definition of "current".  I
am a licensed glider pilot (PP-G, and no, I don't fly no stinking
hang gliders, I fly sailplanes), but haven't flown since the
Labor Day weekend of last year.  I own a small piece of a '78
Grob Twin Astir, which is a high-performance, retractable, dual
seat sailplane of composite construction.

|> How many of those fly airplanes with engines, how many fly those
|> where the designer forgot the engine (ouch:-) ?

	The only thing I begrudge airplane drivers is the ability to
taxi under power.  My Grob is kind of heavy to push around.  Where
I fly (Black Forest), flights of over 500 KM in the Rocky Mountains
is not particularly uncommon.  My personal best is around 80 miles
of free distance.

|> How many of those flying engined airplanes have aircooled porsches ?

|> (I'm assuming no-one here flys a water cooled airplane).

|> Any body here build their own plane (no, somebody building it for you
|> doesn't count !) ?

	I've thought about building my own sailplane from a kit, but have
decided I'm *much* too smart to fly anything that I've built :-)

Dave ('84 Carrera Targa, platinum metallic)

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 1995 18:40:11 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: More stereo advice

Colin here is some more advice regarding your sub:

I will not say that the following advice offered by Tracy is necessarily 
"bad", but I might recommend taking some of it with a grain of salt.  
Opinions are given on the tubes, but let it be known that they *can* be 
mounted in the hatch if you so desire.  As Tracy comments, it is difficult 
to know what your idea of "good bass" is.  *My* general definition of "good 
bass" is bass that is "accurate".  That is, bass that is reproduced with all 
the same tonal qualities contained in the original recording with no 
disproportionate exaggeration or major distortions.  I would *strongly* 
discourage heeding the advice offered regarding a 10" free-air sub for use 
in your particular car.  Free-air subs are constructed differently than 
other conventional drivers intended for use in enclosures, and they have 
rather specific intended applications.  You should note that the description 
"free-air" does not imply that these drivers can simply be mounted anywhere, 
without a box.  It is true that they do not require a purpose built box such 
as other drivers do, but they must be very carefully mounted.  Free-air subs 
are specially manufactured to have expecially rigid suspensions to 
compensate for their lack of a conventional enclosure or box.  In general, 
free-air woofers are intended to be mounted in vehicles having a trunk on 
either the rear deck or on a baffle behind the rear seat.  In such an 
application, the specially made free-air drivers essentially use the entire 
trunk as their enclosure.  It is imperative when using a free-air sub that 
the front and back wave energy eminating from the speaker are completely 
isolated from one another.  That is, the front of the speaker should fire 
into the passenger compartment, and the back of the speaker should fire into 
the trunk, and the air between the two should not mix in any way.  As you 
can see, this is easily accompolished in a car with a trunk, and it allows 
for quick easy bass without the hassle of a box.  It clearly does not lend 
itself to use in a hatch car.  Free-air subs are designed to play into very 
large enclosures.....the size of a whole trunk!  If you were to mount a 
free-air sub in one of the back corner pockets, as Tracy suggests, you would 
obviously be violating this idea.  A free-air sub in such an improper 
application would almost definitely provide very exaggerated, "boomy" 
sounding bass rather than accurate bass.  As before, my advice is to buy or 
construct a suitable hatch sub-box, but listen to find what *you* prefer first.

In reference to the Boston Acoustics, they *are* (IMHO) very good sounding 
separates, but please keep in mind that these are only *OPINIONS*.  Sound is 
a very subjective thing, and what sounds good to person A, may not sound the 
same to person B.  I continue to stress the importance of making one's own 
decisions regarding sound unless you truly rely upon other's 
recommendations.  This advice applies to Tracy as well in choosing separates 
for your car.  Just for comparison's sake you might try auditioning a set of 
Canton's and A/D/S separates against the Boston's.  The important thing is 
to bring your own music that you are familiar with, and to carefully compare 
the two different sounds (side by side if possible).

Happy Listening!  

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 20:02:07 -0700
From: sas@indirect.com (Steve Sapareto)
Subject: Re: Roundabouts

        I, too, have had extensive experience in Paris when I was involved 
in a GUR (geographically undesirable relationship) and made 6 trips in 1.5 
years.  My first observation was that it seemed that every car I saw in the 
city was dented (even the several Porsches - which made me cry).  This is 
clearly unlike Tokyo were cars are taken directly from fender-benders to the 
autobody shop since no-one would dare drive a dented car and lose "face".
        On my 4th or 5th trip to Paris I learned why so many dents when I 
rented a car in Germany (unfortunately not a Porsche!) and drove to Paris.  
It seems that the Parisians are so arrogant that they refuse to accept the 
concept of "yield".  Furthermore, they will not acknowledge the idea of 
"lanes" either.  Now realize that I grew up and learned to drive in Boston 
and know the circles described previously quite well.  However, until Paris, 
I thought Boston drivers were some of the toughest and most agressive 
(except they don't usually drive on the sidewalkslike Parisians).  In my 
little Opel in Paris, I learned that when six cars converge on an the exit 
from a roundabout or entrance to an expressway, no one gives way until they 
*hit*, hence all the dents.
        Anyway I agree that simple small roundabouts are efficient (you 
enter and drive around until you get to your exit and you leave - not 
crossing the path of anyone else) but larger multiple lane roundabouts are a 
nightmare except in light traffic since you must work toward the inner lane 
once you get on and must work your way back out through merging traffic to 
get off.  Yes, the Brits have lots of them but then they drive on the wrong 
side of the road anyway <g>.

Steve Sapareto <sas@samaritan.edu>
85' 944 (Arizona white)

Date: Wed, 1 Feb 1995 19:11:37 -0800
From: "William Dunham" <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: spinning 911s/rear sway bars

On Feb 1,  4:46pm, Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com wrote:

>
>   I'd agree, the 911 is at least a consistent car and won't just spin out
>  of nowhere. But they aren't forgiving to heavy-handling and stiffening
>  them up exacerbates the situation. I'd bet most people would be just
>  as happy without a rear sway bar at all.

>From What I can recall, stiffening up the rear end *REDUCES* the tendency to
oversteer.  Stiffening the rear end reduces the tendency of the car to roll.
Roloing transfers weight from the inside rear tire to the outside.  As the car
becomes unbalanced in the rear it's ability to stick is diminished causing
it to break free earlier (one of the rear tires starts to loose traction)
In the absence of braking, it really depends upon the ratio of the stiffness
between the front and rear whether a car will oversteer (be loose) or
understeer (push), but in general which ever is "looser" will break
free first.

There's a great book called "Race Car Engineering and Mechanics" that explains
suspension set up and it's effect on a car's handling.  I'll post the author
and publisher when I get home and have access to the book.

Bill
'72 911T

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 1995 22:52:06 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Amps hookup

Wayne,

I'm not familiar with your exact model head, but generally speaking it won't 
make a very significant difference in overall sound quality by upgrading 
your head.  The only significant gains that might stem from such an upgrade 
are in making the switch to CD from cassette if your head isn't already a CD 
player.  You may find more conveniences or features (and possibly a better 
tuner) with a new head, but most likely you will see little change in sound 
quality otherwise.

Regarding the connection question, check out an earlier post I made to 
Volney Spalding.  You should use either the DIN to DIN line or the RCA 
(these are also called phono jacks) pre-amp outputs.  Both should be 
low-level lines, and both should give simmilar results.  If you want to be 
sure they sound the same, switch between the two and listen for any 
differences, but it is highly unlikely that you will hear any change.  I am 
not sure what you mean by speaker RCA input because there is no such thing 
in my experience.  The RCA pre-amp inputs on your amp are low-level and 
should *only* be connected to RCA outputs from your head.  If you mean that 
your amp also accepts speaker-level inputs, then these are high-level inputs 
designed to take the line directly from the speaker lines from your head, 
but they should not be RCA style phone jack connectors as with the pre-amp 
input.


Glad to help.

Andy 
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 1995 22:02:47 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: A question....This would be an answer!

Ok, Vol, here goes.....

I assume you know what amps and subs are.  Your head unit(cassette orCD) 
sends a low level signal (called a pre-amp signal) to your amp.  The amp 
then amplifies (duh) that signal and sends it out to the speakers or subs 
which are connected to it. Pretty simple so far.  What happens, however, is 
that you must use different speakers to reproduce different portions of the 
audible spectrum.  That is,  tweeters for the treble, midranges for 
everything in the middle, and subs for the bass.  The important part is that 
you must direct the proper frequencies to the proper speakers. You must not 
send the bass to the tweeters because it will fry them, and likewise if you 
send the treble to the subs it will dirty the sound of the bass.  Thus, this 
frequency chopping and directing is accompolished via a "crossover".  A 
crossover can also be thought of as a filter, and there are three basic 
types of crossovers.  1)low-pass filter  2)band-pass filter  and 3)high-pass 
filter.  As the name implies, a low-pass filter only allows the lows (bass) 
to pass through to the sub, a band-pass only allows a certain "band" of 
frequencies (no highs & no lows) to pass to the midrange, and so on.  I 
could write for a day on the technical aspects of various  crossover 
designs, but that is not practical.  Put simply, each x-over has a different 
"level" called a "SLOPE".  The slope refers to how quickly a x-over 
attenuates the frequencies that it filters off (how steep that chop is).  
Most common slopes are 
6 decibels per octave, 12 dB/octave, 18 dB/octave, and 24 dB/octave.  The 
steeper the slope, the less of the unwanted sounds seep through the filter.  
Now to complicate matters further, there are two basic varieties of 
crossovers.  One is the common passive x-over, and the other is the more 
expensive active (or electronic) x-over.  Basically, passives are simple 
elictrical devices ( either capacitors or inductor coils, and resistors) 
that are hooked up on the positive speaker lead between the amp and each 
speaker.  They are called passive because they require no power source, they 
just use a tiny bit of power directly from the speaker line.  Active 
x-overs, on the other hand, are more complex electrical units usually 
utilizing various IC chips.  The most important difference, however, is that 
you must use a separate amplifier for each of the different x-over "bands".  
This is because an active x-over is placed on the low level signal lines 
between the head-unit and the amps.  Basically, the signal comes from the 
head and is immediately dissected by the crossover.  Then, the appropriate 
sounds are sent to each amp ( for example, the bass frequencies travel to 
the amp powering the subs, and so on).  Active x-overs require their own 
power source (i.e. they must be connected to the car's battery), and they 
are more efficient than passives.  One of the many advantages of the active 
is that it is quickly adjustable (often with knobs) to change the desired 
crossover frequency (passives must be replaced with different component 
values to change the x-over frequency).  Actives are considerably more 
expensive themselves, plus, they require those extra amps.  Each type of 
crossover type has its advantages and disadvantages, but they all do 
essentially the same thing, and any good system should not be without them.


Does this explanation help?

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Crossover)

>Thanks for the well written and informative data!

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 1995 22:03:07 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Another Question...This would be another answer!

Hello Vol!

Basically there are two types of outputs on most modern head-units.  The 
first type is the low-level (also called line-level or pre-amp level) signal 
output, and it usually exits the head via seperate left and right 
phono-connectors (also called RCA connecters).  The second is seperate left 
and right speaker-level outputs ( these are the one's carrying the 25 watts 
of power).  Now, your head unit has what is called a "pre-amp"  this is the 
tiny amplifier that directly amplifies the signal from the electronic laser 
reader in your CD player.  This low-level signal then exits the head through 
the RCA's and travels to your external Alpine amp where the heavy duty 
amp'ing is done.  If the RCA's are not used, and you power your speakers 
directly from the head's 25 watts, then something different occurrs.  That 
pre-amp level signal (from the laser reader) goes to a small 25 watt 
amplifier inside the head unit, and is then sent directly to the speakers 
via the speaker wires protruding from the back of the head.  Essentially, 
this small internal amp would take the place of an external 
amplifier.....unless you opt for the extra power of an outboard amp.  Now, 
many amps have inputs of the same type as the outputs on your head.  Many 
amps have both RCA pre-amp level inputs as well as higher level speaker 
inputs (these high-level inputs are included on some amps to accomodate 
those heads that don't have RCA outputs).  There are a number of ways that 
you can confugure this set up. 

1) you can use only the 25 watts supplied by the head (bad idea if you have 
an amp).

2) you can feed the RCA's to your Alpine and use it alone to power your 
speakers, and leave the speaker lines from your head unused.

3) you can use the Alpine to power fronts, and head unit to power the rears 
(this will probably destroy any front/rear fader capabilities that you have).

To answer your question.  No.  There is no synergy gained by the 25 watts 
going from the head to the amp.  If you are not already using the pre-amp 
RCA outputs from your head to feed the signal to your Alpine, *then you 
should be* (the RCA outs will provide a cleaner signal to the amp).  If you 
are using the speaker wire outputs from your head to feed the amp, then you 
should switch to the RCA's.  If it is indeed the 25 watt lines feeding your 
amp, then this power is merely wasted into heat by voltage-reducing 
resistors within your Alpine before the Alpine ever does its amp'ing duties. 
 Use the RCA outputs and inputs (provided you have them) because if you use 
the high-level lines then you are effectively taking any imperfictions in 
the head's amp and re-amplifying them with the Alpine.

About those Pioneer's, you are probably right about the sun.  Most old 
speakers are made of paper (rather than today's modern plastics) which will 
easily dry-rot and deteriorate in the torture of the sun/temperature even 
though they will continue to operate.  If they still work, fine, but you may 
want to compare the sound with them disconnected.  They may actually be 
negatively contributing to the surely better sounds eminating from the BA's. 
 It is not "mandatory" that you have rear speakers. Just compare, and see 
what *you* like better.

Hope this helped.  Let me know if you have more concerns.

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 1995 17:35:42 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: Hey neighbor...

Sean Says:

>I didn't know that you were in N. Va!  I thought I was speaking to someone in
>California, or something.  I am in DC, but I keep the 928 at my parents "farm"
>in Upper Marlboro most of the time.  I am doing a stealth install, with the 10"
>JL's in a black carpeted box, w/o the cones showing in the rear window.  My Alp
>ine head unit is fully removable, and I do ALWAYS remove it.  I did want to kep
>the door speakers in the stock holes because of fear of having a big 'ol 5" mid
> bass MB Quart with the logo in red sicking out like a sore thumb in the bottom
> of the door.  What car stereo place do you work for?  Maybe I could stop by.
>I still have to buy the coax's for the front doors, a CD changer, and a 4X50 W
>amp.  Talk to you later!  Sean  '80 928


It's good that you pull your head all the time, too many people don't.  Why 
give theives what they want? I understand how you want to keep from having 
an aftermarket speaker sticking out of your doors.  If you can't fit them 
into the stock holes then you must either enlargen the stock holes (make 
sure that the depth of the speakers will fit also) or custom mount the new 
drivers elsewhere on the door.  There are ways to disguise a Quart logo 
grill from standing out.  Some people build custom grill panels and cover 
them with grill cloth to hide the speakers.  There are many possibilities in 
that department.  Unfortunately, I do not currently work for any 
installation shop.  Rather, I am a full time student at Virginia Tech.  I 
have, however, acquired Mobile Electronics Installer certification 
recognized by the EIA (Electronic Industries Association), and I have been 
an audiophile  for many years and involved in car stereo since before I 
could drive.  I have also successfully run my own mobile auto detailing 
business, which is where my earlier knowledge regarding auto refinishing 
stems from.  I have been to many shops in the NOVA area, some good, some 
terrible.  I have had good results in dealing with Myer Emco, and I am 
friends with several installers in the area.  Even though you can't exactly 
"stop by", I am willing to give any advice or opinions that you might want.  
Later.

Andy 
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 1995 17:36:11 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: More stereo advice

Colin Writes:

>Hi everyone-
>Andy Clements mentions that there are standard sizes of 8", 10", etc.  
>Are pre-packaged speakers like Bazooka tubes any good for small cars 
>like the 944?  I saw a 6.5" tube 
>advertised in Crutchfield.  Can something like this reproduce the low 
>frequencies adequately?  I don't want it too be to loud, but I'm not sure 
>what size I need for good base.
>
>Any tips on where to place the thing? Also, what is the best 4x6" plate 
>speaker for moderate power (30 or 40 watts)?  A lot of people talked 
>about Infinity speakers in the archived messages.  Andy?
>
>Thanks!
>Colin O'Keefe
>oreilly@crl.com
>
>'84 944 without a stereo....

Well Colin, there are some different options you may consider.  Obviously, 
the Bazooka's or simmilar tubes are an option.  In *my* opinion (and not 
necessarily everyone's opinion) I dislike the sound of most tubes, as well 
as their mounting schemes.  You can mount them in the hatch, but they must 
be secured somehow (straps, screws, etc) to prevent rolling around.    IMHO 
they often provide poor sound quality with high levels of distortion in 
comparison to a simmilar dedicated sub-box and amplifier.  They are, 
however, quite cost effective when you need bass in your car *right now*.  
As an alternative I would suggest a sub-box and amp combo suited to your 
car.  This box could be sized to fit in your shallow hatch space, and still 
leave *some* storage space.  A sub-box can be custom built by an installer, 
or as a medium-level DIY project, or you can purchase one of the many 
prefabricated sub-boxes.  The best advice is to go to a local stereo 
shop/electronics chain store and carefully listen to each sub with different 
kinds of *your* music and decide which sounds best to *YOU* while fitting 
your needs/budget.  Go see what's out there, but a good starting point for 
your car might be any set-up including a single or dual 8" or 10" sub.  As 
far as mounting goes, it doesn't matter where you put it in the car.  Bass 
frequencies are considered to be non-directional (directionality decreases 
as frequency decreases).  This means that you don't have to be facing a sub 
to hear all of its output.  You will hear it just the same in the hatch as 
if it were in your lap.  Higher frequencies, on the other hand, are 
increasingly directional which is why smaller drivers must be mounted close 
to and facing your ears for best performance.  About those 4x6's, I will not 
say which is the *BEST* brand to buy because that is far too controversial.  
Everyone has different listening tastes, and different music selections.  I 
will say, however, that I have personally had good results with Infinity 
drivers, and many people regard them very highly.  There are many other very 
good brands on the market also, so don't limit yourself to only considering 
one brand.  As before, the best thing to do is to do some careful listening 
for yourself, and decide what *you* like.  Most of the speakers in that size 
range have simmilar power handling ratings, so 30-40 watts    should be 
about right.

Good Luck!  Let me know of any other concerns.

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 01 Feb 1995 17:35:01 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: 928  Door Speaker Fitment ?

Hello Sean!

>Hi Andy, I just plunked down $1,000 for the first stage of my 928 stereo system
>.  I totally agree with what you said, it's hard to explain how more power will
> make your stereo sound better at LOWER levels as well as high levels.  Anyway,
> here's what I have so far- 2 10"8 OHM JL Audio subs in a dual ported custom
>box that fits in the package space behind the rear seats and has a 2X100 Watt
>PPI Sedona amp Xed over at 90HZ  built inside for air flow.  Alpine coax's in
>the rear panels(next to the rear seats).  And finally, I want to put some MB
>Quart coax's up front.  Have you ever opened up an early 928's door to get to
>the speaker cut outs?  I tried, so I could at least get an idea.  No luck.  I
>know how the later 928S had a 4" mid and 1" high in the door, but mine is the
>style before that.  Got any idea what I can fit in there?  Sean  '80 928


Sounds like you have a good start on the "first stage" of your system.  Is 
it a DIY system?  If not, what shop did the work?  Everything you have so 
far is right on target.  I am myself a big fan of JL Audio subwoofers.  
IMHO, JL's are very good drivers for the money, and I plan on upgrading to a 
pair sometime soon.  You said your box is a "dual ported" design.  This 
could be interpreted several ways, but I assume you mean it is composed of  
two divided chambers in one box, each ported.  You have also made a good 
choice among amps, IMHO.  PPI's are great performers!  I assume you have the 
model APA-200 (100 x 2) that is powering your pair of subs.  I don't know 
how you have you amp configured (wired up) but I will assume you have one 
channel powering each 10".  Did you know your amp is bridgeable?  If you 
aren't doing so already, you can reconfigure your set-up so that your Sedona 
will feed both of your 10's in parallel, effectively boosting your amp's 
output to 320 x 1 into 4 ohms!  Funny thing, I'm also a fan of Quart.  They 
should make for a pretty good front stage.  Unfortunately I have never 
opened up a 928's door panel, but many cars work in the same way.   It is 
generally not that difficult of a procedure on many Japanese and German 
cars.  Just look around for how it is fastened to the door if you don't have 
the appropriate repair manual.  There are usually screws attaching map 
pockets, arm rests, and window cranks (if you have any of these) that may be 
hidden by screw covers.  Once all screws/bolts are removed, there are clips 
around the perimeter of the panel which must *carefully* be removed in order 
to reuse them.  A tool called a panel popper is used to do this, but 
sometimes you can *gently* pop the clips one at a time with your hands or a 
flat head screwdriver.  Once all fasteners are detached the panel can be 
lifted straight up off of the window sill.  If you get the panel off, just 
use a ruler and measure all three dimensions of the stock speakers (L x W x 
D).  If they are not the same size you want to replace them with, an 
installer with the right tools can often custom mount a larger driver into 
the stock location with a little cutting.  Another option is to attach 
aftermarket or custom built "speaker pods" to the outer part of the door 
panel, although you will lose that totally stock look.

Hope this helps.  Good Luck!  Let me know how it goes.

Andy
(EIA certifiet Mobile Electronics Installer)

Porschephiles #1128                         Thu Feb 2 10:52:22 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 00:28:52 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: Returned mail: User unknown

On Feb 1,  4:46pm, Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com 
wrote:
>
>>   I'd agree, the 911 is at least a consistent car and won't just spin 
>>   out of nowhere. But they aren't forgiving to heavy-handling and
>>   stiffening them up exacerbates the situation. I'd bet most people 
>>   would be just as happy without a rear sway bar at all.

Forgive me if this has already been covered or is too far off the topic; 
I just joined this list.

Anyway...

Unless you have a limited-slip differential (or a locker), you shouldn't 
install a rear sway bar.

In a corner, the bar transfers weight from the inside wheel to the 
outside wheel.  If you're running an open differential, this is exactly 
what you DON'T want; rear sway bars, if used at all, should be the 
lightest you can find.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 00:48:14 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: autox

Tom Keller (keller@pipeline.com) wrote: 

>Can anybody recommend an autox school in the LA area?  

Tom:

I hope "LA" means Los Angeles, not Louisiana...

You're in luck.  The San Diego Region of the PCA is about to hold its 
annual autocross school.  Naturally, I don't have any copies of the 
newsletter here, but I remember that it's sometime this month.  You 
can, I'm sure, get all the details by calling the region's Info-Line 
(619 944-3869).

I've done the school in previous years; here's how it works:  Friday 
is a 2-3 hour "chalk talk".  Saturday is all-day instruction (with a 
break for lunch), with a half-dozen or so "stations" through which you 
rotate: skid-pad (speaking of rotating...), slalom, braking, a 
mini-autocross course, etc.  Sunday is a "real" autocross; it's the 
second or third one of the Winter season down here, and all the 
regulars'll be there, along with the students from the day before.  
You'll be paired with an instructor who'll ride as your passenger.

If you don't have one, a helmet will be provided.  Other than that, you 
don't need any special equipment, although your car will have to pass 
the usual tech inspection (wheel bearings, brake fluid reservoir, 
battery tie-down, tire wear, throttle-return springs, etc.).

The best part is that the whole thing -- including the entry fee for 
Sunday's autocross -- costs only $90.

Oh... You probably have to be a PCA member.  If you're not, you should 
be, and I'm sure they'll be happy to sign you up.

 -Andy

P.S.  Maybe I should have signed up for the class BEFORE I posted 
this... It's limited to 40 students.


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California
