Date: Thu, 02 Feb 95 07:55:00 PST
From: "Todd, John W., 485/ESC" <jwtodd@stemc.eig485.af.mil>
Subject: 911 or MR2


My wife has a '91 MR2 Turbo, and while my seat time with it has been 
somewhat limited, I can offer the following input.  Yes, the car is tail 
happy, particularly under trailing throttle, but not nearly as much so as my 
'78 930, and while the turbo lag is quite a bit less than the 930 (w/ K27), 
it is still definitely present.  It is small too, but if you're under 6'3", 
you should be ok.  And you can also put all four tires in the passenger 
compartment (they won't fit any place else) when you need to get your 
gumballs to the autocross or your snow tires mounted.  Reliability has been 
good for 90k miles with the exception of the front calipers, which seem to 
last only about 40k.  It is also a noisy car, with the motor directly behind 
your head (and it doesn't sound nearly as sweet as a 911 motor).  It creaks 
a bit too, but that may have something to do with those occasions when it 
has met with solid objects.  Fit and finish on her car seems to be pretty 
good as well, though a couple of minor pieces have come loose.  Controls are 
definitely more modern on the MR2 (though I think I prefer the 930's 
instruments) and the HVAC works much better.  On the styling front, that is 
obviously a personal thing, but the 911 is definitely more unique.  Anyway, 
I like them both, and no matter which one your friend goes with, he can play 
"hide the motor".

John Todd
'78 930

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 95 08:54:01 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: 944 Oil Scum consensus

Hello All;

Thanks to all the Porschephiles that responded to my question about yellowish 
scum in the oil filler cap of my 951.  The general consensus seems to be that 
this is somewhat normal in the colder winter months, especially if the car is 
not driven long enough to thoroughly heat the oil.  The scum is caused by water 
vapor trying to escape the oil reservior.  As long as the scum does not appear 
on the dipstick things are probably OK.

If the scum starts to form on the dispstick (i.e. in the oil reservior), this 
may be the sign of bad things ($$$).  Possibilities are leaking head gasket or 
failure of the oil cooler seals.  There is a Porsche technical bulletin on the 
leaking oil cooler seals which covers replacing the seals AND the lower rod 
bearings.  If one suspects these types of failures there are other places to 
check.  Look for oil in the coolant bottle in the form of a brownish film or the 
smell of coolant in the exhaust.  If you are still unsure, just ask the list.  
This list may be the single largest collection of Porsche knowledge outside of 
Germany.  Thanks again.

Tracy Meyer

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 10:02:03 -0500 (EST)
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: 944 --- 1983 vs 1986 motronic

I once was discussing the 85/1 (ie old) versus 85/2 (ie new) systems of 
the 944 with Larry Bershstein, who was then with Autothority.

He said, uncategorically, that the 2 systems are quite incompatible. So 
I'm not surprised that the person who tried to swap units can't run properly.

Larry is a sometimes pfiles member. Maybe he'll see this and reply with 
more info.

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 1995 10:46:19 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: 911 sub placement

Tom,

Althouth it is usually *difficult* to mount a sub in a 911, it *can* be 
done.  Perhaps I should point out that most of the cars I have seen that I 
reffered to earlier were professionally prepared, competition level ( yes, 
we stereo nuts *do* have an international sanctioning body(s) to see who has 
the best sounding system) cars that involved considerable time, cost, and 
effort.  Don't get discouraged, however, because it *can* be done.  It is 
possible to mount a sub(s) in the trunk of a 911, and you will still hear 
most of the output eminating from it while in the drivers seat.  What we 
call a "duct" (some sort of open passage way(s) from the trunk to the 
passenger compartment) can be used to allow more of the sound to reach the 
passengers un-muffled.  DO NOT, however, confuse a "duct" with a 
"tuned-port" found on the common "ported" (also called bass-reflex) sub-box 
enclosures.  It is not mandatory to go cutting large holes in a precious 
P-car to allow more bass in (in fact I would discourage cutting up such 
cars).  If you have some free time, find a friend or a shop willing to let 
you borrow his/her removable sub-box.  Place the box in your trunk, close 
the hood, play some appropriate music, sit in the front seat, and carefully 
listen to the level of bass.  Then decide for yourself if what you hear is 
what *you* want.  Don't eliminate the rear deck too quickly.  Although it 
*may* involve considerable custom work (read: expensive), a professional can 
mount subs on your rear deck in such a way that the stock appearance is 
maintained and thereby detering any would be thieves or interfering with 
driver visibility.  In reference to the area below the rear seats, I once 
saw a 911 (1984) with two 10" subs mounted there.  Once again, this was a 
professional's car, it involved an aftermarket fiberglass enclosure 
specifically designed for that space in a 911, and it was painstaikingly 
installed.  Done correctly, however, such a job proved to be inconspicous, 
effective, and I am sure it performed well.  I caution you, however, that 
this is not a task I would recommend for a DIY'er without extensive 
experience in all the above areas.  *BUT* if you have the bucks, and this 
sounds like a good idea to you, find a ruputable local pro-installer who can 
do the work.  Sub's provide an important part of the audible spectrum, and 
they are essential to any high-end stereo system, but you must decide what 
you are willing to compromise to get good bass in your ride.

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 1995 11:12:55 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: hey neighbor-- Head units

Starr (is that your correct name)?

Sounds like you have a pretty good idea on what you want out of your system. 
 Call me ignorant, but I really don't know what a "mini cooper" is, but that 
is kindof irrelevant.  In regard to "RDS", I probably know what this is, but 
I can't seem to remember what the acronym stands for.  Could you clarify?  
Also, just for your information, "DPS" is more commonly reffered to industry 
wide as "DSP" which stands for *Digital Signal Processing*.  I am not sure 
what you mean by "slop it into my Carrera", but I presume you want a single 
head that is easily transferrable from one car to another.  If so, then that 
is not an exteremely easy task because head-units are wired directly into 
the cars electrical system.  One method, however, is to buy one of the 
"removable type units" which comes with a sleeve into which it slides.  The 
sleeve is permanently mounted and wired to the dash, and the head unit 
slides into the sleeve.  An electrical connector on the back of the head 
engages another connector on the sleeve when you slide the unit in.  This 
feature is intended as a security device allowing you to remove the stereo 
from the car while parked.  It can, however, be used between two cars.  You 
must somehow purchase (not an easy thing to do) an extra sleeve of the exact 
same type included with your particular model of head.  Mount one sleeve 
into each car, and wire it into place.  Then, you can easily transfer the 
head from one sleeve to another in different cars.
Unless you are looking for truly high-end sounds in your car(s) then the 
head and "gaggle" of speaker you suggest should be adequate.  An amp will 
not be required, but it can improve performance.  For four moderately sized 
speakers, however, a good high-power, 4 channel, head unit should be able to 
fill your expectations.

Let me know if you have more concerns.

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 95 08:14:39 PST
From: radsickt@lablink.ple.af.mil
Subject: Speakers for P-cars

          Greetings,

          At the risk of turning this list into "Stereophiles@tta.com"
          I thought I'd throw out a few comments.

          First:  To those interrested in the 914 subwoofer box
          design, I will fire up the old computer this weekend and try
          to find where I put the design.  I'll post it to the list
          within two weeks.

          Regarding car speakers in general:
          Take exception to anyone who calls a 6.5" woofer a
          "subwoofer."  I guess in the sense that it will make lower
          bass than a OEM 4" dash speaker, it deserves the "sub"
          moniker but in general, subs are speakers designed to put
          out reasonable bass below 100 Hz.  Bass volume is related to
          the amount of displaced volume from the woofer cone.  While
          it is quite possible for a 6.5" to put out 20Hz, the throw
          of the woofer would have to be quite large to put out decent
          volume.  Even a box with an 8" woofer is pushing it.

          For any of the hobbists out there who may be looking for
          good sound on a budget,  I would strongly suggest that you
          get a hold of a speaker driver catalog (from Madisound,
          Meniscus, A&S, etc) and put together your own "separates"
          speaker system.  Making perfect speakers is difficult, but
          making pretty d*mn good speakers is quite possible and
          making speakers that sound better than what you could buy
          for the money is almost guaranteed.  If anyone is
          interested, let me know and I can help you "roll your own."

          (For reference:  I haven't done too much designing recently
          but I am the former owner of "Altair Speaker Design" and did
          alot of undergrad research into electro-acoustic modelling.)

          For those of you not interrested in speakers, I apologize
          for this little diversion....

          -Tim

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 95 11:31:59 EST
From: "John Hora" <jhora@VNET.IBM.COM>
Subject: Gastester

Sean...I have tried two models of the Gastester and they seem to
work OK. JC Whitney has two models of Gastester,which are made in England
and measure only co2,one model has a tach/dwell/multimeter on the same
led meter.I checked both on my 914s after my state emmisions test and
both were right on target.they have a plastic housing but for the
$100to$200 range it's fine.Only other co2 meters I could find were
professional units at $5k and up.My home garage doesn't have that
kind of budget.

John

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 95 10:43:00 cst
From: "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com>
Subject: Re: rusty 914s


Subject: Re: rusty 914s
 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------  
 --
On Jan 25,  4:25pm "Ehler, Kyle" <kehler@ppdpost.wichitaks.ncr.com> writes:

>    -So how are you setting on tools and a shop to work in?

Well, I have just about finished insulating and running electric in our
oversize two car garage.  I have an air compressor and a fair number of
tools, etc.  Don't have a MIG welder only arc and oxy/ace.  So there would
be some tool purchases, but that is part of the benefit of doing it
yourself.  Of course, having someone else do it would go lots faster ;-(.

==  Well, sounds like you are serious and resolved to get on with it.
==  Excellent.  Hang in there!!

I crawled under the car last night and poked around a bit.  The floorpan
looks solid at least!  Even the rocker panels are only rusted in
part, not entirely.  I need to spend some more time working under
the car to determine what is really rusted through.

==  Ok, remember that the floorpan inside is covered with some of that
== bituminous coating, and that can cover rusted metal and pinholes.
==  I've found that picking around the edges of the floorpan -picking
== away some of the edges of the bituminous where it is loose might
== reveal some car-rosion.  I've even used a chisel to peck at it.
==  If the metal is in good shape, it wont peel off the metal.  If there
== is some rust activity -the stuff comes off in chunks.  Cool thing about
== that stuff is you can patch it with a scissor and/or heatgun.
==  Place a strong light under the car when looking from inside for
== rust-holes (do this in darkness).  It helps to remove the seats, and
== carpet  from the rockers.
==
==  On those rockers, usually along the lower edge (and inboard) the joint
== where the floorpan meets is a prime spot for cancer. . .especially along 
the
== stretch just below the seatbelt mount.  The absolute worst zones are on
== the battery side.  Look long and hard around there, and pick with a
== sharp-tip hammer to look for thin metal.  Look for blisters in the metal 
or
== paint.  Pick, pick, PICK!!  (the only chance you'll get to pick on your 
'buddy')
==
==  You said the firewall in front of the motor has holes in it.  Exposing 
these
== requires removing the engine bay pad and the interior rear pad and
== sub-pad.  A lot of crap to go thru, but this area is prone to rust out in
== big holes (I had some large enough to pass a football thru).
==
==  While you have this exposed, carefully inspect the remainder of this
== section of the car for cancer.  You might also want to remove the 
seatbelt
== bolts (on the rocker side).  The condition of those bolts is a very good
== indicator of the condition of the rockers because the bolt tips are 
inside
== the rocker's 'box'.  This opening (~3/8") is a great entry point for a
== borescope inspection of this highly critical segment of the car's 
structure.
==
==  On retrospect, I would say this would be a quick and definite method
== to evaluate the structural condition of a 914:
==         Borescope the seatbelt bolt holes, and the jack points.
==
==  The rear firewall area is a good place to start your restoration 
routine.
==  The only problem to sweat is warpage.  The flat panels with reinforce
== ribs are a little difficult to replicate a patch, depending on the 
severity of
== rustout.
==  But that routine is also an easy beginning, as what lies ahead will make
== this portion of the work seem like a cakewalk. (because of accessibility)
==  Welding these back in can result in warpage, but it will be hidden
== from view when reassembled, so a good place to start for the newbie.

Where did you get your replacement sheet metal?  Who do you suggest?

==  Anybody who offers oem thickness parts. (>1.0mm, or original)
==  I've got a thang for Doc and Cy's at this writing. . .
==  For fabricating your own patches:
==  Domestic gauge sheet is acceptable, the 914 was not
== constructed of special steel sheet (it is not Thiessen or Martensitic).
==  I'm sorry, but I do not have any data pertaining to the steel
== formula used in the 914 (anybody?).  I was perhaps foolhardy
== to use the 'cabinet quality' steel from my employer, but after checking
== with an M.E. decided our stuff was equal or greater.
==  Any of the domestic steel suppliers (local) would have equivalent
==  materials, but will have a minimum purchase ($50-100).
==  The steel supplier can cut stock to sizes too. (a charge?)
==  Then you got to get it home. . .

I am not sure if I am going to have to build a rotisserie (sp?) or
not.  I hope that I could just reinforce the door and work on the
rocker panels.  But I do have space to build the rotisserie if I
do need it (no space to store it though!).

==  Having done so, (and more) I would tend to say that the roto
== is nice for those pesky 'in position' awkward situations, and
== necessary for doing a full rocker (longitudinal) replacment, but
== for the work you are attempting, not needed.  This depends a
== little on your skill too (can you weld 'out of position'?)
==
==  However, constructing a door positioning brace would be
== an excellent idea (maybe even mandatory) when doing
== anything around the rockers, to avoid problems later.
==  Having a rigid platform attached to the car while worked on
== would eliminate the chance of warping the body.

I got this car for cheap.  Spend $300 or so on it.  Pretty clean
and is already stripped.  It is the correct year at least ('72).

==  HOAD!!   (hell of a deal)
==  -and all you gotta do is <insert labor here> long and hard.
==  (some assembly required)
==
==  Keep that (cheap) in mind when you are looking at a critical juncture,
== like those times when you wish someone else would take over.
==  BT,DT.  -looking at a gaping hole (of my own petard)
== I was terrified of the complexity of the task, where to begin?
== how to proceed?  <first, have another beer>
==
==  I survived by sizing up the patch -then reducing the task to its
== smallest possible structure (sps) and fabricating those a step
== at a time.  There was more than once where I took small bits of
== sheet and welded/grind/shape/graft sub-assemblies into a
== structure that was ready to occupy the patch site -in 3D.
==  Yeah, it took lots of time. and I probably didnt save on work
== or money, but I did it MY way.
==
==  Curious thing about it is that I had never screwed with cars like
== this before. . .I've always just wrenched on 'em.  When they get
== rusted out I used to just get depressed.  Now I just 'cut-n-patch'.
==
Thanks for the response.  I am going to need all the help I can
get on this one!

Alex

==  NO sweat!
==  -kyle

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 1995 12:05:32 EST
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Re: spinning 911s/rear sway bars

Bill says
In the absence of braking, it really depends upon the ratio of the
stiffness between the front and rear whether a car will oversteer (be
loose) or understeer (push), but in general which ever is "looser" will
break free first.

It may just be a question of semantics, but I think it's the *stiffest* end
that breaks loose first.

If you're experiencing "push" then loosen the front bar OR tighten the rear
bar...Do just the opposite for oversteer.

Barney Bettilyon
cmxk95a@prodigy.com
'70 914-6 4DTrack
'89 Carrera Cab. 4DCommute

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 12:18:24 -0600
From: clr@edge.ercnet.com (Charlie Robinette)
Subject: Porsche Stops Losing Money

Reuter reported on 1/28/95 that Porsche said it broke even in the first
half of its 1994/95 business year after several years of losses.  Porsche
lost $75 million in the first half of 1993/94 and $79 million a year
earlier. Improved performance was due to stringent cost cutting measures
and the success of the new 911 model. In the six months to the end of
January Porsche had 9,500 new car orders, a rise of 17 percent from a year
earlier.  In calendar 1994, Porsche delivered 18,244 vehicles to dealers
and exporters, up 43 percent from 1993. Deliveries to its key German and
U.S. markets were up 45 percent and 55 percent, respectively, compared with
1993.

Hopefully, Porsche will remain independent.

* clr@edge.ercnet.com *  a ham sandwich is better than nothing. *

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 10:23:51 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: spinning 911s/rear sway bars

>From What I can recall, stiffening up the rear end *REDUCES* the tendency to
>oversteer.  Stiffening the rear end reduces the tendency of the car to roll.
>Roloing transfers weight from the inside rear tire to the outside.  As the car
>becomes unbalanced in the rear it's ability to stick is diminished causing
>it to break free earlier (one of the rear tires starts to loose traction)
>In the absence of braking, it really depends upon the ratio of the stiffness
>between the front and rear whether a car will oversteer (be loose) or
>understeer (push), but in general which ever is "looser" will break
>free first.
>
>There's a great book called "Race Car Engineering and Mechanics" that explains
>suspension set up and it's effect on a car's handling.  I'll post the author
>and publisher when I get home and have access to the book.

Bill,

If you take a neutral handling car and stiffen the rear sway bar,
the car will now have oversteer to some degree.

For example, on my '78 911, I adjust my rear sway bar to full soft
for everyday driving. This makes my car handle fairly neutral for
a 911. When I go to an autocross, I set my rear sway bar to full stiff.
This gives me an oversteering beast that does not push in the corners.

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 12:23:44 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: rear sway bars

>From What I can recall, stiffening up the rear end *REDUCES* the tendency to
>oversteer.  Stiffening the rear end reduces the tendency of the car to roll.

        General rule of thumb is:  A bigger/more effective sway bar on one
end of a car will keep the *other* end sticking to the road.  So you use a
rear bar to cut down on *understeer*.
        As I understand it, the bigger bar reduces body roll at the expense
of putting a greater lateral load on the outside tire.  This makes the tire
slip more easily.  It turns out that this effect dominates over the addi-
tional sticking power gained by reducing body roll--on that end.  However,
since the whole chassis is not rolling as much, the tires on the other end
stick better.

>Unless you have a limited-slip differential (or a locker), you shouldn't
>install a rear sway bar.

        I disagree with that.  In general, the factory set the cars up to
handle pretty decently.  If the car comes from the factory with a partic-
ular sway bar, removing it will adversely effect the handling.  Yes, you
can spin your inside rear wheel, but that is pretty unusual for the stock
setup, even while autocrossing.  Besides, the solution to that problem is
to use a bigger front sway bar.
        If your car was originally shipped with a rear bar, I'd consider
re-installing one of the same size.  If you prefer, you can go for an ad-
justable bar (e.g., Weltmeister and others) which will let you change the
effectiveness of the bar.  Then you can diddle things until you get the
handling set up the way you like it.

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'

such an abrupt manner that the handling will suffer severely.  His suggestion
was to put a small spacer behind the existing bump stop thereby limiting the
travel and retaining the "cushion."   Are there any other opinions?

Any UK lister over 40 will give you the answer to that one -

The mini cooper was a rally version of the Austin Mini produced around 
61-65, it won Monte Carlo rally and many others.

It used a 1000/1275 cc pushrod engine around 70 hp

The mini is still made today it is a 4 seat 2 door saloon weighing about 
1200 lb and smaller than any of the current jap micro cars.

They had a cult following in the 60's famous in the film the Italian Job 
where Michael Caine and fellow crooks drive thru the Rome sewers to escape.

probably 90% of all age 40+ UK drivers have owned/driven a mini at some 
time.

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 95 13:21:33 EST
From: "ken haynes" <ken_haynes@ccmail.crc.com>
Subject: ALL Sway Bars (was spinning 911)

     Slight error by Bill: Stiffening the rear of anything will tend to 
     oversteer more.  Anything that DECREASES capability of rear to corner 
     increases oversteer, and consequently increases marginal steering 
     gain, crispness, response, etc. (up to a point)
     
     What causes oversteer (looseness):
     1. Less rear/more front negative camber
     2. Less rear/more front tire pressure or stickiness
     3. More rear/less front spring rate
     4. More rear/less front sway bar stiffness
     5. Less rear/more front aero downforce
     
     Increased rear wheel/tire width helps to balance the 911's very 
     favorable front/rear weight bias, for usually overall benefit.
     
     Cornering force cause roll, which must be resisted by springs and 
     swaybars.  Front and rear contribute to this.  If you increase the 
     rear'r contribution, you cause the outside tire to have a higher load 
     (vertical and cornering).  But coefficient of friction (mu) does not 
     stay constant as load increases, but begins to decrease at higher 
     loads.
     
     Slip angle (difference in tire direction and "flight-path") is caused 
     by this relationship between cornering force and mu.  This is why 
     loading (stressing) the rear more cause higher slip angles, and 
     perceived "looseness".
     
     Conservative cars (68 Chev Impala, and most older cars) have a large 
     front sway bar and no rear.  This cause ponderous understeer, or 
     "push", under almost all conditions.  This mean it would be near 
     imposible to "provoke" into oversteer.  This is relatively safe, but 
     boreing.
     
     Porsches, being specialty cars, are the best "balanced" of all common 
     (ie. except for maybe things even more exotic than porsches) 
     production cars.  This means that the front/rear slip angles are close 
     to equal when high-g cornering.  Therefore, the driver is constantly 
     and naturally monitoring and adjusting the car to keep it in this 
     balanced mode, which is also the fastest mode to go through a corner.  
     
     When Indy cars "push" the front is slipping too much, and the driver 
     is having trouble missing the exit wall.  If he is too "loose", he is 
     constantly trying to enter the turn just slow enough to avoid hitting 
     the wall backwards after the tail suddenly comes around.
     
     Therefore, ballanced handling gives the driver the most control of the 
     car's attitude under the fastest cornering conditions.  One problem in 
     race cars is keeping it ballanced as fuel load, tires and track 
     change.
     
     This balance doesn't have to be (and won't ever be) perfect, but 
     should be close enough to allow the driver to finish balancing by his 
     active control.  BTW, autox cars can sometimes afford to be much 
     looser than road racers or street cars because of sometimes very tight 
     (small) courses and no consequenses for spinning except losing the 
     run.
     
     All this is very interesting to play with on the autox course if you 
     have opportunity.  In general, though, things should always be changed 
     in fairly conservative and balanced (front/rear) manner, keeping in 
     mind the cost/benefit of mods, and whether there actally needs to be 
     any change. Porches are the least of all cars to need any changes.  My 
     74 914 SE is stock except for gas shocks and lowering the front to 
     where it should have been, and nothing needs to be changed, even the 
     so-called "weak" stock rear springs.
     
     I accept no responsiblity for the (mis)use of this info.  Have fun.
     
     Ken Haynes
     
     KentonH930@aol.com

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 19:55:35 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: sway bars and over/under steer


All this airiation assumes you are driving on a flat road!

sway bars try to make independant wheels work like de dion suspensions ie 
keep both wheels parallel (or at a constant ride height)

strong sway bars work against you on uneven bumps, as they don't allow the 
wheels to follow the ground contours.

get going fast thru a curve and hit a bump with one wheel, and your hefty
sway bars will do their best to reduce your contact patch on the other 
wheel close to zero - if thats the outside wheel say goodnight.

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Thu,  2 Feb 95 13:06:48 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Missing Sway bars, when did Galvanizing start

 re; Missing sway bars and When did Galavanizing start (or, the word according
     to Pano...)

 1.   When did Galvanizing start; the November '75 issue of Pano
    introduces Galvanizing in a 2-page article, saying that '76 911s will
    start to use hot-galvanizing, all areas except the roof. Thickness
    is 10 microns everywhere, except for 20 microns around vulnerable
    areas like the rockers and 50u thick around the rear torsion bar.
    Europe will now be offered a 6-year body rust warranty, Pano wonders
    if the US will also be offered the same.
      Regarding incidental use anywheres else, the article only states
    other non-galvanic protection schemes used since '73, including
    corrosion-free exhaust, undercoated gas tank and increased use of
    aluminum. Makes me think there was -no- galvanizing before this.
      Coincidentally, this is the same issue that introduces a newfangled
    version of the 911 with a turbocharger.... 2514 pounds and 78 hp/liter.

 2. Does missing sway bar increase of decrease oversteer:

       According to the "other" Porsche god (Allan Caldwell...sorry Bruce,
    bumping up HP is interesting but getting my windshield wipers working
    is -compelling-!) in the November '92 issue of pano (A Review of
    Suspension Basics, an 8-page article) there is a table on page 20.
    Summarized;

     To increase oversteer or lessen understeer;
        Lower front spring rate,higher rear spring rate, lower spring rate
      of front sway bar, higher spring rate rear sway bar, weight distribution
      rearward, front shocks softer/rear shocks firmer, front wheel camber
      more negative, rear wheel camber more positive, front tires narrower,
      rear tires wider, front tire pressure higher, rear tire pressure less,
      front track wider, rear track narrower, front spoiler larger, rear
      spoiler smaller (or less angle).

    To increase understeer of lessen oversteer; do the opposite of above.
     Or buy a 928. 

      Since the only competitive driving I do is to beat an empty fuel
     gauge, I can't dispute Mr. Caldwell...the rest I'll leave up to
     you mechanical engineers to explain !

          Lee A.  13mm rear sway bar on my midengined V8...

Dear Don and all,

We buy 914s every day. The problem is transportation. We cannot afford a man,
insurance and a truck to haul a $1,000 parts car. (We of course can afford to
pick up a cheap six cylinder.) Hence, all 914s we buy are delivered to us by
the seller. Prices for a complete parts car range from $500 - $2,500
depending on model and equipment.

Anyone interested in the 914 catalog can give us their name and address and
we will immediately mail one.

George Hussey

it getting sucked in as fresh air, unless there's a problem with his heat
exchangers.

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 1995 17:15:57 EST
From: CMXK95A@prodigy.com ( BARNEY BETTILYON)
Subject: Swaybars and LSD

IMHO, this swaybar setting thread is going to end up causing some problems
for folks who don't read between the lines.

First off, bar settings used for autocrossing rarely convert directly to
bar setting for the track. Low speed understeer almost always becomes high
speed *oversteer* on the track. If you adjust your car for neutral steering
on an autox course and then take it to the track, you will likely
experience substantial oversteer at the first highspeed corner you come to.

Secondly, the words Locker and LSD are *not* interchangeable. Lockers do
exactly that...They lock the rear differential so that both driven wheels
turn at the same speed regardless of conditions.  LSD units allow for
"slippage" between the two driven wheels, while still supplying power to
both. When entering a turn, a locker requires a completely different
driving technique than does an LSD. (If you've ever driven an ATV you
already know about Lockers) And both require a different technique than a
standard differential. (We're talking track driving here,)

Lastly, rear swaybars really do work best on cars equipped with an LSD or
locker because, as the cornering load increases, the loaded end of the
swaybar tries to pick up the unweighted wheel. In a corner, on a car
*without* LSD, the lifting of a driven wheel is the same thing as lifting
off the throttle...You spin.

Just my .02

Barney Bettilyon
cmxk95a@prodigy.com
'70 914-6 4DTrack
'89 Carrera Cab. 4DCommute
'92 S-10 Balzer 4TowingD62DTrack
'91 Southwind 4Living@DTrack


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 95 14:30:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: rear sway bars


>As I understand it, the bigger bar reduces body roll at the expense
>of putting a greater lateral load on the outside tire.

I haven't read the rest of this thread, but scanned this message and
thought I might correct it slightly.

You're almost right, but it's not a question of body roll.  Roll is not so
much the issue, except inasmuch as it moves the car's centre of
gravity, roll centre, and otherwise changes the suspension geometry.
These are really second-order issues in the context of this thread.

The first-order thing is weight transfer.  The stiffer end (ie, stiffer bar)
transfers less weight from the inside tire and to the outside tire.  There
is not a linear relationship between vertical force on a tire (weight)
and its ability to generate a side force (cornering force).  In other
words, the simple linear equation they taught us in secondary school
is not right.

So, because of this non-linearity, when weight is transferred, the outside
tire can do less marginal "work."  And that is why the stiffer end, with
comparatively more weight tranfer, will have a larger slip angle.  And
slip angles are what over/understeer is all about.

Hope this helps (and hope I have it right).  Bottom line is that it's mostly
about weight transfer rather than body roll.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1130                         Fri Feb 3 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 2 Feb 95 13:47:21 PST
From: lingren@lambo.alldata.com (Loren Lingren)
Subject: mini cooper

From porschephiles-request@tta.com Thu Feb  2 12:07:24 1995
Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 19:40:13 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
To: porschefiles <porschephiles@tta.com>
Subject: mini cooper

Any UK lister over 40 will give you the answer to that one -

The mini cooper was a rally version of the Austin Mini produced around
61-65, it won Monte Carlo rally and many others.  It used a 1000/1275
cc pushrod engine around 70 hp The mini is still made today it is a 4
seat 2 door saloon weighing about 1200 lb and smaller than any of the
current jap micro cars.

They had a cult following in the 60's famous in the film the Italian
Job where Michael Caine and fellow crooks drive thru the Rome sewers to
escape.  probably 90% of all age 40+ UK drivers have owned/driven a
mini at some time.

+-------------------------------+ 
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

- ----- End Included Message -----

Greetings Peter & all,

Having been a British auto mechanic for the past 25 years, you've
struck a chord with this Mini talk.  While my specialty was Jaguar, I
have dealt with a few Mini's, on occasion.  (I should try to find a
British car group, as well, similar to porschephiles.  If you know of
one...)

This is 1966 information, for what it is (or isn't) worth...

Mini-Cooper

ENGINE 4cyl.; 64.58 mm. bore, 76.2 mm. stroke; 998 c.c.; 20.3 sq.in.
piston area; 9.0 : 1 compression ratio (optional 7.8 : 1); valvegear,
overhead (pushrod); twin SU HS2 carburetters; max. power, 55 b.h.p. net
at 5,800 r.p.m.; max. torque, 57 lb. ft. net at 3,000 r.p.m.

TRANSMISSION (Manual): B.M.C. diaphragm spring 7 1/8" dia. clutch; 4
speed gearbox (synchromesh on 2-3-4) with overall ratios 3.765, 5.11,
7.213 and 12.05;rev. 12.05; top gear mph. per 1,OOOr.p.m. 14.8.

RUNNING GEAR.-Lockheed hydraulic brakes, 7" dia. discs at front, 7"
dia. drums at rear; front suspension, unequal wishbone; rear, trailing
arm interconnected by Hydrolastic displacers; Cam Gears rack and pinion
steering; Dunlop 5.20 x 10. tyres.

CAPACITIES.-Fuel, 5.5 gal.; cooling system, 6.25 pints (with heater);
engine oil, 8.5 pints.

DIMENSIONS.-Wheelbase, 6' 8+"; track, 3' 11+" front, 3' 10" rear;
length, 10' 0+"; width, 4' 7+"; height, 4' 5"; ground clearance, 6+";
turning circle, 37+'; kerb weight, 12+ cwt.


Mini-Cooper "S"

ENGINE  4 cyl 70.6 mm. bore, 81.33 mm. stroke; 1,275 c.c.; 24 sq.in.
piston area; 9.75 : 1 compression ratio; valvegear, overhead (pushrod)
twin SU HS2 carburetters; max. power, 76 b.h.p. net at 6,000 r.p.m.;
max. torque, 79 ib. ft. net at 3,000 r.p.m.

TRANSMISSION (Manual).-B.M.C. diaphragm spring clutch; 4-speed gearbox
(synchromesh on 2-3-4) with overall ratios 3.444, 4.67, 6.60 and ll.02;
rev. 11.02; top gear m.p.h. per 1,OOO r.p.m. 16.1.

RUNNING GEAR.-Lockheed hydraulic brakes (with vacuum servo) 7 1/2 dia.
discs at front. 7" dia. drums at rear; front suspension, unequal
wishbone; rear, semi-trailing arm, interconnected by Hydrolastic
displacers; Cam Gears rack and pinion steering; Dunlop 14.5 x 10 SP or
5.20 x 10 C41 tyres.

CAPACITIES.-Fuel, 5.5 gal  cooling system, 6.25 pints (with heater);
engine oil, 8.5 pints.

DIMENSIONS.-Wheelbase, 6' 8 1/8" track, 3' 11 1/4" (4' 1/2" with 4 1/2"
rims) front, 3' 10 1/4" (3' 11 1/4 with 4 1/2" rims) rear; length, 10'
1/4"; width, 4' 7 1/2"; height, 4' 5"; ground clearance, 61/8"; turning
circle. 31 1/2'; kerb weight, 13 cwt.

From: Loren Lingren

This group does get into some *interesting* discussions.

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 17:14:40 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Re: Odor of Rotten Eggs

Have your boss do one easy check first.  Next time he smells this odor, have
him open the front bonnet.  If the smell is strong, look to see if the battery
vent is blowing fumes.

Not long ago I lost my alternator and replaced it with a rebuilt.  The rebuilt
had a bad voltage regulator ... (caused lots of damage) ... One symptom was
this rotton egg odor.  The alternator was overcharging my battery.  As
it boiled, the sulfur fumes were vented into the bonnet area and came into the
cabin area thru the dash vents.

Anyway, this is easy to check if there is some uncertainty about the CAT
explanation.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
  Wayne D. Michelsen                | W_Michelsen@lfhs2.hso.link.com
  '87 911 Targa [Guards-Red/Black]  | RedAcorn@aol.com

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 95 16:04:00 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Race 914 Rear Suspension


RE: to the guy with the 914.

I agree with Stan. My experience with some IMSA 914/6s was that a 
minimum of 250 pound springs were required. I personally would be 
more worried that the trailing arms coming into contact with the 
part of the engine shroud that hangs down from the body.

For those of you who aren't familiar with this, the body CAN contact
the trailing arm under severe cornering conditions with wider tires
and a low spring rate. This results in some unusual handling 
characteristics at higher speeds. It also can bend trailing arms at 
the point of contact, resulting in some interesting camber gains that
cannot be adjusted out (replacement of the arms is necessary).

If you start using wide wheels and sticky tires, have the rear arms 
reinforced with extra metal. Automotion sells a fair kit for doing the
arms. You may also consider large (turbo) inside CV joints on your
half-shafts, if you are using real 914/6 arms.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 95 17:56:19 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: re: Tail Happy 911s

>Richard Hocking <hocking@cig.mot.com> wrote: 
>
>| What with the recent thread on whether to let go the controls when in
>| a spin, I was wondering what the expert drivers out there recommend
>| when you start to lose the tail of your 911 ?
>
>The recommended technique is: go to your nearest PCA/BMWCCA driver's
>education event or autocross school. Do not pass go. As with most
>driving techniques, controlling an immenent spin requires precise
>control inputs - it's not likely that you'll be able to read a book (or
>read this email) and then be able to use this info with out some
>practical training.
> ...
>I can't emphasize enough the importance of driver's ed - don't try this
>without some instruction. It'll make you a better driver, and you'll
>have a blast!

For learning car control, at or near the limit (e.g. pushing until there
is a relatively high probability of a spin), I would strongly suggest
autocrossing, as opposed to drivers education at a racetrack. A spin
at an autocross might embarass you, and might even put a black mark
on your car from a cone, which you can rub off. A spin at a racetrack,
where speeds are typically significantly higher and you run out of smooth
asphault much sooner, may result in either ad-hoc barrier crash testing
or rollover testing, both of which are more than embarassing. The
difference is how you approach (or should approach) the two. With
drivers Ed. on a racetrack, you tend to creep up on ultimate cornering
speeds very gradually, always trying hard to make sure you never
exceed your skill level and spin, due to the consequences. You have
many, many laps (on the order of 30-100 a day x many days on the same
track) to learn. In autocrossing, the risk of overcooking it is
relatively small, so you can afford to get closer to the edge quickly,
just to see where the edge really is (for your level of driving skill,
that day). You also typically have many fewer runs at an autocross,
on that particular course. If both autocrosses and racetrack drivers
schools are available, try both, keeping the above perspective in mind.
The real key is to get as much seat time as you can.

I agree with Steve that an autocross school is good, but you can learn a
lot by just going out and trying it. Even finding a large empty parking 
lot (preferably without poles) and experimenting can be a big help, 
combined with question/answer sessions on why certian things happened,
or what you should try instead. In case it is not obvious, some parking
lot owners will have more trouble with your doing this than others.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Thu,  2 Feb 95 17:47:18 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: grown noise when turn the stearing wheel during cold weather

| From: Darryl Wagoner  <darryl@sai.com>
|
| My 944 has a bad grown sound when I first start the car in cold weather.
| It sort of sounds like a belt slipping.  Any ideas?

Tom has already made the obligatory comment about
groan vs. grown. What are these, homonyms?

Sounds like the power steering pump belt is slipping. The belt
is either old and hard or loose. It is easy to replace/tighten,
except the front of the car has to be put on jack stands and
the under pan has to be removed. It has to be done from
underneath (unless you have 4 foot long arms with half
a dozen joints apiece). A pair of 13mm (or is it 10mm,
I forget) flare nut wrenches also helps to loosen and tighten
the turnbuckle. Use proper fitting wrenches rather than pliers
else you will mash the nuts (to say nothing of your knuckles.
But what fun is working on a car without shedding a little blood!?).

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

BTW, thanks Jim and George for the help with my ignition
lock. The new one was rekeyed and I installed it last week.
Now everything works as it should and I learned how the
process of drilling out a lock cylinder works (the locksmith,
recommended by the dealer, was kind enough to explain
the process).

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 17:54:04 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: 911 or MR2

John W. Todd (jwtodd@stemc.eig485.af.mil) wrote: 

>My wife has a '91 MR2 Turbo .... while the turbo lag is quite a bit 
>less than the 930 (w/ K27), it is still definitely present.  It is 
>small too, but if you're under 6'3", you should be ok. .... It is also 
>a noisy car, with the motor directly behind your head .... It creaks 
>a bit too, but that may have something to do with those occasions when 
>it has met with solid objects. .... I like them both

My wife has one, too, and I have slightly different impressions of the 
car:

The MR2's turbo lag is quite a bit easier to handle than a 930's; the 
turbo kicks in at a much lower RPM, and my wife has no problems keeping 
it on boost.

I can't really complain about the size issue (except to say that I'm 
5'10", and my hair brushes the roof unless I recline the seat a bit), 
since my car's a 914-6.  The MR2 has a lot more interior room than my 
914, although trunk space is considerably less.

Compared to the RS motor in my car, the MR2's engine is silent.  John 
didn't mention this, but the MR2s come with just about the best factory 
sound system on the planet.  If the whine of the turbo ever bothers you, 
you can just crank up the stereo.

I've never heard any creaks or rattles in my wife's car.  Build quality 
is excellent; it's a Toyota, after all.

I like them both, too.  Too bad the only exterior difference between the 
MR2 Turbo and the normally-aspirated car is the raised engine-lid 
louvers; Porsche really hit the mark with the Turbo whale tails.

 -Andy

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 18:19:54 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: HELP<914 track car rear susp?

MrBru@aol.com wrote: 

>A slight tire rubs occurs on the outside if I take the springs off of 
the shocks and jack the wheel up to the bump stops.   It won't rub until 
the bump stops are compressed by the weight of the car to about 1/2 of 
their normal length.   Can anyone tell me the liklihood that I would get 
that far into the bump stops?
> ....
>I have never noticed that I was hitting the bump stops before but
>I'm trying to play it safe.

I guess I'm more fanatical about safety than most, but to me, this is a 
little like asking, "There's a sharp steel gusset in the corner of my 
rollcage.  I can tap it with my helmet, but only if I really stretch.  
What's the likelihood of my getting injured in a crash?"

You've got a fast car.  If the tire ever does rub, it's going to be 
while you're travelling at high speed.  I don't know about you, but the 
idea of cutting a highly-loaded tire at speed scares the hell out of me.

Replacing the bump stops with something incompressible will keep the 
tire from rubbing, but you're likely to be extremely displeased by the 
results of hitting THOSE bump stops.  If it were me, I'd either:
a) get new rim halves for those BBS wheels and change the offset, or
b) mod the fenders.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 18:48:54 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: rear sway bars

Dave Darling (darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov) wrote: 

>(Quoting me):   Unless you have a limited-slip differential (or a
>                locker), you shouldn't install a rear sway bar.
>
>I disagree with that.  In general, the factory set the cars up to
>handle pretty decently.  If the car comes from the factory with a 
>particular sway bar, removing it will adversely effect the handling.  
>Yes, you can spin your inside rear wheel, but that is pretty unusual 
>for the stock setup, even while autocrossing.  Besides, the solution to 
>that problem is to use a bigger front sway bar.

You're right, Dave... My comment applies to cars that are already 
well-balanced, like 914s.

Still, I don't think it makes a whole lot of sense to fix a problem at 
the rear of the car by killing the end that IS working...

 -Andy

Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 2 Feb 1995 19:10:30 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: rear sway bar

mwc@lubrizol.com wrote: 

>How does limited slip help [alleviate the problems caused by using a 
>rear sway bar with an open differential]?

Matt:

An open differential sends all the engine's torque to the wheel that's 
most lightly-loaded; this is why, when yuo used to do burnouts in your 
mom's station wagon, you left only one black streak on the road.

A limited-slip differential sends the torque to the tire that's most 
heavily-loaded.

If you're running an open diff and are in a corner, and the inside wheel 
lifts, all the evailable torque will go toward spinning that wheel, 
leaving none for the outside wheel that's still planted firmly planted 
on the track.  With a limited-slip, the outside wheel continues to be 
driven even if the inside wheel is spinning.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 00:42:55 -0500
From: LarryB208@aol.com
Subject: 944 Motronics

The 1983 through 1985 944's used a Bosch 1.1 version Motronic(Registered name
for any of Bosch's lawyers out there.) In mid-1985, with the '85/2 cars, they
Porsche switched to the 1.2 vwrsion. (I think these are the proper
designations. We always just called them Motronic 1 and Motronic 2)

Internally, the systems are entirerly different. The early system used an RCA
processor, and, except in the very latest units, four CMOS memory chips.
Autothority developed a board that replace these four chips, so there is a
performance option there. 

The later systems went to a somewhat more contemporary Intel processor with
EPROM memory.

Surprisingly, I spent some time once going through the wiring diagrams and
parts microfische, and everything matches up except the air flow meter. The
swap should just require that the ECU and air flow meter be matched. All
connectors are interchangeable.

I never tried this on a 944, but did almost the same thing on a 733i BMW by
installing a 3.5 air mass sensor.

FWIW, the cost of an ECU and air flow meter combined would seem to more than
outweigh the difference in price between a chip and the circuit board. Also,
there is no difference in performance between the two options. The additional
4 HP between the '85 and '85/2 came from the exhaust and cam changes.

Larry Bershtein 

note: e-mail address is lbershte@nova.umuc.edu. This will show my aol address
because I'm in San Diego and it's the only way I could get mail while on the
road. And I couldn't face the thought of 10 days worth of p-file reading to
catch up on when I got home. Besides, it's something to do while hanging out
in cheap motel rooms. <g>

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 95 01:37:29 EST
From: "Felix Klauser" <felix@lfs.loral.com>
Subject: gastester

I believe the two gastesters sold by JC Whitney are made by Gunson, the
same company that makes the colour-tune and Eezi-bleed.  They're CO
meters that you put by the tail pipe of your car to measure the CO. Thus
they can't be used under load unless using a chassis dyno. And if you
have access to a chassis dyno, you probably have access at the same time
to something far more sophisticated to measure the CO.

I'm in the process of getting and installing a lambda sensor and
air/fuel ratio monitor to help me tune the twin Weber 40DCOE's on my
non-Porsche.  RPM in Port Orange, FL (occasional Panorama advertiser)
sells such a beast as does TWM Induction in Goleta, CA. My plan is to
monitor the mixture under load and thereby help me find the right
jetting for the current ambient temperature. I'll post again when I have
some further news or experiences.

Felix Klauser
Loral ASIC
Portsmouth, UK

Date: 3 Feb 95 10:33:00 +0000
From: swellen@intgp1.att.com
Subject: Subwoofers

It's good to see the discussion on stereo, there is no
one answer and one persons meat is anothers poison.
I currently run a Kenwood CD player and ignore it's
amp and actively split to three amps. A small Kenwood
(20 "proper" amps a channel) for tweeters, a slightly
larger Kenwood (30 amps) for midrange and a Caliber
(100 amps in mono) for an 8 inch Bazooka tube. I 
haven't given model numbers as they are different
all over the world.
  I've spent the last 5 years experimenting with 944s
and have the following observation. With a 1989 944 only
having one spare rear wheel well I find it too useful
for bottles of wine etc to give it up for a subwoofer
but if you feel differently either gives good results.
So I use the Bazooka which on the rare occasions I
need more luggage space I can unplug and throw in the
house in a few seconds. 
  Experimenting with postioning it works best firing
into the left rear corner but this leaves it visible
to thiefs, a real problem here in England. The second
best position is right behind the left seat and it is
hidden so that was my choice.
  The non-directional effect of low frequencies is
exaggerated, to get the best results from your
subwoofer system get as much bass as you can from
your door speakers. It may well be worth while, if
less fun, getting the pros in for door speaker
modules. 
  Finally for Porsches bias the sound for the front
seats, people in the back are more concerned stopping
their heads hitting the roof then listening to stereo.

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 95 14:14:14 +0200
From: pl@itf.fi (Pekka Laiho)
Subject: SOLEX 40PI venturi


Hi all.

Does anybody has experience from Solex 40PI venturis.

Currently we are building two ('65 and '66 911's) for historic
race and rally. When we float-test the heads before starting modify
them, we found that the venturi reduces over 15 hp power.

Thanks in advance

W: Pekka Laiho

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 07:14:35 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: timing belt intervals

Armagan writes;
<- Does it matter how old the timing belt is (age, not the miles driven)  for
replacement ? The current one has about 26K miles, but about 4  years old.>

The recommended interval is to keep a belt no longer than 3 years,
independent of mileage.. After that you are subject to cracking and
oxidation. My feeling is that you can't be too careful when evaluating timing
belts. I once had a brand new one break on a 944S. It was less than 2500
miles old and had been installed and re tensioned by a Porsche dealer. With
minimal argument they did all necessary repairs, including reconditioning the
head. (bent valves don't do the valve guides any good at all)
Anyway replace it yesterday.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
6:49 am

> In message <950131213847_9545645@aol.com>  writes:
> > Arthur Golden <agolden@pepsi.com> said :
> > 
> > >I originally asked the question and Bruce Anderson responded that _full_ 
> > >galvinization started in '78 on the 911. Bart responded that _partial_ 
> > >galvinization started in '75 with the '76 model year.
> 
> Mike, thanks for giving me the chance to set the record straight, as I 
> screwed-up and deleted Arthur's post before it sunk in that I was being 
> misquoted.  BFD you say, (and you're right. BFD indeed...)
> 
> What I said was that galvanization (NOT partial) started in '75 with the '76 
> model, and that, given Porsche's proclivity to make running changes, some
> '75s may have gotten the benefit.  But who cares? 

Sorry if I missed something here..? but partial galvanizing started in *71* AFAIK, the
floors and inner wings (i.e. all the lower body) was the first step. Full
galvanizing started in year '76 according to all refernces I've seen etc (with 
some '75 models also). I suppose the question is what is "full" galvanizing? - I
take it to mean the unitary body (what about doors & bonnet..)

etc and was interested to see that they classed the Maison Blanche camping area
as a "LayBy" - something I would agree with actually after seeing the crap facilities
the last two years!

Only one *campsite* (as opposed to 3 or 4 Lay-By's)  was listed (Tribune?) - is this 
the one where the PCA/PCGB BBQ was last year?? Any comments on which is the best 
grandstand?? The ACO seems the best??

Kevin.

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 08:02:23 -0500 (EST)
From: Grayson Walker <gwalker@rtfm.mlb.fl.us>
Subject: Night Launch (Non-car story)

Last night's Shuttle launch was spectacular. For those of you out of
the area, we had lift-off at 12:22 pm this morning.

It was a beautiful clear night, temperature in the low 60s (It's winter.)

The first thing I saw was what I thought was a very bright street light
on the next street. I was mistaken -- that was the Shuttle.

The light from the rocket engine's flames was bright enought to cast
very sharp shadows on the lawn -- not quite bright enough to read. A
minute or two later you begin to hear the engines -- the Shuttle is 
now only a pinpoint of light in the sky. The sound builds like distant
thunder -- but it continues for about a minute. Things in the house
rattle and you feel the earth shaking.

In terms of acceleration and speed, 10 minutes after liftoff, the
Shuttle is moving over 15,000 mile per hour, is about 20 miles high,
and almost 2,000 miles north of Kennedy Space Center.

FORZA!                  Smith, Walker And Associates, Melbourne, Florida

GWALKER@RTFM.MLB.FL.US      "Big brown river. . ." Tuli Kupferberg, 1963

Date: 3 Feb 1995 12:26:05 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: 928S Questions.....

                                                                    12:16 PM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      928S Questions.....                           2/3/95
                                                              Date:


I'm a newcomer to this forum and a relatively new Porsche owner.  I have
spent about a year fixing up a
 1984 928S.

There are a few remaining problems that I need 
advice on ... I'm hoping one or more of you may
be able to help me.

(1)  My engine is running slightly hotter than I
would like it to.  I've replaced the fan clutch
(helped a little) and the thermostat (helped some
more), but it still is hotter than I'd like.  
Porsche only makes an 83 degree C (180 degree F) 
thermostat and there is no cross reference to any 
others.  Question: does anyone know of a cooler 
thermostat that would fit or any other alternative? 
Should I attempt to clean the radiator first?

(2)  When I changed the coolant after 9 months of
use, it came out very dark (nearly dark gray) due
to (I think) an oil leak into the coolant.  After 
4 weeks of use and 2,000 miles on the fresh coolant
I drained a cupful and found it to be slightly
darker than the fresh coolant.  I change the oil every 
2 to 3 months and have NEVER noticed any coolant
in it.  Question:  has anyone experienced a similar 
problem before and what do you think might be 
causing it?  Can I live with this and just change the
coolant frequently or am I heading for BIG trouble 
if it's not corrected soon?

(3)  The coolant expansion tank has a coolant level
sender that appears to be malfunctioning.  It has a
very high resistance (several Meg Ohm) when open and
closed, differing only by about 5K Ohm.  After all
the other $$$ I've put into the car, I'm too cheap
to buy a new one.  Any suggestions on how to fix
the darned thing?

(4)  Last and least of all, I think the motor mounts
may need replacing as I notice a vibration when 
the engine runs above 3500-4000 RPM.  Can a slightly
better than average home mechanic change them, is it
worthwhile, or is my car's vibration acceptable?

Thanks in advance for any and all information!!

BTW, There are two good sources for 928 parts here in
Southern California that I recommend:

928 International (800) 634-6117 (new and recycled)
Eurasian Parts Select (800) 824-8814 (new, inexpensive)

Date: Fri,  3 Feb 95 13:29:51 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; gas tester and Air/fuel monitors

>From: "Felix Klauser" <felix@lfs.loral.com>
>Subject: gastester

>I believe the two gastesters sold by JC Whitney are made by Gunson, the
>same company that makes the colour-tune and Eezi-bleed.  They're CO
>meters that you put by the tail pipe of your car to measure the CO. Thus
>they can't be used under load unless using a chassis dyno. And if you
>have access to a chassis dyno, you probably have access at the same time
>to something far more sophisticated to measure the CO.

>I'm in the process of getting and installing a lambda sensor and
>air/fuel ratio monitor to help me tune the twin Weber 40DCOE's on my
>non-Porsche.  RPM in Port Orange, FL (occasional Panorama advertiser)
>sells such a beast as does TWM Induction in Goleta, CA. My plan is to
>monitor the mixture under load and thereby help me find the right
>jetting for the current ambient temperature. I'll post again when I have
>some further news or experiences.

>Felix Klauser
>Loral ASIC
>Portsmouth, UK

   Felix, I don't suppose Edelbrock is a big name in England, but they
  also have an exhaust A/F monitor. Its a self-heated 3-wire oxygen
  sensor (can be mounted anywhere in the exhaust system) and reads out
  on an LED bar display from 12:1 to 15:1 in 1/2 steps. At $130, its
  a very reasonable price.
   MSD (makers of aftermarket ignition boxes) also have a similar unit,
  for $10 more it only has rich/lean LEDs and doesn't appear to be as
  good a value.
     I have the JC Whitney gas analyzer, at $125 it does really help
   when working on idle settings.

           Lee A.

Date: Fri,  3 Feb 95 13:00:15 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Bad motor mounts - what happens?

| From: Armagan Ozkaya  <ozkaya@seas.gwu.edu>
|
| I have a few concerns and would like your help.
|
| 1- I guess my 85.2 944 needs new motor mounts as I feel that the shaking
|    and rattles in steering wheel and hood are becoming more intense.
|    How soon should I have them replaced ?
|    Would they affect anything else in the car if I delay it ?

I am not sure it is good to have things rattling around, but then again
my motor mounts were shot when I bought my car and that did not
seem to cause any collateral damage.

|    Those of you who have them replaced, please write me the cost of it !

I bought the two mounts from Zim's for $126 apiece and put them in myself.
I wouldn't recommend this as your first do-it-yourself repair attempt, but
if you have some mechanical experience, then it is not too hard to do.
Most mechanics will charge 2-3 hours labor and list ($200) each for the
mounts. Figure about $600 for a mechanic to do it for you.

| 2- What is (if any) the most cost-effective way increasing the power
|    (HP) of the car, say 50-60 HP ?

Sell your car and buy an '86 944 turbo. Seriously, this would cost
you about $4000 and there is no way you could get 50-60 more HP
out of your car for that much money. You would either need to add a
turbo to your car or build a very radical engine to get that much HP.
Plus, the 944 turbo has bigger brakes and other reinforcing to handle
the extra HP.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 17:35:18 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: gear linkage rattle

Colin says, "My '87 924s has just developed a rather disturbing rattle in the
rear. It only happens at low revs and in second gear. It sounds like the gear
linkage is hitting the bodywork or something else. In all the other gears or
at speed, no rattle."

Colin, I would look first for a broken/missing doughnut hanger on your
muffler.  These things have a way of disappearing, and they allow the muffler
to touch part of the bodywork occasionally and at certain RPMs (apparently
depending upon vibration level).  Cheap and easy replacement, if that's the
problem.

Regards,

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 95 17:05:24 EST
From: sdandeka@chipcom.com (Shirish Dandekar)



Hello Porschephiles,
 I'm new to the group and would like some advise on purchasing a 911. I've 
reviewed the last three months archives and have read a few articles/books
highlighting the various yearly model changes. I have a few questions regarding 
maintenance, longevity, and cost. I've been focusing on 84 thru 89 model 
years. 

Realizing that the condition of any car will vary depending on how the
car was driven and how well it was maintained, here are my questions:  
 
 - What kind of mileage can I get out of a 3.2l engine before it requires 
  a rebuild? What is the cost of a rebuild? Does the engine usually need to 
  be totally rebuilt? What is the break down - part vs labor?
 
 - How many miles can I expect to get out of the clutch and what should I 
  expect to pay to have it replaced? What is the break down - parts vs labor?
 
 - Is the reliability of the G50 transmission that mush better than the 
  previous transmission (I noticed a few owners of pre 1987 cars requiring 
  transmission rebuilds)?
  
 - What are some of the other higher cost maintenance items I should be prepared
  to replace or rebuild?

 - I noticed that someone recommended the Motronic (post 83) as more reliable 
  than the CIS, is the LE-jet in the 88/89 as reliable?

 - In my area (Greater Boston) I've notice a few different price levels for 911.
     87's with ~100K miles are listed @ 19,000
     87's with ~60K mile are listed @ 23,000
     88/89's with ~60k are listed @ 26,000+
  Do these prices seem reasonable? If not what should I expect to pay?
  Will the 4K I save buying a high mileage car be quickly spent on a engine rebuild?

 - Does any one know any good sources for used P-cars?

 - What are some of the desirable options I should be looking for?

Thanks in advance.

	-RISH- 

<email:sdandeka@chipcom.com>

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 95 14:41:25 PST
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: More on Mini Coopers S's


Since this door has been opened (albeit slightly) . . . 
 
I had a friend in college who's (enlightend) family owned two of these little 
bombs.  In their day the Minis redefined the expression "cornering on rails." 
The Hydroplastic suspension was truly amazing! 
 
My friend's favorite trick was to do ~45-55 mph as he roared up on a car 
stopped for a light.  At the last minute he would use the parking lane to 
negotiate a right turn with nothing more than a quick downshift. 
 
We use to award imaginary points to the drivers of the stationary cars based 
on how long they watched the mini grow ever larger in the rear view mirror 
before turning around with a look of genuine horror as we snicked past with 
inches to spare! 
 
As I recall, the tyres never squelled during any of these exercises, and 
although we occasionally "took to the curbs" I don't believe that we ever bent 
a wheel. 
 
Michael Hodos 
1962 356B Super90 Cabriolet 
 
P.S. If you live in the San Francisco Bay Area you can see lots of Minis and   
     other interesting cars of this vintage by attenting the very informal     
     British Car Show in the park opposite Stanford Shopping Center. 
 
     The show, which I believe is held in late June, is free but not very well 
      publisized. 
 
     The plethora of disparaging Lucas signs almost makes it worth the while, 
     the cars not withstanding! 



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 11:58:12 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: Re: Info on 924 Turbo needed

Hello soon-to-be Porschephiliac.
	An '82 924 Turbo is a rather rare model, the last of the 924 
line.  If indeed it is in good condition, then that is a more than 
reasonable price.  I paid $3700 for my '77 non-turbo 924 but it was in 
excellent conditon in all aspects.  The key here is EXCELLENT condition.  
It is definitely not wise, especially with 924s, to "save" money on a 
poor condition car when nicer cars aren't that much more.  If it is in 
good mechanical condition (make sure the turbo works!!!), go for it, you 
won't regret it.  I've had my 924 for 5 years with minimal problems, and 
it will capture your heart like no other car.  I even commute in it daily 
it is so enjoyable.  If you buy it, tell us all about it and we'll do 
what we can to help.  It would be nice to have more 924/924T input on the 
list. Good Luck!

Jay Karolyi
'77 lima bean green 924 (that's all folks :^)

> Subject: grown noise when turn the stearing wheel during cold weather

My last car - a reliant scimitar used to make the same sort of noise, 
like opening an iron gate with rusty hinges.

So I suggest you check the fluid level.

> BTW, anybody off to the Le Mans - I got the bumpf eventually from them
about booking > etc and was interested to see that they classed the Maison
Blanche camping area > as a "LayBy" - something I would agree with
actually after seeing the crap facilities > the last two years! > > Only
one *campsite* (as opposed to 3 or 4 Lay-By's) was listed (Tribune?) - is
this > the one where the PCA/PCGB BBQ was last year?? Any comments on
which is the best > grandstand?? The ACO seems the best?? > > Kevin.
> 

There was a time not so long ago when I would have said "don't bother with
the stands, the best view are around the back" for example there is always
lots of action where the cars break for the esses as they pass maison
blanche, or my favorite - arnage.

However every time I go, they seem to have put up yet another new wall to
stop people viewing from the track side - I guess they want to force
people into the stands. 

maison blanche is in my estimation the best camp site - the facilities 
are bad on all of them - at least the ground is grassy and flat.

There is another next to garage blue that is quite reasonable, but it is 
15 minutes walk from the aco.

An important consideration is which has the best exit, I have never camped
inside the cct, but it must be murder getting out after the race. 

We usually camp in maison blanche then move the car to the top of the 
hill by the sports stadium. After the race finishes we do the 20 mins 
walk to the car then go....

Haven't been down for the last two years - the 82 race was rubbish 
puegot ran away with it, so we are looking forward to this year - lets hope 
there is a decent entry.

nearer the time we must set up a meeting spot.

Regards Pete

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 95 07:55:38 -0800
From: donr@deltanet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: Felines Perched on P Cars

Ed concluded his message

>Ed

>1988 944 Turbo S (For Sale)
>1986 911 Cab
>5 Felines (All love the new top)

Which reminded me that there was a long discussion some months ago on 
CompuServe which was started by somebody who couldn't keep the neighbors' 
cats off his new car. There were a lot of fine suggestions revolving around 
solutions like shotguns, plugging the car into a 120V outlet (or 240 if 
avail) etc.

Finally someone stated that cats hate mothballs. It so happens that we have 
4 cats here (emphatically, not my doing) who just love hanging around on my 
356 which is covered, and like best the hammock effect of the cover when the 
top is down, which it always is. Not only that, they seem to like doing the 
gross things that cats do on the cover the moment it has been cleaned. What 
retard said cats were clean?

I am happy to announce that the cats are now truly pi**ed at me and glower 
at me each time I encounter them. But they don't do it while lounging on the 
luxury of my car because I attached a few cannisters filled with mothballs 
and with holes punched in them to the cover. No cats. It works!

The shotgun/electric current type of solution is probably less work, but if 
for family reasons there is no open season on cats, the mothballs work great.

Don

'86 911 Carrera
'56 356 Speedster (with no GD cats on it)

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 20:04:19 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  928S Questions.....

This sounds silly, but are you really sure your 928 is running hot?
I notice that my temp gauge goes up significantly when the lights are
on - presumably due to voltage changes somewhere, which affect the
reading, not the actual temperature. The problem is figuring out how
to get a true temperature reading; surely the stuff in the overflow
tank is cool, but it seems to be the only place available to insert a 
thermometer.

As for the coolant level sensor - sounds like you have a choice of
shorting it out or replacing it - might as well go ahead and take
it apart to see what's what - maybe you'll find a cruddy contact.
Let the list know - if yours has failed, can mine be far behind?

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: Fri, 03 Feb 95 19:58:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: Re: timing belt intervals


>>Armagan writes;
>><- Does it matter how old the timing belt is (age, not the miles driven) 
 for
>>replacement ? The current one has about 26K miles, but about 4  years 
old.>

>The recommended interval is to keep a belt no longer than 3 years,
>independent of mileage.. After that you are subject to cracking and
>oxidation. My feeling is that you can't be too careful when evaluating 
timing
>belts. I once had a brand new one break on a 944S. It was less than 2500
>miles old and had been installed and re tensioned by a Porsche dealer. With
>minimal argument they did all necessary repairs, including reconditioning 
the
>head. (bent valves don't do the valve guides any good at all)
>Anyway replace it yesterday.

REPLACE IT NOW!!!
I can't agree with Jerry more. I had mine break on my 944S twice (due to 
dealer neglect). Along with replacing all of the valves and valve guides, 
the head cracked later and needed to be replaced. ($3,500 for the head 
alone) Thank the Porsche god for warranties.
REPLACE IT NOW!!!

Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@Pepsi.com
1988 944S

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 95 17:10:43 -0800
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re:  928S Questions.....

In response to the following:

>Return-Path: <porschephiles-request@tta.com>
>Date: 3 Feb 1995 12:26:05 U
>From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
>Subject: 928S Questions.....
>To: "Porsche 928 folk..." <porschephiles@tta.com>
>
>                                                                    12:16 PM
>  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
>                      Subject:
>                      928S Questions.....                           2/3/95
>                                                              Date:
>
>
>I'm a newcomer to this forum and a relatively new Porsche owner.  I have
>spent about a year fixing up a
> 1984 928S.
.....
>(1)  My engine is running slightly hotter than I
>would like it to.
.....
>(2)  When I changed the coolant after 9 months of
>use, it came out very dark (nearly dark gray) due
>to (I think) an oil leak into the coolant.
.....
>(4)  Last and least of all, I think the motor mounts
>may need replacing as I notice a vibration when 
>the engine runs above 3500-4000 RPM.

- --------------------------------------------------------------------
The reason why I am replying to these items is that I had similar
problems with my 928.  The temperature was always a little high,
especially on a summer day.  I did not have oil in my coolant, but
I had a very slow coolant and oil "seep" from one head gasket.
The price of fixing these "minor irritations" was so high that I
decided to live with it for a while.  Bad mistake.  My engine
overheated instantly one day, the heads warped badly, a pulley on the
front of the engine seized, and I got to ride in a tow truck (again).
I now own a new engine.  Take my advise, if there is any indication
of a blown head gasket, get it fixed.  And do your valves, while
you have it apart.

The engine vibration sounds similar to what I used to experience
at precisely 3100 to 3300 RPM, in any gear, but only when
accelerating.  The problem went away when I got my new engine.
I never asked my mechanic, but perhaps he put in new mounts, or
maybe the new engine sits a little differently.

By the way:  John Lucas, it sounds like you might live in Southern
California.  I, too, shop at 928 International (I think I am their
best customer).  If you indeed live around here, and you want to
get together to commiserate some time, send me Email.


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 03 Feb 95 11:06:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: gear linkage rattle


Colin,

>My '87 924s has just developed a rather disturbing rattle in the rear.
>It only happens at low revs and in second gear.

I have noticed the same thing intermittently on a number of 944-series
cars, typically when the car is fully warmed up and cruising at low
RPM.  Sounds kind of like a chain being dragged across a grate.  It
seems to be normal and I wouldn't worry about it.  I forget the exact
cause.

Kevin Gross

Date: Fri, 03 Feb 95 11:25:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: New magazine


Thought some of you might be interested.  There is a new magazine from
the UK, Race Tech, edited by Ian Bamsey.  The first issue has justed
arrived in the US and it is interesting reading.  Content is quite similar 
to
that of Racecar Engineering: a mix of F1, tech, and enthusiast/club level
articles.  You cannot judge a magazine by a single issue, though, and
I am sure that Race Tech will evolve its editorial personality in future
issues.

Available from EWA in the US: 908 665 7811.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 17:25:48 -0800
From: pouceta@itersd1.iterus.org (Andre Poucet)

As a  newcomer to this list, I have been "listening" for about a week and
now overcome my stage fright.
In Europe, I have a  '73 Euro  911 T coupe, no sunroof, with the S package
(ventilated brakes, spoiler, ...)  in pretty good and original condition
until... last year I broke a timing chain.

I took out the engine and took it apart and was very lucky there was not
very much damage (no valves broken etc.) .

At that time I saw a '73 2.7  RS engine for sale  (the REAL one, type 083
with MFI and everything).
I decided to put that in the car, bought  a new fuel pump (my T engine has
Zenith carburettors and the MFI fuel pump is different), serpentine oil
cooler and installed it. The car drives like a blast but would need
stronger (S type) front brakes.

I feel tempted to convert the car to a full RS replica but before starting
to cut the (very nice) bodywork to install flares etc. I would like to hear
some opinions about:
*       is it a good idea and how much is involved?
*       is it better to bring the car back to original condition (remember I
        still have the T engine and it doesn't need a lot of parts)?
*       would it make sense and is it possible to convert it to a 2.4 S using my
        T engine crankcase, new pistons and cyls. and the MFI, cams, crankshaft,
        rods from the RS engine?
I know it sounds stupid to cannibalize an RS engine, but the 2.4S is highly
valued in Europe.

Note that the car is not driven in the US so I don't care about DOT/EPA etc.
Whatever bits and pieces I would need, I would buy here (i.e. US): this is
a great places for Porschefiles! Lots of stuff around and mucho less
expensive.

Andre Poucet
'73 911 T (in Europe)
'75 911 S targa (in US)
'68 Alfa GTV (in Europe)
'62 Alfa Guilietta spider (in US)
