Date: Fri, 03 Feb 95 11:13:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: door lock sticks on 944S2 Cab...


Carlin,

A little unclear from your description as to the exact problem.  I would
assume that, as a rule, one generally opens a passenger-side door
from the passenger side.

Try the following.  There is a large-headed philips screw in the trailing
edge of the door, which partially retains the door handle mechanism.
If you remove the screw, you can pull the handle out a bit and lubricate
the mechanism.  Use an aerosol lubricant which dries and stays, such
as Wurth HHS 2000, Castle Thrust, or a white lith grease.

Also lubricate the latch mechanism on door trailing side.

Hope this helps.

Kevin

Date: 03 Feb 1995 10:30:51 -0500
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: Re: Are my 911 heater vents working?

>I have a 1986 911 Cab.  I think that I am supposed to be able to direct the
>air flow from the dash controls through the vents by sliding the upper left
>lever to the left.

>It comes out of the defrost vents and the floor fine, but nothing when I try
>to get it to come out the dash vents. 

>Is this abnormal and what are any suggestions on the problem and/or the fix.

If I remember correctly, the dash vents in the center only deliver cold air -
A/C 
and fresh air.  The side ones may deliver heat but I'm not sure.
I know its in the manual because I thought it was strange so I looked
it up (this fall).

------------------------------

Date: 3 Feb 1995 08:16:51 -0800
From: "Bill White" <Bill.White.LDIV@quickmail.llnl.gov>
Subject: Re-Are my 911 heater vents 

>I have a 1986 911 Cab.  I think that I am supposed to be able to direct the
>air flow from the dash controls through the vents by sliding the upper left
>lever to the left.

Ed,
If your 86 is the same as my  87 (I think the routing is the same even if the
vents are a different size), the only dash slider that effects the heat is the
lower one (red on my car) and it sends heat to the defroster vents when moved
to the right and the floor when moved to the left, both if positioned in the
middle. Heat never comes out of my middle dash vents although a small amount
comes out of the outer dash vents when the red slider is positioned for
defrost (this is from memory so that may be floor instead). The top two
sliders adjust fresh air and fan speed. The middle slider routes fresh air
either up to defrost vents (right) or down to the floor (left), as the red
slider does for the hot air.

Either yours is working properly or both of ours are screwed up. However, I
believe that mine is working the way my owners manual describes.

Bill White
1987 911

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 03 Feb 95 10:04:17 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: Mini Coopers and Roundabouts (i.e. Rotaries)


Text item: Text_1

Ahhhh! Nostalgia.......

FYI there were a number of Mini Variants, the basic Mini, a Mini Cooper and the 
Mini Cooper S. The S eventually came in 998 c.c. 1100 c.c. and 1250 c.c. 
versions, I had an 1100 for a year. If I remember correctly the primary mod for 
the Cooper was a hot cam and twin SUs(more nostalgia!), may be it was bored out 
a bit too. The Cooper S was more extensively modified and had a nitrided crank 
and other goodies added. Apparently for a real Rod you replaced the S cam with a
cooking Cooper cam. Engine work was a snip, you could wheel the body away from 
the engine/sub frame in 15 min. I still have the workshop manual.
The reason I sold it was becauseI was into one of the recently discussed 
roundabouts with a great deal of enthusiasm when I decided I wasn't going to 
make it, and being MG A trained and rear wheel drive conditioned I put the boot 
in some more. Well you know the rest, except that the kerb stones were near as 
high as those 10 in wheels. It didn't roll but when I got home I went searching 
for a rear wheel drive. Got a Cortina GT (couldn't afford the Lotus Cortina) 
this beastie cornered on three wheels but that's another story.


------------------------------

Date: 3 Feb 1995 17:27:59 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re:  928S Questions.....

 Reply to:     RE>> 928S Questions.....

Thanks for the quick reply.

Regarding...
>>... but are you really sure your 928 is running hot?
>>I notice that my temp gauge goes up significantly when the lights are
>>on - presumably due to voltage changes somewhere, which affect the
>>reading, not the actual temperature.

So it's not just my car after all!  I have noticed the temp guage jumping
up when I turn the lights on.  However, during the day (no lites) the
needle is above the middle mark when I drive and approaches the 
"hot" top area when I'm in stop and go traffic.  If and when the electric
fan kicks in, the temp drops quickly.

>>As for the coolant level sensor - sounds like you have a choice of
>>shorting it out or replacing it - might as well go ahead and take
>>it apart to see what's what - maybe you'll find a cruddy contact.
>>Let the list know - if yours has failed, can mine be far behind?

The coolant expansion tank is under pressure and I can't take the 
sender apart because if I can't get it back together (it's glued or
press fit plastic) I can't operate the car!

Date: 03 Feb 95 12:09:29 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Bay area 356 mechanic

Volney Spaulding asked about Porsche mechanics in the Bay Area.
 
If others are going to toot their own horn, I'll toot somebody else's.
 
For my money, the absolute best 356 mechanic anywhere is Clark Anderson in
San Jose. You owe it to yourself to talk to him. This won't take as long as
with others in the Bay Area because you don't have to wait for the ego display
to end. And he doesn't charge gold-chainer prices (for gold-plated motors?)
Clark used to be one of the principals at the late lamented Garretson shop,
is the 912 guy on the PCA technical committee (see back of Pano), and is the
brother of the more famous Bruce Anderson but doesn't hold that against him.
Clark has been doing 356s for more than 25 years, and more recently 911/912/
934/935s, including the Garretson cars that went to places like Daytona back
when Porsches were welcome there. He's not known to the general 356 public
because he doesn't have time/ego/writing inclination to attempt a vanity press
effort. He is known and respected by the top people in the 356 hobby.
 
Give him a call at 408-266-3191 and say I sent you.
 
This has been a non-paid, non-political announcement. Bruce has promised not
to revoke my carburetors if I wrote this. <g>
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 08:59:29 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re: gastester

The problem with the garden variety Lambda sensor is the range.  If I remember
the range is limited to about 14.0:1 to 15.0:1.  The original intent of using
these sensors was as switchpoint at the "ideal" A/F ratio of 14.7:1.  They are
not suited to use an analog, linear transducer.  There may be later versions 
that have a wider range, but are probably very expensive

Dan

DSWIGER@QNTM.COM
DSWIGER180@AOL.COM

I believe the two gastesters sold by JC Whitney are made by Gunson, the
same company that makes the colour-tune and Eezi-bleed.  They're CO
meters that you put by the tail pipe of your car to measure the CO. Thus
they can't be used under load unless using a chassis dyno. And if you
have access to a chassis dyno, you probably have access at the same time
to something far more sophisticated to measure the CO.

I'm in the process of getting and installing a lambda sensor and
air/fuel ratio monitor to help me tune the twin Weber 40DCOE's on my
non-Porsche.  RPM in Port Orange, FL (occasional Panorama advertiser)
sells such a beast as does TWM Induction in Goleta, CA. My plan is to
monitor the mixture under load and thereby help me find the right
jetting for the current ambient temperature. I'll post again when I have
some further news or experiences.

Felix Klauser
Loral ASIC
Portsmouth, UK

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 09:34:34 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Oil Pressure problem 911SC

The following is a post for a collegue who has an '82 911SC.  If anyone has
some advise, please send a response to him directly (I'll be out of town for
a while "Trondheim, Norway" Brrrrrr):

B_Eisenhart@lfhs2.hso.link.com

This problem is in regard to a 1982, 911, SC

I pulled into a parking space at work and rolled up the drivers side window 
(I have power windows so the engine was still running) I heard a loud noise.  
I thought that the window had broken, I rolled it down and then back up and 
it worked OK.  I wasn't sure where the sound came from, the window or the 
engine compartment and I am not sure if the noise has any bearing on the 
problem.

When I started the car to go home I noticed that the oil pressure light was 
on.  I immediately turned off the engine.  I then restarted the car to check 
the oil pressure gauge, thinking that it may just be a light sensor failure.  
This time the oil light remained off and the pressure gauge did indicate 
sufficient oil pressure.  When driving home (approx. 2 miles) I noticed that 
the oil pressure gauge was registering higher than normal oil pressure 
(approx. 5 bar. at about 3000 RPMs and approximately 2.5 bar. at idle 
speed).  Approximately one block from home the oil pressure light came on, at 
the same time the oil pressure gauge was indicating sufficient oil pressure.  
I Immediately shut the engine off and coasted home.  I later pulled the car 
into the garage.  For this short period of time the oil pressure light stayed 
off and the gauge indicated sufficient pressure.  I checked the oil level and 
it was OK.

The next day I noticed that oil was leaking from the oil return tubes, I 
suspect that the oil level in the sump is higher than normal when the engine 
is not running.

I checked the oil pressure regulator valve and it was OK but haven't checked 
the pressure relief valve since it requires the removal of the exhaust 
manifold. 

I would appreciate any ideas where I might begin to look for the problem and 
what to do to fix it.  

Please respond to: B_Eisenhart@lfhs2.hso.link.com

Thanks.

Date: Fri, 03 Feb 95 11:17:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Bad motor mounts - what happens?


Armagan,

>1- I guess my 85.2 944 needs new motor mounts as I feel that the shaking
>   and rattles in steering wheel and hood are becoming more intense.
>   How soon should I have them replaced ?
>   Would they affect anything else in the car if I delay it ?

There is risk that the vibration may break or unseal the oil pick-up in
the sump.  Get the mounts fixed right away.  If you suck air, you have a
big problem.

>2- What is (if any) the most cost-effective way increasing the power
>   (HP) of the car, say 50-60 HP ?

Sell it and buy a 944 Turbo.  Really.

>3- Does it matter how old the timing belt is (age, not the miles driven)
>   for replacement ? The current one has about 26K miles, but about 4
>   years old.

Agree with Jerry, three years is about as long as you want to carry
a belt.  I personally like to replace them at about 25K miles.  Cheap
insurance.

Kevin Gross

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 22:39:05 -0600

>My 944 has a bad grown sound when I first start the car in cold weather.
>It sort of sounds like a belt slipping.  Any ideas?

Yea, mine does the same thing. Power steering pump. I have been told that
in cold weather the seals shrink enough to let air into the system, and the
groaning it the power steering fluid cavetating (sp?) in the pump. I have
no idea if this causes damage. I try to situate my car so that when I start
it in the morning I don't have to do any low speed turning as my problem
only occurs when the power steering is really working (ie. - at low
speeds). As soon as the car warms up a little it goes away.

Does anyone know if this problem causes damage to the power steering system ???

Date: Fri, 3 Feb 1995 23:41:47 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject:  Re: Info on 924 Turbo needed.

$2800 sounds like quite a bargain for a 1982 924 Turbo - check it out
carefully before you buy.  One of the consequences of the (inexplicably) low
resale value of the 924 seems to be that many owners bought them cheaply and
(as a result?) seem to abuse them - only to sell them cheaply when they start
giving problems.  This is a shame because they really are fantastic cars.
 When we were shopping for my brothers 924, we must have seen dozens of cars
 - until we found that 'mythical'  one-responsible-mature-owner car (with
receipts even).  
Anyway - take your time and you will find a good one!
I have a 1980 Turbo (the '82 is significantly better though...) and a 1977
924.
I have had few problems although I'd check for cracked manifolds, oil leaks
(in the myriad oil pipes!), smoking exhaust when the car is at idle and also
when accelerating hard.    
Maybe more importantly is just getting a sense of the car.  Is the
engine/engine compartment clean (can you even see the oil pump and the oil
pan?)?  Does everything work?  

Porsche really radically changed the 924 Turbo in 1981.  Smaller Turbo (yes,
that a GOOD thing!), DITC ignition, higher compression ratio, different
transaxle, changed exhaust manifold (the 1980 leaks a bit...), turbo oil
return 'de-aerator' etc.  The 1982 Turbo also has improved AC/ventilation
system (hence making 'your' car quite a bit more desirable).
The M-471 option package includes 16" wheels, large 928 brakes and stiffer
springs/shocks and anti roll bars - very desirable!.

I hope this car turns out to be good - we need more 924 fans on this list.

Cheers:
MIKE
1977 924
1980 924 Turbo (aka 931)            

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 02 Feb 1995 15:11:35 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Regarding All Stereo Threads

OK, for the record:

Incase someone didn't notice judging from the recent volume of stereo 
messages, I am new to this list (or any list for that matter).    I have 
slowly been acumulating as much Porsche literature as possible as I eagerly 
anticipate the day that I will own my own shiny Porsche.  You can surely 
understand my excitement in discovering a list for Pfiles only.  It was my 
intention to quietly join the list and gather as much P-car info as possible 
before the long awaited purchase.  After lurking for a while, I attempted to 
offer my knowledge/advice in reference to a car stereo thread.  I have been 
an audiophile for a number of years, and fully intend to acquire the *right* 
to call myself a Porschephile as well.  I have considerable experience in 
the car audio field, and felt that I could offer my knowledge to such a 
thread.  This topic, however, expanded quickly, and I tried to keep up.  I 
in no way want this list to resemble "stereophiles and a few porschephiles 
on the side@tta.com".  I joined the list *specifically* to augment my own 
*Porsche* knowledge.  

I realize that this is demanding considerable bandwidth at present.  I will 
agree that this topic is not directly P-car related, and differs from the 
usual  threads on the list. I do believe, however, that the topic of 
stereo's is indirectly related to most road going Porsche's, otherwise 
Porsche's wouldn't come with factory stereos at all.  The shear volume 
regarding this topic lately will attest to that fact.  It is obviously a 
topic important to a number of sbscribers, and I feel that, aside of race 
cars/auto-x'ers, a good stereo can only make driving in a *great* car more 
enjoyable.  I am truly a fan of both worlds, so why not mix the best of 
both?  To eliminate the problem of excessive bandwidth, I definitely agree 
with others' advice to take this discussion to private e-mail.  I have 
un-thinkingly posted some privately sent threads to the entire list, and for 
that I sincerely apologize.  It will not happen again.  I will continue to 
offer my advice to those who desire it, but I will only post it to the list 
if I feel it is relevant to others, and the sender approves.  It may help to 
include in your note if you wish me to post to the list or individually.

It is my goal for *me* to gain some valueable Porsche information by 
participating in this list.  I hope that Porschephiles and audiophiles can 
get along, and benefit as a whole from each others' knowledge.  

Sincere Thanks for your understanding,
Andy
944 (*real* soon!)

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 00:50:20 -0700
From: sas@indirect.com (Steve Sapareto)
Subject: Re: Q: antenna and helping Stan

Tony wrote: 
>> This is my first question here, sorry
>> if it's not suitable.
>> 
>> Power antenna of 84 944 does not work.
>> Need help.
>> 
>> Any suggestion is welcome.  
>> Thanks in advance.
>> 
>> Tony
>> UCSD

And George responded:

>Buy new one.
>
>You're welcome.
>
Shame on you George for flaming someone who is obviously a young struggling 
student trying to keep his first Porsche from eating his lunch money!  
Besides maybe he is a tinkerer who enjoys little DIY projects.  And you 
would deprive him of the joy of it...

The Hirschman automatic antenna costs about $130-250, depending on where you 
look so it certainly wouldn't hurt to try to fix it. When mine failed in my 
'84, I took it apart and was able to repair it (don't remember all of the 
details though - it was a broken antenna).  Tony, you didn't say what the 
symptoms are.  If the unit makes noise when you turn the radio on or off 
then you may just have a broken or binding antenna.  These are replaceable 
for about $35 from the mail order places.  There are two antenna types, one 
which has a toothed plastic cable that winds up inside the unit to 
extend/retract it and one that is smooth but may show slight toothlike 
indentations from the drive mechanism. Check which one you have before you 
order.  The replacements come with instructions for installation (pretty 
easy job).

If there is no sound from the motor in the unit, check the connection to the 
radio to see if it is bad (it goes between 0 and 12V to raise and lower).  
The unit itself is in the drivers side wheel well and can be removed pretty 
easily after removing the right front wheel.  The unit can be opened and the 
mechanism is pretty straightforward, a motor, electronics (relay) and a 
takeup spool.  If you can't find any broken wires or figure out how to 
repair it, at least you have done half of the job of replacing it


BTW, since Stan seems to be shy and many of you don't realize it, his 
address is included in the Welcome message.  At the risk of embarassing him, 
I include it here:

Stanley P. Hanks    Principal,    OMNInet Communications
P.O. Box 2087     Bellaire TX  77402-2087
e-mail: stan@tta.com     voice: (713) 661-2084

**************
Steve Sapareto <sas@samaritan.edu>
'85 944 White (with a new little ding - dammit)

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 10:20:09 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re: spinning 911s/rear sway bars

>If you're experiencing "push" then loosen the front bar OR tighten the rear
>bar...Do just the opposite for oversteer.

OK, another question along this line - my car understeers pretty badly in
the slow corners but is delightfully neutral in the fast ones.  I have 
20mm/18mm F/R sway bars (stock on my car was 16mm front - no rear) and 24.1mm
torsion bars in the rear (in lieu of the 23mm stock ones).  I think
part of my problem may be the 185/70 tires in the front on 6 inch wheels/
205/60 in the rear on 7s (try not to laugh - the tire sizes are a result of
the previous owner).  I plan on replacing the fronts with 195/60s and staying
with 205/60s in the rear.  I think this should mitigate my understeering
condition.  What's the consensus?  Maybe I should play with tire pressures
a little?

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911 

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 10:26:26 -0500
From: PKitchak@aol.com
Subject: Re: spinning 911s/rear sway bars

One more note in that respect.
When Russell Racing is teaching driving at the limit, that put you in a formul
a ford and disconnect the front sway bar in order to induce the car to
oversteer. That might bew a convenient way to remember. On the topic, Bruce
Anderson also says:
"On a late model 911 (74 through current) that is being modified for
competition use, I recommend that the stardard front sway bar be replaced
with early 911 (through-the-body) style bar with connecting crop links. This
change is necessary because of the more precise control with the drop link
style sway bar, plus the advantage of a wide  selection of replacement bars
available for this style of bar as opposed to almost none for the later style
street bars.



------------------------------

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 10:32:49 -0500
From: PKitchak@aol.com
Subject: Re: spinning 911s/rear sway bars

A final thought

Scott Winders writes:

 "For example, on my '78 911, I adjust my rear sway bar to full soft
for everyday driving. This makes my car handle fairly neutral for
a 911. When I go to an autocross, I set my rear sway bar to full stiff.
This gives me an oversteering beast that does not push in the corners."

But be careful,..... that works at an autoX, but on a fast race track at a
major event, it might be...well embarassing. If you don't have a C4, we find
that reducing oversteer helps at fast tracks, where getting through the high
speed kinks is more important than getting into the slow corners quickly.

Peter Kitchak

------------------------------

Date: 04 Feb 95 12:33:37 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Andre's 911 T/S/RS

 
Hi, Andre.
 
If you have a complete RS engine including the injection pump (I think the
last three digits on the Bosch part number are 019 for a real RS pump), I
would not hesitate to turn it into an RS replica. OK, so it's not a genuine
RS, but you can make it behave pretty much like a real RS. I would not do
this as an investment, I would do it to enjoy the car. I figure a 911 T is
the bottom of the ladder, with only 130 hp, you can only go up from there.
For readers who don't know, the T had 130 hp, the E 165, the S 190, and the
RS 210. That's going to make a BIG performance difference.
 
Second choice of course would be a 2.4 S, again you won't be fooling any
knowledgeable buyers into thinking it's a real S, but you will have an
enjoyable car at much lower expense than the RS. But then, you have the RS
engine, what are you going to do with it? If you sell it, you'll only be
sorry later. I would use it.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 04 Feb 95 12:33:34 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Gear linkage rattle

 
I assume everybody means something other than the below-2000 rpm rattle that
is typical of 915 transmissions (911) and whatever type is in the 944?
That's normal and you can't do anything about it. That's why they kept
struggling with rubber vibration dampers (which exploded), went back to
spring dampers, went to other rubber dampers, went to dual-mass flywheels,
etc. It's engine torsional vibration setting up rattles in the trans input
and various other bits. If what you have is NOT this typical rattle, I don't
know.
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 04 Feb 95 13:31:10 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Porsche @ Daytona

>   Can anyone explain why Porsche Motorsports withdrew their
> two car entry scheduled for Andretti and Foyt to partner?
> Read something about a last minute IMSA rules change...?
> Curious!!! 
> As a 23 year owner of 911s and follower of Porsche racing history, I continue

> to be baffled at their "play by our rules"
> attitude. I realize the TWR WSC spyders are not legal for IMSA
> but the latter's formula for equalization is sound and it has been known for
> ages that they will not allow turbos....
> What did IMSA do now to make them "take their toys and go home"? 

By your question, you show that you are new to Porschephiles.

This subject was discussed at length two weeks ago, when IMSA decided that
Porsche was sandbagging and imposed airflow restrictions and added weight to
the Porsche entries.

Porsche withdrew, stating that the adjustments to the rules would add four
seconds to each lap.

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 10:43:02 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Parade Registration

Barney -

I think you meant any postmark before the 6th would be returned.  Any
postmark after that date is fine, but you may be on the waiting list.  And
definitely get a receipt of mailing from the post office.  Have heard that
people have had to show that they mailed their application in on time when
they were told their postmark was late and were put on the waiting list. 

> Don't forget to send in your PCA Parade registration on Monday February 6th.
> 
> It *must* be postmarked on Feb. 6, 1995. Any other postmark and it will be
> sent back. Metered mail is *not* acceptable, so take it to the Post Office
> and have it "hand cancelled".

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 13:42:21 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Galvinized Porsches ...again

A fellow out of the Chicago area - Bob White, can probably help settle this
arguement.  I remember Bob telling me that while he was working in Weissach,
under DOT contract, he was given a bare metal, galvanized P-car to drive -
for about 6 months, as I recall.  This was during the mid '70's (around '77,
I believe).  As I recall, this was a coupe, not Targa - so there must be more
than one of these beasts around.

I further recall reading that partial galvalizing began with the 1976 models,
though it may have only been with specific lower body componenets.  I've not
heard of any earlier cars being tested,  though who the heck am I.  

Pat Garvey
stuff

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 04 Feb 1995 13:43:45 -0500 (EST)
From: "James L. Fry" <JFRY@UOFT02.UTOLEDO.EDU>
Subject: 924 Turbo

As someone else has just posted, the 1982 924T (aka 931) was the last of
the breed offered in the USA.  I think they were sold for another year in
Italy.  Although the pre-1981 931s may have gotten bad reviews for 
reliability, etc., my '82 931 was (and still is) a delightful car to drive.
It has all of the running gear of the early 944s and will outrun most of
them (no flames, please!).  It is a high maintenance vehicle, requiring
constant attention to the tightness of the turbo assembly bolts, etc.
You can also expect to rebuild the turbo every 20-30K miles because it 
does not have the water-cooled bearings of the 951.  I sold my 931 to a
friend (that's how much faith I had in the car!) last year for $6K.  It was
in perfect shape with no known defect, new everything, including paint.
Why did I sell it?  I could not resist the allure of the Indischrot 928S!
Neither could I justify having two German metal dollar magnets at the same
time.
If you buy the 924T, you will enjoy it, but it will not be inexpensive.
Best regards.
Jim Fry
'86 928S

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 10:43:23 -0800 (PST)
From: Steve Luntz <sluntz@acorn.ousd.k12.ca.us>
Subject: Re: Info on 924 Turbo needed

Jay writes:

>I've had my 924 for 5 years with minimal problems, and it will capture 
your heart like no other car.

  I had my 924 for 1 year with maximal problems, and it still captured my 
heart.  It was a 1980 in ratty shape (not-so-innocent purchase 
misjudgement).  It was loud (ratty hood insulation), muscular to steer, 
and stiffly sprung.  You had to work it hard to keep up with sporting 
traffic.  The short commute up to work was an adventure in sound and fury.
  My mechanic finally said it would be cheaper just to get a 944, so I 
did.  Now I listen to the CD on the way to work and try to spot other 
P-Cars coming downhill.  But I miss it.

Steve Luntz
'86 944

x-country skiing!  It's the national pastime. . .

beautiful people I've met in all my travels. . .

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 14:25:24 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Rolex 24

John A. Wise says, "I must admit to the occasional Walter Mitty daydream of
being asked to run across the street and get my 911 to help out one of the
teams.  So you see I do have to be there, just in case..."

John, once, back in the '70s at Road Atlanta, this happened to me.  I was a
spectator at a F5000 race, standing by the fence just upstream of the bridge
 - a notorius spot for crashes as it called for heavy braking at the downhill
end of a VERY fast straight - when David Hobbs sailed into view.  He traveled
the last 200 yards down the hill sideways, accompanied by huge clouds of
red-clay dust and minor body parts, and ended up against the bank just below
me.  When the tow-truck arrived, there was a great commotion among Hobbs and
the crew, and he turned to the fence and asked, "Anyone have any tools?"  My
356SC was parked just behind me, so I turned, got the Porsche tool kit from
under the hood and handed it over to Hobbs.  He used it to remove enough
body-work that the tow truck could hook up to the car, then carefully
returned the tools to the kit and handed it back to me.  Those were the days
when racing was more informal than it is today.  You could wander around the
paddock area, poke among the cars, and talk to the drivers.  It's nice to
remember folks like Hobbs, Peter Gregg, Donohue, Ongais....or, to go back
even farther, Juan Manuel Fangio and Stirling Moss!  God, I sound like an
old-timer!

Regards,

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper    

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 14:25:28 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Re: Q: power antenna

Eric says,

"Is it an all or nothing situation? They work or you replace
them?  Good thing mine still works (sort of, 3 of the 4 sections
extend)."

Like all machinery, power antennas need occasional maintenance.  Periodically
(every time you wash the car, for example) extend it fully and thoroughly
clean the grime off with something like WD40 and you will ensure that it
operates for many, many years.

When they get gunked up so badly that the motor can't overcome the friction,
they die.  On a dead one, pull all the sections out by hand and clean them.
 Try the switch.  If it still doesn't work, do as George suggests and buy a
new one. 

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

> AFFORDABLE RACE MANAGEMENT SOFTWARE FOR RACERS BY A RACER.

> WinLAPS is currently being used by NASCAR, IMSA, USAC, SCCA, and PCA
> competitors.  WinLAPS software is being used in Canada, Australia,
> and Great Britian by both professional and amateur race teams.
> What Does WinLAPS Give You?
> The WinLAPS lap timing program will allow the 
> user to time up to eight race vehicles simultaneously.  
> The program may be operated using either the keyboard 
> and/or the mouse.  The following race conditions are 
> managed:
>      . Special Race Condition Settings (Caution/Green Flag Racing)
>      . Graph Laps in Lotus123 
>      . Interval timing between any cars
>      . Single button reset of all dynamic conditions.
>      . Refuel Individual Cars
>      . Pit Stops for Individual Cars
>      . View/Print Laps for Cars
>      . Context Help
>      . Graph Lap times
>      . Save/Print Lap Times
>      . Instantaneous recall of all lap times in dropdown lists
>  
> WinLAPS will provide the user with a history of each car's lap times,
> the number of laps remaining with the current fuel load under both 
> race and caution conditions, and the average speed of the last timed lap.
> What Does WinTIMER Give You?
> The WinTIMER timing program will allow the user to time as many as
> 50 vehicles simultaneously.  Primarily intended for practice/qualifying,
> it allows you to time many cars easily.  It has a mode for timing laps
> containing as many as 5 segments.
>      . Segment timing (single car)
>      . Practice time up to 50 cars  
>      . Sort options: all cars by time, specific car by time, specific
>        car by lap and time or all cars by car number and time.
>      . Context Help
>      . Indicate "sticker" tiresGraph Lap times
>      . Save/Print Lap Times
>      . Instantaneous recall of all lap times in dropdown lists
> What Does WinGEARS Give You?
> The WinGEARS  program will allow the user to optimize the selection of
> gearing for specific tracks.  This is a gear calculator that will show
> you the speed at any rpm simply by sliding the Engine RPM slide bar.
> There is also a handy performance calculator.  Primarily intended for
> maintaining gear inventories and allowing for gear selection by visually
> presenting the performance characteristics of the selected gear set.
>      . Maintain Gear Inventories
>      . Perform performance runs on selected gear set
>      . Print performance statistics
>      . Context Help
>      . Save/Print Gear Inventories
>      . Use the performance calculator to calculate lateral acceleration,
>        compression ratio, displacement, etc.
>

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 17:23:54 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: handling questions/alignment

Mike,
I am no 911 expert but I do have experience on a basically understeering car,
a 951/S. This car with stock suspension is set up to understeer and
understeer it does. However with no other changes I can completely change the
handling characteristics by re aligning the car with a "track alignment". 
The point being that handling is a function of a myriad of variables so
consider all the variables when making changes. For example a little toe out
on my car will turn it into a ill handling SOB on the highway and a car with
great turn in and a bit of oversteer on the track.
Hope I didn't confuse you still further

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
5:07 pm

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 95 18:11:48 -0500
From: kyger@expert.cc.purdue.edu (Les Kyger)
Subject: sway bars

Kevin wrote:

>The first-order thing is weight transfer.  The stiffer end (ie, stiffer bar)
>transfers less weight from the inside tire and to the outside tire. 
          ^^^^^^^^^^^
>So, because of this non-linearity, when weight is transferred, the outside
>tire can do less marginal "work."  And that is why the stiffer end, with
>comparatively more weight tranfer, will have a larger slip angle.
              ^^^^^^^^^^^
>Kevin Gross

I've been following this thread with considerable interest.  Suspension
has always been my "thing", but I have quite a lot yet to learn about it.
So it is with humble confusion that I ask, what am I misunderstanding here?

- --Les

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 19:16:31 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: More on 924s, Don't get BMW!!!

Hello Naresh,
	The reason 924's are said to be so expensive to maintain is 
because of their reputation of having many VW parts.  People are shocked 
that their car mostly consists of Porsche only parts.  I can usally find 
deals on parts, and they really aren't THAT expensive.  OK, for 
specifics.  I have spent about $1200 in five years for my '77 924 during 
which time I have gone from 73K miles to 120K.  This was mostly for 
routine things like shocks, brakes, tires, etc.  My only problems have 
been water pump, $45, and head gasket failure, $50 and two Sundays work 
(or about $200 in mechanics time).  I regularly drive it 15 hours round 
trip to see relatives, and it has NEVER left me stranded.  If you're 
thinking BMW, compare prices for maintenance and repair.  My freind has a 
325e and just rebuilt his engine to the tune of $2100.  By the way, if 
you must get a Bimmer, get an 325i, not a 325e.  Even after the rebuild, 
I can keep up with him, and its a six! (e's are slow).
	About the Turbo.  Take it on a highway and take it up to speed 
in third and you'll FEEL the boost around 3500 RPM if its working.  A 
soft whine is OK, but if its really loud, its probably about to quit.

Good Luck!
I&b{WI45yWM+~ ~?~?~?~?~?~?

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 20:45:34 -0500
From: PORSCHEMF@aol.com
Subject: Fwd: door lock sticks on 944S...

I had a similar problem on a Audi 5000 Turbo. The problem got worst as time
went on and I had to replace the entire handle and trigger mechanism to make
the repair complete. I suppose I could have done the repair myself but when
the mechanism failed I couldn't even open the door! It may be a good idea to
take a look at it now while you still have the use of a functional door.

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 95 19:53:20 -0800
From: donr@deltanet.com (Don Rutherford)
Subject: radar/lser detectors

The consensus clearly favors the Valentine V1 as the best detector. After 
watching a lot of discussion, people who have tested them, and commentary on 
the illegality of radar jamming through the transmission of anything at the 
radar, it is easy to be quite certain that radar jammers are pure baloney.

Yes, the opinions are pretty strong <g>

Don

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 00:38:29 -0800 (PST)
From: Manuel Pardo <mpardo@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
Subject: a used 911 checklist

Dear p-philes:

I recently purchased a 1982 911SC Targa.  In the course of my 4 month search,
I put together a checklist to help organize things.  I read a number of 
books that were helpful in the purchase process, including Porsche 911 
Performance Handbook, Illustrated Porsche Buyer's Guide, The Used 911 Story,
and a video "A Porsche 911 & 930 turbo Close-up".  I also read a year's
worth of Porschephiles Archives (boy, did that take some time!) and found
lots of great tips in buying 911's. I think the best tips were "in 
general, buy the latest model you can afford" and "have a (good) mechanic 
do a pre-purchase inspection".   Anyway, I hope this checklist will make life 
easier for some prospective 911 buyer out there. I also look forward to 
comments for improvement from the long-time members of this group. 
Regards,

Manuel Pardo
mpardo@itsa.ucsf.edu
1982 911SC Targa, Rosewood metallic
1984 VW Scirocco


Porsche 911 Checklist

Date: 
Car:    
Miles: 
Asking price:    
Owner (bank):   
Color:

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 00:34:22 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: spinning 911s/rear sway bars

>A final thought
>
>Scott Winders writes:
>
> "For example, on my '78 911, I adjust my rear sway bar to full soft
>for everyday driving. This makes my car handle fairly neutral for
>a 911. When I go to an autocross, I set my rear sway bar to full stiff.
>This gives me an oversteering beast that does not push in the corners."
>
>But be careful,..... that works at an autoX, but on a fast race track at a
>major event, it might be...well embarassing. If you don't have a C4, we find
>that reducing oversteer helps at fast tracks, where getting through the high
>speed kinks is more important than getting into the slow corners quickly.

Peter,

Please notice that I did say "autocross".  When I go to the big track, I
leave the rear at full soft so I don't have a "oversteering beast" that
will find a way to hurt itself or me.  The point of my statement was to
illustrate that stiffening the rear increases oversteer or reduces
understeer, depending on the original condition.

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 95 15:40:41 +0200
From: pl@itf.fi (Pekka Laiho)
Subject: Re: re; gas tester and Air/fuel monitors


In Finland Company named CRT makes digital Lambda meter.
It has 4 digit display (eg. 0.800 to 1.200 lambda) so it's
wery accurate. I had two of them - one for each bank - and I'm
wery happy with ib because it shows exactly the air/fuel ratio.

Meter cost only 680 FIM (120 $) and you can use many diifferent
style oxygen-sensors with it. My sensors cost 380 FIM (65 $) each.

W:

Pekka Laiho


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 09:30:15 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re : 7x16 Fuchs on '71 911

>Just wondering if anyone is running 7x16 wheels on their early '70's 911.
>I have an opportunity to purchase some locally.  The wheels in question
>have 225/60 P7's which are *way* to wide for my 911.  It looks as though
>205's on a 16" wheel may be too big also.

>My guess is that I should go with 6x16's all around with 195's on the front
>and 205's on the back.  That or go with stock 6x15's.  This is my daily
>driver, I'm interested in updating the appearance from the stock steel
>wheels and a minor handling improvement.

Here are some options:
 - 6x16 all around with 205/55s is a pretty safe bet
 - 7x16 in the rear with a 205/55 *can* fit with some fender lip rolling
 - 7x15 all around with 205/60s (may still require some lip rolling in the
   rear)
 - 7x15 all around with 205/50s front - 225/50s rear (I've seen it done
   although I would not have thought 225s would fit in the rear...)

You'll have more of a problem fitting stuff under the rear flares as the 
fronts are basically the same as SCs/Carreras.  My vote would be to try
to use the 16 inch wheels somehow.

Have a good day!
Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911  




------------------------------

Date: 05 Feb 95 10:01:46 EST
From: "James A. Culbert" <76243.3611@compuserve.com>
Subject: newbe 911T

7#$(e $ $ $ $ $ $..%%%%
%
%(%("%Jx$\PI% %&-*&?$ &-%y&-&-(9,&-&-&-&-&-&-Date: Feb. 2, 1995
From: culbert@hazeltine.com
Subject 71' 911T questions

Because I know I don't know I have been lurking on the side hoping someone else would ask questions that shed light on my problems.

Some background,

In 1961 I bought a 1960 TR3A.  97k miles, one engine and two transmissions later I was married and expecting my first born.  Given the expectant wife could no longer fit in theTR3, I put it in deep storage.  Deep Storage meant digging a hole along side my house removing part of the foundation, and sliding the TR3 down into the cellar. For the next twenty three years, it was fun to watch the expression on peoples faces when they walked into the cellar saw a full size car, with no obvious way for it to be there. 

After the kids graduated from collage I decided to restore the TR3.  I found a guy that knew about restoring TR3's, he also had a beautiful 1971 911T, with 38K miles on it original paint, always stored in the winter, with no obvious rust, just an outrageously beautiful car.  I asked "how much for the 911?"  his answer "not for sale."  During my evaluation of rebuilding the TR3 I reviewed what I wanted in a sports car, and came to the conclusion I wanted a pre 1972 Porsche, but would not be able to find one that fit my requirements.  I made the decision to sell my TR3, and buy a TR3 that was running.  Went back to the TR3 rebuild guy, to see if he would buy my TR3, and sell me one that was running.  Walked into his shop, saw the 911, but did not see anyone else,  looking at the 911 and thinking I was by myself I said out loud "but this is what I really want."  It seemed as though God spoke from the corner of the garage (TR3 rebuild guy), "It's for sale," wife came walking into the garage as He spoke, took one look at the 911 and said "buy the sucker," and I did.  One week after I had the car on the road, I went to a Florist shop to buy the wife flowers, I had spent all my free time on the 911.  There was an older guy who drove an older Volvo standing at the counter.  Staring at the 911 through the shop window he said "beautiful car"  I said "that's why I'm here, I am spending so much time on the car, it may cost me my marriage of 31 years." he said in a low voice "keep the car."

Sorry to bore you folks with idle chit chat.  I get thinking about the 911 and lose all my natural New England conservatism.

Can someone help me with the following questions:

1.	Do I need a CO2 analyzer to keep the car well tuned?  If so where can I buy one, at a reasonable cost that will do the job?

2.	I have not had good results in tuning the car.  I finally broke down and bought a set of factory manuals (worth every cent), reviewing the factory procedures indicates my lack of good results may be because of my amateurish approach to tuning.  The carbs are Zeniths, I want to keep the car original, I have replace the accelerator diaphragms in the carbs.  I have reason to suspect the carbs may need a through cleaning and overhaul however I don't want to "fix something that aint broke".  The car had been in storage for six years and laid up every winter.  When I bought the car I brought it to the local Porsche dealer for an inspection, I thought they did a lousy job, they did not tell me anything that was not obvious.  How do I determine if the carbs need rebuilding or special maintenance?

3.	Major problem is in the range of 700 to 1400 Rpm engine backfires through carbs, and exhaust.  In high range this old cat still has legs, it is very comfortable at 80, will exceed the century mark.  The air cleaner housing (that big black ugly plastic air manifold that sits on top of the velocity stacks) shows signs of melting at cylinders 5 and 6, however that may have happened years ago.  the backfiring is effected by how I set the timing i.e. whether it backfires through the carbs or exhaust, however I can't seem to eliminate it.  All ignition parts are new except the spark plug wires.  I have not done a compression test, therefore the obvious question of what shape the valves are in has not been answered, however gas mileage is reasonable about 18 to 22 miles / gallon.  I have just finished adjusting the valves, they seemed to have been set closer than the recommended tolerance, on most valves I could not get my feeler gage between the rocker arm and the valve stem, however this maybe because the valve clearance is small, oil film strength in .1mm gap is high and it is not easy to line up a feeler gage in a .1mm gap while lying on your back etc.

4.	When I lift my foot off the gas, the engine does not drop in RPM unless I have the original idle set at about 150 to 200 Rpm, i.e. adjusting the screw that determines how far the butterfly valves are open with my foot off the gas peddle.  The Zenith carbs have a  gas enrichment subsystem that injects gas into the manifold as a function of Rpm and throttle position, it is supposed to eliminate hydrocarbon emissions when the engine slows down.  Someone disconnected this sub system.  I did not about this subsystem  until I studied the shop manuals.  Given Webber carbs this auxiliary injection system can be adjusted to control the engine drop in Rpm when butterfly valves are closed, no such adjustment appears on the Zenith setup.

5.	I had the tie rod ends replaced and the car aligned by a shop that came well recommended.  Now at speed, it feels like the back end is swaying, is this shocks, Would improperly torqued lug nuts cause this sensation, or did the alignment shop screw up (yes the tires pressure is correct.) 

6.	Rust is starting to form under the paint in the headlight gasket grove.  I started to remove the rust, and found that a small hole has rusted through.   Can anyone recommend a good Porsche body shop in the Boston MA. area that understands how to permanently fix this seemingly simply but difficult problem?

7.	How do I deal with rust. prevent it, fix it, etc.  There are some spots that are starting to "bloom" where the undercoating has worn away from the bottom of the car, how do I treat it?  I will not run the car in the winter time because the roads up here are heavily salted and sanded, the sand abrades away protective surfaces, and the saltwater solution dissolves steel.

8.	I have a oil level gauge that is not working, I suspect the sender unit, but have not trouble shoot this problem yet.  How do I get at the oil sender unit?  My shop manuals do not show a oil tank with a sender unit in it.  Do you have to dismantle the oil tank from the fender well to get at the sender unit?  Is there a oil leak risk if I disconnect the oil lines from the tank then reconnect them?  Should I replace the oil lines with new ones if I have to dismantle the tank?

I am of the school that gets as much satisfaction from making the car run right, as that great feeling when you've taken a difficult corner at speed with grace and beauty.  Except for the machine shop stuff, front end etc. I get great pleasure from working on the jewel.

Comment, I have an account on Compuserve, the "stuff" on Porschephiles is so good, my time is so limited, that I would not log onto Compuserve for my Porsche fix.  As far as there being "too much stuff" on Porschephile, I download everything into MS Word, sort and store information that interest me Then throw the rest away

Thanks very much Stan I appreciate the information you have made available to me, and keep it all coming.

Sorry about the bandwidth.  Thanks for the forthcoming suggestions.

Jim  911111010505
71 911T, (T = C19H28O2=Testosterone)
87 Celica (winter car)
93 Voyager Van / sports car sailing, biking, skiing camping
Some background:TPMasknow OnPMany',nsation, or did the alignment shop screw up (yes the tires pressure is correct.) 

6.	Rust is starting to form under the paint in the headlight gasket grove.  I started to remove the rust, and found that a small hole has rusted through.   Can anyone recom

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 11:33:10 -0500
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: Re: Word gets around quick...

Kevin,

I agree on many issues. You are right in that people use their real names.
However, that is true for most e-mail as almost everybody includes a
"signature" listing usually more than a name with frequently place of
employment and other info. Few people indeed address each other by screen
handles.
As to the traffic, if you are looking for financial and car-buying info, you
are dead on again. I appreciate people having different interests. For
myself, I am looking for brand specific info (Porsche) on advanced technical
and maintenance issues. It is neither on Compuserve nor America Online. The
car lists on the Internet have a wealth more of information. For example,
Porschephiles has national experts and hands-on experienced enthusiasts
contribute on a daily basis. I can quote the presence of Bruce Anderson
(911), Jim Pasha (924/44), George Beuselinck (944), and George Hussein (914)
as an example. Porschephiles distributes probably 50 messages a day, 1500 a
month etc.(If I look at the technical car messages on CompuServe I see maybe
50 topics a MONTH). With CompuServe pricing structure, it quickly adds up.
Take a surcharge for 9600 Baud access etc. AOL gives me all the above for
about $9 a month.
Again, I should have specified my comments in view of MY specific needs which
are access to the Internet in a most convenient and economic way. I had not
in mind a comparison between online services...
Hope this puts my comments in a different light :-)

Sincerely,

Bart (real name)
(AllPorsche@aol.com)

Pete's right about that.  This is a very subtle rattle (so subtle I never
think about it in my 924S!) compared to the "missing/broken doughnut hanger
on the muffler" rattle.  The former is quiet while the latter is relatively
loud.

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 13:59:59 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: 924 Turbos&Timing belts :^)

Hello Naresh,
	Glad to see your tilt to 924 Turbos.  I just looked through my 
latest Performance Products catalog and found prices on turbos (I just 
LOVE specifics :^) and they want $699 for a rebuilt turbo for an '82 
924T.  They also offer a repair kit (for professionals) for $149, but 
then you must have a mechanic do it and it probably works out the same.  
By the way, are you capable of doing minor repairs and adjustments from 
time to time?  Your maintenance costs will be higher than mine if your 
not able to do minor things.  Get a Haynes manual ($13.99) for the 
924/924T, it can help ANYONE repair their car.  Also get a subscription 
to European Car Magazine ( $18.95 per year), its the BEST magazine for 
locating cheap part advertisers and repair advice.  
	About the timing belt, 30K is the recommended interval, and I've
changed mine once since I got it ( $19 and a Sunday afternoon).  It might 
be harder to replace a 924T belt but it was no sweat for mine.  Again I 
can't stress enough the need to purchase a well maintained, good 
condition example.  You will be sorry if you will have to pay for parts 
that regular maintenace could have prevented.  The car should not drive 
you to the poor house unless you're extremely unlucky, just expect to 
spend a little time with it.  I usually reserve one Sunday per month to 
do little things like maintenace, washing, and occasional minor repairs.  
If you have no time or an ounce of mechanical knowledge, buy a Toyota.  
If you do, it will be the most pleasurable driving experience you will 
ever know!!!  Good Luck

Jay Karolyi

Date: Sun, 05 Feb 1995 13:55:45 -0500 (EST)
From: "James L. Fry" <JFRY@UOFT02.UTOLEDO.EDU>
Subject: 924T Costs

Naresh,
Figure from $600-800 for a rebuild on the turbo if you have a good, non-factory
P-car mechanic put in a kit.  The timing belts are not a big deal to put in 
yourself on the 924T.  They cost ca. $20, are the same as for the none turbo,
and take no more than a couple of hours if you are an average mechanic learn-
ing about your new car.  I suggest you replace the belt tensioner at the same 
as the belt.  They cost ca. $30, but not something you want to go bad after
you have just pulled off everything to put on a new belt.  The '82 931 engine
is very durable if you keep the oil changed, etc.  Mine had 107K on it when
I sold it last year (after 5 years of ownership).  As far as I know, it had
never had the head off and burned no oil.  I did have to repalce the camshaft
and followers ($), the turbo wastegate ($), and the turbo was also rebuilt at
about 84K miles.  If you do buy this car, follow the common sense rules for
this generation turbo, viz. change the oil and filter every 2-2.5K miles,
don't get on the gas immediately upon startup, and let the engine idle for
at least a minute or so before shutdown following any normal run.  The weak
point is the lubrication of the turbo bearings.  You don't want the lubri-
cant to get "coked" on the bearing surfaces because of high-temperature
breakdown.  Synthetic oils such as Mobil One are said to give superior
resistance to this, but I always used Castrol 20W-50 and change it often.
Have fun.
Jim Fry

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 14:34:58 -0500 (EST)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: 914 1st gear

I have question about our 914 73 2.0L 1st gear engage:

To put it into 1st gear, I must put the shift lever exactly in the right
place. I push it hard to the left, then down and slightly to the right at
the last second. If I do not do this exactly 'right', the car is not in
gear at all; then a tap (sometimes more like a hard slam!) will usually
engage the lever so that it is in 1st. 2nd through 5th are pretty ok (2nd
has a slightly worn synchro, no big deal) The problem does not feel like a
synchro is gone, rather like some alignment problem in the lever to
transmission linkage. 

I can now shift this ok 80% of the time -- but the other 20% is a pain, 
and also, while I drive this car most every day, Fred drives sometimes 
too -- especailly at the track and going to and from the track. We'd like 
to fix it!

We are thinking about either (a) The adjustment to the shift linkage
described in the Shop book ( but which doesn't describe why one would want
to adjust and the other gears are fine -- we do not want to mess them up) 
or (b) Changing the shift bushings (but I've read that this is for a 
sloppy shifter and 5 of the 6 gears are not sloppy at all, they are very 
crisp)

Any ideas? Anyone have the same experience?

thanks,

Mark

Date: 05 Feb 95 19:33:48 EST
From: Ray Khorram <70524.3012@compuserve.com>
Subject: Euro 930 charcoal canister / fuel tank breather

Looks like my previous message never made it. Sorry if you have
already seen it but here is a repost in case it really got lost:

Hi,
thanks to everyone who shed some light on the subject but I am still
very confused about the subject of fuel tank venting and federally 
mandated modifications thereto. 

Previously I mentioned that my euro 930 has a broken charcoal canister and
less than spectacular brake performance. Last night I found that these
subjects may actually be related, as I found out that one of the hoses to
the charcoal canister originates from a tap onto the thick hose connected
to the brake booster. I am very mechanically inclinded, but what I know
about brake boosters doesn't make sense to me. I read somewhere that 
engine vacuum is used for this purpose. 

What engine vacuum ? The air intake ? The same vacuum that is being 
pressurized with the turbo charger ? Wouldn't it waste engine performance
to divert the vacuum ? Also, why wouldn't it be dangerous to have an 
air/fuel mixture circulating in brake components that are likely to
get hot every once in a while ?

Since it doesn't seem like a factory unit, the idea of the charcoal 
canister seemed superfluous to me so I just connected the in and out
hoses together, removed the canister, and went for a test ride. There
was no extra performance in either the engine or the brakes, but after
a few minutes I heard a popping sound from the fuel tank area. With bad
conscience I immediately stopped and put the canister back in line, and
I heard a whooshing sound and another pop from the fuel tank as it 
expanded again after sucking in some air. So it is necessary, and it might
be dangerous to bypass it. But this really brings up another set of 
questions: Do US model 930s (or 911s for that matter) have a charcoal
canister ? If so, where and why don't euro models have one ? What is the 
intent of the law related to changing this plumbing ? It seems that the
modified plumbing is inherently less safe than any factory items!

So if you know anything about charcoal canisters / fuel tank venting /
the relationship to brake boosting I would really appreciate the info.
I saw that Performance Products has a book about brakes, and I intend
to get it. I already bought Zimmerman's book "Used 911 story". As a 
helpful Porschephile pointed out, it has some info about gray market
conversions. Are there any other references I should look at ? (I bought
the factory service manual for turbos but this info doesn't appear in it.
I guess I would need the other 2 volumes of the service manual but they
are so expensive!)

Thanks, Ray
'82 Euro 930 
'92 Harley (which has a charcoal canister for the fuel tank breather,
            but isn't in any way related to brakes, and doesn't
	    have any vacuum lines connected either)




------------------------------


Porschephiles #1136                         Mon Feb 6 02:00:05 CST 1995

Subject: Re: 914 1st gear

You wrote: 

>
>I have question about our 914 73 2.0L 1st gear engage:
>
>To put it into 1st gear, I must put the shift lever exactly in the 
right
>place. I push it hard to the left, then down and slightly to the right 
at
>the last second. If I do not do this exactly 'right', the car is not in
>gear at all; then a tap (sometimes more like a hard slam!) will usually
>engage the lever so that it is in 1st. 2nd through 5th are pretty ok 
(2nd
>has a slightly worn synchro, no big deal) The problem does not feel 
like a
>synchro is gone, rather like some alignment problem in the lever to
>transmission linkage. 
>
>I can now shift this ok 80% of the time -- but the other 20% is a pain, 
>and also, while I drive this car most every day, Fred drives sometimes 
>too -- especailly at the track and going to and from the track. We'd 
like 
>to fix it!
>
>We are thinking about either (a) The adjustment to the shift linkage
>described in the Shop book ( but which doesn't describe why one would 
want
>to adjust and the other gears are fine -- we do not want to mess them 
up) 
>or (b) Changing the shift bushings (but I've read that this is for a 
>sloppy shifter and 5 of the 6 gears are not sloppy at all, they are 
very 
>crisp)
>
>Any ideas? Anyone have the same experience?
>
>thanks,
>
>Mark
>
>
>-- 
>-------------.                          .
>Mark Krieger  \     .------------------'  
>President      `---'  UniPress Software    
>msk@unipress.com      (908)287-2100 x937       
>http://www.unipress.com
>
>

You need to ck out all the plastic bushings on your shift linkage. If 
any a worn replace with new ones. These are avail from Automotion, 
Tweeks, Perf prod and others. Cheap fix to try first. The one which will 
cause to most problem is the one at the side rear of the trans. also the 
one under the plastic cover on the trans shift lever if worn out will 
also you give you fits in shifting. 
The bushing in the rear firewall doesn't really wer that much and is a 
real bear to change so leave alone unless really worn.

					mike

- -- 
- --
Mike Willis
Sacramento, CA
mswillis@ix.netcom.com


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 19:42:37 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 heads

First, a question: why are you doing this??? The 2.0 heads in stock form
flow *plenty* of air for up to 7500 RPM with a decent valve job. If you
have 1.7/1.8 heads, you're screwed anyway -- they have bad design for moving
air, even using big valves. And with bigger valves, your low-RPM (i.e.
say under 5000 RPM) performane will just suck...

That being said: 

>    Mark Stephens high performance has advertised 

When helping a friend build a E Production legal engine for his 914, we
had occassion to use some of the Stephens products. The "ready to run"
"super high performance big valve ported and polished" heads had one or
two problems -- like *huge* gouges in the combustion chamber, unchamphered
at that; like the valves *DID NOT SEAT* and would not as a result hold
compression; like the valve springs were clearly pitted with rust.

When there were informed that the product as delivered was less than 
satifactory, they basicly said "so?". Fortunately, they had been
paid for by credit card, so it was possible for my friend to get
his money back and make the problem resolution part be someone else's
job. This *REALLY* pissed them off, since that meant that their
Visa merchant bank wanted to know how things had come to this point, 
gave them a "hickey" on their record, etc. Nasty phone calls followed,
but never ONCE was there an offer to make things right.

Note as well that Stephens is also "Rad Tech Racing" in case you see ads
from THEM.

My basic policy: if you see big flashy ads, don't go there. Quality work takes
time, and costs money. You typically don't have money left to pay for the 
fancy flashy ads. Remember, how many high quality heads can you *DO* in 
a day/week/year?? If you want great heads, go to FAT. 

Stan

Date: Sun, 5 Feb 1995 20:01:41 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: re: 914 1st gear

Mark Krieger (msk@unipress.com) writes:

>I have question about our 914 73 2.0L 1st gear engage:
>
>To put it into 1st gear, I must put the shift lever exactly in the 
>right place. .... If I do not do this exactly 'right', the car is not 
>in gear at all; then a tap (sometimes more like a hard slam!) will 
>usually engage the lever so that it is in 1st. 2nd through 5th are 
>pretty ok .... The problem does not feel like a synchro is gone, rather 
>like some alignment problem in the lever to transmission linkage. 
>
>We are thinking about either (a) The adjustment to the shift linkage
>described in the Shop book ( but which doesn't describe why one would 
>want to adjust and the other gears are fine -- we do not want to mess 
>them up) or (b) Changing the shift bushings (but I've read that this is 
>for a sloppy shifter and 5 of the 6 gears are not sloppy at all, they 
>are very crisp)

Mark:

The symptoms you describe afflict most 914s that I've driven.  You may 
want to try putting the lever in a high gear, like 4th or 5th, before 
trying to shift into 1st.  This sometimes helps.

The shift-linkage alignment shouldn't affect the engagement of the other 
gears; part of the alignment procedure involves making sure that 4th 
gear is still reachable.

The shift bushings are a good upgrade -- Otto's (310 399-3221) makes 
some trick bronzite bushings -- but they're probably not the answer to 
your particular problem.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Porschephiles #1137                         Mon Feb 6 10:02:31 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 06:33:19 -0500
From: X400459@aol.com
Subject: Re: daytona results?

Wilmington News Journal, monday Feb 6, 1995:
"The International Motor Sports Association seemed to do everything it could
to run Porsche out of sports car racing, but the proud German car company
wouldn't leave without a fight. 
  Rules developed 10 days before the start of the Rolex 24 hours of Daytona
race to solely cripple Porsche's chances did little to curtail its resolve.
Hampered bbbwith a smaller engine and extra weight, Porsche used its history
of outlasting its competitors Saturday and Sunday to win its 19th 24-hour
marathon at the Daytona International Speedway. 
  The Porsche driving team of Jurgen Lassig, Christopher Buochut, Giovanni
Lavaggi and Marco Werner drove the Spydr K8-a chopped up verrsion of the old
962 GT Prototype-steered clear of major troubles to easily outdistance a
Oldsmobile Spice BGD02 by five laps-17.8 miles-on the 3.56 mile road course."

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 12:36:45 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: mini cooper

On Fri, 3 Feb 1995 martinw@eapi.com wrote:

> 
> wasn't the mini the first production front engine/front wheel drive
> car?
> --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The mini was the first prod car with a tranverse front engine/fwd, I 
don't think it was the first front eng prod car, I think that was the 
pre-war packard - although as usual my write only memory may be playing 
tricks!

I never drove a rally or autocross mini, but I read that they were 
brutes, those wide tyres, and unequal length drive stafts lead to 
differential wind-up of the shafts, this lead to some lurid power 
understeer problems.

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 08:01:27 -0500
From: wise@db.erau.edu (John Wise)
Subject: Rolex 24

As most of you probably know by now the Kremer Brothers' Porsche Spider K8
won the Daytona 24.   It was the 19th time Porsche has won the Daytona 24. 
An Olsmobile Spice was second (five laps behind), Paul Newman and company
came in third overall in a Rausch Racing Mustang & took first in  GTS1.  A
911 Turbo driven by Rohr, Murry, & Haywood was 4th overall and 2nd in GTS1.
 A Porsche 911 RSR driven by Byner, Calderari, Mastropietro, & Richter was
5th over all & first in GTS2.  

However, you might all find a local story rather interesting.  A *street
legal* 993 owned by Nort Northam of Orlando ran the the entire race,
finished 26th and then (according to the local news) drove back home to
Orlando.  Nort (who owns a local Porsche garage and sells a wide variety of
used sports cars) claims his team even drove the race on street tires.  

John

Try to have the install done so its not obvious you have have a humongous
stereo system (e.g. hide what you're going to use for deep bass... a bazooka
out in the open is a "take me," even *with* an alarm, keep the factory
speaker grills, use a removeable/removeable faceplate stereo, etc.)

>e a factory alarm, and put the factory stickers on the car, will it be obvious
>that I have no alarm to a theif?  Before I go drilling a hole and putting in a

A thief that knowledgeable is going to get what he/she wants, anyways.

>fake flashing red light, I will buy a real alarm.  If I do this should I remove

You can always put the fake flashing light in amongst the middle air
ventilation grills, meaning no drilled holes. You should have some kind of
flashing light. With the sticker, you're assuming thieves are literate, and
will take the time to read the sticker :)

> the factory stickers because it is obvious that I do not have a factory alarm?

No.

>Any theives out there who can tell me how their brains work?!  -Confused 928

Well, if you're worried about the *car* being stolen, that's one thing. If
you're worried about the car being mutilated, that's another. If all you're
worried about is your stereo/contents, I'd make sure they're well hidden.
*Especially* make sure there's no loose stuff in the car, like a briefcase
(or anything that could contain a laptop. Laptops are big items, now). You
don't want to encourage a "smash'n'grab" kind of thief...

Unneccessary aside: Most of the car stereo thieves around here are kids,
under 18 (so they fall under juvenile law). An older kid shows them what to
do, and they go as a gang to hit an apt. bldg. or an underground parking
lot. Whatever you can do that advertises "I'm noisy, I have an alarm, and
there's nothing that's smash'n'grab in me, anyways" will encourage these
kids to move on to another car... I've met enough of these kids, and believe
me, working brains are *not* are pre-requisite.

"Pros," who are after your car, are another matter.



- --- <: snip! ;> ---

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 08:09:54 -0500
From: michael@helix.nih.gov (Michael A. Freed)
Subject: 914 1st gear

        Mark, I have always had the exact same problem (hard to engage
first gear). I did replace the bushings in the shift linkage, which made it
a little easier to shift into first gear, but the problem persisted. I also
fooled with the alignment of the shift linkage (by loosening coupling
between shifter and shift-rod), which helped incrementally. NOw, if I pull
very hard to the left before engaging first, it always works, without
having to pull back too hard. I think, however, that the spring which
resists pulling to the left is too stiff to make shifting easy. Perhaps
this could be modified, but then reverse would be too easy to engage
inadvertently. Michael

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 13:06:50 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Q: power antenna


Check that the antenna is well grounded to the wing, a bit of salt at 
this time of year will scupper the motor.

In theory it should be earthing through a strap, if the arial has been 
replaced with a pattern copy, the fitter may have omitted the strap - 
result arial only grounds through the antenna to hole in wing connection.

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 14:55:02 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Rolex 24


I don't usually follow up my own posts, but in this case
I would like to point out that the speeling mistakes in my last post
were due to foaming-at-the-mouth syndrome induced by the excellent
results from Daytona. I'm feeling much better now.

On another note, I had my street-only 911 lowered by ~30 mm, and 
full geometry and corner balance done at Bob Watson Motor Sport. I have 
had to swap garages with the gf, because the ramp into garage is too steep
and the 911 would ground unless driven in and out with exceeding
care! Apart from that, the lowering and suspension set-up, have sharpened 
up the turn in, much improved the overall "tightness" of the handling. I 
notice that the rear drifts *much* more predictably under power and is
easy to control with tiny amounts of opposite lock and throttle adjustment.

Straight line stability seems much better and in fast sweeping
turns, it now feels like it runs on rails rather than the rather
vague feelings the back end used to make. I have 7J and 8 J x 16
Fuchs with standards section Yoko A008P, and the gaps
between the tyre and wheel arch seem tiny, you can just about get
your finger in between, but even so there was no evidence of the tyre 
making contact, even during extreme cornering force. I can only assume
that under heavy cornering load, the top of they tyres just fit past
the inner lip of the wheel arches, but the clearance must be a few
millimetres at best. Money well spent IMHO, significantly enhanced
the all ready very high big-grin factor associated with this car.

Anyone know what is needed to put turbo brakes into an 88 Carrera? I 
have a technical question. Is there any benefit from upgrading a regular 
Carrera to turbo brakes without increasing the tyre contact patch? Given 
that you can lock the brakes at almost any speed in a 88 911, surely one
must increase the amount of rubber on the road in order to apply more
breaking force. Does anyone have the facts on this one?

Regards

Ben

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 09:57:16 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: remedy for stuck disk brake pistons



I've been doing a total brake R&R on an Alfa Spider this winter and
found a good solution for stuck pistons that will also work on p-cars.
I tried pushing them out the usual way with air, but even at 100psi
they wouldn't budge. I ended up using the master cylinder (out of the
car) and it worked great. I wouldn't recommend doing this with the 
master cylinder in the car because of the risk of getting brake fluid 
on paint. I bought an 8" piece of brake line with fittings ($1.75) to 
use as a shunt between the two unneeded holes in the master cylinder and 
used a piece of flexible brakeline to the brake caliper. From there it 
was easy:

    - Bleed the air out of the caliper in the normal way.
    - Put the master cylinder in some kind of vice (I used a 
      cheap pipe vice that has one stationary end and an adjustable
      end that works on standard threaded pipe - "Pony Clamp")
    - Push the piston on the master cylinder in and out until one
      of the "stuck" pistons starts to move, then C-clamp it when it
      gets about 1/3 of the way out.
    - Continue to pump until the opposing piston is all the way out
      and wiggle the first one with pliers, staying off of the polished
      surface.

This was a lot easier than it sounds. I had both stuck calipers done 
in about 1/2 hour. I used the brake fluid that I removed from the car
rather than waste new, and an old cookie sheet to catch the fluid when
the pistons finally came out. The other good thing about this method is
that the pistons don't pop out with explosive force - although you should
always keep your fingers out from between the pistons just in case.

 -Reid
(reid_zeigler@merck.com)

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 07:04:00 -0800

Subject: Re: 914 1st gear

Hi Mike:

You wrote:
>You need to ck out all the plastic bushings on your shift linkage. If 
>any a worn replace with new ones. These are avail from Automotion, 
>Tweeks, Perf prod and others. Cheap fix to try first. The one which will 
>cause to most problem is the one at the side rear of the trans. also the 
>one under the plastic cover on the trans shift lever if worn out will 
>also you give you fits in shifting. 
>The bushing in the rear firewall doesn't really wer that much and is a 
>real bear to change so leave alone unless really worn.

All the bushings in my car are new - firewall, tranny bracket and the one
on the ball-end that comes out of the tranny.  Yet the problem continues.
The one on the tranny bracket is a bronze one from Otto's. I don't think
these are the problem.

I'd (we'd) like to know not just how to fix this problem (the concensus
seems to be that it's unavoidable), but WHY it happens with this tranny.

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 17:58:01 -0500 (EST)
From: "Kenneth D. Grimm" <GRIMM@alison.sbc.edu>
Subject: Mini Cooper thread

Michael Hodos <MHODOS@us.oracle.com> opined:

>I had a friend in college who's (enlightend) family owned two of these little 
>bombs.  In their day the Minis redefined the expression "cornering on rails." 
>The Hydroplastic suspension was truly amazing! 
.
.
.
>As I recall, the tyres never squelled during any of these exercises, and 
>although we occasionally "took to the curbs" I don't believe that we ever bent 
>a wheel. 

This reminds me of a quiet walk in the Cotswold hills many years ago.  My
sweetheart and I had just crossed over a "hump-backed" bridge over a small
stream in one of the most picturesque parts of Britain.  A tiny dot in the
distance very rapidly grew into the not-much-larger close up size of a
Mini Cooper.  Doing about 45-50 as he hit the take off ramp of the bridge,
I fully expected him to leave the ground.  I was just too far away to see
for sure.  What I was positive of, though, was that I was about to hear the
sound of breaking glass and crumpling metal.  What the Mini Cooper driver
didn't know was that immediately on the other side of the hump-backed bridge
was a T junction with a row of solid Cotswold stone houses extending to
form the top of the T.

The amazing part was that not only did I not hear a crash, I didn't even
hear his tires squeal!!!

I trotted back to the crest of the bridge to find nothing but a tranquil
village scene.

Frankly, I still think that little weenie disappeared into the twilight
zone.

Ken
'83 944 Platin

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 10:05:14 -0500

Thanks to all who replied with advice and concerns about my problem.  The
comment about the safety of "ANY" tire rubbing struck home.  I am also safety
conscious.   The best option appeared to be fender modification since I
really do like the handling balance with the current spring rates etc.
 What's a few hundred more for some paint work anyway?  I enlisted the help
of my friend the body man and worked out the flares to fully clear the tires
at their most extreme position.  Boy - it really hurts to trash a new paint
job, but it seemed better than potentially trashing the whole car if driven
in an unsafe condition.  Now I can go fast again.  The 914 really is a
wonderful creature, all it ever needed was some POWER.

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 11:13:59 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 vibration...

Here's one for your memory banks...

For a while, I was experiencing this really bad vibration on my 85.1 944.
It would occur as I wound up the engine through the RPM range. It occurred
right at about 2800 and until 3200. It was comming from the driver's side.

At first I thought, exhaust system. Went over it from one end to the other.
The vibration, exhibited the tipical exhaust vibration as you went over the
RPM range. Something was resonating at that specific RPM (frequency). I ruled
out motor mounts since car idles very smoothly.

Then I thought broken motor support. I had one of them break when some yahoo
tapped my 300d from the rear in traffic. I did not find anything on the 944. 

Well, I found my problem. Tapping around with my hand at the A/C compressor,
I noticed that the front washer was turning loosely. Yeap, I found that I had
a broken bolt that held the A/C to its mount. I was lucky enough, that there
were two threads extending out from the broken bolt. I got it out using
needle nose pliers. Replaced the bolt (8.8 grade, like before) and the
vibration HAS GONE AWAY!

I figured I pass the info along to all of you. You never know when it might comehandy...

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is
