> (gasp> *street legal* 911 can be up there with the super-exotic...


(grin).  Does anyone has any performace data (lap times, etc) that would
substantiate (OR DENY) IMSA's original claim that Porsche had an "unfair
advantage" for which the infamous last minute rule change came about?
*That's* what's needed as the real follow-up to IMSA.

The ethics of enacting a performance penalty rule on a specific model
because they are more reliable mechanically is a different question.
I'm just curious to find out who was right on the specific issue raised.


 -hh

Robert,

SCCA has moved the Solo II National Championships from Salina KS to 
Topeka KS.  This will be the first year of a new contract with long term 
intentions.  The site will be Forbes Field and the days are:

   Sep 2-3       Pro Solo Season Finale Event
   Sep 4         Course walking, town hall meeting, etc.
   Sep 5-8       Solo II Competition

This event regularly draws 600-700 competitors in 50 classes.  Of course, 
there should be plenty of local events in your area.  To get a contact 
name/phone # for events in your area call SCCA at (303) 779-6622.

Date: Mon, 06 Feb 95 11:20:58 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 FALSE AIR

> 
> Chasing stumbling under load problem with my '88 944.  Pressurized intake 
> tract (bicycle pump) and found pretty major air leak around base of the oil 
> filler tube.
> 
> Anybody know how to tighten / replace / fix this leak?  The 944 manual set I 

> have on fiche shows 2 bolts holding the oil filler tube in place, neither of 

> which appear to affect the seal into the crank case.  So I'm at a loss as to 

> the details of this fitting.
> 
> Thanks to any who respond to me direct - I'll post a response summary if I 
> get much of interest on this one to save bandwidth.
> 
> Kirk
> '88 944

Hi, Kirk.

Strange place for an air leak, but...

if you remove the oil filler tube, you will see a couple of rubber
O-rings that are supposed to seal the beast.

I would suggest replacing those and rechecking.

Good Luck,

Hi, Steve,

For that kind of money, though, you ought to consider rebuilding the unit.

My experience is that you could rebuild the motor correctly for $1000 or so.

PartWerks of Chicago seems like a pretty good bunch to me...
(even though they are my competitors...)

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 09:16:31 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: re: 914 heads

Robert Priddy writes:

>Mark Stephens high performance has advertised a pair of large valve 
>heads for the 914 using 48mm intake/38mm exhaust and racing seats and 
>valves. For the heads, port, polish, and HD springs the price is about 
>$700 a pair or so. I've heard of valves too large for an engine and i 
>wonder how close to being too large this is.
> ....
>will it last?

Robert:

Before I put the six in my 914, Mark Stephens built my 4-cylinder with 
those valves, and I was very happy with it, even though I was still 
running the stock (well... almost stock) fuel injection, rather than 
the carbs for which those valves are ideal.  It was my daily driver, and 
I had no problems with low-speed driveability.

The motor lasted for years; I finally sold it, when it developed a 
totally unrelated problem, to a local PCA member who's here on the list, 
but may not want to be identified (I don't know what class he's running 
his car in).  Stephens Machining had done his motor, too, and he wanted 
mine for the spare parts.

Oh, by the way... I should mention that my engine was a 1.7-liter.  If 
you've already got the 2-liter heads, you may want to think twice 
before cutting them up; they're pretty good as they come from the 
factory (and valuable).

Also... I've heard from people who've had distinctly unsatisfactory 
experiences with Mark Stephens.  As I said, I was happy with my motor, 
but...

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Fri, 03 Feb 95 11:03:04 CST
From: rsmith <rsmith@panasonicfa.com>
Subject: Re: Subwoofers

          Stereo's are one of the few things for Porsche's that are
          not only hard to install, but to install them correctly
          takes time, hard work, and a good degree of patience.
          If anyone is wondering what the "Best Sounding" stereo
          equipment is out there, it would be hands down a set of
          tweeters called "Waveguide Tweeters"  They are a special set
          of tweeters with an incredible soundstage.  They work on a
          "horn" premise, but the sound is crisp, clean, and
          incredible at any audible levels.  They run for about 170 a
          pair, but of all the seperates that I have heard, they were
          the most clear for any type of music.  For any of you that
          are really into doing the "Ultimate Install"  one servo
          controlled subwoofer would do as much as 4 good 10" regular
          subs.  But they cost about 1,500 a piece.  The best thing is
          that with the waveguide tweeters and a servo controlled
          subwoofer, you only need about 100W of power and it will be
          plenty.  One of the great things about servo controlled subs
          is that they are clear down to 20Hz or lower.
          If anyone needs futher info. just write me.

          Ryan Smith
          rsmith@panasonicfa.com

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 11:29:28 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 914 Rot Report

        For those of you following my own 914 saga:
        With the help of the Neidels (national PCA Family of the Year
twice!) I got my car over to the bodywork guy.  He took one look at it
and said, "I thought you said this thing was rusty!"  Evidently all I
need to do is to clean up the surface rust (and it ain't that bad!)
with either a sandblaster or a wire wheel, and cut the little section
in the right corner where the fuel pump used to mount.
        Whew!  Dodged a $300+ bullet, there!
        'Course, the bad news is that I "have" to do it myself...  ;)

- --DD

Subject: Need advice on 3.2L 911 engine noise

I have just completed the 60K mile service on my 86 911 after being gone to
France for an extended period of time. I have not driven the car for about
2 months until last week. I have noticed a noise from my engine that I did
not remember it having.

The engine makes a clicking noise that gets more pronounced as the engine
warms up. The noise can be heard inside the car when running the engine
beteen 2500 and 3000 RPM. It should be noted that I have the rear deck
removed to repair a rear speaker, so the engine noise in general is louder.
The sound is like a sparking noise, as opposed to a pinging noise.

I am not an expert mechanic by any means, so the possible sources I list
might sound dumb.

Possible problems:

   1. Valve adjustment (just adjusted them and checked the clearence twice).
   2. Bad valve
   3. Fuel injectors (do they make any noise?)
   4. Spark plugs
   5. Intake manifold leak
   6. Exhaust leak

I have thought of recording the engine after it warms up and than playing
back the recording into an audio file on my SUN SPARC. The audio file could
then be sent to someone, or FTPed to a server. If anyone with the experience
to diagnose 911 engine problems by listing to them has the time and capability
to playback an audio file, please let me know. Maybe this could be a new area
of information provided by the Porschephiles, training via the Internet.

Thanks!

W.P. Costello

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 09:59:45 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: charcoal canister and power brakes

Ray

I assume your 930 vacuum is plumbed similarly to my 931...

Yes the brake booster derives its power from engine vacuum.  On the
Turbo models, engine intake vacuum can be drawn at the air metering
box, after the filter (which allows the vacuum to exist) and before
the turbo and fuel injection.  This line is Teed into the brake
booster and the charcoal canister.  The other side of the canister is
connected to fuel system and crankcase vents.  The idea is that when
the car sits idle, hydrocarbon vapors that collect in the fuel and
crankcase are absorbed in the charcoal canister as they boil off.
When the car is driven, these vapors are then sucked into the engine
air intake to be burned.  Non-US cars may not require that these
vapors be scavenged, so the canister may be omitted altogether.

The brake booster draws outside air to operate against the vacuum.
Note that there is no "fuel-air mix" involved in the brake booster,
since the vacuum is DRAWING air rather than PUSHING it to the booster.

There is no degradation in engine performance to using vacuum this
way... the vacuum is a nearly unavoidable condition of street
induction systems.  You and I are fortunate that we have turbochargers
so that our engines never see an intake vacuum at the cylinders!!

If your charcoal canister is toast, you better plug that line until
you replace the canister, so that the brakes will work in the mean time.

 -mike   '80 931  fire engine red
________________________________________________________________________
Mike Weihman    mikew@sr.hp.com 
                                 
Hewlett-Packard Co.              | HP Fire/Chem/Medical Response Teams     
Microwave Instruments Division   |                                    
1212 Valley House Drive          | Firefighter/EMT-D                  
Rohnert Park, CA 94928  USA      | Rancho Adobe Fire Protection District 
(707) 794-4454                   | Penngrove, CA

Date: Mon,  6 Feb 95 10:04:10 TZ
From: Marc Olson <marco@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Rolex 24


| However, you might all find a local story rather interesting.  A *street
| legal* 993 owned by Nort Northam of Orlando ran the the entire race,
| finished 26th and then (according to the local news) drove back home to
| Orlando.  Nort (who owns a local Porsche garage and sells a wide variety of
| used sports cars) claims his team even drove the race on street tires.

I was at Daytona this past weekend.  What a blast!  In a field of 74, 
there were 26 Porsches, including the 993 above.  We talked with the 
crew in the pits after the race, and they said they had done nothing to 
the car except change the brake pads and add a roll cage.  They did run 
on street tires, and only added 1/2 qt of oil for the whole race.  They 
were very excited to have finished, and their experience spoke to the 
amazing cars that the factory produces for the street.

We camped in the infield, and went to sleep to the sound of RSRs 
winding through the gears...

Too bad the Porsche factory team didn't come.  The Ferrari WSC cars 
(there were four, I think) were in the top three spots for the first 14 
hours or so.  I woke Sunday morning around 6:00 and the announcer was 
talking about the leading car having been stuck in the pits for 30 
minutes because they couldn't get it started.  They eventually gave up. 
 Another Ferrari team cut a hole in their engine cover to allow the pit 
crew to keep the car running w/ the throttle during driver changes.  
These cars sounded amazing when they were running.

Marc

Date: Mon,  6 Feb 95 13:16:12 PST
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: factory shop manuals


Looking for a factory manual?

Somewhere in the archives I came across a message from someone who ordered the Porsche factory manual on microfilm from TMC Publications.  I 
needed to get a manual myself, so I gave them a call.  At $49 + shipping, it is a heck of a lot better than paying hundreds for the printed copy!

The 928 set comes on 17 pages of microfiche (the small squares about the size of a big index card).  It includes everything (in English!)

I was able to place my order over the telephone with Visa.  The 928 manual was in stock, shipped immediately, and arrived 3 days later by UPS ground.  

I had the manual shipped to my place of business.  When the mailroom couldn't track it down, Jeff Foland (TMC), was VERY helpful.  He returned my calls 
promptly and obtained delivery confirmation from UPS.  When the mailroom still had trouble, Jeff offered to deal with UPS himself and to send a 
replacement manual at no charge to me. [the mailroom later found the manual]  All the time Jeff was courteous, friendly, and helpful.

I was so impressed by Jeff and TMC's commitment to customer satisfaction, I just had to pass it on.  So if you need Porsche doc's (or Benz, BMW, Audi, or 
Jaguar) call Jeff at TMC (410) 367-4490.  They're in Baltimore, MD.


Matt Carpenter
1984 928
(no connection to TMC unother than being a satisfied customer!)
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 13:44:34 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: 944 TURBO TIRES

>Can someone who has experimented with different tire sizes please help me . I
>have an 1988 with stock telephone dial wheels. Recently I put 225/55's on
>front and 245/45's on back ( I know this is the set-up on 1989+, but their
>wheels have more offset ).  I am concerned that I may encounter fender rub
>and/or damage on the track at drivers ed courses. We use a very fast road
>racing course with eleven turns. I would hate to hit a sweeper at 125+ mph
>and cut a tire.
>                                                    Thanks'
>                                         Philip-Alabama,Region

I had 225/50s on 8x16 fuchs (actually 951 rear wheels) on the front and
stock factory sport suspension. I just barely rubbed the tire (street TA)
edge on the fender lip in a big sideways slide at the glen. no damage
(whew!). I would anticipate no problem with 7s. The rear 8s are actually
not quite correct offset for the front.

my current setup, 255/40 and 275/40 rubs in the rear only! nothing "cup"
suspension won't fix.

Oh yeah? My laser produces optical pulses that are 100 femtoseconds (fs) in
duration. A femtosecond is ten to the minus fifteenth seconds. Thats zero
to 300,000,000 (that's 3 times ten to the 8, if I miscounted zeros) meters
per second in 100 fs. Of course each pulse contains less than 10 nanojoules
of energy.

So there. I'm geek of the week.

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

I concede.  Anyway, you can have your "ten to the minus whatever"
facts.  Most of us little boys prefer large numbers of zeros to the LEFT
of the decimal point, this is much better correlated with lots of smoke,
noise, high speeds, property and/or environmental damage, and other 
cheap thrills.  How much fun can you have with a wad of photons only 
30 microns long? ;-)   (PS - if you are involved with the "Shiva" laser,
don't answer that!)

 -Ed


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 95 11:48:04 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924/944 Shifter Rattle and electric antennas


In addition to Pete's comments on the subject,

The shifter rod wears where the rod connects to the shift lever. The
pin on the lever gets eaten and the pin is now loose in the rod end.
It will rattle. Just replacing the lever doesn't help because the rod
is worn in the connector tube and will eat the pin again. Replace 
both AND the pivot bushing (plastic) under the shift level.

Heating the plastic bushing (if it hasn't broken) in very hot water
makes it expand enough to remove. Do the same to install the 
replacement. The shifter rod can be removed with some cursing and 
disassembly from the car.

Electric Antennas. George wasn't being facetious. The usual failure 
mode is corrosion. When they get bad, toss them. Very rarely the 
failure is the relay, which can be crossreferenced to a Radio Shack
part. There are few serviceable parts. The antenna mast is replaceable,
wipe it with WD_40 on a rag every so often and it won't freeze up.

The replacement Hirschmann's run about $60 -80 and are physically 
different than the OEM units. They fit and are electrically the same.

Jim Pasha

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 13:58:00 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 1st gear

> I'd (we'd) like to know not just how to fix this problem (the concensus
> seems to be that it's unavoidable), but WHY it happens with this tranny.

The 901 is basicly a racing 4-speed (2nd-5th) with a first and reverse
grafted onto it. Becomes obvious if you're seen a Hewland apart.

2-5 typically work great, but this "add-on" stuff...

Stan

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 95 12:14:04 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Re: CA Smog ?'s

Cherie,
I've been to the Smog Police a few times with another type of car. They 
basically give there ignorant opinion and place a $ amount on the repair
to make it pass. If all the equipment is correct according to the state,
and the repair is appraised at higher than the $700, then they just give 
you a waiver(smog certificate) and your on your way. They don't actually do the repairs at the smog ref station. They may tinker a little to try to reduce the
emissions but no actual repairs. I actually posted a story about my experience 
with the CA smog Ref a little while back. 
Sean
69 912
Zero & Maddog: 8 legs of Terror!

Date: Mon,  6 Feb 95 13:45:24 CST
From: Bert=Garcia%DSS%DSS=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: RE: Alarm stickers...

Craig:

Definitely get the stickers, a club and a flashing light! or better yet, 
get an good alarm system with a remote kill/panic switch and all of the 
above.  Below is a list of my break-ins to date here in Houston over the 
last 3.5 years with the lesson's I've learned from these experiences:

1) The first 944 I owned was broken into to grab a cheap cellular bag 
phone on the passenger floor board.  The factory alarm went off when they 
opened the door.  I ran outside only to find broken passenger's door glass 
everywhere. The break-in was my stupid mistake.  No stickers, no flashing 
light, obvious valuables on display as if my car were a shopping mall.

2) The second 944 I had was broken into to steal my CD player on the one 
night I didn't hide the remote.  My wife heard the alarm but ignored it.  
She thought it was another car.  I was fast asleep.  Only a neighbor's 
quick thinking kept them from getting the goods.  They heard the alarm, 
turned on their lights and opened the door to let their dog out.  All the 
wiring was torn out but easily fixable.  I had the club but no stickers 
and no flashy lights.  (you'd think I would have already learned my 
lesson)

3) Broke into my 1987 VW Jetta to steal a CHEESY Sanyo cassette deck that 
DIDN'T work.  The only protection the car had was a club.  I believe the 
car would have been stolen if the club was not on the steering wheel.  All 
cars now have an alarm with a flashing light, stickers everywhere, and a 
club.  No problems since.


This 944, '88 944 Turbo S, has it all.  Stickers, club, alarm, flashing 
light, kill switch, etc...  I've also talked to my neighbors and asked 
them to keep an eye out and call me if they notice anything.  I've taken 
the wife to the car and set off the alarm for her so she'll recognize it 
in the future.  I don't leave any valuables in the car AT ALL.  I've had 
the car for quite some time now with NO break-ins.  I also take a quick 
walk around the family cars at night to make sure they're all properly 
emptied, locked and their alarms are armed.  You'd be surprised how many 
times I've found my wife's car unsecured; ie., rear passenger side door 
unlocked and the club not installed.  

The moral to this story is,"Do everything reasonable to protect your 
property even if you live in remote Kansas.  It's your responsibility!"  
Your chances of a break-in are greatly reduced if you demonstrate OBVIOUS 
visual deterrents.  Should a break-in occur, YOUR NEIGHBORS are your BEST 
FRIENDS in helping you thwart the crime (by turning on a light or letting 
the dog loose) or helping you identify the specifics of crime such as a 
description of the vandal.

Hope this helps,

"Soap box mode now off"


Bert
'88 951S, black

Date: Mon, 06 Feb 95 15:21:00 EST
From: "Gregory Nyce" <gnyce@nas.edu>
Subject: 914: in cold, idle and die problem

  Hi all.  This problem hasn't popped up but twice, since it's been a mild
  winter, and since I commute by bike (when I can).  My new (to me) '75 914
  (2.0l) apparently doesn't much like the cold.  It has an uneven idle
  (putting it mildly) when warming up, for the first two minutes, and then
  settles down.  Well, this morning (7 degrees, not counting wind chill), I
  started it ok and was letting it warm up... idled ok, a little rough
  running, for 90-12 seconds or so.  Then it cut out, suddenly.  Started it
  again, ran a few seconds, died.  And again.  Repeat, with shorter running
  interval.  I finally got it semi-moving, out onto the street.  Added a
  little Drygas and Octane Booster ("appeared" to work last time), shook
  liberally, got rolling again.  It gradually corrected itself, and was ok
  once it got warmer, ran fine, no cutting.  Question is, why is it running
  for a little, and then cutting out?  Frankly, I just don't think the
  Drygas/etc. does any good, since this happened before when it was really
  cold... and I buy super-premium gas... I mean, water in the line twice
  like that?  Seems a little improbable IMHO... So, what is it?  Related to
  rough idle normally (vacuum leak?  haven't tried to fix yet)?  Probably,
  but as you can tell from this presentation, I'm not necessarily
  mechanically "apt" (but ya' gotta start somewheres).  Any ideas? Anyone
  seen this?

  -Greg
  gnyce@nas.edu


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 13:11:07 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Screws and other small parts

In my experience, the best all-around source is Stoddard, who has an
800 number (don't have it handy, but it's always in Pano, and probably
listed with 800 information).  Their prices are reasonable, especially
considering they're an authorized Porsche dealer, and they will refer
you to an aftermarket source if what you need isn't a Porsche part.
(Your local dealer will probably feign ignorance about anything
non-factory, and will probably have a higher starting price for the
part.)

Most of all, they *don't* sock you for unreasonable shipping and
"handling" charges.  They charge *actual* shipping, which can be as
little as what it costs to put a stamp on an envelope and put it in
the mail.

So I'm sure they have the screws you need, and that they can get them
to you for a fair price.

BTW, I wanted to replace the 25th anniversary sticker on the right
quarter window of my 911.  A concours aficionado I know bought one at
a swapmeet for $75!  Stoddard has those for about $5.00.  They 'fess
up that it's a repro, but I defy anyone to tell it from the original.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

It should fit any 911T from 1965-1973.

Date: Mon, 06 Feb 95 16:22:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: Re: timing belt intervals


> I was led to believe from previous correspondos that 16 valves do not hit
> pistons, what is the truth in this area.

Both incidents happened under warranty and involved Reno because the factory 
authorized service was negligent. The first incident happened 1k miles after 
my 30k service after I asked that the belt be serviced and Porsche had an 
advisory out to replace the belt with a revised one.

My point is that most of the valves were replaced and either Reno picked up 
the tab or the dealer did. Either way, I'm sure they didn't replace one 
extra screw.

That's my financial answer but I'm sure someone can give a better technical 
one.

Arthur E. Golden
AGolden@aol.com
1988 944S

Yes, I had a feeling this was true - after all, when I'm really enjoying my
914, 1st isn't even in the picture!

I always found it sad that "due to customer complaints" Porsche and BMW did
away with dog-leg 1st gear shift patterns.  Yes, it's a drag in traffic
when 1st is recalcitrant, but when you're _driving_ having a straight shot
down to 2nd from 3rd as you approach a turn is great!

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 95 13:42:55 PST
From: Bill Ataras <Bill_Ataras@ccm.jf.intel.com>
Subject: Predictions


Text item: Text_1

     The following is from the business section of The Kansas City Star, 
     Jan 17, 1995:
     
     "Computers in the future may weigh no more than 1.5 tons."
     - Popular Mechanics, forecasting the relentless march of science,
     1949.
     
     "I think there is a world market for maybe five computers."
     - Thomas Watson, chairman of IBM, 1943.
     
     " I have traveled the length and breadth of this country and talked 
     with the best people, and I can assure you that data processing is a 
     fad that won't last out the year."
     - The editor in charge of business books for Prentice Hall, 1957.
     
     "But what ... is it good for?"
     - Engineer at the Advanced Computing Systems Division of IBM,
     1968, commenting on the microchip.
     
     " There is no reason anyone would want a computer in their home."
     - Ken Olson, president, chairman and founder of Digital
     Equipment Corp., 1977.

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 95 15:48:12 -0600
From: dkelly@tomcat1.tbe.com (David Kelly)
Subject: Re: alarm stickers...

Matt Carpenter said:
> I thought all 928's had a factory alarm standard?  Two keys, one longer
> key that turns a deep tumbler to activcate the alarm? Or, was this added
> in a particular model year?
> 
> I bought my 928 about a month ago, and a longer key wasn't available.  I'm
> not sure if I have a factory alarm or not.  I did find a manual for an
> "Excalibur" alarm in the glove box, so it appears to be an aftermarket.  I
> haven't had a chance to investigate this setup, but the thing squawks
> every time I start up the car...

Take your VIN to your friendly Porsche dealer and ask if the car should
have a factory alarm. If so, they can make or have made the original
master key. This is great if the car has not been re-keyed.

When I purchased my '83 928S, I too didn't get a master key. Had one made.
Found it does not fit in the driver's door (too long.) Is this correct or
has somebody plugged my lock? Works fine on the hatch and ignition. Fits
in the passenger door but nothing works on the passenger door, apparently
the door was replaced and not the lock. Guess I should try arming it and 
try to set it off.

David Kelly N4HHE,   n4hhe@amsat.org,    dkelly@nebula.tbe.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 13:50:56 -0800
From: dthompsn@ix.netcom.com (William D. Thompson)
Subject: Radar Detectors

>DrGEK writes:

>Seeking comments on Bel vs. Valentine for use in 993. Any relevant 
>experience
>appreciated. Thanks.


For my money, the Valentine One is the only way to go.  Here in 
Virginia, it has saved my butt more times than I can count and has also 
saved me in Maryland, where they use laser.  The V1 wins the faceoffs in 
the mags and the Bel usually finishes second.  Both offer stealth (which 
means cops using the VG-1 radar detector detector can't sniff you out). 
 In Virginia, where the things are illegal to use, the stealth feature 
is a must.  The V1 also offers a remote light faceplate that lets you 
put the warning lights down on the dash and out of the line of sight.  
Bel offers a remote version, which the V1 is not, but remote are 
considered less useful because the antenna is mounted too low for long 
distance.  Be prepared for a long wait for a V1.  It took six months to 
get mine back in 1992 and then eight months before my name came up in 
rotation to get the wideband and laser update.

- --Doug


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 13:53:55 -0800
From: dthompsn@ix.netcom.com (William D. Thompson)
Subject: Radar/laser detectors

Luther Wilson writes:
>This is not strictly Porschephile stuff, but I am looking for a 
>reliable 
>detector for my 944. I'm not a speed freak, but I do like to cruise the 
>long empth western highways at slightly above what the law might like.I 
>have seen a relatively new model--Phantom is the brand mane, as I 
>recall
>--that purports to almost instantaneously detect all radar frequencies, 
>and laser as well, and on detecting a signal, transmits a return signal 
>that scrambles the readout on the police screen giving the driver about 
>10 seconds to adjust speed. 
>Does anyone have experience with this detector? Have any other reliable 
>one to recommend?
>Luther

Don't get taken by such claims.  Radar scramblers, as a rule, don't work 
and if they did they'd be so patently illegal that it would cost you a 
lot more than a ticket.  Go for the Valentine One wideband/laser 
detector.

Doug

Date:          Mon, 6 Feb 1995 14:10:16 +0000

Subject:       Strange 911 engine noises

Whilst out and about this weekend in my '75 911S, I had occasion
(and clear road) to put the pedal to the floor from 1st to 3rd gear
(whee!). However, when I hit around 5500 rpm in 2nd (just before I
shifted) I heard a strange sound from the engine.  Kind of a metallic
zinging or buzzing, like a very fast drum-roll on a cymbal.  

I have heard this once before (a few weeks ago), but I didn't think
much of it.  This time I was paying attention, and I was disturbed. 
The car still runs fine, I haven't noticed anything odd before or
since.  I didn't think to check the mirror for smoke, but it was
dark anyways.  The car was in for a tune up (oil, valve adjust,
checkup, etc.) in December, and got a clean bill of health

So, what does this mean?  Am I in for pain and $uffering?  Autocross 
season is upon us, and I don't want to miss it for a blown engine...

Dirk

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 17:19:08 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: HELP<914 track car rear susp?


You wrote:
<I have a 914-6 track car with a 3.2L & all the 
<usual track mods.  I just had
<custom made steel flares installed on the rear 
<(not GT type) & installed
<10x15 BBS rims & 245/50/15 tires.  A slight 
<tire rubs occurs on the outside
<if I take the springs off of the shocks and 
<jack the wheel up to the bump
<stops.   It won't rub until the bump stops are 
<compressed by the weight of
<the car to about 1/2 of their normal length.   
<Can anyone tell me the
<liklihood that I would get that far into the 
<bump stops?   I am using 150lb
<Hyperco springs, adj rear ride height sleeves, 
<Bilstein shocks, & 18mm
<swaybar.  I have never noticed that I was 
<hitting the bump stops before but
<I'm trying to play it safe.  How much travel 
<should I expect?

About your 914-6, 
Are your Bilstiens racing (fully threaded bodies) or street shocks? What is
the free length of your springs? If they are actually hypercoils, I assume
they would be 2-1/2"x10" freelength. 10" springs on race or stree shocks on a
car that has been lowered a great deal may bottom out the shock, but this all
depends on the compression of the springs! Most of the time they are and
should be set to where the shock will not burn out. Rather, the spring will
hit almost full compression even under the most radical of loads and not
bottom out. Typically, the spring should only compress around 30-50 percent
of freelength. It should not hit by the way it sounds. However, your choice
of spring may be too soft for a track car. What rate torsion bars do you
have? Do you have a rear sway bar?

Sean

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 95 14:49:40 PST

Subject: 914 Transmission

>From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)

>If I put it in gently and stay on the gas, it'll stay in, but as soon as I
>let off the gas, it pops right out. I'm hoping it's not a big, expensive fix.

>Secondly, I have the stock steel wheels with 195/50/15 tires on it. I REALLY
>wanna move onto alloy wheels, especially since one of the wheels is a little
>bent and leaking air. (Whatta pain!) Anyone have any nice-condition old 914
>wheels lying around they'd like to sell cheap? Of course, I'd kill for a set
>of 15x5.5 Minilites (or Panasports), but I doubt I'll find those. :)  In
>terms of stock wheels, I'd prefer the ones with the large dome in the middle

- -- 
| Jeff Kyle                           "I don't know what they have to say |
| jkyle914@ix.netcom.com                    It makes no difference anyway |
| "Katarina" '75 Porsche 914             Whatever it is, I'm against it!" |
| "General Lido" '85 Dodge Shelby Charger                   -Groucho Marx |

Hate to sound like an opportunist bastard, but........

Your transmission has the classic symptoms of trashed synchros.  It's
normal for a 914 to crunch a little going into 1st, (Also synchro problems,
but the fix is expensive, and doesn't last long.)  But popping out of
4th is a "bad thing".

I have a transmission out of a '73 that I will probably never use.  I didn't
put a lot of miles on it, but it seemed to work just fine.  I could sell it
for the core charge.

I also have a set of VERY non-stock alloy wheels that were removed from a 
914 that I would GIVE you.  They fit and look fine, but require conversion
from lug bolts to lug studs.

Let me know if you're interested.

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

By the way, your E-Mail address doesn't work.

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 18:11:49 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Q:215/65-15 or 215/60 ?

the trick for tires (at the track) is to put shoe polish over the edge of
the tire. after the session see how far the tire rolled over by by how far
down the sidewall the polish was removed. if its past the edge of the
tread, add air. The right way is to check the tread temp across the
surface, but a 29 cent squeeze tube of shoe polish is cheaper (much). on
the street, the old pressures are probably ok, anything in the low to
mid-thirties.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Porschephiles #1140                         Tue Feb 7 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: 6 Feb 1995 15:44:08 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 1984 928

 Reply to:     RE>1984 928

Matt,

  >>  I just bought a 1984 928 a month ago. 

Glad you like your new car ... I'm still thrilled every time I drive mine
even though I've had it for a year now.

  >>   What I don't know, and maybe you can help me, is if my car
  >>   is a 928 or a 928S.  I believe that the 928S came in 1985 and was
  >>  available in earlier years only in Europe.  Is this true? 
  >>  How can I tell? 

If your car has a front air dam and the (small) rear spoiler, it's a 928S.  
The S4 has the stiffer suspension and a larger rear spoiler.  
The pre-928S did not have a spoiler in the rear as far as I know.  Also,
the 928S has Bilstein shocks (they have a green dab of paint on
the shock body).

  >>  What have the major repairs been?

I have 131,000 miles on my car.  Unfortunately a lot of things
have gone wrong with the car, most of which I attribute
to deferred maintenance on the part of the previous
owner(s).  My biggest single expense was a transmission
rebuild when the mail bearing failed ($1700).

I had a problem with the servo unit that controls the air 
mix.  It was about $400 to replace (my labor).  Also, the 
voltage regulator is integral to the alternator so I had to
replace the alternator ... Porsche wants $899 for an alternator,
so I got the same one, brand new, for about $240 from
another source.  (Make sure the air hose bringing air to the
alternator is in place and not blocked!)

Try to find out when the last time your timing belt was replaced.  
I had mine done ($330 parts and labor at Porsche) and the old one was
beginning to fray a bit.  The belt itself is $35 from Porsche ... if
you're handy you can do the work yourself.  The hardest part
would be tensioning the belt without having access to the 
Porsche special guage.

I've discovered that the 928 needs frequent 
tender loving care and that the price of parts is about
three times higher than you might expect (my previous
car was a Datsun) and that very few parts can be purchased
from places like Pep Boys or Trak Auto.

Keep in touch ... I'll be happy to share information and 
lessons learned.   



------------------------------

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 95 16:07:42 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Gastester/O2 sensor/Tuning 911 MFI

Friends,
I've seen the JC Whitney CO tester discussed here and in other 
fora, and no one has been able to state definitively whether it is 
in fact a CO tester, or simply a garden variety O-2 sensor.  At 
$125,  which is about the same price as the unit advertised in 
Pano costs, and apparently the same price as the Edelbrock 
unit, I'd bet that it's nothing more than an O-2 sensor, which 
costs about $25 for a single wire type, and about $35 for a three 
wire type.

If anyone is really interested, I can post a fairly long, but 
accurate and informative item about O-2 sensors.   Briefly, an 
O-2 sensor generates 0 to 1 v; near 0v if the mixture is lean, 
near 1v if it is rich, and about 0.45v at stoich (when the air/fuel 
ratio is 14.7/1, exactly the right ratio to consume all the fuel 
and leave no excess O-2.)   The sensor output passes through 
0.45v very rapidly, so it gives a poor indication of the exact 
ratio, although it indicates lean and rich quite nicely.  You can 
monitor the output with a high impedance voltmeter, such as 
almost any digital voltmeter, or you can get fancy and 
construct an LED display, or analog meter, which apparently is 
what JC Whitney and others do.  It's a bit of a waste though, 
since the meter (or LED dsplay) will really just indicate lean, or 
rich, and not tell much about the actual ratio, even if it is 
"calibrated" in fuel/air ratios. 

One way EFI systems use the O-2 sensor is to constantly 
monitor its output and constantly adjust the fuel/air ratio to 
try to keep the average output at 0.45v.  If the EFI system 
senses a lean mixture it richens it, and vice versa.  If it does this 
often enough, say several times a second, on average you'll 
always be stoich.

The sensors operate near 600 degrees F.  The single wire 
variety needs to be installed right near the exhaust manifold 
where the gases are hot.  The three wire version has an internal 
heater  that operates  off the 12v car supply (hence the other 
two wires).  It can be installed anywhere in the exhaust system.

I used one to help tune the '72 911E I just restored.  I wanted 
something to help me set the MFI pump, which I had taken 
apart for refurbishing,  so it was way off adjustment when 
installed in the car.  I know how to do carbs, but MFI is new to 
me.  Unlike with carbs,  you can't adjust the MFI with the 
engine running,  so you can't easily tell what effect your 
adjustments are having.  

I bought the cheapest 3-wire O-2 sensor I could find and 
mounted it in a foot-long section of muffler pipe that I clamped 
to the tailpipe.  I ran the voltmeter wires outside the car, in the 
window, to a digital voltmeter sitting on the seat next to me, 
and watched it as I drove around.  I could see under what 
conditions I was lean or rich, and when I changed the MFI 
pump adjustments and drove the same course, I could see the 
effect.  It actually was kind of fun, and worth the $35.  

Just to see what the O-2 sensor would do on a well-regulated 
EFI system, I put it on my 1990 Subaru's tailpipe and drove 
around with it.  Amazing.  The voltmeter hovered bewteen 0.3 
and 0.6 volts under almost all conditions, hot, cold, under load, 
cruising, and so on, indicating that the mixture was almost 
always perfect.  It's remarkable what 25 years of engineering 
has done!

Has anyone else has tried using an O-2 sensor as a tuning aid?

Bob Spindel
'72 911E

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 19:13:20 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Rebuild Update

 Here's the progress on my 66's rebuild project.

   Just received the oil pump back from Lukes&Shoreman. Notified that
the pump was in much better shape than ones they receive from the older
911's but, once you're in...you're in. The case, crank, heads and rods
have all been reconditioned, cleaned, magnafluxed or renewed (where
applicable). The rod from cyc #1 was not servicable. Another rod
was obtained and the whole set ballanced and rebushed. The sheet metal
was all sandblasted and refinished. Wednesday I will be taking the trip
to R&D in Coatsville to pick up the machine shop work. Guess aside from
reassembly and ordering the necessary gaskets, bearings, chains pistons and
cyls I'll be done ;-) 
  
  My 911 looks sooooo lonly under it's winter blanket! Can't wait to hear
the sound of a rebuilt 30 year old motor!

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 95 16:40:28 PST
From: Ehab Aljandali <ehab@cisco.com>
Subject: Re: Gastester/O2 sensor/Tuning 911 MFI


	I used an O2 sensor/digital meter as a tuning aid when I had my 89 
Supra Turbo. I had bought a digital fuel mixture meter that had 14 LED's.
5 yellow ones for lean, 4 green ones for stoich (how do you say this word?) and
5 red ones for rich.
I hooked it up to my O2 three wire sensor. I changed the programming of my CPU
thru a PFC-FCON (an enriching computer) and changed the fuel mixture as I 
increased boost from 5 psi to 15 psi. The response of the meter was instant and
fast, and I tried to keep the LED's in the green when boost was on, by changing
the different curves. This helped a lot in tuning of the system. I had 
problems with the weather changes and had to change the programs almost on
daily basis. As you can emagine this was a lot of fun but not very reliable
for daily commute. When I bought my 911, I slowly but surely lost my interest in
the Supra and turned to the 911. I sold the Supra. I am however planning on
buying another meter to keep an eye on my 3.2 engine. Will share with you the
results if interested.
PS: I would like to suggest using a fast reacting digital voltmeter otherwise
you will not get a real time reading. This is if someone wants to measure the O2
output like you did.



	Ehab.
84 Euro who thinks she is a 930!

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 20:15:27 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Ignitor Pointless Ignition

> Do any of you have any pros or cons?  Is it as simple as they make it sound?
>  How do they work??

Yes, they do work. Yes it is as simple as it sounds. 

There are *THREE* cons:

1) fitment. If they unit you chose isn't an exact fit for the stock distributor,
   you're hosed since you can't "just use a 009" and keep the EFI.

2) wear. These gizmos are heavier than points, so will place extra wear 
   on the advance/retard mechanism in the distributor, the bushings on the
   distributor drive, and most of the other moving points. This may mean
   you get to replace or repair your distributor sooner than you might 
   otherwise, but it's not insurmountable.

3) repair. You can use Beetle points in a pinch if you have to, but where
   are you going to get a replacement ignitor in East Bummfuzzle if it
   "stops working"? Admittedly, this is not a *TYPICAL* problem, but
   I never seem to have those...

If you can live all that, the go for it!

> Stan, before you say how much cheaper regular points are, and how many sets I
> could buy for the price of these, I keep my Porsches for a long time (like 23
> years!) - and I HATE CHANGING POINTS!!!

I hate changing points too. In fact, I used to run magnetic trigger systems
driving CD ingitions on race cars in the '70s when that was *NOT* the way
that you were supposed to do it. I even have breakerless igntion on my
BMW motorcycle (you only *THINK* changing points on a 914 is a pain
in the ass...). And after my friend did his 356 (thanks to everyone who
forwarded info on 6 volt systems!), I'm seriously thinking about changing
Big Red over to breakerless...

Stan

Stan

Hi, Hubert.
 
Are they countersunk phillips head screws? Sort of a rounded head visible?
These are called oval head screws. Are they sheet metal or machine screws?
If sheet metal, you can find U.S. spec stainless phillips head oval head
screws, probably #8 or so. If they are machine screws, it may be a little
harder. A well-stocked hardware store might have them.

we'd know more. (Tell me the description in German in case the translation
is bad; also size and DIN spec number if they give it.)

Date: Mon, 06 Feb 1995 14:32:56 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (Andrew Clements)
Subject: Re: alarm stickers...

Hey Sean,

In order to understand alarms and other theft deterrents you must understand 
the theory behind them.  First of all, theft (car or stereo) is obviously 
illegal.  Thus, the object of a thief is to do it and not get caught!  A 
thief will go to great lengths to steal a hot item, but he/she will *not* 
unnecessarily risk being caught to merely *FIND OUT* if there are valueables 
in a car.  In other words, a thief must have some knowledge that there is 
something in the car either by sight or prior knowledge.  It is for this 
reason that you *never* want to go Ba Ba Booming into a large parking lot 
with your windows down because potential thieves will be on the lookout.  
The moral of the story is that a "stealth" install is always your best first 
defense against having your car broken into.  A THIEF WON'T STEAL WHAT HE 
DOESN'T KNOW IS THERE!  Conceal your stereo equipment as much as possible.

Beyond the basic stealth installation, a good electronic security system is 
your best defense, aside of a steel vault garage.  Keep in mind that 
high-quality alarms do *not* make good first DIY projects.  They require 
significant specialized install knowledge, and considerable experience.  
Leave an alarm up to your trusted installer unless you *really* know what 
you are doing.  As I said before, to understand how an alarm works, you must 
understand the theory behind them.  An alarm does *not* offer any bona-fide 
physical barriers to a thief.  Instead, they do what a thief wants least, 
and that is draw attention.  The best alarm will not keep even the most 
amateur thief out of your car if their is no one around to hear it.  
Remember, just because your car has an alarm doesn't mean that it is a safe 
on wheels.  The stickers and LED's you mention can be thought of as 
"pre-warning" indicators.  Obviously, their purpose is to inform a would be 
thief that your car is armed, and generally he/she will move on to easier 
prey.  This approach is very effective.....most of the time, even if their 
is truly *no alarm at all*.  If you do have an aftermarket alarm installed, 
it will most likely come with its own stickers.  I recommend that you use 
them insted of the factory items!  Most factory alarms don't present much of 
a challenge to the average thief.  Purchase a *high-quality* aftermarket 
alarm made by a *reputable* manufacturer if you decide upon that route. This 
is not an area to pinch pennies because, ultimately, it is what stands 
between you and a thief.  Keep in mind, however, that even top dollar alarms 
won't keep out a determined, professional theif.  These guys have 
sophisticated methods and great experience in disabling most any alarm, and 
unfortunately P-cars, and nice systems are high on the want list ( *good* 
installation techniques help to minimize this).  The best way to protect 
your car is with common sense.  You must begin to think like a thief if you 
want to understand how to best protect your valueables.

Hope this helped.  Let me know if you need more info.

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Installer)



Sean Writes,
>Any theives out there who can tell me how their brains work?!  -Confused 928

Date: Mon, 06 Feb 95 23:31:00 PST
From: "Golden, Arthur" <agolden@pepsi.com>
Subject: RE: radar/laser detectors


Please no flames. There seems to be a little tension on the net lately. I'm 
merely playing counterpoint since everyone else seems to love the Valentine.

Luther, I own the Bel 615STiR (remote). It supports X, K, Ka, superwideband 
Ka, laser and has detection avoidance. I choose the remote because I drive 
through states where radars are illegal and if I understand the law 
correctly, they can ticket you if the radar is in the passanger compartment 
of the car (even if it's not on) but not if it's remote and your'e 
registered in a radar tolerant state.

Bel also makes a portable version with the same features. I have owned Bel 
radars since 1986 and have no complaints (or proof that they're better or 
worse than any other).

Also, someone stated that the lower remote mount does not have the distance 
of a higher portable. Physics tells me that 3 feet over 2800ft (1/2 mile) 
only gives a marginal, if any real, gain and since we don't live in a 
perfect world, the bouncing of radar signals should find any detector as 
long as it's facing the correct direction (stated for simplicity). I could 
be wrong.

my $0.02 and another view

Arthur E. Golden
address withheld to avoid flaming (only kidding)
1988 944S

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 00:22:20 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject:  Mini .. etc.

I don't think that the Mini was the first transverse engine front
wheel drive car.  The Berkeley preceeded it by at least three years
and there may have been others.  Berkeleys were made in Biggleswade,
England.

The Berkeley was 725 pounds of open sports car built with unit
construction in fiberglass with aluminum stiffeners.  The original
Lotus Elan is the only other car that I know of that used this
construction (not to be confused with later cars called Elan)

The Berkeley is properlay air-cooled (no nasty fluids) and dispenses
with any cooling fans.  The air cooled engine came in a 328 cc twin
and a 492 cc three-cylinder .. both two strokes.  In 1959, they also
used a Royal Enfield 700 cc four-stroke, but few of those were
produced.

I still have my original Berkeley purchased in 1959.  It doesn't
rust!   (:-)

Rick Dill
62  356 B ..............  waiting for spring

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 00:26:31 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: 944 air flow meter problem ???

Alright, I think I'm figuring this out.

Over the past few months I have had problems with intermittant studdering
on my '84 944. Up until last night, the problem was too intermittant to
track down, but it has been happening more and I think it is in the air
flow meter. Could the barn door be sticking? Here are the symptoms of my
problem:

        a) car cuts out very sharply from time to time. Usually a change in
accel pedal pressure will solve the problem. Sometimes if I press down on
the accelerator the car will stumble or stall. When it is really bad, I
find that if I carfully find one position to hold the accelerator with my
foot the car will run smooth, but if I press down or back off the least
little bit the car will stumble or stall. This is the reason I feel it is
the air flow meter (if the barn door is sticking then the car can't tell
how much air it's getting and either runs too rich or lean to the point of
stalling).

        b) most commly happens in colder weather (it was well below zero
here in Wi. last night), but it can happen with the engine hot or cold.

        c) happens at idle, part throttle, and full throttle.

        d) I have checked all electrical connections concerning the dme and
fuel management.

        e) this morning it was still a bit of a problem so I tapped on top
of the air flow meter and the problem went away for a little while.

If any of you 944 experts know what this problem could be (could it be the
air flow meter, or am I on glue ???), could you please let me know, cause
I'm kind of stumped here.

***** NOTE *****

The first person who correctly dignoses my problem will recieve a free cd
of their choice from Narada records (a nice New Age/Jazz/World Music record
label). If this kind of music does not interest you, then you at least have
a cd to trade in at a used cd store for something you want !!!

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 06 Feb 1995 15:43:01 +0500
From: aclement@vt.edu (andrew clement)
Subject: Re: Subwoofers

Ryan,

You presented some info. regarding stereo's, but I feel that it needs some 
clarification for both yourself and others.

First of all, that is a pretty bold statement as to what the "Best Sounding" 
stereo equipment is out there when you consider that stereo sound is 
entirely subjective, and everyone has slightly different tastes.  For your 
information, *WaveGuide* tweeters are a brand name of horn-loaded 
compression drivers sold under the USD label by Speaker Works.  They are 
quite sophisticated and unconventional, and they go for about **$1500** not 
$170 as you mentioned.  There are other horn-loaded compression drivers on 
the market closer to that price, but most do not contain the exotic 
construction of the WaveGuide brand.   There are different schools of 
thought regarding the sound of horn-loaded drivers.  Many, such as you, find 
them to sound incredible, but others (including myself) characterize some 
such drivers as sounding "overly-bright", and horn-drivers have a frequent 
tendency to beam.  Likewise, it is entirely possible to create an accurate 
soundstage, and proper imaging with the use of more common cone or dome 
style tweeters and mid-range drivers.  My point is that not everyone views 
sound in the same way, and what sounds good to you may not sound good to others.

In regard to your comment of the "Ultimate Install", I disagree.  It is true 
that servo controlled sub-woofers usually exhibit extended capabilities, but 
they are not for everyone, and they are extremely rare in the auto 
environment.  It is not true that one servo controlled sub will necessarily 
"do as much" as 4 10" regular subs.  A competant installer with experience 
designing sub-woofer enclosures could build a sub-box with performance equal 
to or exceeding that of some servo controlled designs.  You are correct in 
saying that servo designs are *often*  "clear down to 20Hz or lower", and 
that is clearly a function of their servo-controlled correction circuits 
minimizing driver output distortion.  It is not, however, impossible or 
unheard of to obtain flat frequency response down to 20Hz or below using 
conventional non-servo drivers.  Once again, it is all dependant upon the 
proper enclosure design. Servo controlled subs do generally offer 
exceptional accuracy, but they are generally more expensive than 
conventional designs, as you mentioned.  

You also comment "you only need about 100W of power and it will be plenty".  
Plenty for what?  This may or may not necessarily be true.  I assume that 
you mean plenty of power for high output levels.  Output level, however, is 
a function of a driver's sensitivity (among other factors), and high 
sensitivity ratings are commonly found amongst conventional non-servo 
drivers and non-compression drivers as well.  Careful examination of a 
speaker's specs can offer many keys to how well a particular driver may 
perform in a proper enclosure.  Likewise, there is more to "good" sound than 
"about 100W of power".  Any particular amp must be evaluated on specs beyond 
raw power output.  Distorition level, dynamic headroom, RMS power ratings, 
etc. are all factors in describing the capabilities of an amplifier.  

For most people, it takes a great deal more than simply a pair of WaveGuide 
tweeters, a servo sub, and "about 100W of power" to create the "Ultimate 
System", as you suggested.  There are numerous variables that must be 
considered in the installation of a high-fidelity sound system in an 
automobile.  Equipment selection is only half the battle in auto-sound 
systems.  The difficult part is to implement that equipment into the car in 
a way that is asthetically pleasing, safe, and most importantly, offers the 
best possible sound suited to that individuals tastes.  Not necessarily an 
easy task!

Andy
(EIA certified Mobile Electronics Certification)


Ryan Writes:(snipped)

>          If anyone is wondering what the "Best Sounding" stereo
>          equipment is out there, it would be hands down a set of
>          tweeters called "Waveguide Tweeters"  They are a special set
>          of tweeters with an incredible soundstage.  They work on a
>          "horn" premise, but the sound is crisp, clean, and
>          incredible at any audible levels.  They run for about 170 a
>          pair.... For any of you that are really into doing the "Ultimate 
Install" 
>          one servo controlled subwoofer would do as much as 4 good 10"
>          regular subs.  But they cost about 1,500 a piece.  The best thing is
>          that with the waveguide tweeters and a servo controlled
>          subwoofer, you only need about 100W of power and it will be
>          plenty.  One of the great things about servo controlled subs
>          is that they are clear down to 20Hz or lower.
>
>          Ryan Smith
>          rsmith@panasonicfa.com

------------------------------



Porschephiles #1141                         Tue Feb 7 11:04:06 CST 1995
Porschephiles #1141                         Tue Feb 7 11:04:05 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 10:27:16 +0200
From: pl@mistyrivers.itf.fi (Pekka Laiho)
Subject: early ('66) 911 Head flow-test result

Hi all early 911 owners!

We have flow-test '65 911 head before starting modify them for
historic race and rally. Here are results for standard head.

Test pressure: 10
Intake port: 32 mm
Intake valve: 39 mm
Exhaust port: 32 mm
Exhaust valve: 35 mm

Head flow with intake manifold and Solex 40PI carp

Lift mm     CFM  In Val In Flow  Ex Val Ex Flow   E/I %   Power
   1.00   29.00    0.40   11.40    0.34   10.10   88.60   30.71
   2.00   29.00    0.72   21.00    0.66   20.00   95.24   55.27
   3.00   40.00    0.79   31.80    0.78   33.00  103.77   83.12
   4.00   59.00    0.73   43.90    0.69   43.10   98.18  114.01
   5.00   59.00    0.92   55.10    0.81   51.10   92.74  142.90
   6.00   84.00    0.77   65.70    0.92   58.10   88.43  170.10
   7.00   84.00    0.83   71.30    0.71   69.40   97.34  184.56
   8.00   84.00    0.85   73.50    0.77   69.40   94.42  190.11
   9.00   84.00    0.85   73.00    0.79   71.20   97.53  189.00
  10.00   84.00    0.84   72.60    0.81   73.00  100.55  187.89
  11.00   84.00    0.84   72.20    0.82   74.30  102.91  186.78
  12.00   84.00    0.84   72.20    0.83   75.30  104.29  186.78
  13.00   84.00    0.84   72.20    0.85   76.60  106.09  186.78

Some additional info:

8 mm lift:
	Carp -18 hp (pre-atomizer -13 hp!!!)
	Intake manifold -2 hp
	Intake valve -13 hp!!!

As can seen, when cam's  lift is 8 mm, head gives best performance.
Solex's pre-atomizer or venturi (I'm not quit sure for terms) and
intake valve reduces head flow a lot.

Any comments?

W: Pekka Laiho


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 00:52:55 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: My 944 alarm


I've got an Alpine alarm installed in my '86 944. As well as having the
usual door switch sensors, it emits a radar field surrounding the car. The
scope of this field is fully adjustable to 15 levels. If someone intrudes
the outer radar field, the alarm gives several warning chirps.  Inside the
car is a separate inner radar field. If this field is invaded, the alarm
goes off (i.e. if you stick your hand in an open window). The alarm has
outputs for activating other devices when the alarm is triggered. I've
connected a bright amber strobe light (shaped like the police ghost car
ones) using a black coil cord which goes in the dash. When parked, I can 
hang the light over the mirror so it is highly visible. I've had no 
problems with this setup so far.
 
Hmmm, just once it would be cool to clear traffic by turning on the alarm 
siren and putting the strobe light on the dash :^)

Joe Hunter
'86 944

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 1995 10:35:50 +0100
From: Pierre Fournet-fayard <fournet@ilm.loria.fr>
Subject: Re: Alarm stickers... 



Just a few words about the `Alarm stickers' thread:


1/   You can easilly install a fake flashing light.  It's *cheap* ($2).  Mine
is connected to the `always' 12V and the `only-when-running' 12V.  So it flashes
when I cut the motor and stops to flash when I start it.  When you'll connected
it, if it doesn't work, swap the 2 wires.  Flashing lights are diods.

You'll *never* forget it and it won't disturb you when driving in the middle of
the night.

One good location is obviously close to the radio head-unit.  If someone give a
look to your car, he will see it because he's wondering if there's any $$$ CD
player to still.

One other good location is close to the side-glass.  On your both driver and
passenger door, just near the little stick showing if the door is locked or not
(Can someone mail me the english word for it ?)

2/  Metal clubs are good protections too.  It's cheap and everyone knows it'll
take a minute or 2 to remove.

3/  If you install fake alarm stickers (you use stickers but you don't have any
alarm), ask for real stickers !  The ones they sell with the flashing lights are
too lousy to be real !

4/  My opinion is that your goal is to show the burglar that there are many
other cars to break into than yours. 

If someone really wants to attack your car, don't doubt he will do it.  The
protection is to prevent him to try.  After it's too late.


I tought it was forbidden in the states (and in Canada too) too let anything
noticeable in a car.  Is it true ?

This would be a great idea if people takes this habit in France.  Here, cars look
like shops.  You'll see CD players removable but not removed, coats, phones, ...


Pierre F-F.

------------------------------

Date:    Tue, 07 Feb 95 04:59 EST
From: "Colin Murray - (SUKCBM)"                   <SUKCBM@MVS.SAS.COM>
Subject: (Copy) gear linkage rattle


Hi there
My '87 924s has just developed a rather disturbing rattle in the rear.
It only happens at low revs and in second gear. It sounds like the
gear linkage is hitting the bodywork or something else. In all the
other gears or at speed, no rattle.

MYSTERY SOLVED....
Thanks for all the suggestions but the solution was even stranger than
I thought.

My car has rear seatbelts fitted and the lower anchor point is secured
by a bolt that protrudes into the central tunnel. The bolt that was
used was too long and the gear linkage was vibrating against the bolt
in second.

Thanks to the poor mechanic who sat in the back while I drove around
in second gear for twenty minutes while he tapped, prodded and poked
untill this discovery.

Colin Murray - sukcbm@mvs.sas.com
87 924s (no more rattle, a great car!!!)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 11:19:13 +0000 (GMT)
From: pauls@dcs.rhbnc.ac.uk
Subject: Boxster retooling to end 968/928 production

Just something I read in Autocar a couple of weeks ago - so this 
is from memory:

968 and 928 production will cease when the Zuffenhausen (sp) factory
is retooled ready for Boxster (986) production.

Also, I don't remember anyone saying anything much about the new 911 Turbo,
Autocar gave the spec of 404hp (UK) for the twin-turbo (2 intercooler) 911
with the simpler 4 wheel drive a la the 993 C4. 

Just for your information!

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 07:36:37 -0500
From: PSalter@aol.com
Subject: 84 Carrera oil press. light prob

Hopefully someone can give me a meaningful answer about 
oil pressure and other  problems I started having this morning.

The outside air temp was as low as 15*f. this morning when I started
the engine. I noticed the oil level gauge was in the red but I had good
oil pressure. I stopped and checked the oil level and found it to be
between the hi and low marks. I also have had the oil pressure light
dimly glowing.   As the engine warmed, the oil level indicator moved
into the middle range of the gauge. 

As I drove the car about 40 miles with no unusual occurances.

On the way home after dark, lights on, heater fan running , the lights
began to dim.  The engine started running rough and I had to pull over.  I
went to an autoparts store, purchased a new battery and continued home
without futher problems. 

I wonder if someone could have switched the lights, plugging the alt.
light in the oil light recepticle and visa versa. 

That would not explain the oil level gauge problem I had.

Any help would be appreciated.

Phil Salter

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 07:52:58 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: alarm stickers...

>>
>>When I purchased my '83 928S, I too didn't get a master key. Had one made.
>>Found it does not fit in the driver's door (too long.) Is this correct or
>>has somebody plugged my lock? 
>>
On the other hand, I got only the master key for my '84. It fits both doors,
the hatch, and the ignition. It activates and de-activates the alarm from
the passenger door and the hatch, but not the driver door - I assume that
the switch there has gone bad. The wires that connect the switch in the
door across the hinge to the body are in a separate harness, which makes
me think the alarm is an option; incidentally that makes a convenient
spot (the connector) to see whether contacts are doing what they should
if your alarm is malfunctioning.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 09:24:16 -0500
From: Fred Pack <fhp@unipress.com>
Subject: Stan's 914

The response continues to be gratifying.  By Tuesday AM, there have been 85
people who indicated willingness to chip in to help Stan be able to keep his
914 racecar.

We readers of porschephiles have all gotten much benefit out of the list -- at
no cost to us, but at the cost of lots of Stan's time.  Now we can help him
out by contributing a very small amount, $15, so he can afford to keep his
pride&joy.

Send me a message (fhp@unipress.com) if you're willing to contribute. Read
the details below.


++++ MY ORIGINAL MESSAGE ++++++++++++++

I think that the person who suggested that we porschephiles
contribute to buy Stan's 914 racecar for Stan had a very good idea.


Here's my thought:

There are about 500 people on the list (More, I think. I haven't kept the
recent listing of all the names.)

Stan wants $7000 for his car. 

This works out to approx $10-$15 per person.  We have each SURELY gotten this
much value and enjoyment out of pfiles.

SO -- Here's my suggestion:

Each person willing to donate $15 (or more!) should send me an email
off-line, stating his email and willingness to contribute $15. If I get a
critical mass of these I'll let everyone know and the pledgees can actually
make their donations.


		     SEND ME THESE EMAILS BY FEB 11 !!!

If too Few sign up, the idea is a Did Not Start. If Many sign up it's a Go.
If Very Many sign up, the rate per person goes down.

I'll let everyone know the results by Feb 15.

OK???


Fred Pack					fhp@unipress.com
UniPress Software				phone: (908) 287-2100
2025 Lincoln Highway				fax:   (908) 287-4929
Edison NJ 08817					http://www.unipress.com/

'89 944S2
'73 914 2.0L

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 08:33:00 -0600
From: u5c42@lfht1.hso.link.com (Wayne Michelsen)
Subject: Alternator

Last night, I noticed that my battery light was starting to brighten.  The
intensity is real low, but having had alternator problems, I'm sensitive to
this thing.  At idle, the light was barely on.  At higher RPM, it got
brighter.  I'm not thoroughly familiar with the charge system circuitry on
my '87 911.  What exactly is this an indication of?  I installed a rebuilt
alternator, new battery and new V-regulator about 8 months ago.  Is one of
these components failing, or is this charge indication normal?  I've never
noticed it before.

Thanks to all.

  '87 911 Targa [Guards-Red/Black]  | RedAcorn@aol.com

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 07:48:56 MST
From: J.Jones@az05.bull.com (    John Jones [e])
Subject: 928S4 In The Water

I was looking at a car advertized in the local paper. 88 924S4. The car has
apparently been in water. How much I don't know. The story is someone lost it
and ran into some water. The story is supported by damaged wheels on one side.
Anyone know of this car? It's brown. Or of a wrecked but mechanically sound
S4? Anyone dealt with a car that's been in the water? There is no direct
evidence of any water damage, water marks inside or out and no silt apparent
in the engine compartment. In the event the exhaust, transmission etc were
submerged what the likelyhood of internal contamination? What the diagnosis
/treatment.

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 09:55:11 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: 928 Hatch release

>>
>>	The motor to open the rear deck on a 1990 928 is not being actuated when
>>the releases are pulled or the rear deck key is tried.  The fuse is fine.
>>Can anyone shed some light on this failure?  How do you release the latch?
>>
The key in the hatch lid is a mechanical release, at least on the '84.
It does not cause the motor to run. The motor operates on the other
side of the latch mechanism. That is, there are two overlapping
pieces which hold the hatch closed, and if either one retracts, the
hatch can open. The hatch key retracts one, the hatch motor the
other.

As I recall, the hatch motor won't run unless a door is open, presumably
as a safety measure to keep curious fingers from popping the hatch at
speed. Do your interior lights come on when you open the door? If not,
that's the thing to fix first. Beyond that, the motor is right behind
the removable panel that holds tools - look for voltage there and
work your way back - the pull-switches are easily accessible also.
I guess the first thing to figure out is why the mechanical release
doesn't work - fixing that may be all you want or need anyway, since
the electrical release is neither reliable or very useful.

 -John White-
'84 928S


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 07:00 PST
From: bart@research.att.com (Bart N. Locanthi)
Subject: lasers

>Dear Geek of the Week <g>,
> 
>Your laser pulses are 100 fs in duration, so 100 x 10^^-15? C = 3x10^^10
>cm/sec, then your pulses are 0.003 cm long? Wowsers. Can they do that?
>That means if the pulses are, say, red light, what, 600 nm wavelength, each
>pulse is just 50 waves long? Did I do a math mistake?

perhaps they *can* do this, but why bother?  is laser speed detection works
via doppler (on the modulation, not on the .. uhh .. blue shift), it's pretty
likely that the modulation does not exceed a few MHz.

laser diodes are plenty fast, and in the controlled environment of fiber
communications, the pin diodes and surrounding circuitry can be too, but
through the air ir detection with ambient light et al means you're basically
going for max gain in a narrow bandwidth.  detecting a few nA in all that
noise is hard enough without repeating the microwave shit that lasers and
the non-intervention of the fcc give you for free with light.

but this is all smoke.  call mike valentine - he's always willing to chat,
and he knows about porschephiles (though last i knew he wasn't online)
and was *really* jazzed by the stan's www site.


 -bart

Peter,

  | perfectly happy with a coupe. What would be the best reading material so I 
  | could get some background information?

I would suggest that you get these Books; 

The 356 technichal and restoration guide, $19.95 (summary of 20 years of articles
from 356 Registry.)

The restorers guide to Authenticity (?) app. $ 25      (for 356 series)

Driving in it's Purest form. $ 64.95 (as refernce )

Join the 356 registry.

I would recommend buying a T-6 model as first car, then you're left
with B and C models. 
The T-6 is perhaps the easiest and 'cheapest' 356 to restore, more parts on the market. 
They are also more comfortable drivers, and have had less years to
rust... :)

cheers,
Trond V.

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 10:27:49 -0500 (EST)

Subject: Re: Porche Factory Tours

I was at the factory in 87 and arrived there without arranging for a 
tour. Luckily, there was a group of visiting American Mormons and asked 
management to include us on their tour (thanks, Mormons!). 

The point is, you *must* prearrange a tour through the factory/museum. By 
the way, the Porsche Museum is worth the trip alone; blows the D-B museum 
away because all the cars are within inches of each other--and you!


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 10:55:12 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 air flow meter proble...

I experienced  a similar problem several years back and found that the clamps
on the big black intake hose mounted on the back of the meter unit we loose
and were leaking air into the system.

A change of accelerator pressure can cause the motor to move on its mounts
opening or closing the air gap if the hose is loose

Date: 7 Feb 95 11:10:00 EST
From: GIBBS@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com
Subject: Space shuttles, lasers, and geeks

I once toured the Stanford Linear Accelerator in Palo Alto.  This is basically a 1/4 mile 
long waveguide that is pumped by 256 1 megawatt klystrons (microwave tubes).  When they 
fire, it up an inmmensely powerful microwave pulse travels the length of the device.
At the starting end a bunch of electrons is injected, and gets caught in the "trough" 
between two cycles of the microwave radiation.  The electrons ride along there, (technically,
"surfing" the wavefront), and are accelerated to near the speed of light.  According to the 
tour guide, the electrons (which, unlike a laser pulse, actually have mass) hit 99% of the 
speed of light in the first 10 feet.  The remaining length of the accelerator is to get them 
up to 99.999999 or so percent.  I remember thinking what a kick that must be, and what it 
would be like to ride one of those electrons.  0 to 667,000,000 MPH in 10 feet!

There.  Now I'm geek of the week!

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All mine!


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 10:15:33 -0600
From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: 944 Power Steering Hose Leaks


There have been several items on 944 power steering hose leakage
lately.  This seems to be a chronic problem with 944s and I have
not been spared.

The first thing I tried to staunch the flow was change out the
original hose clamps for the improved version - I forget the numbers
but they are available from your friendly Porsche dealer.  This
sufficed for awhile but recently the flow turned into a mini torrent.

I thought I might be able to pull the hoses, trim them a bit to get
to 'fresh' rubber and reinstall.  Alas, the hopes of the terminally
naive!  The hose to the cooler went back on OK but the hose which
runs to the pump disintegrated.  At this point (Sunday afternoon,
no P-parts places open and car needed to get to place of employment
the next day) I got desparate and took a piece of heavy wall Tygon
tubing which I think had about a 1/2" ID and installed it in place
of the dearly departed hose.  Anyway, it fit and best of all it does
not leak whatever!  Since it is more flexible than the original I
took extra care in routing it so that it would not contact anything
it is not supposed to.

I did this replacement as an emergency measure but seems to be
working so well I may keep it.  Folks at work here don't think there
should be any material incompatibility problem and the temperatures
are withing the Tygon's spec range.  Anyone out there in 'Phile
land know whether I am courting disaster?

John

------------------------------

Date: 07 Feb 95 11:32:29 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Radar detector range

 
Arthur Golden writes that
>physics tells me that 3 ft over 2800 ft (1/2 mile) only gives a marginal,
>if any real, gain and since we don't live in a perfect world, the bouncing
>of radar signals should find any detector as long as it's facing the
>correct direction.
 
No flames intended, Arthur, but my own personal experience says that the
mounting height of a radar detector makes a huge difference in detector
range. A few years ago I was involved in testing various brands of detectors
(including the new Valentine One) as a subcontractor to a consultant working
for the association of radar detector manufacturers. Their organization,
RADAR, paid for the testing to quantify some numbers. We had two or three
randomly bought examples of each model to choose from. We tested on a flat,
straight, 4-mile-long desert road (yes, the famous Mrs. Orcutt's Driveway).
I don't have the numbers handy, but in all cases, mounting the detector at the
top of the windshield gave a much longer range than having it on top of the
dash. Maybe 50%, maybe even 100 percent longer? I don't recall exactly, but
it was significant. Mounting it down low, maybe as a fake foglight, will
make it even worse. When dealing with instant-on radar, you want to detect
enemy radar <g> when he is shooting at traffic ahead of you, intermittently.
If your range is significantly shortened by poor mounting location, you may
be in his sights without having detected his earlier shots.
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 95 10:58:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 air flow meter problem ???


Trev,

Could very well be your problem.  The air flow meters do go bad.  Their
are two failure modes I am familiar with:

1. The barn door hangs up,
2. The metering resistive element fails (wears through).

You can check #1 roughly by removing the inlet side boot and manipulating
the barn door with your fingers.  However, your fingers are a little 
different
from air (detailed explanation available upon request), and I would also
do the following.

Hook up a voltmeter across two pins of the air flow meter cable, but with
it nonetheless fully hooked up.  I forget which two, and they probably 
depend
on your model and year anyways.  With the engine off but the electrics
otherwise on, sweep the barn door from closed to WOT and back a few
times.  Look for a progressive and smooth output signal, no jumps or
spikes.  This tests #2.  I forget the correct min and max voltages.  They
are in the manual; however I don't think you need to know them for the
problem at hand.

Now run the engine.  At the throttle cam, manipulate it to bring the engine
up from idle to high RPM, then down, and do this a few times.  You are again
looking for smooth continuous changes, indicating both that the resistive
element is OK and that induced air is able to move the barn door freely.

I find it easiest to pop the black plastic lid off the air flow meter and 
hook the
voltmeter up on the inside of the connector.  This also lets me observe the
sweep of the armature, and visually inspect the condition of the resistive
element.  However, some cars mount the AFM "upside down," making
access to the lid difficult.  (I think the 944S2 is this way.)

If the resistive element is pitted or worn, you may be able to eke a little 
more
life out of it by relocating the swept arm's contacts a little in or out, 
radially.
This is done by changing the bend of the sweeping arm a tad.

BTW, perhaps it is my own incompetence or misunderstanding.  But I have
never been able to get a useful impedence sweep from an AFM.  That is,
unplugging it and hooking an ohmmeter across the contacts doesn't seem
to work.  You have to hook it up, turn on the electrics, and use a 
voltmeter.
No idea why, but this is what the factory manuals tell you to do.

Realistically, though, if your AFM is bad, buy a new used one from George
Beuselinck at 944 Ecology.  You do not want to know what a new one costs
from PCNA, believe me.  There are plenty of good used ones out there, and
that is certainly the route I would follow.

Hope this helps.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 95 11:00:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>

It is certainly possible.  I think that on the Carreras, the connectors just
