Kevin

------------------------------

Date: 07 Feb 95 09:14:13 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Electromotive Crankfire


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Electromotive Crankfire
Date: 1995-02-07 11:10
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


>I've the opportunity to purchase a used electromotive crankfire ignition
for
>a 911.  Are there any gotchas to watch out for when purchasing a used unit?
>Bad coil, etc?

Jeff,  I'm just catching up on some mail after a business trip...

I'm using a used Electromotive crankfire and love it]  mine even looked
pretty kludgy as the pickup wire was silicone sealed to the unit (was pulled
off in a previous life).  I spoke to a guy down in Houston that enduro races
a GT 911 w/ Electromotive -- he said the unit is EXTREMELY durable.  I
myself have had zero problems with the unit itself in 1.5 years of use.
 Mine is the one that has the 3 pack of coils and the 4 pots under a cover
(1 sets init adv., 1 sets 3K, and 1 sets 8k adv., and the last is rev
limit).  Some things I learned form experience and from others:

Use the notch-tooth style trigger wheel.  I started off with the saw-tooth
style and had countless plug fouling problems.  the notch-tooth style wheel
solved this AND seems to have given smoother overall power.

Set advance and rev. limiter *ONLY* with a timing light and accurate tach.
 the indicators on the pots are way off on mine (this may be obvious to
you).

The rev-limiter is extremely smooth at cut-out and it's great that it's so
easy to adjust -- at last year's Pro Solo Finale there was a short chute
that we ran the top of 2nd thru, we were hitting the rev limiter mid way
thru and there was a hard turn right after it (wasn't worth a shift).  We
found we were subconsciously backing off the throttle and loosing some time
 -- so I just bumped the limiter up a few hundred rpm and it worked great]
 Talking to a 911 co-competitor, Rex Carle, who runs a Motronic/Mass flow
set up, they were either having to shift or run thru slower in 2nd...

Good luck]

 -Scott Jessen

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 07:52:58 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: alarm stickers...

>>
>>When I purchased my '83 928S, I too didn't get a master key. Had one made.
>>Found it does not fit in the driver's door (too long.) Is this correct or
>>has somebody plugged my lock? 
>>
On the other hand, I got only the master key for my '84. It fits both doors,
the hatch, and the ignition. It activates and de-activates the alarm from
the passenger door and the hatch, but not the driver door - I assume that
the switch there has gone bad. The wires that connect the switch in the
door across the hinge to the body are in a separate harness, which makes
me think the alarm is an option; incidentally that makes a convenient
spot (the connector) to see whether contacts are doing what they should
if your alarm is malfunctioning.

 -John White-
'84 928S

no cost to us, but at the cost of lots of Stan's time.  Now we can help him
out by contributing a very small amount, $15, so he can afford to keep his
pride&joy.

Send me a message (fhp@unipress.com) if you're willing to contribute. Read
the details below.


++++ MY ORIGINAL MESSAGE ++++++++++++++

I think that the person who suggested that we porschephiles
contribute to buy Stan's 914 racecar for Stan had a very good idea.


Here's my thought:

There are about 500 people on the list (More, I think. I haven't kept the
recent listing of all the names.)

Stan wants $7000 for his car. 

This works out to approx $10-$15 per person.  We have each SURELY gotten this
much value and enjoyment out of pfiles.

SO -- Here's my suggestion:

Each person willing to donate $15 (or more!) should send me an email
off-line, stating his email and willingness to contribute $15. If I get a
critical mass of these I'll let everyone know and the pledgees can actually
make their donations.


		     SEND ME THESE EMAILS BY FEB 11 !!!

If too Few sign up, the idea is a Did Not Start. If Many sign up it's a Go.
If Very Many sign up, the rate per person goes down.

I'll let everyone know the results by Feb 15.

OK???

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 07:48:56 MST
From: J.Jones@az05.bull.com (    John Jones [e])
Subject: 928S4 In The Water

I was looking at a car advertized in the local paper. 88 924S4. The car has
apparently been in water. How much I don't know. The story is someone lost it
and ran into some water. The story is supported by damaged wheels on one side.
Anyone know of this car? It's brown. Or of a wrecked but mechanically sound
S4? Anyone dealt with a car that's been in the water? There is no direct
evidence of any water damage, water marks inside or out and no silt apparent
in the engine compartment. In the event the exhaust, transmission etc were
submerged what the likelyhood of internal contamination? What the diagnosis
/treatment.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 09:55:11 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: 928 Hatch release

>>
>>	The motor to open the rear deck on a 1990 928 is not being actuated when
>>the releases are pulled or the rear deck key is tried.  The fuse is fine.
>>Can anyone shed some light on this failure?  How do you release the latch?
>>
The key in the hatch lid is a mechanical release, at least on the '84.
It does not cause the motor to run. The motor operates on the other
side of the latch mechanism. That is, there are two overlapping
pieces which hold the hatch closed, and if either one retracts, the
hatch can open. The hatch key retracts one, the hatch motor the
other.

As I recall, the hatch motor won't run unless a door is open, presumably
as a safety measure to keep curious fingers from popping the hatch at
speed. Do your interior lights come on when you open the door? If not,
that's the thing to fix first. Beyond that, the motor is right behind
the removable panel that holds tools - look for voltage there and
work your way back - the pull-switches are easily accessible also.
I guess the first thing to figure out is why the mechanical release
doesn't work - fixing that may be all you want or need anyway, since
the electrical release is neither reliable or very useful.

 -John White-
'84 928S


------------------------------

that I would like a "newer" model like "B" or "C" but I would really like

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 07:00 PST
From: bart@research.att.com (Bart N. Locanthi)
Subject: lasers

>Dear Geek of the Week <g>,
> 
>Your laser pulses are 100 fs in duration, so 100 x 10^^-15? C = 3x10^^10
>cm/sec, then your pulses are 0.003 cm long? Wowsers. Can they do that?
>That means if the pulses are, say, red light, what, 600 nm wavelength, each
>pulse is just 50 waves long? Did I do a math mistake?

perhaps they *can* do this, but why bother?  is laser speed detection works
via doppler (on the modulation, not on the .. uhh .. blue shift), it's pretty
likely that the modulation does not exceed a few MHz.

laser diodes are plenty fast, and in the controlled environment of fiber
communications, the pin diodes and surrounding circuitry can be too, but
through the air ir detection with ambient light et al means you're basically
going for max gain in a narrow bandwidth.  detecting a few nA in all that
noise is hard enough without repeating the microwave shit that lasers and
the non-intervention of the fcc give you for free with light.

but this is all smoke.  call mike valentine - he's always willing to chat,
and he knows about porschephiles (though last i knew he wasn't online)
and was *really* jazzed by the stan's www site.


 -bart

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 16:26:34 +0100
From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: Re:356 Restoration

Peter,

  | perfectly happy with a coupe. What would be the best reading material so I 
  | could get some background information?

I would suggest that you get these Books; 

The 356 technichal and restoration guide, $19.95 (summary of 20 years of articles
from 356 Registry.)

The restorers guide to Authenticity (?) app. $ 25      (for 356 series)

Driving in it's Purest form. $ 64.95 (as refernce )

Join the 356 registry.

I would recommend buying a T-6 model as first car, then you're left
with B and C models. 
The T-6 is perhaps the easiest and 'cheapest' 356 to restore, more parts on the market. 
They are also more comfortable drivers, and have had less years to
rust... :)

cheers,
Trond V.

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 10:27:49 -0500 (EST)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: Porche Factory Tours

I was at the factory in 87 and arrived there without arranging for a 
tour. Luckily, there was a group of visiting American Mormons and asked 
management to include us on their tour (thanks, Mormons!). 

The point is, you *must* prearrange a tour through the factory/museum. By 
the way, the Porsche Museum is worth the trip alone; blows the D-B museum 
away because all the cars are within inches of each other--and you!


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 10:55:12 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 air flow meter proble...

I experienced  a similar problem several years back and found that the clamps
on the big black intake hose mounted on the back of the meter unit we loose
and were leaking air into the system.

A change of accelerator pressure can cause the motor to move on its mounts
opening or closing the air gap if the hose is loose

Date: 7 Feb 95 11:10:00 EST
From: GIBBS@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com
Subject: Space shuttles, lasers, and geeks

I once toured the Stanford Linear Accelerator in Palo Alto.  This is basically a 1/4 mile 
long waveguide that is pumped by 256 1 megawatt klystrons (microwave tubes).  When they 
fire, it up an inmmensely powerful microwave pulse travels the length of the device.
At the starting end a bunch of electrons is injected, and gets caught in the "trough" 
between two cycles of the microwave radiation.  The electrons ride along there, (technically,
"surfing" the wavefront), and are accelerated to near the speed of light.  According to the 
tour guide, the electrons (which, unlike a laser pulse, actually have mass) hit 99% of the 
speed of light in the first 10 feet.  The remaining length of the accelerator is to get them 
up to 99.999999 or so percent.  I remember thinking what a kick that must be, and what it 
would be like to ride one of those electrons.  0 to 667,000,000 MPH in 10 feet!

There.  Now I'm geek of the week!

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All mine!


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 10:15:33 -0600
From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: 944 Power Steering Hose Leaks


There have been several items on 944 power steering hose leakage
lately.  This seems to be a chronic problem with 944s and I have
not been spared.

The first thing I tried to staunch the flow was change out the
original hose clamps for the improved version - I forget the numbers
but they are available from your friendly Porsche dealer.  This
sufficed for awhile but recently the flow turned into a mini torrent.

I thought I might be able to pull the hoses, trim them a bit to get
to 'fresh' rubber and reinstall.  Alas, the hopes of the terminally
naive!  The hose to the cooler went back on OK but the hose which
runs to the pump disintegrated.  At this point (Sunday afternoon,
no P-parts places open and car needed to get to place of employment
the next day) I got desparate and took a piece of heavy wall Tygon
tubing which I think had about a 1/2" ID and installed it in place
of the dearly departed hose.  Anyway, it fit and best of all it does
not leak whatever!  Since it is more flexible than the original I
took extra care in routing it so that it would not contact anything
it is not supposed to.

I did this replacement as an emergency measure but seems to be
working so well I may keep it.  Folks at work here don't think there
should be any material incompatibility problem and the temperatures
are withing the Tygon's spec range.  Anyone out there in 'Phile
land know whether I am courting disaster?

John

------------------------------

Date: 07 Feb 95 11:32:29 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Radar detector range

 
Arthur Golden writes that
>physics tells me that 3 ft over 2800 ft (1/2 mile) only gives a marginal,
>if any real, gain and since we don't live in a perfect world, the bouncing
>of radar signals should find any detector as long as it's facing the
>correct direction.
 
No flames intended, Arthur, but my own personal experience says that the
mounting height of a radar detector makes a huge difference in detector
range. A few years ago I was involved in testing various brands of detectors
(including the new Valentine One) as a subcontractor to a consultant working
for the association of radar detector manufacturers. Their organization,
RADAR, paid for the testing to quantify some numbers. We had two or three
randomly bought examples of each model to choose from. We tested on a flat,
straight, 4-mile-long desert road (yes, the famous Mrs. Orcutt's Driveway).
I don't have the numbers handy, but in all cases, mounting the detector at the
top of the windshield gave a much longer range than having it on top of the
dash. Maybe 50%, maybe even 100 percent longer? I don't recall exactly, but
it was significant. Mounting it down low, maybe as a fake foglight, will
make it even worse. When dealing with instant-on radar, you want to detect
enemy radar <g> when he is shooting at traffic ahead of you, intermittently.
If your range is significantly shortened by poor mounting location, you may
be in his sights without having detected his earlier shots.
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 95 10:58:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 air flow meter problem ???


Trev,

Could very well be your problem.  The air flow meters do go bad.  Their
are two failure modes I am familiar with:

1. The barn door hangs up,
2. The metering resistive element fails (wears through).

You can check #1 roughly by removing the inlet side boot and manipulating
the barn door with your fingers.  However, your fingers are a little 
different
from air (detailed explanation available upon request), and I would also
do the following.

Hook up a voltmeter across two pins of the air flow meter cable, but with
it nonetheless fully hooked up.  I forget which two, and they probably 
depend
on your model and year anyways.  With the engine off but the electrics
otherwise on, sweep the barn door from closed to WOT and back a few
times.  Look for a progressive and smooth output signal, no jumps or
spikes.  This tests #2.  I forget the correct min and max voltages.  They
are in the manual; however I don't think you need to know them for the
problem at hand.

Now run the engine.  At the throttle cam, manipulate it to bring the engine
up from idle to high RPM, then down, and do this a few times.  You are again
looking for smooth continuous changes, indicating both that the resistive
element is OK and that induced air is able to move the barn door freely.

I find it easiest to pop the black plastic lid off the air flow meter and 
hook the
voltmeter up on the inside of the connector.  This also lets me observe the
sweep of the armature, and visually inspect the condition of the resistive
element.  However, some cars mount the AFM "upside down," making
access to the lid difficult.  (I think the 944S2 is this way.)

If the resistive element is pitted or worn, you may be able to eke a little 
more
life out of it by relocating the swept arm's contacts a little in or out, 
radially.
This is done by changing the bend of the sweeping arm a tad.

BTW, perhaps it is my own incompetence or misunderstanding.  But I have
never been able to get a useful impedence sweep from an AFM.  That is,
unplugging it and hooking an ohmmeter across the contacts doesn't seem
to work.  You have to hook it up, turn on the electrics, and use a 
voltmeter.
No idea why, but this is what the factory manuals tell you to do.

Realistically, though, if your AFM is bad, buy a new used one from George
Beuselinck at 944 Ecology.  You do not want to know what a new one costs
from PCNA, believe me.  There are plenty of good used ones out there, and
that is certainly the route I would follow.

Hope this helps.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: 07 Feb 95 09:14:13 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Electromotive Crankfire


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Electromotive Crankfire
Date: 1995-02-07 11:10
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------


>I've the opportunity to purchase a used electromotive crankfire ignition
for
>a 911.  Are there any gotchas to watch out for when purchasing a used unit?
>Bad coil, etc?

Jeff,  I'm just catching up on some mail after a business trip...

I'm using a used Electromotive crankfire and love it]  mine even looked
pretty kludgy as the pickup wire was silicone sealed to the unit (was pulled
off in a previous life).  I spoke to a guy down in Houston that enduro races
a GT 911 w/ Electromotive -- he said the unit is EXTREMELY durable.  I
myself have had zero problems with the unit itself in 1.5 years of use.
 Mine is the one that has the 3 pack of coils and the 4 pots under a cover
(1 sets init adv., 1 sets 3K, and 1 sets 8k adv., and the last is rev
limit).  Some things I learned form experience and from others:

Use the notch-tooth style trigger wheel.  I started off with the saw-tooth
style and had countless plug fouling problems.  the notch-tooth style wheel
solved this AND seems to have given smoother overall power.

Set advance and rev. limiter *ONLY* with a timing light and accurate tach.
 the indicators on the pots are way off on mine (this may be obvious to
you).

The rev-limiter is extremely smooth at cut-out and it's great that it's so
easy to adjust -- at last year's Pro Solo Finale there was a short chute
that we ran the top of 2nd thru, we were hitting the rev limiter mid way
thru and there was a hard turn right after it (wasn't worth a shift).  We
found we were subconsciously backing off the throttle and loosing some time
 -- so I just bumped the limiter up a few hundred rpm and it worked great]
 Talking to a 911 co-competitor, Rex Carle, who runs a Motronic/Mass flow
set up, they were either having to shift or run thru slower in 2nd...

Good luck]

 -Scott Jessen



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 13:46:13 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Help with 914!!! :)


Dear Mike,

You wrote:

I have the most puzzling problem.  Here are the symptoms:

After the car warms up, the idle will drop to a very low rate, about
300RPM.  It'll then promptly return to about 1000RPM.  The 300 lasts
for about a second, and the 1000 RPM lasts for about 5 or
so seconds.  The process is repeated until the car just quits and 
stalls.  It is semi-periodic, and the intervals seem almost constant
for each period.

I can notice, when the idle drops, that bubbles in the return
fuel line cease to move, they stagnate in the return fuel line.
Also, the voltage across the terminals on the fuel pump drops
slightly, but I suspect that this is due to the stress on the
alternator from the low idle state.

The car is a 1973 914/4 1.7L.

The fuel pump is a (new) refurbished unit, and I have a new head temperature
sensor as well.

Do you have any idea what this could be caused by?  I'm about to place
an order for other stuff to Auto Atlanta, and would like to pick
up any parts that could help remedy this problem.  BTW, some sleaze-
ball stole the Wolfsberg emblem from the front of the car.  Do you
sell those (couldn't find them in the catalog)?


Thanks for any help,


It sounds like you have an intermittant miss. This could be caused obviously
by a number of things. To test, remove and install all plug wires loosely in
the distibutor cap and then when the problem occurs, disconnect one wire at a
time noting which one does not make an idle difference. This is the cylinder
suspect. If diagonal cylinders are not firing, trigger points are suspect. If
two cylinders on one side are not firing, ground leads are suspect.

Check as well the charge rate at the battery terminals. It should be about
13.6. If it fluctuates radically (for example up to 15 volts), the voltage
regulator has failed and must immediately be replaced and the acid spill
around the battery area neutralized.

Finally, where is the Wolfsberg emblem located on a 914 other than a Euro
model steering wheel center horn pad? Inquiring minds want to know!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 13:51:52 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 front end clunk (?)


Dear Josh,

You wrote:
Hi all,

        Well after a three week hiatus from my car it decided that the best
way to welcome me home is to make a new noise.

        '74 914 2.0L no sway bar, stock suspension w/Rs tires

        Under heavy braking I can hear -and- feel a clunk coming from the
front left suspension, right in front (I think) of the foot pedals. Any
idea off hand what this could be? I don't seem to notice anything in turns.
Thanks. 

        BTW my new/rebuilt transmission from HPH is running like a charm :)
It cost me a pretty penny, but after the fiascos I dealt with elsewhere,
the cost was worth it.


Josh,
Usually the front clunk when braking or bumping is caused by a 100SE front
strut. The nut insert loosens and the cartridge clunks as it moves up and
down. This can easily be solved by elevating the car, dropping the strut,
removing the cone cover and tightening the nut insert. This would also be a
good time to check the strut inserts for wear as worn out ones could also
clunk.

George Hussey

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 11:16:08 -0800

Subject: unsuscribe

It is too much for me, so I must bid adieu.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 11:24:10 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: Dealers


You all know you can't trust a dealer, right?

When the 944 Turbos first arrived in late 1985, the local dealer I did business 
with sold a friend of mine a new one. The next day he brought it to an autocross
and let me drive it. He said the front was a little stiffer than he expected.

I made 1/2 a lap and pulled off when I drove it. It wasn't just a little stiff,
it didn't move! I jacked the front of the car up to take a look. For shipment,
Porsche had installed a rubber collar that kept the front springs in the 
longest extension so the nose would clear transporter ramps, ship ramps, etc.

A pair of wire cutters and some tugging removed the collars and the car handled 
much better. A quick survey revealed that, of the 40 or so initially delivered
in Northern California, 25 were delivered with the collars still on the car.
Dave Colman received a Turbo for a road test with the collars still on. 

In deference to the dealers, only a handful had received any notification about
this and most of the prep groups figured it out themselves. 

Incidentally, I haven't seen the collars on any Concours 944 Turbos. This would 
truely be in "as-delivered" condition.


Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 11:28:56 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Update on pop-off valve installation screwup...


Well, I put the 911 back on the road. I ended up using JB Weld to patch 
the small hole that I put in the top of the cold-start air distribution
mainifold. I experimented with JB weld on some scrap aluminum. I even
baked it at 500C in the oven to see how it holds out. Man, that is 
tough stuff!! If the service is clean, the adhesion is really good. 
Anyways, I used a small piece of metal mesh and some JB Weld to form
a plug on top of the hole (The mesh is to prevent any small pieces breaking
off and getting ingested). I also used the JB Weld on the pop-off
valve. Great stuff.

The 911 is back on the road early because of my winter junker (82 civic)
tranny siezed solid at an intersection. I was nursing the tranny over the
last few months, but I thought that maybe I could get another month
out of it...guesss not. The weather in vancouver is really mild this year
(only froze a couple of times), and driving the p-car is a real blast.

Mike
83 911SC

Date: 07 Feb 95 11:33:30 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: '84 911 questions


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  '84 911 questions
Date: 1995-02-07 13:26

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I finally got a chance last weekend to play with our new (read someone
else's "old") baby ('84 911) and I've got a few questions for those in the
know with Motronics and early 80s 911 Carrera's:

The car has a subtle surge that you can feel most in the lower gears when
running at constant RPM or accelerating mildly to moderately up to about 5K
rpm, it also oscillates at idle when warmed up.  Under hard acceleration it
seems ok.  I loaded it up with a tank of Techron treated fuel and after 1/4
tank it got *worse*.  I then swapped out the O2 sensor with an old one I had
taken off our other Carrera (unknown if it's any good either), and after a
couple of miles it went back to it's "subtle" surge as before.  My question
before I shell out the $$s for a new sensor: are there other things I should
chase down first, or in parallel?  I have an O2 sensor off a low miles'88
motor that has a different plug end -- any problem if I just splice on the
plugs that'll work for my year?  There are three wires that go to the
sensor, I believe two are for preheat and one is the output; does it matter
how the two preheat ones are hooked up (hazardous if switched around)?

Next question:
The odometer has stopped reading, the speedo works tho.  Stan gave me the
name/address of a local VDO person, but I was wondering if anyone out there
has tried to debug one of these (electronic) units? Or even better yet, does
someone have one they'd like to sell?

Last question:
There is a cluster of 3 lights on the dash that consists of the Brake,
Seatbelt and a circle with little dashes around it.  Is this third one the
low-brake lining warning light?  It stays on all the time and I have checked
the pads -- plenty of pad left.  Since I over maintain things and don't need
the light to tell me my pads are worn, can I cut the wires at the pads to
turn it off ?(I doubt cool carbons will have the right sensor any way ;-))


Thanks in advance,
 -Scott Jessen

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 11:42:13 PST
From: juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas)
Subject: Tranny Plug removal update..


I asked some questions about removing a **really** tight 915 drain plug
a while back. This is what happened:

1) The 17mm hex socket stripped out (It was already almost stripped..the
   previous mechanic should have replaced it!!)

2) I tried to use a chisel/hammer to start it to spin. No luck and cut 
   away some of the plug.

3) I used a dremel tool with a carbide bit to cut two slots across the plug,
   and used a solid steel dowel with a pin to try to unscrew it. No such
   luck, I sheared off the rest of the plug so it was pratically flush 
   with the bottom of the tranny.

Now things get serious...

4) I drilled two 1/8" holes through the plug opposite to each other inside
   the socket portion of the plug. I let that drain overnight.

5) I tried another steel dowl with 2 hardened steel pins protruding from the
   bottom of the dowel to unscrew the plug. No such luck, kept bending the pins.

7) Drilled a series of 1/8" holes around the inside of the plug, carefully keeping
   to the side to avoid the magnet at the center of the plug (I bought a new plug
   by then)

8) I then spent over an hour using the dremel tool to "hollow" out between the
   drill holes while carefully not going too deep to allow the shavings to get
   into the tranny.

9) I finially removed the center of the drain plug. The shavings that did get into 
   the tranny where attracted to the magnet that was still attatched to the center
   of the plug.

10) Another hour of grinding/filing to cut two grooves on each side of the cylndrical
    drain plug shell that was left in the tranny. Carefull not to grind down into the
    threads.

11) I partiall collasped the plug using a chisel/hammer. Plug would still not rotate.
    Grind some more...

12) Drove a 1/2 extention into the drain plug, and **finially** managed to start to 

    unscrew the plug....what a feeling!!!

13) Got the plug out. No damage to the threads on the tranny, and no sign of debris 
    in the tranny.

14) Fill the tranny with quakerstate gear oil, and license the car for a day, and 
    go about 50 miles

15) Return to the shop, drop the oil, and fill the tranny with Swepco. Complement 
    yourself on how nice that new drain plug is, and put the old drain plug on
    the wall as a momento.

All in all, serveral nights and lots of swearing just to change the tranny oil...
I wonder whats next?

Mike 83 911SC with new swepco in the tranny.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 09:16:46 -0800
From: gblanche@qntm.com
Subject: Alarms and other deterrents...

One thing that I think is important when trying to deter theft, is to 
make sure the "would-be-thief" knows what he's up against BEFORE 
smashing your window.  There's nothing more frustrating than installing 
an alarm only to have the thief "double check" that the LED is really 
connected to an alarm brain.

Alpine (and I'm sure Clifford as well) offers an alarm with perimeter 
sensing.  Don't confuse this with those rediculous "talking alarms" 
which I'm convinced instigate more vandalism than they prevent.  "STEP 
BACK FROM THE CAR!"  Yeah, right!  What's you're average punk going to 
do when he hears that?!  The perimeter sensing I'm talking about is set 
for distances of about 1 foot around the car.  This detects a thief 
during the "peeking in the windows" phase of the crime, and lets out a 
single yelp from the siren and could flash the lights too.  This is 
enough to let them know that breaking in is probably more trouble than 
it's worth.

While I'm here, let me make a personal plea.  I know when you get an 
alarm system there's a temptation to set the motion/shock sensors to be 
very sensitive.  Yes you're alarm will go off and scare everyone 
initially, but after awhile you'll annoy everybody in your neighborhood 
and soon nobody (including yourself) will pay attention when something 
ACTUALLY happens.  And you can bet your neighbors won't be as helpful in 
watching out for your car if your alarm keeps waking them up in the 
middle of the night.

I'm sure Andy can help with current models that offer the "perimeter 
sensing" feature if anyone's interested...


Greg Blanchette
"A certifiable audio nut with a 1.474HP sound-system"

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 12:02:39 -0800
From: dthompsn@ix.netcom.com (William D. Thompson)
Subject: Radar detectors

Arthur Golden writes:

[Please no flames. There seems to be a little tension on the net lately. I'm 
merely playing counterpoint since everyone else seems to love the Valentine.

Luther, I own the Bel 615STiR (remote). It supports X, K, Ka, superwideband 
Ka, laser and has detection avoidance. I choose the remote because I drive 
through states where radars are illegal and if I understand the law 
correctly, they can ticket you if the radar is in the passanger compartment 
of the car (even if it's not on) but not if it's remote and your'e 
registered in a radar tolerant state.

Bel also makes a portable version with the same features. I have owned Bel 
radars since 1986 and have no complaints (or proof that they're better or 
worse than any other).

Also, someone stated that the lower remote mount does not have the distance 
of a higher portable. Physics tells me that 3 feet over 2800ft (1/2 mile) 
only gives a marginal, if any real, gain and since we don't live in a 
perfect world, the bouncing of radar signals should find any detector as 
long as it's facing the correct direction (stated for simplicity). I could 
be wrong.]

Arthur:  No flames intended here (not even a spark), but a couple of points 
for consideration:

In Virginia (where I live), the law states that radar detectors are illegal to 
"operate."  Courts have rules that having a detector in your car (windshield 
mounted or remote) is considered operation unless you can prove beyond all 
doubts that the unit could not have been operating (like no power cord 
attached).  Virginia State Troopers have been known to impound a car with a 
remote unit unless the owner could remove the detector on the spot.  One 
fellow PCA'r got out of a ticket by showing that no fuse was in the fuse 
holder of his remote detector (in fact, the fuse wire was a dummy.  He had a 
switch under the dash to shut off all power to the unit).

Second, every test of detectors that I have seen mentions mounting height as 
an important point.  Even a few feet apparently makes a difference.  Another 
concern about remote detectors is the fact that the antenna can become blocked 
by dirt (a real problem with laser).

I've owned a Bel unit and it's a good, well-made detector, which is why it 
nearly always finishes second in the comparisons.  The V1 usually finishes 
first.  It is just a better unit, IMHO.

- --Doug

------------------------------

Date: Tue,  7 Feb 95 14:11:59 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re: gastesters,O2,and 911 tuning (or, Gunson's guts)

>From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
>Subject: Gastester/O2 sensor/Tuning 911 MFI

>Friends,
>I've seen the JC Whitney CO tester discussed here and in other
>fora, and no one has been able to state definitively whether it is
>in fact a CO tester, or simply a garden variety O-2 sensor....
 (snip)
>Bob Spindel
>'72 911E

     Bob, I went home at lunch and opened mine up...as you might guess
  nothing very sophisticated in there, just one of those 50 Femtosecond
  pulsing lasers you see at Walgreens...

     :)  No, what I did find is this;
  1. The transducing element is _NOT_ a standard 02 sensor, but a
     center-tapped "wire" spring. One side of the spring is exposed
     to the Car gas, the other is carefully sealed (or, was carefully
     sealed until I took mine apart !) and probably just gets Oxygen.
  2. The main unit is probably a Wein Bridge, and contains a voltage
     regulator, a few diodes, and few passives, and the Meter movement.

  3. Does this really just test Oxygen and not CO ? I suppose yes, but
     according to Gunson's owner's manual they are essentially the same.
     CO is minimum at the lambda 14.7:1, and goes up as the mixture gets
     richer (their chart shows 8% CO at 12:1 mixture, the range of their
     gauge).

   4. As you mentioned, the Oxygen sensors available for cars are meant to
     work abruptly over a narrow range, according to the chart I have
     the output of the Oxygen sensor is about 600mv at 14.7:1, 200mv
     at 15.0:1 and  900mv at 14.5:1. Outside that range, the voltage/oxygen
     curve goes south and the curve gets asymptotic.  The air/fuel monitor
     from MSD is easy, as they just put a comparator at Lambda and pulse
     a "rich" or "Lean" led depending which side it falls on. The Edelbrock
     unit probably uses a string of comparators (to display 12:1 to 15:1
     a/f) each set up with the characteristic value of the standard oxygen
     sensor it uses.

   5. The hard part is that max power is reached around 13:1 ratio, max
     economy around 14.8:1 and absolute lean trouble over 15:1. 14.7:1 is
     picked as optimum for pollution reasons; CO and HC get to their lowest
     at Lambda (and go higher when richer), but NOX shoots thru the roof
     when leaner than 15:1. Before, you could lean your mixture to pass
     Smog tests, if your county tests NOX this won't work anymore. This makes
     the standard Oxygen sensor a great tool for tuning for Smog but not
     quite ideal for tuning for power. I suppose good engine management
     can ignore the Oxygen sensor at high rpms and high load (outside the
     range where the EPA tests and where fuel economy doesn't matter, but I'm
     not sure if any OEM systems do this.
       Note also, getting a lot richer is no problem (for power) but leaning
     just a wee bit can cause fits.

    6. There are 2 great books on engine management, both written by Charles
      Probst and printed by Bentley Publishing; the Bosch Fuel injection book
      is very good an applicable to Porsches, the better book for academics
      is "How to Understand, Service, and Modify Ford Fuel injection and
      Electronic engine Control," available thru Ford SVO Motorsports dealers,
      JC Whitney ($24 for 450 pages) and the publisher at 800-423-4595.

       Anyway, your idea of hooking up the Oxygen sensor with a VOM is a good
      one....BTW, which car would your cheap sender come from ?

               -Lee A.

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 16:32:30 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Flat Eyeballs? or don't stare in the beam with your remaining eye

Doug writes:
> Oh yeah? My laser produces optical pulses that are 100 femtoseconds (fs) in
> duration. A femtosecond is ten to the minus fifteenth seconds. Thats zero
> to 300,000,000 (that's 3 times ten to the 8, if I miscounted zeros) meters
> per second in 100 fs. Of course each pulse contains less than 10 nanojoules
> of energy.

Unless I misunderstood, the "acceleration" involved occurs in a significantly
shorter stretch of time than 100fs. It's the duration of pulse generation
that lasts 100fs - the pulse will continue to propagate until it hits
something. Can a photon exist if it isn't propagating at 186,000mps? I mean,
it's not a photon unless it's moving at the speed of light, is it?
In any case, doug posted LAST week - can I have GotW for THIS week?

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 16:35:08 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: Porsche naming convention



Porsche Design always numbered it's designs, and the 356 was
it's 356th design effort (remember, they did Kubelwagens, sun
glasses, a bicycle, etc. ) When they got to the design for the 901, 
Pugeot or some other low-life company had already trademarked the 
number so they changed it to 911.

The big question is what happens after 999? Of course, for me it
really doesn't matter because the 911 is just fine!

Reid

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 14:59:44 -0700 (MST)
From: bshort@usa.net (Byron D. Short / AFS Inc.)
Subject: Re: Q:215/65-15 or 215/60 ?

doug dykaar debated...

> actually, the sidewalls look vertical on the 7s. I also have 225/50-16 on
> 8s and they look vertical as well. theres an 800 # for BFG and they give a
> range of wheel sizes for a given tire. I'm pretty sure the 225/50-15 is hot
> setup for the track, and I assume for auto-x. I'm sure there are other
> crazies on the list who can correct me...

I guess I qualify as an auto-x crazy, since I'm driving 3500 miles round 
trip for about 8 minutes of Pro Solo thrills in Jacksonville FL later 
this month.  Here's my $.02 on rim sizes and tires.

In general, I run about the biggest thing I can squeeze on the rim that 
doesn't increase overall diameter.  Extensive testing by other BFG Team 
drivers has shown that the wider the tire the better the transient 
response (such as in slaloms), just the sort of thing you need in 
autocrossing.  However, for high speed, large sweepers and little or no 
transition-speed considerations, in many cases a smaller tire will get 
better lap times.  Why?  Because in the middle of the turn either tire is 
using only the last 1" - 2" of tread anyway, but the narrower tire 
decreases friction and allows quicker acceleration off the corner.  
(Please remember, this is for stock-type cars with significant body 
roll--real race cars use their entire tread, even in the turns.)  The 
test which this came from ran 185/60's vs 205/55's both on a 5.5" rim, on 
a Miata.  Most would say the 205/55 is just too wide for the rim, but it's 
consistently faster on the autocross course, while the 185/60 is 
consistently faster on the road race course.

Applying the above to a 951 with 7's and 8's, I went with BFG's 245-45-16 
all the way around with good results, although I wondered if the 225's on 
the front wouldn't wear better.  However, after having the tires shaved I 
got much better tire wear on the front and unbelievable grip.  Now that 
I've switched to the M030 package on the S2 (7.5" & 9" rims) I'm even 
happier with the 245's on the front, and considering carrying a set of 
245's for the rear AND a set of 255-50-16's as well.  The larger size 
effectively gives a different set of gears which allow 63mph out of 
second gear instead of the 245's 58mph top speed.  In effect I could 
change my gears for those rare courses which would otherwise require a 
quick shift up to third and back down.  I've not experienced any rubbing 
of any kind on either end, even in spins.  Remember, however, that your 
alignment settings may also have an effect on rubbing--different camber 
settings move the top of the tire in and out quite a bit...

BTW, Jim Fogarty, a designer of the 230 R1 BFG tire, has an excellent
5 page discussion titled "Care and Feeding of your BFG R1's" (or 
something like that) available on Compuserve.  I can get Jim's permission 
to send it to anyone interested...e-mail me.

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 95 17:09:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Need advice on 3.2L 911 engine noise


William,

The clicking could certainly be your injectors.  Or other stuff.  Perhaps
you will find it easiest to pinpoint the source by using a stethoscope,
or just a length of PVC tubing held to your ear.  Doing so really helps
localize the source of a noise.

BTW, this trick works well for finding vacuum leaks, esp. if you pressurize
the induction system.

Happy hunting,

Kevin Gross

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 14:40:03 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: re:bushing lube

Mike,
I used the automotion stuff ("gorilla snot") on my rear bushings. It seems
pretty waterproof. The spring plates do in fact make some noise though. 
Larger bumps and it's more apparent that the lube is well, Not lubing.
It does make a good seal to keep out the H2O. 
Sean

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 95 11:16:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Patrick Motorsports review


Hello 'philes,

My 914/6 3.0 SC project is slowly moving forward....and the parts
(and bills!) are coming in.  For shifting this monster, I've chosen
to use the Patrick Motorsports cable shifter for the 915 trans.
I received the parts today and examined where my money went.

The welds look great and there are many nicely machined custom
linkage parts on the shifter.  I can see why the retail on this puppy
is $625 - there's a lot of specialized labor involved.  The shift throw
is incredibly short....five inches front to back and possibly shorter
when it's installed in the car.  It has a "spring-loaded-push-down-
reverse-lockout" mechanism as well.

I also ordered some fireproof sheathing, 914 shift box mount, and
a flywheel/pressure plate hardware kit.  I never received the pressure
plate bolts.

I called them up and notified them of this, and the guy on the phone
apologized a lot and will be sending them out today via express post
in a small envelope so they don't get stuck in customs (I live in Canada).
The only questions he asked about the missing bolts was if there was
a hole in the box and to identify what bolts I had to make sure he sent
out the ones I needed.  No interrogating, no feeling awkward.

So, the quality looks good, and the service is great if there is a
problem.

Barring anything really bad happening during installation or actual
use of their parts, I'd buy stuff from them again without hesitation.
(They have a lot of neat racing parts....hi-po clutches, oil systems,
brakes, suspension, CV cages, axles, etc)

Allan
<ajohanson@ea.com>

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 95 19:35:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Porsche naming convention


>Porsche Design always numbered it's designs, and the 356 was
>it's 356th design effort.

Not quite.  If I remember my history, Professor Porsche's first project
number was seven.  He didn't want to present a consulting project to
his customer as Porsche project number one, and thought that seven
would sound like he had a little more experience under his belt.

Kevin

Date: Mon, 6 Feb 1995 12:30:56 -0800
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: Re: 7x16 on 71 911

>Just wondering if anyone is running 7x16 wheels on their early '70's 911.
>I have an opportunity to purchase some locally.  The wheels in question
>have 225/60 P7's which are *way* to wide for my 911.  It looks as though
>205's on a 16" wheel may be too big also.

>My guess is that I should go with 6x16's all around with 195's on the front
>and 205's on the back.  That or go with stock 6x15's.  This is my daily
>driver, I'm interested in updating the appearance from the stock steel
>wheels and a minor handling improvement.

I have 7x16's on my 71 911.  Tires are 205/55's.  There is no clearance
problem front or rear, though hitting a bump at speed can make the
rears bottom momentarily.  The clearance on the front is very close,
but it does not rub even in extreme cornering.

I don't know what you mean by minor handling improvement.  You will have more
grip and slightly slower turn in and acceleration.  All I notice is that with
more rubber there is more grip and seemingly better braking.  The car is *way*
better than me anyway, so any real gains are are more perceived than actual.

YMMV

Vol

Date: Sat, 4 Feb 1995 11:26:24 -0800
From: "William Dunham" <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>
Subject: Handling (was sway bars)

Last week I made a statement that a stiffer rear suspension would cause
a car to understeer rather than oversteer.  That was clearly wrong, but
what I can't figure out is why it causes the reaction that it does.  I have
read somewhere that "two eaually loaded tires can sustain more lateral load
than one tire with twice the load".  So it would seem that the stiffer the
rear sway bar, the better the traction at the rear, and the less the oversteer.
What am I missing?  Is the statement about the tire traction untrue?

Bill

------------------------------

Date: Tue,  7 Feb 95 18:45:35 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Handling (was sway bars)

| From: "William Dunham"  <dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com>
|
| Last week I made a statement that a stiffer rear suspension would cause
| a car to understeer rather than oversteer.  That was clearly wrong, but
| what I can't figure out is why it causes the reaction that it does.  I have
| read somewhere that "two eaually loaded tires can sustain more lateral load
| than one tire with twice the load".  So it would seem that the stiffer the
| rear sway bar, the better the traction at the rear, and the less the 
oversteer.
| What am I missing?  Is the statement about the tire traction untrue?

No, it is absolutely correct. The problem boils down to one of weight
transfer.  The stiffer sway bar causes more weight transfer from one
side to the other on the end to which it is installed. That is, as the
car rolls toward the outside of the turn (compressing the suspension
on the outside), a stiffer sway bar will exert an upward force on the inside
tire (tending to compress the suspension on that side also). The inside
tire will have less weight on it, the outside tire more. The inside tire will
not have enought weight on it for maximum traction and the outside tire
will not gain enough traction to make up for that lost by the inside
tire. Net is less traction. However, body roll will be reduced, so
the tires on the other end will have better weight distribution
between them, so they will have relatively better traction.

BTW, stiffer sway bar does not also mean stiffer suspension. The
spring and shock rates also figure into the equation. The discusions
of using sway bar settings to alter over/under steer assume that all
other settings are kept the same.

The above info paraphrased from "How to Make Your Car Handle"
by Fred Puhn.

BTW, my car handles great, I just need to learn how to drive it! For
me, it is off to the autocross and off to drivers ed.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 1995 20:33:18 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: re: rear wiper kills 930s.  Story at 11...

>
>in order to revive the patient i must return the ignition switch to
>"off" and start
>the car again (ie: with starter).
>
>a
>daryls@microsoft.com
>
>'78 Gold Metalic 450hp, fire-breathing 930 Corvette Humbler.

>
>#<begin uuencode>
>begin 666 WINMAIL.DAT
>M>)\^(J4#`0B`!P`8````25!-+DUI8W)O<V]F="!-86EL+DYO=&4`,0@!`Y`&

>#<end uuencode>
>

Ok I'm not sure what to do with the uuencode data (is it a pix ?)...
the 930 unit needs to have a relay checked. To be more specific it sounds 
like the ignition cutout relay needs a little cleaning. This relay makes 
sure the wiper goes off when the ignition is off. By turning the ignition 
off then on (with rear wiper in a logical condition of ON (You work for 
Microsoft don't ya :-)) you are closing the contact before current is going 
to flow through a HIGH resistance contact.

Do you have the electrical diagram for the car ? If so trace the current 
flow from the rear wiper motor through to all relays involved (probably two).

If this works out put in a good word for me in the 'admissions dept.' at
uSoft, in case they need a few more good men.

69-912
86-Golf
Chris Jungmann

Date: 07 Feb 95 23:54:28 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsche naming convention

 
Actually, the 356 is not the 356th design to come off Porsche's drawing
boards. The first thing the office ever did, a car for Wanderer I think, was
Number 7 because they didn't want the client to think this was their first
job (it was). There are numbers well over 1000, even over 2000. The Indy car
project was in the 2000 range I think, and some of the out-of-house consulting
jobs are also above 1000. I think the Seat engine I worked on was Project
2616.
 
Glasses and cameras and briefcases don't have Porsche type numbers because
they're not built by Porsche the car company; they're designed by Porsche
Design the son's industrial design company and usually manufactured by
somebody else (watches by IWC, etc.)
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 23:07:20 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: re: auto security

While it won't prevent them from taking your stereo, cellular phone or 
anything else inside the car, there is a new idea -- reported in R&T -- from 
County Durham in England.  They put a large sticker in the front windsheild 
that proudly displays the number "25".  This informs the police that the 
owner of the car is over 25 years old.  It seems that the vast majority of 
car theives in England are under 25.

Of course, both the police and you probably would be sued for age 
discrimination in the U.S.

     Bill Marten
     wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1144                         Wed Feb 8 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 23:16:40 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: Demise of the h2o-cooled Porsche

Someone on the list was distraught by the idea that the water-cooled line 
was being discontinued to make room for the Boxster . . .

From R&T:

     - the 4-cyl engine option has been dropped (reason below)
     - the price in Germany is to be ~DM70,000 ($45k American)
     - the base engine will be water-cooled, 2.5 l, H6, 200 bhp
     - up-scale plant 3.0 l, 250 bhp
     - both engines w/4-valve per cyl heads

So, you get to have your Boxster w/water (but don't have it on the rocks.)  
Just in case this was news to anyone.

     Bill Marten
     wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu

I had a plethora of problems like these disappear when I replaced the
relay panel inside the engine compartment.

They're not cheap (GPR has rebuilts), so you might try cleaning it up
real well and see if anything improves.

And note that there are two temperature sensors on the motor.  The other
one is on the block.

Finally, have you made sure that the accelerator VALVE isn't sticking?

gary@superior.ucsf.edu



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 21:42:34 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: Auto Security


You can always use my trick.  (I swiped it from my brother, so it's OK)

I have a pull-out deck.  And when I pull it out, I take a wad of multi-
colored wire and drape it out the hole and under the dash.  An old chunk
of wiring harness saved from the last "intrusion" works well.

When the "discount stereo shopper" sees this, he/she assumes that one
of his comrades has beaten him to it, and moves on.

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Date: Tue, 7 Feb 95 23:06:10 -0800
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re: Spoilers...

>
>I think I just saw a regular early 928 with a "S4" spoiler on the back window.
> I was suprised at how good it looked on an older model.  I bet it would look
>even better on my black 928.  Has anyone else seen/done this?  How about the
>"S" spoilers on a first generation 928?  I have an article on installing "S"
>spoilers, but it looks prohibitively difficult.  Looks like you have to cut out
> air ducts for the brakes.  Just wondering if anyone has any insight into any
>of these add ons...  Sean '80 9
>

I installed a "blade style" late model rear spoiler and an "S" front spoiler
on my '80 928, and it looks great.  It was fairly easy to do.  You have to
drill holes in the rear hatch frame for four bolts (two on each side) to
mount the rear spoiler.  The front spoiler is a little more difficult, only
because locating the correct spots to drill holes requires some care and
fitting.  I did not cut brake venting holes in the front lower body panel.
Because of this, the front spoiler had to be cut with a Dremel grinder to
fit flush.  In my opinion, it looks better than it would with the brake
vent holes (it looks very streamlined).  If you take your time, it might
take 2 hours to mount the rear spoiler and 4 hours for the front (if you
are a perfectionist, like me).  I recommend aftermarket parts, only because
the cost of Porsche parts seems unnecessarily high (aftermarket is just as
good in many cases).  Try calling 928 International in Anaheim, CA for
pricing and spoiler options (714-632-9288).

Date: Tue, 07 Feb 95 23:45:00 PST
From: "Brewer, Bob" <bob@mailbag.des.ucdavis.edu>
Subject: RE: Tranny Plug removal update..


Sorry I missed the first post.  I've had really good luck with stuck stuff 
by simply (so he says) reducing the size of the part or expanding what it's 
stuck in.

If I'm not mistaken (too lazy to look it up) mild steel, for example, 
changes about a thousandth for every degree F in temp.

Dwight Mitchell recommended I heat the shit out of a head with a stuck 
exhaust stud, and it worked.  Damn oil fires.  Gotta watch that torch.

I've had excellent results with cooling parts with Freon (before we knew it 
was nasty on the O.L.) and more recently with liquid nitrogen that I pinch 
from the lab down the hall.

Don't ask me how I'd cool a drain plug on the bottom of the trans with 
nitrogen.  I guess you'd have to invert the car.  Actually, if you'd turned 
the car on it's side, you could have drained it out the fill plug. :)

Bob Brewer
rebrewer@ucdavis.edu

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 95 10:03:24 +0200
From: pl@mistyrivers.itf.fi (Pekka Laiho)
Subject: early 911 head flow-test #2


Hi all early 911 owners.

This is my second mail according to '65 911 head flow-test.

We have made next modifications to the heads:

	1. intake valve modified
	2. intake port modified little

We have not increased port sizes, so the head should still
work wery well in lower RPM range.


Here are test results:

test pressure: 10
Intake port: 32 mm
Intake valve 39 mm
Exhaust port 32 mm
Exhaust valve 35 mm

Head flow with intake manifold and standard Solex 40PI carp.

Lift mm    CFM  In Val In Flow  Ex Val Ex Flow   E/I %   Power
   1.00   29.00    0.40   11.30    0.34   10.10   89.38   30.32
   2.00   29.00    0.80   23.20    0.64   19.40   83.62   61.03
   3.00   40.00    0.88   35.60    0.69   29.50   82.87   93.07
   4.00   59.00    0.79   47.50    0.66   41.20   86.74  123.38
   5.00   59.00    0.97   58.80    0.83   52.40   89.12  152.27
   6.00   84.00    0.80   68.30    0.97   61.60   90.19  176.77
   7.00   84.00    0.86   73.90    0.78   70.30   95.13  191.23
   8.00   84.00    0.91   78.20    0.84   75.70   96.80  202.34
   9.00   84.00    0.94   80.40    0.88   78.90   98.13  207.90
  10.00   84.00    0.94   81.30    0.90   81.10   99.75  210.13
  11.00   84.00    0.95   81.70    0.92   82.50  100.98  211.24
  12.00   84.00    0.96   82.60    0.93   83.90  101.57  213.46
  13.00   84.00    0.96   83.00   94.00   84.80  102.17  214.57

As can seen, we have increased head-flow, and the intake flow do not
decrease anymore after 8 mm lift.

Some interestig info (carps venturi 30)

carps -33 hp
intake manifold -4 hp
intake valve -5 hp (standard -13 hp)

With 01 cams the results is:

	standard head, 186 hp
	modified head, 211 hp

Flow (power) without carps and intake manifold, lift 11 mm:

	standard head, 209 hp
	modified head, 246 hp

This test will continue...

W: Pekka Laiho

From: pl@mistyrivers.itf.fi (Pekka Laiho)

Hi all.

Anybody interested, I can send xwd files
from flow-test we had made to '65 911 head.

intake flow, exhaust flow and calculated power
of the head.

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 04:23:35 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: How a QUAIFE really works?

Can anyone out who REALLY knows how a Quaife differential works explain it to
me? Maybe someone who has worked on one (taken it apart). I know that it
transfers torque more smoothly than a regular limited slip, and it does
change the handling of my car for the better, I think, but it has some
unusual traits. It does not work when one wheel starts on a very slippery
surface, and one wheel can easily spin opposite the other when the car is up
in the air, just like an open rear. I took it out, and I can't say that now I
notice much of a change back to the open rear. If it is broken, I can't tell!
HELP! THANKS.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
84 911 Carrera

------------------------------

Date: Wed, Feb 8, 1995 8:35 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Oil Change Intervals

> I'd love to hear the consensus on this:  

Hooooo boy!  I'm sure you'll hear a lot (but not so sanguine you find any 
consensus...)
> 
> I have a 1995 968. The car was factory delivered with Mobil-1 synthetic oil 
> (and replaced with that at the recommended 2500 mile service).  The service 
> advisor, and other mechanics I've talked to, swear that I really don't need 
> to change the oil more than every 7500 miles.  I'm sure this debate has 
> raged here before.  Should I change it more frequently ?  Most of my driving 
> is stop and go, city commuting (probably about 8-10,000 miles a year).  
> Thanks.

My owner's manual (the distillation of the factory's sacred wisdom) says to
change at 7500 miles, and the factory is often suspected of being a bit 
conservative where the reputation of the good Porsche name is concerned.

On the other hand, necessary or not, there is a widely held idea that there is 
something magical about changing oil *and* filter every 3000 miles.  The owner
who follows this dictum and *keeps* his records meticulousy, is probably going
to get *top* dollar when he sells this toy...

One other, not inconsequential consideration, is that keeping your toy filled 
with *clean* oil is probably the single most important thing you can do for it
to give it's engine a long, happy life.

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss


------------------------------

Date: Wed,  8 Feb 1995 08:44:53 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Oil Change Intervals

Excerpts from mail: 8-Feb-95 Re: Oil Change Intervals by "Barton P.
Chambers"@atl 
> > to change the oil more than every 7500 miles.  I'm sure this debate has 
> > raged here before.  Should I change it more frequently ?  Most of my
driving
>  
> > is stop and go, city commuting (probably about 8-10,000 miles a year).

    argh!  I know Bart didn't write this, but my mailer won't realize
that fact...
    Anyhoo... if most of your driving is stop and go commuting, you
probably should think about maybe changing the oil more often,
especially since you drive such low mileage per year (I'm assuming you
would drive it every day, meaning it only gets driven a short distance
every time it's driven.)
    This kind of driving is very hard on a car... much of the engine
wear occurs at startup, and also if the engine never warms up, the oil
detergents don't work as effectively (solubility of engine crud is
dependent on temp.) and nasty foo can build up in your engine.
    But hell, I was considering switching to Syntec in my '71 914 with
104,000 miles on it, so I may just be overcautious.  Then again, it's a
p-car, so wouldn't it make sense to take extra special care of it?

later,

Nate

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 09:58:16 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: Oil Change Intervals

On cars that run rich (like 951s with chips or carb'd 911) I feel it's
more important to change oil frequently than to use $$ oil.

In my 951 I used Mobil 1 and changed at 4K, or more frequently durring
track season since the performance chips tend to run very ricjh and
dirty the oil.

On my 911 I change every 3-4K and use Castrol or Pennzoil 20W50, since
14x$4.00 is expensive, and the carbs quickly dirty it.

On the hoindas I change every 6K and use  Castrol Syntec, 5-50.  I`ve
got 167K and 133K on them ad they are non oil burning and see 7K rpms
occasionally.  The Ciic Si has even been at the track half a dozen
times.

Anyway, I would worry more about clean oil.  If you change every 3K and
do not have an engine that ruins hot (like a turbo`s turbo) I think
regular oil is OK.  On a car like a hoinda that takes 4 qts, I don't
mind the extra $12 in oil for the peace of mind.

but I'd never do that. I change it every 5000 miles. What the heck--it's 
20 bucks a change that could save the life of my engine, right?

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 09:30:24 -0600
From: martinw@eapi.com

From martinw Wed Feb  8 10:07:56 1995
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>

  >Hooooo boy!  I'm sure you'll hear a lot (but not so sanguine you find any 
  >consensus...)
  >> 
  >> I have a 1995 968. The car was factory delivered with Mobil-1 synthetic oil 
  >> (and replaced with that at the recommended 2500 mile service).  The service 
  >> advisor, and other mechanics I've talked to, swear that I really don't need 
  >> to change the oil more than every 7500 miles.  I'm sure this debate has 
  >> raged here before.  Should I change it more frequently ?  Most of my driving 
  >> is stop and go, city commuting (probably about 8-10,000 miles a year).  

Embry riddle (airplane school) did a test some years ago on the flat
aircooled fours in their fleet of cassna 150's (flight school =
beat on engine).  in several they didn't EVER change the oil over the
life of the engine ~= 2000 hours.  They just topped up and changed the
filter on the normal schedule.  When they tore them down they didn't
find any appreciable wear differences between the oil changed engines
and the non-changed engines.  The only problem they had was keeping the
pH of the oil correct.  'course the engines are operated a little
differently in a plane - but food for thought !

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 10:09:55 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Oil Change Intervals

Sigh...  Some people....

There are three issues  that make oil changes important:

1) viscosity breakdown. Due to the thermal qualities of operating inside
   a contained blast furnace (i.e. your engine), the petroleum base of 
   the oil "cooks" and seeks to re-comform itself into a different
   polymer, one that's not as good at lubrication. This is an
   "hours of operation" issue, since it's time at temp related.
   This motivates oil coolers, and was the origin of the low mile
   oil change recommendation -- early multigrade oils just didn't
   stay together very well.

   Synthetics don't have this problem. Hence the 15000 mile recomendation.

2) particulate contamination. IN layman's terms, "crap in the oil". As
   combustion occurs, you may carbonize small bits of oil on the hot
   parts of the engine. You may have some ring blow-by that inserts
   other particulate into the engine. You may have dust, grit, etc that
   gets in via the breather. You will have small bits of metal as your
   engine wears.

   This is the genesis of the oil filter. No matter if your oil will go
   a million miles, if you don't change the oil filter you will have
   bearing surfaces abraded by the particulate in suspension. Coarse
   particulate will be trapped by the filter or the magnet in the sump.
   The finer particulate will remain suspended in the oil, causing even more 
   abrasion (and more additional fine particulate!). 

   To remove this fine particulate, you have to change the oil. Hence the 
   lower milage oil change requirements.

3) fluid contamination. Your engine requires air, gas, and optionally
   water/coolant. Any of these may mix with the oil if there is any
   leakage. Air causes foaming which reduces all lubricant efficiency and
   elminated cooling capacity. Water makes salad dressing, and is not pretty
   to see what an engine run on Miracle Whip looks like at disassembly.
   Gas may get introduced via "wash down" if you're running too rich or
   if you have rings that haven't seated well. It's a solvent, which reduces
   your oils' ability to do anything.

   The only way to know if you have any of this is to drain the oil. The
   only way to keep it from eating your engine alive is to replace the
   oil.

So, as noted: frequent oil changes. 

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 07 Feb 95 20:16:57 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porschephiles #1141 Tue Feb 7 11:04:02 C

356 carbs and radio
 
Weber carburetors were used on the Carrera GS/GT cars, which used a
completely different engine from your Super 90; that's the famous four-cam
engine. Depending on year, they used Soles 40 PII (like the S 90 and SC) or
Weber 40 DCM. Chances are you have aftermarket Weber 40 IDF carbs. These
usually have a smaller venturi than the stock Solexes, meaning you get less
air flow and less power. Weber - usually 28 mm venturi; Solex - 32 mm
venturi.
 
Radio blanking plates are available to close off the holes already stamped
for the Blaupunkt radio if no radio is installed; these should be one
rectangular hole flanked by two round holes for the control shafts. With the
radio installed, all of the holes are neatly closed (by bezels included with
the radio and knobs). No other plate is needed. If you are using a more
modern radio, I don't know how it fits. You won't be able to hear it anyway,
might as well get a vintage genuine surround sound monaural Blaupunkt. <g>
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 95 10:27:41 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: Oil Change Intervals

Jeff asks:


"I change my oil usually at around 5K miles. But as the original poster
said - where did this 3K miles come from? Just saying "cheap insurance"
doesn't answer the question."


Well, the only way to answer the question is to analyze (as in
performing actual analytical chemistry) the oil every 1K miles to see
how much dirt, moisture, unburnt gasoline and decomposition products
are present. All four are bad. Some people just look at the color of
the oil and change it (and the filter) when it looks too dark.

So unless you want to have the analysis done (which would be expensive
and inconvenient) the answer "cheap insurance" is the right answer.
Assuming you do not race the car, drive very short distances only
(which is a real killer for any engine) or drive in extremely dusty
conditions and, your car is not running outrageously rich... a change
every 3K miles HAS to be safe. This conservative guideline is the best
protection you can provide for your engine.

A convenient, semi-intuitive way to set your own standards would be to
evaluate the color of your oil every 1K miles. You can assume as the
darker the oil becomes the more it has broken down. I doubt if the
color will reflect the presence of gasoline or water. You would need to
have someway to reproducibly evaluate the oil color (say put it in a
small test tube and hold it up in front of the exact same light
source... you could seal the tube and compare each sample as you get to
5K miles). If you don't trust the paradigm of 3K miles, you can make
your own decision.

Synthetic oil is another question. I do not have any idea how readily
this oil absorbs water, how sensitive the viscosity is to gasoline or
how the color changes as it breaks down and gets dirty.

**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

**********************************************************************



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 11:51:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Oil Change Intervals


Bill,

I agree with the received wisdom of 3,000 mile intervals.  Seems to work;
cheap insurance.

One thing to keep in mind when referring to factory recommended intervals
is the following.  Cars are getting rated nowadays by projected service
and repair costs, as for example in AutoWeek and Consumers' Report.  If
you double or quadruple the oil change interval, you halve a cost, and in
fact what some people view as an inconvenience.

With the 993, the book rate for an oil change is -- urgh -- 3 hours.  And, 
as of
the Carrera 4, you have to drop the exhaust to adjust the valves.  That kind
of labour really motivates PCNA to push the service intervals out.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 11:46:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 air flow meter problem ???


Hi Trev,

With respect to the AFM connector, there was in fact a service action or
at least a tech bulletin on a similar problem in, as I recall, the Carrera 4
and 2.  The boot was rubbing against an adjacent something-or-other.

Not a professional mechanic.  I have been playing with/learning about cars
for the last seven or eight years, and hang out with a friend who is a 
professional
mechanics.  What I know, I know because it broke on my car, went into the
race car, or I read about it.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 11:55:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: '84 911 questions


Scott,

Given your description, I recommend you get the car on a gas analyzer and
set its basic mix, ie lambda disconnected.  The surging you describe may
be something which the lambda sensor simply cannot correct.  You may have
false air (vacuum leak).  Pressurize the intake and look for leaks.  Or it 
could
be something else, like a bad idle stabilizer (very rare), or one that's 
clogged
(more common).  But that's the order I'd check things.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 11:13:21 -0600 (CST)
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: Oil Change Intervals

> 
> Yes. The original question remains, and I've often wondered about it
> myself. I believe Porsche recommends 15K miles between oil changes in my
> 944 maintenance manual. Since they made the engine, they should know
> something about it. Changing the oil at 3K increments just wastes money
> if it is doing no good whatsoever.
> 

Yes the manual says 7.5K or 15K.  But, it also says that vehicles
operated under less than ideal conditions should get oil/filter
changes more frequently.  What are "less than ideal" conditions?

    extremes of temperature
    dirty/dusty environments
    frequent short trips
    stop/go driving
    track use

How many cars do you own that are driven only when it's 60-70
degrees F, there's no dust/dirt in the air, for more than thirty
minutes, AND only on an uncrowded highway...

Hey, it's your car.  You pays your money and takes your chances...

mjt

Howdy,

On my '72 S, most of the combinations of 7x15 and 7x16 that were
recommended by several people won't fit on the rear. i.e.

 - 7x16 in the rear with a 205/55 
 - 7x15 all around with 205/60s 
 - 7x15 all around with 205/50s front - 225/50s rear 

I can not even fit 195/60/15 on the rear with stock 7" rims.
But my car is as low as it will go and still handle well. And the 911
cars are not all the same, so try to borrow the size you are interested
in and drive it HARD to see what happens.

I had only slight rubbing problems with 225/50/15 on stock 7x15 on the front.
But on the rear I had to use the early 911R offset wheels (Revolutions).
The stock 7" rims have all the extra 1" width on the outside of the rim.
The 911R has all (or most?) on the inside. 
Still, the 911R wheels rubbed on the inside spring plate, so I had to use
thin spacers under the wheel, which spread the extra 1" evenly inside and
out.
This combination looks funny because the front looks wider than the rear,
and may not be great for high speed track driving (may oversteer).

The 7x15 with 225/50/15's sure make an early 911 look muscular!
Too bad I have to go back to 6x15 and 205/50/15 for SCCA stock class... 
I guess I can still run the big ones in PCA!

Mike Piera '72 911S Targa, AnalogMike@aol.com
aNaLoG MaN Vintage Guitars/effects "I'll trade Porsches for your old
guitars!"


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 12:42:01 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: '84 911 questions

If it is the same as my 84 944 the circle with dashes round it is indeed the
low pad indicator. If your pads are good and the light is still on it
probably means that the sensors were not replaced when the pads were. The way
the sensors work is that once they are ground away by friction with the disc,
the embedded wire is cut, and the light goes on on your dash. 

You have to replace the sensor or the light will not go out. It only takes
one sensor to activate the light, so check them all you may only need to
replace one.

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 13:24:50 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Cessna Oil Change

I am glad I did not have to suffer Embrey Riddle's "experiment"! It is gross
negligence to disregard manufacturer'srecommended maintenance procedures,
especially on something that could kill you if it fails.

As Martin points out, aircraft engines do operate differently; they use
different (ashless) oils, they operate in a, generally, far cleaner
environment than cars - even when on the ground, and they are operated at
constant RPM for the majority of the operating time and subsequently do not
undergo the continual load changes imposed on auto engines, therefore
comparisons with cars gives us little benefit..

Will Hartje

84 944
76 Lola T342
73 Cessna172

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 13:26:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: RE: K&N Air Filter: Does it affect brake booster


That's very interesting.  Actually that brings up another question.  After 
reading the Probst Fuel Injection book over the weekend, it seems that the 
pressure difference will stay the same, because this is a function of the 
throttle valve.  However because the air filter has less restriction, the 
same pressure difference would seem to result in better throttle response. 
 I guess what I'm thinking is that the air would flow slightly more quickly? 
into the cylinder.  Anyway, how would this affect the fuel metering?  Take 
my CIS(K-Jetronic) Rabbit-----please.  Wouldn't the lesser restriction cause 
a change in the sensor plate movement and thus throw off my metering.  Or is 
the change so little as to not affect anything?

(Hopefully my paragraph makes a little sense.  I wrote it in a little bit of 
a hurry.  I do have to do work.)

Thanks,
David B.
'89 944
'81 Rabbit

   From: porschephiles-request
   To: porschephiles
   Subject: K&N Air Filter: Does it affect brake booster
   Date: Wednesday, February 8, 1995 10:43AM

   Hi all,
   I don't want to restart the debate about whether a K&N filter is good
   or bad for engine life, but I am curious about a totally different
   aspect. Fellow Porschephiles helped me understand that a brake booster
   derives the boost from engine vacuum. Now the K&N is supposed to flow
   more air, hence there should be less pressure differential from the air
   intake tract to outside air, and that should cause less vacuum. Would 
this
   be noticable ? Or have I misunderstood something?

   '92 Harley 1200 (which shows lots more hp on a dyno with a K&N air

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 13:41:08 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: Re: Cessna Oil Change

  >environment than cars - even when on the ground, and they are operated at
  >constant RPM for the majority of the operating time and subsequently do not
  >undergo the continual load changes imposed on auto engines, therefore
  >comparisons with cars gives us little benefit..

one thing that we can benefit from the aiviation world, however, is oil
analysis labs.  maybe these advertise in the racing papers too, I don't know.

but plenty of places advertise in the airplane mags.  think the prices
are about $50 a shot.  course only doing it once doesn't really tell
you a whole lot - what you really need is several spaced over racing
season or somthing like that.  they usually will tell you things like
silicate ppm (dirt), carbon, ferrous and non-ferrous metals which are
sometimes in size groups too.  my usuall rule of thumb is if it's
in the oil, ferrous and has a part number on it then somethings
probably wrong :-)
