Date: 8 Feb 1995 10:36:23 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 928S Questions.....

 Reply to:     RE>>928S Questions.....

Bill,
Thanks for your long e-mail regarding my questions!

  >>Changing the thermostat heat value is like wrapping a leaking 
  >> hose with tape

My hoses are new and the pressure cap is new.  I've replaced the thermostat 
and have noticed that the temp seems to run a bit warmer when moving
and a bit cooler when stopped (i.e., the old thermostat probably opened
up too much when moving and didn't open up enough when stopped in
traffic).  I have to wait for summer before I see if it works out OK in
traffic
with the a/c running; however, your point about not screwing around with
a different thermostat due to effects on the rest of the system is well
taken.

  >>1. Make sure your radiator fins are clear of leaves and other garbage
  >> so the air flow through freely

I will try to clean out the fins on the radiator with a hose within 
the next week or two.  I seem to have some dirt in the a/c "radiator"
but can't see the main radiator well enough to know.

  >>Use Phosphate free coolant (Phosphates eat aluminum) and 
  >>distilled water can't hurt.  Be sure to bleed the air out of the 
  >>system per the shop manual.  Air bubbles can cause overheating.  
 
I changed the coolant (phosphate free and distilled water) when I
bought the car in Feb 94 -- it was clear and "new" looking at the time 
(it probably was new in order to disguise any problems).  After 10 
months or so it was gray. I'm hoping that if I do have a leak it's not 
in the head gasket.  It probably isn't, as the engine runs really well 
(no obvious problems that would happen if you had a compression 
leak somewhere).  

  >>Coolant is much more likely to leak to an oil passage than the 
  >>other way around.  This is due to the coolant system being under 
  >>pressure and coolant flows easier than oil


You're right about which way things should leak due to 
pressurization, but here's another fact I didn't communicate 
earlier.  I replaced the coolant expansion tank two weeks ago
because it had a small hole which did 2 things:  it leaked and it 
probably kept the cooling system from attaining proper 
pressurization.  

 >>Water pump coolant is also a good thing to add.  A new water pump
  >> will run you $1,200+.  It's takes about 10 hours labor to do it. 


The water pump costs $1,200???  (Ye Gods!)   Is this a
gold plated pump or can it be had elsewhere for less (like my $240
Valeo alternator that would have cost $899 from Porsche)??
What is "water pump coolant"  and I didn't do anything special to
bleed the system ... what should I have done?

  >>Could be the previous owner loaded it up with stop leak and 
  >> plugged some of the radiator tubes

Don't know for sure, but it doesn't piddle on the ground so I assume
that I don't have any external leaks.

Regarding the electric fan ... it comes on when the engine temp 
gage gets in the hot range and immediately brings the 
temperature down.  The gage never hits the peg.

Question for you... my manual says that the electric fan should 
run even with the ignition off, but it doesn't.  Stop the engine 
and the electric fan stops too.  Does your electric fan run when
the engine is off?

Question for everyone ... I've just bought some cable snow
"Chains" to go up to Mammoth for a ski trip.  Anyone have any
experience with 928's and snow chains/cables?

  >>BTW:  Do you have a US Spec 928 or a Euro Spec model?

I think I have a US Spec model as it has the cat converter needed to
be smog legal in California.  It was purchased from a California dealer
and has all the appropriate stickers that one would expect.

Date: 8 Feb 95 20:36:00 +0000
From: swellen@intgp1.att.com
Subject: factory warning and gossip

No not gossip from the factory but gossip about the factory.
Production of the 968 Cabrio has stopped, there are loads
unsold. That's a shame as we were due to get a 968 Club
Sport Cabrio but this has been cancelled (obviously). 
928 production has practically been an an order basis
for some time.

No more factory trips after June 1995 as the factory is
being overhauled for 986 Boxster and 996 production. The
996 is supposed to be a 911 replacement..... again. They
couldn't stop production of the 911 SC when it was getting
mixed reviews and steady sales so how come they expect the
new 911 Carrera which is getting rave reviews and selling
like hotcakes, well in Britain anyhow, to die? The factory
trips may not re-open until 1997. So anyone interested, as
recent mailings suggest, get your skates on.

The poor sales of the 968 may well be due to love it or
hate styling changes, many 944 owners say they will stay
with the 944 and skip the 968 ready for the Boxster. Shame
as everything else about the 968 seemed right to me.

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 95 12:58:23 PST
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Attempted car theft experience

The discussion of car theft prevention took me back to my school sojourn
in an area of Philadelphia, PA known as "West Philadelphia". 

One morning I came out of the apartment to find my (t)rusty 70T with the 
small triangular passenger's side door window smashed.

The ignition lock cylinder was on the floor.  

It looked like the thief slap hammered it out of the lock, but were scared 
away before they could finish the job.

I went to the dealer and got a new window and epoxied the ignition
lock, minus a few pins messed up by the slap hammer, back together.

Afterwards, I would remove the steering wheel when I parked the car.  

Only one nut holds the 70T steering wheel on, and by punching index
marks on the splined shaft and wheel, it can be re-indexed quickly.

I hadn't fixed my horn, so re-installing the center steering wheel section
was horn noise free.

This was pre-CLUB days.

I assumed the thieves wouldn't be willing to bring their own steering wheel
and would be clever enough to realize they couldn't drive away without one.

I never had another problem.

But I do remember one comment from a passerby seeing me carrying the
steering wheel up to the apartment:

   "Is that all they left?"

John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 13:19:35 -0800
From: "Volney Spalding" <vol@espresso.corp.sgi.com>
Subject: RE: Stan's 914

Pfilers,

Based on the responses I have received today it seems that more
background is needed on the saga of Stan, his 914, his situation,
this group of folks, and the status of the "Rescue Effort".

For a variety of reasons a lot of people are not up to speed on this thread and
are wondering exactly what is going on and why are we appealing to the list
for the 15 clams.  It seems to me that the relatively low number of responses
to
Fred is more indicative of the true number of daily followers than the number
of people willing to help out on this effort :^)

Here is the compressed version of how this thread started and it's
current status:

Definately *not* to scale:

	(Actually I missed the original message and was very confused
	 when the first person suggested we take up a collection so I
	 wrote Stan and said "Huh?"

*	Stan sends message regarding butthead (my word, not his)
	customer who goes Chapter 11 after being 60 days late.
	As a result, Stan decides to put his 914 racer on the block
	for $7000.00

* 	A bunch of people identify this to be a deplorable
	state and suggest taking up a collection so Stan can cover
	short term costs and *not* have to sell his 914.  Some people
	request Stan's snail mail address so they can send money.

	(editorial aside:  RTF Monthly newsletter.  It's there)

	(editorial aside: #2  Ditto re: the thread on Porsche Numbering
	 scheme.  Asking this question proves not having RTF newsletter
	 and displays general lacking of any clue regarding amount of work
	 Stan puts into this thing for our general amusement and knowledge).

*	Fred Pack rises to the occasion and figures someone should
	*actually* do something about this.  Realizing how silly it would
	be for people to randomly send money to Stan, Fred offers to
	collect pledges.  He figures that if 500 or so people are in,
	we can raise the 7k with about 15$/person. (Is this a great
	country or what?)

	Fred offers to collect pledges until 2/11.  If reasonable
	critical mass exists, he will then take the next step which
	is....  I don't know what it is.  Do we all send 15$ to
	Stan and let him go to the bank with  ~500 15$ checks....?
	I don't know but that's a detail we can handle *after* we
	get critical mass.

*	Fred sends out status to the list with news that 85 or so have
	joined up.  Keep the cards and letters coming.

* 	Vol thinks this is pathetic and wonders if we need to print
	up about 500 Certificates with the following:

	**** Dr T*d's No-Op Award for Non-Contribution ****

	Where-in recipients are awarded for the ability to take up space,
	do nothing, add no value and get rewarded for it.

	Instead Vol send's yesterday's post.

*	Several people write to Vol saying:  "I missed this thread and
	would really like to know what's going on".

And here we are.

Keep in mind that Stan has had nothing to do with any of this.  This is
simply something that some folks would like to do.  For a mere 15$ we
can rise to a truly worthy cause.  Why?  Because we can, and wouldn't
it make a great story ;^)

Attached see Freds original post.

Thanks,

Vol

make their donations.

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 95 15:51:03 -0600
From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
Subject: Re: 914 FI help (long)

[edited for television]

>>The god damn car is doing it again! The 914 starts runs exactly 2 minutes 
>>perfectly at a fast idle around 1200 rpms. It creeps up to 1500 then dies. 
>>After that you have to crank the engine over at 5 min intervals for about 
>>half an hour. When it finally starts it will run at only 4000 rpms plus for 
>>about five min.

>>This prblem is completely temp dependent. Summer no problem winter 
>>frustration city.
- ----- end original message -----
>I had a plethora of problems like these disappear when I replaced the 
>relay panel inside the engine compartment. 

>And note that there are two temperature sensors on the motor.  The other 
>one is on the block. 
> 
>Finally, have you made sure that the accelerator VALVE isn't sticking? 
> 
>gary@superior.ucsf.edu 
- ----- end follow-up post -----

Couldn't it also be a failing manifold pressure sensor?  It could cause a 
rich-running condition that is less of a problem when the engine is cold.  
The waiting time would be for the excess fuel to evaporate and the rising 
idle would be from the extra fuel.  Of course, it doesn't explain the 
seasonal symptoms.  It might be worth the few seconds it takes to sniff the 
oil filler cap.  If it smells like gasoline, check the pressure sensor.

Side note to Gary:  Where would the second engine temperature sensor be?  I 
would swear that my `74 2.0 only has the head temp sensor (and the air temp 
sensor in the air cleaner).  I've also never seen any reference to it in any 
of the manuals.

Regards,

     Bill Marten
     wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 16:45:52 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE : 911 Wheel Bearings

juzenas@mprgate.mpr.ca (Mike Juzenas) wrote :

>When the front bearings are **exactly** right, should there be **any** 
>top-to-bottom slop? ie. I find on my SC that I have to tighten the bearning
>nut really tight (certainly much more than specified in the Hayes manual, 
>where you should be able to rotate the thrust washer) to reduce the slop.
>I have not tighted them so tight to have the wheels exibit no slop. Of
>course, the slop is noticed when the car is jacked up with the front
>wheels in the air. So, how tight should the bearing nut be? 

Mike,

I've never had any luck with the procedure in the Haynes manual (which
I believe was taken out of the Porsche factory manual). If you leave
them slightly loose like Haynes says (able to move the washer under gentle
force from a screwdriver), they will loosen up more and become way too
loose ("way" is a scientific term, because I am a scientist).

So I tighten them enough so that it takes some force to move the washer,
and the bearings will stay tight for years. There may still be a slight bit
of slop by shaking the top of the wheels, this is normal. But it should
not be much.

Good Luck, Mike Piera AnalogMike@aol.com '72 911S, '73 914/2.0


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 16:50:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Re: 928S Questions.....


> The water pump costs $1,200???  (Ye Gods!)

When I had the water pump installed I had the belt changed as well.  Since 
it was so far apart, it seemed like a good idea.  Some small parts were 
needed for the belt adjuster, but nothing major.

Most of the expense was I had it done at the dealer which uses new Porsche 
parts only.  I have not found any mechanics out my way that I trust very far 
with my Chevy commuter car, much less my 928.  So far the dealer has done 
good work and has all the right "special' tools.  From the ads in Pano and 
Excellence, repairs done at a Porsche dealer are guaranteed for two years, 
unlimited mileage.  Should the dealer screw up though, I can always cry to 
Porsche N.A.  This adds a comfort factor, though expensive.


> What is "water pump coolant"
It's an additive you can buy at most auto part stores for your cooling 
system, you just dump it in.  Prestone makes it among others.  Your coolant 
most likely already has it included in it's mix.  I change coolant every two 
years and add a can every other year between these changes.


> I didn't do anything special to bleed the system ... what should I have 
done?
I'd have to check the book to be sure.  I believe the heater control has to 
be set to hot with the car level for the '84.  It varies by year.  The 
problem is the radiator is lower than the engine, so special steps are 
needed.  This is the reason the overflow tank is located back by the 
firewall, to get up high as possible.

Chilton has a mini repair book for the 944 & 928.  I highly recommend 
getting one.  No one else (Haynes, Motor, etc.) makes a book on the 928. 
 Though it's not near as comprehensive as the workshop manuals, it is a good 
deal at $8-10.  I refer to it for it's brief comprehensive explanations and 
diagrams.  It's also easier to hold! :)  It's handy for things like bleeding 
the cooling system.
I use my shop manuals when I need more detailed info. and before treading 
into new areas of the car repair.


> I replaced the coolant expansion tank two weeks ago
Did you resolve the coolant level problem, or was it legitimately low due to 
the leaks?


> my manual says that the electric fan should run even with the ignition 
off, but it
>  doesn't.  Stop the engine and the electric fan stops too.

Mine works the same way.  I believe earlier years worked that way, but too 
many batteries died as a result.  Never a problem.


> Regarding the electric fan ... it comes on when the engine temp.
> gage gets in the hot range and immediately brings the
> temperature down.  The gage never hits the peg.

Working perfectly.

> Question for everyone ... I've just bought some cable snow
> "Chains" to go up to Mammoth for a ski trip.  Anyone have any
> experience with 928's and snow chains/cables?

Not personally.  But I've heard you need to get very thin ones (like the 
ones Porsche sells/use to sell?) or they will hit the lip of the fender. 
 Careful not to nick up the forged alloy rims, they go for $1,200 each new 
($200-400 used).

>I think I have a US Spec. model
The beauty of the US engine is it's lower compression ratio.  Should your 
timing belt break, the valves will NOT hit your pistons and cause a 
financial hemorrhage.  Mine went last fall and despite constant cranking 
after the fact (I didn't suspected the belt at first), no bent valves!  I'll 
trade the few extra HP for this peace of mind any day!

The valves will meet pistons (and bend) when the belt breaks on ALL water 
cooled Porsche engines EXCEPT on the 16 valve US Spec.. 928 engine.


Here's a question for you.  Does your High intensity washer pump work?  This 
is the button under your dash pod next to the wiper delay control wheel.  If 
it does, can you tell if it uses the same pump as your windshield/headlamp 
washers?  Mine does not work and I'm wondering if there is another pump for 
this, or if it is the wiring.
My normal windshield washer and headlight washer both work OK off the wiper 
control stick.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

Porschephiles #1147                         Wed Feb 8 20:34:37 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 17:01:48 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: tires for sale

A money saving tip - check out "Tire Rack" for your tires 1-800-428-8355.
they will ship you your tires at a much lower price than the high street tire
stores, and, as they are in Indiana and you are in California -No Tax!, just
a $6.00 approx shipping charge per tire.

I shopped around the high street stores, the best deal in Phoenix  (Discount
Tire) for Yokohama A008P's was $175.99 per tire + balancing + tax = $799.56
for four.

By drop shipping the same tires to my Porsche repair shop it is $135.00 per
tire + $6.00 delivery + 0 Tax  then $60.00 mount and balance for a total of
$620.00 -   BIG DIFFERENCE!


If you have no inexpensive means to get them mounted and balanced you can
always beat Discount Tire over the head with Tire Rack's price and they will
match it but you will still pay tax and stems and balancing.

Good luck

Will Hartje

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 14:29:00 PST
From: "Lai, Hubert" <hl@msmail.orsil.ubc.ca>
Subject: Headlight Washer


On my 1983 944, I have little headlight washers.  These are mounted on the 
front bumper, and when I press the button in the cockpit a high pressure 
stream of windshield washer fluid blasts the headlights.

At least, that's the way it's supposed to work.

When I press the button, only the left headlight washer works.  The 
right-hand one doesn't work.  I though it might be plugged up with wax or 
something, but despite poking around as best I could with a needle in the 
nozzle, I wasn't able to fix it.

Washer fluid is getting to the front of the car though, because even though 
washer fluid doesn't come out of the nozzle, it does leak out under the 
front spoiler somewhere.  Indeed, it gushes each time I press the button. 
 Now, because the washer nozzle is mounted on the bumper, I don't see any 
easy way to get at this and fix it.  Does anyone know what's involved here? 
 Should I just cave in and take it to my mechanic?

Thanks in advance for any advice.

 Hubert Lai
 hl@orsil.ubc.ca

Subject: RE > 928S Questions & Stuff

                                                                    2:22 PM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      RE > 928S Questions & Stuff                   2/8/95
                                                              Date:


  >>Does your High intensity washer pump work?  This 
  >> is the button under your dash pod next to the wiper delay control wheel.

Mine was broken so I replaced it and I can hear a relay "click" when it's
pushed, but nothing else happens.  My normal washer pump works OK
and the headlite pump works great (when the headlites are up only!), but
whatever pump is run by the button doesn't do diddly.

In fixing the rest of the washer system I did run across multiple pumps (one
under the front tank that contains your special washer/cleaning solution and
one on the right fender).  For the life of me, I simply can't remember if
there
is also a pump under the fender tank.

I know the pump *on* the fender is the one for the windshield normal 
squirts as I had to trouble-shoot it.

This is one of my lower priority projects!

  >> Did you resolve the coolant level problem, or was it legitimately low
due to 
  >> the leaks?

After several days operation (heater on, a/c on, nothing on, etc.) and
checking
the level each day (add H2O a few times) it seems to be stable.  I'll check
again after my weekend trip (approx 650 miles).

  >> Chilton has a mini repair book for the 944 & 928.

Got it.  And the Porsche shop manuals.  And a bootlegged troubleshooting
guide for the temp controls.  Each has its use and (usually) the Chilton
manual
complements the Porsche manuals nicely.  At the least, you get two different
diagrams or pictures of the same thing ... sometimes that clears up questions
by itself!


John

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 17:55:40 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Headlight Washer

> 
> On my 1983 944, I have little headlight washers.  These are mounted on the 
> front bumper, and when I press the button in the cockpit a high pressure 
> stream of windshield washer fluid blasts the headlights.
> 
> At least, that's the way it's supposed to work.
> 
> When I press the button, only the left headlight washer works.  The 
> right-hand one doesn't work.  I though it might be plugged up with wax or 
> something, but despite poking around as best I could with a needle in the 
> nozzle, I wasn't able to fix it.

If you look inside the front bumper, you will see a couple of hoses with
connections that feed both the left and the right HL washer.  Since your
left one is working, you can assume that the fluid pressure is getting to
the junction...diagnosis from this point is left as an exercise for the
student.


> Washer fluid is getting to the front of the car though, because even though 
> washer fluid doesn't come out of the nozzle, it does leak out under the 
> front spoiler somewhere.  Indeed, it gushes each time I press the button. 
>  Now, because the washer nozzle is mounted on the bumper, I don't see any 
> easy way to get at this and fix it.  Does anyone know what's involved here? 
>  Should I just cave in and take it to my mechanic?
> 

Oh, the bumper is removed by two 19 mm bolts (accessed from the bottom of
the bumper through two access holes).  Use a half-inch drive socket if you
have it available. Rust can occasionally be hard to work through.
Be careful not to damage the connections to the lights mounted in the bumper.

Good luck,

- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 14:55:51 -0800 (PST)
From: Cherie Woodward <cherie@corp.cirrus.com>
Subject: Stan's 914 - Why? Because We Love It!



	I just wanted to add my $.02 to try and get this thread 
	to add up to a buck.

	Porschephiles is the greatest thing since baked and sliced
	ftp directories. We have a special forum and access to 
	an enormous amount of make-specific P-car information.
	At the drop of an email address, we can find out the
	how-tos of our next procedure, or (my case) start a
	conversation about the outcome of various adversities
	we're staring into (like the black hole containing 
	smog referees).

	These features and more and it's FREE! but not without great
	cost to the ListMeister (aka Stan).

	 There are other
	forums that we belong to that are luxuries - not necessities
	like PCA. We all have great fun and glean much information
	from our colleagues and gain special priviledges, but there are dues. 

	In this forum, we have real-time access to the *World*
	of Porsches. We don't have to wait until the next meeting
	or AutoX to chat up friends, peers and fellow 
	lovers of the marque.
	
	IMHO - If we think of this small donation
	as a one-time user fee, the value we've already gained
	has been offset.

	With fervent advocation in this regard -

	cherie

	PS Lend your support ASAP!

Date: Wed,  8 Feb 95 17:54:57 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 1995 Parade

> How long does it take to get notified if you are one
> of the 625 selected to go to the Parade?
It depends completely on the individual who's handling the registration 
task.  This year, with things going through PCA National, it's a bit 
different so nobody knows yet.  Historically the Registrar took a 
first-come, first-serve approach, based on normal your entry postmark 
date.  When the Registrar had sufficient personal time, he/she mailed 
confirmation packets.

> Also, does anyone know how the 'waiting list' works?
Same as above.  Once the 625 spots are filled, you go into a queue 
based on the postmark of your entry form.

		Jim

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 17:58:47 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 993s...questions about models?

> I haven't kept up very well with the new 993s. My father is considering getti
ng
> one and I'd like to have a better idea of what I'm talking about. Some
> questions:
> 
> 1) What is the 996? when is it coming out?
> 2) Has the C4, C2, and turbo all be updated to the new body style?
> 3) Prices of these models?
> 4) The targa is gone, right?
> 5) Can you get C2, C4, and Turbo is convertible?

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 18:57:03 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Handling (was sway bars)

Subj:	Handling (was sway bars)
Date:	95-02-08 05:50:05 EST
From:	dunham@bonehead.esd.sgi.com
To:porschephiles@tta.com


Last week I made a statement that a stiffer rear suspension would cause
a car to understeer rather than oversteer.  That was clearly
wrong.........(edited)

Bill

================================================================
Bill,  A sway bar is designed to help reduce body roll by increasing roll
resistance. This means that it will put more load on the outside tire than if
there were no swaybar. This will in effect make the load on the tires more
unequal, and reduce the traction at that end of the car. So a rear sway bar
would make the car oversteer more. This does not mean that you are ruining
the traction at that end of the car though. The loss of traction (due to
higher outside tire loading) is usually compensated for by better camber (due
to less roll). Also the traction at the OTHER end of the car is improved
because it will roll less as well. This also contributes to more oversteer. I
have found that you should tune your car to be neutral for best results. If
you can put larger rear tires on, the car will understeer more, so tighten or
install a larger rear swaybar to take advantage of the improved traction at
the back. This will transfer more traction to the front, make the car neutral
again, and improve your overall grip. Hope that wasn't too long winded!

Larry Herman
HermanHome@aol.com

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 95 19:54:54 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: How do you choose your oil.........


Text item: Text_1

We have had a lot of discussion recently about oil change intervals recently 
just about all of it driven by emotion not fact. As a relatively new owner (5 
months) of a relatively old (1986) 930 I am about to change my tranny oil both 
as prep for drivers ed. and as part of my twice yearly ritual. What I really 
need to know is whether there are any FACTS on which to base a choice of 
manufacturer or type ('natural' or synthetic?
For your info I choose my brand mainly by emotion. When I first owned an i.c.e. 
powered vehicle one od-ed on the smell of Castrol R so Castrol it had to be. 
Then my favorite Rally teams started to use Duckham's so I changed. When I moved
to good old Cinci, being 10 years behind the rest of the world meant no more of 
either so I switched to unknown brands like Quaker State and Valvolene. I am 
convinced that my Detroit V8 which couldn't pull the skin off boiled milk wore a
lot faster and sludged up more than the hotter little guys I had been used to. 
When Castrol became available here I switched back and my Fierro V6 never seemed
to wear or sludge much. However no facts............
It would also seem to me that the cost of synthetics and fancy brands (swepco) 
have a very poor price/performance ratio. I can get about four changes of 
Castrol dino base for the cost of one fancy oil, surely this would be a lot 
better for the mechanicals, especially with all of those little particles and 
gas and what not that Stan reminded us about floating about in the oil?
Any one have any facts? the facts man, just the facts..........

neil_nw_walker@ae.ge.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 21:48:31 -0500
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Re: How do you choose your oil.........

Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B wrote:
>It would also seem to me that the cost of synthetics and fancy brands
(swepco) >have a very poor price/performance ratio. I can get about four
changes of Castrol >dino base for the cost of one fancy oil, surely this
would be a lot better for the >mechanicals, especially with all of those
little particles and gas and what not >that Stan reminded us about floating
about in the oil? Any one have any facts? the >facts man, just the
facts..........

Well, as for facts, synthetics offer superior lubrication and better
viscosity characteristics, but they get just as dirty and contaminated as
any other oil.

I would use synthetic in a 930 (especially an early one) because synthetics
are much more resistant to "coking" (getting fried by turbo heat, and thus
leaving deposits on turbo bearings, leading to more turbo maintenance,
leading to thin wallet <grin>).

Your oil-change interval is up to you.. because it depends on *your*
driving. The only sure way to know is to get the oil tested (not a bad idea
in any case, but a bit expensive, as has been pointed out). The penalty for
over-due changes is pretty high, though.

One case where synthetics are clearly superior is in cold-weather startup.
If you live in an area like I do (and for your sake I hope you don't :), a
synthetic will actually save money over 5w30 dino in the winter if you're a
typical city commuter.


- --- <: snip! ;> ---
+ Craig Seko in Ottawa, the second coldest national capital in the world! +
| Personal'n'Porsche mail: cseko@inasec.ca  Work mail: sekocet@statcan.ca |
| URL Moved! http://www.inasec.ca/cseko/Welcome.html -nothing new, tho :( |
+ Usual opinion disclaimer :) I speak only for myself. Live free or die.  +

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 08 Feb 1995 19:28:01 -0800
From: David Gluss <david@pure.com>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1147 Wed Feb 8 20:34:36 CST 1995 

> I'm trying to replace the power window switches on my '80 928, the
> little diagrams on them have worn off.  How do I get them off?  How
> do I put the new ones on?  Thanks, Sean

Assuming it's the same as my 924 (which I am in the midst of),
you gently pull off the door liners and the switches are spring
mounted; they just pop off.  The switch top pops right off, spilling
little ball bearings and stuff.  If you want to cope with that, you
might be able to pry the switch out without removing the liner but
I wouldn't recommend it.

Once the switch is out, popping the top off and cleaning out the innards
is trivial.  I used brake cleaner, then WD40 in mine and now the windows
go up and down.

- --David Gluss    david@pure.com     408-524-3028  (1980 924)



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 19:41:55 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
Subject: Re : 7x16 Fuchs on '71 911

Hi Mike,

Thanks for the reply.

I did have an opportunity to try the wheels in question as you suggested.
My results were wierd to say the least. . .

The 7x16 with 225/50's were *way* to big on the back.  They actually stuck
out from underneath the wheel wells!  Attmpting to drive the car would have
probably resulted in crunched fenders and ruined tires!  They did fit on
the front but the looked really goofy.

The 6x16 with 205/55's fit well on the back, but here is where it gets
wierd.  The left wheel stuck out approx 1.5 cm further than the right wheel
on my 911.  At first I thought that the offset on these wheels *must* be
different.  Nope, same offset.

My car has never been crunched so that can't be the problem.  It tracks
well and tires wear out fairly evenly so alignment must be OK.  Then I got
to thinking that Porsches are, for the most part, handmade so there must be
some variation in the tolerances.  I wouldn't expect 1.5 cm though.

The point is moot though since I've decided that I don't really like that
"muscular" look on my car.  This in part because the black centers on the
16" wheels make my tangerene 911 look somewhat pumpkin like.

So, given the L to R difference on the rear and my desire to reduce the
pumpkin look, I've decided to look for some 6x15's with silver/polished on
black spokes and I'll probably go with 195/65's all around. They won't give
the grip of the 205/55 16's, but they will ride better, wear longer and
they will probably extend the limit of my car *way* beyond my ability.  At
least for a little while. :-}

Your suggestion about the 911R wheels is good, but I don't think I could
find them anywhere.  I understand they are extremely rare and therefore
very expensive.

Take care,



Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe
"I'm not sure we understand everything we know about this".

mailer!!  (Yes, I triple-checked the address!)

Paul F. Lyman
'82 911SC Targa  (and ~1/600 of a 914???)

P.S. Fred, Thanks again for taking the lead on this, and count me in!

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 22:49:13 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: WSCLM Porsche

Greetings:

Those of you who are lamenting the recent demise of the WSCLM factory
Porsches, there may still be hope.  Last week the registrar of the Sebring
PCA Club Race recieved a late entry.  The entrant was Porsche Motorsport and
the car was described as: Model-WSC, Color-white, Year-1995, Driver-unknown.
 Could this be a used as a test session for the 12 Hour in March?  Could
their withdrawl from Daytona have been due to the fact that they did not have
time to develop and test a new configuration?  Could this merely be a cruel
joke?
As the race is this weekend, and I will be there in the role of Chief
Steward, I will post the results of this interesting excersize early next
week.
Keep the WSCLM faith!!

pm9146@aol.com (Pat Moyle)

Date: Wed,  8 Feb 95 19:00:03 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: '74 Carrera RS

According to Lugvigsen, a few over 100 '74 Carrera RSs were made,
with about half being converted to RSRs. So, were any of the remaining
RSs imported into the States? If so, are they as expensive as '73 RSs?
Has anyone seen one for sale recently? Anyone know of an RS for sale
waiting to be restored? (Sure, fat chance, but I had to ask!)

They are obviously asking too much or they would have been sold by
now. $80K? Sheesh...

    Eric

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 21:46:52 -0700
From: Steve "THRUD" Cook <steve@prism.nmt.edu>
Subject: 944 water leak


  Hello Pphiles!
  Well, just about the time I get my license plate put on my new 944, 
I now find that I have a coolant leak.
  At first I thought it must be the H2O pump.  The leak, from looking
under the car, appeared to be underneath where the pump is located, but
further back.  The coolant comes down near the back end of the 
plate/"shield" at the bottom of the engine.  (through the last two "vents"
and off the back edge).  I checked the water pump, and I couldn't couldn't
see/feel any water coming from it. (hoses were dry and gasket seal appeared
to be intact-no coolant).
  I tried taking off the under plate/"shield" but couldn't get it off -
I must be missing some connection besides the two scresws and two bolts.
Could it be the block drain plug or something in that area?  Is there a bolt
or screw that I am missing to take the under plate off?  Any Ideas?

Thanks in Advance!
 -steve

General Location (SouthWest,West,NorthWest,Heartland,etc - or PCA region)
City
Address
Name
Description of past experiences/prices/quality of work etc.
Anything else you might think is interesting.

it becomes worthwhile :)

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 00:54:43 -0500
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: YAOQ-Yet another oil question

Given that one *is* changing one's oil every 5000kms, and one attends the
odd track event... should one, in addition:

        a. change the oil before a track event?
        b. change the oil after a track event?
        c. neither... just stick with the every 5000kms rule
        d. change the oil both before and after a track event.

It doesn't seem obvious to me, unlike changing brake fluid. The safe answer
is d., but I'm leaning towards c., in the absence of new knowledge. If one
had a carbureted car, I guess b. would make sense, to eliminate gasoline
introduced into the oil system by constant introduction of full-throttle,
but that should be negligible on a street-oriented car, anyways.

| URL Moved! http://www.inasec.ca/cseko/Welcome.html -nothing new, tho :( |
+ Usual opinion disclaimer :) I speak only for myself. Live free or die.  +

boom, once they hit 900 everything seemed to click.

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 1995 22:52:26 -0800 (PST)
From: Michael Lee <gqsmooth@u.washington.edu>
Subject: Re: Light bulbs absorb darkness?

Ligth bulbs work by causing an energy change in something.  This energy 
change causes some energy to be "kicked out".  In the case of most 
lightbulbs it is a tungsten filiament that is heated electrically till it 
gives off light.  But the same principal can be adaped to produce of the 
electromagnetic spectrum.

On Wed, 8 Feb 1995, Loren Lingren wrote:

> It has been brought to my attention that light bulbs don't really emit light, but
> rather absorb darkness.
> 
> Any comments or clairifications?
> 
> loren lingren
> 
> 

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 95 22:59:12 -0800
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Re:  928 Questions.....

On the subject of repair manuals...

>Chilton has a mini repair book for the 944 & 928.  I highly recommend 
>getting one.  No one else (Haynes, Motor, etc.) makes a book on the 928. 
> Though it's not near as comprehensive as the workshop manuals, it is a >good 
>deal at $8-10.  I refer to it for it's brief comprehensive explanations and 
>diagrams.  It's also easier to hold! :)  It's handy for things like >bleeding 
>the cooling system.
>I use my shop manuals when I need more detailed info. and before treading 
>into new areas of the car repair.

I was going to buy the Porsche repair manuals (before learning the price).  Much
to my surprise, the microfilm version of the shop manuals is very cheap.  I 
bought
the film, used, for $20, and a reader for $70.  The film covers all models from
1978-1989 (all country variations, also).  It is a photographic duplicate of the
printed manuals.

As for the Chilton's book:  I find it usefull for its brief and clear 
descriptions,
but it is lacking in many sections;  it cops out by saying that certain work 
must
only be attempted by qualified repair personnel (and, with this excuse, it 
simply
will not tell you what you need to know--as if you might injure yourself, or 
your
car, out of your own stupidity).


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 8 Feb 95 23:20:27 -0800
From: mike_s@deltanet.com (Mike Selfridge)
Subject: Leather or no dash...

>Return-Path: <porschephiles-request@tta.com>
>Date:         Wed, 08 Feb 95 17:43:14 EST
>From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
>Organization: The American University
>Subject:      Leather or no dash...
>To: Porschephiles@tta.com
>
>I want to buy a new door for my 928's glovebox.  I've found a couple of people
>who are parting 928's, but they all have asked me if I want a leather one or
>not.  My dashboard looks like leather,but so do my seats, which are vinyl(and
>psychedelic velour!).  The glovebox door has a wavering line across the top
>that looks like there is an air bubble under the leather/vinyl, does this mean
>anything to anyone, as far as to if it is leather or not?  Also, how much shoul
>d a used vinyl or leather glovebox door cost?  Thanks for any help, Se
>

I don't know of how much use this will be to you, but I had the same problem 
with
my 928 glove box.  Mine was sun damaged (warped and starting to crack).  My dash
is leather, and presumeably, so was my glove box door.  I priced a new 
leather glove
box door at $600!  I decided to pass up this incredible bargain, and purchase a
vinyl one for $100.  The vinyl one matches my leather dash pretty well.  Others
mistake it for leather.  I guess the point is, if you can't tell the difference,
why pay the difference?  My recommendation is:  (1) Determine if you dash is 
leather
(try scraping it with a knife blade in a hidden spot, and see if it roughs 
up like
leather).  (2) If it is leather, try to find a used leather glove box door 
for under
$200.  (3) If you can't find a used one, either pay the price for a new leather
one (ouch!), or try to match a vinyl one (seems a shame, but there are 
better things
on which to spend that extra $500).


------------------------------




Porschephiles #1149                         Thu Feb 9 09:47:16 CST 1995

Porschephiles #1149                         Thu Feb 9 09:47:16 CST 1995
Porschephiles #1149                         Thu Feb 9 09:47:16 CST 1995
Porschephiles #1149                         Thu Feb 9 09:47:16 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 02:03:56 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: YAOQ-Yet another oil question

> Given that one *is* changing one's oil every 5000kms, and one attends the
> odd track event... should one, in addition:
> 
>         a. change the oil before a track event?
>         b. change the oil after a track event?
>         c. neither... just stick with the every 5000kms rule
>         d. change the oil both before and after a track event.

Well, it depends. On the race cars, they get oil changes before every
day that they go onto the track, at after the end of the last day of
being on the track for a given weekend.

That typically means after Friday practice, after the race on Saturday
and Sunday. 

For a street car, I'd change oil after the track event even if I just
changed the oil before the track event. Remember, the main goal is to
remove crap from the engine, so after is better than before unless
the oil is really ugly before...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 02:05:57 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Confusing standards

> I'm not sure if this subject has been touched on yet but it would be 
> great if anyone could explain the differences between DIN, SAE, Break  
> Horsepower, European HP Standard, and anything else that appears in refrence 
> materials along the same line.  Any elaborations or conversion factors would 
> be appriciated. If this subject has been beaten to death sometime before 
> I joined, please reply to my personal E-mail.  

You need "the" reference book on all this stuff -- the Bosch Automotive
Handbook. It has all the definitions, all the conversions, and a ton
of useful formulas and capsule explainations of the theory, etc.

Available at many of the aftermarket suppliers for about $30, it's a
great investment in your automotive education.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 01:06:59 -0800
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: 912 Problem

To: Porschephiles

Subject: 912 Problem





     OK, guys- here's a True Story- one that happened this Monday-

and was an exercise in Porsche Problem Solving. See ifin you can

get the correct answer:

     The jinx, er, car in question was a 1969 912 that the owner

brought in smoking, leaking, and clutch-slipping.

     So, the Maestro grabbed one of his rebuilt '69 912 engines

off the shelf and stuck it into the owner's engine bay. Fired it up 

and voila- a nice-running, leak-free, power plant with a 

working clutch even. The owner was happy. The Maestro was happy. 

Everybody was happy! 

    A week later, last Sunday night in fact, the guy calls- he 

had broken down a few miles from the Maestro's shop, and was having 

the car towed over! The new engine had been running fine down the 

freeway, but when he pulled off to get gas, he heard a horrible 

grinding sound from the engine, followed by the Sound of Silence. 

   He tried to restart, but all he got was a "click" from

the starter. He tried to push-start it, but the ENGINE WOULDN'T 

TURN OVER! It was "seized", he said! 

     Bright and Early Monday Morning, the melancholy

Maestro made it to the shop. And sho' 'nough- there was the 

cursed 912 waiting for him- it's rust-filled front end grinnin' 

an evil grin. Sigh. 

    The Maestro got the keys that had been stuffed through

the mailbox slot, traipsed to the car like a man to the gallows, 

and tried to start it up. No go- the starter clicked weakly and 

that was it- it was just like the Gasoline Hammer Effect,...

or a seized engine! 

    The Maestro unhappily pushed it into his Shop. And hooked up 

a fresh 12 Volt battery to the beastie- and tried again. 

Still nothing- just a slightly longer "click" from the starter. 

  The Maestro got out his Metric Adjustible Wrench, attached it 

to the pulley nut and tried to turn the engine over. No go. 

No turnee. The pulley wouldn't turn either way! 

    Moan! Groan! Beseech the Porsche gods. Break the Emergency Virgin

Case and sacrifice one to the gods. Still no go.

The engine refused to turn over with the Starter or a wrench on the

pulley nut! 

 

   Question: What was wrong? (Hint: No Pete, it WASN'T the Maestro's

Engine that was at fault!)

      The Best Guess gets a free Spec Book!  Answer by E-mail

or call direct at (408) 727-1864.



And:

KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH

The Maestro




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:23:03 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: re: RE: Boxter retooling to end 968/928 production


| I can see  how the 928 could have problems with value/price positioning 
| relative to the new 993. It's always been an expensive Luxo barge and 
| I guess it's now caught on a sand bank.  I wonder why they never lowered 
| the price.  Surely it doesn't cost Porsche so much to make a 928 that they 
| ask for 80K+ a copy after delivery, dealer margin, etc., does it?

>From what I remember of visiting The Factory, about 1 or 2 928 are built
each day. You can't get much lower volume car production than that. The
lower the volume the higher the fixed costs per unit, OK they might have 
amortised off all the plant and tools since the 928 is 15 or so 
years old. Even so, building one car per day, not on a production line, 
mainly by hand is a *very* expensive process. Also, don't forget that 
labour, a significant component, is expensive in Europe. Also,
don't forget that Porsche actually make a tiny proportion of the 
components of their cars. In fact, the only thing that they really
fabricate is the leather interior, most everything else comes
in from outside manufacturers, I hate to think of the cost of
the 300 or so 928 aluminium blocks, crankshafts, camshafts or
cylinder heads required each year, in very low volume production runs. 
Ouch!

If the 928 and 968 made any significant money for Porsche, then 
I would expect them to bash them out as fast as possible. As it is,
the 993 in various forms makes up the greatest proportion of
production at Porsche, and one would presume, is the product
that is pushing Porsche back to being a viable business. Cut
your losses and roll your gains is the maxim being applied here I think.

I like all Porsche, the luxo barge <g> and other water
pumping variants are cool, and am sorry to seem them go, but the 
new company strategy seems to be to develop a core of related products (ie 
boxer-engined sports cars, from entry level to high-performance 
Ferrari bashers), to replace the existing incoherent "model range" 
(hotch-potch?) of somewhat ageing and wildly different cars.

Just my $0.02, I expect fully to be proven totally wrong <g>

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:19:51 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles/Stan's 914


Nate writes:

| What exactly did this guy do, anyway?  He sounds prettyu legendary,
| as most of the times I've seen his name mentioned it was spelled T*d. 
| How could somebody be such an asshole that he could be rejected by
| pfiles (who have put up with my most stupid of questions?)

As an historian of the ousting of T*d M, I would like
to recount the following incidents for the edification of those
who were not on the list at the time. T*d M appeared on the
list and caused heated flame wars on many subject including
the following crimes:


1.  Claimed skinny tyres and wheels always improve 911 handling

2.  Claimed racing on public roads was k00L

3.  Suggested that "the English is all screwed up" in the
    Haynes manual, causes much hilarity here in Europe, seems
    totally unaware that his dialect is not commonly spoken in 
    the English speaking world.

4.  Empirically demonstrated that early 911 power to weight
    ratio was superior to late model, once his math error
    was corrected, evidence contradicted his claim. Then suggests
    that power to weight ratio was unimportant in 911 performance.

5.  Unable to accept that he was wrong on any technical matter
    even when presented with factual evidence

6.  Claimed cheapo Wall-mart shocks better and longer lasting
    Bilstein or Koni.

7.  Kerb surfedDate: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 02:03:56 -0600 (CST)

>

>         b. change the oil after a track event?
>         c. neither... just stick with the every 5000kms rule
>         d. change the oil both before and after a track event.

day that they go onto the track, at after the end of the last day of

and Sunday. 

For a street car, I'd change oil after the track event even if I just

the oil is really ugly before...

pumping variants are cool, and am sorry to seem them go, but the 
new company strategy seems to be to develop a core of related products (ie 
boxer-engined sports cars, from entry level to high-performance 
Ferrari bashers), to replace the existing incoherent "model range" 
(hotch-potch?) of somewhat ageing and wildly different cars.

Just my $0.02, I expect fully to be proven totally wrong <g>

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:19:51 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles/Stan's 914


Nate writes:

| What exactly did this guy do, anyway?  He sounds prettyu legendary,
| as most of the times I've seen his name mentioned it was spelled T*d. 
| How could somebody be such an asshole that he could be rejected by
| pfiles (who have put up with my most stupid of questions?)

As an historian of the ousting of T*d M, I would like
to recount the following incidents for the edification of those
who were not on the list at the time. T*d M appeared on the
list and caused heated flame wars on many subject including
the following crimes:


1.  Claimed skinny tyres and wheels always improve 911 handling

2.  Claimed racing on public roads was k00L

3.  Suggested that "the English is all screwed up" in the
    Haynes manual, causes much hilarity here in Europe, seems
    totally unaware that his dialect is not commonly spoken in 
    the English speaking world.

4.  Empirically demonstrated that early 911 power to weight
    ratio was superior to late model, once his math error
    was corrected, evidence contradicted his claim. Then suggests
    that power to weight ratio was unimportant in 911 performance.

5.  Unable to accept that he was wrong on any technical matter
    even when presented with factual evidence

6.  Claimed cheapo Wall-mart shocks better and longer lasting
    Bilstein or Koni.

7.  Kerb surfedDate: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 02:03:56 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: YAOQ-Yet another oil question

> Given that one *is* changing one's oil every 5000kms, and one attends the
> odd track event... should one, in addition:
> 
>         a. change the oil before a track event?
>         b. change the oil after a track event?
>         c. neither... just stick with the every 5000kms rule
>         d. change the oil both before and after a track event.

Well, it depends. On the race cars, they get oil changes before every
day that they go onto the track, at after the end of the last day of
being on the track for a given weekend.

That typically means after Friday practice, after the race on Saturday
and Sunday. 

For a street car, I'd change oil after the track event even if I just
changed the oil before the track event. Remember, the main goal is to
remove crap from the engine, so after is better than before unless
the oil is really ugly before...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 02:05:57 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Confusing standards

> I'm not sure if this subject has been touched on yet but it would be 
> great if anyone could explain the differences between DIN, SAE, Break  
> Horsepower, European HP Standard, and anything else that appears in refrence 
> materials along the same line.  Any elaborations or conversion factors would 
> be appriciated. If this subject has been beaten to death sometime before 
> I joined, please reply to my personal E-mail.  

You need "the" reference book on all this stuff -- the Bosch Automotive
Handbook. It has all the definitions, all the conversions, and a ton
of useful formulas and capsule explainations of the theory, etc.

Available at many of the aftermarket suppliers for about $30, it's a
great investment in your automotive education.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 01:06:59 -0800
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: 912 Problem

To: Porschephiles

Subject: 912 Problem





     OK, guys- here's a True Story- one that happened this Monday-

and was an exercise in Porsche Problem Solving. See ifin you can

get the correct answer:

     The jinx, er, car in question was a 1969 912 that the owner

brought in smoking, leaking, and clutch-slipping.

     So, the Maestro grabbed one of his rebuilt '69 912 engines

off the shelf and stuck it into the owner's engine bay. Fired it up 

and voila- a nice-running, leak-free, power plant with a 

working clutch even. The owner was happy. The Maestro was happy. 

Everybody was happy! 

    A week later, last Sunday night in fact, the guy calls- he 

had broken down a few miles from the Maestro's shop, and was having 

the car towed over! The new engine had been running fine down the 

freeway, but when he pulled off to get gas, he heard a horrible 

grinding sound from the engine, followed by the Sound of Silence. 

   He tried to restart, but all he got was a "click" from

the starter. He tried to push-start it, but the ENGINE WOULDN'T 

TURN OVER! It was "seized", he said! 

     Bright and Early Monday Morning, the melancholy

Maestro made it to the shop. And sho' 'nough- there was the 

cursed 912 waiting for him- it's rust-filled front end grinnin' 

an evil grin. Sigh. 

    The Maestro got the keys that had been stuffed through

the mailbox slot, traipsed to the car like a man to the gallows, 

and tried to start it up. No go- the starter clicked weakly and 

that was it- it was just like the Gasoline Hammer Effect,...

or a seized engine! 

    The Maestro unhappily pushed it into his Shop. And hooked up 

a fresh 12 Volt battery to the beastie- and tried again. 

Still nothing- just a slightly longer "click" from the starter. 

  The Maestro got out his Metric Adjustible Wrench, attached it 

to the pulley nut and tried to turn the engine over. No go. 

No turnee. The pulley wouldn't turn either way! 

    Moan! Groan! Beseech the Porsche gods. Break the Emergency Virgin

Case and sacrifice one to the gods. Still no go.

The engine refused to turn over with the Starter or a wrench on the

pulley nut! 

 

   Question: What was wrong? (Hint: No Pete, it WASN'T the Maestro's

Engine that was at fault!)

      The Best Guess gets a free Spec Book!  Answer by E-mail

or call direct at (408) 727-1864.



And:

KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH

The Maestro




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:23:03 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: re: RE: Boxter retooling to end 968/928 production


| I can see  how the 928 could have problems with value/price positioning 
| relative to the new 993. It's always been an expensive Luxo barge and 
| I guess it's now caught on a sand bank.  I wonder why they never lowered 
| the price.  Surely it doesn't cost Porsche so much to make a 928 that they 
| ask for 80K+ a copy after delivery, dealer margin, etc., does it?

>From what I remember of visiting The Factory, about 1 or 2 928 are built
each day. You can't get much lower volume car production than that. The
lower the volume the higher the fixed costs per unit, OK they might have 
amortised off all the plant and tools since the 928 is 15 or so 
years old. Even so, building one car per day, not on a production line, 
mainly by hand is a *very* expensive process. Also, don't forget that 
labour, a significant component, is expensive in Europe. Also,
don't forget that Porsche actually make a tiny proportion of the 
components of their cars. In fact, the only thing that they really
fabricate is the leather interior, most everything else comes
in from outside manufacturers, I hate to think of the cost of
the 300 or so 928 aluminium blocks, crankshafts, camshafts or
cylinder heads required each year, in very low volume production runs. 
Ouch!

If the 928 and 968 made any significant money for Porsche, then 
I would expect them to bash them out as fast as possible. As it is,
the 993 in various forms makes up the greatest proportion of
production at Porsche, and one would presume, is the product
that is pushing Porsche back to being a viable business. Cut
your losses and roll your gains is the maxim being applied here I think.

I like all Porsche, the luxo barge <g> and other water
pumping variants are cool, and am sorry to seem them go, but the 
new company strategy seems to be to develop a core of related products (ie 
boxer-engined sports cars, from entry level to high-performance 
Ferrari bashers), to replace the existing incoherent "model range" 
(hotch-potch?) of somewhat ageing and wildly different cars.

Just my $0.02, I expect fully to be proven totally wrong <g>

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:19:51 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles/Stan's 914


Nate writes:

| What exactly did this guy do, anyway?  He sounds prettyu legendary,
| as most of the times I've seen his name mentioned it was spelled T*d. 
| How could somebody be such an asshole that he could be rejected by
| pfiles (who have put up with my most stupid of questions?)

As an historian of the ousting of T*d M, I would like
to recount the following incidents for the edification of those
who were not on the list at the time. T*d M appeared on the
list and caused heated flame wars on many subject including
the following crimes:


1.  Claimed skinny tyres and wheels always improve 911 handling

2.  Claimed racing on public roads was k00L

3.  Suggested that "the English is all screwed up" in the
    Haynes manual, causes much hilarity here in Europe, seems
    totally unaware that his dialect is not commonly spoken in 
    the English speaking world.

4.  Empirically demonstrated that early 911 power to weight
    ratio was superior to late model, once his math error
    was corrected, evidence contradicted his claim. Then suggests
    that power to weight ratio was unimportant in 911 performance.

5.  Unable to accept that he was wrong on any technical matter
    even when presented with factual evidence

6.  Claimed cheapo Wall-mart shocks better and longer lasting
    Bilstein or Koni.

7.  Kerb surfed his 911 as a demonstration of his driving prowess

8   Locked his keys in 911 with engine running, calls SO to
    bring spare keys, can't find them, breaks window (with head I expect)
    to get in. Wonders why everyone laughed at this story

9.  Claims Japanese sports cars are "better" than Porsche

10. Caused Stan to write three warnings including including the
    classic

   | Ted,
   |
   | I've had about enough of this crap. 

11. Started his own 911 email list, because Porschephiles not good enough
    for him, enrolled lots of porschephiles members without asking!

12. Autocrossed his 911 with four different tyres, including different
    sizes and manufaturers on the same axle!

13. Proved himself unable to stay on the course while autocrossing and
    clocked up times that could be beaten by a man with one leg on
    on a bicycle.

14. Was banned from the list due to massive public demand, then mail bombed
    list and individuals causing the list to be shut down for two
    days while emergency anti-Ted filters set up.

15. Wasted the Listmeisters time.

16. Caused me to write the following commemorative poem.

    Ted gone, forever
    roadkill on the infobahn.
    Listmeister got him, splat.

Regards

Ben

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:05:28 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Track oil frequency

Craig,
I don't have any real reason for doing this other than peer pressure but I
change my oil before every track event. I feel (in an anthropomorphic way)
that cars are like people. They perform better with a drink of fresh blood.
I also have this fear, because I've seen this happen, that I will blow an
engine and the first question that people will ask is "When is the last time
you changed your oil?"

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:47 am

------------------------------

Date: Thu, Feb 9, 1995 8:13 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Attempted car theft experience

Hi John,

> Afterwards, I would remove the steering wheel when I parked the car.

Neat story.  Takes me back to sunny Saigon, where everyone drove stolen
jeeps.  The principal difference between Newbies and old hands was the 
possession of a stolen Jeep.  Even those who were *issued* jeeps.  It was
sort of a rite of passage, and worked like this.

Newbie gets issued jeep, M1A1, one each.
Newbie takes jeep into Saigon, parks and locks same.
Newbie goes into Bar/Restaurant/Steam bath/Military Facility (take your pick).
Newbie comes back out to find jeep gone.
Old hands let newbie in on secret, *all* jeeps in use in Saigon are Stolen.
Newbie returns to Saigon and finds replacement, is now "old hand".
Old hand paints new bumper numbers on jeep, takes jeep to Saigon, parks same 
     and removes coil wire.
     [...too many time passes...] (no, that's not a misprint...)
Old hand comes out and finds jeep gone.  (using old coil wire) obtains *new*
    Jeep. 
Etc.

(sigh...)  War is Hell...



Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:14:46 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  928 Questions.....

    I too have the fiche version of the 928 shop manual. My problem
with it is that I find the schematics to be illegible - I just can't
read the little alphanumerics that you need to make the best use of
them. Are yours better? In general, the text is fine, the pictures are
more or less OK (hard to interpret sometimes, being negatives), but
the schematics just don't cut it. I'm trying to figure out whether
I need new fiche and/or reader, or if what I've got is about as good
as it's going to get, as long as I'm too cheap to spring for the
paper version.

 -John White-
'84 928S

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:51:48 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: who was t*d


Nathan asks:

>    What exactly did this guy do, anyway?  He sounds prettyu legendary,
>as most of the times I've seen his name mentioned it was spelled T*d. 
>How could somebody be such an asshole that he could be rejected by
>pfiles (who have put up with my most stupid of questions?)


How can I put it? T*d was a legend in his own mind, A rebel
without a clue, #10 on the sphincter scale. He had at least 6 months 
of warnings and good people were bailing out to keep from having
their computer space polluted by the guy several times a day.
Stan finally did the right thing - it was a mercy killing, honest.

By the way, Ted R. is the only one allowed to spell T*d's name
because of a terrible case of mistaken identity and filtered
mail, for which we are all deeply apologetic.

 - Reid





------------------------------

Date: Thu,  9 Feb 95 09:13:19 PST
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: power steering


I'm doing winter maintenance on my '84 928S and am considering flushing the power steering hydraulic fluid.  The shop manual has no information on this 
procedure - is it unnecessary?  I just recently bought the car; it has 61K miles and I must assume that this was never done.

There is a section on bleeding the system, but nothing on draining.  Any suggestions?  I thought I would just disconnect the pressure hose and run the pump 
until nothing comes out while turning the wheel.  Do I risk burning up the pump?  Also, I couldn't find a torque specification for the pressure hose in the 
manual (I may have overlooked it).

Any comments?  Is there a fluid change interval?  If I flush now, I probably won't flush for 4+ years (40,000 miles).

Matt Carpenter
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com



------------------------------

Date: Thu,  9 Feb 95 09:06:52 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; leather or not on dash


re; Leather or not on dash
>
>I want to buy a new door for my 928's glovebox.  I've found a couple of
> people who are parting 928's, but they all have asked me if I want a
> leather one or not.  My dashboard looks like leather,but so do my seats,
> which are vinyl(and psychedelic velour!).

   If your dashboard is warped, its Porsche Leather. If its cracked, its
 Porsche Vinyl.

   Likely your dash is leather if your door panels, headliner, center
 console and rear inner quarters are also leather. Vinyl looks pebbly
 and leather looks grainy. Chances are if you have the velour art deco
 interior then (lucky you) the only leather in the car is the shift boot.  

   Porsche cannot make dashes worth crap, but their vinyl dashes hold out
 10 times better than their leather-covered ones and the "full leather"
 option is a regrettable choice.
                                                          
             -Lee A.

interested reading, for those who may have a common problem, or would just
like to hear other owners comments and problems, without having to search all
the past archives.

help if you can. This would be a great addition to the FAQ!

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 1995 07:22:20 -0800 (PST)
From: YASEKR@YMV5.YMP.GOV
Subject: Oil filters (was oil interval)

Hey P-filers,

The thread about oil change intervals brought to mind my 
father's thoughts on the subject. He believes in changing 
the oil often, but contends that the filter need only be
changed every other oil change (which would put it at 
the regular recommended interval, or half that, depending
upon how often one changes oil). This seems to make sense,
since the filter is probably designed to handle the longer
interval. The main problem that I see is in 'contamination'
of the new oil with the old filter and remnant oil.

Is there merit to this or is it just New England parsimony 
showing through?

Regards,

Rob Yasek
'73 911T
'91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: 09 Feb 95 10:21:47 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Dealers & belt tension

 
Joe Hunter writes
>I suspect they do it [setting timing belt tension] by feel only. I guess if
>you do enough of these jobs, you get to know how tight from experience.
 
Even at Porsche, I knew lots of great mechanics who did not use the official
tensioning tool on some of our experimental engines, even though it was
readily available. They thought it was pretty mickey mouse and just did it
by feel. We never lost a belt, even with 600 hour full-throttle endurance
tests. Lost some other unrelated stuff though. These were non-Porsche engines.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:28:35 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Steve's water leak

Steve:
>I now find that I have a coolant leak.
>  At first I thought it must be the H2O pump.  The leak, from looking
>under the car, appeared to be underneath where the pump is located, but
>further back.  The coolant comes down near the back end of the 
>plate/"shield" at the bottom of the engine.  (through the last two "vents"
>and off the back edge).  I checked the water pump, and I couldn't couldn't
>see/feel any water coming from it. (hoses were dry and gasket seal appeared
>to be intact-no coolant).

How were you able to check the pump without removing the belt covers?
It has been my exprience that you can't see much of the pump to make a
true evaluation unless you remove the belts and covers. Lot's of work!

>  I tried taking off the under plate/"shield" but couldn't get it off -
>I must be missing some connection besides the two scresws and two bolts.
>Could it be the block drain plug or something in that area?  Is there a bolt
>or screw that I am missing to take the under plate off?  Any Ideas?

The shield is held in place by 7 bolts (10mm socket). 2 in front, 3 into
the crossmember (at the rear of the belly pan), an one each on the
side, by the chassis longitudinals...

Look for h20 leaks at the bottom of your timing belt covers. Water runs down
the back of the cover, and gets pushed by the air flow backwards. It will get
your sway bar wet, drip on the belly pan and flow back towards the
rear. There is drain plug by the exhaust manifold, hard to see or get to, but
I doubt that this is leaking.

Also, check the hoses that connect to the heater valve, right next to the 
brake booster. Hoses and valve could be leaking. They will drip by the clutch
housing and travel to the bottom...

Don't ask how I know about these things...:))))

Hope it helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:54:17 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turbo Life

<Jay writes, "How do I keep my 951 alive, it has 127,000 miles on it <and I
do track events

Jay,
You'll love the TA's. They really stick and are extremely stiff so you don't
want to go overboard on the camber. The numbers I gave you should be fine and
streetable also.
To keep you're turbo alive you need to do the rod bearings ASAP unless you
are sure of the cars' history. For example if it always used synthetic oil
and it always was changed at every 5000 miles and didn't spend allot of time
on the track and it never got low then I would say perhaps take a chance. If
not then get the bearings done. I know it's a major hit but trashing an
engine is allot worse and peace of mind is importatant when you are in a
situation the demands concentration.
To keep it alive after that I offer these suggestions,
1. Use synthetic oil
2. change it before every track event and every 5000 miles if no events.
3. ALWAYS keep it 1/2 quart high. (check after every run group)
4. If the temp gauge ever gets into the h his 911 as a demonstration of his driving prowess

8   Locked his keys in 911 with engine running, calls SO to
    bring spare keys, can't find them, breaks window (with head I expect)
    to get in. Wonders why everyone laughed at this story

9.  Claims Japanese sports cars are "better" than Porsche

10. Caused Stan to write three warnings including including the
    classic

   | Ted,
   |
   | I've had about enough of this crap. 

11. Started his own 911 email list, because Porschephiles not good enough
    for him, enrolled lots of porschephiles members without asking!

12. Autocrossed his 911 with four different tyres, including different
    sizes and manufaturers on the same axle!

13. Proved himself unable to stay on the course while autocrossing and
    clocked up times that could be beaten by a man with one leg on
    on a bicycle.

14. Was banned from the list due to massive public demand, then mail bombed
    list and individuals causing the list to be shut down for two
    days while emergency anti-Ted filters set up.

15. Wasted the Listmeisters time.

16. Caused me to write the following commemorative poem.

    Ted gone, forever
    roadkill on the infobahn.
    Listmeister got him, splat.

Regards

Ben

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:05:28 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Track oil frequency

Craig,
I don't have any real reason for doing this other than peer pressure but I
change my oil before every track event. I feel (in an anthropomorphic way)
that cars are like people. They perform better with a drink of fresh blood.
I also have this fear, because I've seen this happen, that I will blow an
engine and the first question that people will ask is "When is the last time
you changed your oil?"

Regards,
Jerry

89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats

Date: Thu, Feb 9, 1995 8:13 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Attempted car theft experience

Hi John,

> Afterwards, I would remove the steering wheel when I parked the car.

Neat story.  Takes me back to sunny Saigon, where everyone drove stolen
jeeps.  The principal difference between Newbies and old hands was the 
possession of a stolen Jeep.  Even those who were *issued* jeeps.  It was
sort of a rite of passage, and worked like this.

Newbie gets issued jeep, M1A1, one each.
Newbie takes jeep into Saigon, parks and locks same.
Newbie goes into Bar/Restaurant/Steam bath/Military Facility (take your pick).
Newbie comes back out to find jeep gone.
Old hands let newbie in on secret, *all* jeeps in use in Saigon are Stolen.
Newbie returns to Saigon and finds replacement, is now "old hand".
Old hand paints new bumper numbers on jeep, takes jeep to Saigon, parks same 
     and removes coil wire.
     [...too many time passes...] (no, that's not a misprint...)
Old hand comes out and finds jeep gone.  (using old coil wire) obtains *new*
    Jeep. 
Etc.

(sigh...)  War is Hell...



Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:52:38 -0500 (EST)

Subject: P9201 source

sources.  At the moment I'm trying to find a good price on a 944 Cam Belt Tool.

How can I put it? T*d was a legend in his own mind, A rebel
without a clue, #10 on the sphincter scale. He had at least 6 months 
of warnings and good people were bailing out to keep from having
their computer space polluted by the guy several times a day.
Stan finally did the right thing - it was a mercy killing, honest.

By the way, Ted R. is the only one allowed to spell T*d's name
because of a terrible case of mistaken identity and filtered
mail, for which we are all deeply apologetic.

Date: Thu,  9 Feb 95 09:13:19 PST
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: power steering


I'm doing winter maintenance on my '84 928S and am considering flushing the power steering hydraulic fluid.  The shop manual has no information on this 
procedure - is it unnecessary?  I just recently bought the car; it has 61K miles and I must assume that this was never done.

There is a section on bleeding the system, but nothing on draining.  Any suggestions?  I thought I would just disconnect the pressure hose and run the pump 
until nothing comes out while turning the wheel.  Do I risk burning up the pump?  Also, I couldn't find a torque specification for the pressure hose in the 
manual (I may have overlooked it).

Any comments?  Is there a fluid change interval?  If I flush now, I probably won't flush for 4+ years (40,000 miles).

Matt Carpenter
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com



------------------------------

Date: Thu,  9 Feb 95 09:06:52 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; leather or not on dash


re; Leather or not on dash
>
>I want to buy a new door for my 928's glovebox.  I've found a couple of
> people who are parting 928's, but they all have asked me if I want a
> leather one or not.  My dashboard looks like leather,but so do my seats,
> which are vinyl(and psychedelic velour!).

   If your dashboard is warped, its Porsche Leather. If its cracked, its
 Porsche Vinyl.

   Likely your dash is leather if your door panels, headliner, center
 console and rear inner quarters are also leather. Vinyl looks pebbly
 and leather looks grainy. Chances are if you have the velour art deco
 interior then (lucky you) the only leather in the car is the shift boot.  

   Porsche cannot make dashes worth crap, but their vinyl dashes hold out
 10 times better than their leather-covered ones and the "full leather"
 option is a regrettable choice.
                                                          
             -Lee A.

Date: 09 Feb 95 10:10:23 EST
From: Michael Kehr <71324.3010@compuserve.com>
Subject: 924/944/968 Owners Survey for FAQ

******************************************************************************

This is the second version of the 944 FAQ Survey Form. I have made a few
corrections (added current mileage, color, corrected spelling etc.) List 
members that have already completed this survey need not do so again. If you 
would like to send me your current mileage that would be great, but it is not 
nessessary

******************************************************************************


Hello All,

I am trying to prepare a owners report survey for the new 924/944/968 FAQ.
The purpose of the survey is to collect maintenance and repair records for the
924/944/968 series. I am including a form to make data input easier for you.

I am not sure what the final format will, but I will get a better idea when I
recieve your input. A comments section will appear at the end of the form for
any additional information you can provide. When completed, it make for some
interested reading, for those who may have a common problem, or would just
like to hear other owners comments and problems, without having to search all
the past archives.

  The more info I recieve the more accurate the survey. Please try to
help if you can. This would be a great addition to the FAQ!

Once I have the compilied the past section of the owners survey, I will
update the the owners report from time to time. This will then be posted
to the FAQ .(also to the list so all can see the results)

The completed form can be sent to me directly for review. DO NOT SEND TO
ENTIRE LIST!!

Mike Kehr  INTERNET:71324.3010@compuserve.com

I was thinking that a mileage format would be a good idea ( repairs and 
maintance list by mileage, and a topic, format ie. Waterpumps, motor mounts, 
clutches etc. Any comments, let me know.


TIA
