Date: Thu, 09 Feb 1995 07:22:20 -0800 (PST)
From: YASEKR@YMV5.YMP.GOV
Subject: Oil filters (was oil interval)

Hey P-filers,

The thread about oil change intervals brought to mind my 
father's thoughts on the subject. He believes in changing 
the oil often, but contends that the filter need only be
changed every other oil change (which would put it at 
the regular recommended interval, or half that, depending
upon how often one changes oil). This seems to make sense,
since the filter is probably designed to handle the longer
interval. The main problem that I see is in 'contamination'
of the new oil with the old filter and remnant oil.

Is there merit to this or is it just New England parsimony 
showing through?

Regards,

Rob Yasek
'73 911T
'91 Bixby Noodlehead

------------------------------

Date: 09 Feb 95 10:22:07 EST

I had full leather interiors with leather sport seats in my 81, 84 and 85
911s. I know the 81 was all manual; I don't remember how the 84 and 85 seats
adjusted. I liked the 81 sport seat design best of all.
 
Pete

Date: 09 Feb 95 10:21:47 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Dealers & belt tension

 
Joe Hunter writes
>I suspect they do it [setting timing belt tension] by feel only. I guess if
>you do enough of these jobs, you get to know how tight from experience.
 
Even at Porsche, I knew lots of great mechanics who did not use the official
tensioning tool on some of our experimental engines, even though it was
readily available. They thought it was pretty mickey mouse and just did it
by feel. We never lost a belt, even with 600 hour full-throttle endurance
tests. Lost some other unrelated stuff though. These were non-Porsche engines.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:28:35 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Steve's water leak

Steve:
>I now find that I have a coolant leak.
>  At first I thought it must be the H2O pump.  The leak, from looking
>under the car, appeared to be underneath where the pump is located, but
>further back.  The coolant comes down near the back end of the 
>plate/"shield" at the bottom of the engine.  (through the last two "vents"
>and off the back edge).  I checked the water pump, and I couldn't couldn't
>see/feel any water coming from it. (hoses were dry and gasket seal appeared
>to be intact-no coolant).

How were you able to check the pump without removing the belt covers?
It has been my exprience that you can't see much of the pump to make a
true evaluation unless you remove the belts and covers. Lot's of work!

>  I tried taking off the under plate/"shield" but couldn't get it off -
>I must be missing some connection besides the two scresws and two bolts.
>Could it be the block drain plug or something in that area?  Is there a bolt
>or screw that I am missing to take the under plate off?  Any Ideas?

The shield is held in place by 7 bolts (10mm socket). 2 in front, 3 into
the crossmember (at the rear of the belly pan), an one each on the
side, by the chassis longitudinals...

Look for h20 leaks at the bottom of your timing belt covers. Water runs down
the back of the cover, and gets pushed by the air flow backwards. It will get
your sway bar wet, drip on the belly pan and flow back towards the
rear. There is drain plug by the exhaust manifold, hard to see or get to, but
I doubt that this is leaking.

Also, check the hoses that connect to the heater valve, right next to the 
brake booster. Hoses and valve could be leaking. They will drip by the clutch
housing and travel to the bottom...

Don't ask how I know about these things...:))))

Hope it helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:54:17 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turbo Life

<Jay writes, "How do I keep my 951 alive, it has 127,000 miles on it <and I
do track events

Jay,
You'll love the TA's. They really stick and are extremely stiff so you don't
want to go overboard on the camber. The numbers I gave you should be fine and
streetable also.
To keep you're turbo alive you need to do the rod bearings ASAP unless you
are sure of the cars' history. For example if it always used synthetic oil
and it always was changed at every 5000 miles and didn't spend allot of time
on the track and it never got low then I would say perhaps take a chance. If
not then get the bearings done. I know it's a major hit but trashing an
engine is allot worse and peace of mind is importatant when you are in a
situation the demands concentration.
To keep it alive after that I offer these suggestions,
1. Use synthetic oil
2. change it before every track event and every 5000 miles if no events.
3. ALWAYS keep it 1/2 quart high. (check after every run group)
4. If the temp gauge ever gets into the high range shut it down and find out
what is wrong.
5. Use 93 octane gas always.
6. Don't put a chip in it. You WILL blow a head gasket, thereby getting water
in the oil and necessitating another bearing change.
I could go on and on about chips but that is another topic for another day.
BTW I didn't know that turn 4 was a real turn, I always treated it as a place
to lift a little and turn in. Actually having slid sideways down the chute
once I do treat that area with a great deal of respect. I do brake a bit
there.
Got to pack, leaving for Sebring at 4 this afternoon. I'll let you know what
happens

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
10:44 am

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 95 10:55:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Headlight Washer


If it's tough for you to fix, imagine what the dealer will charge you to do 
it!  I had a similar problem on my 928.  I was able to get to it once I 
jacked the front of the car up and went from underneath, still wasn't easy! 
 There are some hoses and some plastic pieces, somewhere it was clogged. 
 Blowing compressed air through it cleared it up for me.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 95 10:55:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Power window switches...


Sean,
If you take the carpeted side panel off from the side of the console you can 
reach in and push the switch up.  There is only a retainer clip that holds 
them in.  Similar to removing the coin dispenser on the drivers door.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 95 10:55:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Leather or no dash...


Sean,
Sounds like you have vinyl.   If your dash is leather, you should see 
pronounced stitching on your dash.

I've only seen the leather dash come with leather seats as part of a 
complete leather package.  Leather seats were available with the standard 
vinyl dash as well.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:54:17 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turbo Life

<Jay writes, "How do I keep my 951 alive, it has 127,000 miles on it <and I
do track events

Jay,
You'll love the TA's. They really stick and are extremely stiff so you don't
want to go overboard on the camber. The numbers I gave you should be fine and
streetable also.
To keep you're turbo alive you need to do the rod bearings ASAP unless you
are sure of the cars' history. For example if it always used synthetic oil
and it always was changed at every 5000 miles and didn't spend allot of time
on the track and it never got low then I would say perhaps take a chance. If
not then get the bearings done. I know it's a major hit but trashing an
engine is allot worse and peace of mind is importatant when you are in a
situation the demands concentration.
To keep it alive after that I offer these suggestions,
1. Use synthetic oil
2. change it before every track event and every 5000 miles if no events.
3. ALWAYS keep it 1/2 quart high. (check after every run group)
4. If the temp gauge ever gets into the high range shut it down and find out
what is wrong.
5. Use 93 octane gas always.
6. Don't put a chip in it. You WILL blow a head gasket, thereby getting water
in the oil and necessitating another bearing change.
I could go on and on about chips but that is another topic for another day.
BTW I didn't know that turn 4 was a real turn, I always treated it as a place
to lift a little and turn in. Actually having slid sideways down the chute
once I do treat that area with a great deal of respect. I do brake a bit
there.
Got to pack, leaving for Sebring at 4 this afternoon. I'll let you know what
happens

Regards,
Jerry

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 95 10:55:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Headlight Washer


If it's tough for you to fix, imagine what the dealer will charge you to do 
it!  I had a similar problem on my 928.  I was able to get to it once I 
jacked the front of the car up and went from underneath, still wasn't easy! 
 There are some hoses and some plastic pieces, somewhere it was clogged. 
 Blowing compressed air through it cleared it up for me.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 95 10:55:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Power window switches...


Sean,
If you take the carpeted side panel off from the side of the console you can 
reach in and push the switch up.  There is only a retainer clip that holds 
them in.  Similar to removing the coin dispenser on the drivers door.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 95 10:55:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Leather or no dash...


Sean,
Sounds like you have vinyl.   If your dash is leather, you should see 
pronounced stitching on your dash.

I've only seen the leather dash come with leather seats as part of a 
complete leather package.  Leather seats were available with the standard 
vinyl dash as well.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 02:03:56 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: YAOQ-Yet another oil question

> Given that one *is* changing one's oil every 5000kms, and one attends the
> odd track event... should one, in addition:
> 
>         a. change the oil before a track event?
>         b. change the oil after a track event?
>         c. neither... just stick with the every 5000kms rule
>         d. change the oil both before and after a track event.

Well, it depends. On the race cars, they get oil changes before every
day that they go onto the track, at after the end of the last day of
being on the track for a given weekend.

That typically means after Friday practice, after the race on Saturday
and Sunday. 

For a street car, I'd change oil after the track event even if I just
changed the oil before the track event. Remember, the main goal is to
remove crap from the engine, so after is better than before unless
the oil is really ugly before...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 02:05:57 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Confusing standards

> I'm not sure if this subject has been touched on yet but it would be 
> great if anyone could explain the differences between DIN, SAE, Break  
> Horsepower, European HP Standard, and anything else that appears in refrence 
> materials along the same line.  Any elaborations or conversion factors would 
> be appriciated. If this subject has been beaten to death sometime before 
> I joined, please reply to my personal E-mail.  

You need "the" reference book on all this stuff -- the Bosch Automotive
Handbook. It has all the definitions, all the conversions, and a ton
of useful formulas and capsule explainations of the theory, etc.

Available at many of the aftermarket suppliers for about $30, it's a
great investment in your automotive education.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 01:06:59 -0800
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: 912 Problem

To: Porschephiles

Subject: 912 Problem





     OK, guys- here's a True Story- one that happened this Monday-

and was an exercise in Porsche Problem Solving. See ifin you can

get the correct answer:

     The jinx, er, car in question was a 1969 912 that the owner

brought in smoking, leaking, and clutch-slipping.

     So, the Maestro grabbed one of his rebuilt '69 912 engines

off the shelf and stuck it into the owner's engine bay. Fired it up 

and voila- a nice-running, leak-free, power plant with a 

working clutch even. The owner was happy. The Maestro was happy. 

Everybody was happy! 

    A week later, last Sunday night in fact, the guy calls- he 

had broken down a few miles from the Maestro's shop, and was having 

the car towed over! The new engine had been running fine down the 

freeway, but when he pulled off to get gas, he heard a horrible 

grinding sound from the engine, followed by the Sound of Silence. 

   He tried to restart, but all he got was a "click" from

the starter. He tried to push-start it, but the ENGINE WOULDN'T 

TURN OVER! It was "seized", he said! 

     Bright and Early Monday Morning, the melancholy

Maestro made it to the shop. And sho' 'nough- there was the 

cursed 912 waiting for him- it's rust-filled front end grinnin' 

an evil grin. Sigh. 

    The Maestro got the keys that had been stuffed through

the mailbox slot, traipsed to the car like a man to the gallows, 

and tried to start it up. No go- the starter clicked weakly and 

that was it- it was just like the Gasoline Hammer Effect,...

or a seized engine! 

    The Maestro unhappily pushed it into his Shop. And hooked up 

a fresh 12 Volt battery to the beastie- and tried again. 

Still nothing- just a slightly longer "click" from the starter. 

  The Maestro got out his Metric Adjustible Wrench, attached it 

to the pulley nut and tried to turn the engine over. No go. 

No turnee. The pulley wouldn't turn either way! 

    Moan! Groan! Beseech the Porsche gods. Break the Emergency Virgin

Case and sacrifice one to the gods. Still no go.

The engine refused to turn over with the Starter or a wrench on the

pulley nut! 

 

   Question: What was wrong? (Hint: No Pete, it WASN'T the Maestro's

Engine that was at fault!)

      The Best Guess gets a free Spec Book!  Answer by E-mail

or call direct at (408) 727-1864.



And:

KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH

The Maestro




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:23:03 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: re: RE: Boxter retooling to end 968/928 production


| I can see  how the 928 could have problems with value/price positioning 
| relative to the new 993. It's always been an expensive Luxo barge and 
| I guess it's now caught on a sand bank.  I wonder why they never lowered 
| the price.  Surely it doesn't cost Porsche so much to make a 928 that they 
| ask for 80K+ a copy after delivery, dealer margin, etc., does it?

>From what I remember of visiting The Factory, about 1 or 2 928 are built
each day. You can't get much lower volume car production than that. The
lower the volume the higher the fixed costs per unit, OK they might have 
amortised off all the plant and tools since the 928 is 15 or so 
years old. Even so, building one car per day, not on a production line, 
mainly by hand is a *very* expensive process. Also, don't forget that 
labour, a significant component, is expensive in Europe. Also,
don't forget that Porsche actually make a tiny proportion of the 
components of their cars. In fact, the only thing that they really
fabricate is the leather interior, most everything else comes
in from outside manufacturers, I hate to think of the cost of
the 300 or so 928 aluminium blocks, crankshafts, camshafts or
cylinder heads required each year, in very low volume production runs. 
Ouch!

If the 928 and 968 made any significant money for Porsche, then 
I would expect them to bash them out as fast as possible. As it is,
the 993 in various forms makes up the greatest proportion of
production at Porsche, and one would presume, is the product
that is pushing Porsche back to being a viable business. Cut
your losses and roll your gains is the maxim being applied here I think.

I like all Porsche, the luxo barge <g> and other water
pumping variants are cool, and am sorry to seem them go, but the 
new company strategy seems to be to develop a core of related products (ie 
boxer-engined sports cars, from entry level to high-performance 
Ferrari bashers), to replace the existing incoherent "model range" 
(hotch-potch?) of somewhat ageing and wildly different cars.

Just my $0.02, I expect fully to be proven totally wrong <g>

Regards

Ben

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:19:51 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles/Stan's 914


Nate writes:

| What exactly did this guy do, anyway?  He sounds prettyu legendary,
| as most of the times I've seen his name mentioned it was spelled T*d. 
| How could somebody be such an asshole that he could be rejected by
| pfiles (who have put up with my most stupid of questions?)

As an historian of the ousting of T*d M, I would like
to recount the following incidents for the edification of those
who were not on the list at the time. T*d M appeared on the
list and caused heated flame wars on many subject including
the following crimes:


1.  Claimed skinny tyres and wheels always improve 911 handling

2.  Claimed racing on public roads was k00L

3.  Suggested that "the English is all screwed up" in the
    Haynes manual, causes much hilarity here in Europe, seems
    totally unaware that his dialect is not commonly spoken in 
    the English speaking world.

4.  Empirically demonstrated that early 911 power to weight
    ratio was superior to late model, once his math error
    was corrected, evidence contradicted his claim. Then suggests
    that power to weight ratio was unimportant in 911 performance.

5.  Unable to accept that he was wrong on any technical matter
    even when presented with factual evidence

6.  Claimed cheapo Wall-mart shocks better and longer lasting
    Bilstein or Koni.

7.  Kerb surfed his 911 as a demonstration of his driving prowess

8   Locked his keys in 911 with engine running, calls SO to
    bring spare keys, can't find them, breaks window (with head I expect)
    to get in. Wonders why everyone laughed at this story

9.  Claims Japanese sports cars are "better" than Porsche

10. Caused Stan to write three warnings including including the
    classic

   | Ted,
   |
   | I've had about enough of this crap. 

11. Started his own 911 email list, because Porschephiles not good enough
    for him, enrolled lots of porschephiles members without asking!

12. Autocrossed his 911 with four different tyres, including different
    sizes and manufaturers on the same axle!

13. Proved himself unable to stay on the course while autocrossing and
    clocked up times that could be beaten by a man with one leg on
    on a bicycle.

14. Was banned from the list due to massive public demand, then mail bombed
    list and individuals causing the list to be shut down for two
    days while emergency anti-Ted filters set up.

15. Wasted the Listmeisters time.

16. Caused me to write the following commemorative poem.

    Ted gone, forever
    roadkill on the infobahn.
    Listmeister got him, splat.

Regards

Ben

Craig,
I don't have any real reason for doing this other than peer pressure but I
change my oil before every track event. I feel (in an anthropomorphic way)
that cars are like people. They perform better with a drink of fresh blood.
I also have this fear, because I've seen this happen, that I will blow an
engine and the first question that people will ask is "When is the last time
you changed your oil?"

Date: Thu, Feb 9, 1995 8:13 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Attempted car theft experience

Hi John,

> Afterwards, I would remove the steering wheel when I parked the car.

Neat story.  Takes me back to sunny Saigon, where everyone drove stolen
jeeps.  The principal difference between Newbies and old hands was the 
possession of a stolen Jeep.  Even those who were *issued* jeeps.  It was
sort of a rite of passage, and worked like this.

Newbie gets issued jeep, M1A1, one each.
Newbie takes jeep into Saigon, parks and locks same.
Newbie goes into Bar/Restaurant/Steam bath/Military Facility (take your pick).
Newbie comes back out to find jeep gone.
Old hands let newbie in on secret, *all* jeeps in use in Saigon are Stolen.
Newbie returns to Saigon and finds replacement, is now "old hand".
Old hand paints new bumper numbers on jeep, takes jeep to Saigon, parks same 
     and removes coil wire.
     [...too many time passes...] (no, that's not a misprint...)
Old hand comes out and finds jeep gone.  (using old coil wire) obtains *new*
    Jeep. 
Etc.

(sigh...)  War is Hell...



Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora
'77 Feline Varmint, Felix, Gray
'86 Carrera Cabriolet, Indischrot
'87 Syncro (Stealth Quattro) Alpenweiss

Date: Thu,  9 Feb 95 09:13:19 PST
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: power steering


I'm doing winter maintenance on my '84 928S and am considering flushing the power steering hydraulic fluid.  The shop manual has no information on this 
procedure - is it unnecessary?  I just recently bought the car; it has 61K miles and I must assume that this was never done.

There is a section on bleeding the system, but nothing on draining.  Any suggestions?  I thought I would just disconnect the pressure hose and run the pump 
until nothing comes out while turning the wheel.  Do I risk burning up the pump?  Also, I couldn't find a torque specification for the pressure hose in the 
manual (I may have overlooked it).

Any comments?  Is there a fluid change interval?  If I flush now, I probably won't flush for 4+ years (40,000 miles).

Matt Carpenter
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com



------------------------------

Date: Thu,  9 Feb 95 09:06:52 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; leather or not on dash


re; Leather or not on dash
>
>I want to buy a new door for my 928's glovebox.  I've found a couple of
> people who are parting 928's, but they all have asked me if I want a
> leather one or not.  My dashboard looks like leather,but so do my seats,
> which are vinyl(and psychedelic velour!).

   If your dashboard is warped, its Porsche Leather. If its cracked, its
 Porsche Vinyl.

   Likely your dash is leather if your door panels, headliner, center
 console and rear inner quarters are also leather. Vinyl looks pebbly
 and leather looks grainy. Chances are if you have the velour art deco
 interior then (lucky you) the only leather in the car is the shift boot.  

   Porsche cannot make dashes worth crap, but their vinyl dashes hold out
 10 times better than their leather-covered ones and the "full leather"
 option is a regrettable choice.
                                                          
             -Lee A.

Hello All,

I am trying to prepare a owners report survey for the new 924/944/968 FAQ.
The purpose of the survey is to collect maintenance and repair records for the
924/944/968 series. I am including a form to make data input easier for you.

I am not sure what the final format will, but I will get a better idea when I
recieve your input. A comments section will appear at the end of the form for
any additional information you can provide. When completed, it make for some
interested reading, for those who may have a common problem, or would just
like to hear other owners comments and problems, without having to search all
the past archives.

help if you can. This would be a great addition to the FAQ!

update the the owners report from time to time. This will then be posted
to the FAQ .(also to the list so all can see the results)

ENTIRE LIST!!

Mike Kehr  INTERNET:71324.3010@compuserve.com

Sean,
If you take the carpeted side panel off from the side of the console you can

them in.  Similar to removing the coin dispenser on the drivers door.

From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: RE: Leather or no dash...


Sean,
Sounds like you have vinyl.   If your dash is leather, you should see 
pronounced stitching on your dash.

I've only seen the leather dash come with leather seats as part of a 
complete leather package.  Leather seats were available with the standard 
vinyl dash as well.

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 1995 07:22:20 -0800 (PST)
From: YASEKR@YMV5.YMP.GOV
Subject: Oil filters (was oil interval)

Hey P-filers,

The thread about oil change intervals brought to mind my 
father's thoughts on the subject. He believes in changing 
the oil often, but contends that the filter need only be
changed every other oil change (which would put it at 
the regular recommended interval, or half that, depending
upon how often one changes oil). This seems to make sense,
since the filter is probably designed to handle the longer
interval. The main problem that I see is in 'contamination'
of the new oil with the old filter and remnant oil.

Is there merit to this or is it just New England parsimony 
showing through?

Regards,

Rob Yasek
'73 911T
'91 Bixby Noodlehead

Date: 09 Feb 95 10:21:47 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Dealers & belt tension

 
Joe Hunter writes
>I suspect they do it [setting timing belt tension] by feel only. I guess if
>you do enough of these jobs, you get to know how tight from experience.
 
Even at Porsche, I knew lots of great mechanics who did not use the official
tensioning tool on some of our experimental engines, even though it was
readily available. They thought it was pretty mickey mouse and just did it
by feel. We never lost a belt, even with 600 hour full-throttle endurance
tests. Lost some other unrelated stuff though. These were non-Porsche engines.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:28:35 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: Steve's water leak

Steve:
>I now find that I have a coolant leak.
>  At first I thought it must be the H2O pump.  The leak, from looking
>under the car, appeared to be underneath where the pump is located, but
>further back.  The coolant comes down near the back end of the 
>plate/"shield" at the bottom of the engine.  (through the last two "vents"
>and off the back edge).  I checked the water pump, and I couldn't couldn't
>see/feel any water coming from it. (hoses were dry and gasket seal appeared
>to be intact-no coolant).

How were you able to check the pump without removing the belt covers?
It has been my exprience that you can't see much of the pump to make a
true evaluation unless you remove the belts and covers. Lot's of work!

>  I tried taking off the under plate/"shield" but couldn't get it off -
>I must be missing some connection besides the two scresws and two bolts.
>Could it be the block drain plug or something in that area?  Is there a bolt
>or screw that I am missing to take the under plate off?  Any Ideas?

The shield is held in place by 7 bolts (10mm socket). 2 in front, 3 into
the crossmember (at the rear of the belly pan), an one each on the
side, by the chassis longitudinals...

Look for h20 leaks at the bottom of your timing belt covers. Water runs down
the back of the cover, and gets pushed by the air flow backwards. It will get
your sway bar wet, drip on the belly pan and flow back towards the
rear. There is drain plug by the exhaust manifold, hard to see or get to, but
I doubt that this is leaking.

Also, check the hoses that connect to the heater valve, right next to the 
brake booster. Hoses and valve could be leaking. They will drip by the clutch
housing and travel to the bottom...

Don't ask how I know about these things...:))))

Hope it helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:54:17 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Turbo Life

<Jay writes, "How do I keep my 951 alive, it has 127,000 miles on it <and I
do track events

Jay,
You'll love the TA's. They really stick and are extremely stiff so you don't
want to go overboard on the camber. The numbers I gave you should be fine and
streetable also.
To keep you're turbo alive you need to do the rod bearings ASAP unless you
are sure of the cars' history. For example if it always used synthetic oil
and it always was changed at every 5000 miles and didn't spend allot of time
on the track and it never got low then I would say perhaps take a chance. If
not then get the bearings done. I know it's a major hit but trashing an
engine is allot worse and peace of mind is importatant when you are in a
situation the demands concentration.
To keep it alive after that I offer these suggestions,
1. Use synthetic oil
2. change it before every track event and every 5000 miles if no events.
3. ALWAYS keep it 1/2 quart high. (check after every run group)
4. If the temp gauge ever gets into the high range shut it down and find out
what is wrong.
5. Use 93 octane gas always.
6. Don't put a chip in it. You WILL blow a head gasket, thereby getting water
in the oil and necessitating another bearing change.
I could go on and on about chips but that is another topic for another day.
BTW I didn't know that turn 4 was a real turn, I always treated it as a place
to lift a little and turn in. Actually having slid sideways down the chute
once I do treat that area with a great deal of respect. I do brake a bit
there.
Got to pack, leaving for Sebring at 4 this afternoon. I'll let you know what
happens

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
10:44 am

John,
The book covers both the 928 and the 924/944.  It is sold anywhere they sell 
these mini Chilton books (part stores, book stores) .  If you do not see it, 
look in the back of any Chilton book for a listing of all the Chilton repair 
guides with their numbers.  The sales clerk should be able to order you one 
from that.

I also remember one of the large glossy mail order houses selling it, I 
think Automotion.  But they sell it for full list price + S/H.

Bob,

Thanks for the info on meters' impedance.
I read a post today from Lee Atkinson with great interest : it seems
that at best power the mixture should be rich, and this is all I care about.

So I think a Digital meter on the 0-2 sensor will be up near
1V when it is rich enough for best power 13-14. So I may be better
off with something like the Edelbrock meter which is calibrateed from
12 and up. It must be sensitive to small changes around 1V.

I'm glad to hear you had success in cleaning out you MFI pump
yourself. I'm afraid mine needs more than cleaning, as it's calibration
was screwed up by Hans at H & R. Next month I will have time to
send it out and get it checked.

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:15:46 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Big tires on early 911

Dave--

I hadn't responded to this thread until now, but my experience might be
useful.  My '72 came to me with 7x15 wheels and with 205-60s on the
front and 215-60s on the back.  It also came to me with blisters on the
two rear fenders where the back tires had rubbed.  It didn't seem to
happen often, though, so I drove carefully until I replaced the tires
with 205-60s all around.  I've been in this configuration for 5 years
now.  I occasionally hear a quick rubbing noise on bumps, but I haven't
had any further problem with blisters.

I have a suspicion that my ride height is less than standard, and that
if the car was raised a tiny bit I'd have no problem at all.  But I like
the way it looks at the current height :-)

Another data point for you to consider...

- --Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil)

------------------------------

Date: 09 Feb 95 08:39:23 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Do winged 911s run cooler?


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Do winged 911s run cooler?
Date: 1995-02-09 10:25
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

OK I've got a new thread for you guys.  I noticed something a few years back
when I put a duck tail on our '72 911 -- it seemed to run cooler.  I was
reminded of this when we got the '84 recently, it has a Carrera tail and
seems to run cooler than our other '84 that didn't have one.  Being the
shadetree en-gun-neer that I am, I was wondering if anyone that truly
understands the aerodynamics or other forces at work could explain this.

The way I figure:  A tail causes either less lift or maybe even downforce at
speed, right?  If there is lift at the back of the car (now I'm thinking in
terms of a slight vacuum), then the cooling fan is less efficient at pulling
air in and pushing it over the cylinders and engine oil cooler.  If you
decrease the lift the fan moves more air at any given rpm, thus a cooler
running motor.  If the wing is large enough to actually create downforce,
well all the better...

OK, I'm ready for this one to be swiss-cheesed by all you rapid firing
"real" en-gun-neers...

 -Scott Jessen
'72 ASP 911 (ugly *and* mean)
'84 911 Carrera (too cool to go slow) (or is that *not* cool to go slow ;-))



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 09:05:29 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Theory of Dark

The recent discussion of light bulb theory caused me to resurrect the
following from a newsletter I used to edit; it's a bit off topic, but it
should settle the issue once and for all... :-)

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

DARKNESS, BE GONE

For years it has been believed that electric bulbs emitted a substance
or energy called light.  Recent information, however, has proven
otherwise.  Electric bulbs don't emit light - they suck dark.  We
should thus call these bulbs dark suckers.  In addition to proving this
fact, the Dark Sucker Theory also presents a number of other basic
theorems concerning the properties of dark.  For example, the speed of
dark is greater than that of light, and dark has greater mass than
light.

The basis of the Dark Sucker Theory is that electric bulbs suck dark.
Take for example the dark suckers in the room where you are.  There is
less dark right next to them than there is elsewhere.  The larger the
dark suckers, the greater their capacity to suck dark.  Dark suckers in
a parking lot have much greater capacity than the ones in this room.
As with all things, dark suckers don't last forever.  Once they are
full of dark, they can no longer suck.  This is proven by the black
spot on a full dark sucker.  

A candle is a primitive dark sucker.  A new candle has a white wick.
You will notice that after the first use, the wick turns black,
representing the dark which has been sucked into it.  If you hold a
pencil next to the wick on an operating candle, the tip will turn
black, because it got in the way of the dark flowing into the candle.

There are also portable dark suckers.  The bulbs in these units can't
handle all of the dark by themselves, and must be aided by a dark
storage unit.  When the dark storage unit is full, it must be either
emptied or replaced before the portable dark sucker can operate again.
If you break open one of these filled canisters, one will see that
there is indeed a great quantity of stored dark on the inside.  

Dark has mass.  When dark goes into a dark sucker, friction from this
mass passing through another mass will generate a certain amount of
heat.  It is commonly known that an operating dark sucker generates
heat.  The dark suckers with the greatest capacities force the dark to
travel through the impeding media at greater rates of speed, so they
develop greater amounts of heat.  Thus, it is not wise to touch a
operating dark sucker.

Candles present a special problem.  Though the light does not have to
travel through a solid substance like the glass forming an electric
bulb, the dark must travel into the solid wick, instead of a void as is
found inside of the bulb.  As we all know, this process generates a
great amount of heat.  In fact, flammable items which come into contact
with an operating candle will be set on fire because of the amount of
heat generated.  Thus, it can be even more dangerous to touch a
operating candle.

Further proof of dark's mass is illustrated by the smoke generated by
inefficient or extinguished candles.  The intermediate state of dark
during its destruction is a visible soot or smoke.  Once again, casual
observers will attempt to refute the mass of darkness by noting that
smoke generally rises.  The same physical laws which allow clouds to
float, when water is heavier than air, cause smoke to rise.  In an
uncleaned area, it is easy to note the `rain' of soot which accumulates
on surfaces.

Though many are not aware of the incredible technology behind candles,
they illustrate another one of the many characteristics of dark.
Consider the fact that dark suckers absorb and store light.  At first
glance it may seem that this fact is a childish myth, since an
operating candle eventually diminishes to nothing.  Proponents of this
argument fail to realize that the candle is actually destroying the
dark which it sucks!  You may wonder why a room full of dark does not
become empty of dark after a while.  The answer is simple; dark is
capable of regenerating itself.  It is important to note that the speed
of regeneration is proportional to the volume of dark already present.
For example, in a closet where the volume is small, the candle will be
able to suck dark faster than the dark reproduces itself.  In a huge
cavern, however, a candle will not be able to keep up, thus we need
dark suckers with greater capacities when we use them in large spaces.

Further support for the destruction of dark is illustrated by the
previous reference to dark storage units.  Though most inexpensive
storage units will get full, and therefore become useless, the higher
priced ones can be attached to a charger which empties the canister by
destroying the dark inside.  The canister is then able to be used
again.

Dark is also heavier than light.  If you swim just below the surface of
a lake, you will see a lot of light.  As you swim deeper and deeper,
you notice it gets slowly darker and darker.  When you reach a depth of
approximately fifty feet, you are in total darkness.  This is because
the heavier dark sinks to the bottom of the lake and the lighter light
floats to the top.  This immense power of dark can be utilized to man's
advantage.  We can collect the dark that has settled to the bottom of
lakes and push it through turbines, which generate electricity and help
push dark to the oceans, where it can be safely stored.  Prior to
turbines, it was much more difficult to get dark from the rivers and
lakes to the oceans.  The Indians recognized this problem and tried to
solve it.  When on a river in a canoe, traveling the same direction as
the flow of dark, they paddled slowly, so as not to stop the flow of
dark; but when they traveled against the dark, they paddled quickly, so
as to help push the dark along its way.

Finally, we can show that dark is faster than light.  If you were to
stand in an illuminated room in front of a closed dark closet, and then
slowly open the closed door, you would see the light slowly enter the
closet; but since the dark is so fast you are not be able to see the
dark leave the closet.

In conclusion, dark suckers make all our lives much easier.  The next
time you look at an electric bulb, remember that it is a indeed a dark
sucker.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

- --Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil)

Date: 09 Feb 95 08:39:24 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: Best tire prices (was: tires for sal


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: Best tire prices (was: tires for sale)
Date: 1995-02-09 10:07
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Will Hartje wrote:

<stuff deleted about Tire Rack vs. local tire stores>

>If you have no inexpensive means to get them mounted and balanced you can
>always beat Discount Tire over the head with Tire Rack's price and they
will
>match it but you will still pay tax and stems and balancing.

It seems to pretty common practice for Discount Tire stores in our area to
match Tire Rack's price without any dickering whatsoever.  An even better
trick is to take their own ad from R&T or some such and get them to match
*that* price.  From what I've compared, the Discount Tire Direct mail order
is cheaper than Tire Rack and you also can get them to lower their shipping
prices while "price comparing"...  Since we do a whole lot of tires during
the season, I made a point of getting to know the manager of *ONE* Discount
Tire store -- he mounts and balances all of our race tires for free and
steeply discounts any of the street tire services we need.  Another
advantage is all the free rotations, etc. when I don't have time to do it
myself (they have even done the trailer's tires ;-))...

 -Scott Jessen

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 10:38:28 -0600

From martinw Thu Feb  9 11:24:58 1995

Subject: Re: How do you choose your oil.........
X-Mailer: SCO Portfolio 2.0
Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:24:52 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID:  <9502091124.aa26837@eptax.eapi.com>


  >Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B wrote:
  >>It would also seem to me that the cost of synthetics and fancy brands
  >(swepco) >have a very poor price/performance ratio. I can get about four
  >changes of Castrol >dino base for the cost of one fancy oil, surely this
  >would be a lot better for the >mechanicals, especially with all of those
  >little particles and gas and what not >that Stan reminded us about floating
  >about in the oil? Any one have any facts? the >facts man, just the
  >facts..........

  >Well, as for facts, synthetics offer superior lubrication and better
  >viscosity characteristics, but they get just as dirty and contaminated as

  >I would use synthetic in a 930 (especially an early one) because synthetics
  >are much more resistant to "coking" (getting fried by turbo heat, and thus

details please .... did this come off the sales info from madison avenue or
is there somewhere we can actually look at some unbiased test results

  >One case where synthetics are clearly superior is in cold-weather startup.
  >If you live in an area like I do (and for your sake I hope you don't :), a
  >synthetic will actually save money over 5w30 dino in the winter if you're a
  >typical city commuter.

I understand from this (and other rumors too...) that synthetics have a
better wide-range performance than multi-grades  ie lower pour point and
better lubrication through the heat/pressure range.  Is this true...details ?

yes...we're ganging up on this one !

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:40:29 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: T*d for Newbies


Hi, gang,

    A recent thread wondered about T*d.  Frankly, I am also a newcomer (~6 
weeks).  I have also wondered about The Listmeister's mysterious warnings
in the monthly rules about a certain, unnamed individual, and about the
frequent references to T*d.  So I took a crash course in Ted.  I will
*briefly* summarize.  

"Warning: the following may be tiresome for oldtimers!"

      I simply chose two months at random from the archives, Jan. 94 and June
94.  I loaded into my word processor and searched for "Ted."  I realize that 
this distills the *worst* of the p-philes.  However, I also got to read some
nice letters from Ted Rodgers this way <g>.

Jan. 94:  Ted M. appears to be a relative newcomer, but slightly outspoken.
  His mail generally centers around the condition of his tired 2.7L engine.
  Interactions with the list are slightly argumentative about why a rebuild
  is warranted.  Calls Bruce Andersen on the phone for second opinion. He 
  appears to be a bit annoying, but earnest.

Fast forward to June 94:  Ted sends constant discourses on why the Ultimate
  Porsche is a 3L SC engine in a pre-SC body.  Why?  The Almighty Weight 
  Difference.  This "definitely" makes it a Carrera-killer.  When asked to
  back this up with track experience, Ted cites street racing (which he calls
  "track racing.")  Boastfully challenges others to street showdowns.  Also, 
  as noted yesterday, he offers opinions on *everything*.  One example:  
  Someone wants to know what to look for when shopping for a '85 Carrera, 
  Ted answers "Carrera tensioners and pop-off valve."  Uh-huh.

    Sociological observation:  Ted is target and participant of open flame-war
  unlike anything found here.  Looked like something from rec.autos.driving.
  It reminded me of "The Lord of the Flies," as hostilities and infighting 
  threatened a meltdown of accepted social mores.

  'Nuff said.  Thanks for weathering the storm, guys and gals.  My crash 
course has made me appreciate this forum all the more.  Made me realize
why I hate Usenet groups.  Thanks,  Oh Listmeister, for what you have 
gone through to make this a place that people WANT to tune in to.

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa  (that is a 3L SC engine in an SC body!)
                 (aaaargh, a chocolate brown Targa -- just like you-know-who!)


	

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:57:45 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE: '74 Carrera RS

Eric Brown  <ericb@microsoft.com> asked :

>According to Lugvigsen, a few over 100 '74 Carrera RSs were made,
>with about half being converted to RSRs. So, were any of the remaining
>RSs imported into the States? If so, are they as expensive as '73 RSs?
>Has anyone seen one for sale recently? Anyone know of an RS for sale
>waiting to be restored? (Sure, fat chance, but I had to ask!)

The '74 "Euro" Carrera used a mechanical fuel injected 2.7 L engine just
like the '73 RS (which is a 2.4S engine with bigger pistons and cylinders).
They were not sold new in the US, they were not certified by Porsche.
The USA got the '74 Carrera with CIS injection with about 30 HP less.
A few Euro's were imported in the 80's with the grey market boom. A friend
of mine from school, who's father was the president of the NYC area PCA (?)
had one at Rensselaer. They were available for about $15,000 in the early
80s in Europe. His was the day-glo green which was popular at the time.
I've seen another for sale in this area pretty reasonably. They are
definitely
cheaper than a '73 RS.

I think the '74 "RS" Carrera used a 3-litre engine, and are MUCH more
expensive and rare. There was a mint one in a recent Pano article
I think. These were the basis for the Penske IROC cars.

>BTW, I've seen the ads for RSs that are perpetually in the back of Pano.
>They are obviously asking too much or they would have been sold by
>now. $80K? Sheesh...

These people are living in the past or have too much money invested in the
cars. They were going for $100,000 in the boom years, when they went from
$40,000 to double that in about a year. Too many speculators...

Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S (The closest thing to an RS Targa)

Date: Thu,  9 Feb 1995 12:05:24 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: 914 lube points? (long - sorry)

    Hi there,

as regular readers of this group ay be aware, I got a screaming deal a
while back on a nice but wrecked 914 that had been sitting a while (i.e.
I could afford it ;) )
    Anyway, as it has been sitting a (unspecified) while, I consider all
fluids in this car to be suspect and ready for a changing.  I already
have changed the oil and put in a happy Mahle oil filter, my next
projects next time I go home are to repack the front bearings (thanks
for the help on picking a grease - I think I may go with redline because
Summit Racing sells it and I can get stuff from there in 2 days) and to
change the tranny oil.
    Any recommends on a tranny oil?
    Also, where else on this car should be lubed, and what would you
recommend? (If other than the standard lithium grease.)  Any zerk
fittings, or are all loints/bushings/etc. "permanently" lubed?
    My Haynes manual only shows engine oil, tranny/diff, front hubs, CV
joints (can I do this myself?), and air cleaner (oil bath!).  anything
else?  Also, anyone willing to photocopy a '71 owner's manual for me? 
Mine's trash, and $50+ is just out of the question.
    Yes, I know I should check this out myself, but I'm trying to
collect as much info. as I can while I'm here at school so when I go
home I can get the most work done in the least amount of time.

    Slightly unrelated question:  My exhaust leaks.  I have SS heat
exchangers, so I am assuming I need new gaskets (which I already
purchased from Auto. Atlanta.)  i'm scared to unbolt the heat exchangers
from the head, though.  What am I likely to find?  Pulled/broken stud? 
Erosion around the old gasket?  What to do in either case?  Would it be
OK to epoxy in any pits if I do find erosion?  What epoxy would
withstand exhaust temp.'s?
    Some wanker installed a 916 rear end and a Monza exhaust on my car,
which are NOT compatible (the tips hit the bottom of the valence.)  So
instead of cutting the valence, he just pushed the exhaust system down
so the muffler brace actually is jammed below the studs on the tranny
it's supposed to be bolted to.  That's why I think it's a misaligned
gasket near the head. (thank god, only one side!) and hopefully not a
broken stud.  Needless to say, if I elect to keep the 916 rear
(dependent on whether or not I find a cheap rubber thingy for the top of
my rear bumper - fat chance) I WILL cut notches in the bottom.
    Also, the rear flange of my heat exchangers appears to be NOT SS.
(why?)  How do I keep those gaskets from getting trashed again?  Or will
driving the car keep huge chunks of rust from building up again? (right
now, the gasket is about useless, as big wide chunks of rust have forced
the mufflers away from the heat exchangers.

    Finally, apparenly one of my pretty alloy wheels (Pedrinni) appears
to have been mildly curb surfed.  About 1" of the rim is bent
ever-so-slightly.  Obviously, when I get new tires, this will become my
spare.  Question:  should I try to hammer it back, or is it just not
worth it?  Also, if anyone has either one Pedrinni or two steelies
laying around that they'll let go cheap, I could use them (alloy for
obvious reasons, steelies because I already have two and might want to
play snow-rally-driver someday - hey, I live in PA!)  Do VW hubcaps fit
on the steelies?  I don't rally care too much about appearance, but no
caps just look BAD. My Haynes manual shows a pic. of a 914 with what
look like regular bug 'caps.
    How do I get corrosion off my alloys?  The outsides look OK, but the
insides are just heinous.  This is the first car I have ever owned with
alloys, so I've never had to take care of them before.

Thanks much (and sorry so long!)

Nate,

who still loves his primer-colored, dented, leaky, and STILL FUN 914.

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:31:05 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: Naming convention (stuck in 900s)

> So if the number is the design number, then why did Porsche get stuck in
> the 900's.  I find it hard to believe that they went through some 500
> designs after the 356 before they found one that would last, yet
> boom, once they hit 900 everything seemed to click.

I'm sure that the 900 thing is as much a marketing decision as anything.
Back in the "good old days" you could have odd numbers like 356, and
those few aficionados who cared didn't have to be sold on the cars.
Now everything is affected by the marketplace and advertising
considerations.  Given the rate at which the factory went through
numbers, for instance from 356 to 901 in about 15 years, by now they
should be up over 2000.  They probably are up in that range in some
internal accounting, since the model numbers we hear about shifted from
"pure" to "market-driven" sometime in the last 30 years.

- --Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil)

Date: 9 Feb 1995 08:45:27 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 928S Questions.....

 Reply to:     RE>>928S Questions.....


>> Stoddard has all the 928 technical supplements...

This sounds great!  If you could dig up the phone number for me 
I sure would appreciate it.  

>> good mail order part houses to try are:  PAP in GA

I called them and found that they don't mail fliers out anymore.  
However, the guy I talked to said that he carries used parts as 
well as new.  Sounds like a great parts source.

>> remote hatch release have never worked 

When you pull on the electric release (with the door open, of course) 
do you get any activity from the hatch release motor at all?  If the 
motor works, it could be a misalignment between the motor and the 
latch on the hatch.  If the motor doesn't run, it could be because the 
interior lites are not coming on when you open the door or your motor 
could be dead.  The motor is similar to the one that runs the rear wiper 
arm ... that one stopped on me, so I took it apart (after checking that 
there was voltage on the connector) and cleaned the brushes and 
armature.  It works great again and cost me nothing but time(!).

The deal you got on rotors from Vertex is super ... I just put all four 
rotors on a few months back and I thought I had the best deal going, 
but you've found a better one.


------------------------------

Date: 9 Feb 1995 10:17:10 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 928S Questions.....

 Reply to:     RE>>928S Questions.....

>>Does your lock release turn contiguously or just one revolution?


It should turn only one revolution.  If you take the motor apart, you
may find a Rube Goldberg mechanical device that will stop the motor
once it has completed a single revolution.  Something may be 
broken or just dirty.

If your motor doesn't work properly anyway, you probably have little
or nothing to lose by taking it apart.

If you do, make sure you work where you can find small parts that
jump out when you open things up!

>> Used parts are something I have to see first before I drop my $ down

I would hesitate to buy electric or hydraulic parts used, but... you can
really save big bucks on mechanical or cosmetic stuff.  For example,
I rebuilt my Hirschmann power antenna from my original, a new mast
from Hirschmann, and a used antenna box from 928 International (needed
the circuit board).  I spent less than I would have to buy a new one and
it works great.

Also bought the air filter housing (lower half) used and a few other things.

Date: 09 Feb 95 14:37:10 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: The T*d.

 
Ben left out some great T*d D*tails.
 
The lockout incident -- he called a locksmith. Locksmith finally got a tool
down inside the door to unlock it, but scratched glass in the process.
Windshield as I recall. T*d wanted to sue him for it. It was this incident
that made me suspect that T*d was a counterfeit personality, because this is
the stuff of an old Urban Legend -- locksmith unlocks door, owner complains
about price or scratches or something, locksmith takes keys out of owner's
hand, throws them back in car, locks door, drives away. Classic.
 
Curb (or do you say Kerb) Surfing -- he bent some alloy wheels in the process.
Claims that he knows a shop that will unbend them, good as new. He tried to
foist these wheels off on P'philes for months, it seemed. If I remember, he
also had an air leak from one wheel, but didn't connect the dots inside his
brain...
 
Claims steel wheels are dangerous, ignoring the fact that most cars ever made
rolled on steel wheels. Says forged aluminum wheels fracture, cast wheels bend
nicely and safely. He should know.
 
Japanese shocks (KYB) are better because the Japanese are much more careful
craftsmen than those feelthy Germans. We suspect that he has one of those
rare made-in-Japan 911s.
 
The four different tires for autocrossing -- I came up with the comment that
he had "an entire Franklin Mint Collection of Classic Performance Tires on
his car." I'm proud of that one, if I do say so.
 
Autocrossing -- his hot-sh*t 77 or whatever 911, with 3 liter and 4 different
performance tires and KYB shocks was beaten in T*d's first-ever slalom
outing by both members of a husband/wife team (also on P'philes) driving a
bone stock 1971? 911 T, the bottom of the Porsche performance hierarchy at
that time, also on their first outing, and not just beaten, but beaten like
a drum -- 5 seconds on a 50ish second course? T*d claimed that even if he
clobbered the cones after the finish and hence got a DNF, he had a faster
run.
 
When he started mail bombing all P'philes with his own list, and even
multiple copies thereof, and repeated requests over two days did not stop
the posts, I fixed the problem on my end by calling the legal
department at his place of employment and leaving a nastygram. The posts
to my account stopped immediately.
 
Things have been sort of boring since Stan threw The T*d off the list, but
it had to be done. Fortunately, yesterday I discovered that The Spirit of
T*d lives. I needed to do some small stuff at the local community college
body and fender class. There is a guy there replacing a rear fender on a 914
1.7. He asked me if it is possible to move the rear suspension inward about
an inch on each side. "Why would you want to do that?" So's I can put on
great big wide wheels and tires. "Why don't you do what the factory did?
Instead of moving in, move out. Put on the 916-type flares." Naah, I don't
like dat Look. "You realize that even if you can move the pickups inward, you
will have to do all sorts of other stuff, like shorten the halfshafts?" Yeah.
So what? "What engine are you going to use in all this?" Uhh, just the
reg'lar one that's in there now.
 
At that point I gave up. (This guy has never, ever finished any of his
projects.)
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 95 10:55:00 PST
From: "Smyth, Bill" <SmythB@dbisna.com>
Subject: Re: 928S Questions.....


John,
The book covers both the 928 and the 924/944.  It is sold anywhere they sell 
these mini Chilton books (part stores, book stores) .  If you do not see it, 
look in the back of any Chilton book for a listing of all the Chilton repair 
guides with their numbers.  The sales clerk should be able to order you one 
from that.

I also remember one of the large glossy mail order houses selling it, I 
think Automotion.  But they sell it for full list price + S/H.

Bill Smyth
'84 928S

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 12:02:27 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: O-2 Stuff

Bob,

Thanks for the info on meters' impedance.
I read a post today from Lee Atkinson with great interest : it seems
that at best power the mixture should be rich, and this is all I care about.

So I think a Digital meter on the 0-2 sensor will be up near
1V when it is rich enough for best power 13-14. So I may be better
off with something like the Edelbrock meter which is calibrateed from
12 and up. It must be sensitive to small changes around 1V.

I'm glad to hear you had success in cleaning out you MFI pump
yourself. I'm afraid mine needs more than cleaning, as it's calibration
was screwed up by Hans at H & R. Next month I will have time to
send it out and get it checked.

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:15:46 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Big tires on early 911

Dave--

I hadn't responded to this thread until now, but my experience might be
useful.  My '72 came to me with 7x15 wheels and with 205-60s on the
front and 215-60s on the back.  It also came to me with blisters on the
two rear fenders where the back tires had rubbed.  It didn't seem to
happen often, though, so I drove carefully until I replaced the tires
with 205-60s all around.  I've been in this configuration for 5 years
now.  I occasionally hear a quick rubbing noise on bumps, but I haven't
had any further problem with blisters.

I have a suspicion that my ride height is less than standard, and that
if the car was raised a tiny bit I'd have no problem at all.  But I like
the way it looks at the current height :-)

Another data point for you to consider...

- --Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil)

Date: 09 Feb 95 08:39:23 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Do winged 911s run cooler?


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Do winged 911s run cooler?
Date: 1995-02-09 10:25
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

OK I've got a new thread for you guys.  I noticed something a few years back
when I put a duck tail on our '72 911 -- it seemed to run cooler.  I was
reminded of this when we got the '84 recently, it has a Carrera tail and
seems to run cooler than our other '84 that didn't have one.  Being the
shadetree en-gun-neer that I am, I was wondering if anyone that truly
understands the aerodynamics or other forces at work could explain this.

The way I figure:  A tail causes either less lift or maybe even downforce at
speed, right?  If there is lift at the back of the car (now I'm thinking in
terms of a slight vacuum), then the cooling fan is less efficient at pulling
air in and pushing it over the cylinders and engine oil cooler.  If you
decrease the lift the fan moves more air at any given rpm, thus a cooler
running motor.  If the wing is large enough to actually create downforce,
well all the better...

OK, I'm ready for this one to be swiss-cheesed by all you rapid firing
"real" en-gun-neers...

 -Scott Jessen
'72 ASP 911 (ugly *and* mean)
'84 911 Carrera (too cool to go slow) (or is that *not* cool to go slow ;-))



------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 09:05:29 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Theory of Dark

The recent discussion of light bulb theory caused me to resurrect the
following from a newsletter I used to edit; it's a bit off topic, but it
should settle the issue once and for all... :-)

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

DARKNESS, BE GONE

For years it has been believed that electric bulbs emitted a substance
or energy called light.  Recent information, however, has proven
otherwise.  Electric bulbs don't emit light - they suck dark.  We
should thus call these bulbs dark suckers.  In addition to proving this
fact, the Dark Sucker Theory also presents a number of other basic
theorems concerning the properties of dark.  For example, the speed of
dark is greater than that of light, and dark has greater mass than
light.

The basis of the Dark Sucker Theory is that electric bulbs suck dark.
Take for example the dark suckers in the room where you are.  There is
less dark right next to them than there is elsewhere.  The larger the
dark suckers, the greater their capacity to suck dark.  Dark suckers in
a parking lot have much greater capacity than the ones in this room.
As with all things, dark suckers don't last forever.  Once they are
full of dark, they can no longer suck.  This is proven by the black
spot on a full dark sucker.  

A candle is a primitive dark sucker.  A new candle has a white wick.
You will notice that after the first use, the wick turns black,
representing the dark which has been sucked into it.  If you hold a
pencil next to the wick on an operating candle, the tip will turn
black, because it got in the way of the dark flowing into the candle.

There are also portable dark suckers.  The bulbs in these units can't
handle all of the dark by themselves, and must be aided by a dark
storage unit.  When the dark storage unit is full, it must be either
emptied or replaced before the portable dark sucker can operate again.
If you break open one of these filled canisters, one will see that
there is indeed a great quantity of stored dark on the inside.  

Dark has mass.  When dark goes into a dark sucker, friction from this
mass passing through another mass will generate a certain amount of
heat.  It is commonly known that an operating dark sucker generates
heat.  The dark suckers with the greatest capacities force the dark to
travel through the impeding media at greater rates of speed, so they
develop greater amounts of heat.  Thus, it is not wise to touch a
operating dark sucker.

Candles present a special problem.  Though the light does not have to
travel through a solid substance like the glass forming an electric
bulb, the dark must travel into the solid wick, instead of a void as is
found inside of the bulb.  As we all know, this process generates a
great amount of heat.  In fact, flammable items which come into contact
with an operating candle will be set on fire because of the amount of
heat generated.  Thus, it can be even more dangerous to touch a
operating candle.

Further proof of dark's mass is illustrated by the smoke generated by
inefficient or extinguished candles.  The intermediate state of dark
during its destruction is a visible soot or smoke.  Once again, casual
observers will attempt to refute the mass of darkness by noting that
smoke generally rises.  The same physical laws which allow clouds to
float, when water is heavier than air, cause smoke to rise.  In an
uncleaned area, it is easy to note the `rain' of soot which accumulates
on surfaces.

Though many are not aware of the incredible technology behind candles,
they illustrate another one of the many characteristics of dark.
Consider the fact that dark suckers absorb and store light.  At first
glance it may seem that this fact is a childish myth, since an
operating candle eventually diminishes to nothing.  Proponents of this
argument fail to realize that the candle is actually destroying the
dark which it sucks!  You may wonder why a room full of dark does not
become empty of dark after a while.  The answer is simple; dark is
capable of regenerating itself.  It is important to note that the speed
of regeneration is proportional to the volume of dark already present.
For example, in a closet where the volume is small, the candle will be
able to suck dark faster than the dark reproduces itself.  In a huge
cavern, however, a candle will not be able to keep up, thus we need
dark suckers with greater capacities when we use them in large spaces.

Further support for the destruction of dark is illustrated by the
previous reference to dark storage units.  Though most inexpensive
storage units will get full, and therefore become useless, the higher
priced ones can be attached to a charger which empties the canister by
destroying the dark inside.  The canister is then able to be used
again.

Dark is also heavier than light.  If you swim just below the surface of
a lake, you will see a lot of light.  As you swim deeper and deeper,
you notice it gets slowly darker and darker.  When you reach a depth of
approximately fifty feet, you are in total darkness.  This is because
the heavier dark sinks to the bottom of the lake and the lighter light
floats to the top.  This immense power of dark can be utilized to man's
advantage.  We can collect the dark that has settled to the bottom of
lakes and push it through turbines, which generate electricity and help
push dark to the oceans, where it can be safely stored.  Prior to
turbines, it was much more difficult to get dark from the rivers and
lakes to the oceans.  The Indians recognized this problem and tried to
solve it.  When on a river in a canoe, traveling the same direction as
the flow of dark, they paddled slowly, so as not to stop the flow of
dark; but when they traveled against the dark, they paddled quickly, so
as to help push the dark along its way.

Finally, we can show that dark is faster than light.  If you were to
stand in an illuminated room in front of a closed dark closet, and then
slowly open the closed door, you would see the light slowly enter the
closet; but since the dark is so fast you are not be able to see the
dark leave the closet.

In conclusion, dark suckers make all our lives much easier.  The next
time you look at an electric bulb, remember that it is a indeed a dark
sucker.

+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

- --Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil)

Date: 09 Feb 95 08:39:24 PST

From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: Best tire prices (was: tires for sale)
Date: 1995-02-09 10:07
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Will Hartje wrote:

<stuff deleted about Tire Rack vs. local tire stores>

>If you have no inexpensive means to get them mounted and balanced you can
>always beat Discount Tire over the head with Tire Rack's price and they
will
>match it but you will still pay tax and stems and balancing.

It seems to pretty common practice for Discount Tire stores in our area to
match Tire Rack's price without any dickering whatsoever.  An even better
trick is to take their own ad from R&T or some such and get them to match
*that* price.  From what I've compared, the Discount Tire Direct mail order
is cheaper than Tire Rack and you also can get them to lower their shipping
prices while "price comparing"...  Since we do a whole lot of tires during
the season, I made a point of getting to know the manager of *ONE* Discount
Tire store -- he mounts and balances all of our race tires for free and
steeply discounts any of the street tire services we need.  Another
advantage is all the free rotations, etc. when I don't have time to do it
myself (they have even done the trailer's tires ;-))...

 -Scott Jessen

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:40:29 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: T*d for Newbies


Hi, gang,

    A recent thread wondered about T*d.  Frankly, I am also a newcomer (~6 
weeks).  I have also wondered about The Listmeister's mysterious warnings
in the monthly rules about a certain, unnamed individual, and about the
frequent references to T*d.  So I took a crash course in Ted.  I will
*briefly* summarize.  

"Warning: the following may be tiresome for oldtimers!"

      I simply chose two months at random from the archives, Jan. 94 and June
94.  I loaded into my word processor and searched for "Ted."  I realize that 
this distills the *worst* of the p-philes.  However, I also got to read some
nice letters from Ted Rodgers this way <g>.

Jan. 94:  Ted M. appears to be a relative newcomer, but slightly outspoken.
  His mail generally centers around the condition of his tired 2.7L engine.
  Interactions with the list are slightly argumentative about why a rebuild
  is warranted.  Calls Bruce Andersen on the phone for second opinion. He 
  appears to be a bit annoying, but earnest.

Fast forward to June 94:  Ted sends constant discourses on why the Ultimate
  Porsche is a 3L SC engine in a pre-SC body.  Why?  The Almighty Weight 
  Difference.  This "definitely" makes it a Carrera-killer.  When asked to
  back this up with track experience, Ted cites street racing (which he calls
  "track racing.")  Boastfully challenges others to street showdowns.  Also, 
  as noted yesterday, he offers opinions on *everything*.  One example:  
  Someone wants to know what to look for when shopping for a '85 Carrera, 
  Ted answers "Carrera tensioners and pop-off valve."  Uh-huh.

    Sociological observation:  Ted is target and participant of open flame-war
  unlike anything found here.  Looked like something from rec.autos.driving.
  It reminded me of "The Lord of the Flies," as hostilities and infighting 
  threatened a meltdown of accepted social mores.

  'Nuff said.  Thanks for weathering the storm, guys and gals.  My crash 
course has made me appreciate this forum all the more.  Made me realize
why I hate Usenet groups.  Thanks,  Oh Listmeister, for what you have 
gone through to make this a place that people WANT to tune in to.

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa  (that is a 3L SC engine in an SC body!)
                 (aaaargh, a chocolate brown Targa -- just like you-know-who!)


	

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 11:57:45 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE: '74 Carrera RS

Eric Brown  <ericb@microsoft.com> asked :

>According to Lugvigsen, a few over 100 '74 Carrera RSs were made,
>with about half being converted to RSRs. So, were any of the remaining
>RSs imported into the States? If so, are they as expensive as '73 RSs?
>Has anyone seen one for sale recently? Anyone know of an RS for sale
>waiting to be restored? (Sure, fat chance, but I had to ask!)

The '74 "Euro" Carrera used a mechanical fuel injected 2.7 L engine just
like the '73 RS (which is a 2.4S engine with bigger pistons and cylinders).
They were not sold new in the US, they were not certified by Porsche.
The USA got the '74 Carrera with CIS injection with about 30 HP less.
A few Euro's were imported in the 80's with the grey market boom. A friend
of mine from school, who's father was the president of the NYC area PCA (?)
had one at Rensselaer. They were available for about $15,000 in the early
80s in Europe. His was the day-glo green which was popular at the time.
I've seen another for sale in this area pretty reasonably. They are
definitely
cheaper than a '73 RS.

I think the '74 "RS" Carrera used a 3-litre engine, and are MUCH more
expensive and rare. There was a mint one in a recent Pano article
I think. These were the basis for the Penske IROC cars.

>BTW, I've seen the ads for RSs that are perpetually in the back of Pano.
>They are obviously asking too much or they would have been sold by
>now. $80K? Sheesh...

These people are living in the past or have too much money invested in the
cars. They were going for $100,000 in the boom years, when they went from
$40,000 to double that in about a year. Too many speculators...

Regards, Mike Piera  '72 911S (The closest thing to an RS Targa)

Date: Thu,  9 Feb 1995 12:05:24 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: 914 lube points? (long - sorry)

    Hi there,

as regular readers of this group ay be aware, I got a screaming deal a
while back on a nice but wrecked 914 that had been sitting a while (i.e.
I could afford it ;) )
    Anyway, as it has been sitting a (unspecified) while, I consider all
fluids in this car to be suspect and ready for a changing.  I already
have changed the oil and put in a happy Mahle oil filter, my next
projects next time I go home are to repack the front bearings (thanks
for the help on picking a grease - I think I may go with redline because
Summit Racing sells it and I can get stuff from there in 2 days) and to
change the tranny oil.
    Any recommends on a tranny oil?
    Also, where else on this car should be lubed, and what would you
recommend? (If other than the standard lithium grease.)  Any zerk
fittings, or are all loints/bushings/etc. "permanently" lubed?
    My Haynes manual only shows engine oil, tranny/diff, front hubs, CV
joints (can I do this myself?), and air cleaner (oil bath!).  anything
else?  Also, anyone willing to photocopy a '71 owner's manual for me? 
Mine's trash, and $50+ is just out of the question.
    Yes, I know I should check this out myself, but I'm trying to
collect as much info. as I can while I'm here at school so when I go
home I can get the most work done in the least amount of time.

    Slightly unrelated question:  My exhaust leaks.  I have SS heat
exchangers, so I am assuming I need new gaskets (which I already
purchased from Auto. Atlanta.)  i'm scared to unbolt the heat exchangers
from the head, though.  What am I likely to find?  Pulled/broken stud? 
Erosion around the old gasket?  What to do in either case?  Would it be
OK to epoxy in any pits if I do find erosion?  What epoxy would
withstand exhaust temp.'s?
    Some wanker installed a 916 rear end and a Monza exhaust on my car,
which are NOT compatible (the tips hit the bottom of the valence.)  So
instead of cutting the valence, he just pushed the exhaust system down
so the muffler brace actually is jammed below the studs on the tranny
it's supposed to be bolted to.  That's why I think it's a misaligned
gasket near the head. (thank god, only one side!) and hopefully not a
broken stud.  Needless to say, if I elect to keep the 916 rear
(dependent on whether or not I find a cheap rubber thingy for the top of
my rear bumper - fat chance) I WILL cut notches in the bottom.
    Also, the rear flange of my heat exchangers appears to be NOT SS.
(why?)  How do I keep those gaskets from getting trashed again?  Or will
driving the car keep huge chunks of rust from building up again? (right
now, the gasket is about useless, as big wide chunks of rust have forced
the mufflers away from the heat exchangers.

    Finally, apparenly one of my pretty alloy wheels (Pedrinni) appears
to have been mildly curb surfed.  About 1" of the rim is bent
ever-so-slightly.  Obviously, when I get new tires, this will become my
spare.  Question:  should I try to hammer it back, or is it just not
worth it?  Also, if anyone has either one Pedrinni or two steelies
laying around that they'll let go cheap, I could use them (alloy for
obvious reasons, steelies because I already have two and might want to
play snow-rally-driver someday - hey, I live in PA!)  Do VW hubcaps fit
on the steelies?  I don't rally care too much about appearance, but no
caps just look BAD. My Haynes manual shows a pic. of a 914 with what
look like regular bug 'caps.
    How do I get corrosion off my alloys?  The outsides look OK, but the
insides are just heinous.  This is the first car I have ever owned with
alloys, so I've never had to take care of them before.

Thanks much (and sorry so long!)

Nate,

who still loves his primer-colored, dented, leaky, and STILL FUN 914.

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 08:31:05 -0800
From: thode@nprdc.navy.mil (Walt Thode)
Subject: Re: Naming convention (stuck in 900s)

> So if the number is the design number, then why did Porsche get stuck in
> the 900's.  I find it hard to believe that they went through some 500
> designs after the 356 before they found one that would last, yet
> boom, once they hit 900 everything seemed to click.

I'm sure that the 900 thing is as much a marketing decision as anything.
Back in the "good old days" you could have odd numbers like 356, and
those few aficionados who cared didn't have to be sold on the cars.
Now everything is affected by the marketplace and advertising
considerations.  Given the rate at which the factory went through
numbers, for instance from 356 to 901 in about 15 years, by now they
should be up over 2000.  They probably are up in that range in some
internal accounting, since the model numbers we hear about shifted from
"pure" to "market-driven" sometime in the last 30 years.

- --Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil)
