------------------------------

Date: 9 Feb 1995 08:45:27 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 928S Questions.....

 Reply to:     RE>>928S Questions.....


>> Stoddard has all the 928 technical supplements...

This sounds great!  If you could dig up the phone number for me 
I sure would appreciate it.  

>> good mail order part houses to try are:  PAP in GA

I called them and found that they don't mail fliers out anymore.  
However, the guy I talked to said that he carries used parts as 
well as new.  Sounds like a great parts source.

>> remote hatch release have never worked 

When you pull on the electric release (with the door open, of course) 
do you get any activity from the hatch release motor at all?  If the 
motor works, it could be a misalignment between the motor and the 
latch on the hatch.  If the motor doesn't run, it could be because the 
interior lites are not coming on when you open the door or your motor 
could be dead.  The motor is similar to the one that runs the rear wiper 
arm ... that one stopped on me, so I took it apart (after checking that 
there was voltage on the connector) and cleaned the brushes and 
armature.  It works great again and cost me nothing but time(!).

The deal you got on rotors from Vertex is super ... I just put all four 
rotors on a few months back and I thought I had the best deal going, 
but you've found a better one.


------------------------------

Date: 9 Feb 1995 10:17:10 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 928S Questions.....

 Reply to:     RE>>928S Questions.....

>>Does your lock release turn contiguously or just one revolution?


It should turn only one revolution.  If you take the motor apart, you
may find a Rube Goldberg mechanical device that will stop the motor
once it has completed a single revolution.  Something may be 
broken or just dirty.

If your motor doesn't work properly anyway, you probably have little
or nothing to lose by taking it apart.

If you do, make sure you work where you can find small parts that
jump out when you open things up!

>> Used parts are something I have to see first before I drop my $ down

I would hesitate to buy electric or hydraulic parts used, but... you can
really save big bucks on mechanical or cosmetic stuff.  For example,
I rebuilt my Hirschmann power antenna from my original, a new mast
from Hirschmann, and a used antenna box from 928 International (needed
the circuit board).  I spent less than I would have to buy a new one and
it works great.

Also bought the air filter housing (lower half) used and a few other things.

Date: 09 Feb 95 14:37:10 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: The T*d.

 
Ben left out some great T*d D*tails.
 
The lockout incident -- he called a locksmith. Locksmith finally got a tool
down inside the door to unlock it, but scratched glass in the process.
Windshield as I recall. T*d wanted to sue him for it. It was this incident
that made me suspect that T*d was a counterfeit personality, because this is
the stuff of an old Urban Legend -- locksmith unlocks door, owner complains
about price or scratches or something, locksmith takes keys out of owner's
hand, throws them back in car, locks door, drives away. Classic.
 
Curb (or do you say Kerb) Surfing -- he bent some alloy wheels in the process.
Claims that he knows a shop that will unbend them, good as new. He tried to
foist these wheels off on P'philes for months, it seemed. If I remember, he
also had an air leak from one wheel, but didn't connect the dots inside his
brain...
 
Claims steel wheels are dangerous, ignoring the fact that most cars ever made
rolled on steel wheels. Says forged aluminum wheels fracture, cast wheels bend
nicely and safely. He should know.
 
Japanese shocks (KYB) are better because the Japanese are much more careful
craftsmen than those feelthy Germans. We suspect that he has one of those
rare made-in-Japan 911s.
 
The four different tires for autocrossing -- I came up with the comment that
he had "an entire Franklin Mint Collection of Classic Performance Tires on
his car." I'm proud of that one, if I do say so.
 
Autocrossing -- his hot-sh*t 77 or whatever 911, with 3 liter and 4 different
performance tires and KYB shocks was beaten in T*d's first-ever slalom
outing by both members of a husband/wife team (also on P'philes) driving a
bone stock 1971? 911 T, the bottom of the Porsche performance hierarchy at
that time, also on their first outing, and not just beaten, but beaten like
a drum -- 5 seconds on a 50ish second course? T*d claimed that even if he
clobbered the cones after the finish and hence got a DNF, he had a faster
run.
 
When he started mail bombing all P'philes with his own list, and even
multiple copies thereof, and repeated requests over two days did not stop
the posts, I fixed the problem on my end by calling the legal
department at his place of employment and leaving a nastygram. The posts
to my account stopped immediately.
 
Things have been sort of boring since Stan threw The T*d off the list, but
it had to be done. Fortunately, yesterday I discovered that The Spirit of
T*d lives. I needed to do some small stuff at the local community college
body and fender class. There is a guy there replacing a rear fender on a 914
1.7. He asked me if it is possible to move the rear suspension inward about
an inch on each side. "Why would you want to do that?" So's I can put on
great big wide wheels and tires. "Why don't you do what the factory did?
Instead of moving in, move out. Put on the 916-type flares." Naah, I don't
like dat Look. "You realize that even if you can move the pickups inward, you
will have to do all sorts of other stuff, like shorten the halfshafts?" Yeah.
So what? "What engine are you going to use in all this?" Uhh, just the
reg'lar one that's in there now.
 
At that point I gave up. (This guy has never, ever finished any of his
projects.)
 
Pete

Date: 09 Feb 95 14:46:15 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Book search

 
Maltby, Porsche 356 & 550 -- Motorbooks International, ISBN 0-87938-551-0
 
Johnson, 356 Restorer's Guide -- Beeman Jorgensen Inc., (which is Brett
Johnson), ISBN 0-929758-06-4 hardcover, 0-929758-08-0 softcover. Order from
Beeman Jorgensen, 1-800-553-5319.
 
Rasmussen, 356 & 550 -- Top Ten Publishing, ISBN 1-879301-03-2.
 
All of these are available from Motorbooks. Rasmussen is mostly a pitcher
book. Maltby has more meat. Johnson is the only one of its kind.
 
Also Johnson has just come out with a 400 page compendium of 356 Registry
tech articles, called the 356 Restoration Guide. Well worth it at about $20.
 
I'm going to the L.A. model and literature meet on Saturday. If anybody on
the list is there, stop on by. I will have the following books for sale, all
unused:
 
356 Restorer's Guide to Authenticity
VW Beetle Restorer's Guide (1949-1959)
Porsche 911 and 912 Restorer's Guide (1965-1973)
914 and 914/6 Restorer's Guide
356 Restoration Manual
Porsche 356 - Driving in its Purest Form (Conradt)
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 14:59:07 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org>
Subject: RE: K&N Air Filter: Does it affect brake booster (long)

>>
>>There are two types of vacuum signals found under the hoods of our cars.  
>>The first is manifold vacuum.  Manifold vacuum exists between the throttle 
>>plates and the intake valves.  This vacuum is created by the restriction of 
>>the throttle plates not the air filter.  Manifold vacuum is inversly 
>>proportional to engine load.  At idle a street car with a well tuned engine 
>>will read 18-22 in-HG of manifold vacuum.  This will drop quite a bit under 
>>full throttle acceleration.  Manifold vacuum is where the brake booster 
>>gets it signal.
>>
>>The second type of vacuum is ported vacuum.  Ported vacuum exists between 
>>the throttle plates and the air filter.  The ported signal is proportional 
>>to engine load.  In other words, ported vacuum increases as engine load 
>>increases.  In older (read non-electronic) cars, ported vacuum was tapped 
>>for quite a few purposes.  This is the source of the vacuum advance signal 
>>(or vacuum retard if you will).
>>
>>

OK, but what if the engine is supercharged? Seems like the only vacuum
to be found then is the ported vacuum, which must be pretty weak.

 -John White-
'84 928S (non-supercharged)


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 95 11:43:03 -0700
From: "Drew A. Spencer" <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Re: Need a back seat for a 911



Begin forwarded message:

> Hi,
> 

> I have a 93 RS America - my dream come true - but also have 3 kids 

> (they're important, too).  My RS has no back seat and, with appropriate 

> spousal influence, have determined that it is in my best interests to 

> get one (a back seat, that is).
> 

> I am told that all the late model 911's have common mounting for the 

> back seat.  Does anyone know if this is actually true?
> 

> Either way, is any one out there parting out a 911 who wishes to sell 

> the back seat?  My RS has black cloth upholstery but I could get it 

> recovered if necessary.  

> 

> thanks,
> pete
> 


Congrats Pete!

Being of the same familial composition, I've encountered some of this 

myself.  The problem is, with 3 young'ns someone still has to stay home
since there's only 2 full and 2 half seats in a 911.  Of course, my SO
would probably rejoice at the thought of hauling the kids off in the 

p-car in order to enjoy som peace and quiet, but I digress....
My solution is to use rides in the p-car as a form of reward for good
behavior...

Regarding what you asked about to begin with...
Yes, I do believe that all the mounting points for the seats are still
there underneath the storage bins.  Apparently, the bins are bolted into
the same points that the seats would use.  The only problem your going
to have is recovering from the blunt head trauma your wife will inflict
on you when she finds out how much it's going to cost to get all the
misc bits for seatbelts, seats, trim, and such.  There's a good chance
you'll be able to find what your looking for from a salvager like Aase
or some such where you could get a whole set.  


Good luck,
Drew
'93 RS America
'82 911 SC (track car under construction)

P.S.  The RS Americas continue to get rarer as yet another was 

wadded up at a time trial at Willow Springs (end-over-end roll).  

This makes 3 in the last 6 months (2 at Willow, 1 at Laguna Seca).
The good part is that as a result of the car's construction, none
of the drivers were seriously hurt.  Be careful out there...

Date: 9 Feb 1995 12:48:44 -0500

_______________________________________________________________________________
From: Robert Hellman /OTL on Thu, Feb 9, 1995 10:02 AM
Subject: Porsche Motorcycle Redux
To: Mohr Bob
Cc: Jorgensen, Ed; Miller, Kristie; Stevens, Frank (BMW NA)

To: Bob Mohr (Porsche Forum)

Dear Bob:

	CYCLE WORLD has bit on the Porsche motorcycle story in a big way, just in
time for MOTORRAD (Germany's most prestigious two-wheel publication) to run a
brief interview with a Porsche spokesperson. The latter said there is not now,
nor has there ever been, a Porsche motorcycle initiative.
	The Porsche hoax first emerged months ago in British MOTOR CYCLE NEWS,
citing Australian sources. The same sources, cited in the same publication, are
now touting a Harley-Davidson Grand Prix bike. It should be noted that Harley
has yet to fully sort out its VR-1000 racer in the Superbike class--and that is
a four-stroke machine having some application to street machines of the future.
A "GP" bike would be prohibitively expensive and, as a two-stroke exotic, make
little sense for future H-D production plans.
	Someone is funning us out there.
							Robert Hellman
							Editor
							On the Level
							BMW RA To Bob Mohr

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 95 09:33:28 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: Re: 912 Problem


Harry,

        Maybe you should call it in to the Tappet Brothers!  Let's see - The 
MEASTRO's toupee disapeared during reassembly, and got jammed between the 
ring gear and the starter.

        OK, you've said it wasn't the engine.  "Ifn" it was the tranny, 
disengaging the clutch would allow the engine to turn, so it can't be that.  
So we're down to the clutch and flywheel.

        Now I have a Jeep story.  I like to Jeep in the dunes.  Many years 
ago I replaced the Jeep clutch pressure plate.  The new pressure plate was 
the three finger type (I did say this was long ago).  It came with 3 small 
wooden spacers under the three fingers such that during reassembly, the 
clutch disk could be moved around for alignment purposes.  Then you 
activated the clutch and the 3 little spacers would just fall into the 
bottom of the bell housing.

        Well, this worked fine until one day in the dunes.  The starter was 
jammed hard and wouldn't turn the engine.  Upon starter removal, one of the 
little wooden spacers was jammed between the starter gear and the ring gear. 
Appearantly the dune-cresting technique (you kind of have to have the front 
in the air on sharp crests to keep from getting high-centered) caused the 
spacers to fly around and one of them just happened to nestle into the 
starter Bendix cavity, and was jammed against the flywheel when next 
activated.  One of those one-in-a-million things. So I dug the wood spacer 
out with my Swiss army knife, slapped the starter back in, and was on my 
way.  I figgured the chance of that happening again was nil.

        Well, 2 more times over the next 3 years, always whilst in the 
dunes, the other 2 spacers found their ways into the same spot.  The second 
time I couldn't believe it.  The third time, I believed it!

        So my guess is that something (not necessarily you hair piece) 
became jammed in the area of the flywheel/ring gear/pressure plate.  
Guessing what would make good campfire conversation :)

Bob

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 95 09:00:45 PDT
From: lemq@ccmail.apldbio.com
Subject: Re[2]: Attempted car theft experience

>Takes me back to sunny Saigon, where everyone drove stolen
>jeeps

Bart,

If my memory of those days in Saigon is correct, it is that everybody rode those  
Honda 50 scooters (they called them motorcycles, hah!). The ones driving jeeps 
were American soldiers and were deemed to deserve to have their Jeeps ripped off 
because they don't own the Jeeps anyway. Actually, anything not nailed down and 
a few things that were nailed down got ripped off. Ah, war is hell, but poverty 
and the huge difference between have's and have-not's were the biggest motivator 
of mid-night (mid-day too) creative shopping.

Minh

Date: Thu, 09 Feb 1995 14:20:40 -0700
From: stephenk@lmc.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: Auxiliary Air Regulator

Bart writes:

>I am trying to fix my '73 914 2.0 auxiliary air regulator...

With all the talk about auxiliary air regulators going on this last month I
finally opened up my nonworking unit to see if I could fix it.  I found two
problems.  The valve was rusted stuck in the open position and the heater
had some kind of calcified (electrolytic?) growth surrounding part of the
heating wire.

The stuck valve was relatively was relatively easy to correct...drown it for
three days in Balkamp Penetrant.  Valve works fine now.

The other problem is a little trickier to solve.  I suspect the heating
element wasn't warming sufficiently (because of this built-up).  I'm
thinking about building a new heater for the regulator.  The books call for
about 30 ohms on this heater element.  Mine measures about 13 ohms (using a
cheap DMM so it may be correct or not); it's possible that this stuff is
shorting out the heating element.  A ceramic disk with a few feet if 30
gauge nichrome coiled onto the surface should do the job nicely.

It was pretty difficult getting the old cannister apart; I had to file the
folded edge to get it started.  I want something that I can periodically
disassemble for cleaning.  (Say once a year or so; it's pretty wet around
here). I've designed a housing that will fit within the available space and
worked up a preliminary design for a new heater.  Everything looks feasible
and I'm preparing to build a prototype, assuming I can find a source of
Nichrome wire.

Given the rather large sums used and NOS aux. air regulators command these
days, rebuilding mine seems a sensible approach.

Anybody have any thoughts about this?  See anything I'm missing?  BTDT?

Stph
'73 914 2.0L
stephenk@lmc.com

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 20:00:53 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Engine Oil Temps

Guten tag,

I read an interesting response to an oil temperature question
recently posed in "European Car" magazine.  The person was 
asking if he should be trying to bring down an oil temp of 240
degrees.  They responded with, and I quote :

"Don't worry too much about the oil temperatures in the 240-
250 degree range, particularly if you use a good synthetic,
which we highly recommend.  Despite what you may have heard
or seen in print, VW is quite happy with an oil temp in this
range.  Anything less may make less horsepower, and will
certainly lower fuel mileage and increase emissions.  Too
cool is worse than too hot, particularly with a synthetic oil
that won't break down until 350-400 degrees."

I thought this was interesting.  Sorry for the bandwidth
wasting...

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 95 17:58:41 -0700
From: "Drew A. Spencer" <Drew_Spencer@Novell.COM>
Subject: Re: RS America



Begin forwarded message:
> 

> Text item: Text_1
> 

>      I've heard about this car. It doesn't seem to have *anything*. No 

>      stereo, AC, leather etc etc. Is this true ? Is it basically a stripped 

>      version of a real 911 ?
                    ^^^^^^^^
Hmmm.....  Stripped does not include the drivetrain so it's still considered
by most to be a REAL 911 ;^).  Now, I won't go as far to say that
the RS moniker is necessarily deserved, but the essence of the car is oriented
more towards driving than a loaded down luxo-boat.  To set the record straight,
the RS America looks more like a stripper than it is.  It still has power seats
and windows, alarm system, etc.  The options were: 5 paint colors, Limited
slip, sunroof, casette stereo, and A/C.  Standard equipment consists of fixed 

Carrera tail, cloth sport seats 17" turbo-style wheels, M030 sport 

suspension, and storage bins in place of the rear seats.  The remainder of 

the car is a C2.  Some, however, claim that early examples had some additional
chassis reinforcement ala the Euro Carrera RS and Cup Cars which is outlined in
the factory workshop manuals.  From the factory, it only weights 100 or so
pounds less than a C2 in similar configuration.

Drew
'93 RS America GP White (LSD, Stereo, Sunroof, No air) 

'82 911 SC (every friggn weight-adding option one could think of...)

was free!

Ah T*d.

He wasn't just a person, he was more of an era.  A legend, an epoch.
An infinite no-op.

Some suggested he didn't really exist--he was actually a
read-only, anti-matter, AI program that *can't* learn no matter HOW MUCH
compelling evidence was poured down his throat while holding his nose...
In fact he would reply to others in the most patronizing tone as though
someday they may understand how clueless they really were: "You're catching
on Sempai" etc.

He was not only clueless but he was utterly clueless in the most amazing way.
It was as though he somehow grew to semi-adulthood with the world
view and social perspective of a 10 year old (I'm being generous here).

He lived in his own parallel universe and would make an excellent subject
for some sociological study.

Let's give him credit for coining the phrase "Nazi Sheep".  This gave
Trond (I think) the opportunity to suggest the above must have originated
from Baaden Baaden...  Perhaps the line of the year.

Vol

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 22:42:12 -0500
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Factory Tours and 1995 Treffen

PCNA advised dealers that Porsche AG " will restructure production facilities
commencing in October 1995 to prepare for the Boxster production.  As a
result, all factory tours will be suspended as of October 1, 1995.  The
regular tours will actually be discontinued as of July 15, with "restricted"
tours possible August 15 through September 30."

See your dealer for details, no definition given for "restricted" tours.

With regard to 1995 Tourist Delivery Group Tours (which they're calling
"Treffens" and which some of you may remember the PCA controversy on
continuation with certain travel agencies in the early
 80's), PCNA advised dealers on Feb 7, 1995 (paraphrased): Three Tourist
delivery events (April 27-28, June 29-30, Sept 28-29) for 1995.  Customer
makes own travel arrangements.  Two day event, day 1: Complete paper work &
informal dinner, day 2: Visit Museum, tour production facilities, lunch at
the Casino, visit Weissach R&D Center (rides in test cars), delivery of new
car, cocktail party and dinner.  Customers responsible for travel arangements
but special rate at Graf Zeppelin in Stuttgart.  Lunch, dinners, and local
travel sponsored by PCNA and Porsche AG.

Vehicles order for April tour must be received by PCNA NLT end of February.
 See your dealer for details, they are asked to coordinate with Cheryl Whitake
r at 702-348-3109.

As an aside, apparently no Boxsters will be available even for the Sep 28-29
delivery event.  Other "good" news above was transmitted along with
information on the 2 percent price increase (deliveries through March will
apparently be "price protected", but again contact your dealer if you have
one on order).

Perry

Perry

Date: Thu, 9 Feb 1995 21:56:59 -0500
From: rgrayson@atlanta.com (Richard Grayson)
Subject: 914 2.0 FI vs Webers

I'm finally serious about getting my "project car." Saturday I'll look at a
1973 914 2.0 liter. The car has Webers, Konis front/Bilsteins rear, Yokos,
"Euro pistons", CD ignition, no rust, $3500. The current (2nd) owner
mentioned that the first owner did some (guess what) autocrossing with the car.

The stock FI has been replaced by Webers. I understand this was a common
occurrence, mostly because folks didn't understand the FI, and were more
familiar with good ole carbs.

I know very little about Webers. Will they require lots more fiddling to
keep running well? I'm somewhat spoiled because my current 911 has the Bosch
Motronic system.

I plan to use the car as a daily driver and possible autox weapon. (Yes,
I'll need to check the mods to see what's legal.)

I don't live in California, so the non-stock carbs are OK, FOR NOW. Does
anyone think the rest of the US will someday adopt the more restrictive
California standards? In other words will I someday have convert back to FI?
Yeah, good luck on finding the parts....

Richard Grayson 
rgrayson@atlanta.com
1985 911 coupe

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 00:22:02 -0500
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Re: How do you choose your oil.........

Hmmm. Time to appeal to authority here...

>Martin wrote in responst to what I wrote:
>  >I would use synthetic in a 930 (especially an early one) because synthetics
>  >are much more resistant to "coking" (getting fried by turbo heat, and thus
>details please .... did this come off the sales info from madison avenue or
>is there somewhere we can actually look at some unbiased test results

"Synthetics have an advantage in high temperature lubrication of engines and
particularly for turbocharger shafts and bearings. The ester type synthetics
have an affinity for hot metal and are used as metal wetting additives to
prevent hot drain seizure. In addition, the ester synthetics prevent the
coking and varnishing of turbocharger shafts and bearings...."

 - Bruce Anderson, "Multiviscosity Oils and Your Porsche," March/84, as
reprinted in Up-fixin, Vol. 7, page 44. A biography is given for the
article. (Yes, most of the references are from oil companies, but what do
you expect?)

(And that was written over 10 years ago, when there was still quite a bit of
debate whether one should use straight-weight or multi-grade oils in one's
Porsche, and Mobil 1 was still pretty hard to find.)

>  >One case where synthetics are clearly superior is in cold-weather startup.
>  >If you live in an area like I do (and for your sake I hope you don't :), a
>I understand from this (and other rumors too...) that synthetics have a
>better wide-range performance than multi-grades  ie lower pour point and
>better lubrication through the heat/pressure range.  Is this true...details ?

Well, all you had to do around here (earlier this week, anyways, when it was
below -30 Celsius *and* Fahrenheit) would be to place a litre of 5w30 dino
and a litre of 5w30 synthetic outside for an hour or so, and try to pour
them. You would see for yourself whether the rumour that synthetics have a
lower pour point is true or not :)

"Other potential advantages of these synthetic lubricants are their higher
thermal oxidation index and their higher inherent viscosity index."

 - Bruce Anderson, from the above-quoted article.

>yes...we're ganging up on this one !

Well, *I*'m not going to argue with Mr. Anderson. You can ask him for
details if you want <grin>.

BTW, quick plug here for the Up-fixin books... if one works on one's
Porsche, they're *extremely* handy to have around, and well worth what PCA
charges for them. The indexing alone makes it easy to look up stuff like this...

Craig.


- --- <: snip! ;> ---
+ Craig Seko in Ottawa, the second coldest national capital in the world! +
| Personal'n'Porsche mail: cseko@inasec.ca  Work mail: sekocet@statcan.ca |
| URL Moved! http://www.inasec.ca/cseko/welcome.html -new stuff, finally! |
+ Usual opinion disclaimer :) I speak only for myself. Live free or die.  +

of the people on the list to share their views, however outrageous, for fear
of similar punitive action.  Now, everytime I access the postings, I get the
distinct image of a group of very intelligent and enthusiastic people holding
back for fear of a backlash from the Internet Police (InterPol?).

I still remember with great fondness the repartee occasioned by Miss Jeanie
(where are you when we need you most??!!).  Everyday, I looked forward to the
MissJeanie postings to see what literary gems would issue forth from the
list.  They were smart, intelligent, and funny as hell.

T*d deserved to be expelled from the list, but I fear he took our soul away
with him, and that is the real tragedy.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 07:53:02 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re: 928S Questions.....

>>
>> Reply to:     RE>>928S Questions.....
>>
>>>>Does your lock release turn contiguously or just one revolution?
>>
>>
>>It should turn only one revolution.  If you take the motor apart, you
>>may find a Rube Goldberg mechanical device that will stop the motor
>>once it has completed a single revolution.  Something may be 
>>broken or just dirty.
>>
>>

The secret to the lock release (on the 928) stopping at the right place
is a little fuse, a few inches up the wire from the release motor
itself. That fuse (not mentioned in the owner's manual) provides the
power that drives the motor back to the correct stopping point when
you release the switch. If it is blown, the motor will just stop
immediately, at whatever point in the cycle it happens to be, which
may mean that you can't get your hatch to stay shut because the motor
stopped with the latch in the release position. The fuse is a 1 amp
cylindrical glass fuse, that you can get at your local electronic
parts store.

 -John White-


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 95 15:55:46 +0200
From: pl@mistyrivers.itf.fi (Pekka Laiho)
Subject: early 911 head flow-test


Hi all.

First one histroric rule.

IT IS NOT ALLOWED TO CHANGE VALVE SIZE!
So we test the heads only with standard size valves.

Something about the flow test we had made.

When you look the table and colums in it, specially
the HP column, please remember that the values are
meassured or calculated. So, the hp column has nothing
to do with real power got out from the engine.

The main idea is first flow-test the original head,
modify the head, flow test it and compare the
results. We was not quite happy to us 1st modification
so we will continue modificate the head and flow-test it.

With standard head, early 2 liter 911 engine gives 130 hp
with solex PI40 carps, so if we got 25 calculated hp more, I
suppose that ours engine now gives more power, but how much, I
don't know. In ours test we use same venturi (30) and it's not
anymore correct choice for modificated head.

Another thing you must remember when looking flow-test results.
It's quite sure for test, that what bigger the ports are that better
flow and hp you get. BUT, with large ports you lost power an torgue
in lower RPM range.

With large port size, you can get head that start works after 5000 RPM.
it's good if you have wery wild cam eg 906 or GE-80 cam and you
only race with that car but it's not good for street or rally.

All comments are welcome.

W: Pekka Laiho

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 95 09:26:50 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 rear spacers

> Hello Sport Fans...
> 
> My 944 has 7" wheels all around and what appears to be a 1" spacer on the 
> rear wheels.
> 
> I just bought a set of 7 & 8 wheels. Should the spacer be removed? I will be 

> running 215/60-15 (standard size) on them.
> 
> Thanks!
> 
> Lou Nicotra

Hi, Lou,

The one inch spacer stays.

The 7+8x15 wheels were the sport suspension option on the early (83-85/1)
944 cars. (Mine came with them...) Also included was the rear 14 mm sway bar.

Later,

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 08:11:30 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: The Official Word on the "Save the 914 Foundation"

Dearest List Members,

This outpouring of attention has been overwhelming. I have had *NO* idea
how best to deal with this, so have put off saying anything until I knew
what it was that I wanted to say. Since we're rolling up on Fred's 2/11 
deadline, I figured it was time to speak up, even though I'm still speachless.

First, *THANK YOU*. Your care and attention has amazed me. From my perspective
I've just been sort of doing my thing here, and while many of you have become
personal friends, this incredible outpouring of concern and offers to help
is beyond anything I've ever experienced. I'm really and truly starting
to feel like Jimmy Stewart's character in "It's a Wonderful Life".  Regardless
of whatever else follows, I'm greatly enriched by knowing each and every
one of you. Thank you again.

Second, the 914 is sold. I will be delivering it today to Bart Denys
in scenic Thibodaux, LA. I held off doing this for a good while, thinking 
that well, I *could* let the group buy the car from me, and had to do a 
lot of soul-searching before coming to the conclusion: even if I kept the 
car, I would not have had the chance to race it this year. At all. It's 
just not in the cards. I can *ALWAYS* build another later but it's nearly 
criminal to let a car this well prepared *JUST SIT* and dry rot when it 
could be doing *SOMETHING*. Someone needs to be getting some enjoyment
from it, and it was just making me miserable sitting there, looking back
with those taped-over eyes asking to be taken for a romp at Hallett or
Cabaniss or TWS or Road America...

And I can always try to buy it back later...

Last, well, I don't know; *IS* it time to start a Porschephiles Defense
Fund to keep this thing operating?? I'm not likely to run out of desire to
do it, and I sort of have the Internet connection part "wired" so to speak,
(at least for now) but it's running on pretty tired 3 or 4 year old 
hardware that wasn't that fast to begin with... I refuse to be in a 
position to personally profit from a group fund raising effort, but if we
are having a bake sale, it might be time to get new hardware.

Anyway, I'll not be reading mail from about 11:30 AM CST today until
about 8:00 PM CST Saturday.  You all have good weekends, take your cars
and commune with the open road or the closed circuit or whereever you find
your peace.

Stan Hanks
ListMeister

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 95 07:32:31 PST
From: pat@cor.cerfnet.com (Pat Hohl [5607])
Subject: tensioning 944 belts

Richard;
You can buy a tool if you have your heart set on 
blowing $500, but I (and many others) don't think
you need to.  I have an 84 944 and when I did my
belts I was faced w/ the same problem.  I did a lot
of research, and many "shops" (not P dealers) that
do 928/944 work don't even own the tool.  They use
the accepted belt tensioning wisdom that they use
on BMW, Mercedes, Ford, Toyota etc.  That's what I did
and I have 25k  miles on my belts now.  And I don't
drive like an old lady either!

FIRST
Make sure you got them on right.
Then make double sure you got them on right.

1) Twist the longest span of the belt w/ your fingers.
Shoot for tension that allows you to turn the belt
about 1/4 turn.  
(my belts seemed slightly less than 1/4 when all done)

2) Leave the covers off, and start it up.
If the belt screams at you - it's too tight.

3) Leave the balancer shaft belt on the loose side
while you get the Cam belt right.  Then do the Balancer
belt.

4) Use common sense.

5) Recheck the belts in a couple thousand, because they seem
to give a little when you first install them.


USE CAUTION - this topic is flame bait.

 -pat
'84 944

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 09:55:44 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: renewing oil cooler

> One thing I haven't seen anyting on
> is renewing the oil cooler. For that matter the oil tank.
>  The reason for the rebuild is a broken wrist pin on #1. 

After you break any metal parts in the inside of the engine, you
need to do a few things differently than you might for a "normal"
rebuild 

* Always have the oil cooler, lines, and tank cleaned very , very
  well. There is residual cruft in there that can make your new
  engine not be very new in short order.

* For the lines and cooler, the procedure I use is pressure flushing
  with denatured alcohol. Then, of course, pressure testing the
  cooler, and often the lines if they're not pretty new.

* For the tank, that varies. I've been known to just send the tank to
  the radiator shop and have it "tanked" like I do with gas tank,
  then seal it with Wurth gas tank sealer. I've also been known to
  powder coat them if I had a box of other crap getting powder
  coated and it was easy to just toss it on the pile. I'd *NEVER*
  pay extra to get one coated as a special, but if it's just another
  part in the pile, well, why not?

Stan

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 10:34:07 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: T*d Went a-Racin'

        Gee, all of this T*d-nostalgia makes me remember...
        PCA Zone 7 Autocross in the Oakland Coliseum parking lot.
I get there about 11AM, since my group wasn't running or working
in the morning.  As I drive 'round the outside of the lot to get
to the grid area, I see a dog-doo brown 911 going around on the
course.  Accelerating hard, evidently--the nose is *way* up in
the air!  Then I notice that the driver is *braking*--when the
car accelerates, the nose goes up even higher!  I thought it was
going to flip!
        Sure enough, it was T*d.  We thought that his "competition
alignment" was pretty interesting.
        He was out there again the next day.  Heck, he was the
flagman for part of the day!  (Eeek!)  No pile-ups, though.  On
one particularly memorable run, T*d sets up way off line for the
second of a series of "gates".  Sure enough, he spins right at the
gate.  Gets the car around again, off he goes for the next gate,
SKREEEK!  Another spin.  Several of us on the sidelines are looking
on with smiles on our faces, probably remembering a time or two
that we did something like that...  And what the heck, it was just
a practice lap, right?  Then he comes around on his timed lap--
sets up in the exact same place for the gate, same result--around
he goes!  Gets the car moving again, and guess what?  Spins yet
again at the exact same place!  This elicited some laughter from
the crowd.
        On his next run, the announcer said, "Wing Commander T*d
Matsumura has already given us a demonstration of his loop-the-loop,
now he's going to try wing-walking!"  By that time, we were rolling
on the ground, howling with laughter.  Thus was born the Wing Com-
mander title.
        And remember, all this was after about three months of con-
stant flame-wars about how much better T*d's car was and how much
better T*d's driving was than anyone else!
        Aaah--the memories...

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 09:15:43 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 FI vs Webers

I'm finally serious about getting my "project car." Saturday I'll look at a
1973 914 2.0 liter. The car has Webers, Konis front/Bilsteins rear, Yokos,
"Euro pistons", CD ignition, no rust, $3500. The current (2nd) owner
mentioned that the first owner did some (guess what) autocrossing with the car.

The stock FI has been replaced by Webers. I understand this was a common
occurrence, mostly because folks didn't understand the FI, and were more
familiar with good ole carbs.

I know very little about Webers. Will they require lots more fiddling to
keep running well? I'm somewhat spoiled because my current 911 has the Bosch
Motronic system.

I plan to use the car as a daily driver and possible autox weapon. (Yes,
I'll need to check the mods to see what's legal.)

I don't live in California, so the non-stock carbs are OK, FOR NOW. Does
anyone think the rest of the US will someday adopt the more restrictive
California standards? In other words will I someday have convert back to FI?
Yeah, good luck on finding the parts....

Richard Grayson 
rgrayson@atlanta.com
1985 911 coupe

I think that all states will require some sort of annual or bi-annual smog
inspections, so it is in your interest to at least have the equipment to 
return the car to its F.I. condition.  If the engine does not have a cam too
wild for the F.I. (too much duration!). then the Webers are probably a waste
and only good for sex appeal.  The F.I. is much better suited to every day
driving, good mid range, and as much top end as the engine can use in a semi-
stock state of tune.  If the engine has a cam with more duration than the F.I.
can tolerate, then you might see overall performance improve, but probably only
realized if you auto-cross.  The fuel economy of the F.I. will not be matched
by that of the Webers either.  The Webers do require tuning, something not 
needed the F.I.. The F.I is generally more reliable, the only problems I have
had in 20+ years of 914 ownership, is the wiring and connections.  I have never
had a F.I. component failure, save for one injector that started sticking afer
10+ years.

Dan
75 914 2.0 ROAD WARRIOR
70 914/6
Dswiger@QNTM.COM
DSIWGER180@AOL.COM

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 95 10:40:27 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: re: 914 FI help

>From: wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu (William C. Marten)
>Subject: Re: 914 FI help (long)
>
>[edited for television]
>
>Side note to Gary:  Where would the second engine temperature sensor be?  I 
>would swear that my `74 2.0 only has the head temp sensor (and the air temp 
>sensor in the air cleaner).  I've also never seen any reference to it in any 
>of the manuals.
>
>Regards,
>
>     Bill Marten
>     wcmarten@facstaff.wisc.edu

The second sensor is supposed to be on the top of the block.  My manual
shows one sensor hooked to pin 23 of the ECU (This is the head sensor),
and the other connected between pins 1 and 13.

gary@superior.ucsf.edu

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 13:43:57 -0500 (EST)
From: qhq2227@dcro2.dcro.dla.mil (Larry Dunlap)
Subject: Tire Recommendations?

Hey Guys,

Does anybody have any good recommendations on tires?  I have an '84 944 that
I use as a daily driver.  I am looking for a decent tire that will give some
kind of grip in the wet.  I have gone through several makes of tires (Michelin
XGTV, Dunlops, Pirelli 190's) but haven't found any that fit the bill.  The
Michelins were fine on dry pavement, the Pirellis are winter tires (they
offer great traction but aren't exactly suited far alittle spirited driving).
I live in Cleveland, so rain and snow are an everyday fact of life.  I am
looking for a happy compromise in performance/traction.  Any suggestions?

                                                           -Larry

ldunlap@dcro.dla.mil

1979 924

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 95 11:13:27 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: tensioning 944 belts

| From: Pat Hohl 5607]  <pat@cor.cerfnet.com>

<stuff deleted>

| 1) Twist the longest span of the belt w/ your fingers.
| Shoot for tension that allows you to turn the belt
| about 1/4 turn.
| (my belts seemed slightly less than 1/4 when all done)

I used the same technique to tension my cam belt. It was, however,
a temporary step to allow me to drive to a local mechanic who has
the TOOL. He told me that I had it much too tight. The point being
that doing it by hand is too imprecise.

| 2) Leave the covers off, and start it up.
| If the belt screams at you - it's too tight.

This is also rather vague. The belts still whine somewhat even
when correctly tensioned.

The local dealer wants $120 to do a belt tension. The independent
mechanic charged half that. I figure it is cheap insurance. Of course,
some folks don't believe in insurance. YMMV.

    Eric, '84 944 Ruby Red

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 95 14:20:31 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Tire Recommendations?

> Hey Guys,
> 
> Does anybody have any good recommendations on tires?  I have an '84 944 that
> I use as a daily driver.  I am looking for a decent tire that will give some
> kind of grip in the wet.  I have gone through several makes of tires (Micheli
n
> XGTV, Dunlops, Pirelli 190's) but haven't found any that fit the bill.  The
> Michelins were fine on dry pavement, the Pirellis are winter tires (they
> offer great traction but aren't exactly suited far alittle spirited driving).

> I live in Cleveland, so rain and snow are an everyday fact of life.  I am
> looking for a happy compromise in performance/traction.  Any suggestions?
> 
>                                                            -Larry
> 
> ldunlap@dcro.dla.mil
> 1984 944
> 1979 924
> 
> 

If you want to drive your Porsche in the snow, my recommendation is to
acquire a separate set of snow tires and wheels.  In the latest Porsche
Panorama, a classified ad lists 4 steel wheels and 4 Pirelli Winter 190 Tires
for $350 for a set of 4.  Check Page 106 of the February 95 Panorama for the
ad (I won't post here, because if you ain't a PCA member, you're going to 
miss out.)

That having been said, the Bridgestone RE-71 and the Dunlop D40-M2 tires
have worked extremely well for me in both the dry and the wet, on the street
and at the track.

YMMV
- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: 10 Feb 95 15:11:49 EST

------------------------------

Date: 10 Feb 95 15:11:52 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Renewing oil cooler

Hi, Stan.
 
You mention hot tanking an oil cooler.
 
Just a word of caution to others on the list: don't do this with aluminum
coolers! (I can't remember where Porsche used aluminum coolers, but I think
they did on some models/some years/some applications). The caustic tank at
the radiator shop will dissolve the stuff.
 
I remember having a replacement cooler tanked at a very friendly shop nearby
 - Caps Radiator Shop on Beach Blvd, Huntington Beach, CA, for any locals;
these guys are really helpful and don't even charge an arm and a leg. I
practically had to beg them to take some money for the job. Anyway, the late
356 oil cooler is usually painted in metallic silver. They said that if it has
any aluminum, it would boil immediately when put in the tank. They put it in,
and what boiled was the silver paint, but they could tell immediately that
the amount of boiling was not consistent with aluminum parts so they went
ahead with it.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 12:21:36 -0800 (PST)
From: Cherie Woodward <cherie@corp.cirrus.com>
Subject: CA Smog ?s - SUMMARY




Here is a  summary of the responses I received from my esteemed colleagues on
 P-philes regarding the posting on CA smog rules. 
My original question was: Does the necessary-to-pass work HAVE to be done at a
 smog-certified mechanic?

	Most persons agreed that the work can be done
 as you wish (that is, you can do the work; your mechanic can do the work;
 you can opt for the smog station to do the work).
	The 'hitch' is:
		You only get ONE waiver per car.

	The workarounds presented:

	Register in a non-smog county (which?)

	Find 'someone' to give you a certificate (at no small cost, I'm afraid)

	Have mechanic dial-in Zeniths just before test (should pass - obvious)

	Go to a motorcycle junkyard; buy cheap non-running junker; register (no certificate required); use current tag on licence plate (no corresponding
 numbers on registration); keep car's registration up-to-date (just needing smog certificate) - illegal, but innovative and hard to trace.

I think the State's system really sucks (no pun intended). If the repairs amount to over the limit (currently $400 - soon to be $700), it seems that you're
 given a waiver. New legislation (proposed to go into effect 1/1/96 - not
 currently passed) states that there will be only one waiver allowed per
 vehicle. 

A quote from Sean Steinman puts it plainly, "All in all these guys (certified
  smog stations [sic]) are milking the state for funds. They only charge for the certificate and the state pays them for their work. SCAM."  - Amen brother.

	cherie
	'68 911 Orange Monster
	'70 911T SO love & consternation
	'87 Greyhound x Borsoi (0-45 in 2.2 sec.)


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 15:51:43 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: 912E#1 has been TOTALLED! Details...

Greetings Porsche Dwellers,
	I was having an enjoyable commute to work when I passed the 
mechanics shop that I sold the 912E to when I see "my" car looking like 
it had been run over by a freight train!!!  On my way home I stopped to 
check out the story.  He had swapped in a spare 914 motor so he could 
drive it while shelving the original.  Its been foggy and nasty here for 
the past few days and he was driving down a city street.  He looked down 
to adjust the heat (BAD IDEA) and when he looked up the car in front of 
him had just rapidly changed lanes.  He suddenly became face to face with 
a parked UPS truck!  Luckily  the driver was out of the truck, but poor 
Greg (the mechanic) got a taste of Porsche's fat 3-spoke wheel.  He's OK, 
but the car is wrecked beyond belief.  The front part is totally smashed and 
it buckled in the middle so the doors are about five inches behind where 
they are supposed to be. (NASTY :^()
	Anyway, he had his dealer tag on it and his insurance will only 
give him $7600 for it!  He asked me to write here for suggestions.  What 
should he do with it?  He can pay $1500 for the remnant and try to 
rebuild it but it isn't worth it, is it?  What to do? Any suggestions 
would be appreciated.

Jay Karolyi
'77 924 "the green machine"
Greg Hansen
'76 912E #1 (this piece of history IS history)  :^( 

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 12:52:13 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: CA Smog ?s - SUMMARY

There used to be non-smog counties in California, but I think that's a
thing of the past.  Misery loves company, and though smog isn't a
problem on the coast, the bureaucrats want to treat everybody equally.

In Nevada, smog inspections are required in Clark and Washoe counties,
but not in any others (that means Reno yes, Carson City no).  They're 
annual, but pretty much tailpipe only, and no catalytic converter
required before '81.  Meanwhile, in the People's Republic of
California one can probably find individual solutions if needed, but
they would have to be kept private for the sake of all concerned.

These are consequences of whom we elect to public office--consequences
that are often learned after it's too late.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: 10 Feb 95 15:58:45 EST
From: Mark Doyle <MDOYLE@laitram.mhs.compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: Lame Headlights

Sean,

I had the same problem a while ago.  Turned out to be a broken ground 
connection at the dim light.  At first it made no sense that the light 
was dim.  You would expect the light to not work at all with a broken 
ground wire.  However, a current path still exists.  The current path is 
thru the dim light's low beam filament, to the common ground connection 
inside the headlight (which is not grounded anymore), thru the dim lights 
high beam filament, thru the car's wiring harness to the other 
headlight's high beam filament, then to the good ground of the other 
headlight.  Some current could flow, but not enough to make the light 
bright.

If your ground wire is OK, check the headlight with an ohmmeter.  The 
ground connection could be broken inside the headlight.

Mark Doyle



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 95 16:26:00 PST
From: Shafer Kirk <ShaferK@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: 944 FALSE AIR (the follow up)


FWIW.....Summarized responses.........




ORIGINAL POSTING...........

Chasing stumbling under load problem with my '88 944.  Pressurized intake 
tract (bicycle pump) and found pretty major air leak around base of the oil 
filler tube.

Anybody know how to tighten / replace / fix this leak?  The 944 manual set I 
have on fiche shows 2 bolts holding the oil filler tube in place, neither of 
which appear to affect the seal into the crank case.  So I'm at a loss as to 
the details of this fitting.

Thanks to any who respond to me direct - I'll post a response summary if I 
get much of interest on this one to save bandwidth.

Kirk
'88 944





RESPONSES.............
_____________________________________

Strange place for an air leak, but...

if you remove the oil filler tube, you will see a couple of rubber
O-rings that are supposed to seal the beast.

I would suggest replacing those and rechecking.

Good Luck,

 --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593
_____________________________________


My 85 944/2 has an O ring there
 -bob

_____________________________________


What you probably need to replace are o-ring seals which push on
to the oil separator/filler tower where it plugs into the engine.

Kevin

Date: 10 Feb 1995 15:26:53 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: T*d story that can't be bea

                      Subject:                              Time:  3:10 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         T*d story that can't be beat          Date:  2/10/95

Probably one of the most hilarious T*d stories I heard (directly
from him, BTW...I actually had lunch with the legend a few times
and even met Akiko, his fiance!) involved his troubleshooting
skills under the engine lid:

One afternoon right after work T*d sought to better understand
that peculiar noise coming from the engine bay.  With the engine
idling, T*d rolled up his sleeves, sharpened his eyes, tucked his
head under the lid and...promptly caught his necktie in the fan belt.
Damn near killed him.  Never got the courage to tell Akiko about it.
Was afraid she'd make him sell his beloved lightweight,
aerodynamic 77 911S.

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 18:35:45 -0500

Well, when we should be beginning to see some milder winter weather here, we
get near-zero temps and snow on the ground for 3 weeks!  The Porsches are
still under cover - but the batteries are out for charging - they were all
near death!

My question is rather embarrassing (you'd think I'd know better after keeping
these things going for 23 year), but how can I tell if the batteries are
charged to the proper amperage level?  You can't check specific gravity with
maintenance free types, and my gravity tester is probably 20 years old too.
 I can trickle charge till I'm blue in the face ,and have plenty of voltage,
but how do I know they amps are were they should be?  Batteries, 1 for the
914 and 2 for the T, are all less than 3 years old and should be fine - but
how can I be sure?

Pat Garvey
too f......'n cold!

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 15:52:11 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Tire Recommendations?

>Does anybody have any good recommendations on tires?  I have an '84 944 that
>I use as a daily driver.  I am looking for a decent tire that will give some
>kind of grip in the wet.  I have gone through several makes of tires (Michelin
>XGTV, Dunlops, Pirelli 190's) but haven't found any that fit the bill.  The
>Michelins were fine on dry pavement, the Pirellis are winter tires (they
>offer great traction but aren't exactly suited far alittle spirited driving).
>I live in Cleveland, so rain and snow are an everyday fact of life.  I am
>looking for a happy compromise in performance/traction.  Any suggestions?

If you want the best of both worlds, you'll want to pick up a set of snow tires (and 
probably wheels, if you want to keep the originals nice and salt-free - unless it's 
too late. :).
For snows, Nokias are probably the best - you can get Hakkapelliita (or however 
it's spelled!) 10s, which are pure snow tires, or... Shoot, can't remember the 
name, but they also make a high-performance snow tires. Both are 
uni-directional, the hi-po ones look most like the usual unidirection summer 
tires.

As for summers, I think everyone will give a different answer. I myself like the 
Comp T/A ZRs, the new ones - plus they're pretty inexpensive.

If you insist on an all-season, there are some newer high-perf ones that should 
be very good in both - BF Goodrich has been advertising the Comp T/A ZR4, an 
all-season ZR tires.

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 19:36:39 -0500
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Re: Tire Recommendations?

George wrote:
>Larry wrote:
>> Does anybody have any good recommendations on tires?  I have an '84 944 that
>> I use as a daily driver.  I am looking for a decent tire that will give ...
>> I live in Cleveland, so rain and snow are an everyday fact of life.  I am
>> looking for a happy compromise in performance/traction.  Any suggestions?
>...That having been said, the Bridgestone RE-71 and the Dunlop D40-M2 tires
>have worked extremely well for me in both the dry and the wet, on the street

Note that the RE-71's, anyways, are pretty much useless in cold weather.
According to local Bridgestone rep., the tread compound of the RE-71's is
designed to be grippy in the usual spring/summer/fall temperature range,
while not getting too soft when the going gets hot (e.g. on the track). The
trade-off is rubber that's as hard as concrete at colder temps, and not much
traction, either. I can vouch personally that the RE-71's snow performance
leaves a lot to be desired <cough>.

I have "high-performance" all-season Bridgstone RE-92's on my 924. The snow
performance is decent, the ride is smoother and has less tread noise than an
RE-71, and they handle nicely on the track. Unfortunately, if you go at
decent black run group track speeds, the tread squirm (and resulting
4-wheel-drifting) leads to not-nice-looking wear patterns and a bit of
chunking. They should be just about right for a daily driver, though, and
the H-rated version (which are fine for the street) have much higher wear
ratings than the V-rated version (which is what I have).

A better solution is, of course, like George mentioned, a second set of rims
and something like the 190's for the winter (I'd say Blizzaks, but they're
too radical a snow tire for most people). Then you could put RE-71's on your
regular rims for the summer, and get another set of rims to put track tires
on, and...


Craig.

Parade entrant;  Easiest thing to do is to enter the parade now, if you do
not get in on the first try, do not worry, a goodly number of people drop,
10-15% in most years.  If you really want to know about the waiting list,
call the registrar and prepare yourself for a formula, which may be fair,but
is rather complicated to explain, simply put if you are one of the few people
from a far away region, don't worry you will get in.

I have a quick question about the 911SC that I hope someone can answer.

noticed that in one section he says that in '81, the SC's compression was 
upped from 8.5:1 to 9.8. This was complimented with a supposed increase 
in HP from 180-204.  Is this accurate?  Why is this the only literature 
that I have read about this in?  If this is true, does the increased

the increase in HP worth the effort looking for an '81,'2,'3 (assuming it 
is true)?  Thanks for the info.

Boys and girls,

We all owe Fred an enormous debt for getting this effort off the ground.
We've seen that Stan, sadly, has sold the 914, and his reasoning was sound.

Thanks Fred, for motivating us, however unsuccesful we were, to try to pay Stan 
back for *his* generosity!

stuff.  Stan shouldn't have to bear any of that cost.  It's our list, and
we oughta cough up the nosh required to make it happen.

Fred got the ball rolling.  I leave it to him if he wants to stay with this,
and if not, I'll volunteer to be accountable to coordinate the upgrade fund
raising (I know, Jim and Herb, I clearly haven't learned a f*cking thing...Boy, 
will my First Shirt have a case of the red *ss if he hears about *this*...)

Anyway, here's a set of rules I propose, open to discussion, for the effort 
regardless of who is in the barrel for coordinating the bucks:

Coordinator sets up bank account in name of "Porschephiles"
Coordinator publishes Bank name and account number to list
DONOR(s) sends check made out to "Porschephiles Acct No #####" to coordinator.
     Back of check is pre-endorsed by donor, 
     "for deposit only to"Porschephiles Acct No #####" 
coordinator sends donor email with number of donors deposit (#1 through  n
     donors)  Donor may be anonymous or public.  Public donors should send mail
     to list with amount donated.
coordinator publishes weekly funds report. Weekly funds report is in 
the following format:

Donation number   Name (anon)  anount   deposit date total to date.
1                 anon          50        2/15/95          50
2                 jones         50        2/16/95         100
3                 smith         15        2/19/95         115
4                 newman, ae    50        2/19/95         165
...(time passes, stuff happens...)
n                 anon         30         2/15/99   1,590,000

Coordinator sends money to Stan
Stan gets rich, he and Mary run off to beautiful downtown Grozny and set
up internet Porsche Dealership;

   Well, maybe there's a bug or two here, but  this is only version 1.0.  
   If I can get my hands on a pentium, I can work them out by version
   1.999973...

at some time, say weekly, bi-weekly, monthly or whatever, transfers shall be
made to Stan for his disposition, as he sees fit.  Allowable uses of the
fund shall be *strictly* limited to those things Stan deems proper.  Such 
uses shall include, but not be limited to, Computers, Software. Porsches,
Porsche parts, Booze, broa...oooops, sorry Mary, make that, "and such other
uses as Stan, in his infinite wisdom, may deem fit."

What say ye, ;Philes...?

Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora
(cars & Varmint)

quoting prices etc. It seems depending on who you get on the phone, 
you'll get a different price. I call Automotion and the guy tries to 
charge me $13 for shipping a belt. So I hangup and call back a few 
minutes later and get another guy. He ships it to me for $4 or so.
 
Re: "exchange rates" and "world markets", I'm sure the P9201 is a hot, 
world commodity subject to monthly fluctuations in price :^)
 
Joe
'86 944

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 21:33:23 -0600

At 4:23 am 2/9/95, Ben Evans wrote:

>If the 928 and 968 made any significant money for Porsche, then

>the 993 in various forms makes up the greatest proportion of
>production at Porsche, and one would presume, is the product
>that is pushing Porsche back to being a viable business. Cut
>your losses and roll your gains is the maxim being applied here I think.

>I like all Porsche, the luxo barge <g> and other water
>pumping variants are cool, and am sorry to seem them go, but the
>new company strategy seems to be to develop a core of related products (ie
>boxer-engined sports cars, from entry level to high-performance
>Ferrari bashers), to replace the existing incoherent "model range"
>(hotch-potch?) of somewhat ageing and wildly different cars.

help keep Porsche going, and I think we all want to see Porsche keep going

Just my $.00000002 worth !!!

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 23:48:23 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: Starting a Porsche after hibern

Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca> asked :

>I'll soon be starting my 944 for the first time since early December. I'm 
>concerned about lack of lube during the initial startup. What is the 
>recommended startup procedure for a car that's been dormant for several 
>months? 

My car has been basically hibernating on and off for the past 4 years,
running it every month or so (in the winter only a few times when the
roads are clean).

Every time I start it, I push it out of the garage, get it rolling down the
hill,
and pop the clutch in 2nd gear with the key in the ON position.
This gets oil pressure up in a few seconds without the engine running.
Then I stop the car and start it with the starter. My MFI engine will not
start
right without the priming" squirt from the starter position.

It's my poor-man's accusump. Luckily I have no power features (steering,
brakes, etc) so it is easy, but in a 944 it could be a problem.

I hear that the majority of engine wear comes from cold starts, so I hope
my engine hasn't worn at all in the last 4 years.

Mike Piera '72 911S AnalogMike@aol.com


------------------------------

Yeah, it is a little hard to read sometimes.  I bought a higher
magnification lens for my reader to make it easier.  As for the
problem interpreting the negative pictures, you might be able to
have positives printed at a local library, college library, or
print shop that has fiche readers with printers.

Date: Fri, 10 Feb 1995 23:40:17 -0800
From: Harry Pellow <maestro@well.sf.ca.us>
Subject: 912 Problem- the Answer.

To: porschephiles
To: Porschephiles

Subject: 912 Problem, the Answer





     God, you guys are Good! Out of 30 E-mails concerning the "seized"

912 Problem, 8 hit the nail on the head- including our Fearless Leader,

Stan!  So the Maestro's gonna reveal the Answer before he runs out

of Spec Books.

    If you'll remember the problem:

       The new '69 912 engine had been running fine untl the 

owner pulled off to get gas, whereupon he heard a horrible 

grinding sound from the engine, followed by the Sound of Silence. 

And a "seized" engine. Towed to the Maestro's  Shop, the Maestro

discovered that neither a fresh 12 Volt battery nor his 

Metric Adjustible Wrench, attached to the pulley would turn it over.



And now, for Part 2:

    Moan! Groan! Beseech the Porsche gods. Break the Emergency Virgin

Case and sacrifice one to the gods. Still, the engine refused to turn 

over with the Starter or a wrench on the pulley nut! 

     The Maestro wandered around the shop in an 

angry/depressed/self-pitying haze for a while until his 

Center of Higher Reasoning decided it was time to step in. 

     "OK", it said, sounding like Mrs. Maestro.

so you've got a problem. Big Deal. Pull the engine. Find out

what's wrong. And fix it. Besides, there might be a Story there. 

     So, the Maestro gritted his teeth, grabbed his tools and attacked 

the seized 912 with a newfound passion. Inside of half an hour he had 

the wires disconnected, the mount bolts off, the engine lowered and 

out of the car.    

    As he pulled it out from under the 912, the Maestro wondered just 

what the hell had gone so wrong to seize it up tighter than a bull

in fly time. 

    He grabbed the flywheel and pulled/pushed back and forth to see 

ifin it was a broken crank or a loosened flywheel nut. No. He tried 

rotating the flywheel by hand. It rotated nicely. 

   IT ROTATED NICELY???!!! Wait a minute! I thought you said it was seized!|

   It WAS seized- before, when it was in the car! The Maestro 

glanced at the pulley as he rotated the flywheel- the pulley now TURNED!

The Engine was NOT seized! 

    So, what the hell happened??? THe Maestro grabbed the Main Shaft of the

912's transmission and rotated it. It rotated freely! 

    Well, what's left??? What could have caused this???

    The Maestro thought about this for a little while and then- his 

Center of Higher Reasoning made a Connection! Of Course- you idiot- 

it had to be that. What else can it be? 

    It was the STARTER! Somehow the El-Cheapo, non-Bosch rebuilt

Starter stuck its mechanical foreskin into the flywheel when the 

engine was running! Which accounts for the funny grinding

sounds. Fortunately, the flywheel ring ring gear teeth were none the

worse for wear.

     And, off course, when the Maestro pulled out the starter- 

sho' 'nough the pinion gear of the Starter looked like an incompetent 

dentist had ground down half of its teeth! 

     Somehow, the starter had engaged its teeth into the flywheel- making

a good flywheel LOCK- not unlike the flywheel lock the Maestro uses to 

keep the flywheel from turning when he tightens the flywheel nut down!|

    It was something the Maestro had NEVER seen before (and hopes he 

never sees again!). 

    Fortunately, the ring gear teeth of the flywheel were OK, but to be

sure the Maestro fired the engine up on the ground. All was fortunately

well. So back in it went! 

   Now, of course, had the Maestro thought this thing through- he mightave

concluded that the Only Possible Cause was obviously the Starter and
replaced

it straight away, instead of pulling the engine.

But then, this Story wouldn't have been nearly as much fun, now would it? 

    These things happen when you:|

KEEP THE 356 FAITH!!!

The Maestro

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 07:52:59 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 1995 Parade

>Paul Andrus writes looking for information about geeting into Parade and
>wanting to know how the "wait" list works.  Past experience has been about
>4-6 weeks before you get any confirmation about whether you made it. 

Parade has NOT sold out very early in recent memory. The Cincinnati Parade,
for example, closed out about 2 weeks prior to the Parade itself and that was
more for convinience than being oversold.  Based on the past ten years
experience, if you get your entry postmarked on the first legal day, you WILL
get in.  The last Parade that I know of that was sold out real early and
turned away first day registrants was the Ashville Parade in the early '80's.
Some Parades have taken entrants during Parade week itself. Portland may be
different, since they will have a Driver's school and a race tied into the
event, tow STRONG inducements to travel that far.  Late entries could also
get closed out of meal packages even though they get into Parade itself since
those are now required to be purchased up front.

Jon Lowe
Cinci Parade Tech Quiz Chairman

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 09:28:51 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: C-2 Turbo Wheels on an '86 911


For 9" wheels you'll have to get to 23.3mm offset 

(911 7, 8" wheels are 10.8, 9" are 23.3, and 951 7, 8", before '87 are 23.3.

You'll need to get to 10.8 in the front to fill things out with a 7" wheel.  With 8" 23.3 is optimum since it puts the extra inch all on the inside (moves offset ~1/2" or 12.5mm)

Assuming the 7" are 53.3mm offset, as standard for C2, There are to get the extra 30mm of hub you'll need in the front:

1) Run spacers (30mm is a commpn size, don't forget the longer studs,
or buy those "bolt on" spacers, whcih I don't trust)

2) Upgrade to 81+ 930 hubs and calipers.

Option 2 is more costly, but if you're thinking of it, it's a good
time.

In the rear you're pretty much stuck with using spacers.  If the offset
is 53.3mm (that should be stamped inside a spoke or available from the
dealer), the difference is again 30mm.

I ran the 8" C2 wheels on the front of my 911 SC -w- 930 hubs.  They
could have used about 10mm more outset, but they fit fine -w-
245-45-16s.

On the topic of offset, I just stuffed 9.5 + 11.5 -w- 275-40-17 and
315-35-17 under my (now) 930 bodied car.  Took a while to guess it
right.  If anyone needs offsets for this I now have them.

S

------------------------------

Date:         Sat, 11 Feb 95 09:21:06 EST
From: "Sean P. Simmen" <SS8299A@american.edu>
Subject:      Million $ Cars!!!

I had the most unexpectedly thrilling experience when I went to pick up my 928
from getting its new stereo installed!  The shop in Rockville, Maryland shares
garage space with a BMW repair shop.  When I got there they informed me that my
 stereo had taken a LOT longer to instal than they had expected, and were still
 working on it (this is at 7PM! on a Friday!)  They invited me back to the gara
ge to watch him finish up.  First thing I see when I walk into the garage: a 73
 BMW 2002 BAUER convertible!  While I am exclaiming, the stereo guy says, "what
? The one up on the rack?" and I said no, the one in front of me!  Wondering wh
at he thought I was exclaiming at, I look over at one of the car lifts and see
a '57 BMW **507**!!!!  That made my mouth drop and I was speechless!  I finally
 managed to utter "...507...507...507!...less than 300 in the WORLD".  He said
"yeah, it's worth a million dollars, has the most bizzare V8 I've ever seen..."
I walked around it a while and noticed that it had some rust and normal wear,
in other words; THIS CAR IS DRIVEN!  To make a long story short, I started look
ing around at other cars sitting around and noticed a *brand new* '70's BMW 3.0
CSi Alpina, and then some cars with parachute covers on them...  I walked over
and lifted up one cover and discovered a BMW 2002 *pickup truck*!  And, are you
 ready for this?  The last car over in the corner was a PORSCHE 904!!!!!!!!!!!!
I lost it.  I was sitting (I had to sit to get down to its level!) with #12 of
12 Porsche 904's in the world.  It was beautiful and very orange.  Quite and ex
perience... By the way, the new stereo system was done *superbly*.  Everything
was done as stealthly as possible and came out perfectly.  If anyone wants to
know how to build a full range system in a 928, e-mail me.  My question is:
How much is that BMW 507 worth?   How much is a 904 worth?  Why are they here,
in Maryland?!!?!?!?!
                                  Sean  '80 928

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 11:50:03 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: Need some flames

Here's the story of T*d per Pete.
 (forwarded with his permission)
 








It's kind of hard to describe. The T*d was one T*d Matsumura (the * is
because I think Stan installed something that will blast any message coming
from The T*d; seems there is a strong possibility he was trying to mailbomb
the list at the end of this sordid affair).
 
Anyway, T*d lived in an alternate universe. Some things that come to mind:

1) Narrow tires are better for slalom than wide tires. On some cars. On some
tracks. Sometimes. You'd have to ask a slalomin' fool like The T*d to tell
you exactly what is the right tire for your car.  

2) T*d told us on several occasions what a hard drivin' son of a gun he is,
canyon racing in the Bay Area for years and years, he knows somethin' about
drivin' an' racin.'
 
3) T*d ran his first slalom while on this list. He has I think a 77 911 with
an updated 78 3.0 liter SC engine. He was beaten by FIVE SECONDS by another
first timer and his wife driving a stock, "lowly" 1972 911 E with its 2.4
liter engine. Musta had really narrow tires. People who have seen him drive
said he was really spectacular -- spectacularly out of control.
 
4) T*d once told us what tires he runs -- turns out he had three or four
different BRANDS of tire on his car -- Toyo, Riken, Dunlop, I don't know
what all. I posted some sort of message about his "entire Franklin Mint
Collection of Famous Performance Tires" or something.
 
5) T*d once claimed that the Factory saved 6 lbs per wheel by going to
centerlock wheels on their race cars. (How much do YOUR lugnuts weigh?)
 
6) T*d kept trying to sell these beat up wheels to the list. I think they
were BBS alloys. He bounced the car off a curb. He was very proud that the
wheels did not break, only bend. Factory forged wheels break, he says. Cast
wheels are stronger, he says. Steel wheels? He wouldn't let his dog drive on
steel wheels. (I have steel wheels on all my 356s because that's what 356s
have. Most cars ever made have steel wheels. They work. They're not as light
and not as sexy but they hold the round black things.) As a result of his
exploits I dubbed him Curbsurfer T*d. He claims to have a place that can do
a beautiful job of rebending bent alloy wheels. Several people on the list
pointed out to him that bend wheels make great coffee tables but are no
longer safe for the road, even after straightening. Went right over his head.

7) KYB shocks are better than all that German crap. Cheaper too.
 
8) This is what finally got him thrown off the list -- apparently he posted
a message signed "Ferry Porsche" saying how great F. Porsche finds this
Porschephiles thing on the information superhighway and by the way, if
anybody has any questions about how to set up their cars for slalom, contact
Porsche's U.S. representative, T*d Matsumura.
 
9) After T*d was thrown off the list, there were numerous breakin attempts,
apparently not without some success, to Stan's system. Stan ain't happy
about that, because the system is his livelihood (not Porschephiles; he does
something else with his system that makes real money). (snipped!!)
 
10) T*d started his own 911 list. Unfortunately he decided to junkmail the
thing to EVERYBODY on Porschephiles. I didn't want it. Neither did lots of
other people, and told him to drop their names immediately. It didn't
happen. People mailed him again. Still no drop. People started getting mad
at Stan and Porschephiles for the added bandwidth (lots of stuff from The
T*d's list was getting posted 3, 4, 5 times, I think) so they asked to be
dropped from Porschephiles too. I couldn't get The T*d to take me off the
list by asking nicely, so I called his place of employment, where his net
serve lives, got the legal department voicemail, and left a VERYnastyGram.
Surprise, the junk mail stopped. T*d wasn't happy (calls me a racist; not
true, I hate everybody, especially fools of any race, color, creed, or
political party) but the messages stopped and that's all I care about.
 
See, Porschephiles with The T*d was always an adventure. You'd wake up in
the morning and rush to the machine to see what the blithering idiot has
done now, and how some of the more prominent flamethrower artists
responded.It was just beautiful. Sigh. Now we have conversations about
windshield washers. It just ain't the same. That's why I proposed we create
our own "virtual T*d" so anybody could flame him, or pretend to be him to
flame others back -- just for entertainment, not to actually flame any real
person.
 
Pete
 

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0
1966 911 cpe (in renewal state)

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 17:55:11 GMT
From: Mike Yang <yang@research.att.com>
Subject: Re: Tire Recommendations?


> For snows, Nokias are probably the best - you can get Hakkapelliita
> (or however it's spelled!) 10s, which are pure snow tires,
> or... Shoot, can't remember the name, but they also make a
> high-performance snow tires. Both are uni-directional, the hi-po
> ones look most like the usual unidirection summer tires.

The high performance Nokia snow tires are called NRWs.  I have them on
my '93 318i and I love them.  Really good grip in snow (I was able to
make it up a 20 deg incline without any problem), not bad handling (a
bit of sidewall flex).  BTW, the ones I have are HR rated.

If any one is interested I can post the place I mail ordered them.

				Mike

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 13:34:49 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: balance shaft bearings on 944

Here's one for you Porsche friends:
	Has anyone ever replaced the upper balance shaft bearing
due to wear? I'm getting this rattling noise, and it sure seems
to be comming from the rear cover of the cam housing. Looking at the
manual, it seems that there is one bearing in the back of the
balance shaft and the other one is in the front where the seals are.

The car has 95K miles. The noise only occurs in a very narrow
engine speed range. It happens on acceleration,about 1.5K, goes away after
about 2K RPM, and then it happens again as the engine revs down from
a higher RPM range.

Thanks!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689

'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

Yes, anyone who's played with the edge on a 91* has either come near or 
actually spun. The key there is to leave a lot of room for recovery (as in 
room to stop). I've done it twice unintenionally and been lucky both times 
(read lots of room).

I propose a warning plaque on the instrument panel of all 91*'s:

        WARNING: (1) BEFORE FLIGHT CHECK YOUR EQUIPMENT
                 (2) BEFORE FLIGHT PLAN YOUR ROUTE
                 (3) BEFORE FLIGHT CHECK THE PILOT

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 13:39:54 -0700

>
>Engine that was at fault!)
>
