Harry,

Ok I'll admit I'm starting logically here but that won't last: If it's not 
the new power plant it must have something to to with what the power plant 
is connected to. On my 912 the transmission is connected to the engine so 
that must be it. Of course I'll have to be more specific and this is where I 
start guessing a bit: The flywheel rubs against the pressure plate which 
drives the transmision, but wait if the engine does not turn because of the 
transmission then the engine would have been spinning when the car was being 
towed! Ouch. well as long as they did'nt go too fast.

I had my clutch seize while I was restoring my 912. I would not release but 
I was able to turn the engine by hand (the car would move too).

Well then my logic falls apart here. If the clutch did not sperate for some 
reason then you would still have been able to at least 'budge' the car with 
the starter. Unless if the transmission had turned to rock.

Let me guess: You pulled the engine to find that it fired up fine. I'm 
tempted to blame the clutch throwout fork/bearing but you would have felt it 
when you pressed the clutch in. So I'll blame it on a loose roll pin caught 
by the flywheel (starter teeth).

Don't keep me in suspence too long :->

69-912 Alpine White (The Creature)



Chris Jungmann

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 16:00:58 -0500
From: rgrayson@atlanta.com (Richard Grayson)
Subject: 914 2.0 FI retrofit

The other day I asked about whether I should buy a 1973 914 2.0 liter with
Webers, Konis front/Bilsteins rear, Yokos, "Euro pistons", CD ignition, no
rust. I was concerned that someday soon the car would be unregisterable due
to the non-original carbs.

The consensus on the net was that FI is preferable. And, if the rest of the
U.S. follows California the car will indeed someday be unregisterable.

Problem is, I still like the car. If I have to spend $1000 (wild guess) on a
used FI setup, the car might still be worthwhile.

But here's my question. The car has a "hotter" cam and somewhat larger
pistons. (Don't know specifics yet.) One mechanic says it will still run OK
with stock FI, but the idle may be a little rough. Another expert (one I'm
more likely to trust) says it will never run acceptably with the stock FI
and a hotter cam.

Any opinions on this out there?  

Thanks in advance.


Richard Grayson 
rgrayson@atlanta.com
1985 911 coupe

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 17:01:37 -0500 (EST)
From: Mark Krieger <msk@unipress.com>
Subject: 914 1st gear fixed -- accidentally

Fred and I bought a bushing kit to try to fix the 1st gear in our 73 914 
2.0L...

We took the gearshift lever arrangement out of the car, found that it all 
looked fine, and the bushings we had were for further back anyway, and so 
we put it back. 

We obviously bolted the gearshift lever stuff back onto the 
long rod a little differently than it had been on, because now first gear 
works perfectly. As does reverse and all the other gears. The bolt which 
tightens the lever mechanism to the rod is obvious -- it is in a hole you 
can see if you take the stuff off the shifter.

Now first gear lever slides right into a "further down"  position which 
engages every time, whether standing or moving.

The factory manual in fact says that to adjust the gearshift, one loosens 
the bolt and rotates the long rod and then tightens the bolt. You can get 
to the bolt without taking anything apart, there is a hole in the top of 
the lever mechanism to get to it. ANd trial and error would probably work 
like it did for us.

I hope this is clear for the dozen or so of you who indicated you had the 
same problem. This car is a great joy to drive, but now it is even 
better: I do not gnash my teeth -- like gears -- at lights!

Have fun.

Mark

 -- 
- -------------.                          .
Mark Krieger  \     .------------------'  
President      `---'  UniPress Software    
msk@unipress.com      (908)287-2100 x937       
http://www.unipress.com

I believe the proper way to breakin R1s is to get them fully warm and then
let them sit for at least 24 hours.  This allows them to fully complete
their first heat-cycle.

Date: Sat, 11 Feb 1995 17:52:53 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: More wrecked RS Americas

Drew wrote,

"P.S.  The RS Americas continue to get rarer as yet another was wadded up at
a time trial at Willow Springs (end-over-end roll).  
This makes 3 [totalled RS Americas] in the last 6 months (2 at Willow, 1 at
Laguna Seca)."

Well, make that 4 RS Americas.  I went to drivers' ed at Sebring in late
September. When I got there, there was a totalled RS America. Apparently the
driver lost the brakes going down the straight of the short track and
couldn't make the hairpin turn. He missed the turn going about 70mph, went
through the grass, up an embankment and stopped and the car then fell over
onto its' roof. He was fine but the car was totalled. This is all second
hand, it had happened the day before when the Suncoast region was having
their drivers ed. I imagine that he must have reached 140mph going down the
straight, because when I followed the proper groove I managed 125mph.  So RS
Americas are going to become collectors items.  Fewer and fewer every race
season.

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

P.S. Count me in on the hardware upgrade.

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 09:33:18 -0500
From: PSalter@aol.com
Subject: 84 911 Tranny Troubles,,,HELP!!!

My 911 tranny with 55k miles on it has shifting problems.

It all starts with trying to shift into reverse without grinding.  Then 1st
gear is hard to shift in without the same problem.  When shifting from 
1st to 2nd  I sometime have problems getting into second. 2nd doesnt grind
but, just will not go into gear.

When down shifting from 3rd to 2nd I again have problems getting  the tranny
into gear.  !st  is a grinder from 2nd and I am sure synchros would be
helpful. 

I am wondering if my problem might be shift fork adjustment or even clutch
adjustment.

Any help is appreciated.

Thanks in advance

Phil Salter

84 911 
86 944 Turbo
76 914 (deceased)


74 914
73 914

This poses a small problem for people from outside the US. For me it a _lot_
cheaper transferring the $ directly into the bank-account. That "only" costs
$20 - checks costs around $75 to have made out.

>     Back of check is pre-endorsed by donor, 
>     "for deposit only to"Porschephiles Acct No #####" 
>coordinator sends donor email with number of donors deposit (#1 through  n
>     donors)  Donor may be anonymous or public.  Public donors should send mail
>     to list with amount donated.

Why send mail to the list? Wouldn't the weekly funds report suggested below 
be enough? Otherwise we'll increase the number of mails on the list 
un-necessary.

>coordinator publishes weekly funds report. Weekly funds report is in 
>the following format:
>
>Donation number   Name (anon)  anount   deposit date total to date.
>1                 anon          50        2/15/95          50
>2                 jones         50        2/16/95         100

>up internet Porsche Dealership;

>   1.999973...

>made to Stan for his disposition, as he sees fit.  Allowable uses of the
>fund shall be *strictly* limited to those things Stan deems proper.  Such 
>uses shall include, but not be limited to, Computers, Software. Porsches,

>Porsche parts, Booze, broa...oooops, sorry Mary, make that, "and such other
>uses as Stan, in his infinite wisdom, may deem fit."
>

Hmmm... This part bothers me a small bit. If the only purpose it to ship
money to Stan I'd say it's a bit too commercial for my taste.

Besides I think newcomers will have a problem understanding why we are 
shipping money to the list-meister. Most mailing lists do not ship money
around.

I have another suggestion. It might be way off or completely insane, but I'm

always open to being told that :-). Why not make this the first Virtual
Porsche Club in the world?

We could pay a yearly fee, say $15 (or $20 or whatever), for being a member.
The money would of course be shipped to Stan for equipment related to the
club (no booze here, unless he needs a steady hand to set it up - only
kidding :-) ). The club could the have a president (Stan), a board, a cashier 
and whatever else is needed in a regular club.

Then some time down the road we could have virtual autox and track races when
evebody gets their VR-helmets in place <g>. Okay, okay my mind went crazy for
a moment, but you get the (crazy) idea.

Perhaps we can even get the OK from Porsche for being an official club :-)

>What say ye, ;Philes...?
>
>Cheers,
>
>Bart Chambers
>Frau, Dora
>(cars & Varmint)


Regards,

Christian

where people could say stupid things and flame one another all in good fun

hard feelings either way. It would be a way for the flamethrower artists
to practice their craft. Nobody picked up on it.

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 13:01:33 -0500
From: NannW@aol.com
Subject: Parade Registration

Just want to reinforce/clarify several of the messages over the past week
regarding registration, wait lists, etc.

My significant other was the Registrar for the 1991 Parade in Boston, as well
as for the 1994 Parade in Lake Placid.  I guess that qualifies him as an
"expert!"

The reality is that a Parade has not been sold out since the Downeast Parade
in 1986.  We were, in fact, #56 on the wait list after the initial
registration opening day.  We did, in fact, get into the Parade, and knew
this by the middle of May (Parade was held in July).

If you are interested in attending the Portland Parade this year, and have
not yet submitted a registration form, I encourage you to do so in the near
future.  You are not likely to be waitlisted, nor, at the very worst, shut
out of the opportunity to attend/participate.

The Cincinnati Parade also offered attendees the opportunity to combine their
Parade experience with a couple days of drivers education at the Mid-Ohio
track in nearby Lexington, Ohio.  This still did not cause the Parade to be
sold out.

Jon Lowe was correct that the Parade officials may, at some point, decide to
close out the Parade registration because at some point the paperwork and
recordkeeping must be finalized.

Bottom line....go for it!  It is a great experience, and an opportunity to
meet a bunch of fun peopole who also happen to own Porsches.

Nann Weissenberger
Goodie Store Chair - Boston '91 Parade AND Lake Placid '94 Parade
National Membership Committee member
Porsche Lover
Owner of four cats!

                       Subject:                               Time:2:04 PM
  OFFICE MEMO          Stalling 911 SC                        Date:2/12/95
I need some diagnostic help.
Two days ago I drove my '83 911 SC about 85 miles at an average speed of
70mph.   Temperature was in the high 20s.  As I braked getting off the
expressway and fell below 40mph the car stalled.  I stopped and the car
started right up, but then stalled again.  It started right up again and with
 a little help on the throttle I made it to a light a few 100 yards away
where the car stalled again.  Once again it started right up and I drove
perhaps a mile where I had to stop - car ran perfectly.  The car has
continued to operate perfectly.
What could the problem have been?  Is it serious?  Is it likely to happen
again, but worse?   Any help would be appreciated.

Date: 12 Feb 95 11:38:01 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: NOTE 02/12/95 11:32:00


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Date: 1995-02-12 13:13
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Scott Winders asks:

>I ordered a set of BFG R1 230 compound tires for the upcoming
>autocross season. However, I forgot to order them "shaved". I
>have read in my Team TA newsletter that the tires will last
>longer and work better if they are shaved. So, I have these
>questions:
>
>1. Should I have the tires shaved?
>2. If yes, to what tread depth?
>3. Who does this in the San Jose area that can be trusted to
>   do it right?
>
>On a slightly different subject, how do the BFG R1 users out
>there breakin your autocross tires?

For the sizes you are running (I think 225s fr. and 245s rear?) -- you might
be able to get away with what we did last season on the 226s (same carcass
 -- same general characteristics).  We ran full depth in the rear and shaved
the fronts to 4/32nds.  the fronts, if run at full depth, would scallop
badly and wear quicker than when shaved.  I don't know about who might shave
tires in San Jose, but Roger Krause Racing shaves tires (Hayward I think).
 For maximum life at minimal degradation in performance BFG recommends a
complete initial heat cycle which is bringing the tires up to temperature
without abusing them (will be difficult to do in winter), which for 230s is
in the 150 deg + range, then pulling them off the car (but not off the
wheels) and letting them "cure" for 24 - 48 hrs.  The tires are not properly
heat cycled by merely heating them (as in using an oven), but by "working"
them, albeit not aggressively.  Most of this info comes from Jim Fogerty who
is a BFG tire engineer -- "father" of the current R1 series -- he listens in
on the team.net list.  I may have his compuserve address at work if you want
more specific info...

 -Scott Jessen
ASP 911 -- at 90+% point of being "dialed" for the season opener in
Jacksonville....

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 14:11:55 -0600 (CST)

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 14:44:52 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Value of vin plates & 912E#1 totalled

> >... He said "If I wreck it, it's no big deal as long as I 
> >have the plate with the VIN number on it
> 
> Somehow I wonder if this could be 100% true. 

Pretty much so. You also need some other odd bits of metal, but I used to have
several 914-6s in my desk drawer - title, VIN plate, window tag with serial
number, and some of the other odd bits. 

More than one '70 914 1.7 became an "authentic" 914-6 that way.

Done right, even an expert can't tell the diff. Particularly if an
expert did the work in the first place. You can't fake things, you
must use the exact right parts. You have to do concours grade work.
You have to make sure a priori that you *KNOW* that the donor car
(i.e. the car the VIN came from) is destroyed and that you can effectively
despose of the "remains" of the target car (i.e. it's VIN number and
registration). It's also useful to know that the target car isnt' stolen,
but that's a legal issue... That's for "street cars".

In the superexotic market, where you're dealing with true one-off cars
or very, very limited production cars like 917s or *REAL* '73 RSRs
(what was that Excellence article about the RSR a few years ago --
"113 made, 5000 sold"??) things get tougher. You *CAN'T* just fabricate
a car from scratch and have it accepted. You *CAN* however, **REBUILD** a
car completely from scratch -- if you have the basic right pieces, you
can even get the factory to authorize re-issuance of the VIN tags. That
sort of thing used to happen in the Ferarri market all the time a few
years ago -- someone would come up with a slagged wreck with the correct
provenance to indicate that it was so-and-so's racer from the mid '50s and
had been damaged beyond repair in the '80s and gosh it would be a shame
to NOT bring it back from the dead... See also a fairly recent Excellence
where doing the same for a 904 was discussed.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 95 13:58:09 PST
From: ssu!scruffy!myers@nbn.nbn.com (Alan W. Myers)
Subject: 914 valve adjust

What's the best way to find TDC for each cylinder when the marks on the
impeller are worn off?  Hayne's is not very clear to me on this.  Assuming
you find TDC for #1, then Haynes says to rotate the distributor cam shaft
90 degrees.  How exact does this have to be?  It seems that "eyeballing"
the rotor is not very exact.

Any help on this would be much appreciated
TIA
alan
myers@abratech.com


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 15:53:31 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Proposal to the List Membership

Folks,

This is fairly long, please bear with me.  I've been thinking about this for 
a couple of days now, and I have come up with *exactly* the right idea. 
Please weigh this, evaluate it, and get back to me. 

The issue is this: how to keep Porschephiles on the air in perpetuity.

To date, I've done this from my own pocket. At first, it was just
a corner of a machine I had charge of at Baylor College of Medicine
and tacit approval to consume network resources. Then I re-hosted to
a semi-publicly available system there controlled by a group at the
University of Houston that I farmed certain consulting work out to. 

Then several years ago, it moved to tta.com, when my consulting group went 
on-line. Since then, the list has nudged it's way off the main hardware here 
to take up it's own complete system, and is eating a larger and larger 
fraction of our T1 to the Internet. With my day-to-day involvement in the 
consulting practice going to near zero last year while I was off doing 
NetSmiths, and with my new involvement in TeleCommute SolutionS and 
TCS-OMNInet taking me further away from TTA, it seems likely that we'll 
need to move again.

I have considered turning this into a profie center by taking offers I've
received (unsolicited) from a few smaller on-line service providers to
partner with them. While that solves one problem, it creates many more
and does not serve the list membership very well.

I would like Porschephiles to have a permanent home, a domain name
that's NOT tied to a company, newer faster hardware, and the ability
to support it's own direct Internet connection should that time ever
come when it *MUST* do so or die. I do not wish do to this in a way
that I personally profit from, except recovery of costs incurred 
going forward if possible. Once some of my other involvements are hitting
on all cylinders again, even that is not necessary except that if it's 
part of the plan, then it will NEVER be an issue again if I hit shortfalls.

The following observations have been made:

* "We are a Porsche Club Region in the Internet Era." (Pasha)

* "why not print up some "porschephiles@tta.com" window stickers" (Ryan)

* "Why not have a T-shirt too" (Marefat)

* "I also belong to the british-cars list (affectionately known
   as the Scions Of Lucas --SOL)  and the list has come up with
   an SOL logo on computer which various companies have printed
   on stickers, shirts, mugs, etc.  Might be a good idea to do
   a similar thing on this list, yes?" (Radsick)

* "Does anyone (Pete, Jim, Larry, Harry, anyone) with close ties to PCNA 
  think they could get corporate permission to use the crest, or have 
  interest in pursuing the issue with them?" (Chambers)

OK, anyone who's ever been closely involved in Region management enough to
have read the Manual should be able to see the synergy here:

- --> How about forming Porschephiles as a PCA Region??

This gives us several things:

1) right to charge dues and mechanism to collect them (via PCA)

2) additional revenue via PCA special distributions to Regions

3) affiliation with a 501(c)6 non-profit institution that umbrellas
   us if the right safeguards are taken

4) right to use the various bits of PCNA intellectual properties for
   purposes of promoting the Region and it's events (crest, etc)
   This includes goodie store items.

5) PCA members with other Home Regions can also affiliate with us, and
   those that wish may have this be their Home Region and affiliate with
   other local regions.

6) right to admit non-members to our "events" so non-members are
   not excluded in this change (I *WILL NOT* tolerate a solution that
   is exclusionary).

7) we can seek to register the "pca.org" domain, and issue a subdomain
   as the permanent address for Porschephiles. We can also provide 
   name registry services, and possibly other services, for other PCA
   regions and national board functions.

It imposes some other requirements:

* we need members, that means current PCA members. That also means that
  we can recruit NEW members.

* we have to pass through an approval process at PCA, which means we 
  may need "friends" including letters of committment, recommendation,
  etc.

* there needs to be a club managment structure which provides appropriate
  checks and balances. That means volunteers (even the kind that are
  pushed forward) for P, VP, Treas., Sec. Event Chair, NL Editor, etc.

* there may need to be conference calls for the management team from
  time to time to satisfy some other odd bits of law

* we need to figure out what sort of "events" an *ON-LINE* region can have.
  I can see how we'd do the newsletter 8{), but other things are harder?
  Do we autox by running locally and then applying some math function to
  "predict" the winner in "our" event?? Do we have concours by uploading
  GIF files?? Do we have tours by linking up in person?? You get the 
  picture...

Anyway, I'm throwing down the gauntlet on this:

Monday, I will call Ruth and request the Formation of a New Region Kit. 
I will register intent for form a new region, the Electronic Frontier Region.

If you are currently a PCA member, and wish to be a founding member
of the EFR, send me either via public post or private mail:

	your name and name of your affiliate member as it appears on the
	PCA membership card
	your current region affliation
	your current address (as far as PCA goes)
	your membership number

If the region is accepted, I'll put out the call for initial startup 
contributions and instructions on where to send those.   Let's move
smartly -- I'd like to have something done by the weekend...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 95 14:10:59 PST
From: ssu!scruffy!myers@nbn.nbn.com (Alan W. Myers)
Subject: S.F. Bay Area junk yard report

First of all, thanks to all those that sent suggestions of good junk yards!
E.A.S.Y. in particular was a good spot.  They are not big, and had only
3 914's when I dropped by, but they had what I wanted at a _very_ good
price.   The staff was both helpful and knowledgable, and let us climb
around in back to look around (always a wallet buster).  Definitely two
thumbs up!
Also I would like to mention that if you have the time, the standard junk 
yards, can have amazing deals!  The two that I went to in Hayward, 
Doris and Pick Your Part, did have porsches.  Doris in fact had a surprising
amount of European cars including audi's, bmw's, and others.  I also saw
several 924's there.  Pick Your Part, had only one 914 that I could see,
but it was still fairly complete as far as junk cars go.  The standard lots
are pretty much a crap shoot, but if you have the time to go looking, it 
sure saves the $$.

alan


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 95 18:03:00 PST
From: Shafer Kirk <ShaferK@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: 944 O2 sensor behavior (input at DME)


History - My problem is stumble under load and jumpy, dropout idle in cold 
ambient temps.

Tired of screwing with testing sensors and finding everything OK, and then 
wondering "what is the DME actually seeing".  So, laid open my DME on the 
passenger floor so I could monitor signals with voltmeter.  I know, 
electrostatic damage, sensitive DME electronics, dangerous voltages, big $$$ 
 - life's a risk.  Anyway, question I have is:

Does anyone know what kind of voltage behavior I should see at the DME O2 
sensor input?

I expected to see something hovering pretty tightly around 0.45 volts or so. 
 But instead I saw [with respect to DME input pin 1 GND] a slowly 
oscillating voltage ranging from about -12.5v to -13.5v.  Same pin pretty 
well stuck at -13.0v with O2 sensor disconnected at back of engine.  So I 
did see the characteristic 1v ranging like I thought O2 sensors generate, 
but such a negative level?  And why can't it seem to hold steady at stoich? 
 Is the DME hunting?  This slow 1 to 2 second oscillation was evident at 
idle, steady cruise, and under load from what I could tell from voltmeter 
glances between watching the road.  I'm an EE so I know at least a little 
about electronics but I don't know what is correct behavior on some of these 
inputs.

BTW, FWIW, looks like an INTEL 8705 (8-bitter?) is the micro.  Would kill 
for a schematic of this DME.  Also, trivia, you can actually drive this car 
(limp home) without an Air flow meter or an O2 sensor (learned accidentally 
 - left air flow meter disconnected).  DME must default to idle mixture map 
data - stalls out (lean?) if you go for any revs in this mode.

I'll post ONE summary of any responses if anyone can offer help direct. 
 Thank you to anyone's ideas.  I may not solve my problem but I'm sure as 
hell learning a ton about how my car works [or doesn't work].

Oh, one other question:  How is crankcase ventilated to intake tract?  Saw 
one hose from air filter case to cam belt cover.  Is that it?  Trying to 
explain air leak I saw at oil filler base when I pressurized the intake 
tract at the air flow meter.  Air leaked past rings?

Kirk
'88 944

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 18:58:12 -0500
From: JMICHAELGR@aol.com
Subject: Dumb Questions

The list is great; thanks for the time and energy you spend making it all
possible.

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 19:56:04 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Re;noise in rear of 944 engine

Based on your diagnosis of the noise in the rear of your 944 engine are you
sure that you are not hearing the echo of gear rattle from the transmission
or possibly some noise from the throw out bearing, why not try to declutch at
the speeds this happens and see if the noise disappears.  I have never heard
of any bearing problems with the balance shafts, leaks in the front, sure,
but never bearing noise esp. at such a low mileage of 95K

                         Steve

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 19:16:45 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 motor mods

> What upgrades/mods can be done to a 2.0 with FI
> and/or Webers,

Lots. 

If you just tweak things a little, you can get another 10-15 HP.
You can make up to 150 HP on factory EFI, you can get to over 220 HP for
about 10 hours of engine operation if you push it. 

How much do you want to spend??

> Do we go straght for the heads, or split the case??
> any comments welcome

Any meaningful mod you make to get more power will require doing both. 
Most will leave you with the case as the only stock part.

Answer Question Number One above, and let's go from there.

Stan

Porschephiles #1159                         Mon Feb 13 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 22:13:37 -0500
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: T*d Nostalgia

P-friends,

I have been watching T*d's rise and demise on Porschephiles, and the
occosional resurrection of his deeds.

The fact is (Note:this is my *OPINION* only, so no flames) that he displays
many traits of a sociopath. These people frequently are treated as the
"village idiot", or regarded as bizarre or eccentric. They tend to be single
minded, and believe in their visions. Whether right or wrong, nobody can
change their viewpoints. They believe to be the source of a certain
knowledge, and can not understand  that people don't see the light. This may
sound harmless, but can lead to disaster as history has shown repetitively
(Nazi Sheep ???). Let's apply this to T*d:
 -He is transfixed on suspension setup. The general consensus is that he
doesn't have a clue. Yet, again all common wisdom, he persists. He even
participates in autox to prove his points. When that tends to be disastruous,
he still is convinced of his right thinking, and quotes many reasons for his
demise. These do not include "mistakes" in his suspension setup.
 -Certain topics/issues/incidents act like triggers and result in a sudden
change in communications/actions. Remember the allusion to a "darkened out
car with wheels sticking out the wells....". This innocent (to most of the
participants) joke results in a flame war with racist undertone.
 -Unbeaten, T*d proceeds to find an alternative route for his teachings and
self proclaimed expertise. Born is the 911 list. Unbelievably, he manages to
obtain the PORSCHE.ORG domain (are you listening PCNA ???).
 -The innocent "village idiot" becomes an Internet guerilla when access to
porschephiles is denied. And that's where danger lurks. When someone gets in
the way of their goals, it's a justified and holy war. Breakins, mail bombing
etc... Fortunately, this has been limited to the virtual reality of the
Internet.
 -The unsolicited inclusion on the 911 list has to be seen in the same light.
It is not harassement, but an attempt to show you the truth, uncensored by Evi
l Stan. 

What I am trying to say is that T*d did indeed add color to Porschephiles
initially. Intuitively, Stan saw probably a different picture after a while,
something that triggered his decision to terminate. I believe it to be the
right move as T*d's subsequent actions have proven. Ultimately, it's a sad,
sad story: what was hilarious as a perceived fictitous character, is sad as a
real human being.

And to conclude, the 911 list is almost an exclusive monolog. The 7x16 Golden
BBS RA wheel with the "slight dent" is still for sale @ $70.00 (with the
comment that Porsche Racing uses BBS wheels). If you have a 26mm rear torsion
bar (from 930) for a '77 911S, you may have a buyer. Ditto for a 22mm rear
sway bar. No plans for a front sway bar yet.

Hope I didn't bore or offend, as this was NEVER the intent....

Bart D (no relation to Bart C  :-)  )

Date: 12 Feb 95 22:22:56 EST

Subject: 924/944/968 Owners Survey For FAQ

ATTENTION: 924/944/968 OWNERS
THIS IS THE LAST TIME I AM GOING TO POST THIS TO THE LIST!
RESPONSE HAS BEEN GREAT SO FAR, BUT A FEW MORE COULDN'T HURT.
THANKS AGAIN, FOR ALL WHO HAVE REPLIED!!

******************************************************************************

This is the second version of the 944 FAQ Survey Form. I have made a few
corrections (added current mileage, color, corrected spelling etc.) List 
members that have already completed this survey need not do so again. If you 
would like to send me your current mileage that would be great, but it is not 
nessessary

******************************************************************************


Hello All,

I am trying to prepare a owners report survey for the new 924/944/968 FAQ.
The purpose of the survey is to collect maintenance and repair records for the
924/944/968 series. I am including a form to make data input easier for you.

I am not sure what the final format will, but I will get a better idea when I
recieve your input. A comments section will appear at the end of the form for
any additional information you can provide. When completed, it make for some
interested reading, for those who may have a common problem, or would just
like to hear other owners comments and problems, without having to search all
the past archives.

  The more info I recieve the more accurate the survey. Please try to
help if you can. This would be a great addition to the FAQ!

Once I have the compilied the past section of the owners survey, I will
update the the owners report from time to time. This will then be posted
to the FAQ .(also to the list so all can see the results)

The completed form can be sent to me directly for review. DO NOT SEND TO
ENTIRE LIST!!

Mike Kehr  INTERNET:71324.3010@compuserve.com

I was thinking that a mileage format would be a good idea ( repairs and 
maintance list by mileage, and a topic, format ie. Waterpumps, motor mounts, 
clutches etc. Any comments, let me know.


TIA

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 23:03:46 -0500 (EST)
From: roberto rabe <rrabe@gwis2.circ.gwu.edu>
Subject: Senders and Gauges on 924S

Porschephiles,

	My fuel and oil gauges on my 1987 924S are failing me.  The fuel gauge 
reports the wrong level of fuel while the oil pressure gauge moves directly to 
bar 5 once the key is in the 'accessory on' position and when the engine 
is running.  I would like to kindly ask anyone out there who has had 
these problems and how to fix them...

Mainly:
1.  Where is the fuel level sender and how do you get to it and 
repair/replace it?
2.  Which would most likely need repairs or replacement - the oil 
pressure gauge or the sender?  And how would I get to either 
the gauge or the sender and repair/replace them?...

Any information, instructions, warnings, or letters of heartfelt pain 
would be greatly appreciated...

Thanks in advance...

Roberto Rabe

P.S.  I'm all up for the Porschephiles chartering...

I'm pretty new to Porschephiles, but so far am quite impressed with 
everything, and will probably be more noisy in the spring, when 
Katarina (my 914) goes on the road.

Regarding the formation of another PCA region... I've been sorta 
meaning to join the local chapter, but have never quite gotten 
around to it. I was planning on joining up either before or soon 
after the car goes back on the road... But I'd certainly be interested 
in joining an online chapter. What are the logistics of belonging to 
two different regions? I would assume this means two sets of dues, 
et al... Not being a member, I dunno how much, but being on a 
limited budget, I'd have a hard time choosing which to join. I'd 
almost certainly find more information online here, however there 
would be a couple other benefits to the local region (I think they 
head down to Watkins Glen every now and then...)

As for meetings, well, I dunno if anyone else is in the Northeast, 
but I'm at Watkins Glen for the IMSA and the Vintage Races... 
Anyone else?

From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: Stan's 914

P-friends,

As Stan has announced, I bought THE 914. After assuring that Stan really
wanted to sell the car, I did not hesitate. I believed that it would be in
better hands with a porschephile member.
It was an exciting weekend. My new baby arrived, hand delivered by the
Listmeister himself. I kept going over the intricacies of Stan's setup.
As officially a Porschephile car as it gets. Signed by the Listmeister, even
with a TTA license plate !
The porschephile 914 got a good home. Since I've never raced, the future of
the car looks quiet for now. Stan can be assured that the car will not be
butchered and probably will be the subject of many of my P-file questions.

As to the subject of T-shirts, stickers, coffee mugs, I'm all for. How about
windshield screen? May I propose a simple design ? How about  just
"porschephile@tta.com" spelled out in black on white, using a terminal (type
writer) style font ?  I there anyone on the list with experience in these
things ? I am volunteering to help/coordinate/distribute.

Bart D

You have a primary region usually the one in you town or close by. If 
you find that you do not want to be in that region you can request thru 
national to change your region. If you want to be with two region then 
the second region is a "dual" membership. you will be able to do 
everything but vote.

as well
>as for the 1994 Parade in Lake Placid.  I guess that qualifies him as 
an
>"expert!"
>
>The reality is that a Parade has not been sold out since the Downeast 
Parade
>in 1986.  We were, in fact, #56 on the wait list after the initial
>registration opening day.  We did, in fact, get into the Parade, and 
knew
>this by the middle of May (Parade was held in July).
>
>If you are interested in attending the Portland Parade this year, and 
have
>not yet submitted a registration form, I encourage you to do so in the 
near
>future.  You are not likely to be waitlisted, nor, at the very worst, 
shut
>out of the opportunity to attend/participate.
>
>The Cincinnati Parade also offered attendees the opportunity to combine 
their
>Parade experience with a couple days of drivers education at the 
Mid-Ohio
>track in nearby Lexington, Ohio.  This still did not cause the Parade 
to be
>sold out.
>
>Jon Lowe was correct that the Parade officials may, at some point, 
decide to
>close out the Parade registration because at some point the paperwork 
and
>recordkeeping must be finalized.
>
>Bottom line....go for it!  It is a great experience, and an opportunity 
to
>meet a bunch of fun peopole who also happen to own Porsches.
>
>Nann Weissenberger
>Goodie Store Chair - Boston '91 Parade AND Lake Placid '94 Parade
>National Membership Committee member
>Porsche Lover
>Owner of four cats!
> 
>
>

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 21:17:36 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Dues etc.

In response to Jeff Kyle's question, my guess is that this is
something that would be worked out with PCA National upon formation of
the cyber-region.  This is a matter that should probably be part of
Stan's proposal.  They'll probably want to know this:  i.e., would
membership in a land-based region be a prerequisite?  Normally, dual
memberships are handled by the regions themselves on an informal
basis.  This would be a special situation, and there would be a number
of ways to go on it.  Part of the regular dues involves a subscription
to _Pano_, and the assumption is that most people don't need two of
these.

Steve Gilbert
SJR; dual in SVR
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 00:17:36 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Dues etc.

> This is a matter that should probably be part of
> Stan's proposal.  They'll probably want to know this:  i.e., would
> membership in a land-based region be a prerequisite?  

Oh, I expect *LOTS* of issues to come up... I wound up sitting and chatting
with Bert and Judy about this at Parade in July.

I expect some people will want their primary affiliation to be the
new region. Some of these will want secondary affiliations to their
"normal" local region.  There was a note I saw somewhere in O'Reilly-land
on the 'Web "If you LIVE On-Line, SHOP On-Line"; same has got to apply
to the way at least some people will think about PCA.

I expect a lot of people will want a secondary affiliation to the
new region. Some will want to maintain local affiliation for political
reasons, some because it's more comfortable or is required for some
event-oriented thing. Some will just want to support the list.

I expect that that's the least of the worries that PCA National may
have about this in some respects. Think about the *STAGGERING* cultural 
change this represents. Think about how "left in the dust" this may make 
some of the Old Guard feel. Thing about all the excuses you could
use to kill it if you just didn't want to do it...

When I said we needed friends, I wasn't kidding. Start the press NOW.
I'll have the kit from Ruth as soon as she can send it after I call her
about 9:00 AM my time. Probably mid-week. I'll turn around the paper
work same day, and the process starts. I looked *REAL* hard at what
it takes to start a new region a few years ago (some LSR members may
or may not recall the big flap over elections) and expect this to be
complex, messy, and to take time.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 00:38:14 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: 914 2.0 FI retrofit

> Problem is, I still like the car. If I have to spend $1000 (wild guess) on a
> used FI setup, the car might still be worthwhile.

Plan on more like $500 or so for the basics, then whatever it takes to make
it run. Maybe $100 in hose. Maybe $140 in new injectors. Maybe $150 in 
new fuel pump (HINT: buy new injectors, fuel pump, sensors, and contacts.
It makes getting all this running MUUUUCH easier.)

> But here's my question. The car has a "hotter" cam and somewhat larger
> pistons. (Don't know specifics yet.) One mechanic says it will still run OK
> with stock FI, but the idle may be a little rough. Another expert (one I'm
> more likely to trust) says it will never run acceptably with the stock FI
> and a hotter cam.

Depends. On the cam, mainly. And what you find "acceptible". There are
two cams that work *FINE* on street EFI cars -- one from SCAT, one
from FAT. There are two more cams that work so-so for street cars,
one from WEB-CAM and one from FAT. There are several that just don't work
right at all on street cars with EFI. Just about everyone makes one 
of those...

Things get even more complicated if you have (God forbid) air conditioning.
Then you not only have to run right idle, you also have to run right
at idle with the A/C compressor engaged. There are very, very few cams
that do that...

There are some idle fixing tricks you can use -- drill out the hole in the
butterfly plate to flow more air, etc. But if you have too much cam, 
you just have too much cam...

Unfortunately, there's no way to tell without splitting the case, or just
trying it, unless you happen to have the cam maker and part number.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 23:14:04 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Dues etc.

What Stan said is pretty much what I would envision.  I had started a
postscript in a subsequent post, but my connection got put on hold and
then I got busy with something else.

What would be important as far as PCA goes would be for all list
participants to be PCA members.  Granting regionhood to the list would
enable new members who first become acquainted with PCA via the net to
join that way.  Dual membership in regions now is tantamount to a
newsletter subscription, so list membership would constitute a
perfectly analogous situation.

From my experience as a newsletter editor and region president, I have
noted fees for dual memberships ranging from $12 to $20.  Regions with
better newsletter can command higher fees.  I would expect an on-line
service to be at the high end of the dual membership scale, and
rightly so.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Sun, 12 Feb 1995 18:26:07 -0500 (EST)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: Million $ Cars!!

On Sat, 11 Feb 1995 Sean wrote:

>  ready for this?  The last car over in the corner was a PORSCHE 904!!!!!!!!!!!!
> I lost it.  I was sitting (I had to sit to get down to its level!) with #12 of
> 12 Porsche 904's in the world.  It was beautiful and very orange.  Quite and ex

Not exactly. This is #12 of the 12 904/6's (chassis number 906012) This 
is the same car featured in both Automobile Quarterly and Pano back 
around 1970 or '71 when its then owner Vern Kovert installed the "T" top. 
He proceeded to use it as a daily driver, accumulating, I've been told, 
over 175,000 miles on the car.

As far as value, well... last I heard, the owner was interested in 
offers. I know he would take a lot less than $1 million <g>. 

And yes, I must admit to having driven this car, although I was very 
nervous at the time - the owner was in the passenger seat and I knew it 
was worth more, in fact a lot more, than my house.

Larry Bershtein

Hi,

Instead of the back seats, there is a carpeted plywood shelf about 8 inches 
above the lowest point of where would be the back seats (the lowest point 
being the 'butt point').  Under the shelf are 2 doors facing forward which 
are useful for storage and are about the size of 2 large glove compartments. 
I put owners manuals, camera in one.  The other one has a subwoofer. 

BTW, are you interested in swapping all the stuff with the shelf for all the 
stuff with the seats?  My upholstery is black cloth.

pete

the front seats backing up to a rear panel? I would like to replace the back 
seats in my 86 911 with an area for tool storage. I keep the rear seats 
folded down all the time anyway.

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 07:45:35 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Senders and Gauges on 924S

> Porschephiles,
> 
> 	My fuel and oil gauges on my 1987 924S are failing me.  The fuel gauge 
> reports the wrong level of fuel while the oil pressure gauge moves directly t
> bar 5 once the key is in the 'accessory on' position and when the engine 
> is running.  I would like to kindly ask anyone out there who has had 
> these problems and how to fix them...

90% chance that both of these problems are related to the senders and not
the gauges themselves.  Both have fairly high rates of failure.

> 
> Mainly:
> 1.  Where is the fuel level sender and how do you get to it and 
> repair/replace it?

Fuel level sender is under the luggage compartment carpet, under a woven
fiberglass cloth square, and under a plastic seal (top to bottom, in that
order.)  It is held in place by 5 or 6 allen head bolts (i'm too lazy to go
downstairs to look).  Do not loosen the bolts unless you have less than half
a tank of gas, or you will leak gas all over the place (FIRE HAZARD)...

Once the bolts (and electrical connections) are loosened, you can raise the
sender slowly, while the fuel contained in the sender drains out.  While
repairs can be made, new ones are available from the dealer or used ones are
available from me (blatant plug intended)...

> 2.  Which would most likely need repairs or replacement - the oil 
> pressure gauge or the sender?  And how would I get to either 
> the gauge or the sender and repair/replace them?...

As I said above, most likely the sender, which is located at the passenger
front of the motor, below the oil filter.  For this one, I recommend a new
sender. I have gone through 3 of them in 85 K miles. I would not recommend a
used oil gauge sender, (since I don't have any good ones...) <g>

> 
> Any information, instructions, warnings, or letters of heartfelt pain 
> would be greatly appreciated...

You got 'em.

- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 08:03:54 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 O2 sensor behavior (input at DME)

> 
> History - My problem is stumble under load and jumpy, dropout idle in cold 
> ambient temps.

Sounds like a worn-out O2 sensor. My experience is that you get about 50 to
60K miles out of a Bosch sensor, then have to throw it away.

> 
> Tired of screwing with testing sensors and finding everything OK, and then 
> wondering "what is the DME actually seeing".  So, laid open my DME on the 
> passenger floor so I could monitor signals with voltmeter.  I know, 
> electrostatic damage, sensitive DME electronics, dangerous voltages, big $$$ 

>  - life's a risk.  Anyway, question I have is:
> 
> Does anyone know what kind of voltage behavior I should see at the DME O2 
> sensor input?

According to the Probst book (Bosch Fuel Injection and Engine Management)
the sensor voltage of a new sensor should cycle between 0.2 to 0.8 Vdc.
He also shows a graph of how an aged sensor gets lazy and doesn't output the
proper voltage at the appropriate air/fuel ratios.

For a good sensor, the lambda point is about 500 mVdc, measured at the
sensor connection.

> 
> I expected to see something hovering pretty tightly around 0.45 volts or so. 

>  But instead I saw [with respect to DME input pin 1 GND] a slowly 
> oscillating voltage ranging from about -12.5v to -13.5v.  Same pin pretty 
> well stuck at -13.0v with O2 sensor disconnected at back of engine.  So I 
> did see the characteristic 1v ranging like I thought O2 sensors generate, 
> but such a negative level?  And why can't it seem to hold steady at stoich? 
>  Is the DME hunting?  This slow 1 to 2 second oscillation was evident at 
> idle, steady cruise, and under load from what I could tell from voltmeter 
> glances between watching the road.  I'm an EE so I know at least a little 
> about electronics but I don't know what is correct behavior on some of these 

> inputs.
> 
> BTW, FWIW, looks like an INTEL 8705 (8-bitter?) is the micro.  Would kill 
> for a schematic of this DME.  Also, trivia, you can actually drive this car 

Call Autothority for a schematic of the DME...That is, if they'll let that
proprietary info out of their offices... <g>

> (limp home) without an Air flow meter or an O2 sensor (learned accidentally 
>  - left air flow meter disconnected).  DME must default to idle mixture map 
> data - stalls out (lean?) if you go for any revs in this mode.
> 
> I'll post ONE summary of any responses if anyone can offer help direct. 
>  Thank you to anyone's ideas.  I may not solve my problem but I'm sure as 
> hell learning a ton about how my car works [or doesn't work].
> 
> Oh, one other question:  How is crankcase ventilated to intake tract?  Saw 
> one hose from air filter case to cam belt cover.  Is that it?  Trying to 
> explain air leak I saw at oil filler base when I pressurized the intake 
> tract at the air flow meter.  Air leaked past rings?
> 

At the base of the rubber boot between the airflow sensor and the throttle
valve is a connection to a 3/4 inch (metric equivalent...) hose which
eventually connects to the top of the breather next to the oil filler tube.
Your problem with the oil has to do with the Orings at the bottom of this
assembly.


You're supposed to pressurize the intake tract at the throttle body, or the
intake manifold, not the airflow sensor.  All you did was pressurize the
crankcase through this hose.

If you want to measure for bad rings, use a leakdown tester at the sparkplug
hole.
- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 08:30:54 -0500 (EST)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Webers and backfiring

Okay, this is my first post here, so I'm not exactly sure if I'm doing 
this right (but don't everyone mail me "Yup, you are" as I already get 
200 pieces of mail a day)

Problem is... I've got Weber carbs in a '73 911 T (all well and fine, 
everyting seems to be okay with it, it runs well once it gets on its way) 
Now, after it sits for maybe three days or so, it will backfire about 400 
revs into the day, I forget the numbering sequence, but I believe it is:

	O   o
	X   o
	O   o (Oil filter, filler etc. on this side)
	FRONT OF CAR UP

(And it always happens, and it is always EXTREMELY LOUD (not just your 
average joe backfire, but like a cannon)

Now, the other thing, although I haven't again figured out which one, is: 
the same side, very likely same cylinder every 20-30 seconds or so (at 
idle) makes a short pss type noise.... kinda like boom boom boom boom pss 
boom... no longer than one piston cycle, but always the same one, and 
exact timing too.

Any ideas? I think it may be the timing. 
 -Derek Cahill

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 08:31:52 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Same dumb questions....

> I heartily agree and have the same dumb questions.  I spent an hour clearing
> and reading selectively the Porsche philes messages yesterday and this
> morning there are fifty more in my mailbox.  

There is, simply put, no easy way to do this. "How high is up??" The volume
on this list is what it is, and that's that. Want a low volume list, 
try "yugo-philes"... 8{)

There are a few options that help:

1) faster modems
2) better mail software. Since you're coming in via AOL, contact their
   tech support and see if they have something better suited to the task.
   Ideally, you want to be able to download the From/Subject pairs and
   select which messages you want to download. 
3) if AOL can't help, change to a local Internet Services Provider and
   use better mail software. I use ELM, and manage to read just over 350
   messages a day -- about half of which are work, the others from various
   non-work lists I monitor.
4) there's always Evelyn Woods...

> can't find a way to mass delete them or to just receive the digest (which I
> believe I requested), I will have to bid a sad farewell to this lively bb.

If you'd really requested to be the digest (either in your initial note
or in a followup to "porschephiles-request@tta.com") you'd be getting it.
You'll get it starting in about half an hour.

Stan Hanks
ListMeister

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 09:50:10 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 status


Dear Jerry,

1.  The Boxter is water cooled! The front end has been lengthened since the
Detroit auto show and the round front nose air scoops have been eliminated.

2.  All 914 impellor fans are the same when new, then marked for 1.7, 2.0
with a white or 0 notch for TDC and a red mark for 27 degrees BTDC. 1.8
models are marked with a red notch for 7 degrees BTDC only.

3.  Vacuum hose kits with proper vacuum cartoon and precut are available
here. They are available as follows:
    1. 70 - 73 1.7
    2. 74 - 75 1.8
    3. 73 - 74 2.0
    4. 75 - 76 2.0

4. 73 - 74 2.0 injectors are the best for overall performance on a 2.0 engine
as 75 - 76 injectors run leaner. We always install 73 - 74 2.0 injectors in
all 73 - 76 914 2.0 (of course as a set).

5. If you do not have the 914 World Headquarters catalog, send us your
address and we will send you one!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 09:45:47 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 lube points? (long - sorry)


Dear Nathan,

I. 914 mechanical lube points front to rear are as follows:

   1. Inner and outer front wheel bearings:  repack with axle grease.
   2. Tie rod ends inner and outer:  rueglide or silicone grease.
   3. Upper strut bushings:  rueglide or silicone grease.
   4. Front and rear torsion bar bushings:  rueglide or silicone grease.
   5. Rear suspension bushings inner and outer:  Rueglide or silicone grease.
   6. CV joints (4): repack with moly grease
   7. Front engine mounts, rear transmission mounts:  rueglide or silcone
grease
   8. Engine:  40W oil summer; 20W50 winter (oil bath air cleaner filled to
red line)
   9. Transaxle:  Quaker state special 80/90 weight VW Porsch transaxle
lubricant.

II. Porsche rips us with a $51.00 914 owners manual when all of the current
ones are only about $25.00. We, with permission, duplicated the no longer
available 72 owners manuals, but a good copying job costs us $35.00 each. If
you can read German, we have a factory new 71 manual for only $25.00.

III. Since you already have stainless steel exchangers, they should easily
unbolt from the head. Just make sure you lubricate the nuts over night before
unbolting and replace them with the copper locking variety.

     The stainless exchangers have a much narrower wall than the factory
steel ones, so they are harder to seal. Make sure you dress both pipe tops
together with a large flat file, replace the copper sealing rings with new
ones, making sure the old ones are removed (Some people have double stacked
them like idiots hoping for extra seal) and finally, mount each heat
exchanger individually torqueing the nuts in an "X" pattern until snug (about
18 ft. lbs.). If you happen to break or strip a stud, replacements are
available in 8, 9 and 10mm size or oversize and the head is easily tapped
(carefully!).

    As an addendum, always make sure the muffler bracket is firmly installed.
It takes the muffler/heat exchanger weight off the head studs, saving them
from exhaust leaks.

IV. Pedrinnin alloys, originally painted by the manufacturer are easily
refinished with a high quality silver wheel paint (like Wurth) with all of
the wheel straightening companies now in the U.S. and the rarity and value of
Pedrinnis (they are not available new). Don't ever take a hammer to your
wheel or you will encur the wrath of Dr. 914!

    Valve clearance is most easily checked with a 10 inch feeler gauge. This
provides ready access for the hard to access adjusters!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 09:51:01 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: 914 storage


from letter to Benjamin Beasley:

914 storage is easily accomplished in a heated dehumidified garage. The
following steps should be followed:

1. Steam clean complete underneath of car and thoroughly dry.
2, Add the right amount of gas stabilizer (such as POR-15) into the tank and
completely fill with gasoline, operate engine until solution has had time to
work through to the injectors. Top tank to the brim.
3. Remove the spark plugs, squirt oil in the cylinders and turn the engine
over to coat the cylinders. Reinstall plugs loosely.
4. Change engine oil and refill adding an extra quart.
5. Thoroughly bleed the brake system with fresh fluid.
6. Relieve the pressure on the windshield washer bottle.
7. Remove the battery and eacid the area with battery cleaner or baking soda
and water.
8. Lubricate all rubber seals with silicone and thoroughly carnuba wax the
car. Install flannel-lined car cover.
9. Elevate car and rest on padded jackstands under floor pan triangles.
10. Inflate tires to 50 lbs.
11. Lay an oil dry mat under the power plant to catch any drips.

George Hussey

You get one humungous message (hell, maybe two, I dunno) that is the composite
of all the individual messages sent during the 24 hr period.  

You may have to save it as text, and read it with a Word-processor if it exceeds
the limit imposed by your system (my system freaks at messages > 32K)  No sweat.

Just save as text, then delete mail msg, open and read the saved text at your 
leasure.

Please don't go. we'd miss you!

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 10:10:16 -0500
From: Mike.Worland@DANA.COM
Subject: RE:Webers and Backfiring



You wrote...

>Problem is... I've got Weber carbs in a '73 911 T (all well and fine,
>everyting seems to be okay with it, it runs well once it gets on its way)
>Now, after it sits for maybe three days or so, it will backfire about 400
>revs into the day, I forget the numbering sequence, but I believe it is:
>
>    O   o
>    X   o
>    O   o (Oil filter, filler etc. on this side)
>    FRONT OF CAR UP
>
>(And it always happens, and it is always EXTREMELY LOUD (not just your
>average joe backfire, but like a cannon)

>Now, the other thing, although I haven't again figured out which one, is:
>the same side, very likely same cylinder every 20-30 seconds or so (at
>idle) makes a short pss type noise.... kinda like boom boom boom boom pss
>boom... no longer than one piston cycle, but always the same one, and
>exact timing too.


Derek,

Ok, here goes...
It could be a lot of things that cause the problem you described. Basically
it could be poor valve seats (not the most likley) or bad timing, unbalanced
carbs,idle mixture settings,debris in the bowl (which will block a
passage),possibly an ignition problem,carb linkage not synchronized,+++
others.

My point is this may not be a cut and dry problem. I am not trying to make
this seem like an impossible task, but it may get frustrating (especially if
you shy around carbs).
My suggestion here is to start with the simple stuff and move on from there.
A couple of questions: Did an event happen that caused these symptoms? How
many miles are on the car ? How many miles since valve lash adjust?

Things to start with: Check the plugs (are they fouled?)
I have found the most common reason for this is a bad plug. I know you said
that the motor runs good once you get going, but the idle on these setups is
fairly rich and will cause a plug to foul if it isn't up to par.

I'll be glad to give you ideas and help where I can.

Mike.Worland@dana.com
All standard disclaimers apply

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 10:31:36 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: batteries and corrosion

George Hussey gave some really good advice on 914 storage that could
also be used for any Porsche. But I would like to suggest a slight
modification to tip # 7.

"7. Remove the battery and eacid the area with battery cleaner or
baking soda and water."

By all means remove the battery. I would not advise people to use
baking soda to to deal with battery acid. While baking soda will
neuteralize the acid it will produce salts (not NaCl) but sulfates.
These salts could catalyze corrosion. I would suggest the best way to
deal with battery acid is to dilute it with tap water. First vaccume up
any white powder (lead sulfates). Use very damp old or inexpensive
sponge. This process basically involves many rinses/dry cycles.  This
process will dilute the acid residue and dissolve and dilute residual
amounts of salts as well. Do the wiring harness battery connections as
well. Throw the sponge/rags you use away. Make sure the entire area is
very dry. If you use baking soda you should do a multiple rinse cycle
anyway to remove the salts, so why not just dilute the acid away
without prodcuing salts? Also if the acid has reacted with the metal it
will produce iron sulfates which also should be rinsed away as well.

I follow this up with a liberal spraying of the entire battery area
with WD-40.  For longer storage a heavier lubricant or even an
anti-rust jelly could be used. The purpose of these  is to seal the
metal from oxygen and moisture.

I don't know what battery cleaner is... so perhaps its use avoids the
production of salts. If there is an acid spill, remeber the addition of
a base will generate heat so again the use of baking soda is
problematic. Companies that sell lab safety supplies make a product
that absorbs the acid to avoid this very problem... but I digress.

If you'r messing with the battery at all it would be a good idea to wear
safety glasses/goggles and wear gloves.


**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021  1971 911e coupe

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

**********************************************************************

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 08:48:40 -0800
From: gblanche@qntm.com
Subject: 911 Test Drives...

This weekend I got a chance to test drive a couple more 911s.  Let the 
buyer beware if you are car shopping in the S.F.Bay area, or maybe CA in 
general.  I drove one car that was under water during the recent 
flooding, but surprisingly the dealer forgot to mention it!  The 
giveaway was the fact that one section of rear carpet was missing and 
the exposed pan had "algae" looking green crud growing on it.  I noticed 
missing carpet pieces on a couple other cars, and when I confronted the 
dealer, he admitted that his entire lot had been underwater....I can 
only guess how much "hidden" damage the car(s) had.  NO SALE!

On a better note, I drove an '88 Coupe that seemed nice.  (Different 
dealer)  It had those sport seats I like.  The interior was OK.  Some 
knobs were missing, and there was  white overspray on the trim pieces 
between the seats and on the door sills from when they re-colored the 
seats.  The pockets on the door panels were broken and pulled loose when 
you try to open the storage flap thingie.  (I've seen this on almost 
every 911 I've checked.  Is this a bad design?)  Exterior was a metallic 
blue with typical wax residue in all the cracks, various paint chips and 
scratches and a pretty big chunk of the front spoiler was missing, 
probably due to someone "surfing" it over a curb.  Dealer wants $28,000 
for it, I want a MUCH better car for that kind of money.  This weekend I 
drove 2 cars, the '88 coupe just described, and an '87 Cabriolet 
"Amphibio-mobile"

(Blaspehmous comments follow)

Let me say first that I love the 911 and I have since my High School 
days.  I'm thrilled to finally be shopping for one, but the test drives 
did not give me the rush I was expecting.  The car rides really well.  
It feels SOLID over bumps and irregularities, and the quality of 
construction is obvious...no complaints there.  The mechanics and 
dealers have told me: "It pulls hard up to 4000, and from 4000 on up it 
will scare you!"  I felt a solid shove in the back, but not the sense of 
immediacy I had imagined would be there.  The revs just didn't climb 
very fast.  Each gear felt equally capable of adding velocity, and the 
engine felt flexible just not as sweet as I had imagined.  I tried to 
blame my lack of expertise with 911s for the poor performance...but my 
test simply involved flooring the pedal in second gear...no real skill 
required.

(End of blasphemy)

I'm not going to let these first few experiences deter me.  I'm going to 
keep driving and familiarizing myself with the car, and hopefully will 
find some explanation for why I felt this way.  Maybe I got a bad car. 
Maybe I need a turbo to feel what I'm expecting, maybe I need a lighter 
early 70's version...who knows?  (Gosh, if only T*d was here... <extreme 
sarcasm alert>) 

I'd be interested to hear any comments on this "emotionally disturbing" 
topic.  BTW if you're curious which dealership was selling the Aqua-Cars 
E-Mail me directly...


Thanks for putting up with this,


Greg Blanchette
gblanche@qntm.com

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 12:48:32 PST
From: Robert M Zampardi <us000812@interramp.com>
Subject: Restoring/Painting? **Read Me


Recently I had my 76 914 blasted with a low agression blaster,
This shop Elaborate Enterprises 203-355-5225 in CT (Mike or Bill)
blasted my 914 inside/outside and upside down with a plastic media
that did not damage the underlying metal, but did remove ALL paint/bondo/
dirt etc, it is really cool to see a 914 in naked metal, I fought a 
temptation to clear coat it!!  After blasting we painted the car with 
por-15 and the proper base/color coats and added a clear.
The point is that these cars are getting old and it is really difficult to
do a repaint well without removing the old finish.  this procedure was
pretty reasonable at $650 for blasting, compared to chemical or acid
dipping.  just thought i'd pass along the experience.
comments??
rz

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 09:08:28 PST
From: pat@cor.cerfnet.com (Pat Hohl [5607])
Subject: what do w/ 944 valve/hyd lifter click?

Dear P-philes;

Let's discuss yet another 944'ism.

I have an '84. 70k miles and running great.

When I drive parallel to a solid wall (like brick)
(i.e. a wall that reflects high % of sound)  I hear a
valve sounding clicking.  If I just heard the noise
without knowing the car had hyd lifters, I would 
instantly say,  "OH - I know that sound, you need to 
adjust the valves".  

With the hood up and head inside, I hear the noise but
I doesn't seem THAT bad.  

1) Is this "common".
2) Is there anything to do about it?

The FORD dealer told me how to adjust the hyd lifters of
my ford bronco II w/ V6, and that quieted it down
quite a bit.  Is there a siimilar procedure for
P water pumper?

 -pat
'84 944

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 12:58:22 -0500 (EST)
From: "Kenneth D. Grimm" <GRIMM@alison.sbc.edu>

Date: 13 Feb 95 13:39:47 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 911 T to RS replica

 
Hi, Andre.
 
I don't know much about RSs except the sordid details of the injection pump
(I have drawings for every single part inside the RS pump, from when I
worked at Bosch) and the fact that I want one. I also want Claudia Schiffer,
but I'm more likely to get an RS someday. Cheaper to maintain too, and you
can't insure Significant Others against theft.
 
Anyway, many of the answers to your questions can be found in a
hyperexpensive book entitled "Carrera RS" by Gruber and Konradsheim,
available in German and English. Motorbooks in USA sells the English for
$300, but realistically it can be found for less than that. I am not aware
of a French edition, but it may exist. Is there a French automotive book
store? (I only know of one such store, in Strasbourg). They can probably
help you. If not, you can try contacting the authors at TAG Verlag GmbH,
Postfach 911, A-1020, Wien ("Vienna" en Anglais). Fax (Austria) 0222/2143953
 
The book is hardbound, in a slipcase, 26 x 30 cm, 256 pages, all color,
numbered editions of 3000. The ISBN number in my English edition is
3-9500179-1-7.
 
Everyone who owns a genuine RS must have this book. For the rest of us, it's
very desirable in spite of the price.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 13 Feb 95 13:39:20 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Senders and gauges for 924 S

Roberto Rabe writes that
>The fuel gauge reports the wrong level of fuel
and
>the oil pressure gauge moves directly to bar 5 once the key is in the
>'accessory' position
 
I don't know specifics about the fuel sender location, but I think I can
help on the oil pressure.
 
Yesterday I rigged up my 356 to read oil pressure on the fuel level gauge.
In the process of fiddling with the system, calibrating the sender against
the gauge and such, I found among other things that if the sender is
disconnected from the gauge (no input to gauge) then the needle pegs at 5
bar (or whatever). Check your wiring, then check your sender.
 
I don't know what the 924 sender looks like. The VDO sender I got for the
356 has two posts, one marked WK and one marked G (presumably German for
"Warnkontakt" und "Geber"; warning [light] contact and 'giver,' the pressure
sender.) The sender is merely a potentiometer, a device whose resistance
goes up as pressure goes up. If you have an ohmmeter, check the resistance
of the pressure sender (one lead on terminal of sender, other lead to
ground). Start the engine, check resistance again. It should be much higher
with oil pressure on the sender. In my case, the resistance was as follows:
 
pressure (bar)         resistance (ohms)
0                           7
1                          51
2                          84
3                         117
4                         147
5                         177
 
If the sender seems to be acting normally, check the wiring from the sender
to the gauge for breaks/disconnections.
 
It's possible your problems are related, somewhere in the dashboard
electrical stuff.
 
Pete

Date: 13 Feb 95 13:40:23 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsche model numbers

There was some discussion last week about Porsche model designations and
project numbers.
 
The upcoming book, "Porsche 911 -- Forever Young" by Tobias Aichele has the
following explanation of the 901 number:
 
"In the meantime, the new Porsche was named 901. This designation appears
in writing for the first time on May 17, 1962. Initially, the T8 designation
was still added in parentheses. The renaming did not mean that this car's
design carried project number 901 in the sequence of all projects which the
Porsche design bureau had taken on since its founding on April 25, 1931. The
longest-serving Porsche employee, Karl Rabe, administrator of the project
numbers, was far too unsystematic for that and the story is somewhat more
complicated. At the beginning of the 1960s, a merging of the Porsche and
Volkswagen organizations was envisioned. To that end, the computer in the
spare parts department at Wolfsburg searched for unassigned numbers so that
no complications would arise after the fusion. The computer spit out "901"
as a suitable combination of numbers, so the new car received that
designation. Even today, the designation of all new Porsche car models
begins with a 9."
 
 
 
Pete

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 18:38:40 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re:Dues, etc..


Cherie and Philes,

As one of the European minority on the list, I must say 
that I am less keen than most on the affilation of the list to
PCA.

In an ideal world I would like to see Porschephiles expressed as a 
Cyber Porsche Club, with it's own contacts with the factory and it's 
own contacts the other Porsche Clubs which are restricted by geography. 
Perhaps we might want to have links with PCA or PCGB or whatever, but 
I'm not sure that we should be subsiderary to them.

I wonder if Porschephiles is a long-term threat to some of the functions 
of the PCA (or PCGB for that matter) after all we have the best, fastest, 
real-time, diagnosis, support, engineering expertise, vendors, etc etc, 
only an email away.

This makes many earth-bound club publications slightly redundant in some 
senses. For technical Porsche matters, the list is starting 
to become *the* source.

Also, due to the wisdom of our benign despot, The Listmeister, we don't have 
the kind of political struggles the PCGB wastes so much time and money on.

Do we want to be regulated by the PCA rulebook (if such a thing exists),
or do we wnat to cut our own groove on the infobahn?

I am all for the creation of virtual Porschephile lebensraum by putting 
together a hardware and software infrastructure to support it, and I am very 
happy to contribute. I am against affiliation by geographical region, when
we are are associated by the net and not the vagaries of geography.

Regards

ben

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 11:52:19 -0700
From: mhatch@utg.org (Mark Hatch)
Subject: (Q) re: Restoring/Painting? **Read Me

I did the same thing with my 73'911 T Targa. Sure helps to identify the
spots that need work (instead of finding them in a couple years as they
rust through).


One question, did you spray por-15 on? Did you have any problems with what
seems like dust in the paint?

The reason I ask is that I have had two samples of their black paint and
both times I used them (I brushed them on), I end up with a surface that
looked like I hadn't tack clothed it! This doesn't seem to be a problem
with the silver color...

BTW: Did you wet sand it after you were done prior to top coating it? This
seems to be a lot of work and so I have limited my use of POR to just the
most critical areas.

mark

>
>Recently I had my 76 914 blasted with a low agression blaster,

>blasted my 914 inside/outside and upside down with a plastic media
>that did not damage the underlying metal, but did remove ALL paint/bondo/
>dirt etc, it is really cool to see a 914 in naked metal, I fought a
>temptation to clear coat it!!  After blasting we painted the car with
>por-15 and the proper base/color coats and added a clear.
>The point is that these cars are getting old and it is really difficult to
>do a repaint well without removing the old finish.  this procedure was
>pretty reasonable at $650 for blasting, compared to chemical or acid
>dipping.  just thought i'd pass along the experience.

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 14:02:41 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: what do w/ 944 valve/hyd lifter click?

> Dear P-philes;
> 
> Let's discuss yet another 944'ism.
> 
> I have an '84. 70k miles and running great.
> 
> When I drive parallel to a solid wall (like brick)
> (i.e. a wall that reflects high % of sound)  I hear a
> valve sounding clicking.  If I just heard the noise
> without knowing the car had hyd lifters, I would 
> instantly say,  "OH - I know that sound, you need to 
> adjust the valves".  
> 
> With the hood up and head inside, I hear the noise but
> I doesn't seem THAT bad.  
> 
> 1) Is this "common".
> 2) Is there anything to do about it?
> 
> The FORD dealer told me how to adjust the hyd lifters of
> my ford bronco II w/ V6, and that quieted it down
> quite a bit.  Is there a siimilar procedure for
> P water pumper?
> 
> -pat
> '84 944 

Hi, pat,

No adjustment is available for the hydraulic lifters on your 944.

On the other hand, it is probably not the lifters that is causing the noise.
On my 83 944, for example, the solenoids in the fuel injectors clatter a bit,
not extremely noisy, but they are louder than the rest of the engine at idle.

If you still believe that the hydraulic lifters are the problem, you have
three courses of action:

1) Replace all the lifters with new ones.
2) Try a heavier weight oil (e.g. 20W50)
3) Burn the car for the insurance... <g>

Of course, you could trade the car for a Bronco with adjustable hydraulic
lifters... <another g>

- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: 13 Feb 95 14:04:40 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: batteries and corrosion

 
Bill Hutton points out that using baking soda will leave sulfates behind,
and must be rinsed.
 
On a non-battery subject, I have recently seen people offer "baking soda
blasting" as a means of removing paint and rust, an alternative to media
blasting. What they don't tell you is that the baking soda is blasted on
wet, and like the sand or walnut shells or plastic beads, gets into
everything. And it gets in there wet. I don't have any firsthand experience
with baking soda blasting, but it doesn't quite seem right... (I have had
experience with walnut shells).
 
Pete

Date: 13 Feb 95 14:19:54 EST
From: Mark Doyle <MDOYLE@laitram.mhs.compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: Battery State of Charge

Pat Garvey asked how to check the state of charge in sealed lead acid 
batteries.



You can check the state of charge in a sealed lead acid battery by very 
accurately measuring it's open circuit voltage.  First, disconnect the 
battery charger.  Disconnect the negative battery cable if the battery is 
still in the car.  This will let the battery voltage assume open circuit 
voltage after a short time (wait an hour to be safe).  With an accurate 
digital volt meter, measure the battery voltage.  Use the following table 
to find the state of charge for a 12 volt battery (6 volt battery would 
be half these values):



100% charged                12.66

75% charged                  12.45

50% charged                  12.24

25% charged                  12.03 

0% charged                    11.82



These values are valid for a battery at 25 degrees Celsius.  For a 
battery at 0 degrees Celsius, reduce the table values by .03 volts ( i.e. 
12.63 is 100% charged for a battery at 0 degrees Celsius).



I hope this helps you to keep your batteries in good shape thru the 
storage period.



Mark Doyle

'85 911 Coupe

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 12:17:04 PST
From: gary@superior.ucsf.EDU (Gary Helbig)
Subject: RE: 914 valve adjust

>Date: Sun, 12 Feb 95 13:58:09 PST
>From: ssu!scruffy!myers@nbn.nbn.com (Alan W. Myers)
>To: porschephiles@tta.com
>Subject: 914 valve adjust
>
>What's the best way to find TDC for each cylinder when the marks on the
>impeller are worn off?  Hayne's is not very clear to me on this.  Assuming
>you find TDC for #1, then Haynes says to rotate the distributor cam shaft
>90 degrees.  How exact does this have to be?  It seems that "eyeballing"
>the rotor is not very exact.
>
>Any help on this would be much appreciated
>TIA
>alan
>myers@abratech.com

What I do to find TDC for each cylinder:

Put a lightbulb across the points like you were going to static-time
the engine.  Remove the distributor can, and turn the ignition on.

I put the back end up on jack-stands, and block one of the wheels to
keep it from turning.  With the car in 4th gear, I can then turn the
other wheel, and watch for the light to come on.

If you are turning the motor the right way, the light should come on
right at TDC.  (Assuming the car is in tune; this may not be true for
a 1.8 motor.)

You can either look at the rotor to know which cylinder, or remember
the firing order (1-4-3-2).

gary@superior.ucsf.edu
