Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 09:46:52 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Value of vin plates and 912E #1 totaled

>..a vintage Ferrari racer) said "If I wreck it, it's no big deal as long 
> as I have the plate with the VIN number on it. I can have another car
>built from scratch around the plate for only $40,000 and the car 
>is worth over a million"  The magic VIN number is where the value
>lies. 
>
>Reid

>Somehow I wonder if this could be 100% true. Otherwise anyone could
><simply>, have a duplicate made of the vin plate(s) and place the copy on
>another car, sell it for big bucks and quietly keep the original.
>Were talking about forgery sure, but I tend to feel (like with art) that the
>work of art without its signature is not complete and vice versa.
(snip)
>Chris Jungmann

     A late 50's TestaRossa owner had bought his car in the 60's (in pieces)
 for $4700. In the late 80's with a value of $1-2 million he still raced
 the car in Vintage events, even once sliding into the guardrail. "I have
 to remind myself its just a $4700 car," he quipped. Super-rare Ferraris
 (Barchettas, 250LM, the GTOs) are frequently driven, raced and even sometimes
 wrecked. But they never die.
     Since all the really valuable Ferraris were built by hand (dies ?
 Stampings ? no, just a hammer and a piece of sheet metal) ANY of the early
 Ferraris can be made from scratch. Ferraristi have an obsession with serial
 numbers, as long as they can track the ownership they are still outrageously
 valuable.
     Ferrari -Frames- have been rumored to sell for $100k. "Re-bodys"
 are common in the Ferrari world. Ferraris that were supposedly burned and
 buried have later been hunted and dug up like so much buried treasure.
    There was some outfit in northern Italy that -was- making forgeries of
 vintage Ferraris and selling them as authentic. Since engines are available
 (there were enough not-so-valuable Ferraris made along the really expensive
 ones that not All cars are rebuilt) and the rest can be made from scratch
 (or is repro'd) they apparently sold quite a few cars (cars that sell from
 $50-300k each) before getting shut down.
                        
  Where does this leave 912E vin #1 ? Probably hopelessly smashed, with
 few parts worth anything. Rarity doesn't really have that much to do
 with car value (really !), that the '76 912E had no race history or stand out
 it in any historical, technical, or aesthetic way it would take one really
 generous guy to rebuild that car....

          Lee A. (ashes to ashes, dust to dust....)

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 14:17:31 -0600

        Aah, the E-region rears its head again.  Last time, I
believe that the idea was stillborn.  For some reason, it sounds
like a much better idea this time through!
        However, what about the well-known PCA "exclusivity"

        Another concern is that, if we do go the e-region route,
our "benevolent dictatorship" would become a democracy.  We may
all want Stan to be the President of the Region, but that will
eventually (10 years?) change.  And the powers of Region Presi-
dents are somewhat more limited than those of the person who
effectively owns the list.  I'm not sure that I care for that.
        My $00.05.  (Everything Porsche costs 2.5 X what it
should...)

- --DD

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 16:30:39 EST
From: strcklnd@aur.alcatel.com (Craig Strickland)
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1161 Mon Feb 13 14:36:25 CST 1995

Robert,

>Recently I had my 76 914 blasted with a low agression blaster,
This shop Elaborate Enterprises 203-355-5225 in CT (Mike or Bill)
blasted my 914 inside/outside and upside down with a plastic media
that did not damage the underlying metal, but did remove ALL paint/bondo/
dirt etc, it is really cool to see a 914 in naked metal, I fought a 
temptation to clear coat it!!  After blasting we painted the car with 
por-15 and the proper base/color coats and added a clear.
The point is that these cars are getting old and it is really difficult to
do a repaint well without removing the old finish.  this procedure was
pretty reasonable at $650 for blasting, compared to chemical or acid
dipping.  just thought i'd pass along the experience.
comments??
rz

That's exactly what I had done to my '76 914 project. I considered dipping the car but the hoses in the longitudinals would have disintigrated and would have been a pain to replace not to mention the seams will drip the stripping chemical for a long time. It's amazing how the car looks when entirely to the metal. The POR-15 on the usual trouble spots was next followed by the epoxy primer, etc. Advice to potential POR-15 users; great stuff but don't get it on your skin, I think a tatoo would come off easier! Also, I had the suspension powder coated and it turned out great.

Craig
'76 914
'83 Gizmo the feline

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 16:59:32 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Storage

I would like to make few additions to the excellent recommendations by W.C.
Hutton and George Hussey.  

1.  An alternative to steam cleaning is pressure washing.  This tends to be
less abusive to the paint and rubber parts.  It will remove the collected
road salts and grime and tends to remove less paint.  Once these areas are
cleaned, a coat of wax will help protect against rust. You don't have to hand
wax the underside or engine compartment, a product like Sonax Hard Wax Spray
will apply an even coating of wax on these areas.  It doesn't chalk or leave
white residue.  This is also a great product for wheels.

2. An excellent battery cleaner is Wurth Battery Cleaner & Leak Detector.  It
neutralizes the acids and dissolves the salts so that they may be washed
away.  Once the battery compartment is clean, an excellent protective coating
is Wurth Rust Guard.  This may be brushed or sprayed on and forms a rock hard
coating that is almost totally impervious.  They used to make it in a clear
that did not need to be painted, but now is only available in black.  This
may be painted to match.  Make sure that all drain holes are not clogged.
 When the battery is reinstalled, spray the Battery Cleaner on the posts
after they are connected.  It sprays on yellow and turns pink if there is an
acid leak.

3. The exterior of the car should be given a coat of your favorite wax prior
to storage.  The interior leather should receive a treatment of a quality
leather treatment.  All vinyl areas should also be treated with a quality
vinyl care product .  A product that contains significant amount of silicone
may not be that beneficial to rubber or vinyl and may prove to be
detrimental.

4. The wheels should be thoroughly clean of brake dust residue as this
residue will turn acid and etch the wheels.  A coating of spray wax or
petroleum jelly after washing will help protect the wheels.

5.  All rubber areas (including the tires, gaskets, hoses) should have a
coating of a quality rubber treatment to protect against ozone damage.  Again
avoid silicone as it can dissolve the protective waxes in the rubber and
allow ozone degradation.

6. A last point on any storage is to protect you car against the little furry
creatures.  They love to make nests in the insulation and nibble on the
wiring.  Omni bags are one way to close down the rodent condo association.

If there are any questions, please contact me.


Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specailties, Inc.
Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
carcaresp@aol.com

NNJR/PCA Member
86 944 Turbo
90 944 Cabrio

The above opinions do reflect those of the management of C.C.S.

BTW, I agree with Cherie that out electronic list is international in nature
and perhaps should be directly affiliated with the factory. This is definitely
a quantum shift and some non-electronic-age folks may have a hard time
understanding our unique nature. I have no problem with being
affiliated with the PCA, but we ought to be affiliated with Porsche 
clubs in all
countries with list members. This is why some direct factory endorsement
would give us a more global charter.

To answer the question about the nature of Electronic Frontier Region
events, well we regularly have two: tech sessions (ongoing) and
socialization (also ongoing electronically and occasionally face to face).

I really like the idea of an EFR t-shirt. Instead of a bumper sticker, we
ought to have a window decal.

------------------------------

Date: 13 Feb 95 14:33
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: Re: 911T to RS replica


[Text item: Text_1]
     Hi Andre:
     
     I have a 73 RS and the Carrera RS book.  Both are great!  I purchased 
     the book from Automobilia in San Francisco for $200. The car was 
     slightly more expensive.
     
     For your T to RS conversion, I recommend going with the conversion to 
     the touring version.  This will be the easiest, least expensive, and 
     most representative of the RS's built (around 80 - 90% were touring, 
     10 - 15% were sport and intended for racing, 50 or so were RSR's, and 
     the first few were stripped homologation versions).
     
     The touring version comes with the 911 S interior, including Recaro 
     cloth and leather sports seats (typically), so your interior changes 
     should be minimal.
     
     Other key features of the touring version (besides the engine which 
     you already have):
     
     Front spoiler:  usually the fiberglass version with the rubber strip, 
     but could come with the S steel spoiler.  Aftermarket versions of the 
     spoiler are available from several sources listed in Pano, our Porsche 
     Club of America magazine. I have seen originals from places like 
     Stoddard, but prices are around $1,000 or more.
     
     Rear bumpers:  Came standard as metal, could be ordered with the 
     fiberglass one-piece if desired.  Again, aftermarket fiberglass rear 
     bumpers are available.  The fiberglass really looks good.
     
     Fender flares:  RS rear flares are wider to accomodate the 7" rear 
     wheels.  These flares are probably available factory of aftermarket.  
     Front fenders are standard, and use 6" wheels.
     
     Gas tank:  The gas tank is extra large (85 liters?) and plastic.  On 
     models with air conditioning (believe it or not, some RS's, including 
     mine, have factor a/c) the extra blower up front necessitated the use 
     of the steel tank.  I have seen used plastic gas tanks advertised for 
     $400 to $800, but they don't become available often.  Don't know if 
     they're available from the factory anymore.
     
     Suspension:  Bilstein shocks (green), an aluminum front crossmember, 
     and mostly S equipment were standard.  On mine, the rear 'banana' arm 
     appears to have some extra support welded to the flange that attaches 
     to the hub area.
     
     Graphics:  You probably already know this part.  The stickers are 
     widely available as repros, with black the appropriate choice for any 
     car that isn't Grand Prix white.
     
     Transmission:  First versions had an oil cooling line, later serial 
     numbers didn't.  I'm not sure where the change occurred.  I believe 
     they all had a limited slip differential, but I'm not positive.  This 
     is listed as an option in the Carrera RS book.
     
     I'm no RS expert; there are probably some other changes that I haven't 
     detailed here.
     
     Please note also that there were many changes during the model run.  
     For instance, during the production run the speedometer was changed 
     from 250 km/hr to 300 km/hr, sheet metal changed thickness, and the 
     suspension was modified somewhat.  What you got depended on when your 
     car was built, and every RS out there is most likely unique.
     
     Also, many customers ordered special things, so some have rollbars, 
     some have the racing type hood and decklid rubber releases, some have 
     different mirrors...  Anyway, you get the idea.  The Carrera RS book 
     is your best source for this, and also includes some great photos.
     
     Let me know if you'd like any more info.
     
     Jeff Jensen
     jcjensen@raychem.com

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 15:26:51 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Tire Recommendations?

>Yes I can testify to the HUGE difference :)

Yep. I'm convinced - I'll be putting Nokias on every winter car from here out.

>As for the Blizzaks, I heard they are supposed to be coated with this
>extra amazing grip compound that should be really good on ice.  But
>then the compound wears in about 15K miles, rendering the tire an ordinary
>all season tire.  That's why I am going for the Nokias.  Too bad they are
>not as popular in this country (US). 

The Blizzaks that we've had DO seem extremely soft and squishy to the touch... Curiously so. But, again, I imagine they wear out awfully damn fast - and 
I just can't believe that their tread pattern, with narrow spaces between blocks, would work as well as Nokia's big-space unidirectional pattern. I'd love to 
see a "real" comparison, but haven't seen one yet...

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 16:26:27 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Another 2c on the PCA E.R. region.

From reading the rather voluminous amount of mail generated, 
I thought I'd throw out my observations on the whole scene...

Obviously, the subscribers to Porschephiles feel the urge to 
belong to an official online group. That's basically already 
here, the only additions being perhaps "boutique" stuff... 
Shirts, etcetera. Plus we don't want to exclude non-Porsche 
owners from the list.

Obviously, the non-P-car owners can still read Porschephiles in 
any incarnation that I could see - after all, are we going to go to 
every subscriber's house and verify that they're not lying about 
owning one? However, if we're forming an online club, perhaps 
something can be working out with PCA (and, perhaps, Porsche 
AG, as well as Porsche clubs in other parts of the world) to 
become the official headquarters. Obviously, enough people are 
willing to donate the money that we might be able to get our 
own Site... Porsche.com? Perhaps if we could prove to PCA, 
Porsche AG, et al that it won't cost them anything, and will be 
simply good PR at little if any effort on their part... Surely 
there's gotta be some Porsche employees who are on the Net 
and are willing to donate a little bit of time to such a project.

Well, I think I'm doing a bit of rambling, but I think our first 
priority would be to band together, form an official group, and 
see if that can become either an PCA Region, or perhaps an 
all-new type of PCA support base. The only problem is, if we're 
mentioned in Panorama, the already busy P-philes list might 
explode, and perhaps would need to be switched in the future to 
specialized lists - Porschephiles914, Porschephiles911, etc.

Well, those are just some random foodstuffs for thought. 
Whatever happens, count me in. I'd be proud to stick a 
Porschephiles decal on my 914. (Perhaps we should leave a 
blank spot, or provide a matching decal, to include our own Net 
address?)


- -- 
| Jeff Kyle                           "I don't know what they have to say |
| jeffk914@ix.netcom.com                    It makes no difference anyway |
| "Katarina" '75 Porsche 914             Whatever it is, I'm against it!" |
| "General Lido" '85 Dodge Shelby Charger                   -Groucho Marx |

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 18:38:59 CST
From: drozt@comm.mot.com (Peter Drozt)
Subject: '87 Carrera


After encouragement from my wife to look for a latter '80s Porsche,
I found an '87 which seems to fit what I'm looking for.  After
talking to the owner on the phone, here are some of the highlights
that I know about it so far:

   - '87 Carrera coupe with sunroof.

   - 50K miles.

   - Partial leather interior.

   - Original paint.

   - Last major service at about 43K miles.

   - Only major repairs since new has been to replace an AC hose and
     replace the lateral stabilizer shock(?).

   - Only put on about 5K miles in last 3 or 4 years.  Only service
     done in that time has been an oil change.

   - Has maintenance records.

The owner is asking $26K (firm) and I plan on looking at it over the
weekend.  And if things look okay, I'll have a mechanic look over it
more carefully.  In the meantime, I'd appreciate any advice I can get:
Does this seem to be a fair price?  What sort of things should I look
at when I go to see the car?  Is there anything specific to an '87 that
I should be aware of?

About the only thing that this car doesn't have that I would like
is front and rear spoilers.  How feasible is it to add these?  How
much would it cost?  Is it something that I could do myself?

And one last thing for now.  I may need to finance part of this car.
Can anyone recommend a place with good rates and good service?

Thanks...
Peter Drozt
drozt@comm.mot.com

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 19:59:23 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: EFR status

Well, as advertised, I called Ruth this AM and have a New Region kit
coming...

I also have about 90 requests to be charter members! This is wild!!!
When National sees that sort of support, it should help.

I also noted some concerns. I'll do my best to answer them in the next
day or so but right now I have to go do Real Work (have a presentation
in the AM I haven't prepared for yet). In the mean time:

* stated position is that NO ONE WILL BE REFUSED ACCESS TO THE LIST. EVER.
  Unless they're a dick like T*d, of course.

* the PCA vs. PCx thing, where "A" is America and "x" is RoW: it *IS* a
  real issue, needs to be dealt with. Executive summary: there is a forum
  for recognition under the PCA banner that gives us a LOT if valuable
  stuff (tax exempt status, granted use of Porsche logos, etc.); there is
  no "umbrella" organization for the world at large. It's unfair, but it's
  necessary. So we have to do our dead-level best to make world members
  feel welcome, and not get bent out of shape over the "A" vs. "x" thing.

* keep them cards and letters coming! Right now, we'd hit the ground running
  with more members that many regions, the more the merrier...

Stan

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1163                         Tue Feb 14 01:56:00 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 21:36:59 -0500
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: EFR issues - my $0.015 (long)

Well, I guess everyone realizes there are *lots* of things to think about here.

Anyways... here are some comments about what others have said:

1. The International angle.

Well, I live in Canada, and the Porsche Club of Canada doesn't exist
anymore... it was absorbed into PCA (perhaps PCA should change their name...
mind you, everyone thinks we're placid Americans with health care and no
guns anyways... :) There is also a PCA region in Germany.

The appeal is great for a separate, international club (yes, there is a
Porsche Club co-ordinator, Ilse is her name, I think, at Porsche), but Stan
is in the U.S., and there are quite a few legal, tax-related, and insurance
advantages to piggy-backing onto PCA. I'm not saying those advantages
outweigh the disadvantages, but right now, Stan is under a certain amount of
risk running the list (an extremely small amount of risk, but the potential
is there). Setting up a separate entity may prove to be a *lot* more work
than convincing PCA National.

2. Peoples who don't own Porsches, or don't want to belong to PCA.

The "Porsche owners only" rule of PCA is one that I pretty sure is nearly
impossible to change. I wouldn't even try. Tied in with this is the
(unenforceable) PCA by-law that Region members have to belong to PCA, and
vice versa.

Note that there isn't any PCA by-law against non-members participating in,
and paying to participate in, *Regional* events. The only restriction (for
insurance reasons) is that the region must run the event. Non-members can
subscribe to region newsletters, so...

The point is the rules can be worked around. It *would* create "classes" of
people on the list, though... primarily in terms of voting vs. non-voting
people.

People have co-owned cars in PCA, but a vehicle existing just to get around
the rules is exactly the type of thing that would get PCA National's back
up. Ya gotta be quiet about these things <grin>.

3. List vs. Club

Right now, its Stan's list. Many people would like it to remain Stan's list.
Just as regional newsletter editors wield tremendous power, so will the
listmeister.

There should be more to the region than just the list (although, like a
regional newsletter, it'll be the "lifeblood" of the region).

Right now there's an ftp site and a Web site. There's also a PCA-editor's
list that runs thanks to Stan's assistance. Larry Wilson capably runs that
list. Someone mentioned they had a "talk" site accessible. What about an IRC
channel? If you've got a microphone and a sound card, you can even have
vocal conversations throught the Internet. Point being that there's *lots*
of other stuff that can be done in Cyberspace... e.g., WAIS indexing of the
archives would be really nice (and a LOT of work too), but there's tons of
possibilities besides just the list... Web services to other regions/clubs,
advertising, FAQ's...


Anyways, I'm sure Stan has given a lot of thought to all the issues, and he
thinks he's "come up with the *exactly* the right idea." I'm inclined to agree.


Enough blathering for now,
Craig.

- --- <: snip! ;> ---
+ Craig Seko in Ottawa, the second coldest national capital in the world! +
| Personal'n'Porsche mail: cseko@inasec.ca  Work mail: sekocet@statcan.ca |
| Don't go to http://www.inasec.ca/cseko/welcome.html - its lost in space |
+ Usual opinion disclaimer :) I speak only for myself. Live free or die.  +

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 95 22:47:03 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Roof on 944

> Hello all:

First of all, congratulations on med school. Hope that it serves you well.

> Recently I purchased my very first car, an early 85 944.  I LOVE IT.
> It is the most fun a person can have with their clothes on *SNICKER*.
> However, I have a rather peculiar problem, my sun roof wiggles and 
> sometimes in high speeds wistles.  Is there any way for me to adjust the
> level that the room is pulled down so I can create a snugger fit?

Not much adjustment. If the roof comes down level with the rest of the roof,
then the mechanism is properly adjusted.  If the roof is still wiggling
after that, you may have some worn parts, namely the lifting arms or the
slots in the sunroof into which they fit.  A little inspection should help
you identify the parts which need to be replaced.

> If not does anybody know where I can buy a roof inner pannel (Black)
> in good condition?

Yep, got one (part of a complete sunroof) for sale. give me a call and we
can discuss price and terms.

> And a note on the side anybody have the clear moonroof for the 944?
> How do you like/hate it and do u know of one for sale and what is a 
> good price for one?

The tradename for such a beast is a Saratoga Top.  Not available anymore,
except used.  My 2 cents worth is that I don't like them. Too much glare on
a bright day... You may be able to find one at a swap meet for $200-$300,
but will take patience and perseverance...
- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 22:59:39 -0500
From: WRLSAJ@aol.com
Subject: .Battery mats in older 911s

As my 72 911T waits for spring in the garage..
I decided to do a preventative  upgrade in the front
dual battery boxes.  My battery boxes are presently
in excellent shape for some reason, no rust but my batteries
are emitting their vapors and bubbling the paint.  I treated
these areas with a dilute solution of baking soda, sanded and
applied rust blocker paint. I believe it was Martin who
posted an excellent procedure on taking care
of this area awhile back. 

The current, somewhat new, Interstate unsealed batteries are snug fits. 
 I bought two Battery Mats from Zims to install under these
batteries, with the ideal of placing a  trimmed piece across
each row of caps to further help control the acid fumes.
Short of it is, they do not fit.  Everything is too tight.  Dang!

My question is:
Has anybody install these Battery Mats in their earlier vintage
911?  An I wasting my time when there is a better alternative?
Is one approach is to move to a single, nonvented battery,
setup secured outside of the battery boxes? But hey won't a single
battery upset my car's balance? 8{)  (This would have
been  a T*d bait question)

This month's Pano does mention a Miata battery box adaptation but 
the 912 original setup did not look like my box situation. Thanks in
advance for your suggestions.

Bill

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 20:17:20 -0800
From: dem@best.com (Dennis Mitsch)
Subject: 944 oil leak


Hi 'philes!

Lazy person that I am, I have my mechanic do my oil changes.  Last Tuesday I 
had this done, and by the weekend I noticed 5 or 6 two to three inch oil 
spots on my driveway (!).  I figured, by now, my oil is probably pretty low 
so I checked it. It was still at the *TOP* mark on the dipstick.  Between 
the leakage and the normal amount of oil my car "eats" (about 1/4 quart 
every week), I would have expected it to be low.  My car has never had any 
leakage that managed to make it onto the driveway before.

So what I'm wondering, is if they severely overfilled my oil, could it have 
accelerated the seal failure this quickly? (I can't see exactly where it is 
leaking, it's dripping onto the gravel guard and running to the edge - my 
car is parked at an angle, it is towards the front of the engine though).  
Am I dreaming here that I expect them to at least split the labor with me 
for repairing it?  The seal may have already been leaking, but not enough to 
make spots on my driveway.

Take this as a lesson, change your own damn oil. :)

Dennis Mitsch
1988 944S(radiator, windshield, oil problems all in the last 30 days)
1995 924/944/968 FAQ(if you're not on the pre-release screening list and 
would like to be, send me mail)

Date: Wed, 01 Mar 95 21:56:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 O2 sensor behavior (input at DME)


Kirk,

Pin 1 on your car's DME connector is the ignition pulse to the coil.  If you
want ground, suggest you use a ground point rather than breaking out
the DME.

Kevin Gross

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 22:34:47 -0600
From: knestle@interaccess.com (Ken Nestle)
Subject: Re: Million $ Cars!!!

Sean

That's a lot of pricey iron. I have no idea of the values.

I know this is a little off the Porsche track, but you started it :-).

In the shop where my 914 currently resides there are:

a. a 30's vintage Dusenburg SJ duel cowel phaeton. A fairly rare piece.
    The owner was offered $4,000,000 for it and she turned it down. She is
now deceased and it is part of her estate.

b. a 1964 Ford GT40. One of only four on the planet.
    The owner of this one (the same guy who installed the V8 in my 914) was
offered $1.8 mil when it was only a                bare chassis, half a
body, and disassebnled engine. He's got it almost completely restored now
and estimates its value at $4.5 mil.

No bragging or pretension intended. They are not mine. I will never ride in
either of them. They just happen to occupy space near my vehicle.
I wonder what percentage of the really rare cars in the world are stuck
away in off the path establihments like this, rather than museums.

Ken Nestle '75 914/V8

First, please put a signature with your email address somewhere in your 
messages, preferably at the bottom.  You can list your cars, wife, ex-wives, 
cats, farm animals that you are particularly fond of, children, etc.  There 
are many mail systems that strip out the headers and we can't tell who you 
are.

Second, lots of us don't know shit either.  I suspect the reason you only 
got a few answers to your chip question was that not too many folks may 
know.  Sorry.

My take on this list is that most folks are willing to help those of us who 
are ignorant.  I've thrown out questions and got absolutely NO response.  I 
asked one question and got about 10 reponses in 2 hours.  Depends on the 
question, time of day/week/month/year etc.

BTW, I don't buy that 'I'm too old' stuff.  My dad's a retired accountant 
and he's pretty sharp.  Kinda grumpy, but pretty smart.

Sorry we come across as a bunch of snobs.  It certainly isn't intentional as 
far as I've seen.  There are some pretty decent folks here.  Where else can 
you find a couple of hundred people who are willing to cough up $15-100+ for 
a fellow most have never met in person.  For some of us, that was grocery 
money.

That said, about your paint (I missed your first post):  if you have never 
painted before, or don't have someone who can show you (I'd never done it 
before, but have a buddy who paints and he guided me through painting a 
5-series BMW) I'd give serious thought to plunking down the $300 buck to 
have the hood re-shot.  Tell us where you live, and I bet you'll get some 
comments about paint shops in your area.  One thing most people aren't short 
on is opinions.

Now, is it true that if I roll my IRA into....... :)

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 23:35:28 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Oil leaks (was: 944 oil leak)

In my experience, oil spots on the ground always look like more than
they actually are.  This is even more so with the thinner fluids
(brake and transmission).

There's also the heat factor, which would make the spots look large
relative to their actual volume.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 23:41:23 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: powder coating

No doubt there are those who know more than I do, but as I understand
it powder coating uses an electrolytic (electrostatic) process.  It's
thinner than paint and becomes more integral with the coated part.  At
least that's how I understand it.  The metal gearshift lever, for
example, is powder coated, is it not?

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

I think you're refering to the 904 that was fire bombed in South Africa and 
almost completely destroyed. But the frame was there. I can't see how even 
an expert can take the VIN tags from a destroyed 916 for example install 
them on a 914-4 and say "That's the original car" (after making appropriate 
mods.)

I guess the guestion comes down to this: one can replicate the car around 
the VIN tag but it won't be the same, you won't have the car's "soul". By 
this I mean the original workmanship quirks etc. that made it worth $1Meg in 
the first place.

I would not want to pay a fortune for a car that was not built by the 
factory team.

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 00:04:31 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: NON-P-OWNERS welcomed by PCA?

So far as I know, PCA requires the joiner to be an owner or co-owner
of a Porsche.  They probably don't check, however.  Also, co-owner
cuts a wide swath.  If you're leasing a new Porsche, your equity
percentage is pretty small.

My own region lets members who have sold their cars continue as
associate members, and in that capacity they can do everything but
serve as president or vice president.  As far as PCA National is
concerned, it's unlikely that they would ever know--or care.
Basically, they want members.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 00:06:41 -0800 (PST)
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptd257.al.intel.com>
Subject: Mystery Accountant guests

Dear Mystery Accountant:

Terribly sorry that you were ignored during you previous crys for help.
Perhaps they were so pitiful that we couldn't hear them over the racious
laughter from the recent rehash of T*d'isms.  Or perhaps, with all the money

thing I did notice was your failure to identify yourself either in a cutsie
choice of login at aol or in the form of a signature of some sort.  (Now
really what sort of name is X40045?  It doesn't even make a good cpu)

I realize that many many wet behind the ears folks are jumping on the big
diesel bus to gawk at the info super highway, so its understandable that you
were just following the guy in the seat next to you.  (After all I'm sure you
saw that we are all really just Nazi Sheep....)  

I'll make you a deal:  You add a signature to your next post, and in return
I'll repost this rather longish article I wrote awhile ago on touching up
dings.  Oh yeah, and send Stan $100 for the hardware fund.   :^)


> I have some paint left over from a repair job from way back.
> 
> 	I'd like some suggestions/advice for preparing the area before I apply
> the paint and also any tips on how to actually apply it.
> 

I'm goming to presume that the chip is down to the bare metal for this
process.  First, get some items to help you with the job:

	small bit of primer, compatible with the paint on your car
	color matched paint
	A very sharp #2 pencil with unused eraser on the end
	two or three extra pencils with unused erasers
	double sided tape or contact cement (cc preferred)
	600 grit wet/dry sandpaper
	320 grit wet/dry sandpaper
	220 grit wet/dry sandpaper
	some organic cleaner (simple green works great)
	a couple of cotton tipped q-tips, paper shafts required
	optionally a magnifying glass
	spray cleaner (Aero Kroil is the best I've found) or rubbing alcohol
	empty shoe box bottom, cut to fit over area with chip.
	Polishing compund (not rubbing compound)
	cloth diaper if possible, or lint free terry cloth rag


Carefully clean the chipped area with the undiluted organic cleaner and
examine the edges of the chip to see if they are loose edges to the chip.
Probe the area carefully with the sharpened pencil point (the graphite point
is soft enough to not damage the paint edges, and will come off with the
alcohol or spray cleaner easily with out rubbing) to look for areas that are
lifting up.  Make mental notes if any areas exist, or if possible, remove
them.

Cut a small circle of 220 grit sandpaper and glue it to the eraser on the
pencil.  Attach some 320 grit sandpaper to another pencil, repeat with 600
you'll need both of these soon, so do them all together.  Use this to
carefully roughen up the edges of the chip and the exposed bare metal.  Use 
the spray cleaner to remove the dust particles.  The spray cleaners have a 
high rate of evaporation, so should not interfere with the paint.

Use the 320 to roughen up about a small area of paint outside the chip, about
3 or 4 millimeters should be enough.  Use the spray cleaner to remove the
dust.

Carefully pull _most_ of the cotton off one end of the swab.  Just a minor
bit is needed since you are using the paper shaft as well to apply paint.
Dip the prepared end into the primer about 5 mm and dab the paint into the
chip.  Start at the center to create a dome of paint and pull it out to the
edges.  If there were loose edges of paint, try to get the primer under them
as well as coating most of the roughened up paint.  Leave about 1 mm of
exposed roughened paint around the primer.  The coat should be very thin.
If the first drop didn't cover the chip completely, in the next step, dip the
swap deeper into the paint.  But don't over do it.  It is much better to have
too little paint in a layer than too much.  Probably another 3 mm is enough.
Allow 2 hours to dry (!).  You'll thank me later that you waited this long.
take the shoe box and make sure that it can easily cover the area you just
put paint on, trim it if needed to fit better.  I use my car cover to hold it
in place.  This keeps the dust out while the paint is drying.

Once the paint is dry, use 600 grit to roughen up the surface and reapply
another dallop of primer in the same manner.  Let it dry another 2 hours.

Once the paint is dry, use 600 grit to roughen up the surface if you can see
bare metal in the scratches, repeat the previous steps one more time.
Usually two coats is enough however.

This time apply the color paint in the same manner, dip the sheared swab
about 5mm into the paint, and place a drop in the center of the chip, then
pull it out to cover the chip entirely.  Spread out the paint to cover all
the area that is roughened up.  Don't worry if you go over the area, it will
be removed later.  This layer of paint should be very thin, perhaps not even
obscuring the scratches or some of the primer.  That's ok.  Cover it with
your shoebox, and let it dry for 2 hours.

Add another drop of paint and spread it out to cover the chip.  The secret to
this method is that you should never redip the swab when applying a layer of
paint.  If the chip is larger, dip the swab deeper into the paint this time,
but only a little bit.  Don't worry if the chip is not covered with paint
yet, follow the same method you did with the primer and each successive layer
adds a bit more paint to the initial drop, until the area covered is the
right size.  Again let this layer dry for at least 2 hours.

Repeat the spreading drop of paint, 2 hour drying time, a number of times.
The idea is to make the combined layers of paint ever so thicker than the
painted surface of your car.  I predict for a chip that is to bare metal, you
will need about 2 coats of primer and 8 to 10 coats of paint.  As always,
more layers won't hurt, it just takes a lot more time.  The 2 hours between
coats is imperiative.  DO NOT SKIP THIS STEP.

By now you should have a small blister of paint a fraction of a millimeter
thicker than the paint job on your car.  Let the last coat dry about a week
before doing the next step.  Really.

Wrap the diaper around your index finger and make sure the tip is covered.  
Use this to apply a small amount of polishing compound to the ex-chip, and
polish the area in small circular motions.  Use a clean area of diaper when
the diaper is paint colored.  Examine the blister of paint to see if it is
blended in to the correct layer yet.  Once it is, clean your car like normal.
Then wax it with a good hard wax of your choice.

Yes this is a labor intensive process, but when you consider how much money a
new paint job is going to cost, its pretty minor.  I have used this method
many time (unfortunantly) and you would be hard pressed to find the chips on
the front of my car, even though it's black lacquer, the worst offender for
chipping and showing blemishes.


- -- 
Miq Millman   mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com	  503 642 6139   (Aloha site)
AL4-55  Intel, 5200 NE Elam Young Parkway, Hillsboro, OR 97124-6497
See also miq@teleport.com

Porschephiles #1164                         Tue Feb 14 10:28:01 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 09:41:24 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Re: pilot bearing

>When installing the piolt bearing, is it supposed
>to be lubricated and, if so, what should be used?
>The original one appeared to be lubricated, but was
>in sad shape.  Any help here would be appreciated.

Having just replaced the one in my project 914 as I rebuild the engine, I can
tell you what I learned in the process.

First make sure the new pilot bearing is installed at the correct depth.  On
the 914 the pilot bearing should be recessed 3.2mm from the clutch side.  I
noticed that this was about the same as the width of the felt washer which
follows the bearing installation, and I assume it helps the grease stay put.

I used LubroMoly Moly Grease.  My Verlobte said that moly grease has 
problems at high temps but the manual recommends a molybdenum disulfide grease.

- -- 
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady           
 - '70 914 1.9 
 - '84 Saab 900T(winter sedan)

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 10:31:08 GMT

Neil Writes:

| Just a quick question regarding tires. I need a set of 205/60/15   for my '73
| 911. Since I live in the US (no Autobahn speeds) and I'm not planning on
| doing many drivers' Eds, I've decided to get H rated tires.

Neil, just my $0.02, not a flame, but putting inferior tires on 
a 911 is not a quality solution. For the saving of $200 you are
having a major impact on the only place your 911 touches the ground.
Say your tires last a nominale 10000 miles, Then you are saving
(coincidentally!) $0.02 per mile. Is it really worth it to cripple your
911 to save that cash?

Those four contact points are where maximum quality is needed. Whether
you do autobahn speeds or not is immaterial, you also need to
consider how many g you are pulling in acceleration and deceleration,
what dry and wet performance characteristics you need, what sidewall
stiffness is required. You should buy the best possible tyres. I like 
Yokohama A008P, there are others that are at least as good if not better.
I think that it is a false economy to purchase inferior tires for a 911,
if you cut corners here it will show in the handling and safety
of the car.

Regards


Ben

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 07:38:29 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Disgruntled new Porschephile

"A disgruntled porschephile" writes:
>   Well, eather you folks want new members who are eager and simply don't have

> the knowledge or you don't. I'm a little too old to try to figure out how to
> ask a question in such a way that you guys won't think I'm stupid and thus,
> don't warrent the help I'm asking for. For what its worth, you as a group
> come accross as a bunch of aristocrats (in your own minds).. 

Dear disgruntled:

Yep, you are right in your assessment of what it is that we are doing here.

The group that makes up Porschephiles is nothing more than several hundred
people with an interest in Porsches and access to the internet mailing
systems.  Each of those people pays in his own way for that access.

Now some of those very people are right this minute having a good day, and
some are having a bad day. (I'll tell you what, ask me a question when I am
having a bad day and I will give you a completely different answer than when
I am having a good day.).  Furthermore, some of those people who are having
a good day know the answer to your questions and some don't.

What I'm trying to say is that if you don't get a response the first time,
ask again, perhaps in a different way.

It could just be that the one guy who knows the answer to your question is
too busy at his real job to spend the time answering it again.

I guess the other thing to remember is that none of us is getting paid for
this (except Peter Albrecht, who has my dream job...) and that the
information that you see here is sometimes right and sometimes wrong, a lot
of opinion without fact, and occasionally information distilled from years
of experience and cogitation.

Don't give up on us.  Every one of us was a newbie to Porschephiles at the
beginning...

BTW, please feel free have me ask any questions that you think are
embarrassing on your behalf.  Think of me as the anon remailer...


- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 07:43:19 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Disgruntled new Porschephile

Regarding performance chips in a 1985 911 Carrera:

Yes, they are out there. Yes they do provide some improvement in performance,
The bottom line is, though, if you do not have a turbocharger on your engine,
chipping the engine will provide modest results.  

On the other hand, it may be just what you want.

For my money, the best performance improvement you can make to your Porsche
is to attend PCA Driver Education events at tracks, so that you can learn 
how your car performs at the limits of what Porsche has designed into it.

Regarding paint chips:

Already answered by someone who obviously knows a lot more about paint than I
ever will... However, if you want some disinformation, ask me again and I wil
be happy to mislead you...

- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 08:35:36 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: leakdown tester

>| > I am thinking about getting a leakdown tester, but have never
>| > seen one for sale anywhere. What are the brands and where
>| > are they sold?
>|
>| I noted with some surprise that Engine Builders Supply is now selling
>| a leak-down tester for $49. Their ads are *everywhere*...
>
>Has anyone used or seen the EBS leakdown tester? I wonder how it
>compares in quality to the SnapOn one (which is probably $200,
>but then again their stuff is not notch). Of course I don't need
>industrial quality, but I don't want to buy junk either.

I have an inexpensive leakdown tester I bought about 25 years ago, and
I have always wondered if it reads the same for the same leakage as
other leakdown testers. I think it is fairly easy to get a 1st order
calibration by making a "calibrated leak" with a known size drilled hole.
Could we get anyone on the list to try some different hole sizes and
report the readings? An easy way is to put a brass pipe plug in the
end of a quick disconnect fitting, and drill the hole in the pipe plug.
If we could get someone with a "good" leakdown tester to do this,
like the Snap-On, and then also do it for the "cheap" one, we could
at least figure out if they both measured the same thing. Perhaps
the hole size which produces say 5% leakdown would be a good choice. 

BTW- the reason this is an issue is that leakdown testers measure
pressure drop across an internal orifice, analogous to voltage drop
agross a resistance to measure current. However, there doesn't seem
to be any standardization of the internal orifice.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

the Hakkas and NRWs supposedly have 50K mile tire life.

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 09:29:00 CST
From: babak marefat <bmarefat@tigr1.fhsu.edu>
Subject: esson learned

Hello all:
Sorry for subjecting u to line noise, but I heard yesterday and u know.
wont happen again.
On another note:
Dennis Mitsch complains of oil changes in 944 and recommends to:
"do ur own" or something along the line. Here is a little tip my 
mechanic showed me.  Before changing oil on 944s/late 924s, punch a 
hole in the top of the oil filter that way all the oil in it flows down
and wont spill when u undo the filter.
Hope this helps
Babak Marefat
early 85 944, muddy and slitty

someone's neck" *sheepish grin* (this one aint mine either)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 15:20:03 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Porsche Storage


Ref Steam cleaning / high pressure cleaning

Both are great if you want to sell the car or show it.

Both methods - especially steam - tend to remove essential lubes.

There are regular air safety warning about steam cleaning of aircraft, 
the problem is not so critical on cars, but whatever grease is removed by 
cleaning, must be replaced - especially throttle linkages, hand brakes 
and suspension parts.


+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 23:04:14 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Valve Clearance, help...

Oh great purveyors of net wisdom:

I'm (as always) rebuilding my 914 1.7 with a 96mm NPR kit, FAT FI cam and new
lifters.  I was working on getting the valve clearances set when I ran into
the following problem:

   #1 exhaust clearance .15mm
      intake  clearance .15mm
   #2 exhaust clearance .15mm
      intake  clearance .15mm
   #3 exhaust clearance .15mm
      intake  clearance .15mm
   #4 exhaust clearance .00mm ***** <--- with adjustment screw removed!
      intake  clearance .15mm

I removed the rocker assembly for #4 and double checked that the pushrods 
were seated firmly on the lifters and checked the retaining clip.  I have
absolutely no idea what is wrong.  Any ideas?

I'd hate to have to tear the heads off.  Help.
  
- -- 
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady
 - '70 914 1.9 (96mm NPR, canary yellow 916 conversion)

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 10:15:41 CST

>the subscribers feel a need to belong to an official group
 
Well, not really, not if it causes complications (like you MUST have a
P-car, you MUST vote for democratically elected officials, etc). The whole
thing started as a fine way to get Stan some money for his efforts, to buy
new equipment etc. I don't think anybody feels a "need" to do anything, or
to belong to anything. If too many rules get imposed on this thing, nobody
will want to do it. I think Stan has a good grasp of what it will take;
nobody gets cut out, even foreign devils are made welcome <g>, etc. More so
than the rest of the lemming population, I think people on Internet are
more individualistic and not automatically "joiners." An example of
vestigial Hacker Ethic?
 
Only question is, who gets to design the official uniform? Gotta have a
uniform. It's very German, you know. I propose maroon coveralls (like
technicians at Weissach) but with gold epaulets, braid, and campaign ribbons
for slaloms, rallies, tech quizzes, concors, beer blasts... And one of those
nifty hats with a BIG visor. Summer uniform gets maroon coveralls cut off at
the knees. With knee-length socks and sandals.
 
Pete (also foreign devil, in deep cover)

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 11:54:40 -0500
From: JOHNM@icac.org (John Mulligan)
Subject: Porsche "psychographics" research

My father-in-law (wow, that's the first time I've had to call him that!
Weird), who lives in Australia, sent me an article published in their
Financial Review (20 Jan. '95). Here goes:

"The "psychographics" of Porsche owners produce five unusual, and not
necessarily flattering, personal profiles, according to a report in Fortune
magazine detailing market research conducted by Porsche Cars North America.
The company recruited a team of anthropologists to find out who was buying
Porsches.

The five Porsche owning groups the anthropologists defined are Top Guns,
Elitists, Proud Patrons, Bon Vivants and Fantasisers.

Mr. Bartsch said Porsche Australia had no plans to go down the same route
in determining the characteristics of Porsche's growing list of local
owners. The company celebrated the end of 1994 after lifting sales by more
than 50 per cent, to 212 units against 140 sold in 1993."

Next to this article is a cartoon; One man is interviewing another - a desk
between the two. Interviewer to small, bald man: "We're doing a survey on
Porsche drivers: Are you (a) small, (b) bald, (c) old, (d) a jerk?"

An accompanying article mentions that Porsche Australia hopes to sell the
Boxter late in '96 for under Aus $100,00.00.

Thought, anyone?

John
JOHNM@icac.org

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 11:29:04 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: Disgruntled new Porschephile

  I must remark, however, that your group must not be interested in people
>with little knowledge about the cars--you come accross as a bunch of snobs
>rather than people who would willingly help those of us who probably need the

Mr. X,
    I am a rather new recipient of this list also. I can't beleive you 
feel that there are a bunch of "snobs" here. I have felt that there is
a great variety of information/personality available. I feel it is
(to quote the FAQ) a feature. I have received better information and
advice here than anywhere else I know of.


>help most. Early on, I asked a question about performance chips. I got one
>really good response, another from a guy selling chips and SILENCE from the
>rest. Next, via email yet, I followed up a note about paint work procedures
>(I have numerous chips on the hood and have never worked on paint on a car
>-let alone a Porsche) requesting help to get started. I got SILENCE. 

I thought the general opinion on these devices was that they are
cash flow devices. As far as paint touch up is concerned I have had
reasonable luck using touchup paint then wet sanding the area, and retouching
it again. The object is to build up the chipped area to the original level
of the rest of the paint. Normaly takes 3 or 4 times to make it look
reasonable. Afterwards one uses compound and then polish/wax to bring
it up to it's original finish. The idea is to have a surface that the eye
doesen't catch. If you stare at your finished work, chances are that you
will notice the work. Then again my Porsches live inside in the winter.

>For what its worth, you as a group
>come accross as a bunch of aristocrats (in your own minds).. 

 Guess everyone has an opinion, we all know what that's worth;-) Stick around
 You might find something of interest.

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0
1966 911 cpe (in renewal state)

Date: 14 Feb 95 08:46
From: jcjensen@raychem.com
Subject: 911 2.7: install shuffe pins?


[Text item: Text_1]
     Hi P-groupies:
     
     I've seen the process of installing shuffle pins (aka 
     anti-shuffle pins or dowel pins) advertised.  I know almost 
     nothing about this.
     
     As I understand it, pins are installed around the crankshaft area 
     in one case half with corresponding holes in the other half.  
     This prevents the case halves from sliding or shuffling around 
     the crankshaft.  This process seems to require incredible 
     precision; if the pin/hole combo is off, the bearings will bind, 
     and if the holes are slightly oversized to ensure non-binding 
     then the pins really won't prevent shuffling.
     
     I am rebuilding a 911 2.7 and wondered when this process is 
     appropriate.  Is it really only used for very high revving race 
     applications?  My engine will be a standard RS with 7300 rpm 
     redline, probably making around 230 hp.  Car use will be street 
     and occasional track.
     
     Any thoughts would be appreciated.
     
     Jeff Jensen
     jcjensen@raychem.com
     73 911 Carrera RS
     one disgruntled cat

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 9:20:18 PST
From: Steve Bochinski <Steve.Bochinski@wellsfargo.com>
Subject: Re: Stalling 911 SC

A very mysterious problem I have had on and off for the past 2 years
of owning my 73 911 was randomly the tach would drop to zero and the
past redline, a misfiring about once/hour of operation and finally
last weekend in Reno, I started up the car drove it 2 minutes and
it shut off, would not start at all, but did turnover.

Well, the triple A guy comes out and fiddles with the points with
his screwdriver and the car starts!  I decided to wait till monday
before going back to San Francisco and went by Motor Classics in Reno
first thing Monday morning.  The mechanic there tells me that it
is very common in my car that carbon from the distributor gets into
the points and causes all of the above symptoms.  I put in a new
set of points, but the guy was very nice and even showed me how to
clean the points with a business card in case I get stuck out in
the woods...  Hope this helps you, but you might have another type
of distributore.
 
Steve

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 11:22:09 -0600
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  914 Horn Help?

Hello all,

At some point, a previous owner had installed an aftermarket steering wheel on my 914.  It was
later replaced with the original.  Unfortunately, I am missing some pieces inside the steering
wheel for the horn contact.  If I remove the center section of the steering wheel, I see a hole at
the edge of the center hub that has the horn wire in it.  The wire is cut off flush with the hub.  There
is a stamped steel ring attached to the hub to which the center section clips.  This ring has a
hole in it which is aligned with the hole in the hub where the cut wire is.  Something is apparently
supposed to go in this hole and attach to the horn wire in order for the horn to work.
Does anyone know what piece(s) am I missing?

Thanks,
Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

Date: 14 Feb 95 12:36:53 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Valve clearance, help

 
Jerry Brady reports that he has zero valve clearance on #4 exhaust, even
with adjusting screw removed.
 
Probably the valve has pounded its way into the seat, so the stem sticks out
into the head a lot farther than it's supposed to and takes up all the
available adjustment space. I've seen this before. This is not good and
can't continue for long. Eventually the valve seat breaks into little
pieces, some go out the exhaust pipe, some don't...Replace/recondition that
head. A temporary solution, but not a good one, is to put HARDENED washers
under the rocker stands to space them out a bit. If you do a compression or
leakdown test, chances are that you won't even detect anything "wrong" with
that cylinder.
 
A good book to explain this sort of butchery is the "VW Repair for the
Compleat Idiot" book by John Muir. It's good for get-you-home or dead-broke
college student type repairs, but the only right way is to fix that head. If
the damage is limited to the seat, a good shop can probably press a new seat
in for you at reasonable cost.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 10:41:21 -0700 (MST)
From: bshort@usa.net (Byron D. Short / AFS Inc.)
Subject: Re: EF Region

My primary reason for supporting the concept of the EF Region is that I 
see it as a good way to help assure the longterm viability of 
Porschephiles.  Becoming a region of PCA does offer a few hoops, but we 
don't have to handle ourselves the way other regions do.  My suggestion 
is this.  Since PCA requires Porsche ownership, EF Region must therefore 
require Porsche ownership.  However, non-PCA members can and do attend 
PCA functions in some regions.  Our primary function is, of course, 
porschephiles.  

So...

Members of the EF Region must own Porsches, must pay dues, etc. 
Non-members are those who, for whatever reasons of their own, (starving
students, them damned ferrenners, non-P Car owners, etc) who still
participate in our one great perpetual event (Porschephiles).  In their
case, they pay a yearly fee, (just like a non-member still has to pay to
run the auto-x), which is (surprise) just like the region portion of the
annual dues.  Special rates for starving students and other deserving
contributors are common at autocrosses, etc, and could be applied here as
well. 

PCA should have no problem with this structure; all we're really doing is 
allowing non-members to participate in our one great perpetual 
event--Porschephiles.

- --

                   *   to do real work, I'd have gotten a real job!    *

                   *    lack the time to make it shorter." -- Pascal   *

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 10:17:41 -0800
From: dthompsn@ix.netcom.com (William D. Thompson)
Subject: RE: Disgruntled Porschephile

Amid the flames that have responded to your request, I see a number of 
people offered useful suggestions and advice.  I can't offer much advice 
on performance chips (the only thing "electronic" in my '72 911T is the 
radar detector) but paint chips are something we all fight.  I don't 
know what PCA region you are in, but I'd strongly suggest you attend 
some meetings of your region and you will find more help than you'll 
probably ever need.  In the Potomac region (D.C. area), we have 
designated experts on each Porsche series.  Enrolling in driver's ed is 
a good way to learn how to drive your new toy the way it should be 
driven and most regions also have regular tech sessions.  You've paid 
your money to belong to PCA, so you might as well put it to the best 
use. It's always amazed me that of the 1,400 members we have in our 
region, it is only the same 50-75 people who come to the meetings and 
the events.

Doug Thompson
'72 911T
'71 914
'74 TR6

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 10:25:31 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: PCA membership


Hi all,

To be a member of PCA it costs $36 (US) per annum. Regions are allowed
surcharges for special things like extra postage, etc.

You must also be an owner, part owner or leasse of a Porsche at time of 
application.

So...what does this mean?
Not a lot to those that own a car under the definition above. Just send 
your application or affiliation to PCA headquarters with EFR listed as
your region.

For those of you who don't own (but have a strong desire to) a Porsche
there is a simple solution. Be an affiliate with all priviledges of
EFR participation except those which require a national membership. I'm 
sure and easy way can be worked out. I think this availability is what 
this is all about. I would not like to see these participants excluded.

For international members, you are now an American as far as PCA is 
concerned. Your address is a little different, that's all. In this info 
world it is possible. 

The lady at Porsche AG is Ilse Naedle, I hope I spelled Frau Naedle 
correctly. She coordinates activites between the factory and the various 
Porsche clubs world-wide. A charming lady.

So far, I've seen a lot of positive ideas passed by, except by Mr. 
Disgruntled. 

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 11:27:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: new injectors


>I plan on using vaseline on the O rings as a little lubricant so they
>don't get damaged and they slip in/on OK....any comments ?

Martin,

Use a little fuel or motor oil instead.  Otherwise, no prep required.
Do be careful pushing the plastic hat onto the end of each injector.
The best technique known to me is to seat the hat in a deep socket
of just the right ID, and use it to push the hat on.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 11:35:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Disgruntled new Porschephile


Hi,

With respect to your question regarding chips, the same damn question
gets asked about once a week.  People get tired of answering it, which is
why there are FAQ's.

Moreover, no one *owes* you an answer.  This list is a voluntary community,
no one gets paid, and a lot of us pay to participate.  If you want to get 
owed
an answer, go to a local dealer or shop, credit card in hand.

To answer the question, you will not get any meaningful power gains from
an '85 Carrera by changing the chip, unless you also change other things as
well.  I published a set of dyno result a few months ago, which showed what
does and does not work.  If you are nice to me, I might dig 'em out.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 11:23:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 oil leak


Dennis,

It's basically impossible to change a 944's oil filter without making a
mess, and that's probably what you have on your hands.  Oil tends
to get onto the P/S pump and other surrounding bits, and onto the
belly pan.

Best solution is to drop the pan, clean it with a degreaser such as
Simple Green, and wipe down what you can of the P/S pump, etc.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 11:21:00 EST

>There is a global club co-ordinator, Ilse <can't remember surname>,

Ilse Naedele (where "ae" is really a-umlaut).

K.

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 12:12:21 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Horn Help?

        BT, DT...  Sorta.
        The horn contact is a metal ring on the center pad.  The ring
has a metal tab in the middle of it which the push-on connector which
should be on the end of the wire connects to.  When you push the pad,
you rock it one way or t'other on the rubber pivot, the metal ring
makes contact with the ring on the wheel part, you get a circuit, and
BEEP!  My metal tab broke off, and the wire grounded itself to the
rest of the wheel.  On the highway--very embarrassing!
        You should be able to get new bits from one or another of the
wreckers.

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 11:02:34 -0800
From: pouceta@itersd1.iterus.org (Andre Poucet)
Subject: Re: 911 T to RS replica

> ...
>   By the way, what is the number of the engine?  I own an RS, but it
>does not have the original engine.  I've always dreamed of finding the
>original engine for it.
>   Good luck with your project!
>
>Claudia Conrad
>1973 Carrera RS
>1971 914-6

Claudia,

Thanks for your message.

The type number of the RS engine (that's the number you can find on a small
horizontal surface on the block behind where the oil pressure transmitter
is)
is 911/83.

The engine is very much like a 2.4 S engine with a bigger bore (but
certainly not boring!) and with a modified MFI pump.


Andre Poucet

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 10:44:42 PST
From: ssu!scruffy!myers@nbn.nbn.com (Alan W. Myers)
Subject: valve/timing adjust w/o the timing marks

Thank you, to whoever it was (perhaps George B.)
who sent me the info on finding TDC.  I read it
thought, this is a _great_ idea! and promptly deleted my message (ooops!).
Unfortunately after thinking about it awhile, monitoring the points to see when
the gap closes to find TDC only will work if  the timing is adjusted 
properly.  But... my timing marks are worn off, and if my timing's off,
I'm back to square one.  Which brings up another question:  
How does one adjust the timing without the timing marks on the impeller?
Again, Thanks,
alan
myers@abratech.com

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 11:06:51 PST
From: pat@cor.cerfnet.com (Pat Hohl [5607])
Subject: Summary:  What causes 944 engine clicking?

Here is a summary of several answers to
my question regarding the cause of 944 
engine "clicking" that sounds something
like noisy valves.


Yes, it is a common noise.

It's not a hyd lifter, and there is no way to
"adjust" the hyd lifters like there is in some
american iron.

The fuel injector solenoids make a click noise.
Use a good injector cleaner at every oil change.

An exhaust leak from one cylinder can cause
a similar sound.

 -pat
'84 944

advertise it for.   This car looks good with it's stainless steel roll bar,
chrome parts, and targa top.  Still debating, as I have been for about two
years, whether to sell it or not. But I need the money for a down payment for
either a newer toy or a house to put one in.  I've owned it about 4 years, and
I think I'm the third owner.  I believe that the engine and transmission were
rebuilt before I bought it (don't remember and don't have records, but I do
have the previous owners phone number.)  I know I should have taken it in for a
pre-purchase inspection, but I was young and didn't have the wisdom of this
list then, plus the car was "me" when I saw it.

'71 911 T Targa Red ( used to be a mustard color.)

Comfort option 14' Fuch's.

for older Porsche work.)

Rust started on front pan (where battery acid must have run down?, I've seen
this before on a 912 I looked at and noticed it recently on my car.)

Yokohama 388 205/70/HR14 (less than about 2,000 miles on them)

Carburetor kits.

Porsche engine spanner (to turn the engine with the pulley).
Jack.

I checked.  So I feel that $8,500 is a good price for it.  I bought it for
$8,000 and invested many more dollars and hours into it since then that I'll
never recover, but it's been worth it.  So, what do you think it's worth and
are you interested?  Trades + $ for newer Porsche will be considered.

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 11:38:35 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re[2]: leakdown tester

> I am thinking about getting a leakdown tester, but have never
> seen one for sale anywhere. What are the brands and where
> are they sold?

I noted with some surprise that Engine Builders Supply is now selling
a leak-down tester for $49. Their ads are *everywhere*...

Stan

The leak-down tester that EBS sells is not the conventional Pressure fed
type leak down tester.  It is a Vacuum based device, that is related to 
the Vacuum brake bleeder and vacuum device tester, with some different 
adapters.  I know this because I purchased one.  I have not used it yet,
but I'm sure it will give some engine health indication.  I am not sure if
it will give the same results from using a pressure fed device. The loading
on the rings would be different and not like that of normal operation.

Dan

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 15:14:19 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Paint Chip Repair

A possible alternative to the last step in the detailed and excellent methods
to repair paint chips offered by Mr. Millman may be as follows.

1. The touchup paint has been applied to the surface and allowed to dry for
at least 1 week, and resembles a minute mound ( __o__ ){ this is exagerated}
on the flat plane of the existing paint.  The object is to remove the mound
and make the surface of the paint one continous flat plane.  Instead of
polishing compound on a diaper,  try a Meguiar 2000 grit Finesse Block.  The
Finesse Block offers the ability to gently remove only the high spot of the
repair.  Unlike sandpaper or polish on a rag, the five usable sides of the
block are flat and act like a "wood plane"  to remove only the elevated areas
of the repair.  The 2000 grit will not leave scratches.

2. Soak the Finesse Block in clean water for 24 hours prior to use.  Then
gently "plane" the high spot on the paint.  I prefer to "plane" in one
direction (usually back to front - drawing the block towards me).  If the
block dries out, rewet and continue use.  When the new and existing paints
are blended (smoothed to the flat plane) to your satisfaction, clean the area
with a quality car wash and then use a quality glaze to restore the high
gloss finish.  I prefer 3M Imperial Hand Glaze.  Don't use a machine on your
Porsche,  as they deserve to be caressed by hand.  Use the machine on your
Yugo. 

3.  When applying either a glaze or a wax,  apply to your soft cotton cloth
or applicator pad (don't squirt the stuff on the car) and work in one directio
n only.  Don't go around in circles like dear of dad .  Circles are many
times the cause of "swirl marks" .  A front to back / back to front motion
(the way the air flows over the car) will help minimize swirl marks or at
least make them less visible.  Buff out with a soft cotton cloth.  If it
looks good, wax with a quality hard wax and you are done.

4. Tip for applying wax.  If you are using a quality carnuba based wax, try
applying it with you fingers instead of a pad or cloth.  Hold your fingers
together and use your finger tips as an applicator pad.  The tactile feedback
from your fingers will tell you when the wax has been worked into the paint.
 If grit should lodge under your fingers, you will know immediately and not
grind it into the paint.  A pad will not allow this tactile feedback and
these devil grits become sandpaper.  A circular motion of the pad has made a
360 degree swirl mark.  All marks on paint are most visible at a 90 degree
viewing angle.  Thus the front to back marks are most visible from the sides,
whereas a circle stands out from any viewing angle.

I hope that the above may provide some additional food for thought on the
subject of chips.


Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specialties
Distributors of Quality Car Care Products
carcaresp@aol.com
Phone (201) 796-8300 
Fax (201) 791-9743

944 Turbo
944 S2 Cabrio
1 Wife
4 Kids
1 Grandchild
1 Granddog 
0 Farm Animals

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 12:42:06 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Timing Marks


Alan-

An infallible way to find TDC , and also to recalibrate
the timing mark on your crankshaft pulley, is to remove 
the #1 spark plug.  Turn the engine (BY HAND) and in 
order of preference:

1) Mount a depth gauge in the spark plug hole and watch 
for TDC as you rotate the engine.

2) Hold a screwdriver vertically in the hole as you turn 
the engine and see when it reaches its apex.  Don't use a 
pencil or something that can break off if it gets jammed.  
(Don't ask me why I give you that last piece of advice.)

3) Look down the hole as you turn the engine and spot 
when the piston is at its peak.

The piston reaches TDC twice in each 4-cycle event.  
You'll want to know if you are at TDC on the compression 
stroke since that's where you want to set the timing.  
When you find one of the TDC's, see if the distributor 
rotor is pointing towards the terminal that goes to the 
spark plug in cylinder #1.  That's the right TDC.  Mark the 
pulley.  If it isn't, continue to turn the engine to the next 
TDC..  It will be the right one.

You can do this for each cylinder if you wish, or simply 
use a
protractor to locate the other pulley marks.

Does this help you?


Bob Spindel
'72 911E Restored and Running!!!

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 15:26:35 EST
From: tynor@atlanta.twr.com (Steve Tynor)
Subject: Cleaning a neglected car

OK, I admit it. I take a sort of perverse pride in not washing my
car. As the year goes on, it accumulates more and more grime and melted
rubber (track events, donchya know). Once every couple of months, I give
it a half hearted once over with a bucket of soapy water and a sponge,
but that really just takes away the surface grime.  The melted tires and
more stubborn stains are undeterred and unaffected.

About once a year, I get the urge to really clean the car.  Get rid of
the grime; get rid of the melted rubber. Buff it with some McGuires
pre-wax cleaner and give it a good coat of wax.  The problem is that in
order to get the stubborn stains and tire marks, I seem to have to
resort to strong solvents (like gasoline or undiluted Simple Green)
and/or abrasives (rubbing/polishing compounds) and lots of elbow grease.
I suspect that none of this is good for my paint.

I'd really like to find a "better" / "easier" way.  Is there one? (I
hope the answer isn't "don't let it get so bad...").

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
Porsche is a two syllable word.
  '74 914 2L (silver being overtaken by rust) [toy car]
  '87 951    (grimy guards red w/ specks of melted rubber) [track car 
	      and daily driver]
  no cats

Steve Tynor		Internet: Steve.Tynor@atlanta.twr.com
Tower Technology	UUCP:     twratl!Steve.Tynor
			WWW:      http://www.cm.cf.ac.uk/Tower/

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 16:19:37 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: RE: 944 oil leak

>It's basically impossible to change a 944's oil filter without making a
>mess, and that's probably what you have on your hands.  Oil tends
>to get onto the P/S pump and other surrounding bits, and onto the
>belly pan.
>Kevin Gross

I have found a better way. Buy a roll of aluminum roof flashing (which,
BTW, is right up there with duct tape, bailing wire and chewing gum as
a universal fix-it material). It is about 0.010" thick, and easy to cut
with sissors, bend with your fingers, etc. Cut a piece about a foot
long and perhaps 6-8" wide, then cut and bend it until it forms a nice
cup under the lower edge of the filter, and forms a trough which carries
the oil which leaks from the filter when you loosen it out past the
edge of the belly pan. Put your oil drain pan under the end of the
trough. You may need to try more than once to get something which
stays in place as you loosen the filter, doesn't leak from the sides,
etc., but it is not that hard, and the stuff is cheap enough to try
several times. Mine doesn't leak a drop when I remove the filter this
way.

Then do the same thing for all of your other cars where the *%$# designer
mounted the oil filter in an inaccessible space, drippy side down.
Each car will require a unique design, but a roll of aluminum will
make a whole bunch of troughs.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 16:28:43 -0500
From: AllPorsche@aol.com
Subject: Re:Disgruntled Porschephile

Dear Mr. X (Name ???)

I am sorry that you feel this way. However, before flaming the list
generically as snobbish, some introspection may be helpful. You could ask
yourself *WHY* you didn't get an immediate amswer to your questions:
 - Nobody knows the answer
 -The question may have been answered 15 times last week, and the week
before....if possible, check the Porschephiles Archives.
 -You posted the question on a low traffic day. If the sun is out, or a great
autox on Sunday when you posted the message, many people will quickly scan
the mail on Monday when other work needs attended to.
 -The one person that knows the answer is on vacation etc...

I recently asked a question about parking brake adjustment on turbo bodies
and got 1 reply. However when I needed info on towing a 914, over 30 people
responded...

This list is not the *ONLY* source of information.

I assume that you have Panorama and some technical books on your Porsche such
as the Hayes manual, Upfixin-Der-Porsche etc.. Cars are not difficult to work
on, but a ton of different skills are required: Bodywork, painting,
upholstery, electrics, engine, mechanicals etc...A lot can be learned by
doing it. Unfortunately, there is nobody on this list who can change you into
an experienced painter. It takes reading, looking, imitating, mistakes,
trying, and trying before the basic skills are mastered. So be not surprised
if you get little response to basic skill questions. 

Again, I am truly sorry that you feel disappointed in your expectations of
the list. I look at the list more as an extended circle of friends with a
common interest. We are from diverse backgrounds, and all add a little bit.
There is often great trust between members when parts are swapped. Commonly,
I have either sent parts before receiving payment, or sent money upfront. It
has been an emotional support structure whenever a friend cried for help,
something I have yet to see happening on any other Internet special interest
group. I believe that the strong hand of the Listmeister has given this list
a closer, familial feel than most other mailers. Rather than "snobbish", most
people here are as down to earth as it gets (Gold chains, open shirt, cool
shades, you know.. :-)

Enjoy you Porsche and lighten up !

Bart D
'87 911 Cabrio (Black/Black)
'87 911 Turbolook Cabrio (Platinum Blue/Camel)(temporary visitor)
'87 951 (Black/Black)
'74 914 2.0 Porschephile Racer (Tangerine/Black)
'74 914 1.8 Project 914-6 (Summer Yellow/Black)
'73 914 2.0 Future Project (Signal Orange/Black)
'93 Grand Cherokee Ltd. Family and Car Hauler (Diamond Blue)
