Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 13:17:34 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Re: Nate's 914 question du jour.

    Just wondering... I've seen various people mentioning that they have
a 911 "combination instrument" in their 914's, and I have also seen in
the Auto Atlanta catalog a mention of a factory oil temp. gauge that
fits in place of the brake warning light.  I would really like to have a
temp. gauge in my car as I have no idea what the condition of my
thermostat is.
    Here's my question - with either of these swaps, what kind of sender
would I have to use?  Are all p-car senders basically standard, or did
they change with year/model?  Which swap would you recommend?
    Also, just assuming on the wild chance I could find a set of 911
gauges, what would be required to make them work with my 914?  How would
I make the tach work with my 1.7? (or maybe a set of 912 gauges would
work?)
    Just pondering at random, wasting bandwidth like a madman,

Nate

'71 914
Nate

There are a couple of answers to the instrument question.  First, Later
914s had a temp gauge where the old and large parking brake light were, the
light is now like the oil pressure light.  I don't think this was an option,
but just available on later models.  You will have to do some re-wiring - minor.
I should also mention that the face-style of these instruments can be slighty
different as well.

As far as the 911 cluster, I thing what is being referred to is the combination
Oil temp and pressure instrument.  This fits where the 914 gas gauge cluster
is.  The problem is that will not provide a gas gauge for you.  You will have
mount a separate gas gauge, probably near center dash (console area).  These 
are available from Automobile Atlanta.  Make sure that you get the correct one
for the year 914 as the senders are different in the early years.  

As far as the senders.  Well, you want to make sure that the sender matches the
gauge movement.  If you remove the gauge movement from the cluster, you can see
small hand written numbers which are the temperature calibration numbers.  
Choose your sender based on these.  The oil pressure sender will be a VDO part
for the model year 911 the cluster came from.  There are two styles available.
One has just the pressure transducer and the other has both the transducer and
the idiot light switch.  

Have fun

Dan
 \
dswiger@qntm.com
dswiger180@qntm.com

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 16:36:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: lesson learned


>Before changing oil on 944s/late 924s, punch a
>hole in the top of the oil filter that way all the oil in it flows down
>and wont spill when u undo the filter.

This is OK to do *after* you have broken the filter free, ie, got it
to turn a bit.  You don't want to punch a hole, find the filter frozen,
then have to figure out a way to get the car to your mechanic
with a holed filter.

K.

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 16:15:58 CST
From: Brian=Wagner%Radio%WILL@bigbird.will.uiuc.edu
Subject: What is that thang

 On page 5 of the latest Panorama, there is a picture of the Porsche WSC car
(Mario Andretti walking in front of it). From the middle of the front 
"spoiler" (?) there projects a device, a rod with a 90 degree bend pointing 
ahead. What is that? A Pitot tube, perhaps?
 -Brian


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 17:34:28 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: Re: What is that thang

Actually it's a fuel deatomizer recovery device.  The idea is that the
WSC car comes up behind the ferraris and collects all the unburnt fuel
coming out of the exhaust.  This cuts down on pit-stops for refueling
by nearly 6%.

Since it's limited to ferraris because of optimal exhaust height
collection, it's only usually functional for the first half of the
race.

I have some for sale for the PCA racing.  Available in fiberglass for
$300 or carbon fibre for $625.  Mine have a goosenech adjustable for
anything from 914s to 951s.  DOn't work on C2s though.  Combiustion's
too efficient.

FYI,
	Steve
- ----- Begin Included Message -----

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 17:31:34 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: Oils-Again!


Text item: Text_1

After my last posting I did some research on what is used on the motors which 
generate my paycheck, up to 110,000 lb thrust,yea its the correct number of 
zeros. Basic oil spec allows dino and synthetic BUT oils are approved by brand 
and type, just because it meets basic spec doesn't cut the mustard. Main problem
as you have probably guessed is coking due to heat soak after shut down. Most 
operators use Mobil Jet A, I believe Castrol has caused coking problems. On this
basis does any one have experience of Mobil 1 (I think thats the right one for 
us)?
Other things which might interest are that there is never an 'Oil Change' 
consumption at .05 th .2 gph causes refills to keep the oil fresh, closed 
systems get an oil change about every 600 hrs so the starter which has 500-700 
c.c. in it does 250,000 miles between oil changes! Oil filter gets changed any 
where between 500 and 15000 hours but does have an impending blockage indicator 
and SOAP smples (oil analysis) is frequent. Oil temperature run around 250F but 
can get to 350 on rare occasions. Under these conditions 15000 hrs between 
overhauls is common and 25000 is not unknown.
Thread to P-philes is that after all of this I am now leaning towards synthetic,
Mobil, for the 930 engine and probably for the tranny too.
Thanks for all of the public and direct responses.

neil_nw_walker@ae.ge.com

Don't be so hard on us.  There are hundreds of us (a thousand now?) and
many of us figure someone with better experience or more time or just
special interest in your specific query will give it the right attention.
Most of the time a simple, "This is my 2nd post on this matter...won't
someone
help?" will take care of it.  I can assure you we do not discriminate against
new Porsche owners.

Congrats on your 85 Carrera.  I'm on my 4th Carrera now, and my sixth
911/912.  These cars are great fun and you'll love it.

Re performance chips: my first hand experience is they are a waste of money.
In my case the 89 911 came with an AutoThority chip.  And frankly I couldn't
be sure I noticed *any* difference.  Bruce Anderson, local 911 guru, did an
article for Excellence Magazine a couple years back.   His benchmarking
didn't show much, if any, performance improvement.  Sorry I don't have
details
at hand but I can look up the article and refer you to Excellence if you
like.

There have been some good postings about paint chip repairs over the last
couple of years.  Perhaps it would be worth your time checking the archives.
Or maybe you'll get some good advice from a kindly reader with the know-how.
Not my strength.

Hope that helps.  And go a little easier on us.  This group is terrific but
it
takes an investment of time just to weed through all the mail!

Porschephiles #1167                         Tue Feb 14 19:36:28 CST 1995
Date: 14 Feb 1995 14:12:30 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: 87 911 price

                      Subject:                              Time:  1:57 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         87 911 price                          Date:  2/14/95

> From: drozt@comm.mot.com (Peter Drozt)
> Subject: '87 Carrera
> Re 87 911 for $27k...

Peter,
I would agree that the price is a little high for an 87.  You should be
able to get a good 87 for $22-24k or so.  I recently sold a fairly high
mileage 88 factory turbo-look in *great shape* for $26.5k.  And a
near-perfect low mileage 89 silver anniv coupe for $28.5k.

But I am also convinced you should spend a little more for a very good
example.  A poorly maintained car will end up costing you more in the
long run; on these cars maintenance makes all the difference.  And
appearance, inside and out, is usually very telling.

There are no special trouble spots on these cars.  Cam towers, oil
return tubes sometimes leak.  The rear torsion bar brace is known
to fail (too many speed bumps?) but the updated bracket is much better.
Get it inspected by a pro and look for signs of collision.  Do the
leakdown test.  Check the service records carefully and look to see
whether the owner has cut corners.

I would shy away from adding spoilers and wings.  Originality matters
a lot to many people.  Find a different car is this is important.

87-89 are my favorite years.  I had very good luck with several
Carreras.

Regards,
Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
95 993 coupe, guards red
85 535i, everyday grey
PCA# 91049838

Better include California buyers. The cars can be taken out of CA, 
registered in AZ which eliminates the Salvage designation from the title, 
then reregistered in CA with a clean title.

BTW for those that expresssed interest in the "911 Submarine (84 Carrera)" 
that was in this category, the insurance company still hasn't set a date for 
auctioning the vehicle and will not talk to private buyes. Last word as to 
auction date is "March or April"

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 13:32:19 -0800
From: gblanche@qntm.com
Subject: 911 Prices...

People seem to ask about typical prices for 911s.  I'll offer the 
following list to help:

Year  Median Price

1978  12,800
1979  12,500
1980  15,025
1981  16,900
1982  17,900
1983  15,898
1984  18,900
1985  19,500
1986  23,995
1987  24,500
1988  27,650
1989  29,900

I use "Median Price" to prevent extremely high or low asking prices from 
affecting the numbers.  This was generated from data I collected from 
P.M.L., a publication I would recommend if you're in the market for any 
Porsche.  This prices here are for coupes only...sorry that's the only 
one I did.  You can probably get a good enough idea from these numbers 
to extrapolate a cost for a Targa or Cabrio if that's what you're after.


Greg Blanchette
gblanche@qntm.com
"If only that 911 Club Sport was under $30K..."

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 15:11:00 PST
From: "Johanson, Al" <AJohanson@ea.com>
Subject: Re: 911 gauges in a 914


Nate wrote one day....

>    Also, just assuming on the wild chance I could find a set of 911
>gauges, what would be required to make them work with my 914?

I wondered about that too.....and then decided the easiest way
to get the gauges to work was to install a 911 engine.  :-)

If the info you have doesn't seem to work, call Getty Design.
Look for their ads in the usual places.  They sell (or did anyway) a
911 dashboard for your 914.  I'm sure not all of their customers
had 914-6's....so they might know about the required senders.

If you wanted all 911 gauges then you could buy their 911 dash.
Then you'll have 5 holes to fill.....oil pressure/temp, speedo, tach,
fuel/oil level, and a clock.  Oil level gauge won't do you much good,
but perhaps you could make a windshield washer fluid gauge out
of it....

sand in it when the car is running, say 2K rpm on up.  I've heard that when
the tensioners fail it sounds like "gravel in a mixer", so am I paranoid or
am I hearing next-to-failure?  Again, the car has 118K miles on it.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 15:56:17 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: CIS Injector Seals

> 
> From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
> Subject: new injectors
> 
> [stuff deleted]
> 
> Is there anything I should do to either the injectors or the car to
> prepare these things or just pop them in ?
> 
> I plan on using vaseline on the O rings as a little lubricant so they
> don't get damaged and they slip in/on OK....any comments ?
>

When I did mine I was chasing a vacuum leak at the same time.  Even with
NEW o-rings I wasn't getting a satisfactory seal around the injectors.
I guess the proper fix would've been to track down the next larger size
o-ring.  Instead what I did was

1) clean and degrease injector
2) lube o-ring (I used Parker O-Lube)
3) install o-ring on injector from bottom
4) clean and degrease injector bore
5) press injector and o-ring into place; o-ring kind of "clicks"
   into its seat 
6) (this is the different part) flow self-levelling RTV onto top
   of o-ring (in the small recess there) to guarantee the seal.
   I used Dow 3140 which is a non-acidic aircraft/electronic sealant
   (and pri$ed accordingly) but any "self leveling" (flowable)
   hardware store silicone oughta do.  NOT bathtub caulk though!

Mine stayed sealed for 100k miles until my next injector replacement,
and the RTV was soft enough to pop out of the intake tube without much
hassle when the time came.

For checking/monitoring mixture an independent meter like the gastester
is invaluable but don't forget that on the '80-'83 SCs the CIS brain
(under the passenger seat) provides a diagnostic output that tells how
much lean/rich adjustment the brain is providing to the fuel
distributor.  The output is a pulse duty cycle calibrated so you can
read it with an ordinary dwell meter (the one you haven't touched since
you GOT your SC!).  I forget what pin the signal is on; it's in one of
the Bosch FI books or I can look it up if anyone's interested.  Anyway
this output is super handy for tracking down intake leaks ("probe" with
an unlit butane lighter), setting the static mixture, etc.; it is also
fun to watch when underway as you can see the brain compensate for
altitude changes, watch the warmup cycle, verify that the Wide Open
Throttle system is working (brain should go open loop), etc.  Another
interesting data point for gauge freaks like me.

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 16:08:56 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Stalling in Cold Weather

>
> Two days ago I drove my '83 911 SC about 85 miles at an average speed *of
> 70mph.   Temperature was in the high 20s.  As I braked getting off the
> expressway and fell below 40mph the car stalled.  I stopped and the car
> started right up, but then stalled again.  It started right up again and
> with  a little help on the throttle I made it to a light a few 100 yards
> away where the car stalled again.  Once again it started right up and I
> drove perhaps a mile where I had to stop - car ran perfectly.  The car has
> continued to operate perfectly.
> 
> TIA
> Elliot 
> 

Hmmm, when I lived in a cold place and drove a carbureted car these
symptoms were consistent with either 1) ice in a fuel line or 2) ice in
the venturi.  I presume these can both happen to a CIS car although 1)
the fuel pump's much stronger and the fuel goes in circles continuosly,
and 2) the venturi (read "throttle plate") is nowhere near as critical,
so I kind of doubt whether it would ice up.  Was the humidity high (fog,
snow, freezing rain, etc) at the time?

The traditional fix was Dry-Gas (alcohol, usually methanol, sometimes
ethanol).  On a CIS car this must be used with caution though!  Possibly
you could drain and dry your gas tank if you decide this is the problem?

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 18:36:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Sebring PCA Club Race


>OK, I'm dying of curiosity!  Did the Porsche WSC car show up for the 
Sebring
>Club race or was this a hoax?  If so, who drove it?    Anything else of
>interest at the Club Race?

No, it was registered but did not show up.  There were an awful lot of very
fast and very tuned cars.  The lead dogs in the A class were two 935's
(one ex-John Paul, the other the Bayside car) and an (ex?) Kelly-Moss
SuperCup car.  The Champion car which Stuck et al drove at the 24 hrs
of Daytona was also on display.

The event was *very* well run, and I had a blast.  I did not compete; I 
drove
in the "touring" groups, which meant run groups all three days.  That was
a really nice touch, mixing in non-competitive driver/ing.  Other nice 
touches
included the framed participation trophy everyone took home, the dinners,
and that two regions co-sponsored the event.

I had a local instructor sit in my passenger seat, John M., a super nice
guy.  Sebring is a seventeen-turn circuit, apparently the oldest race
track in the country, and it is a kick.  Two turns, one at the end of the
runway and onto the front straight, the other at the end of that front
straight, rate an easy eleven on the pucker factor scale.

Kevin

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 19:05:44 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Re: Oil pumps for 911

 <<<<Dan said>>>>

>Does anyone know about reconditioning or rebuilding of 911 oil pumps.
>I am rebuilding a 2.2 liter motor for a 914/6.  I have a pump from a 2.4
>liter that looks a little rough, and the I don't presently know the 
>condition of the pump in the 2.2 motor.  Also does anyone know who has the
>best price on new pumps.

 The pricing I have found on new pumps for my 2.0 were in the $450-$550
range. The best was either Derentz or Westex (forget which). I found 1
better. Send your pump to Lukes&Shoreman. They'll rebuild it for you for
$242.00. That's the route I took. I was told that I didn't realy need to
have it rebuilt but, once they open it you are in for the full program.
I feel $242 is cheap insurance for a rebuild!




Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0
1966 911 cpe (in renewal state)

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 20:09:59 -0500
From: TimK913781@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 Test Drives...

gblanche@qntm.com wrote ...

 I felt a solid shove in the back, but not the sense of immediacy I had imagin
ed would be there.  The revs just didn't climb very fast.  Each gear felt
equally capable of adding velocity, and the engine felt flexible just not as
sweet as I had imagined.  I tried to blame my lack of expertise with 911s for
the poor performance...but my test simply involved flooring the pedal in
second gear...no real skill required.

... end of quote.

When I first started test driving 911s, I had some of the same feelings --
until I liked one enough to have a Porsche mechanic look it over.  Part of
the pre-purchase inspection involved a quick drive with the mechanic; he
drove.  He tooled around a little bit, listening for valve clatter and the
usual suspects.  We turned around and he started DRIVING.  We did a quick
130, followed by an impressive display of breaking and a tour of a nice
S-curve.  I knew I wasn't in my wife's Miata anymore.  Boy, that was fun.

 Now that I've owned that same car (78 911SC) for two years, I've come to
appreciate that the car doesn't come into its own until a few twists are
thrown at it.  It scoots along just fine in a straight line, but any
16-year-old kid of average hormonal balance in a five liter Mustang can
out-accelerate me.  Its on a road with some good elevation change and 35MPH
corners that I most respect the car and enjoy being its caretaker

Tim Krone
timk913781@aol.com.

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 17:37:39 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Annual Recruitment Message



Subject: Annual Recruitment Message

As the PCA National Newsletter Committee chairman, I'm looking to expand
membership on our PCA Editors Mail List. Here's the deal:

If you are a PCA member and your region is NOT listed among the 36 regions
currently on the Editors List nor among the 9 regions who have been
contacted recently (see both lists below), please consider helping the
editor of your region's newsletter by getting on the PCA Editors Mail List.
If you ARE the editor, please contact me now.

The PCA Editors Mail List, also hosted by Stan Hanks, works like the
Associated Press and provides text, in the form of e-mail to PCA regional
editors. PCA regions are represented on the Editors List either by the
editor (if he/she has Internet access), or by another member of the region
having access who relays the text on disk to the editor. The message traffic
is held to a minimum by allowing only editors or relayers on the Editors
List. Each editor/relayer may also post to the Editors List those local
stories/tech tips that would be of general interest to the readers of other
region newsletters. 

I receive all PCNA press releases and post those to the Editors List along
with summaries of recent PCNA Technical and Campaign Bulletins. We have
other writers who produce stories (some very humorous) and tech tips for
posting. I also receive by snail-mail newsletters from about 60 PCA regions
and post OCR-ed text of tech tips and Porsche stories of general interest
from these newsletters.

About 70 stories/press releases/tech tips have been posted to the Editors
List since it began September 1, 1994. Many come from Porschephiles (with
the author's permission, of course). We now average about 15 postings per
month. It's all good stuff for regional newsletter readers.

You might want to become a "relayer" for your PCA region (if your editor
does not have Internet access) by converting the postings to text files and
giving them to your editor on disk. Please call your editor to see if your
region is interested in subscribing. If so, please send me a note to:   

larry_wilson@macnexus.org

These 36 regions are now represented on the PCA Editors List:
Alabama Region, California Central , Canada West Region, Carrera Region,
Central Wisconsin Region, Coastal Bend Region, Diablo Region, Green Mountain
Region, Gulf Coast Region, Heart o Dixie Region, Hudson Champlain Region,
Hudson Valley Region, Intermountain Region, Jersey Shore Region, Lincoln
Trail Region, Loma Prieta Region, Lone Star Region, Longhorn Region,
Monterey Bay Region, Motorstadt Region, Nord Stern Region, Northeast Region,
Northern Ohio Region, Orange Coast Region, Polar Region, Potomac Region,
Rennsport Region, Riesentoter Region, Rocky Mountain Region, Sacramento
Valley Region, San Diego Region, San Joaquin Region, Silver Sage Region, So.
Arizona Region, Upper Canada Region, and Yosemite Region.

E-mail inquiries have been sent in the last several weeks to members of
these 9 regions:
Alpine Mountain Region, Arizona Region, Blue Ridge Region, Carolinas Region,
Connecticut Valley Region, Las Vegas Region, Oregon Region, Pacific
Northwest Region, and Suncoast Region.

Larry Wilson
PCA Newsletter Committee
larry_wilson@macnexus.org

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 17:35:24 PST
From: lingren@lambo.alldata.com (Loren Lingren)
Subject: Re: Calif Smog

Hi All,
I found the newest flyer from the State of Calif, Bureau of Automotive Repair,
regarding smog checks.  It comes with the DMV renewal form.

Loren Lingren
lingren@alldata.com

- ----------Begin Included Message---------------

How To Get A Smog Check

Smog Check gives you the opportunity to help clean and protect our
state's fragile environment. Since the program began in 1984, it has
reduced harmful auto emissions by more than 17 percent, and is
continuing to work toward a 25 percent emissions reduction goal.

When you are due to have a Smog Check test (usually required every two
years), a notice will be printed on the vehicle registration renewal
form you receive from the Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV).

After you receive your notice:

Drive to the official Smog Check inspection station of your choice;
garage, service station or dealership displaying the familiar Smog
Check sign. Feel free to shop around for the best inspection and repair
prices. While the Bureau of Automotive Repair does not regulate
inspection fees, the Smog Check certificate is $7.

After completing a three-part test which includes a visual inspection,
a functional check, and a computerized tailpipe emissions measurement,
your technician will provide you with the test results. If your vehicle
passes all three parts of the inspection, you will be issued a Smog
Check certificate.

What if my vehicle fails?

NEW REGULATIONS GO INTO EFFECT 1/1/95
If after January 1, 1995, your vehicle fails Smog Check, new federal
law requires you to make necessary repairs to reduce your vehicle's
emissions to required levels.

If your vehicle is not under warranty, and you have spent more than
$450 for appropriate emissions-related repairs at a licensed Smog Check
repair facility, you may be eligible for a one-time waiver. Repair
waivers will NOT be issued for:

^ Vehicles with missing, modified or disconnected emissions control
equipment, regardless of the costs to make repairs;

^ Vehicles identified as "Gross Polluters"-vehicles which have much
higher emissions than properly maintained vehicles in their class;

^ Vehicles that obtained a repair waiver after 111195 in their most
recent biennial inspection or transfer of ownership. Two consecutive
repair waivers will not be issued after 111195.  Before a certificate
can be issued. warranty-covered defects must be corrected.
Manufacturers are required to provide the following warranties:

Model Year - Emission Control Warranty

1989 and older 5 years/50,000 miles 1990 and newer 3 years/50.000 miles
1990 an parts costing over $300 7 Year?/70,000 miles

Check the vehicle warranty for specific parts covered. For a free
warranty brochure, call 1-800-242-4450.

After receiving your Smog Check certificate, mail it, along with your
renewal registration forms and the required fee, to the DMV.

Which vehicles need Smog Checks?

1966 and newer vehicles powered by gasoline, liquid propane gas (LPG).
natural gas (LNG/CNG) and methanol are now required to have Smog Check
inspections every two years.

Heavy duty vehicles (8,501 pounds gross vehicle weight and over),
including commercial and recreational vehicles, are also included in
the program.

Are any vehicles exempt?

1965 and older vehicles, vehicles with two-cycle engines or engines
under 50 cubic inch displacement, and vehicles powered by diesel fuel
or electricity are exempt trom the program.

It you own such a vehicle, and your registration renewal form says
"Smog Check Required", you may need to make an appointment to take it
to a Referee station for verfication. For a Referee appointment call
toll free 1-800-622-7733.

What if I sell or buy a vehicle?

When a vehicle changes ownership, a Smog Check is usually required,
unless the vehicle has received a Smog Check certificate within 60 days
prior to the change of ownership. The SELLER must provide the buyer
with a Smog Check certiticate prior to the transfer of ownership.

CALIFORNIA DEPARRMENT OF CONSUMER AFFAIRS Bureau of AutomotIve RepaIr

For assistance with automotive repair dispute resolution call toll free
1-800-952-5210

- -------------End Included Message---------------------------

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1168                         Wed Feb 15 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: 14 Feb 95 20:49:07 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Cleaning neglected car

 
Try R-M 900, "Pre-Kleano." (Don't laugh). It's used to remove silicone and
wax and stuff from cars before painting. A quart is about $6. I don't know
if it takes off rubber bunnies from your fenders or not. My second choice
would be mineral spirits (oil-base paint thinner). My third choice, if those
don't cut it, is to get brutal with the buffer. But then my daily driver has
layers and layers of old paint so I can afford to use the buffer to clean
the dead stuff off.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 14 Feb 95 20:49:11 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: What is that thang

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 21:03:06 -0500
From: Drive951@aol.com
Subject: Electronic Frontier Region

P-philers,

I am a recent Porschephiler (6 weeks or so) and a semi-recent Porsche owner
and PCA member (~2 years).

I support the notion of merging Porschephiles with PCA in some way.  I am
hesitant to call it a "region", though.  The democracy (read bureaucracy) of
Region management is *NOT* something we want for Porschephiles, and is not
required.  I believe most of the publicly posted support for EFR agrees:
 most people want to retain Stan as the benevolent dictator.  

I think what we TRULY want (mainly because we can't hold Driver's Ed,
Concours, Monthly meetings, etc... on Porschephiles) is a non-discriminatory
way to reach everybody interested in Porsches providing:  

 - A facility for the proliferation of all the knowledge and information that
PCAers have

 - Promotion of all the activities offered by the current Regions.  These
activities can GREATLY enhance your enjoyment of your German metal.
 Participation in Region events helps each Region which, in turn, helps PCA
(which helps P-philes, read on!).

 - Provide stability and financial backing for Porschephiles.  Isn't money
what started the latest talk for an EFR, anyway?

Why not have "Porschephiles, the Internet address of the Porsche Club of
America.  All who own, love, or admire Porsches welcome."  Simply have
National PCA support Porschephiles financially.  I am sure Stan will let them
know what they need to charge us. :)  Let anyone join for a free trial time,
and then have them pay dues.  They won't be PCA members, just users of a PCA
"service(?)" or "partner".

To sum this up, my $.02 is that we stay away from calling ourselves a
"Region" and move for affiliation.  We will not alienate anyone and maybe we
could have/eat the proverbial cake...

At any rate, we offer our support for PCA affiliation and "Ether-Region"
status.

Count us in as founding/charter members:

Charlie Boyer & Katie Winn (affiliate, soon to be Katie Boyer...! :)   )
Members of Board of Governors, Northern New Jersey Region
49 Sand Spring Road
Morristown, NJ  07960
PCA #:  93075699

'86 951
'94 Jetta
Dog named Cody (named after the Houston Oiler's QB, poor thing)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 18:08:22 -0800 (PST)
From: Joe Hunter <jhunter@freenet.vancouver.bc.ca>
Subject: RE: lesson learned

On Tue, 14 Feb 1995, Kevin Gross wrote:

> >Before changing oil on 944s/late 924s, punch a
> >hole in the top of the oil filter that way all the oil in it flows down
> >and wont spill when u undo the filter.
> 
> This is OK to do *after* you have broken the filter free, ie, got it
> to turn a bit.  You don't want to punch a hole, find the filter frozen,
> then have to figure out a way to get the car to your mechanic
> with a holed filter.
> 

I've never had a problem with oil leaking when you remove the filter. It 
seems that the check valve inside holds it all in even when you hold the 
filter with the opening facing down. Of course you get a few drippings 
but nothing that cannot be wiped up by a rag.

If punching a hole is all that is required to let the oil drain out then,

a. Your filter doesn't have a check valve and all you've done is equalized 
   the pressure inside and outside the filter.
 
b. You've damaged the check valve which now allows for a. to occur.
 
Both would allow for a chance of having tiny shards of metal enter the 
engine...something I'd have reservations about.
 
BTW, I highly recommend the 'coil' type filter wrench for the 944 
(Automotion carries this). By the way it's designed, there is practically 
NO way you cannot remove the filter. The tighter you turn, the tighter it 
grips. Plus you practically need no additional clearance around the 
filter for manoeuvering.

Joe
'86 944

years ago (I lived in Denver at the time) because of work.  I did drive down 
for the concours, and it was a blast!  It appeared to be open to anyone.

about them.  I think you're only excluded from participating in the 
"official" events if you don't register.  At least this was the case in 
Colorado Springs.

Date:  Tue, 14 Feb 1995 22:51:49 -0500
From: TODD.COHEN@LYNVA.RRDONNELLEY.sprint.com
Subject:  EFR Region (long)

RR DONNELLEY & SONS COMPANY
 
          TO:        OAS     -00000001 *
 
          FROM:      TODD.COHEN
 
          DATE:      02/14/95
          SUBJECT:   EFR Region (long)
 
 
 
I think the EFR Region idea is interesting.
 
As far as owning/not owning/owning a part of a Porsche is concerned.  Does
it really matter?  If you do treat the EFR Region like a regular region,
then the only people who could pay dues are owners.  Like a regular
region, non-owners can participate in events, or attend meetings.  Now I
know that most people would not go to a PCA event without being invited,
unless you just happened to come across one.  As in, meetings are not
published to the general public, but Rally's and Autox's are out in the
public's eye.
 
With Porschephiles (or Porschephiles-request) being public knowledge, and
a public address we would have to have some provisions for non-owners who
find out about the list, and send email to join.  Like, "You cannot
register with the list unless you provide proof of Porsche Ownership".  It
sounds a little snobbish or stuck-up to me.  Besides On-Line services
like Compuserve or AOL, are there other lists that charge for services?
I would hate to have the list be stereotyped, don't flame me, we all know
what I am talking about.
 
I realize that most of the people, besides the newcomers looking for
purchase info, who post regularly are PCA members, does that mean we all
should be.  People join clubs and organizations for different reasons.
 
I was a member of a private sports car club for years before joining SCCA.
Being a underpaid college student I could not afford $45 or $50 for SCCA.
I eventually joined SCCA when I had the money, mostly for Autox, but over
the years I have worked Hillclimbs and Races.  After purchasing my 911, I
immediately joined PCA, this was before I joined Porschephiles.  I joined
PCA for the technical information (which Porschephiles provides more
timely and more opinions), I wanted Pano, and to do track events.
 
I wish I had joined Porschephiles before I purchased my car, but I thought
that there was no information I could use until I owned a car (boy, was I
ever wrong), and I did not know I could access Porschephiles from my
Compuserve account, so I waited until I had an Internet account (this
shows how little people know about how the Internet works, even people
like me who earn their living and support their Pcar habit from
computers).
 
I think Porschephiles is a great asset to owners and future owners.
Especially since most new Porsche owners are owners of used ones.  I would
hate to loose the mix that the list provides.  Last, but not least, I do
pledge $50 to the list for hardware/software support, if someone is still
counting.
 
Todd Cohen
1972 911T (Leaf Green)

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 23:36:39 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Fwd: Dumb Questions

John Michael said:

jm> 
jm> 1. How can I view only the most recent pp mail? It takes 15 minutes
jm> just to cursor thru the old stuff. 
jm> 
jm> 2. How can I mass delete the non pertinent mail? From AOL mail, it
jm> would take hours to select and delete each individual message. 
jm> 
jm> 3. Is there a way of only receiving the pp mail upon request; say,
jm> the last weeks mail or something? 
jm> 
jm> 4. Is key word search or something of the like possible? The pp
jm> list info is invaluable, but the chance of finding germane messages
jm> seems slim.

Use Flashsessions to download all of your mail at once, and scroll thru it
offline.  All Mac versions of AOL have Flashsessions, and the new Windoze 2.0
versions have them.  I open the message at the bottom of the window of
messages first (last being oldest), then use the arrow keys to go thru them
till I'm done.  Then I delete in mass.  I save any I want to keep first to
text files by going to the file menu or by hitting Command-S on a Mac (assume
there are similiar keys in Windoze).  You can select all messages in the
meassge listing by clicking on the last (or first) message, scrolling to the
end, hold down the shift key (on a Mac; again assume there is a similiar way
in Windoze) and click on the first (or last) message, hit the "Delete"
button, click "ok" when the "are you sure message" comes up, and away they
go. And no, there is NO way to get rid of the "are you sure" message!

NO way of sorting mail on AOL, sorry! No key word or anything like it.

If you want the digest version instead of individual messages, send email to
"porschephiles-request@tta.com" and ask for it. Give Stan a couple of days to
change you. DO NOT SEND THESE MESSAGES TO THE MAIN LIST!!!!

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 23:38:16 -0500
From: Hultgrenho@aol.com
Subject: list dues/PCA region

Stan et al,
I read and lurk, only occasionally address the list.  Love the knowledge and
humor.  Will try to contribute more when my local access provider comes
on-line in March (currently a long distance call for me to read my mail).
No problem with financial contribution to keep listserve serving.  Big
problem with PCA region idea.  I already belong to the CVR region and have no
desire to make PCA membership anymore than it is.  The Club does many things
besides communicate:  Track events, concours, rallies, picnics, dinners and
other social gatherings, fund raising for charities, etc.  This list
communicates amoungst its "members" (splendidly at that) and does tech via
E-mail.  Yeah its a unique group, but I think it falls pretty short as a car
club "region".  I don't agree that it's a good match.
Many organizations have other entities within their umbrella structures --
special interest groups (SIGs) -- for example, or institutes or subunits of
the club.  Perhaps Pfiles should define such a new subunit ... I just can't
equate the participants to the region concept.
I love the idea of a cool-looking cyberspace pfilers window sticker for the
small rear window of my porsche.  I still have one from the now defunct 944
registry, which is still very-cool.  How about that ... the Porschephiles
cyberspace (Internet?) registry?
Ah well, the idea still needs developing I guess.
Lon Hultgren
1987 944S (Waiting for clear roads again)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 14 Feb 1995 23:59:45 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Air Cooled Cylinder Head Temp. Gauges

We've all seen CHT (cylinder head temp.) gauges advertised in P-car 
magazines but I have yet to see one installed in a car. The oil temp gives 
and indirect indication of CHT but I think it might be valuable to have a 
direct indication from each cylinder, or at least each head.

Each cylinder probably operates at a different temp. and an accurate reading 
would help in tuning and diagnosis.

Aircraft use this to help properly lean the mixture as well as to avoid 
shock cooling the power plant. (during a reduced power descent.)

Has anyone installed or used CHT guages in air cooled road machines with 
info to share ?
Chris Jungmann


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1169                         Wed Feb 15 10:54:01 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 14 Feb 95 16:51:50 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Electronic Frontier Region of the PCA

Some points have been brought up by myself and others
and Stan has responded to some of them.

One point is that affiliating with the Porsche Club of America
seems to be in conflict with the international nature of the Internet
and this list. I think this is a pragmatic choice and Stan points out
the U.S. tax benefits of becoming a PCA region. If we send money
to Stan for whatever reason, he would have to declare it as taxable
income unless it was earmarked as bonafide club dues. Perhaps
at some point we could be given a charter directly by the Porsche
factory, but in the mean time it is expeditious to seek affiliation with
the PCA.

Second point is avoidance of club spawned bureaucracy. I propose
that our bylaws stipulate that whomever is maintaining the
computer equipment and the list be president. Hopefully this
would not contravene PCA rules. We (the founding members of the
EFR) will need to write a "creative" region charter and bylaws.

Lastly is the possibility of the exclusion of folks who don't own a
p-car. Well, there is no reason why list membership must equal
EFR membership. The club members would be a subset of the
general list membership and could perhaps have a few extra
privileges, like paying dues (towards equipment maintenance),
using the "goodie" store to buy t-shirts and the like, and if need
be, voting. PCA club members also receive Panorama, of course.
The porschephiles mailing list could be a "public service" that
the region provides, free of charge.

That'l be $0.02, please. ;-)

    Eric

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 08:27:24 EST
From: scott_humphreys@pts.mot.com (Scott Humphreys)
Subject: RE: 944 Oil Leak


> It's basically impossible to change a 944's oil filter without making a
> mess, and that's probably what you have on your hands.

Has anyone asked Porsche (dealers/mechanics) how
they deal with this?

Eventually I ended up stuffing old shop rags in around the base of
the filter before unscrewing it.  Most of the oil ended up on the
rags, which were then thrown out.  Some oil still made its way
down around the pump and belts, though.

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 05:58:09 -0800
From: hqb@netcom.com (Henry Bibb)
Subject: Speedo repairs


Nate wrote:
>     Just reminded me... anyone recommend a good speedo shop?  My car's
> orig. speedo is in a plastic baggie (looks like maybe parts missing?  I
> know the needle is bent to hell) and the previous owner installed a 160
> MPH speedo that does not match the other gauges.  Could I trust it to N.
> Hollywood Speedo (in the FAQ and all the mag's)?

Nate, I don't know about Hollywood Speedo, but VDO instruments, the
folks who made it, are located in Winchester, Va.  I got their number from
Ma Bell when mine went out, called them, and arranged to send it directly 
to them for repair.  They were quite helpful, and who would better know 
how to put it back into shape?

I think this might also be true, but I need to measure it tonite to see.

>Another problem is measurement, without cylinger head temperature
>measurement at least, you have to monitor a derivative, like oil temp,
>and there may be effects like a cooler in the circuit etc. Personally I
>would love to see cylinder head temperature measuring instruments as
>standard in the 911 as in light aircraft.

Thanks for your analysis, Ben.  I think you're right on about only having
only oil temp to rely on.  It would be nice to be able to tap into the
existing Motronic head temp sensor signal and have it displayed (in
meaningful units) on the dash...

 -Scott Jessen




------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 08:55:14 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: Cylinder Head Temperature Gauges

I put one of my own design on a Berkeley engine some years ago.  That
was a 3-cylinder two-stroke which had no cooling fans at all.  It
was placed crosswise just behind the grille opening.  Two strokes are
sensitive to mixture (they commonly eat petrol and pistons) and it
was very helpful to the running of this little car.  I used only one
in spite of having 3 carbs and 3 separate cylinder heads.

Classic aircraft engines do not have altitude compensated carbs, but
have manual mixture control.  It is common to use exhaust gas temperature
to optimize the mixture.  Note that these tend to operate at steady
power for long periods.  Sometimes they are fitted with one gauge per
cylinder which let's one optimize mixture without the risk of leaning
out any cylinder too much.  Cylinder head gauges are generally intended
to detect warm-up and gross engine malfunction.  They react too slowly
to tune mixture.

On a Porsche, you probably couldn't get much useful information out of
more than two gauges, one for each cylinder.  That would tell if one
bank was hotter than the other (or if the sensors weren't matched).
Oil temperature is probably nearly as good.

Rick Dill
62-356B without head temperature gauge .. waiting for spring
59-Berkeley 492 with head temperature gauge .. waiting for care and license.

------------------------------

Date: 15 Feb 95 06:14:46 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>

This may be too much of a fringe topic, but with the towing (read:

for their tow vehicles.  We've upgraded our trailer this year and it's
*heavy* so I'd like to give the ol'chevy a treat for having to lug this
thing around.  We have a '90 Chevy 4x4 with a 350 and 4 speed auto (3.73
rear axle), I put a K&N and Dynomax on it last year and got a big boost in
mileage and torque (seat of pants for latter, measured 12% for former).  I
am considering the Hyperchip Towmaster (I think that's the name) and it's
companion thermostat.

any longevity concerns I should have?

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 09:25:45 -0500
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Re: tire advice

I have used the Bridgestone RE-71s in H rated version. I saved about
$75/tire. Since I also live in the US and couldn't go above 120mph I decided
to save the money. 
Anyway, I think that the RE71s are the best tire out there. Tremendous grip
in the dry with plenty of feedback at the limit. Smooth progressive sliding
when that does happen. Decent performance in the rain and snow.

Barry Lenoble
86 944

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 09:54:22 -0500
From: X400459@aol.com
Subject: Undisgruntled Porschephile

First, I must apologize formally to the group. While, initially you came
accross as snobs--I was wrong. I've received many useful hints, particularly
on paint in recent days.
  As an old dog, retired accountant, I don't have much tech knowhow to offer
the group. I do, however, have a number of old car stories I could share with
you folks, if this is proper for your forum. I was interested in cars in the
late fifties, early sixties. In 59, I bought and Austin Healy 3000 and had it
for about 3 years before selling it for furniture and marrage bliss. In those
days, the "big healys" were quite the car; able to compete with the Detroit
Iron of the time. 
  I had a buddy who bought a red Porsche 1500 356 (I think it was a 56). Keep
in mind that at that time I wasn't a Porsche owner. At any rate, that car
(the Porsche) wasn't very fast off the line but was excellent for autocrosses
and gymkannas (spelling?). Well, this guy traded his v8 55 chevy for the
Porsche. He was disappointed with the acceleration. One day, as we cruised
the city streets, he pulled up next to a bright yellow Renault Daulphine with
a Chicken Delight Sign painted all over it and a big CHICKEN HEAD on the
roof. Well this was his chance. He gunned the engine and popped the clutch
and the Chicken Delight car did the same. Well, he beat us--badly. Now this
guy (my buddy) became obsessed with the Chicken Delight car. As I recall, he
went out and got an Abarth Muffler system, had it tuned on a dynomometer, and
had other performance work done on his P car. Next, he found out where the
home base for the Chicken Delight car was (4th and Washington, Gary,
Indiana). We went down there and, sure enough, after about a half hour of
waiting, the Chicken Delight car showed up--same driver.Well we followed him,
after he picked up his orders to deliver. He was easy to follow, the chicken
head sort of stuck out in traffic. You know the end of the story--we caught
him at a light and he beat us soundly. After several addition unsuccessful
trys, we gave up trying to beat the Chicken car.

If you're interested in added sports car war stories by a driver (not
mechanically inclined) let me know. If this isn't the forem for such fond
memories, I'll understand.

x400459
Mystery accountant, retired
85 911 Targa, black/w tail (35 year dream car)
84 Saab Turbo, black (go to store-get newspaper-car)
86 Puegot, silver (wife's daily driver, she works)
2 standard poodles 
Duffy (father of 2 litters, 12 and 13 respectively)
Mitzie (daughter of legendary Duffy)
black, w/tails (cropped)

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 01:23:16 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: Re: 930 pricing

>From: sdandeka@chipcom.com (Shirish Dandekar)
>Subject: 930 Pricing
>I recently noticed a 1979 930 listed in the local paper. The
>car had 32k mile on it. No price was given. No other details
>were listed. I was wondering what the going price for this 
>vintage car might be? 

Well I spent the last year looking for a good 911, but I changed my
mind in favor of a 930 once I had the chance to see one up close.
In New England, there weren't that many turbos available, but
I found that the pricing for 78-83 cars was generally in the range
of $ 22K - 30K depending on miles and condition. This is for real
930s, you can find lots of oddball aftermarket turbo-look or turbo
conversions for less. To learn more about my prospective purchase,
I had bought the books "The 911 performance Handbook", "Porsche 911
Turbo", and "The Used 911 story". When I found a european '82 930
with adjustable turbo boost and other performance goodies, I decided
to take the plunge. But I drove the car for 250 miles and had it
checked out by two mechanics. (Trouble is they gave me different
points of view.) Regarding maintenance, I have the schedules for both
the turbo and the regular 911, and there doesn't seem to be that much
difference in terms of the labor that is needed, but when I look at
the Automotion and Performance Products catalogs I find that a lot of
spare parts are significantly more expensive for the turbo. (E.g.
regular spark plugs are a couple of bucks, the turbo's platinum plugs
are around $19 each) Also, I should note that in the maintenance 
records of my car I found that the previous owner had spent over $7K 
rebuilding the engine at 39K miles. So you would be wise to do a lot
of research, but I found the "window shopping" to be lots of fun!


Ray Khorram (email: Ray@Arkay.MV.COM or 70524.3012@compuserve.com)
'82 930	(bought it last November)
'92 Harley Sportster
'83 and '88 Toyotas
//-------------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 10:58:43 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: ramps/jacks for 944

Nathan asks:

What is the best way to get under a Porsche for repairs?  Are there any ramps
available for home use that a 944S can drive up on without ripping off the
spoiler?  Are there any jacks that are stable enough so the car won't
slip/fall?  Any thoughts will be appreciated.

Nathan Hanson
1987 944S
==========================
Nathan, I have built a set of ramps out of wood. I think I used 3/4" wood.
I had originally made them to be able to get the 911 off the groun. I have
4. I measured the 911 clearance and worked around that. I have a 1/2' lip
in the front to prevent me from falling over :)

I can use them on the 944 also. I had to cut a bit off the lip to clear the
spoiler. So now I have L & R sides... Ususally use them in the front to work
on the engine...

I also use 6x6s by about 10" to get the whole car off the ground without tires.
Like when I did by brakes, FE work etc. I use a hydrolic jack and then place 
the 6x6s under the longitudinal beams in the front, enf by the suspension on
the rear. The 944 is so stiff that if I use 3 points, the 4th is on the air.

Also have a set of safety jacks. Do not get under the car unless it is well
secured. Also use wedges (2x4) to prevent car from rolling when on ramps.

YMMV. Hope this helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 11:20:17 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Transmission.


Dear Jeff:

<Speaking of trannies, anyone have any recommendations as to a short 
shift kit for 914s? Is it worth spending the money to buy one of the nice 
ones? I like my tranny the way it is, but I'd love to give it nice, short 
throws. Any suggestions?>


The short shift is definitely worthwhile for 70-72 914s after the linkage is
rebuilt but does little for 73-76 models (assuming the linkage and bushings
and roll pin/set screws are within specs.

Conclusion:  purchase the kit for 71-72 only after rebuilding the shift
linkage; don't waste your money on the 73-76 kit!

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: 15 Feb 95 11:20:11 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356/912 oil coolers

 
Chris Jungmann asks about auxiliary oil coolers for his 912.
 
My 356 doesn't need one. Even going up long steep grades (like the Grapevine
on I-5) at paralegal speeds, the
oil temperature never climbs much above midscale. Sustained high speeds on
I-5 up to San Francisco in the middle of summer (air temp 90-100 deg.)
doesn't cause problems either. 20 or 30 minute race track (not slalom!)
sessions don't even see it reach midscale. In anything less than summer
temperatures, like what we have now, it doesn't even get to 1/4 scale.
In my opinion, installing an oil cooler is more trouble than it's worth. You
have to hack holes in the fan shroud and find a place to put it and run oil
lines etc. If you are building an E/Prod race car, something with more than
130ish horsepower, yeah, you need this, but not for a street car with modern
motor oil.
 
My third 356 was found dead on the freeway. Some kid had bought it a week
before from an old guy, who got it from his son. Kid broke down because
throttle linkage broke (another one of those genius Weber conversion jobs).
I got him going again by tying the carbs half open with some string and
showing him how to drive with the ignition switch. He was going to Gary
Emory's Parts Obsolete in Costa Mesa, near my house, to try to sell the car,
so I offered to guide him there ("DON'T get behind me; watch the mirror for
my turn signals!") The car had some odd stuff on it -- kid said something
about the old man saying it was a lightweight but he didn't have time to
research it and just wanted out of it. That night, I called Germany and
confirmed it was indeed a lightweight with aluminum panels (engine
lid was obviously aluminum, with louvers like Carrera), price was right so I
wound up buying it. Now here's where the oil cooler comes in. Somebody had
mounted an oil cooler right in front of the fan shroud air inlet, and mounted a
full-flow oil filter. They were taking the heat out of the oil and putting it
right back into the cooling air. Pure genius. And the throttle linkage had
broken because the vertical rod from the transmission bellcrank was
bending over the hoses stuffed behind the shroud every time the gas pedal
moved. Even after it was fixed (the kid had somebody next to Gary's shop do
it before I bought it) the throttle would only open about halfway, with
about an inch of effective travel down near the floor. Typical Weber kludge,
I've seen more like this since then. Anyway, after I bought the car, I did a
title search and traced previous owners, right back to the original owners.
The old guy's son (this is now 4 owners ago) was in Kansas. I called there,
and talked at length. It turns out that most of the "improvements" were done
by him. He is a high school shop teacher. "Yep, I put dat dere orl cooler in.
It's what we do to keep Beetles alive in Kansas summers."
 
CHT (or better yet, EGT - exhaust gas) temperature gauge sounds like a good
idea but I've never fooled with one (on a car). Especially good idea for
air-cooled cars. The engine oil temp gauge would give only a rough indication
of a problem such as running too lean, it's really more of an outside air
temperature gauge! (Hot day outside, oil runs hot). And it sort of averages
all four cylinders, twice removed. Any serious problem will take time to show
up in the oil temp, and you'd have to know what the gauge would normally
read under those outside air temp and engine load conditions anyway.
 
Pegasus Auto Racing Supplies sells EGT probes and gauges. Call 414-782-0880
for exact prices and catalog. Single EGT gauge about $50, probe $40,
probe extension $10, four-position selector for reading four probes with one
gauge $30. So for a full rig on a 4-cyl. car you're looking at close to
$300.
 
You might try aircraft EGT gauges but I suspect they only work on 28 Volts,
and the probes might be bigger and restrict exhaust gas flow.
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 11:51:15 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: 356/912 oil coolers

  >You might try aircraft EGT gauges but I suspect they only work on 28 Volts,
  >and the probes might be bigger and restrict exhaust gas flow.

nope.  most that I've used are self contained.  no external power except
for maybe a lighted dial.  they use thermocouples not rtd's so they
generate their own power.  The probes are generally about 3.5" long
with about 1/2 of that inside the exhaust stack.  Usu about 1/8" dia.
if you put in more than one they must all be exactly the same distance
from the valve, any more than, say, about 4" is probably too much.  useful
range is from about 1200 - 2000 deg f.  all that's from memory, mines
busted right now so I don't look at it
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin C. Walker                                         martinw@eapi.com
Project Lead                                         Voice (513) 629-2517
Eagle-Picher Industries                                    (513) 721-7010
580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 09:09:26 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)
Subject: Re: 911 2.7: install shuffe pins?

You wrote: 

>
>
>[Text item: Text_1]
>     Hi P-groupies:
>     
>     I've seen the process of installing shuffle pins (aka 
>     anti-shuffle pins or dowel pins) advertised.  I know almost 
>     nothing about this.
>     
>     As I understand it, pins are installed around the crankshaft area 
>     in one case half with corresponding holes in the other half.  
>     This prevents the case halves from sliding or shuffling around 
>     the crankshaft.  This process seems to require incredible 
>     precision; if the pin/hole combo is off, the bearings will bind, 
>     and if the holes are slightly oversized to ensure non-binding 
>     then the pins really won't prevent shuffling.
>     
>     I am rebuilding a 911 2.7 and wondered when this process is 
>     appropriate.  Is it really only used for very high revving race 
>     applications?  My engine will be a standard RS with 7300 rpm 
>     redline, probably making around 230 hp.  Car use will be street 
>     and occasional track.
>     
>     Any thoughts would be appreciated.
>     
>     Jeff Jensen
>     jcjensen@raychem.com
>     73 911 Carrera RS
>     one disgruntled cat
>     
>
>Did NOT have it done when my 74 carrera eng was rebuilt. You MUST have 
all the head studs replaced with delvair studs.

The shuffle pins are usually done on 914 engines which are going to be 
"raced"

					mike

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 11:07:11 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: media blasting question

> I assume that if plastic media did get into
> suspension parts etc. it wouldn't do much damage?

I've been meaning to write in about this... 

Plastic, walnut shells, sand -- whatever. All that crap is abrasive
and will cause untold difficulties if you get it in the moving parts.
Had to rebuild a freshly rebuilt 911 engine once due to an
unplanned encounter with a bead-blaster....

My metric is simple: if its' not a single part with no attached moving
parts, and if I can't clean it very, very well when done blasting, don't
blast it.

Stan

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 11:30:11 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: powder coating

> For those of us in the dark what is powder coating?  Could someone explain
> the process and it's benefits?  Thanks in advance.

Powder coating is an electrostatic painting method. You strip, blast,
and etch the metal in question, then hang it in an electrostatic charge
field. You then apply paint in powder form (sort of just fogging it out of
a big nozzle) that is oppositely charged. It covers *everything*  -- no runs,
no missed spots. The piece is then heated in a blast furnace to melt
the powerder paint, leaving the metal very effectively enamaled. 

GREAT stuff for high-abuse items, like sheet metal, wheels, tools...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: 15 Feb 95 12:44:08 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Valve clearance, help

re Jerry Brady's no clearance on #4 exhaust --
 
If you take it apart, also check the length of the valves. Valves can
stretch before the head breaks off. Also check pushrod length. I can't
imagine these changing enough to matter but it's easy enough to do. Maybe
some unmatched part snuck in there?
 
Question is, if you have a sunk seat or stretched valve, why did it do that?
Probably running too lean on that cylinder, and/or detonating (but usually #3
gets hottest first, at least on Beetle/356/912 applications). #3, just so
we're using the same nomenclature, is on the flywheel end, not the pulley
end. (on 356/912 is driver side, toward front of car).
 
If you need to replace valves, definitely go with the sodium cooled ones. I
don't even know if non-sodium filled exhausts are available, but don't use
them if they are.
 
For cheap entertainment, you can dispose of junk sodium valves yourself.
The manual says to cut them in half and throw the pieces, from a long way
away, into a large vat of water. Wait until explosion dies down... I used to
know a guy who went to MIT, whose idea of a cheap thrill on a Saturday night
was to get a kilo of elemental sodium from the chemistry stockroom, go to a
bridge over the Charles River, open the container (it comes packed in
glycerine) and heave it as far as he could into the river.
 
Pete

Date: 15 Feb 95 12:43:59 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356/912 oil coolers

Hi, Martin.
 
OK, if they are thermocouples, not thermistors, then they don't need a power
source but to be pedantic they need a reference cell of some sort --
"electronic ice point." Do aircraft EGTs then do away with this and just
figure the variation due to ambient temperature will be buried in the noise
anyway? Or run 50 deg or whatever rich of max egt, regardless of what max egt
is, in which case the actual number doesn't matter? It's been too long since
I flew anything with an EGT (last one, I think, was my multi engine
checkride and I don't want to think how long ago that was.)
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 09:40:59 -0800
From: hqb@netcom.com (Henry Bibb)
Subject: Leakdown tester


I believe the item known in aviation circles as the "differential
cylinder pressure tester" is the same thing, right?

If so, an outfit named Aircraft Tool Supply has them for $39.95
"for most small to medium engines".  A bigger one is $49.95, but
is intended "for engines over 1,000 cu. in."  (and locomotives, I 
presume).

There is another one listed as an "Eastern brand" tester for $69.95.

The illustration and description indicates they hook up to shop air
and then to the spark plug hole.  It's got two gauges, with some 
kind of control knob on it.  Instuctions presumably furnished.

ATS is at (800)248-0638.  They're not the only aviation company that
has these;  they may not even be the least expensive.  I just happen
to have their catalog handy today.

Henry Bibb
hqb@netcom.com

Usual disclaimers:  No interest affiliation, etc.

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 09:37:32 -0800
From: emn@llnl.gov
Subject:  Rear *&#@? Interior Panel -Reply

Fellow 912 owner Sean Steinman asked how to get the rear quarter interior
panels out.  Assuming a '69 uses the same mounts as a '67, here goes:  

The panels are held in place in three ways:  the TOP is held in place by the
interior trim piece that runs along the bottom of the rear quarter window, and,
depending on the year, the MIDDLE is held by the shoulder belt mount, and the
BOTTOM is held in place by a hidden, angled metal tab that slides into a slot
on the body along the face of the wheel-well bulge.  I suspect that tab is
what's giving you problems.  Once the obvious fastenings are removed, you need
to gently lift the panel straight UP about one inch to unhook the hidden tab. 
For reference, similar tabs hold the back interior panel (the one behind the
rear seats) in place.

Eric Nichols
1967 912 Light Ivory
Robin and Damien, asleep between meals.

or power leads to hook up.  What's the max differnce we could get wihtout
it....hmmm flying from chicago last week (-30's) to death valley in july
(say, what, 120 in the shade) thats 150 deg., about 10% error midrange which
is actually pretty big but I guess not big enough to matter.

  >is, in which case the actual number doesn't matter? It's been too long since
the actual number doesn't matter anyway - and would change on a day-to-day
basis even if you could measure it accurately.  What matters is peak
and a couple of points around peak (eg 50 deg lean, 75 deg rich etc)

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 18:25:32 GMT
From: michgg@ramp.com (Michael Gray)
Subject: RE: 944 Oil Leak

Dennis,

Sorry to hear your 944 is hemmorhaging its most precious fluid on your driveway.
There is a lot to be said for changing your own oil, but we all know that
it's not always convenient.  
The first thing I'd do is check to make sure the filter is on tight.  I
usually change my own oil, but I had a similar experience with my 944 when I
took it to a local shop on my way out of town on vacation.  I must have made
the mechanic nervous when I hovered over everything he did.  The filter was
still a half turn loose when I left, and I left very similar spots.  The
ammount of oil escaping wasn't enough to affect the dipstick 
level either by the time I figured it out.
As far as the gaskets/seals go I've heard too much oil may do this BUT, it
seems to 
me it would take an awful lot of overfill.  If the mechanic did that, they
should blatently reimburse you 100% for damages.  If they lacked the
knowledge  to do the 
job right they should never have started.  An oil change on a 944 is no
different than any other car!

Ron Bauer
'83 944  blk/blk

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 10:23:20 -0800
From: "John Milton" <porsche@hpcvusm.cv.hp.com>
Subject: Re: 911 information general

On Feb 14,  7:21pm, fiechner@Laser.NET wrote:
> Subject: 911 information general
> I am driving an '86 928S.  I enjoy the car.  I had thought of buying
> a 911.  I would love some feedback from 911 fans about their views
> of the car and why it has such staying power in the maket and minds
> of its fans.  Why 2 valves, air cooled, etc?

Well, I've got an '86 928S as well and had previously owned a '71
911T so I feel I can give a somewhat educated opinion.   As you
probably know, the 928 and 911 are two entirely different cars.
Yes, they're both fast and handle quite well, but they achieve
their performance from different angles.  The 911 is more of a
sports car than the 928 will ever be.  My 911 felt much more
'tossable' than my 928, and since I have the automatic I'm not
quite as involved when driving the 928 as when driving the 911.
Not to mention that the 928 has power everything.  I bought the
928 instead of the 911 because I could get more bang for the buck
in a 928, and the 928 has bigger back seats (for my 5yr old twin
daughters, they even pronounce Porsche correctly).  Why does the
911 have such staying power?  You tell me what car comes to mind
when you think of Porsche.  I'll be you see a 911, and I'd bet the
same goes for the general public (when was the last time you saw
a television ad for a 928?)  I'll also bet that in general the
maintanence is easier for a 911 than a 928, and that parts may be
a little cheaper as well (especially radiators and water pumps :-).

Do I enjoy my 928?  Absolutely.  What will my next Porsche be?
A 95 911 C4 Coupe (993) (in 2010, unless I get a phone call from
Ed McMahon).

John Milton

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 12:38:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Cylinder Head Temperature Gauges


Inasmuch as you are concerned about fuel mix, your best bet in the gauge
department would be an exhaust temp gauge.  It isn't particularly good at
fine tuning, but it would tend to show up severe problems.  With a way-lean
mix, exhaust temp would shoot up, for example.  A fat mix would run cool.

Of course, the high line approach to this problem is a wide-ranging lambda
sensor exhaust monitoring system.  They are available but are very
expensive.

A cylinder head temp sender might reveal basic problems with cooling the
engine, particularly an air cooled engine.  I don't have any experience with
cylinder head temp measurement.

On a street car, you have no need for either.  Porsche did their homework.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 12:50:14 -0600
From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: Replace those divots...

Pano had an article last year (or so) on concours preparation which
included a simple method of repairing stone chips.

After cleaning, fill the ding with touch-up paint.  This may take
several coats.  After drying, "sand" the new blob down to the level
of the original paint using a small wood block covered with a single
layer of cloth (T-shirt fabric works great) and moistened with
lacquer thinner.

This method is very easy and relatively safe.  The original baked on
finish is not affected by the thinner.  Also, with other methods of
sanding it is very easy to go to far.

This method works well for me.  Last fall I was first in my class
(alright, it was a small class) with my 80,000+ mile daily driver.
And these miles were accumulated in Houston - stone chip capital
of the world!  Argh, I left out 'concours at a local PCA event' in
the second sentence of this paragraph (my attention span isn't as
long as it used to be!).

John	'89 944

Date: 15 Feb 95 14:19:00 EST
From: "LOGISX::GIBBS" <GIBBS%LOGISX.decnet@vaxa.acdnj.itt.com>
Subject: Jacking/raising a 944

Gee-

I've been using a hydraulic floor jack to lift my 944 at the corners (in the points
shown for a floor jack in the Haynes book and owners manual), then using Jack stands
to support each corner as I move on to the next.  Takes a little while to do all 4
corners, but it seems to work alright.  I have also cheated on occasion by using the
jack (with a Griots Garage yellow plastic jack pad) to lift one entire side of the car
at the point where the factory jack inserts, the slipping jack stands under both 
floor jack points at once.

I also recently bought a small bottle jack, and I have been planning to try using 
it to lift the left side of the front end (again in the floor jack spot) while using
a floor jack to lift the other side of the front end (this because the car is in the 
garage for the winter, and there isn't room next to it to work the handle of the floor
jack on the left side).  Of course, I would then insert my jack stands before getting 
under.

Anyone care to comment on these procedures?  Are ramps (oak or not) better?  (Of 
course, you can't pull the wheels on a ramp).  Why would it be necessary to use 
a 6x6 when jacking the car?

BTW - I have noticed that if I only jack one corner, after I let it down that corner
seems to sit higher than the rest until I drive it, after which it seems to even out.
Is this normal behavior after the suspension has been fully extended?

Ed Gibbs
gibbs@avionics.itt.com
'84 944, Guards Red, All mine!

Nate,
 Thank you for being my doorway to the p-guys and Stan. I was going to
update the list when I can speak (This has happend before). Well I looked
at FI parts prices abd discovered that I could get a cylinder head temp
sensor for 12 bucks. Some one mentioned to me that this could be it. I
called my X FI mechanic and he said no chance its working fine. I replaced
it any way (Talk about a tight spot and creative wrench attachments to get
to it!). Results are fantastic. The car runs when its cold at lowet than 4k
RPMs! The car doesn't stall lurch or stumble. It used to be I'd have to sit
for 10 min and let the car warm up at 4k RPMs now I get in start it tune
the radio wait to feel a little heat at my feet and off I go. The only
thing left is a slight hesitation that occers randamly. I can';t hear the
injectors fire at with ignition on engine off, so throttle switches are my
best guess and I be replacing them. Then I hope to have a completely normal
car and am no longer afarid of FI so screw going to the mechanic I'll
figure it out myself.
        Now the only thing is do I buy snow tirers for the thing. All this
snow in PA is a pain in the tail as the 914 is the only car I have.
Nick

degree mark it gets waxed too

I'm keeping a copy to send when I have access.

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 09:19:50 -0600
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: 944 oil leak

Kevin writes:
>It's basically impossible to change a 944's oil filter without making a
>mess, and that's probably what you have on your hands.  Oil tends
>to get onto the P/S pump and other surrounding bits, and onto the
>belly pan.
>Kevin Gross

I'm a veteran at making messes during oil changes, even on my old truck
which has lots of room. No matter what precautions I use (news papers
all over the garage and driveway) I will always find a way to dump the
oil and/or filter all over myself, the car, the garage, and then drag
the stuff into the house, its incredible. (after re-reading this it's
not as bad as it sounds).

However, to minimize oil leaking from the filter when removing it. I
first break the filter loose, use a plastic bag from the grocery store
and place over it. Keeping the bag up against the block, unscrew the
filter and let it fall into the bag. I don't know how it will work on a
944, but it may be worth a try.

hope this helps,
Brian Scudder
'83 928S
'70 old blue truck
'94 Redi (the Cat)

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 13:35:28 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 911 information general

> Why 2 valves, air cooled, etc?

        Someone once called the 911, "A bad idea taken to its logical
extreme, and then perfected."
        "Why" has a lot of different answers on a lot of different
levels.  First off is money.  The 911, ass-engined, air-cooled, two-
valve, and all the other "unique" features, sells.  Part of that is due
to Porsche's racing heritage--and 911 derivatives have been wildly
successful--probably more so than any other car ever designed.  Part
of that is undoubtedly due to the fact that the 911 is very different
from any other car currently made.  It is unique, and that appeals to
a lot of people.  Most of these differences give it "character".
("Character" seems to refer to things that detractors see as "bugs",
and afficionados see as "features".)
        Why aircooled?  Aircooled engines are (can be) lighter-weight
and simpler than their water-cooled counterparts.  Air-cooling has its
imitations, however.  One of which is that it is difficult to make four-
valve heads that last any reasonable amount of time.  Air-cooled en-
gines also tend to be louder than water-pumpers.  Water-pumpers gener-
ally run cooler than the air-heads, which can make for longer engine
life, and also lets you do more to the engine (in terms of mods, etc.).
        Aircooled is good.  At least to me.  I like the 911.

- --DD

"No cones, no cones..."    ____--/~|___\_____.      _____
                          (  _             _  >    |_____|___|__/____|_
Dave Darling               ~' `~~~~~~~~~~~' `~      _____|   |       |
darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov `~'           `~'

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 15:03:03 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Transmission.


Dear Jeff:

<Speaking of trannies, anyone have any recommendations as to a short 
shift kit for 914s? Is it worth spending the money to buy one of the nice 
ones? I like my tranny the way it is, but I'd love to give it nice, short 
throws. Any suggestions?>


The short shift is definitely worthwhile for 70-72 914s after the linkage is
rebuilt but does little for 73-76 models (assuming the linkage and bushings
and roll pin/set screws are within specs.

Conclusion:  purchase the kit for 71-72 only after rebuilding the shift
linkage; don't waste your money on the 73-76 kit!

George Hussey

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 09:23:00 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; Aqua 911s and title laundering


>>Apparently, these flood damaged cars can be totaled by the insurance
>>companies, sold as scrap, recovered by someone else, taken out of
>>California, retitled (now the new title does not say recovered), and sold
>>to some poor souls. Disgustingly dishonest! So buyers of cars in Oregon,
>>Nevada, Washington, etc., be aware!
>>Minh Le.

>Better include California buyers. The cars can be taken out of CA,
>registered in AZ which eliminates the Salvage designation from the title,
>then reregistered in CA with a clean title.
 (snip)
>Don

   This won't work in Texas; a car recovered by then sold by the insurance
company will print the mark "Water damaged" on a flood car (or "reconditioned"
for a wrecked car). If taken out of the state, then re-titled back in Texas 
the mark _isn't_ erased as a title search shows the history and the car stays
"marked," i.e. title laundring doesn't work. Of course, its completely up to 
 the donor state if it doesn't return to Texas. 

   Probably 90% or better of water damaged cars end up back on the road, there
 is -no- condition of car where Texas demands "scrapping" the car (there
 should be; burnt hulks of expensive cars can sell for thousands of dollars
 at auction, this is purely for the theft market where car identities are
 needed...That the price gets bid to say, $7000 for a worthless, burnt
 Mercedes is kind of scary since it means there is -competition- among thieves
 for the VIN/title....Insurance companies would be smart to privately scrap
 these cars instead of dumping them thru the salvage auctions, but whats it
 to them ??).
    One sure way to avoid getting burned is to ask for records for a car.
 You sort out guys who aren't obsessed with the maintenance of their cars
 and are sure to get only personal cars with proven care.

  At auction, flood cars can sell for nearly wholesale (there are no easy
 bargains in the car world). But flood cars can make good cars, and if fixed
 right the only damage is the stain you can't get off the title...

            Lee A.
