Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 15:18:36 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Clear Coat Paint Chip Repair

The question was asked if clear touchup should be used as a final coat to
repair chips on a clear coat paint.

There are two view points to this question.

1. The purist will say yes, the paint has a clear coat and thus, the repair
should also.  The process is the same as previously described, except the
clear coat is substitued for the last 2-3 coats or paint.  I do not have the
touch or the art of a painter.  I personally have not had that much luck with
the two process system.  One of my cars is Cyclemen Red (Black Cherry
Metalic) with a clear coat.  This color is more difficult to repair the any
other.  Black is a snap compared to this.  As this is a concour car, I tried
to be a purist.  Lacking the skills of a surgeon, instead of a Q-tip shaft, I
use the point of a round, undyed,  wood toothpick to apply the paint.  Dip
the point in to the paint to get a thin coating on the first 1-2 mm of the
toothpick.  If there is a blob on the end, gently scrape it back into the
bottle. Place the tip of the toothpick against the center of the chip and
allow capillary action to literly flow the paint into the depression of the
chip. Allow to dry 2 hours and repeat 8-12 times till the depression is
filled with paint and bulges slightly upward.   If I use anything larger than
a toothpick,  I wind up with a mess.  After many attempts, I finally gave up
the two step process.  This is my failing and not a slur on the system.
      

2. The practical world says no.  The touchup paint is different from the
original paint and is formulated only as a touchup paint.  Once it is applied
it should, according to the manufacturer, match well enough to be all but
invisible.  I have found this to be the case with the numerous repairs on the
many cars/colors, I have completed.  If you are using the original paint as a
touchup ( I have not done this with a clear coated car),  then my understandin
g is that you should use the clear as a topcoat.  The color coat of some
paints will many times be relatively dull in appearance.  These paints rely
on the clear coat to provide the "shine".  

Try one chip in an area that is not that visible.  If the process works, then
continue with the rest.  If not try the clear coat.  The idea is to develop
your technique on an area of the car that does not stand out. Then move into
the major playing fields.

I hope that the above has added a little more food for thought on chips.  (Or
chips as thought of food)

Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specialties, Inc.
Distributors of Quality Car Care Products
Phone (201)796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com



------------------------------


Porschephiles #1171                         Wed Feb 15 23:59:33 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 12:32:02 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: CHT Gauges

Chris Jungmann wrote:

> 
> Has anyone installed or used CHT guages in air cooled road machines with 
> info to share ?
> 

I put the VDO cylinder head temperature gauge in my '83 SC.  It gives a
useable reading but has several problems.  Problem 1 is that it is a
thermocouple type sensor *without* cold junction compensation which 
[cut to chase] means that what it really measures is the temp
*difference* between the air in the engine bay and the cylinder head.
Thus you're not measuring actual temperature, and must apply a mental
fudge factor based on a guess of ambient temperature, to get an
indication of how much fun your valve guides, head joint, and piston
crowns are having.  Problem 2 is minor; the gauge covers 100-650F
and my car is mostly 250-300F with occasional excursions to 200 and
350... so you're trying to read a 1/16" gauge division for all your
info.  Problem 3 is that I don't have any idea what constitutes "safe",
"warning", and "alarm" head temperatures, and the gauge comes with zero
supplemental info.  Perhaps some of you Lycoming floggers can provide
some input on this.

On the plus side it is a gauge of significant amusement *and* you can use
it to make life easier for your engine, though I suspect the engine can
handle anything you can dish out, CHT-wise.  In particular you can
notice how much less heat capacity high-altitude air has, leading to
indicated CHTs 50 degrees hotter at 6000 ft, and also you can note the
correlation between CHT and high-load, low-rpm situations such as
climbing a long hill in 5th.  And armed with this info, you can change
down a gear and watch the CHT drop from 350 to 300, or at least you can
if you're an anal-retentive gauge freak like me (like I said I doubt any
of this matters to the engine as much as, say, keeping your *oil* cool
and clean).

The ultimate solution of course is those lightplane multi-cylinder bargraph
displays of *each* cylinder's CHT and EGT... gauge freak heaven... but
even a *used* one I once saw was around $1500, and that's most of the
price of the Jim Russel driving school....

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 14:29:37 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: Old Car Stories


Text item: Text_1

Old Car Stories and the near, miss thread we nearly had a few months ago:
Waaaaaaaaay back in the mid/late fifties before UK instigated real vehicle MOTs 
and there were lots of cheap iron on the road in the same condition as you see 
them in Ohio today, I was browsing around in the very back of a cheap very used 
motor cycle lot. I was an apprentice at the time with a weekly rent more than my
weekly pay and looking for cheap transport like L25 out of the door. Any way in 
the gloom and dust I foud TWO DBR-1s still with race numbers and direct from Le 
Mans. Asking price was L750 each!!! of course to me it was like asking for the 
moon, but in ones dotage one can still dream.............
I did find a bike, a 1933 AJS 500 single, it laste about three months before it 
siezed and I was back to the human powered bike. After that a 1936 Rover Sixteen
with a straight Six and rear hinged doors. That car had the best, silkiest gear 
box ever known to man. Overhauled the engine by sitting on the front fender, 
feet inside the engine bay taking off bits and putting them back with the car 
parked in the street. Engine was to heavy for me to handle other than a bit at a
time.
Nostalgia...........

neil_nw-walker@ae.ge.com

Subject: 911 oil gauge

P-folk:
   I am a former 944T owner, new 993 owner, still getting used
to all the wonderful features of the new car. But I find the oil
gauges particularly mystifiying. Why are there three of the 
little suckers, for one thing? Why does it take 25 minutes of
driving to get the oil-temp sensor to kick in and give you a 
reading? And how do you read the gauge when the needle is
so sensitive to car velocity and all that oil sloshing around the
sump? My gauge (on a car with 700-mi. on the odo) basically
resides in the red (as in down 2 galllons) zone while I'm motoring,
then slinks back up to the quasi-OK zone when I'm stationary.
Which is the proper reading? And is this really the pinnacle of modern
automotive technology?
    Wondering in Washington (D.C.)

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 17:44:13 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: Euro 911/930 turn signal indicator

When activating either the left or the right turn signal, BOTH my 
left AND right arrow indicators on the instrument panel flash. 
According to the owner's manual, this is supposed to happen when a
bulb is defective, but all bulbs are ok (front, side, and rear turn
signals on both sides) I checked the wiring diagram, but that didn't
help because the euro models aren't covered very well (doesn't show 
wiring for parking lights, side turn signals, etc).

Does anyone else have this problem ? So far, I assume that either
the flasher relay is bad, some wiring or ground connection is bad, 
or that the bulbs don't draw enough current. When the hazard light 
is on, the big red button flashes, but the turn signal indicators 
don't. Is this normal behavior ?

Thanks, 
Ray 	(Ray@Arkay.MV.COM or 70524.3012@Compuserve.com)

number that begins with WPOZZ which I recognize to be a European VIN.

and generally seems well taken care of. The salesman says they have B&R 
and that I can come look at them tomorrow when his boss returns.

reasonable?

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 17:18:18 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)
Subject: Re: 911 oil gauge

At 06:33 PM 2/15/95 -0500, LeeW639371@aol.com wrote:
>P-folk:
>   I am a former 944T owner, new 993 owner, still getting used
>to all the wonderful features of the new car. But I find the oil
>gauges particularly mystifiying. Why are there three of the 
>little suckers, for one thing? Why does it take 25 minutes of
>driving to get the oil-temp sensor to kick in and give you a 
>reading? And how do you read the gauge when the needle is
>so sensitive to car velocity and all that oil sloshing around the
>sump? My gauge (on a car with 700-mi. on the odo) basically
>resides in the red (as in down 2 galllons) zone while I'm motoring,
>then slinks back up to the quasi-OK zone when I'm stationary.
>Which is the proper reading? And is this really the pinnacle of modern
>automotive technology?
>    Wondering in Washington (D.C.) 

Wondering,

        The "gauge that resides in the red"  is indicating the amount of oil 
in the tank, not the engine.  As the oil changes temperature, the volume 
will change, and the speed with which it is scavanged out of the "dry" sump 
back into the tank will change.  As the rpm changes, the speed of the 2 oil 
pumps will change, causing the oil distribution between the engine and tank 
to vary.  The gauge is intended as an indication of oil in the system.  To 
REALLY measure it, use the dip stick.

        As to the other questions, not having a 993, I'd have to take yours 
for a spin to see what you're talking about :)

Bob



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 19:37:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944S stalling out


Hi Chris,

If your engine runs fine when cold but has a problem warm, I'd
look for something temperature related.  This could be an injector
o-ring or the intake manifold gasket.  You can test both for vacuum
leaks by dribbling tap water on them.  If, when you dribble it at a
particular place, the engine note changes, or you hear or see the
water being sucked into the intake, you've found a problem.

You cannot get the idle stabilizer out of a 944S without removing
the intake manifold.  When you do so, you will need a new gasket
for the manifold (p/n 944.110.305.02, list $10.80).  It goes on dry,
no sealant.

Could be an O2 sensor; they get slow with age.  However, if after
about three minutes of driving from dead cold, you do not have an
idle problem, I think the O2 sensor is probably not to blame.  That
is, if the problem doesn't surface until long after the cat has lit off
and the DME has started running closed loop, it is not the closed
loop that is causing the problem.

I found that my car is very sensitive to getting the baseline mixture
adjustment correct.  I do not have the spec in front of me, but whatever
is in the workshop manual is what you want.

Hope this helps, keep me posted.

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 17:35:56 -0800 (PST)
From: Clark Wallace <SAVE@CPVA.SAIC.COM>
Subject: 944s2 Plug Quandry


So 45K rolls over on the ol'944s2  odometer and me thinks its maybe time for
some new plugs (last changed at 30k).  Being a modern thinking kind of guy, I
decide to pick-up a set of Bosch platinums - WR5DP - as recommended by Mr.
Bosch himself.  After removing the old plugs - WR7DC - I gap (.75mm) the
platinums, slap on a leetol beet of anti-sieze and in they go.  Since then
it's been running rougher and hotter than before the change.  I should say "it 
seems to be running hotter" since I'm basing this on my opinion that the air 
temperature from the vents with the heater on is noticeably warmer at settings
that were previously acceptable (of course I could be the one full of hot air
on this one).  Trust me on the rougher part!

Are platinums just a bad idea on an '89 944s2?  Should I have used the WR7DP's?
Rechecking the gaps and boots is on my agenda, but that obviously won't help if
I've got the wrong part.

Thanks in advance,  Clark

Date: 15 Feb 1995 17:40:46 U
From: "Lance Keigwin" <lance_keigwin@Baynetworks.COM>
Subject: "9 Months" 911 cabs for sal

                      Subject:                              Time:  4:44 PM
  OFFICE MEMO         "9 Months" 911 cabs for sale          Date:  2/15/95

Just for fun I called on the 20th Century Fox Films cars
advertised in the S.F. Chronicle.  They have three red 911
cabs for sale, all made very close in appearance for
obvious reasons.  At least they were close in appearance
*before* filming began.

These cars were used for stunt.  Most of the stunts were
things like crashing into dummy barriers, hard acceleration
and braking, skidding, etc.  Some of it was a bit rougher,
however.  One 88 cab was jumped off a four foot ramp at
high speed, flying airborn across an intersection.   (This
is beginning to sound like Bart's Corvette story that nearly
killed him...or did it kill him?  I've forgotten.  I think it did
kill him; yes I'm sure now.)

Anyway, the guy I talked to pointed out that normally they
just junk stunt cars after a movie but the 911 handled the
abuse so well they are now able to sell it as is (hmmm...).
Crashing through prop barricades mostly just cost a
windshield and headlight here and there.  But the numerous
jumps were a little more serious.  The installed steel
undercarriage panels ("skid plates") protected the running
gear pretty well and the "tubed" tires must have been done
for similar reasons.  The fuel tank had to be pulled, natch.
Other vague changes to the fuel system were done (no doubt
so that it would accelerate to speed without a fuel tank).

All cars had some amount of interior work done so they
looked alike; the 83, a stripped theft recovery, was updated
to look like the other 88's.  And somehow the tops on all
three cars were damaged and need repair, even the 83
"backup stunt car" and 88 show car that weren't jumped.
All cars had been painted too.

There are dozens of caveats for each car, listed on a fact
sheet available by fax.  Some are really funny: "Lights
updated to look like an 88.  May not be wired correctly."
"Electrical system needs to be checked for alterations and
safety."  "Wrong suspension strut was installed on the left
front."  "Some body deformation noted."

Prices?
88 non-stunt: bids start at $25k
88 stunt: bids start at $11k
83 stunt backup: bids start at $12k

Call 415-522-5085 to buy one.  Think of the money you'll
save.  No need for a pre-purchase inspection!

Lance Keigwin, lkeigwin@baynetworks.com (Santa Clara)
95 993 coupe, guards red
85 535i, everyday grey
PCA# 91049838

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 18:01:33 -0800 (PST)
From: Clark Wallace <SAVE@CPVA.SAIC.COM>
Subject: Re: esson learned

>From: babak marefat <bmarefat@tigr1.fhsu.edu>
>Subject: esson learned

babak marefat writes:
[snip happens]
>Dennis Mitsch complains of oil changes in 944 and recommends to:
>"do ur own" or something along the line. Here is a little tip my
>mechanic showed me.  Before changing oil on 944s/late 924s, punch a
>hole in the top of the oil filter that way all the oil in it flows down
>and wont spill when u undo the filter.

This, to me, has a got to be one of the great 924/944 urban legends.  I too
was informed of this "trick" in order to avoid the Exxon Valdez disaster
at every oil change. So, like any good shade tree mechanic I punched a hole in
the top and "let the oil drain".  A half hour later I start spinning the filter
off and notice oil gushing from the base of the filter.  "Ah sh*t!!", so
I start spinning it madly and pull it out only to turn it over in the process
and create the Exxon Valdez disaster II on the cowl and my pant leg (hole in 
top was forgotten when hole at bottom began oozing).

These things have drain back valves that prevent them from emptying completely,
even if you do punch a hole in them (they do, don't they??). I tried this
technique once more (oil was real hot and I taped the hole over before I 
started removing the filter) and it still didn't work.  Gotta be an urban
legend, its just gotta.

Of course, I could have bought a dozen of those gag oil filters I've heard
rumored about . . .

Clark

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 1995 18:03:59 -0800

Subject: A porschephiles success story...

Hello everyone,

I finally found, checked out and purchased an '84 black 5spd 928S.  Much of
the credit goes you all you Porschephiles who helped answer my newbie
questions, and to one Porschephile in particular who went way, way out of
his way to help:  Alan Watkins of San Diego.

After answering (in great detail) an endless torrent of questions about his
'86 928, and educating me via email on the ins and outs of Porsches, 928's
and cars in general, Alan even took time one Saturday to pick me (a virtual
stranger) up from the San Diego airport (The car was in San Diego. I live
in San Jose) and drove out to see the car with me!!  He even let me drive
his car!  It was _way_ beyond the call of duty. I can't thank Alan enough
(Thank you Alan), and I think he deserves a Porschephiles round of
applause...

I'd say this helps put to rest any undeserved accusations of snobbishness
and unfriendliness that have been or will be directed at Porschephiles,
past, present or future.  I have to believe that this kind of assistance is
what we all joined the list for.

[I hesitate to say it, but even T*d helped.  While searching through the
archives, I came across mechanic recommendation from him for Heyer
Performance in Mountain View, who I've since gone to, and am completely
happy with.  (I guess T*d was only wrong 99.9% of the time.. :-)]

No doubt that the information I got here (and the people I met) on
Porschephiles saved me lots of money, and it's only right that I put some
of that savings toward supporting the list.  Count me in when all the dust
clears about how Stan is going to pay for upgrading the equipment.

Thanks again.  I'll be back when I have something useful to say...  (not
that that's necessarily a requirement for this list... ;-)

 - Pete Richardson
'84 928S         - Black, 5spd
'94 Quadra 840AV - Platinum, 40MHz

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 15 Feb 95 22:56:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944s2 Plug Quandry


Clark,

There are really at least two issues here.  The first is using heat range 5
versus heat range 7 plugs.  The 5 is a colder plug, meaning that it has a
shorter nose and, for that reason, its electrode will run cooler.  Porsche
has OK'ed both the 5 and 7 for the 944S2 (not sure about 968).  The 5
might have some advantage if you track the car.  For a pure street car,
a 7 is probably indicated.

A plug which is too cold will take longer too (or may never) reach self-
cleaning temperature, about 400 degrees C.  Which makes it (more)
prone to fouling.  Some mechanics dislike the platinum design because
its electrode design -- small and flush with the nose -- makes it more
susceptible to fouling.

The rough idle you experience is what I would expect when switching down
a heat range or two.  I tried a set of 5's in my own car (944S) a few years
ago, and had just the symptoms you describe.

Gap the plugs to the low end of the range: 0.7 mm.  The gap opens up over
time, and the 0.8 is more or less the top end of what you want, to my
understanding.  Don't use anti-seize on the threads.  Bosch ships the
plugs coated with a lubricant which they feel is adequate and correct.

Kevin Gross

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 02:29:06 -0500

>>Porschephiles is probably not the place to ask how to copy diskettes, how
to format your hard-drive, or how to type an umlaut over your vowels...<<

With all due respect, and trying to be very constructive (and knowing myself
how to copy and format disks etc.) I find George's response to reflect
precisely what the retired accountant was observing, his own real or
perceived failings notwithstanding.

Guys and Gals, I think it is more cool and rewarding to work hard at
maintaining a civil and positive attitude towards anyone on (or off) this
list who needs help, rather than to practice the Professor's relentless
Schwabian one-upmanship at every opportunity.

We are all super-cool because we all love Porsches AND can access the 'net,
and we all enjoy a healthy good laugh, but why not try to keep this "a
kinder, gentler" forum in consideration of all of our colleagues and partners
- -- give a hand, instead of sticking a tongue!!
(I for one, and probably Janet too, appreciated much more the Listmeister's
helpful response to her message.)

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 02:35:27 -0500
From: Jon50g@aol.com
Subject: Re: '87 Carrera

Peter,

Two things about the '87 911.
 -It was the first year the 911 saw the hydrolicly activated clutch.  
 This is opposed to the cable.  It behaves more smoothly.
 -It was the first year of the G50 transmission.  I felt the shifter on 
 one once in an '87 w/ >110k and was amazed at the improvement
 in the precision of the gate.  The fact that it had been 15+ yrs since 
 Porsche last changed it probably had something to do w/ it.

Chris Woodward
944S

while using

is in the 
>garage for the winter, and there isn't room next to it to work the handle of
the floor
>jack on the left side).  Of course, I would then insert my jack stands

>under.

My 944 is standing on jackstands (4) all winter long and i use a floor jack
to raise one
side (where the HAYNES manual is saying) install two jacks then do the same
on the other
side. I usually raise the car gradually from one side to the other until it
is about 12-14 inches 
high, giving me enough space to work there and have a beer at the same time.
Since the winter is quite long in Province of Quebec, Canada I have plenty of
time to kill 
under my baby (words from my wife).

Porschephiles #1173                         Thu Feb 16 09:50:46 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 01:26:21 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: 356/912 oil coolers

>Chris Jungmann asks about auxiliary oil coolers for his 912.

And Peter Albrecht responds:
 
>My 356 doesn't need one. Even going up long steep grades (like the Grapevine
>on I-5) at paralegal speeds, the
>oil temperature never climbs much above midscale. Sustained high speeds on

I've had the car 8 years now. I've always assumed my temps were normal. (A 
little on the high side) But since moving to 5500' altiture (New Mexico) it 
has gotten worse. (Thin air means less perf. and less cooling mass)

But, now I may have a problem. Oil temp gets to midscale in 32 degree 
weather (climbing) and 5/6 scale on hot days up long grades. Never too close 
to red line because I'll slow down before that.

I replaced the oil cooler 'O' rings many years ago and cleaned out the oil 
cooler at the same time, so I can rule that out.

The obvious first: Fan belt OK, Air flow plates OK, Webers synchronized.
Engine mileage: +/- 15K since rebuilt to 1780cc
The unknown: Condition of jets, Internal friction, Oil flow, other ?


Chris Jungmann


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 01:26:18 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: Air Cooled Cylinder Head Temp. Gauges

>Chris,
>
>My old corvair ('65 turbo Corsa) had a CHT gauge.  I believe that it only 
>had one sender (probably one per bank), as AL is such a good conductor of 
>Z snip Z
>Exhaust Gas temp (EGT) gauges are another story.  Unless I'm wrong (hard to 
>imagine, I realize, but just *possible*), your reference to aircraft was 
>actually a reference to EGT.  Whatever... I've read several articles, in 
Z snip Z
>
>Bart Chambers 

Hate to admit but I'm not right and you're not wrong:-). The gauge response 
is instantaneous (no thermal inertia except for the sensor head) so it must 
be EGT not CHT. I've been flying low perf. aircraft mostly that don't have 
EGT guage. (You lean it until RPM drops then enrich the mixture a bit, and 
watch passenger's expression:-). Not very precise ...



Chris Jungmann


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 01:26:23 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: CHT Gauges

>Chris Jungmann wrote:
>> Has anyone installed or used CHT guages in air cooled road machines with 
>> info to share ?

Ed Mellinger responded:
>
>I put the VDO cylinder head temperature gauge in my '83 SC.  It gives a
>useable reading but has several problems.  Problem 1 is that it is a
Z snip Z
>notice how much less heat capacity high-altitude air has, leading to
>indicated CHTs 50 degrees hotter at 6000 ft, and also you can note the

Less power too. It explains why I've noticed higher operating temps since 
moving to Albuquerque, NM (5500') from sea level. The terain is more 
challenging too with a lot of climbing and descending. I WILL need to find a 
way to optimize my cooling since I sometimes have to slow down as the oil 
temp guage edges closer to red-line. Any thoughts on that ?
 
Chris Jungmann

Bart said: Chris,
>
>My old corvair ('65 turbo Corsa) had a CHT gauge.  I believe that it only 
>had one sender (probably one per bank), as AL is such a good conductor of 
>Z snip Z
>Exhaust Gas temp (EGT) gauges are another story.  Unless I'm wrong (hard to 
>imagine, I realize, but just *possible*), your reference to aircraft was 
>actually a reference to EGT.  Whatever... I've read several articles, in 
Z snip Z
>

Hate to admit but I'm not right and you're not wrong:-). The gauge response 
is instantaneous (no thermal inertia except for the sensor head) so it must 
be EGT not CHT. I've been flying low perf. aircraft mostly that don't have 
EGT guage. (You lean it until RPM drops then enrich the mixture a bit, and 
watch passenger's expression:-). Not very precise ...
Chris Jungmann

Then Chris Jungmann gets worried:

I've had the car 8 years now. I've always assumed my temps were normal. (A 
little on the higher side) But since moving to 5500' altiture (New Mexico) 
it has gotten worse. (Thin air means less perf. and less cooling mass)

But, now I may have a problem. Oil temp gets to midscale in 32 degree 
weather (climbing) and 5/6 scale on hot days up long grades. Never too close 
to red line because I'll slow down before that.>

I replaced the oil cooler 'O' rings many years ago and cleaned out the oil 
cooler at the same time, so I can rule that out.

The obvious first: Fan belt OK, Air flow plates OK, Webers synchronized.
Engine mileage: +/- 15K since rebuilt to 1780cc
The unknown: Condition of jets, Internal friction, Oil flow, other ?
Chris Jungmann

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 14:04:53 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Accountants - attitudes - Navi sheep etc


Any body out there ever driven an old TR6?

When you met another TR did the driver wave, and exhibit that "hey nice 
to see another mug" behaviour. The chances are he did.

When I drive the 944, other porsche driver always avoid any
acknowledgement of the existence of my car. If I am sitting at lights 
along side another porsche the drivers always seem to stare ahead, 
careful to avoid eye contact. You are actually more likely to get a smile 
from a chap on a motor bike, than a p-driver

This could be just a UK attitude, we have a year of registration indicator
on our plates, so every one knows how old my car is. I think what happens 
is - 

other driver says hmm my cars newer than his so I am superior, so I won't
wave
or - 
my car is older than that "clever clogs" so I am not going to toady to HIM
or - 
I have a 911 so I am not going to wave to that 924 driver...... 

When the 924 first came out PClub GB would not accept 924 drivers as 
members, this persisted until the 924 turbo came out.


From the above, I would conclude that there is a high level of elitism 
among UK porsche driver - though having said that, the few other porsche 
owners that I meet regularly are charming people, so it could be that the 
types I refered to above are not clubby people.

Of course it is probably different in the US, where a newish porsche does 
not cost more than 1 years average income.

Pete D

Date: 16 Feb 95 09:53:07 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: More on cyl head temp gauges

 
>What, you got a TIT gauge now and burning kerosene...
 
(For the politically correct, TIT is turbine inlet temp.)
 
No, not turbines. And not burning kerosene. The thing was a Piper Apache
which burned oil. My instructor would not let me fire it up if there were
any strangers on the ramp, if any FAA types saw this thing's oil smoke on
startup, they would probably ground it. (In fact, it was just like starting
up every 911, new or old, I've ever driven). I think the airplane eventually
lost an engine, had to do an off-field landing and stuffed one main gear
strut through the wing. At a value of $10,000 (with two high-time engines)
it wasn't worth saving. The Apache is a great trainer because Vmc, minimum
control speed with the critical engine out, is only a few knots below Vxse,
best angle of climb speed (for avoiding those trees you noticed at the end of
the runway just as the critical engine failed).
 
Thermocouples need to be temperature compensated to read accurate
temperature; otherwise they generate a voltage based on the delta t between
the connections. Consider a Type J (iron-constantan) TC:
 
     _iron_______
    /            |
   o             V                          This is an uncompensated TC.
    \____________|copper leads in rest of circuit.
      constantan
 
 
You may wonder if the junctions between the iron and copper, and constantan
and copper, don't generate voltage of their own. There is something called
the Law of Intermediate Metals: "If a third metal is in the circuit as
shown, the net emf [voltage] of the circuit is not affected as long as the
new connections are at the same temperature."
 
A compensated thermocouple is like the following, using either a container
of ice and water (usually a thermos flask with ice and water) or an
electronic ice point which typically uses a small camera battery for power.
 
                ____constantan_____________________
               /                                   |
junction      o                                    V
(measuring     \_iron____     __constantan_________|
point)                   |   |
                   ||    |   |     ||
                   ||    |   |     ||
                   ||     \  /     ||
                   ||      o       ||
                   ||==============||  ice water bucket
 
Assuming a linear thermocouple response, measuring temperatures with the
other junction (you have another thermocouple junction, even if you don't
know it; if there is no compensating TC, the other junction is inside the
measuring instrument, where the connections are made) at room temperature,
say 70 deg F, instead of 32 deg F results in a temperature measuring error
of 38 deg. (70 - 32). If what you are trying to measure is at 70 deg F and
the gauge is also at 70 deg, you measure a temperature of zero (actually
measuring temperature DIFFERENCE). So if you use the example of leaving
Chicago on a -30 deg day, and flying to Death Valley where it is 120, your
uncompensated TC will read high on departure and low on arrival.
 
TCs are not strictly linear, but that's the general idea.
To see how nonlinear they are: (gauge will not read 30 deg. too high if
flying in air 30 deg. above freezing point of water):
 
Let's see, suppose actual EGT is 1200 deg. F and ambient is -30, gauge
sees 37.694 millivolts, which it "thinks" is 1250 deg. F. (not exactly the
62 deg. difference you expect but close).
 
Second case, actual EGT 1200 deg F and ambient 120, gauge sees 33.473 mV
which it interprets as 1124 deg. Again not exactly the 88 deg difference you
expect but only about 10 deg. off.
 
So now we have a temperature gauge swing of 126 degrees, while true exhaust
temperature has not changed at all (assuming this fictitious airplane
doesn't undergo mixture changes as air gets hotter/colder/thinner/denser.)
and ambient air temperature has changed not by 126 but by 150 degrees.
 
This is why for any accurate (laboratory) temperature measurement you need
an ice point of some sort.
 
I found more cylinder head temperature gauge stuff in the Aircraft Spruce
and Specialty catalog. 714-870-7551.
 
They have a CHT setup for kit planes using VW or Rotax engines, which I
figure would be perfect for 4-cyl Porsches. An individual 0-600 deg F gauge
is $35, an individual 14 mm spark plug gasket-type sensor is 10.30. Says
"multiple switching available." Leads are 4 ft. long.
 
Also an EGT setup, 700 to 1700 deg F, $35; clamp type senders with 3/16 dia.
probe, 1/2 or 1" long tip, $23.45; bayonet type 1/4" threads, $28.80;
bayonet type for VW, 1.5" OD tailpipe, $23.40. Leads are 4 ft. long.
 
It looks to me like these are lots cheaper than the prices I got from the
Pegasus catalog. Adds to about $150, not counting a rotary selector switch to
go to different cylinders. (Usually you put this stuff on #3 and assume
you're not running exceptionally lean on any others).
 
Wait, here it is, selector switch for EGT or CHT, they have 2,4, and 6
cylinder switches, $18.45 for 4 cyl and $21.85 for six.
 
But there's more. Next page shows quad CHT and EGT gauges. $139 each. They
also have add-on kits and "engine analyzer kits" which include all the extra
sensors and selectors.
 
They also have "scanners" which cycle through all cylinders and display the
EGT or CHT and a pointer to indicate which cylinder is currently being
read. Blurb says "These scanners feature circuitry which automatically
compensates for ambient temperature with an error of less than 2%. ...very
low power design, operating on less than 20 mA on 12 or 24 V systems. The
unit can be powered by a single 9 V transistor battery if normal aircraft
battery is not available." Sounds like an electronic ice point thermocouple
set up.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 95 10:27:45 PST
From: Robert M Zampardi <us000812@interramp.com>
Subject: RE: Thieves & title laundering 

I wrote:
from my experience cars that have 'dirty' titles, ie floods, wrecks
burns etc are USELESS to a thief if they are stamped that way; also
known as 907a titles.  The reason is that in order to register a vehicle
that has a 907a title, it must be inspected, all damage had to have
been repaired with legit parts, (they check numbers with paperwork you better 
have)  All wreck parts from later p-cars are vin'ed missing numbers, and
you cant register.  So thieves actually need clean titled cars that they
can register and put STOLEN parts on.  MAYBE YOUR CAR!!?

rz

y'all wrote:
>
>>>Apparently, these flood damaged cars can be totaled by the insurance
>>>companies, sold as scrap, recovered by someone else, taken out of
>>>California, retitled (now the new title does not say recovered), and sold
>>>to some poor souls. Disgustingly dishonest! So buyers of cars in Oregon,
>>>Nevada, Washington, etc., be aware!
>>>Minh Le.
>
>>Better include California buyers. The cars can be taken out of CA,
>>registered in AZ which eliminates the Salvage designation from the title,
>>then reregistered in CA with a clean title.
> (snip)
>>Don
>
>   This won't work in Texas; a car recovered by then sold by the insurance
>company will print the mark "Water damaged" on a flood car (or 
"reconditioned"
>for a wrecked car). If taken out of the state, then re-titled back in Texas 
>the mark _isn't_ erased as a title search shows the history and the car 
stays
>"marked," i.e. title laundring doesn't work. Of course, its completely up to 
> the donor state if it doesn't return to Texas. 
>
>   Probably 90% or better of water damaged cars end up back on the road, 
there
> is -no- condition of car where Texas demands "scrapping" the car (there
> should be; burnt hulks of expensive cars can sell for thousands of dollars
> at auction, this is purely for the theft market where car identities are
> needed...That the price gets bid to say, $7000 for a worthless, burnt
> Mercedes is kind of scary since it means there is -competition- among 
thieves
> for the VIN/title....Insurance companies would be smart to privately scrap
> these cars instead of dumping them thru the salvage auctions, but whats it
> to them ??).
>    One sure way to avoid getting burned is to ask for records for a car.
> You sort out guys who aren't obsessed with the maintenance of their cars
> and are sure to get only personal cars with proven care.
>
>  At auction, flood cars can sell for nearly wholesale (there are no easy
> bargains in the car world). But flood cars can make good cars, and if fixed
> right the only damage is the stain you can't get off the title...
>
>            Lee A. 
>

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 10:20:08 -0500 (EST)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: 944 tires

If you've got *any* high performance car, much less a Porsche, definitely 
go with Pirelli P Zeroes. I've tried them all: Yokohama, Goodyears, 
Michelin, Avon (!), and more--the Zeroes are the best of the lot. As for 
RE 71s, I wouldn't buy a Bridgestone/Firestone product because of what 
the Japanese owners/mgmnt did to striking US workers (they canned 'em 
all, despite pleas from the US govt). 

The Zeroes are also quite good in the snow, and as a 944 has a 50-50 
weight distribution,(my Turbo has limited slip, too), you should have 
pretty good traction. Really, the Zeroes aren't that much more than other 
brands--stick with 'em. 


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 09:37:00 -0500 (EST)

          Hi all,
          
          Since joining this list two weeks ago, I've learned an 
          immeasurable amount of information about P-cars.  I've bought 
          texts that have been mentioned in p-philes and am very thankful 
          for the guidance everyone gives!  Sometime ago I "inherited" what
          is a shell and frame of a 1957 356A.  The car's body and frame 
          are in excellent condition, it's been in storage for about 20+ 
          years (I've been drooling over it since I was 7, I'm 28 now).  
          Now for the problem - this car has NOTHING on it.  No gauges, 
          interior, trim, electrical, windscreen, trans, or motor.  The 
          chassis is rolling, but the car has been modified somewhat:  Disk 
          brakes, Carrera GT style roll bar, flared rear wheel wells.  
          Since the previous owner is no longer with us, and not thinking I 
          would ever aquire it, I never asked about the car's history.  
          According to his wife, it seems that he was trying to make it 
          into a "Carrera GT" but never able to find the proper drive train 
          (or be able to afford it, according to Hemmings, nore will I).
          
          I WANT to finish it.  Because of the mods, I don't think it's 
          worth much, so I don't want to follow a concours restoration.  
          I've seen numerous advertisers supplying 356 resto parts, any 
          recommendations?  I want this car to be my daily driver when it's 
          done (summer only), so I need a motor and trans that would hold 
          up to spirited driving, and which parts are plentiful. Maybe a 
          912?  Any suggestions?
          
          Thanks everyone!
          
                          -Paul Souza, but usually go by "Cello"
          
          '57 356A
          '85 Audi Coupe GT

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 10:12:15 EST
From: kresh@cvi.hahnemann.edu
Subject: Re: 924S Question(s)


From: Keith M Roberts <kroberts@crl.com>



>I recently came across a 1987 924S at a "Tote your note" style used car
>dealer and I just had to take a look.
>I noticed something I thught was rather odd in that the VIN number on the
>windshield pillar (which matches the title) was your typical North
>American #, It started: WPOAA.... But when I looked under the hood I see
>another number stamped on the passenger side firewall area I see a different
>number that begins with WPOZZ which I recognize to be a European VIN.
>Anyone have an explanation for this?


My understanding is that the "ZZ's" are "universal" wehen the VIN is stamped on
the chassis. If the last 4-5 digits are identical this 
would indicate that it is *not* a hybrid of few cars.

Regards, Jascha

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 09:36:51 -0600
From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: 944 belt case vent hose

Kirk Shafer asked about a vent hose that runs from the upper corner of the
cam belt cover to the air filter case.  Porsche has issued a bulletin to
remove this hose and cap off the connections at the air filter box and belt
cover with rubber caps sold by your friendly Porsche dealer parts people
(they are very inexpensive).

The bulletin can be found at the back of the Euro Select Parts catalog.
No reason is given but my guess is that it keeps belt fluff from clogging
up the air filter when the sprockets eat a belt.

By the way, belt fluff detection is a good argument for keeping your
engine clean.  When it starts to show up on the engine you have maybe a
couple of very short trips before all the teeth are eaten through and it
is time to replace the belt and the offending sprocket.

John	'89 944

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 09:43:01 -0600
From: smaardyk@rs6000.houston.wireline.SLB.COM
Subject: Sodium Thrills

Peter Albrecht writes about entertainment from sodium.  Actually, I think
the story about the Charles River may be an old urban legend.  I used to
dump 500 lbs of boiling sodium into concrete crucibles for the US Nuclear
Regulatory Commission.  Now that can get exciting but even there the only
explosions were from hydrogen released by the sodium/concrete reactions.

We used to practice extinguishing sodium fires by burning a brick weighing
about two lbs in air.  Spraying water on it just produced lots of smoke.
In short, it is not nearly as reactive as we have all been led to believe
by our high school chemistry teachers.

John

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 10:54:16 -0500 (EST)

> by our high school chemistry teachers.
>  
> John

its low surface area per unit volume.  Try that with POWDERED sodium,
and then you have some fun!

later,

Nate

Porschephiles #1174                         Thu Feb 16 13:12:09 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 08:04:55 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: RE: region formation

Stan -

As I had promised, I went looking for the old porcedure manual I had on 
the shelf.  There is a section on region formation which has 6 
requirements.  They are:

	1.  There must be 25 or more who subscribe to the general 
objectives of the club and who will not adopt rules that are inconsistent 
with the National Bylaws.

	2.  Talks about forming a region out of territory already aprt of 
another region.........this doesn't seem to apply,but what territory 
would we have?

	3.  Talks about funds from previous region not being owned by the 
new region and any National dues going to the old region stay until a 
charter is granted.

	4.  You must have elected officials.

	5.  Must submit a signed petition to become chartered.  Must be 
signed by officers, any current PCA members and others who have applied 
for membership.  There must be a minimum of 25 people including officers.

	6.  Must submit region bylaws within 60 days.

Further it states that you should incorporate (though not necessarily) to 
limit liability of officers of the club and National.  Dues are $36 per 
year with part of it being refunded to the region and the remainder going 
to publish Panorama, insurance for club activities, salaries and expense 
for maintaining the National Executive office and general expenses for 
National officers meetings and attending Parades.

I would assume most of this would be in your Region Formation packet but 
just in case I have submitted it here.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

Date: 16 Feb 1995 08:10:58 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: 928S Oil Pressure Question

                                                                    8:02 AM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      928S Oil Pressure Question                    2/16/95
                                                              Date:


Just read a question about a 944 pressure gage and that
prompted me to ask this question about my 84 928S gage.

I remember reading somewhere that the gage should 
register 5 bar at about 5,000 RPM.  My gage (when the
engine is at normal operating temperature) indicates
3 bar at idle and just hits 5 bar at 2,000 RPM.

The questions I have are as follows:  what do you other
928 folk experience?  Could my gage be inaccurate and
should I care (as long as I register oil pressure, should
it matter how much?)?  Is there some way to test this 
without replacing the gage?  Could the sender be fouled
and, if so, is this something I can clean?

Thanks in advance for any suggestions, hints, or advice!

John
'84 928S 5Spd

few others whose names I forget or were forgettable.  Of course the main 
stars were the cars, a California-ized Silver '57 or '58 Carrera Speedster, 
a '63 Vette and a slew of other great cars with cameo appearances by 
serveral other Porsches.  It was the the eternal battle of good versus 
evil, Harry Hamlin vs Dennis Hopper, Sane vs Insane, Porsche vs Chevy.

cliff or blown up.  I wonder if anyone ever picked it up for salvage

ought to do a Where Are They Now?

Date: 16 Feb 95 11:26:41 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Engine-turned sheet metal

 
There are different ways to do it. Some machinists like to use a wooden
dowel in a milling machine, with lapping compound. Some like those new
scotchbrite-like pads stuck to the end of a dowel. Good for one swirly mark
apiece before you need to glue another on (tedious).
 
I found a method I like. I coat the work with a thin layer of oil, sprinkle
some carborundum abrasive on it (experiment with different sizes to get the
effect you want) and run a rubber disc (used for pressure-sensitive adhesive
backed grinding discs, but without the abrasive) into the work. It's quick, you
just need to brush some of the oil-carbo mixture onto the spot you are going
to hit next, run the disc down manually (drill press works fine) and presto,
swirly marks.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 10:36:58 -0500 (EST)
From: jrb@one.com (Jerry Brady)
Subject: Valve clearance status...

If at first you don't succeed...

Thanks to all who gave insight into possible causes of the zero clearance,
but the problem was more stupid than anyone(including myself) imagined.

Frustrated, I tore down the head in question the valve seats looked fine
and all the springs/caps seemed to be dead level with each other.  Okay, so
I can use the same machine shop again; that was reassuring.

Could FAT of sent me a faulty cam?  Pull lifters, rotate to TDC for #3 and #4
while visually inspecting the cam and its lobes.  Seemed to be dead flat for
both at TDC for each.  Okay, so FAT lives up to it's name.

So, I built the head back up and torqued it down.  While installing the 
rockers and attempting yet again to set the clearance, the problem moved 
from #4 to #3!  Then I noticed the problem existed for #4 as well!  If I
were in Denmark I would of smelled something rotten.

I backed off the rockers a bit and wiggled them back and forth with one hand
while I moved the pushrod up with the other(I don't have the luxury of an
engine stand - the engine is on a bench) and low and behold - pop goes the
pushrod.  The pushrod had not seated at the bottom of the lifter!  I had
more clearance now than I knew what to do with.  So, repeat process for 
*all* of the cylinders to correct the problem(it existed on many of the
other pushrods as well.

Everything is wonderful again and my spirits lifted.  I can't believe how
ridiculous the problem was, but I perserverd in spite of my ignorance.  I 
still can't believe the pushrods could of opened the valves without seating
themselves on the lifters.  Bizarre.  

And so the rebuild saga continues...
- -----------------------------------------------------------------------------
 - Jerry R. Brady 
 - '70 914 1.9 (96mm NPR, canary yellow 916 conversion)

Date: 16 Feb 1995 09:04:08 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: Shocks

                                                                    8:55 AM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      RE>Shocks                                     2/16/95
                                                              Date:


>>  I have an '86 928 with 29K miles.  The shocks are OEM.
Snip
>>  Are the Bilsteins brutal?

I replaced a set of old Bilsteins on my 84 928S with all
new Bilsteins and am very happy with the ride.  It's not
a soft ride (i.e., you can feel the road surface texture 
quite nicely) but it won't loosen your dental fillings either.

The suspension is designed for a specific combination
of shock and spring ... I have no idea what the effect
would be of putting a stiffer shock without changing the
springs.

John
84 928S 5Spd

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 95 10:27:16 -0700
From: dhagood@page.mmc.com (Dave Hagood)
Subject: 1995 Porsche 993 at Daytona

Pfellow Pfilers:

	I had previously mentioned the new 993 that ran at Daytona
in GTS-2.  I have more information from Bob LaPiana, who was part
of the crew.  From rec.auto.sport.info, the 993 finished:

26. (GTS-2, 13th) Jarett Freeman, Portland, Ore., Simon Gregg,
Jacksonville, Fla., Nort Northam, Winter Park, Fla., Max Schmidt,
Oglesby, Ill., and Rusty Schmidt, Vail, Colo., Porsche 911, 553.


    The the mods made to the 1995 993 were.

   *  Removal of brake shields, A/C, radio, interior, sunroof motor
      and mufflers, the catalytic conveter was still in place.

   *  Springs and shocks were changed and the car was lowered.

   *  Added a roll cage, fuel cell, radio and battery cutoff.

   *  Used Cool Carbon brake pads.

   *  Stock wheels (7x17 and 9x17) with Street legal Toyo tires.

   
      The car was driven by Jarett Freeman, Simon Gregg, Nort Northam and
   Max Schmidt.  It was Simon Greggs racing professional debut (Peter's son).
   The car was owned by Bud and Jarett Freeman.  The only things we changed
   during the race were tires and brake pads.  We added about one quart of
   oil and about 2 oz. of brake fluid.  The brake fluid was added when the
   left front brake pad went metal to metal and a little fluid leaked out.


                                                       Bob LaPiana
                                                     W: (407) 356-8367

   P.S.    The car was driven to and from the track.  Only the windshield
           was cleaned before the drive home.  The car was FLAWLESS.


	Also, interestingly enough, I met Max Schmidt here in Denver when we
were both looking at an '81 911SC coupe.  We spent a couple of hours checking
the car out and gabbing about racing.  He mentioned they were trying to put
something together for Daytona....

	Cool.

Dave

domain, by becoming part of PCA it becomes private in some respects. Don't
get me wrong, I think PCA is great as well, I'm a member. But I don't think
it applies here. The bottom line is that if Stan wishes to continue the list,
Great!!, but why get caught up in more bull from an organization. Just an
additional $.02.

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 95 12:40:52 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: Re: Accountants - attitudes - Navi sheep etc

>Any body out there ever driven an old TR6?
>
>When you met another TR did the driver wave, and exhibit that "hey nice 
>to see another mug" behaviour. The chances are he did.
>
>When I drive the 944, other porsche driver always avoid any
>acknowledgement of the existence of my car. If I am sitting at lights 
>along side another porsche the drivers always seem to stare ahead, 
>careful to avoid eye contact. You are actually more likely to get a smile 
>from a chap on a motor bike, than a p-driver
>
>This could be just a UK attitude, we have a year of registration indicator
>on our plates, so every one knows how old my car is. I think what happens 
>is - 
>...
>>From the above, I would conclude that there is a high level of elitism 
>among UK porsche driver - though having said that, the few other porsche 
>owners that I meet regularly are charming people, so it could be that the 
>types I refered to above are not clubby people.
>
>Of course it is probably different in the US, where a newish porsche does 
>not cost more than 1 years average income.

Actually, this sounds very much like the US. I drove a variety of Triumphs
years ago (RHD TR3, LHD TR3, TR4A), and waves to other drivers of similar
cars almost always elicited a return wave, or some other acknowledgement.
When I drove a Lotus Elan (the early one), an encounter with any other
Lotus was virtually certain to include some type of waving, if not
stopping to talk (or perhaps we just simulaneously stopped to fix
something which broke, a common occurance with these cars).

When I got my first Porsche (a 1967 911S, in 1970), I found much less
waving, etc among the Porsche crowd, and virtually none with the other
up-scale sports cars of the era. Now, when I wave to another Porsche
from my 944S, it seems I almost always get some type of a "what kind
of nut are you?" look in response.

I don't know if the change was chronological, or was related to the
cost of the cars, or their previous relative rarity, but there certainly
has been a change.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 13:19:00 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: powder coating

Stan writes:

 "The piece is then heated in a blast furnace to melt
the powerder paint, leaving the metal very effectively enamaled. 

GREAT stuff for high-abuse items, like sheet metal, wheels, tools..."



But - I am told that it is unwise to powder coat items that may suffer
hairline cracking and subsequent  failure  under stress as the can crack
beneath the coating and you will not be able to (visually) detect the the
problem before it occurs

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 10:07:49 -0800
From: dswiger@qntm.com
Subject: Engine Rebuild for 914/6, to 2.2E


I am rebuilding the engine in my 914/6 to a 2.2E motor.  The main question I
have is about the crank.  Since the original motor is based on a 69 911T motor,
the crank is not counterweighted.  The rods may be different as well.  I am
wondering if the crank will be up to the stresses of the larger discplacement
as well as a slightly higher RPM redline.  I don't plan on spinning it any 
higher than 6500, but would want to know if that would be safe/reliable.  

I know that some racer types use the non-counterweighted cranks to lessen 
reciprocating weight, but they tear down their motors more often than I want
to!  Any ideas??

        Thanks, Dan

dswiger@qntm.com
dswiger180@aol.com
70 914/6 2.0
75 914-2.0, "Road Warrior"

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 95 10:34:48 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: re: ramps/jacks


>What is the best way to get under a Porsche for repairs?

I have a friend who bought an hydraulic lift that he
uses in his garage.  It's portable, i.e., is not bolted
to the floor or otherwise attached.  He has been very,
very happy with it, and he just told me that one of his
friends also purchased one after seeing his.  He says
that in a garage with normal height, the car can be
lifted high enough for you to comfortably sit under it.

Cost was about $1600 or $1700.  If you're interested
I can get the manufacturer's name for you.

Bob Spindel

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 13:42:00 -0500
From: AnalogMike@aol.com
Subject: RE: 944s2 Plug Quandry

Clark is having problems with plugs in his 944S engine.

As Kevin said, the WRxDP "K-Mart" platinum plugs are NG.
They barely run at all in my 911S engine.

Try the Bosch silver plugs in 7 or 6 range, they work great in
my '72 911S. They are WRxDS I think, and not too expensive.
I would stick with the stock range (7?) unless you are on a
race track.

Mike Piera '72 911S '73 914/2.0

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 95 10:51:27 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: RE: Porsche Dauphine


One of my cohorts at Berkely in the sixties was a guy named Keith 
Duckworth. Keith's dad had bought him a '59 Dauphine for graduation to
commute in (this wa in '64). The paint was a real beat pale blue and it 
leaked everywhere. My roommate had a '62 B coupe that Keith would have 
killed for.

We decided to help out friend a little. I went out and bought some black 
paint and a vacuum cleaner paint spray kit from JC Whitney. We painted it 
black, the paint was decent. It still looked plain though. I had a few 
beers and a plan formed. I got some blue metalflake paint and put scallops
on it, adding some bad imitations of Von Dutch's pinstriping in places 
that seemed appropriate. My room mate thought this was great, but the 
front was too high. I made a modification to the front that dropped it 2 
inches.

We all piled in the following Saturday to go cruising. More women thought 
the damn thing was cute. The guys laughed at it. Anyone that cruised East
14th Street in 1964-65 will remember it. My room mate and I painted one
pink for a lady he was seeing, white scallops there.

Keith sold the Renault to buy his first Porsche in 1966. He still has that 
1964 SC coupe. We still get a few laughs out of the Dauphine.

Jim Pasha

walled socket.  I use the spark plug tool supplied

thin-walled deep socket for this application?

Date:     Thu, 16 Feb 95 14:25:42 EST

  (I got silence too...I guess I'm the only one with no garage :-)
   I suspect the windshield gasket...any other recommendations?


You should be able to find your color ID label in the boot, passenger's
front fender area near the spare tire.  FWIW, if you don't have any
touch-up paint, for your '85 it might be no longer available.  I found
that Iris Blue Metallic is NLA; I think the minimum size was a quart.


A car bra is supposed to prevent NEW chips, but there's some pros/cons to
their use.  I got a [factory] bra for Christmas but I only know the very
basics...ie, I shouldn't leave them on wet nor leave it on enough that I
get differential sun fade on the paint...but WHAT ELSE?

Hugh

Peter Diffey bemoans the lack of camaraderie between Porsche drivers in GB.
 
Same thing here. The only Porsche people who greet each other on the road
are the 356 folk. Porsches of all descriptions are common here in California
so maybe the owners don't make a big deal of seeing another. It's not
unusual at an intersection to look around and see most of the basic Porsche
configurations ever built -- 911, 928, 924/44, 914 and of course self in own
356.
 
In Germany, 911 drivers used to flash their headlights at each other, about
10 years ago. Probably hasn't changed.
 
Pete

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 15:15:51 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: RE: re tire advice

Thanks for all the advice on tires. I would have responded earlier but AOL
mail has lately been slower than snail mail. There has been a little debate
whether or not putting H rated Yokohama A509 would cripple a '73 911S targa.
 Here are some of the positive responses to my comments. They will remain
anonymous to leave the authors out of this little debate-

"I've A509s in 225/50-16.  I  would buy them again."

"Highly biased, personally, to the A509 or AVS Intermediate for 911
applications
that don't involve "serious" driving"

Now for some negative comments and my answers to their criticisms.

Ben asked "Is it really worth it to cripple your 911 to save that cash
($200)?" 

I would agree with him if I planned on racing my car. However, I'm not
planning on it and there are several other factors that come into play.
Anyway, it's not like I'm planning on putting the cheapest tires I can find.
I'm buying one of the better (best?) H rated tires on the market. Which will
be better than any tire that the car originally came with.

 I don't plan on going over 130mph. I would like to but it isn't realistic or
advisable to try in Florida. Too many state troopers with radars. In N.
California it was possible to hit speeds over 130 at  3 A.M. on 280 between
Woodside Road and Black Mountain because the the police couldn't ambush you
with radar. But I live here in Florida where that is impossible, just ask
Jose Canseco- the baseball player.

Ben continues "you also need to consider how many g you are pulling in
acceleration and deceleration," 

 I don't plan on going racing and Miami roads don't demand much from the
tires as the city is laid out in a grid system. There just aren't any
interesting roads to street race on, which is what you seem to like. Come
drive here in Miami and you will see what I'm talking about. The only
excitement I get is from one large roundabout and one highway  on-ramp.
Expensive hi-performance tires aren't necessary in stop'n go traffic or on
straight 60mph roads. That's the reality here.  

Neil Kumpers
'73 911S targa

P.S. If you weren't trying to flame me, why didn't you just try to e-mail me
directly like many people did, instead of going through the whole group? But
thanks for you concern anyway.

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 15:12:23 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Parts Needed !!!

 I'm about to put the bottom end of my 911 motor back together.(yeaaaaaa!!)
Everything going great. I have run into a small sumbling (sp) block. There
is a 2" stud (part # 900.061.115.02..probably has replacement # by now) that
is on the very back hand right side of the right side of the case. I 
broke this when I was taking it apart. The machine shop removed it and the
thread in the case is fine. The stud is 8mm. There is no replacement
available thru PCNA or any of my normal sorces. I did find one at the local
hardware reseller. I am a little aprehensive about using this part no
knowing how it will react to the heating and cooling of the block. The
other stud that is missing is on of the studs that holds the breather on top
of the motor. This I have found replacement for localy and doesen't
realy scare me as much as one that holds the block (or the #8 bearing) together.

   We have no local Porsche Recyclers local. Do you have one or booth
of these around that you will sell to me? I need it yeaterday. Still
shooting for compleation fo this job on April 1st. TIA!!!

Call me at 18006415581 if you have one of these. 
Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org

From: NannW@aol.com
Subject: 1995 Parade Registration Update

As of earlier this week, there are 575 registrations in place for the
Portland Parade.  Since the cap on the number that will be accepted is 650,
this means that there are 75 more slots available.  If you have not yet sent
in your registration, there is still time to do so.

suggests that an additional 25 or so slots will open up over the course of
the next two to three months.

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 16:08:07 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Re: Cleaning a neglected car

Dear Steve:

Your question of the best way to clean a neglected car with little effort was
answered "Take it to a detailer". 

This is the easiest, albeit the most expensive.  A less costly yet more labor
intensive might include the following.

1. Insure that the car is cool to the touch and in shade, then wash the car
thoroughly with a quality car wash and dry.

2. Pick a fender, or door or any surface of the car that is separated by a
seam.  Complete all the below steps on this ONE area before moving onto
another area.  This way you don't start out on Saturday morning full of
energy and strip all the wax off the car and then run out of steam (or get
handed some honeydo's) and leave the car stripped of all wax.  

Note: The following steps are listed in the most conservative (read labor
intensive/easiest on the car) order.  Any solvents used on your Porsche's
paint should be tested prior to use.  Pick an area of the paint that is not
visible.  I like to use the seam under the rocker panels.  It is almost
invisible and has a nice coat of paint.  Apply a little solvent to your rag
and rub the test area.  If paint does not stain the rag, then in all
probability, the solvent is safe for your paint.  If it does stain the rag,
you may wish to use a different solvent.

3. Clean the surface of the paint with a quality glaze. I prefer 3M Imperial
Hand Glaze but there are several other quality glazes.  Apply the glaze to
your 100% cotton cloth or applicator pad and gently rub in a back to front /
front to back motion. Work the glaze into the surface thoroughly and allow to
dry.  Buff out using another soft 100% cotton cloth. (I use my wife's old
flannel sheets). If this has produced the finish you desire, then follow up
with a quality hard wax. Apply the wax with your fingers and buff out with
yet another cotton cloth.  Move onto another section of the car.  

4. The track rubber marks will come out this way, but will take some time and
effort.  For areas that are especially difficult to remove try using either
P21S Total Auto Wash, Wurth Citrus Degreaser or Oil Flo Safety Solvent to
remove these marks. (I use the Oil Flo). Take a soft cloth, apply a small
amount of one of the above solvents to the cloth and gently rub out the
rubber mark.  These products will not normally harm a hardened paint if used
as directed.  Immediately rinse the area to remove any trace of the solvent.
Dry and if the mark is gone, give the spot area another quick glaze.  Then
apply a coat of wax to the entire section.

5. If your car looks like it was hit with a canon blast of black gum drops (3
days at Watkins Glen), then you may wish to reverse steps 3 and 4.  The
safest method of using any solvent is to allow it to remain in contact with
the paint for ONLY the amount of time that it takes to do the job and rinse
completely. 

6. For wheel wells, spray one of the above solvents directly onto the area to
be cleaned.  Allow a few moments for the solvent to work, gently sponge or
use a VERY soft brush to loosen the grime.  Rinse with a lot of water to
remove all traces of the solvent.  Dry throughly.  A trick to reduce the
amount of crud that builds up in the wheel wells is to give them a coat of
Sonax Hard Wax Spray.  This will provide a thin coat of wax to help stop the
build up street grunge and track "rubber snakes".

If you have any questions or wish amplification of any of the above, please
let me know.


Larry Reynolds
Care Care Specialties, Inc.
Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com

86 944 Turbo Tracker
90 944 S2 Cabrio Cleaner
19__ Wife
1988 Canine Domesticus


 

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 12:55:19 -0500
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: Extrude Honing/951 engine rebuild

Someone over on the quattro list sez (wrt EH of turbo parts):
"I estimated the hp by isolating this addition (one of the few I did as stand
alone) with the vericom and/or the g alnalyst (can't remember which since I
did it about 1 1/2 yrs ago...  I did help a guy do this (EH the exh impellor
and housing only) on a 944turbo that sat on the dyno and we got +14hp @6200
isolating the EH and a torque increase as well (1.8bar at 2100rpm vs 1.8@3k
b4).  Definitely a must do at 100.00.  All you need is some patience (EH
turnaround is about 2weeks) and a rebuild kit for your turbo.  Just about
EVERY racer that runs a turbo has this as a speed secret (no more!).  If you
want some more unbelievable numbers, send your intake/head/exhaust man/turbo
as a single unit to EH and they will match all four components and the
results of this defy any logical explanation, the results are phenominal..."

The way I understand it, EH increases air-flow by removing a tiny layer from 
treated parts.  How exactly do they do this, is it by acid-dipping and does 
this weaken parts?  Is EH recommended for *street* engines with occasional 
track excursions?  I would not think of taking my engine apart to do this now 
but when it's time for a re-build, I'd consider it then.  I've also talked to 
a couple of people who've rebuilt their 2.5L Turbo to a 2.8L.  One guy who did
that is now building a 3.0L Turbo using a 944S2 block and '89 TurboS 
head/turbo/brakes etc with custom chips.  
He's expecting 300-330 reliable HP.  Any comments?

Steve J. 
'87 951 Pearl Black

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 15:51:22 -0600
From: martinw@eapi.com

From martinw Thu Feb 16 16:30:04 1995
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
To: root@patrick.mdn.com, porschephiles@tta.com
Subject: '79SC Valve noise. ??Stretched valve??
X-Mailer: SCO Portfolio 2.0
Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 16:29:58 -0500 (EST)
Message-ID:  <9502161630.aa01289@eptax.eapi.com>


  >My '79SC has a slight valve tick from #1 cyl.

  >The mechanic that has done all the service said the #1 exhaust
  >valve is "stretched".  It does not smoke, only has the 'tick'.

if it stretched I'd guess you have a heat or detonation problem - it;s
gotta get pretty hot to soften the valve doesn't it ?
also a tuliped valve head would seem the same - horrible results
(did one in an airplane I was flying once - yeee haaa :-()

however, if any of that happened - the valve/rocker clearance would decrease
wouldn't it ?  I would have thought it would have to increase to
give you the tick.
- --------------------------------------------------------------------------------

580 Walnut St, Cinti, OH 45202                         Fax (513) 629-2449


------------------------------

Date: 16 Feb 1995 14:01:14 CST
From: "Jay Deinken" <JJDEINKE@SCIMAIL.remnet.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: Waving at other Porsches




The discussion about Porsche vs. Triumph, Lotus, etc. drivers waving at each
other reminds me of a story I heard about one of the Mitchell brothers, the
infamous pornographers in the San Francisco area.

Artie Mitchell drove a 911 in the early 70's.  He got so irritated at other
Porsche drivers waving at him and flashing their lights at him that he painted
the car with a brush, using different colors of paint, with the intention of
making the car look so bad that no other Porsche driver would acknowledge him.

Jay Deinken
jjdeinke@scimail.remnet.rockwell.com

> *not* become a sub-region of PCA.
> [remainder deleted}

I can see the problems with PCA affiliation for those in other parts of
the world.  Why not think in terms of "Electronic Frontier Region"
affiliation with as many Porsche-related organizations as possible?  If
affiliation with PCA is feasible, similar affiliation with PCGB or
other groups (the factory?) may also be feasible.  Each affiliation
would be for individuals for whom it makes sense.  For instance, it
wouldn't make much sense for me to be affiliated with PCGB.

Just a thought...

- --Walt Thode (thode@nprdc.navy.mil)

Frank wrote:

(snip)

When I got my first Porsche (a 1967 911S, in 1970), I found much less
waving, etc among the Porsche crowd, and virtually none with the other
up-scale sports cars of the era. Now, when I wave to another Porsche
from my 944S, it seems I almost always get some type of a "what kind
of nut are you?" look in response.

I don't know if the change was chronological, or...

(snip again)
- -----------

I have to agree with Frank.  I used to drive an old '63 Buick LeSabre 
convertible before my enlightenment and would trade waves with other 
convertible and classic pilots all the time; especially when the "canopy" 
was down in the spring/summer.  The only waves I get back now are from 
people at four way stops.  Sad.

It seems there's no spirit of camaraderie on the road in the Porsche 
world.

Bert

Suffer you Americanos, (we use the term Septics ! short for rhyming slang
                                                  Septic Tanks ie Yanks)
there are 18 RSR's coming to the land Down-Under.

One of the dealers just gave us the good oil !!
8 touring, read Road Legal,
10 Full RSR, read race cars.  The race version has full cage, harnesses,
dry break fuel system, fire extinguishers and only one seat.
The Touring version has two seats and a few of life's necessities for
road use, but no more sound proofing. Stereo is an option.

Can't wait to see one, hopefully March 5th, first race domestic Australian
Porsche Cup.

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 19:32:08 -0500
From: X400459@aol.com
Subject: I surrender

This morning, the wife left for work in my Saab-her Puegot was under the
weather. Ten minutes later, she called--had had an accident on our hill, just
over the crest on the way down. The only car I had left was the 911.
Unknowingly, there was a sheet of ice on the hill--with no warning--just over
the crest. I gingerly approached the group of cars involved in the original,
carefully dropping my speed to 5mph. Sure enough the 911 wouldn't stop and,
in slow motion, I ploughed into a 88 Chevy truck bumper. Damage assessments:

Saab--driver's door big ding--mirror demolished.
Porsche--Passenger front headlight smashed
            --Pass side bumper bent
            --Hood damaged
            --Pass side front fender badly damaged

I've been sitting here musing about the timing of Flameing the group and this
misfortune. Perhaps I should modify my behavior. (how did you find me so
soon?)

x400459@aol.com
Rich Brown aka Mystery Accountant
85 911 Targa, black w/tail (wounded)
84 Saab Turbo, black  (wounded)
86 Puegot, silver (dead battery)
2 standard poodles (peed in family room while I was gone)

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 18:38:06 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: 914 Fuel Line Recall Program ?

>I'm not sure if the fuel lines in my car have been upgraded, but does any one
>know for sure if this program is still on going ?

        Yes, it is.  Call up your local dealer with your VIN, and
ask.  It took them a few hours for mine--they had to call Reno, but
the info was there.  They do have to keep track of which cars have
had the work done.
