Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 18:40:44 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: powder coating

> But - I am told that it is unwise to powder coat items that may suffer
> hairline cracking and subsequent  failure  under stress as the can crack
> beneath the coating and you will not be able to (visually) detect the the
> problem before it occurs

It's also not a great idea to powder coat the fan shroud on a 356 until
you have the little cable tie-down gizmos lined up right, or you'll
break the enamaling off when you bend them back to the right place...

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 20:07:20 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: sebring ramblings(long)

Apologies to everyone who asked for Sebring info. This is the first time all
week that I've felt conscious enough to type legibly. It was a long and
exhausting weekend.
Let it be said that it sure was a shock to go from the single digits of PA to
the 60's and 70's. Even had some sun.
First of all it was the 60 hours of Sebring since the event started on
Friday. The catch was that on Fri the event was run under driver's ed rules
instead of PCA racing rules, i.e. no passing in the corners or in the braking
zones. In spite of our best intentions some of us, well, forgot that little
rule and apparently scared the bejesus out of the drivers ed guys. Sorry Pat,
we didn't mean to be a problem and Axel sends his apologies for his numerous
transgressions.
I had never been to Sebring before and it was unlike any track I've ever
visited. First of all it is huge with 17 turns and some serious straights. It
is also flat and very rough. In fact the FIA berms were the smoothest part of
the track. It took me all of Friday (4 sessions) to find the track and
develop a line. The track is so wide in some places that you can go four
abreast thru a couple of the turns then it turns right around and becomes
narrow. It is also very fast with average speeds for my group (E stock) being
over 85MPH. Turn 16 dumped you off onto a HUGE straight. Not only was it long
but wide since they used to land B52's on the straight. It wasn't unusual to
see 6 to 8 cars going down that straight together. Not one after the other
but roughly abreast. It's that wide. The other major problem was reference
points. I'm sure that they are there but the area really is featureless.
My braking point at the end of the 150MPH straight was a bunch of cows on an
adjacent farm. Tragically the cows had a propensity to move around as did my
braking point. In short it was a tough track to learn and be proficient,
 with the home field advantage being a factor until well into the weekend.
Saturday started the actual race practice sessions. There were a few fender
benders but nothing serious. There did seem to be allot of attrition however.
Our group of Riesentoter members had to come to the aid of one of ours and
drop the engine and trans out of his 73 911 S. We found a loose flywheel and
no other damage. He ended up only missing 2 run groups.
There were about 200 entries and I have never seen such an amazing group of P
cars in one place. The quality of the cars was sensational! There were also
some professional teams there such as Kelly-Moss. They had 4 cars present and
boy were they ever competitive. Of course there were your usual 935's, 934's
and everything else as well as a mid engined Porsche that was a thinly
disguised 962.
The Sunday races went very well with no serious incidents although there again
 was an unusual amount of attrition (rough surface.. long stretches at full
throttle?) There were 47 cars in my race group which consisted of E1, E and F
stock. The other race groups had a likewise number of entrants. The starts
were spectacular and noisy. You had to watch your tach carefully as hearing
was impossible. Imagine 47 cars trying to get thru the first corner. Exciting
and frightening.
I had qualified 20th and had a really great, fun race. I spent the last 3
laps one on one with a 930. We passed each other about 3 times a lap.
Unfortunately he passed me last and beat me by a headlight at the finish
line. I ended up in 15th place and couldn't be happier. Not bad for a 50 year
old dentist who had never seen the track before. If anyone needs specific
info let me know as I have some of the results sheets. I think Pat Moyer
(national rep) will post all results as soon as he receives them.
It was a once in a lifetime experience and everyone that does Club Racing
should really try and be there next year. It is worth the effort and expense.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
6:07 pm



------------------------------


Porschephiles #1176                         Fri Feb 17 02:00:14 CST 1995
Date: Thu, 16 Feb 95 16:41:26 PST
From: albrecht@nosc.mil (Robert H. Albrecht)

At 03:56 PM 2/16/95 -0800, Jeff Kyle wrote:
>>Same thing here. The only Porsche people who greet each other on the road
>>are the 356 folk. Porsches of all descriptions are common here in California
>
>The only real greeting while driving my 914 (only had it for one summer so 
>far) was a 911 flashed his lights... As for me, I will sometimes wave at 911s, 

Flashers,

        You must remember when the flashing started.  It was in the '50s 
when German cars COULD flash, and British cars couldn't (because of the 
Lucas Electrics of course).  With Detroit Iron, it took too much effort to 
find the knob, then pull and push it.

        These days, the only cars feeling it necessary to demonstrate they 
still can flash are 356s.  The British still can't.  911s became so common 
people began wearing out their switches.

Bob

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 1995 17:14:56 -0800
From: mswillis@ix.netcom.com (Michael Willis)

You wrote: 

>
>
>I was just flipping throught the pages of my Automotion catalog and 
came across 
>a Tech Tip indicating a fuel line recall program for 914s still being 
active.  
>I'm not sure if the fuel lines in my car have been upgraded, but does

>know for sure if this program is still on going ?  I'm very sure many 
of us 914 
>owners would like an answer on this one.
>
>Craig Z.
>'74 914 2.0L
>
>

The fuel line recall is still in effect.  If you have braided fuel lines 
then you need to take the 914 to any dealer and have them update it.

From what I have read and heard, I think I am going to try the BFG Comp T/As 
for the combination of performance and price.  Thanks.

I plan to attend a few driving schools through NNJR/PCA this season.  
Hopefully I sent my form in time for the novice group for Bridgehampton I.

Cheers,

Bill Kan
88 951
- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------
- ---------------------
Bill, unless you are going to get R1's you should go to NTW (National Tire
Warehouse). They have great prices, and usually treat your wheels properly.
The ones around Philadelphia know how particular Porsche owners are. If you
are going to get R1's, you should join Goodrich's Team TA plan. Track tires
are really cheap, around $130 each......but they don't last long. Usually
around 10 track hours if you really push them.

Larry Herman
HermanHome@aol.com
84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: 17 Feb 95 00:43:47 EST
From: alan halpern <74367.53@compuserve.com>
Subject: 87 911 speedo

I have an 87 911 with an erratic speedo. It behaves as follows: When the car is
cold -no speedo. As the car warms up the speedo comes on and then functions
normaly until it is shut off and cools down for more than 1/2 hour. The warm up
time required to get the speedo operating has been increasing over the past few
months. Cruise control does operate but only when the speedo is "on".I have
tested the speedo "Haines" style by hooking up a test meter at the connection in
the access compartment in the back seat and in fact the speedo needle did jump.
Someone has suggested that the speedo needle is "sticky " and reccomended that I
open up the speedo and lube the needle shaft. I wonder if somehow the electric
sender in the tranny is faulty? Has anyone heard of a similar situation?

Alan
87 Diamond Blue Coupe -  daily driver and PCA driver ed
91 Volvo Sedan - family mobile
1 wife

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 02:13:42 -0500
From: Stantonlas@aol.com
Subject: 914 Speedo Cable Failures

Hi Porschephiles,
Fellow PCA member with 74 914 has had the speedo cable break about 1 to 2
inches inside the cable housing just forward of the angle drive.  This is the
third occurance, at the same place.  Previous fixes included:  new angle
drive unit, 2 new speedo cable units plus the original (to him-had the car 6
months), and he had speedo completely rebuilt.  All done by a repair shop, so
he tells me.  Claims there are no binding turns in the cable.  First and
subsequent failures gave no warning, no noise, no needle wobble, etc.  

I have replaced the entire assembly from angle drive to the speedo on my 73
914 and had the speedo head rebuilt, but have not seen or heard of repeat
failures after replacing all that.  Any thoughts?

All help appreciated, especially by Walt.

Thanks,

Stan Stanton

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 10:57:27 GMT
From: ben@wet.sbi.com (Ben Evans)
Subject: Re: My first driving event


| I'm about to enter my first driving event.  I'm very interested in any
| advice anyone would like to offer.  I'll be driving my brand-new, heavily
| financed 968 at Texas World Speedway in a "high-speed driver education
| program".  I understand other cars will be on the track at the same time
| (although it's not racing - things are carefully monitored).  I'm really
| excited, but also a little nervous.  Any comments ?

1. Check that your insurance covers you, let the company know.
2. Full pre-flight your car including, oil, water, tyres, battery
   and especially brakes.
3. Check that all overmats and other loose objects are removed or secured.
4. Wear appropriate shoes and clothing.
5. Make sure your helmet fits properly and complies with local regs.
6. Listen up at the drivers briefing and do exactly as you instructor
   says.
7. In a Porsche on the track it should be possible to keep your hands
   at the 10:10 position all the way around, steering needs to come
   from your arms and upper body movement rather than feeding the wheel
   through as you may have been taught for road driving.
8. Complete all your braking before you get to the turn-in!
9. Observe the line and turn in that the other drivers in front take.
10. Have fun, your Porsche was made for this!

I don't know what Texas World Speedway is like, but the first time
I drove my 911 on a track it was on the Silverstone GP circuit before
the more recent modifications. Very, very, very fast and pretty scary
experience. All the turns looked the same at first, I really needed
the instructor.

Regards

Ben

Date: Fri, Feb 17, 1995 8:21 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Extrude Honing/951 engine rebuild

Hi Steve,

> The way I understand it, EH increases air-flow by removing a tiny layer from 
> treated parts.  How exactly do they do this, is it by acid-dipping and does 
> this weaken parts?  Is EH recommended for *street* engines with occasional 
> track excursions?  I would not think of taking my engine apart to do this now 

EH is what the name says.  They use a (patented) putty-like substance as a 
matrix to hold abrasive.  The process works on anything that acts as a pipe.
They put the part in a jig, force the abrasive putty through it, and, Voila!
a pipe with a larger, smooth, interior surface area that will now flow more
fluid (gasses are fluids).  More flow, more good stuff.  I don't know anyone
who has tried it, but lots of rags have reported on the process.

Bart

left turn, left side blinks).

something electrical is going wrong. Anyone know how to fix this, and is 
there a way to do it without removing the tach? Oh, BTW, the stereo amp 
is mounted to the back side of the trunk, so it is next to impossible to 
remove that carboard thing to get at the wiring.

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 08:45:50 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: 944 shocks

Babak asks:
Hello all:
Getting ready to change the cartridges for the front shocks in my
early 85 944.  Any advice, tips, horror stories anyone?
Babak Marefat

Here are my experiences ...

Tools you'll need:
Spring compressor
large pipe wrench
jack stands
19 or 17mm socket to loosen wheel caliper

Start by lifting car, take wheel off. Remove brake caliper. I think I also
removed rotor by loosening c-clamp at hub. Use a hex bit.

I did some time ago, please bear with me... Hang brake caliper with a piece
of wire, don't let it dangle by the hose. Compress spring, loosen bolt that
attaches a-arm to strut assembly. Loosen top nut at strut bearing. Might be
a good idea to check/clean upper strut bearing. I replaced mine at 90K or so...

TO loosen top nut I used a 22mm? socket and a hex bit. Pass the hex bit through
the the socket and use a pipe wrench to turn socket. Ruins the chroming on the
socket, but it gives it character, (also makes it easy to find ). I think there
is a special tool for that. This method has worked well on my old GTI, my 300D
,my 911 and the 944. 

THe strut assembly will drop out. Once out, remove spring (no need to undo 
compressor). Use large pipe wrench to loosen collar. Remove strut insert.
I bought Bilsteins and they included a new collar and a wrench that fits it.
Some people recommend adding a few tablespoons of oil to the inside of the
strut assembly to help with heat transfer. 

Put everything back together the way it came out...Repack wheel bearings, if you
like and adjust until the washer can be barely moved with a screw driver.
HAve the car aligned...Enjoy! My right shock was so bad, that it would bottom
and bounce every time I hit a bump.

I might have left minor details out. It is not hard. Use a good 6 point socket
to loosen the brake caliper bolts. They might be frozen (just ask Steve J :)
Might help to have a friend to hold the strut down while you use the large
pipe wrench to loosen collar. I did it myelf.

Hope this helps!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689
'84 Guards Red Carrera Targa  / '85 Guards Red 944
'87 Pearl Black Mercedes 300D Turbo / '88 Silver BMW 325is

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 08:39:56 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: flashing and waving



911 drivers here on the East coast usually flash or wave and
there is virtually no snobbery toward older cars. If anything
C-2,4 and 930 drivers seem to get a kick out of seeing early
911's on the road. I've even flashed early 70's VW beetles that
were the same in-your-face yellow.

Never had any luck flashing other flavors of P-cars because it
takes them so long to, how shall I say? *get it up* that I was a
mile down the road. ;-)

Also, after some mistaken cases of mistaken identity where I
flashed Mazdas or Nissans I gave up on the waterlogged p-cars.
:-) :-)

Reid



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 14:05:10 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Turn signals doin' somethin' wrong...

On Fri, 17 Feb 1995, Derek Cahill wrote:

> Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 08:14:46 -0500 (EST)
> From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
> To: porschephiles@tta.com
> Cc: porschephiles@tta.com
> Subject: Turn signals doin' somethin' wrong...
> 
> 'nother problem (this car has only put on 125 miles or so in the past two 
> years)... The turn signals (left or right) will do their thing normally 
> on the first blink. On the second blink and each one after, both turn 
> signal indicators (those things up top of the tach) blink each time. 
> Outside, only the correct side blinks (ie. right turn, right side blinks, 
> left turn, left side blinks).

Its probably a bad earth.

If you cannot find the bad earth, I suggest you check for poor grounding.

Failing that check for corroded wiring connectors where they connect to 
the car body....

If all else fails take it to your local auto electrician who will take 
$550.25 and return the car with one headlight not working and a story 
about having to replace a faulty alterwatsit. 

He probably found the corroded terminal after 10 mins, but he does have 
to feed the kids!!

Go on get stuck in head under the dash, feet sticking out the windows - 
nose blocked cos you have a cold.

Don't ever moan about Lucas wiring, at least the switches fell to bits 
before the connectors corroded up.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, Feb 17, 1995 10:52 AM
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bchambers@atlantic.nos.noaa.gov>
Subject: Re: Porsche Information

In message <199502171455.IAA09373@tta.com>  writes:

> Would you please send me information on Porsches.  Thanks

Gladly.  Porsches are German-made antidotes to boredom and an excess of
financial resources.  All that it has been my pleasure to observe closely
have shared *superb* handling and brakes, great power/weight ratio, assembly to 
incredibly high build-quality standards, and very high market value.

They come in many flavors: 6 cylinder, air-cooled, rear-mounted engines behind 
the driven rear wheels (as God and Dr. Porsche intended... say, it just occurs 
to me that I've never seen God and Dr. Porsche *together* at the same time; you 
don't suppose....) and both 4- and 8-cylinder, front-mounted, rear driven, water
cooled engines.

There are definitely things that one can engage in that are more pleasurable
than owning and driving a Porsche, but they generally require the removal of
clothing and the participation of another person, preferably of another gender
(from my perspective, in any event...)

Now that I've satisfied your request, may I make one of you?  Would you please
send me large quantities of money?  Thank you.


Cheers,

Bart Chambers
Frau, Dora

------------------------------

Date: 17 Feb 1995 08:22:13 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re:  87 911 Speedo

                                                                    8:08 AM
  OFFICE MEMO                                                 Time:
                      Subject:
                      RE> 87 911 Speedo                             2/17/95
                                                              Date:


I have zilch experience with 911's, much less with an 
erratic speedo, but I did have a similar problem with my
84 928.  

On my car there is a printed circuit foil on the back of the
instrument cluster.  All inputs are routed to the
instruments via circuits on the foil.  The input for the 
speedo is connected to the speedo mechanism by a little
pin on the foil.  The connection from the foil to the pin
is by a *rivet* !!  No kidding!  

Apparently, they can't create a solder joint because it
would melt the foil.  The signal level from the sensor on 
the tranny is probably in the millivolt region and therefore
a mechanical connection via the rivet could easily fail if
the rivet isn't tight.  Sure enough, the rivet on my car was
slightly loose and everything cleared up after I squeezed
it flat with a large channel lock pliers.  

If it's possible to wiggle the circuit foil while the rear tires
are turning (dangerous if you're driving the car, better if
you jack it up and block it safely) you might be able to
get some activity out of the needle ... if so, it probably is
worth taking things apart to check the electrical 
connections.

Again, I realize this pertains only to my 928 and may not
apply to your car, but what the heck?!

Good luck!

John
'84 928S

Date: Thu, 16 Feb 95 19:59:53 PST

> on a 911? What about airbag(s)? I think they started with the
> C2, but don't know for sure. My safety conscious spouse would
> like me to consider a newer 911.

Jon, I had the same aspect when I bought my 911 1990-C2 Targa
a month ago. 
Only the C2(90-) and the C4(89-) has the ABS brakes.
I think the same is true for the air bags, but I'm not 100%.

And then I have something for the list.
* When I cold start I usually have to try 3 times, this
is not good for the start engine. The mechanic has looked at
it, he replaced the O2 sensor and a heat sensor, but it did
not help. The car idles fine once it has started, and there
is no problem if the car is started on a warm day.

* Also the horn does not work but when I set the alarm off, the horn
goes off, I've checked the fuse. What should I do next, replace the relay?

* The Targa top is fine, little wind noise, and almost completely dry
when it rains hard, but it squeaks annoyingly in one corner. I don't want
to rebuild the whole top, is there any small fix I could do?

And maybe all new list members should start getting the digest instead,
then they wouldn't drown in all incoming mail, this way we wouldn't
have as many mail saying unsubscribe me or similar.....

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 12:08:42 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: shock replacement

Mike replies to my procedure on changing shocks:

>You can do the shock replacement without the spring compressor though you 
>just be careful.  It rewuires setting the corner (which ever one first) 
>on a jack stand and using the floor jack to compress the strut from 
>pushing up on the disk.  Then you take a 22mm offset combo wrench and 
...etc...

Yes, you probably could get away doing that. But springs contain a lot more 
energy that I feel comfortable with. I rather do it "long hand"

I once heard about this poor fellow who did what you suggested. Unfrtunaly,
the spring sprung and hit him on the head. Gave him a slight headache.
Went to bed that night a never woke up. Kind of ruined his and his family's
day. Not to say not being able to drive cars any more :{

Just be careful out there! Don't want any of my Porschephile buddies to get
hurt. THINK!

On a not related note. I have an income tax question... Yeah, is that time
of the year. Any accountants out there that might answer a question for me?
Please reply by private email.

Have a good weekend! Wife and I are going to a Driver's ED rookie session
sponsored by NNJR on Sunday. Should be fun!

Lou Nicotra
AT&T Bell Laboratories     len@library.att.com	   201-386-3689

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 9:21:08 PST
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: 911T Resto - UPDATE

Well gang, the restoration is nearly complete.  The engine has been
put back in the car, and I am anxiously awaiting the arrival of
my batteries and muffler.  

The weather around here is getting much better, so I would really like
to crank it over and take it for a spin.  Just dumped 9.5 qts of
oil in it last night.  As I was putting in the second to last quart,
my wife came out to the garage and said, "This looks serious, your
actually putting fluids back in, let me get the camera!".
Of course this was right after her usual "Is it done yet?"

I have not completed the body resto yet, as I plan to leave that till next
winter, when the car is stuck back in the garage.  However, I have
removed all the rust and performed all the necessary body work.  Whats
left is paint, all new rubber, and new trim pieces.

Bottom line on this project, that is over a year in the making, I could
not have gotten this far and had this much confidence that everything
is right, had it not been for this list.  It's not just the questions
that have been posted by me, but all the other info I've gleened
from interloping.

Special thanks to Bob Spindle, Pete, Trond, and of course the "The 
Listmeister".  Whether you know it or not, your involvement in this
group has aided me immensely.  Thats what makes this great!

Tom

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 09:32:15 PST
From: jaironf@PacBell.COM (Jeff Ironfield)
Subject: Cam Adjustment?

My mechanic tells me that he can get me a substantial performance increase
in the 60-100 mph range by adjusting the cam timing.  Currently, engine
comes on at about 3800 rpm he says that by adjusting the cams he can lower
this to about 3200 rpm, thereby giving me increased performance at a lower
rpm.  BTW, I own an 87 Carrera.  All I loose, other than $600, is some top
end speed.  I do much of my driving in the 3k rpm range and I wouldn't mind
having the performance the engine has at the higher rpm in this range.  My
questions are:

Is this for real?

Are there any other things I am sacraficing other than the top end speed and
cash?  Perhaps lower engine life?

$600 seems like a lot of money, around ten hours of labor. Is this really
what it will take?

Any comments appreciated.  You can email direct at jaironf@pacbell.com.

Jeff Ironfield
'87 911 Targa

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 11:40:37 -0600
From: Richard Hocking <hocking@cig.mot.com>
Subject: Re: 87 911 speedo


- -- Begin original message --

> From: alan halpern <74367.53@compuserve.com>
> Date: 17 Feb 95 00:43:47 EST
> Subject: 87 911 speedo
> To: mx% <porschephiles@tta.com>
>
> I have an 87 911 with an erratic speedo. It behaves as follows: 
...
> Someone has suggested that the speedo needle is "sticky " and reccomended that

> I
> open up the speedo and lube the needle shaft. I wonder if somehow the electric
> sender in the tranny is faulty? Has anyone heard of a similar situation?
> 
> Alan

- -- End original message --


I had a similar problem with my speedo a while back.  It turned out to be the
sender (I didn't know it was in the tranny).  My mechanic tells me it is 
a fairly common problem.

Only good thing about it, the odometer wasn't working when the speedo
wasn't working.  I wasn't sure whether to fix it :-)  But being followed
by a cop for 10 miles with no idea how fast I was going convinced me
it would probably be wise to get it fixed.   (I hear telling the judge your
speedo is broken is good for getting the speeding ticket AND a ticket
for faulty equipment.)

Good Luck with getting it fixed,
Richard Hocking
'87 911 Targa   [ RICK GB 1 ]

My father, who had a 928 at the time, pointed out that the car they 
drive around in is a 928S, but the car that goes into the lake is a 
928.  The driver had S wheels, the 'U-boat' had phone-dials.

Only-vaguely-related-note:

I had a dream last week that I was driving my old Datsun wagon.  I 
kept pushing the pedal harder, but nothing was happening--the car was 
slow as molases.  I kept thinking how awful it was compared to the 
911.  Finally, in disgust, I pulled over, got out and started 
walking.

Porsche. There is NO substitute...

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 11:52:56 -0800
From: Steve Saunders <saunders@interval.com>
Subject: Re: Turn signals doin' somethin' wrong...

>From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
>
>... The turn signals (left or right) will do their thing normally
>on the first blink. On the second blink and each one after, both turn
>signal indicators (those things up top of the tach) blink each time.
...
> -Derek Cahill

My '68 912 behaved just like that ... for a while, because it did that only
while on the road at mid-to-high rpms (never in the driveway).  Finally
(after someone here suggested a bad ground connection to someone else whose
car did this only under low-voltage conditions) I took all the signal
lights off, reseated all the wire connections, reseated the bulbs, and
tried it out:  no more trouble.  No analysis, not much understanding
gained, but try it and good luck!

                Steve Saunders



------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 12:03:20 PST
From: "EHSMITH.US.ORACLE.COM" <EHSMITH@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Flashing


This thread brings back a memory or two.....In the early 70's I had a 62 Super 
90 Cpe, red of course and 356 types in Southern New England were fairly rare. 
So, people flashed the hell out of each other from opposite directions, 
passsing, etc.  Nice atmosphere of camaraderie.  Problem was that people (not 
just Porsch types but everyone)would flash oncoming cars after passing a cop 
on the side of the road to warn them of possible radar traps, or just fuzz 
lurking in wait. 
 
Rhode Island even passed a law making it illegal to warn oncoming cars of 
police presence in this fashion.   You can probably guess most of the rest.... 
 Flashed another 356 after passing a b&w a mile or so back, was spotted by a 
b&W  that was not far behind the car I flashed and he did a very aggressive U 
turn to pull me over.  Smilingly explained the nature of my gesture to the 
officer but got no where.  I think my post Viet Nam attitude caused me to say 
something like "F**k you then, write the ticket".  This led to furthur 
escalation, intense physical activity, escalated legal charges and a night in 
the local jail.  I  had to explain it to the judge who had no sympathy. "If 
you can afford a Porsche you can afford the fine".  He probably drove a Buick. 
 
Anyway, I still flash 356's from the B cpe and 911's when in the 911.  356 
people are very friendly and will even make U turns for a better look.  The 
911 types are less so, preferring to respond only when flashed by a car that 
is of equal or greater perceived value than the one they're driving.  I 
haven't quite figured out the etiquette of it all but usually don't hesitate 
to be the first flasher. 
 
Ted Smith 
too many cars-too litle time 
one half dead cat

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 15:27:46 EST
From: "Jeffrey A. Shorey" <js@ee.duke.edu>
Subject: Re:  Euro 911/930 turn signal indicator

Stan wrote:
> OK, I don't have an answer for that, but how about *THIS*: 
>
> in my 356SC, when you step on the brakes, the front turn signals
> light up in addition to the brake lights...

I can beat that.  In my old 914, if you left your foot on the brake pedal
while you turned the ignition off, the car would continue to run.  It would
die as soon as you took your foot off the pedal.

BTW my flashers exhibit the same double blinking symptom.  I suspect the
22-year-old flasher unit, but it blinks the light fine on the outside so
I haven't felt like investing $50 or whatever it costs to find out for sure.

 - Jeff Shorey
'73 911S Coupe (the black beast)
'85 BMW 535i (the wife's get-around)

you folks can forgive me, my finances were hellish but the car deserved 
better...
	Anyway he has a bunch of basket case 914s lying around, the most 
interesting is one that I thought was a 914/6.  It has fender flares 
which are fiberglass and had an opposed six in it.  I asked about it and 
it turns out someone had slapped a CORVAIR engine in it!!!???  Is this 
conversion common and/or fast?  The car is rusted to death but you can 
tell someone once spent a lot of money on it, like leather upholstery, 
WIDE minilite style wheels, wild looking suspension, etc.  The shop owner 
doesn't know its history, he bought it with the shop some eight years 
ago.  He thinks it might be an original 914/6 because of its early build 
date (11/69) and its uplevel interior and tougher looking suspension.  
His question and mine...how do you tell a 914/4 from a 914/6?  Are the 
VIN #s different?  Suspensions?  Any info would be helpful.

Here's to Tom Cruise, awesome 928's, and beautiful women!

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 12:50:29 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Greeting other Porsches

I think it's a difference between Porsche enthusiasts who pride
themselves on their older cars, on upgrading them for performance
and/or preserving them for concours, and people who buy new Porsches
for any number of reasons, including the desire to show the world that
they can afford them.  Buyers of expensive cars often do so in pursuit
of exclusivity, which mitigates against admitting marque camaraderie.  

This reflects (appropriate word) on a problem PCA has had in
recruiting members among buyers of new Porsches--or more precisely,
people who buy new Porsches who have never owned a Porsche before.  It
has also made the relationship between Porsche dealers and PCA regions
often less than salutary, as their respective goals have diverged.

Steve Gilbert
San Joaquin Region, PCA
steveng@csufresno.edu
"I wouldn't belong to any club that would have me as a member"
                                --Groucho Marx

> > 10 years ago. Probably hasn't changed.
> 
> I find that, usually on surface streets here in San Diego, other 911 
> drivers will greet me if their cars are about as old as mine ('72 
> 911T).  Not a peep from the others, however.
> 
> --Walt Thode

could buy an RSR in Europe, ship it piece-by-piece via air mail,

it with one of Stan's '69 911T serial numbers in his desk!

twin turbo) but they are not legal on the streets, only for racing.

  >I can beat that.  In my old 914, if you left your foot on the brake pedal
  >while you turned the ignition off, the car would continue to run.  It would
  >die as soon as you took your foot off the pedal.

my fraternirt in college had it's own bmw !  A 2002i that had been to the
moon and was on it's way back !  When I first drove it the actual yelled
at my because I shifted before passing redline.

anyway - turn on the wipers and the turn signals would flash in random
patterns.  If you hit the brakes hard, the horn would come on and stay
on till you hit the horn.  If you hit the horn and the wipers were off,
they'd come on.  Always started though.  If it was rainy out you
would progress down the street with all sorts of beeping and flashing
, what an amazing car.

we once had a party where everyone was given a colored magic marker and
invited to write on the car (which was white).  It was even more fun to
drive after that !

Date: 17 Feb 95 13:10:17 -0800
From: Daryl Savage (Exchange) <daryls@microsoft.com>
Subject: I wave, I flash, I am...

at the beginning of the Straight, I flash to pass.

at the middle of the Straight I *wave* ThoseWhoAreFasterThroughTheCorners 
(often 914's and 911's but hey, if you were faster through the corners
in my old
'58 Simca Arende i'd let you pass too) cause its the right thing to do...

on the street, I Wave (elbow, elbow, wrist, wrist...) as i pass those
niggling corvettes;
then i Flash 'em with a flameball and leave their bumpers smoking and
eyebrows singed cause thats just what my track prepared 930 at 450hp
does when you lift  :):)

i even waved nicely to that NSX that i just barely passed down at PIR  a couple
years back.  boy i wanted him bad.  felt really good to till i turned
my head around
just  in time to note that Turn 1 was upon me... and me caught with a head full
of ego and an intercooler full-o-boost.  lovely scenic grassy runoff there just
past the entrance of turn 1.  too bad the windows were open :(

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 14:19:06 -0500
From: sjagernauth@attmail.com (Stephen I Jagernauth)
Subject: Polishing wheels/Flashing

Hi:

Since we're in winter's icy grip in the NE, I'm getting around to those little
projects:

1. I have polished wheels with painted center caps. The paint on the center
caps is peeling and needs renewing.  I'd like to remove the silver paint 
and polish these to a high gloss to match my wheels and then repaint just the 
crest.  What is the best way to polish aluminium?  I have air tools, which 
would be fastest but least precise.  How about a Dremel tool or good ol' fine 
sandpaper?

2.  The current thread on flashing (i.e. one's lights) reminds me of a feature
I wish my car had: the ability to flash the driving lights.  When I first got 
the 944, I would yank the turn-signal lever out of reflex to flash someone.  
If the headlights are in the closed position, this doesn't do much good.  
This feature would have several uses:
	a. acknowledge other P-cars 
	b. warn oncoming traffic of speed-traps (3 quick flashes)
	c. flash the idiot poking along in the fast lane (reserved use only) 
	   or about to cut you off 

Since I'm upgrading the driving lights to 100W, now is a good time to do this.
 Has anyone done this, comments?

BTW, thanks for the responses on Extrude Honing.

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 17:01:17 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Motor assembly question

 The bottom end of my motor is now assembeled. When I disassembeled the motor
I removed the heads in banks of 3. I had the machine shop renew the heads
and do what was necessary to bring them to spec. I also requested that they
reassemble them so that I could just "bolt them on". I requested that they
put the cam in a possition that assumed #1 was at TDC. Now after reading all
the material that I have, I see most instructions call for the cam and the
rockers to be installed after assembly. Can I install them the way they are
now? Can't I put #1 at TDC and not move the crank? Should I get a "real"
mechanic:-)?

Fred L Hess  
fhess@free.org
717.248.5581 (work most of the time)
Lewistown, PA.
1974 914 2.0
1966 911 cpe (in renewal state)


------------------------------

Date: 17 Feb 95 16:33:10 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: 356/912 oil coolers

Bob asks
 
>Okay, Pete, but what's the rest of the story!?!  I know we're not in Kansas
>anymore, but what's a lightweight 356 doing in the heartland?  Where did it
>come from, and what did the owners do with it?  For that matter, what did YOU
>do with it?
 
The lightweight was bought by a U.S. Army captain and his German wife in
Munich, 1961. It was their second Porsche. They got moved back to the
states, I have pictures of the car at Ft. Hood, TX. He went to Green Beret
school, went to Vietnam, and was killed while advising the locals, May of
'65. At the time Vietnam was page 10 news (I have the clippings mentioning
his death, from NY Times, Washington Post, LA Times, SF Chronicle). Widow
had to 1) identify the body in Hawaii and 2) hustle self and kids off to
Germany to keep the U.S. Government from deporting her and keeping the kids.
Left car behind, his family took care of selling it. Went from Ohio to
Pennsylvania to Missouri to Illinois to Kansas to California, where I got
it.
 
What were the Green Beret and his wife doing with a lightweight in the first
place? I asked the widow. "Well, we went to a race at Watkins Glen while he
was TDY back in the states. We hung out with the Porsche factory team. Do
you know a Huschke von Hanstein? Well, he told us if we order another one
with the intention of rallying and hillclimbing, we should make sure he got
our order, he would put the non-catalog aluminum lids on it." I asked why it
had an extended steering column. The captain was 6foot something and needed
to have the seat all the way back, then have the wheel moved back to meet
him. They learned this from their first car. She also asked "is the racing
seat still in there?" No. "Are the red seat belts still in there?" Yes. "My
husband put those in." She remarried a U.S. Army officer, he's retired, they
live near Heidelberg, drive a 928 and we met a couple of years ago at
Hockenheim during a German Porsche Club event.
 
After driving it around the block and deciding it was unsafe/butchered by VW
Visigoths, I parked it pending a full restoration. I don't even want to get
into what else the "shop teacher" did to it, but fortunately it can all be
undone. It's going to take a cutting torch and grinding wheel though.
 
Pete

Date: 17 Feb 1995 17:12:02 -0500

flashing lights as "revenuers ahead, slow down".  Kind of kill-joy 
thing to do to someone.  (I wave out the sunroof instead.)

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 12:57:06 -0600
From: Brian Scudder <bscudder@spd.dsccc.com>
Subject: C4/C2/951/928 Wheels for sale

I have two 8x16" and two 9x16" Design 90 wheels for sale. The Design 90
wheel has 7 "spokes". The cutouts are like rounded triangles. I think
these were the standard wheel on most Porsches in the early 90s.

8"  PN# 964.362.116.01   offset: 52.5mm
9"  PN# 928.362.118.02   offset: 52.5mm

These were used exclusively on the track for 2 seasons (ie. no
curbsurfing). They have scuffs and scratches (I'm going to clean and
polish them tonight to get the extent). These will make excellent track
wheels and possibly good looking street wheels. I bought them from a
friend who used them on his C4. Another friend is using the same size on
his '86 951. The 9s fill up the rear fenders of the 928, however, the 8s
do not have the right offset for the front and problems could arise if
the car has been lowered or has weak springs.

I'm asking $1000 OBO and shipping from Dallas is also negotiable.


thanks
Brian Scudder
'83 928s
'70 old blue truck
'93 Redi (the Cat)

Porschephiles #1179                         Sat Feb 18 01:22:07 CST 1995

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 15:23:20 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: flashing and waving

Someone once observed a "flashing" incident while I was piloting, um, a
different brand of german metal, and remarked "just lift two fingers
above the wheel, that's what the Porsche drivers do... no need for a
light show".  Since she had impeccable taste (other than dating me) and
was accomplished in a variety of activities, I gave her words careful
consideration, and have my confined myself to this salute ever since.
Unless I just passed a radar trap, in which case deserving oncoming
drivers get three short flashes...

 -Ed

Let me make a couple of suggestions for those not wildly enthusiastic
over the idea of the PCA/EFR business (the sound of non-US ears pricking up,
all over the world):

There's no reason we can't have it all.  Porschephiles exists.  We are
Porschephiles.  Some of us are also PCA or PCGB, or other, but we are all
still Porschephiles.  If I could only belong ot PCA or Porschephiles, sorry
PCA, but there'd be no contest.  I *am* a Porschephile first, last and always.

I also want to be a founding member of a new PCA Region, EFR, but I will
always be a Porschephile first and independently of how that works out.

*NO ONE HAS TO SEND A CENT*  On the other hand, those who do, should have
some recognition.  We owe Stan a debt that we can never pay, but we can
show our appreciation (as has already been discussed to death, <vbg>) by
lifting the financial burden off his shoulders, leaving him the control as
is his *well earned* right.

So on the levels of contribution issue, I suggest, as an initiation, $15 for 
students, $50 for regular members, $100 for Patrons.  send all checks to me
and I will keep a spreadsheet with the check number and amount (and the order
received.  I'm of mixed emotions on publishing the amounts with the names,
but I *will* publish the names of those from whom I have received donations.
If you let me know, via email or note with your check, I will publish the
amount of your donation; otherwise I will only publish the total in the fund
and the names of the guilty... er, *Contributors*

So, it's time to shi... er...defecate or vacate...  Talk to me.  Better,
send me money.

So, as the actress said to the bishop, "it been a business doing pleasure
with you!"

Bart

camaraderie of a friendly wave.

believe it was a Corvette that got torched :^) .  My exploding 924 was

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 15:57:03 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Accountants, attitudes, N...

>I suppose you were trying to insult us 944 owners but I feel strangely
>"uninsulted". 

I didn't mean to insult anyone. It's just that both the 944 and the 308 landed in the 
hands of non-enthusiasts much more than other cars by the respective companies.

>The Ferrari 308 (did you mean GT4, GTB, GTS or GTO?) is a great vehicle The
>GTO  at 400 BHP and 180mph is a car I would love to have. 

I don't put the 308 in the same breath as a GTO. I've put a good number of miles on an 
'82 308GTB, and it was NOT a very nice car - truthfully, I wish it wasn't a Ferrari. It 
was an early fuel-injected model, which had weird problems, and smog pumps, and it 
wasn't a Quattrovalvole (those began in... '83? '84?). I like the 328 quite a bit though - 
much better, though quite similar.

>Please insult me some more.

Naw, I wouldn't do that. :)
I should rephrase my statement, in a more verbose way:
If you see someone coming out of a 356 or early 911, there's a good chance that that 
person is an enthusiast, and a fairly knowledgable Porsche fan.
If you see someone coming out of a Ferrari Dino (a friend of mine just sold his '72, 
leaving him with only his '69... Whatta car! Factory knock-off wheels, Daytona seats, 
etc, etc... Beeeeeeoooteeefooool.) or a 250GT, chances are that it's an enthusiast and a 
knowledgable Ferrari fan.

However, if you see someone coming out of a 944, there is a far less chance that they 
are an enthusiast. Ditto for a 308. The cars were marketed more towards the young, 
affluent type as something to drive to work, rather than a sports car to blast down the 
back roads. And, not to be a snob, but I hate the idea of a sports car being driven exactly 
the same way that a luxury car or family care would be driven.


- --

| "General Lido" '85 Dodge Shelby Charger                   -Groucho Marx |

Fred-

Sounds like you have the cylinders installed, and the cam 
towers all mounted on the heads.  Now you want to bolt 'em 
together.  You believe the left bank has the cam correctly 
placed for #1 to be at TDC, and I assume, although you 
haven't said it, that you believe the right hand cam is aligned 
such that it is in the position it should be when #1 is at TDC.  
Lot of believing and assuming going on here.
Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 15:23:20 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: flashing and waving

Someone once observed a "flashing" incident while I was piloting, um, a
different brand of german metal, and remarked "just lift two fingers
above the wheel, that's what the Porsche drivers do... no need for a
light show".  Since she had impeccable taste (other than dating me) and
was accomplished in a variety of activities, I gave her words careful
consideration, and have my confined myself to this salute ever since.
Unless I just passed a radar trap, in which case deserving oncoming
drivers get three short flashes...

 -Ed

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 19:14:26 -0500

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 16:18:31 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Fred's Heads


Fred-

Sounds like you have the cylinders installed, and the cam 
towers all mounted on the heads.  Now you want to bolt 'em 
together.  You believe the left bank has the cam correctly 
placed for #1 to be at TDC, and I assume, although you 
haven't said it, that you believe the right hand cam is aligned 
such that it is in the position it should be when #1 is at TDC.  
Lot of believing and assuming going on here.

One way to see if things are roughly correct is to check the 
position of the indents on the ends of the camshafts.  Both 
ought to be pointing approximately straight up when the 
heads are positioned for mounting.  If they pass that test, you 
ought to be OK.  It means #1 and #4 are set properly, and all 
the rest then fall into place.

Then you can do as you state, put #1 at TDC and mount the 
heads.  For peace of mind, before you mount them, you might 
want to look at those  cylinders whose valves are extended at the 
moment, and  check that the corresponding piston is somewhere 
down in the bore where it won't hit the valves.  It should be.

I don't remember this part exactly, but on my engine (don't know 
if they're all this way) there wasn't enough span in the chains to,

1) slip them over the camshafts once the heads were bolted down,

2) or slip them over the sprocket and get the sprocket on once the 
heads were bolted down, or,

3) both of the above.  

So just be sure you check this part before you compress those nice 
new headgaskets. :-) Also, tighten the headbolts progressively and 
give the cam a turn after each tightening sequence.  If the cam 
binds, try another sequence.

 -Bob Spindel



P.S.  I sent this to the group at large just in
case I'm all screwed up.  One of us would be enough...


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 16:23:11 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Vintage Races/swap meets

>What are the dates for IMSA and Vintage Races at the Glen?  I was up there 
>last August for a track event and loved the track.  What exotic cars 
>(Porsches, Ferraris etc) do you see at the vintage events?  Does the track 
>allow camping (I didn't notice any showers)?  Do you have dates also for 
>events at Pocono since I'm only 1 hr away?  

I don't have the exact dates for the Watkins Glen dates. Perhaps I'll give them a 
call and get a brochure. Actually, I've seen brochures at local hotels, maybe I'll 
grab one there. Either way, I'll find out.
And to answer the other questions:
Yes, you can camp anywhere you like. (I stuffed the 914 full of camping stuff and 
stayed in the "woods" by the back straight. They start qualifying early-early - it 
was great to awaken to the sounds of racing motors at 7:30am! I swear, I could 
LIVE there. :)
I dunno about showers. I figure I can go one night without a shower - not like I 
was sweating, it was COLD there! (And me with no heater! Brr.)
As for cars, not TOO many Ferraris. There was a 275 last year, a 250LM the 
year before, and plenty of 308s, 328s, Testarossas, etc just driving around. There 
are a ZILLION Porsches, almost all 356s. Tons of MGs... A couple Aston Martins. 
Lots of weird old hard-to-identify stuff. I have a zillion pictures, a couple of 
which are on the computer - I plan on putting this year's pictures on Photo CD 
as well as print, so I can make JPeGs out of 'em and distribute them.
Anyways, Watkins Glen is the only "real" sports car track I've been to, but from 
what I've seen on the boob tube, it's definetely one of the nicer ones. I find it 
quite beautiful... And a nice drive for me. (About two hours of back roads.)

>BTW, any info on the big Porsche swap meet in PA?  

I don't know anything about them, except what others have told me.

Pat,

I lived in Italy for about 10 years (and am still living there for about
10% of the time) and it's a GREAT country. There is so much to see that is
is difficult to give you advice without having any specifics about which
part you want to visit and what your main interests are (apart from german
metal).

If it's cars you want to see, visit the Museo dell'automobile in Torino or
the Alfa factory museum in Arese. They're both worthwhile.

If you send some more specific information, I could maybe help better.

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 12:06:57 +1100 (EST)
From: Mark Kosten <ccmk@lucid.com>
Subject: Movie Porsches

I am surprised no one has mentioned No Man's Land (1987), with
Charlie Sheen and D.B. Sweeney. The whole film revolves around
stealing Porsches and driving them fast. Lots of detail on
how to steal them, if you are into that sort of thing.

Oh, it is an okay movie, with a story really about a young
cop seduced by the criminal lifestyle. Worth watching if you
haven't seen it.

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 20:43:11 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject:  Memory Flashes


Hi, all,

    My favorite flashing incident happened on a backroad of NH (which we were 
just informed has a law against it, BTW).  I was driving my beat up ol' '76 
Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce  (i.e., an Alfetta GT for non-'76 models).  Going
down a sleepy road on my way to a conference on Lake Winnipisauke (sp?), when
I started noticing an inordinate number of Alfa Spyders going the other way.
Started wondering what was going on.  Then, around a curve came a MINT '59 (?)
Alfa Guilia -- and HE flashed ME!!!  I was thrilled!  Never did find out what
the Alfa "swarm" was about, though.
    Of course, this was the same trip that I discovered how thoughtful Italian
engineering can be.  Upon departing said sleepy backwoods NH town, discovered
that the engine would not start because the A/C compressor had seized.  Well,
I'll just cut the belt, I thought.  Nope!  In Milan they put the A/C where the
alternator should be, and piggyback the alternator off of the A/C pulley!!
Took a little while to rip out the A/C, remount the alternator in its rightful
place (which mounts to an exhaust stud!!), and finally to convince the auto
parts store (for replacement belt) that my car did NOT have A/C :^)  
   Do you think we P-philes could start a flashing fad?  Might ruin us 911
driver's high-beam switches, though :^(   At least the 914 guys got the sturdier
VW switch!

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa  
ex-'76 Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce rustbucket

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 21:03:38 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: Movies rated "P"


Hello, gang,

   I recently saw an otherwise forgettable movie that had *tons* of 911's. It
was called "No Man's Land," and it "starred" Charlie Sheen.  It was about a
ring of thieves who only stole Porsches!  Lots of gorgeous cars and some good
driving scenes.  Only problem was the chase scenes:  The anti-heroes had stolen
a 930, but were being chased by the "real" bad guys, a rival car theft ring.
The bad guys were in some big '80's Mercury sedan, and an IROC Z, but the Merc'
was keeping up!!  It was ridiculous; the 930 would come screaming around a 
corner in an insane, heel-toe, four-wheel drift, and then the Merc' would 
fishtail around the same corner, and then the Detroit Iron would start gaining 
on the Zuffenhausen alloy.  Ahh, Hollywood.

    Siskel & Ebert give it two thumbs down
    Andersen & Hanks give it one heel and one toe

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa (and late-night cable)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 21:26:45 -0500
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: RE: PCA vs PCX vs List

Hi all,

It seems that the driving force behind being affiliated with PCA(X) is
economic.

The Tax benefits of becoming a Non-Profit organization are worthy of
considerations. But do we have to be under Porsche Club of America, AG or
whatever? 

Why not start our own Porsche special interest group? There are many Porsche
Clubs out there like Porsche Owners Club, 356 Registry, 914 Owners
Associations etc. that have Non-Profit Tax Status. We could start the first
Porschephiles Club or some other applicable name. 

In California, most PCA regions are Non-Profit Corporations. They are treated
individually as Non-Profit entities by the government. All income has to
follow the Non-Profit guidelines of the Fed & State, but that's it! As long
as the purpose stated behind the Non-Profit application is accepted and
adhered to by the club, you are treated as a non-profit group.

Some of the discussion has raised concerns over geographical boundaries and
P-Car ownership. Creating our own Porsche Enthusiasts Club would let us
decide how the club is operated, dues and set own membership guidelines.

I think there are some very creative folks on this list. If we wanted to
pursue this avenue we need to accumulate the Non-Profit laws for each state
of the US to determine which one has the best opportunities for our group.
Merchandising considerations would be determined by the Non-Profit law we
would be under. 

In California, some PCA regions are having difficulties with the State
Non-Profit Authorities over Member vs. Non-Member income. One of the reasons
we are having these problems, is the way PCA is structured. Regions are
separately governed entities under a large umbrella. Other car clubs are not
encountering the same problems because there membership is "Under" one
governing body.

Don't get me wrong, I have been a member of PCA for many years. I enjoy PCA
and have been very active in the local region (Orange Coast Region) for over
15 years. I would support an EFR region as a Dual member, if we felt this was
our best alternative.

That is my $0.10 (inflation). I understand the reasons for wanting to
affiliate with PCA. But I also think it may be prudent to explore becoming a
separate Non-Profit club.


Bev Frohm
70 911E Tangerine Targa    (Show & Touring car)
74 914 2.0 - butt ugly at the moment (race and daily driver)
86 Freckles the Calico Cat
89 Elmer the six toed tear (named after the glue cause those extra toes stick
to everything!)

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

James Eley wrote:

>I'm about to enter my first driving event.  I'm very interested in any
>advice anyone would like to offer.  I'll be driving my brand-new, heavily
>financed 968 at Texas World Speedway in a "high-speed driver education
>program".  I understand other cars will be on the track at the same time
>(although it's not racing - things are carefully monitored).  I'm really
>excited, but also a little nervous.  Any comments ?

First off, follow the advice Ben Evans gave you -- the pre-event tech will
check most  of the safety items too.  And secondly, relax a bit.  TWS is a
very safe track as tracks go.  If we even hold the event (not NEAR enough
registered drivers right now) I'll be one of the instructors and Sally will
be doing laps in our "new" '84.

Just as a small example of how safe TWS is, I was instructing there a year
or so back and we exited the course at about 80 mph (not on purpose, mind
you) -- I just told the driver (as calmly as one can when siting in their
own p_ss) to drive straight and slow down e-a-s-y (which we did), there was
no damage to the car at all as TWS has lots of runout room on most all
corners.  This was with VERY spirited driving on the advanced student's
part, and I don't think you should worry too much about it.  Most all the
instructors up there WILL NOT let you get in over your head (I know I
won't).

What makes this an even cuter story, is that Sally was my student and it was
OUR car she was driving...

You'll have a blast.  I'd also highly suggest you come out to some of our
autocrosses which will teach you the same skills but at slower and safer
speeds.  (in fact *I* think it should be a prerequisite of high speed event
attendance)...

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

FYI, I looked up X400459's profile and his name is listed as Rich.

Rich's curt message was not called for, he would have received much better
responses if he had been polite. It was obivously out of frustration and to a
newcomer this list can be a bit intimidating.

In time, you get to know the personalities and take things in stride. What is
difficult for newcomer's, is that it takes a couple month's to become
"involved". I have heard the same complaint from new member's of a PCA
region. "The people are cliquish". They are not, but that is the apperance.

If you are a newcomer to the list, Be Patient. 
If you feel your questions have not been heard - Be Polite! 
Curt messages will yeild curt messages.

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 23:06:25 -0500 (EST)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: 911 cam timing

We did a good bit of dyno testing many years ago at AutoThority (when 
they did that sort of thing.) 

First, the general rule of thumb is that advancing the cam timing helps 
low-end, retarding the cam timing accentuates the top-end. SC's, although 
always supplied with the same cams, went through several different cam 
timing specs.

One other note: the factory typically sets cam timing in the middle of 
the published "acceptable" range. After the chains break-in, they have 
stretched a bit and retarded the cam timing.

Anyway, yes, advancing the cams will help mid-range performance. Not  
a great deal, but some. No numbers for you, but I can say I talked to many 
people who had it done and felt it was worthwhile. We usually shot for 
1.55mm.

Larry Bershtein

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 22:01:14 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: your mail

>I can beat that.  In my old 914, if you left your foot on the brake pedal

but forgot *CLEAN* about the true Car From Hell -- The Chasemobile!

This is (was? never know...) a Saab 99 of dubious vintage that had a
special hole crafted in the dash directly in front of the passenger's
left shoulder. The job of the passenger was to peer through the hole from
time to time to see if the car had caught fire yet, and if so, to
blow out the flame by exhaling rapidly and frequently through same said
hole...

The owner, despite being a good friend of mine and *way* high up on
the genius scale, never seemed interested in a fix. He continued to live
with this "work-around" until he finished grad school and passed the car
on to his brother who was just entering grad school at the same hallowed
institution. Best of my knowlege, the car never got fixed.

No, Dave Barry had *NOTHING* to do with this, despite a vague similarity
in overall outlook, and living in reasonable proximity to the owner's 
parents...

Stan

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 22:22:28 -0600
From: mcerny@sam.neosoft.com (Michael Cerny)
Subject: New Porsche Enthusiasts


I'm not so sure that there has to be a difference between buyers of new
Porsches and owners of old Porsches.    

I just bought my first Porsche (new) this week, and must say that I'm
really looking forward to some on-the-road cameraderie.  Before buying the
Porsche, I had a 94 RX-7 (which I still enjoy), but there is something
different about a Porsche.  From the time you walk into the dealership you
realize that there more to Porsches than other cars -- there's a history
and a level of craftsmenship that you just don't see anywhere else.  

- --Mike

Most PCA regions which are close to "race tracks" have porsche time 
trials, driving schools. These are the best for learning to drive YOUR 
car.

I would start with a autocross school first and a couple of atuocross 
them move on up to the race track events. 

The race tracks can be a little intimidating the first time out.

Date: 17 Feb 95 23:32:50 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Leakdown tester

There was a thread here over the past week re leakdown testers.
 
Aircraft Spruce and Specialty sells a pressure-type leakdown tester (not the
Mity-Vac kind), $49.95, with an 18 mm plug adapter. A 14 mm plug adapter is
another $8.30.
 
Pete



------------------------------

Date: 17 Feb 95 23:32:52 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Battery acid protectant

Also while browsing through the Aircraft Spruce and Specialty catalog, I
found something they call "battery cable guard. Forms a thin protective
coating that will neutralize battery acid on all treated areas. It is an
excellent way to clean the battery, hold down straps, and all metal parts
you want to protect including cables, clamps, box, and posts. Excellent for
aluminum battery boxes." 4 oz can $4.95, 7.5 oz. $8.95, 16 oz. $14.95.
 
Pete

Back in the '60s you had to be careful to catch the eye of oncoming drivers;
otherwise, they tended to fixate on the 356 to the extent that they drifted
over into your lane!  I've taken to the shoulder a few times to avoid being
sideswiped (or hit head-on).  Flashing them usually broke the trance.

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 01:32:07 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Flashing

Greetings:

For 914 owners who are looking for that "different sort of flash",  you know,
the one that sets you apart from all those "normal" 914 flashers, try pulling
the switch out and back in as fast as you can.
If you do it just right you will raise and lower just one headlight instead
of both effectively winking at the oncoming p-car.  It takes a bit of
practice to be able to do it right every time, but the look on the flashees
face as he passes is well worth the effort.

;;; pm9146@aol.com

Pat Moyle

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 00:38:22 -0700

>doesn't know its history, he bought it with the shop some eight years

>His question and mine...how do you tell a 914/4 from a 914/6?  Are the 
>VIN #s different?  Suspensions?  Any info would be helpful.
>Jay Karolyi

Jay,

According to 'Das Book' 13312 1969 914.4's were made and 2668 914.6's were made.

The serial numbers were:

914.4:  4702900001-4702913312
914.6:  9140430001-9140432668

If the number is between 91423300010-9142330020 then call me :-O

One way to see if things are roughly correct is to check the 
position of the indents on the ends of the camshafts.  Both 
ought to be pointing approximately straight up when the 
heads are positioned for mounting.  If they pass that test, you 
ought to be OK.  It means #1 and #4 are set properly, and all 
the rest then fall into place.

Then you can do as you state, put #1 at TDC and mount the 
heads.  For peace of mind, before you mount them, you might 
want to look at those  cylinders whose valves are extended at the 
moment, and  check that the corresponding piston is somewhere 
down in the bore where it won't hit the valves.  It should be.

I don't remember this part exactly, but on my engine (don't know 
if they're all this way) there wasn't enough span in the chains to,

1) slip them over the camshafts once the heads were bolted down,

2) or slip them over the sprocket and get the sprocket on once the 
heads were bolted down, or,

3) both of the above.  

So just be sure you check this part before you compress those nice 
new headgaskets. :-) Also, tighten the headbolts progressively and 
give the cam a turn after each tightening sequence.  If the cam 
binds, try another sequence.

 -Bob Spindel



P.S.  I sent this to the group at large just in
case I'm all screwed up.  One of us would be enough...


------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 16:23:11 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Vintage Races/swap meets

>What are the dates for IMSA and Vintage Races at the Glen?  I was up there 
>last August for a track event and loved the track.  What exotic cars 
>(Porsches, Ferraris etc) do you see at the vintage events?  Does the track 
>allow camping (I didn't notice any showers)?  Do you have dates also for 
>events at Pocono since I'm only 1 hr away?  

I don't have the exact dates for the Watkins Glen dates. Perhaps I'll give them a 
call and get a brochure. Actually, I've seen brochures at local hotels, maybe I'll 
grab one there. Either way, I'll find out.
And to answer the other questions:
Yes, you can camp anywhere you like. (I stuffed the 914 full of camping stuff and 
stayed in the "woods" by the back straight. They start qualifying early-early - it 
was great to awaken to the sounds of racing motors at 7:30am! I swear, I could 
LIVE there. :)
I dunno about showers. I figure I can go one night without a shower - not like I 
was sweating, it was COLD there! (And me with no heater! Brr.)
As for cars, not TOO many Ferraris. There was a 275 last year, a 250LM the 
year before, and plenty of 308s, 328s, Testarossas, etc just driving around. There 
are a ZILLION Porsches, almost all 356s. Tons of MGs... A couple Aston Martins. 
Lots of weird old hard-to-identify stuff. I have a zillion pictures, a couple of 
which are on the computer - I plan on putting this year's pictures on Photo CD 
as well as print, so I can make JPeGs out of 'em and distribute them.
Anyways, Watkins Glen is the only "real" sports car track I've been to, but from 
what I've seen on the boob tube, it's definetely one of the nicer ones. I find it 
quite beautiful... And a nice drive for me. (About two hours of back roads.)

>BTW, any info on the big Porsche swap meet in PA?  

I don't know anything about them, except what others have told me.

Pat,

I lived in Italy for about 10 years (and am still living there for about
10% of the time) and it's a GREAT country. There is so much to see that is
is difficult to give you advice without having any specifics about which
part you want to visit and what your main interests are (apart from german
metal).

If it's cars you want to see, visit the Museo dell'automobile in Torino or
the Alfa factory museum in Arese. They're both worthwhile.

If you send some more specific information, I could maybe help better.

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 12:06:57 +1100 (EST)

Subject: Movie Porsches

I am surprised no one has mentioned No Man's Land (1987), with
Charlie Sheen and D.B. Sweeney. The whole film revolves around
stealing Porsches and driving them fast. Lots of detail on
how to steal them, if you are into that sort of thing.

Oh, it is an okay movie, with a story really about a young
cop seduced by the criminal lifestyle. Worth watching if you
haven't seen it.

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 20:43:11 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject:  Memory Flashes


Hi, all,

    My favorite flashing incident happened on a backroad of NH (which we were 
just informed has a law against it, BTW).  I was driving my beat up ol' '76 
Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce  (i.e., an Alfetta GT for non-'76 models).  Going
down a sleepy road on my way to a conference on Lake Winnipisauke (sp?), when
I started noticing an inordinate number of Alfa Spyders going the other way.
Started wondering what was going on.  Then, around a curve came a MINT '59 (?)
Alfa Guilia -- and HE flashed ME!!!  I was thrilled!  Never did find out what
the Alfa "swarm" was about, though.
    Of course, this was the same trip that I discovered how thoughtful Italian
engineering can be.  Upon departing said sleepy backwoods NH town, discovered
that the engine would not start because the A/C compressor had seized.  Well,
I'll just cut the belt, I thought.  Nope!  In Milan they put the A/C where the
alternator should be, and piggyback the alternator off of the A/C pulley!!
Took a little while to rip out the A/C, remount the alternator in its rightful
place (which mounts to an exhaust stud!!), and finally to convince the auto
parts store (for replacement belt) that my car did NOT have A/C :^)  
   Do you think we P-philes could start a flashing fad?  Might ruin us 911
driver's high-beam switches, though :^(   At least the 914 guys got the sturdier
VW switch!

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa  
ex-'76 Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce rustbucket

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 21:03:38 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject: Movies rated "P"


Hello, gang,

   I recently saw an otherwise forgettable movie that had *tons* of 911's. It
was called "No Man's Land," and it "starred" Charlie Sheen.  It was about a
ring of thieves who only stole Porsches!  Lots of gorgeous cars and some good
driving scenes.  Only problem was the chase scenes:  The anti-heroes had stolen
a 930, but were being chased by the "real" bad guys, a rival car theft ring.
The bad guys were in some big '80's Mercury sedan, and an IROC Z, but the Merc'
was keeping up!!  It was ridiculous; the 930 would come screaming around a 
corner in an insane, heel-toe, four-wheel drift, and then the Merc' would 
fishtail around the same corner, and then the Detroit Iron would start gaining 
on the Zuffenhausen alloy.  Ahh, Hollywood.

    Siskel & Ebert give it two thumbs down
    Andersen & Hanks give it one heel and one toe

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa (and late-night cable)

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 21:26:45 -0500
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: RE: PCA vs PCX vs List

Hi all,

It seems that the driving force behind being affiliated with PCA(X) is
economic.

The Tax benefits of becoming a Non-Profit organization are worthy of
considerations. But do we have to be under Porsche Club of America, AG or
whatever? 

Why not start our own Porsche special interest group? There are many Porsche
Clubs out there like Porsche Owners Club, 356 Registry, 914 Owners
Associations etc. that have Non-Profit Tax Status. We could start the first
Porschephiles Club or some other applicable name. 

In California, most PCA regions are Non-Profit Corporations. They are treated
individually as Non-Profit entities by the government. All income has to
follow the Non-Profit guidelines of the Fed & State, but that's it! As long
as the purpose stated behind the Non-Profit application is accepted and
adhered to by the club, you are treated as a non-profit group.

Some of the discussion has raised concerns over geographical boundaries and
P-Car ownership. Creating our own Porsche Enthusiasts Club would let us
decide how the club is operated, dues and set own membership guidelines.

I think there are some very creative folks on this list. If we wanted to
pursue this avenue we need to accumulate the Non-Profit laws for each state
of the US to determine which one has the best opportunities for our group.
Merchandising considerations would be determined by the Non-Profit law we
would be under. 

In California, some PCA regions are having difficulties with the State
Non-Profit Authorities over Member vs. Non-Member income. One of the reasons
we are having these problems, is the way PCA is structured. Regions are
separately governed entities under a large umbrella. Other car clubs are not
encountering the same problems because there membership is "Under" one
governing body.

Don't get me wrong, I have been a member of PCA for many years. I enjoy PCA
and have been very active in the local region (Orange Coast Region) for over
15 years. I would support an EFR region as a Dual member, if we felt this was
our best alternative.

That is my $0.10 (inflation). I understand the reasons for wanting to
affiliate with PCA. But I also think it may be prudent to explore becoming a
separate Non-Profit club.


Bev Frohm
70 911E Tangerine Targa    (Show & Touring car)
74 914 2.0 - butt ugly at the moment (race and daily driver)
86 Freckles the Calico Cat
89 Elmer the six toed tear (named after the glue cause those extra toes stick
to everything!)

Date: 17 Feb 95 18:49:13 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: My first driving event


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: My first driving event
Date: 1995-02-17 20:38
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

James Eley wrote:

>I'm about to enter my first driving event.  I'm very interested in any
>advice anyone would like to offer.  I'll be driving my brand-new, heavily
>financed 968 at Texas World Speedway in a "high-speed driver education
>program".  I understand other cars will be on the track at the same time
>(although it's not racing - things are carefully monitored).  I'm really
>excited, but also a little nervous.  Any comments ?

First off, follow the advice Ben Evans gave you -- the pre-event tech will
check most  of the safety items too.  And secondly, relax a bit.  TWS is a
very safe track as tracks go.  If we even hold the event (not NEAR enough
registered drivers right now) I'll be one of the instructors and Sally will
be doing laps in our "new" '84.

Just as a small example of how safe TWS is, I was instructing there a year
or so back and we exited the course at about 80 mph (not on purpose, mind
you) -- I just told the driver (as calmly as one can when siting in their
own p_ss) to drive straight and slow down e-a-s-y (which we did), there was
no damage to the car at all as TWS has lots of runout room on most all
corners.  This was with VERY spirited driving on the advanced student's
part, and I don't think you should worry too much about it.  Most all the
instructors up there WILL NOT let you get in over your head (I know I
won't).

What makes this an even cuter story, is that Sally was my student and it was
OUR car she was driving...

You'll have a blast.  I'd also highly suggest you come out to some of our
autocrosses which will teach you the same skills but at slower and safer
speeds.  (in fact *I* think it should be a prerequisite of high speed event
attendance)...

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 23:06:25 -0500 (EST)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: 911 cam timing

We did a good bit of dyno testing many years ago at AutoThority (when 
they did that sort of thing.) 

First, the general rule of thumb is that advancing the cam timing helps 
low-end, retarding the cam timing accentuates the top-end. SC's, although 
always supplied with the same cams, went through several different cam 
timing specs.

One other note: the factory typically sets cam timing in the middle of 
the published "acceptable" range. After the chains break-in, they have 
stretched a bit and retarded the cam timing.

Anyway, yes, advancing the cams will help mid-range performance. Not  
a great deal, but some. No numbers for you, but I can say I talked to many 
people who had it done and felt it was worthwhile. We usually shot for 
1.55mm.

Larry Bershtein

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 22:01:14 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: your mail

>I can beat that.  In my old 914, if you left your foot on the brake pedal

but forgot *CLEAN* about the true Car From Hell -- The Chasemobile!

This is (was? never know...) a Saab 99 of dubious vintage that had a
special hole crafted in the dash directly in front of the passenger's
left shoulder. The job of the passenger was to peer through the hole from
time to time to see if the car had caught fire yet, and if so, to
blow out the flame by exhaling rapidly and frequently through same said
hole...

The owner, despite being a good friend of mine and *way* high up on
the genius scale, never seemed interested in a fix. He continued to live
with this "work-around" until he finished grad school and passed the car
on to his brother who was just entering grad school at the same hallowed
institution. Best of my knowlege, the car never got fixed.

No, Dave Barry had *NOTHING* to do with this, despite a vague similarity
in overall outlook, and living in reasonable proximity to the owner's 
parents...

Stan

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 22:22:28 -0600
From: mcerny@sam.neosoft.com (Michael Cerny)
Subject: New Porsche Enthusiasts


I'm not so sure that there has to be a difference between buyers of new
Porsches and owners of old Porsches.    

I just bought my first Porsche (new) this week, and must say that I'm
really looking forward to some on-the-road cameraderie.  Before buying the
Porsche, I had a 94 RX-7 (which I still enjoy), but there is something
different about a Porsche.  From the time you walk into the dealership you
realize that there more to Porsches than other cars -- there's a history
and a level of craftsmenship that you just don't see anywhere else.  

- --Mike

Most PCA regions which are close to "race tracks" have porsche time 
trials, driving schools. These are the best for learning to drive YOUR 
car.

I would start with a autocross school first and a couple of atuocross 
them move on up to the race track events. 

The race tracks can be a little intimidating the first time out.

Date: 17 Feb 95 23:32:50 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Leakdown tester

There was a thread here over the past week re leakdown testers.
 
Aircraft Spruce and Specialty sells a pressure-type leakdown tester (not the
Mity-Vac kind), $49.95, with an 18 mm plug adapter. A 14 mm plug adapter is
another $8.30.
 
Pete



------------------------------

Date: 17 Feb 95 23:32:52 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Battery acid protectant

Also while browsing through the Aircraft Spruce and Specialty catalog, I
found something they call "battery cable guard. Forms a thin protective
coating that will neutralize battery acid on all treated areas. It is an
excellent way to clean the battery, hold down straps, and all metal parts
you want to protect including cables, clamps, box, and posts. Excellent for
aluminum battery boxes." 4 oz can $4.95, 7.5 oz. $8.95, 16 oz. $14.95.
 
Pete

Back in the '60s you had to be careful to catch the eye of oncoming drivers;
otherwise, they tended to fixate on the 356 to the extent that they drifted
over into your lane!  I've taken to the shoulder a few times to avoid being
sideswiped (or hit head-on).  Flashing them usually broke the trance.
