Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 01:32:07 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Flashing

Greetings:

For 914 owners who are looking for that "different sort of flash",  you know,
the one that sets you apart from all those "normal" 914 flashers, try pulling
the switch out and back in as fast as you can.
If you do it just right you will raise and lower just one headlight instead
of both effectively winking at the oncoming p-car.  It takes a bit of
practice to be able to do it right every time, but the look on the flashees
face as he passes is well worth the effort.

;;; pm9146@aol.com

Pat Moyle

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 00:38:22 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: 912E #1 update&corvair pwrd 914?

>doesn't know its history, he bought it with the shop some eight years 
>ago.  He thinks it might be an original 914/6 because of its early build 
>date (11/69) and its uplevel interior and tougher looking suspension.  
>His question and mine...how do you tell a 914/4 from a 914/6?  Are the 
>VIN #s different?  Suspensions?  Any info would be helpful.
>Jay Karolyi

Jay,

According to 'Das Book' 13312 1969 914.4's were made and 2668 914.6's were made.

The serial numbers were:

914.4:  4702900001-4702913312
914.6:  9140430001-9140432668

If the number is between 91423300010-9142330020 then call me :-O

Porschephiles #1179                         Sat Feb 18 01:22:07 CST 1995
Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 15:23:20 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: flashing and waving

Someone once observed a "flashing" incident while I was piloting, um, a
different brand of german metal, and remarked "just lift two fingers
above the wheel, that's what the Porsche drivers do... no need for a
light show".  Since she had impeccable taste (other than dating me) and
was accomplished in a variety of activities, I gave her words careful
consideration, and have my confined myself to this salute ever since.
Unless I just passed a radar trap, in which case deserving oncoming
drivers get three short flashes...

 -Ed

Let me make a couple of suggestions for those not wildly enthusiastic
over the idea of the PCA/EFR business (the sound of non-US ears pricking up,
all over the world):

There's no reason we can't have it all.  Porschephiles exists.  We are
Porschephiles.  Some of us are also PCA or PCGB, or other, but we are all
still Porschephiles.  If I could only belong ot PCA or Porschephiles, sorry
PCA, but there'd be no contest.  I *am* a Porschephile first, last and always.

I also want to be a founding member of a new PCA Region, EFR, but I will
always be a Porschephile first and independently of how that works out.

*NO ONE HAS TO SEND A CENT*  On the other hand, those who do, should have
some recognition.  We owe Stan a debt that we can never pay, but we can
show our appreciation (as has already been discussed to death, <vbg>) by
lifting the financial burden off his shoulders, leaving him the control as
is his *well earned* right.

students, $50 for regular members, $100 for Patrons.  send all checks to me
and I will keep a spreadsheet with the check number and amount (and the order
received.  I'm of mixed emotions on publishing the amounts with the names,
but I *will* publish the names of those from whom I have received donations.
If you let me know, via email or note with your check, I will publish the
amount of your donation; otherwise I will only publish the total in the fund
and the names of the guilty... er, *Contributors*

So, it's time to shi... er...defecate or vacate...  Talk to me.  Better,
send me money.

So, as the actress said to the bishop, "it been a business doing pleasure
with you!"

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 15:57:03 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Accountants, attitudes, N...

>I suppose you were trying to insult us 944 owners but I feel strangely
>"uninsulted". 

I didn't mean to insult anyone. It's just that both the 944 and the 308 landed in the 
hands of non-enthusiasts much more than other cars by the respective companies.

>The Ferrari 308 (did you mean GT4, GTB, GTS or GTO?) is a great vehicle The
>GTO  at 400 BHP and 180mph is a car I would love to have. 

I don't put the 308 in the same breath as a GTO. I've put a good number of miles on an 
'82 308GTB, and it was NOT a very nice car - truthfully, I wish it wasn't a Ferrari. It 
was an early fuel-injected model, which had weird problems, and smog pumps, and it 
wasn't a Quattrovalvole (those began in... '83? '84?). I like the 328 quite a bit though - 
much better, though quite similar.

>Please insult me some more.

Naw, I wouldn't do that. :)
I should rephrase my statement, in a more verbose way:
If you see someone coming out of a 356 or early 911, there's a good chance that that 
person is an enthusiast, and a fairly knowledgable Porsche fan.
If you see someone coming out of a Ferrari Dino (a friend of mine just sold his '72, 
leaving him with only his '69... Whatta car! Factory knock-off wheels, Daytona seats, 
etc, etc... Beeeeeeoooteeefooool.) or a 250GT, chances are that it's an enthusiast and a 
knowledgable Ferrari fan.

However, if you see someone coming out of a 944, there is a far less chance that they 
are an enthusiast. Ditto for a 308. The cars were marketed more towards the young, 
affluent type as something to drive to work, rather than a sports car to blast down the 
back roads. And, not to be a snob, but I hate the idea of a sports car being driven exactly 
the same way that a luxury car or family care would be driven.

| "General Lido" '85 Dodge Shelby Charger                   -Groucho Marx |

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 19:02:33 -0500 (EST)
From: "Nathan J. Nagel" <nn22+@andrew.cmu.edu>
Subject: Re: Porsche Information

Excerpts from mail: 17-Feb-95 Re: Porsche Information by "Barton P.
Chambers"@atl 
> They come in many flavors: 6 cylinder, air-cooled, rear-mounted
engines behind 
> the driven rear wheels (as God and Dr. Porsche intended... say, it
just occurs 
> to me that I've never seen God and Dr. Porsche *together* at the same
time; you 
> 
> don't suppose....) and both 4- and 8-cylinder, front-mounted, rear
driven, water
> 
> cooled engines.

    Erm, you forgot the four and six-cylinder MID-engine cars, which,
while not perhaps what Dr. Porsche originally intended, produces
handling that I'm sure both would approve of.

later,

Nate

'71 914

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 16:18:31 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Fred's Heads


Fred-

Sounds like you have the cylinders installed, and the cam 
towers all mounted on the heads.  Now you want to bolt 'em 
together.  You believe the left bank has the cam correctly 
placed for #1 to be at TDC, and I assume, although you 
haven't said it, that you believe the right hand cam is aligned 
such that it is in the position it should be when #1 is at TDC.  
Lot of believing and assuming going on here.

One way to see if things are roughly correct is to check the 
position of the indents on the ends of the camshafts.  Both 
ought to be pointing approximately straight up when the 
heads are positioned for mounting.  If they pass that test, you 
ought to be OK.  It means #1 and #4 are set properly, and all 
the rest then fall into place.

Then you can do as you state, put #1 at TDC and mount the 
heads.  For peace of mind, before you mount them, you might 
want to look at those  cylinders whose valves are extended at the 
moment, and  check that the corresponding piston is somewhere 
down in the bore where it won't hit the valves.  It should be.

I don't remember this part exactly, but on my engine (don't know 
if they're all this way) there wasn't enough span in the chains to,

1) slip them over the camshafts once the heads were bolted down,

2) or slip them over the sprocket and get the sprocket on once the 
heads were bolted down, or,

3) both of the above.  

So just be sure you check this part before you compress those nice 
new headgaskets. :-) Also, tighten the headbolts progressively and 
give the cam a turn after each tightening sequence.  If the cam 
binds, try another sequence.

 -Bob Spindel



P.S.  I sent this to the group at large just in
case I'm all screwed up.  One of us would be enough...

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 16:23:11 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Vintage Races/swap meets

>What are the dates for IMSA and Vintage Races at the Glen?  I was up there 
>last August for a track event and loved the track.  What exotic cars 
>(Porsches, Ferraris etc) do you see at the vintage events?  Does the track 
>allow camping (I didn't notice any showers)?  Do you have dates also for 
>events at Pocono since I'm only 1 hr away?  

I don't have the exact dates for the Watkins Glen dates. Perhaps I'll give them a 
call and get a brochure. Actually, I've seen brochures at local hotels, maybe I'll 
grab one there. Either way, I'll find out.
And to answer the other questions:
Yes, you can camp anywhere you like. (I stuffed the 914 full of camping stuff and 
stayed in the "woods" by the back straight. They start qualifying early-early - it 
was great to awaken to the sounds of racing motors at 7:30am! I swear, I could 
LIVE there. :)
I dunno about showers. I figure I can go one night without a shower - not like I 
was sweating, it was COLD there! (And me with no heater! Brr.)
As for cars, not TOO many Ferraris. There was a 275 last year, a 250LM the 
year before, and plenty of 308s, 328s, Testarossas, etc just driving around. There 
are a ZILLION Porsches, almost all 356s. Tons of MGs... A couple Aston Martins. 
Lots of weird old hard-to-identify stuff. I have a zillion pictures, a couple of 
which are on the computer - I plan on putting this year's pictures on Photo CD 
as well as print, so I can make JPeGs out of 'em and distribute them.
Anyways, Watkins Glen is the only "real" sports car track I've been to, but from 
what I've seen on the boob tube, it's definetely one of the nicer ones. I find it 
quite beautiful... And a nice drive for me. (About two hours of back roads.)

>BTW, any info on the big Porsche swap meet in PA?  

I don't know anything about them, except what others have told me.

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 20:43:11 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject:  Memory Flashes


Hi, all,

    My favorite flashing incident happened on a backroad of NH (which we were 
just informed has a law against it, BTW).  I was driving my beat up ol' '76 
Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce  (i.e., an Alfetta GT for non-'76 models).  Going
down a sleepy road on my way to a conference on Lake Winnipisauke (sp?), when
I started noticing an inordinate number of Alfa Spyders going the other way.
Started wondering what was going on.  Then, around a curve came a MINT '59 (?)
Alfa Guilia -- and HE flashed ME!!!  I was thrilled!  Never did find out what
the Alfa "swarm" was about, though.
    Of course, this was the same trip that I discovered how thoughtful Italian
engineering can be.  Upon departing said sleepy backwoods NH town, discovered
that the engine would not start because the A/C compressor had seized.  Well,
I'll just cut the belt, I thought.  Nope!  In Milan they put the A/C where the
alternator should be, and piggyback the alternator off of the A/C pulley!!
Took a little while to rip out the A/C, remount the alternator in its rightful
place (which mounts to an exhaust stud!!), and finally to convince the auto
parts store (for replacement belt) that my car did NOT have A/C :^)  
   Do you think we P-philes could start a flashing fad?  Might ruin us 911
driver's high-beam switches, though :^(   At least the 914 guys got the sturdier
VW switch!

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa  
ex-'76 Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce rustbucket

Hello, gang,

   I recently saw an otherwise forgettable movie that had *tons* of 911's. It
was called "No Man's Land," and it "starred" Charlie Sheen.  It was about a
ring of thieves who only stole Porsches!  Lots of gorgeous cars and some good
driving scenes.  Only problem was the chase scenes:  The anti-heroes had stolen
a 930, but were being chased by the "real" bad guys, a rival car theft ring.
The bad guys were in some big '80's Mercury sedan, and an IROC Z, but the Merc'
was keeping up!!  It was ridiculous; the 930 would come screaming around a 
corner in an insane, heel-toe, four-wheel drift, and then the Merc' would 
fishtail around the same corner, and then the Detroit Iron would start gaining 
on the Zuffenhausen alloy.  Ahh, Hollywood.

    Andersen & Hanks give it one heel and one toe

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 21:26:45 -0500
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: RE: PCA vs PCX vs List

Hi all,

It seems that the driving force behind being affiliated with PCA(X) is
economic.

The Tax benefits of becoming a Non-Profit organization are worthy of
considerations. But do we have to be under Porsche Club of America, AG or
whatever? 

Why not start our own Porsche special interest group? There are many Porsche
Clubs out there like Porsche Owners Club, 356 Registry, 914 Owners
Associations etc. that have Non-Profit Tax Status. We could start the first
Porschephiles Club or some other applicable name. 

In California, most PCA regions are Non-Profit Corporations. They are treated
individually as Non-Profit entities by the government. All income has to
follow the Non-Profit guidelines of the Fed & State, but that's it! As long
as the purpose stated behind the Non-Profit application is accepted and
adhered to by the club, you are treated as a non-profit group.

Some of the discussion has raised concerns over geographical boundaries and
P-Car ownership. Creating our own Porsche Enthusiasts Club would let us
decide how the club is operated, dues and set own membership guidelines.

I think there are some very creative folks on this list. If we wanted to
pursue this avenue we need to accumulate the Non-Profit laws for each state
of the US to determine which one has the best opportunities for our group.
Merchandising considerations would be determined by the Non-Profit law we
would be under. 

In California, some PCA regions are having difficulties with the State
Non-Profit Authorities over Member vs. Non-Member income. One of the reasons
we are having these problems, is the way PCA is structured. Regions are
separately governed entities under a large umbrella. Other car clubs are not
encountering the same problems because there membership is "Under" one
governing body.

Don't get me wrong, I have been a member of PCA for many years. I enjoy PCA
and have been very active in the local region (Orange Coast Region) for over
15 years. I would support an EFR region as a Dual member, if we felt this was
our best alternative.

That is my $0.10 (inflation). I understand the reasons for wanting to
affiliate with PCA. But I also think it may be prudent to explore becoming a
separate Non-Profit club.


Bev Frohm
70 911E Tangerine Targa    (Show & Touring car)
74 914 2.0 - butt ugly at the moment (race and daily driver)
86 Freckles the Calico Cat
89 Elmer the six toed tear (named after the glue cause those extra toes stick
to everything!)

Date: 17 Feb 95 18:49:13 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: My first driving event


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: My first driving event
Date: 1995-02-17 20:38
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

James Eley wrote:

>I'm about to enter my first driving event.  I'm very interested in any
>advice anyone would like to offer.  I'll be driving my brand-new, heavily
>financed 968 at Texas World Speedway in a "high-speed driver education
>program".  I understand other cars will be on the track at the same time
>(although it's not racing - things are carefully monitored).  I'm really
>excited, but also a little nervous.  Any comments ?

First off, follow the advice Ben Evans gave you -- the pre-event tech will
check most  of the safety items too.  And secondly, relax a bit.  TWS is a
very safe track as tracks go.  If we even hold the event (not NEAR enough
registered drivers right now) I'll be one of the instructors and Sally will
be doing laps in our "new" '84.

Just as a small example of how safe TWS is, I was instructing there a year
or so back and we exited the course at about 80 mph (not on purpose, mind
you) -- I just told the driver (as calmly as one can when siting in their
own p_ss) to drive straight and slow down e-a-s-y (which we did), there was
no damage to the car at all as TWS has lots of runout room on most all
corners.  This was with VERY spirited driving on the advanced student's
part, and I don't think you should worry too much about it.  Most all the
instructors up there WILL NOT let you get in over your head (I know I
won't).

What makes this an even cuter story, is that Sally was my student and it was
OUR car she was driving...

You'll have a blast.  I'd also highly suggest you come out to some of our
autocrosses which will teach you the same skills but at slower and safer
speeds.  (in fact *I* think it should be a prerequisite of high speed event
attendance)...

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 15:57:03 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re: Accountants, attitudes, N...

>I suppose you were trying to insult us 944 owners but I feel strangely
>"uninsulted". 

I didn't mean to insult anyone. It's just that both the 944 and the 308 landed in the 
hands of non-enthusiasts much more than other cars by the respective companies.

>The Ferrari 308 (did you mean GT4, GTB, GTS or GTO?) is a great vehicle The
>GTO  at 400 BHP and 180mph is a car I would love to have. 

I don't put the 308 in the same breath as a GTO. I've put a good number of miles on an 
'82 308GTB, and it was NOT a very nice car - truthfully, I wish it wasn't a Ferrari. It 
was an early fuel-injected model, which had weird problems, and smog pumps, and it 
wasn't a Quattrovalvole (those began in... '83? '84?). I like the 328 quite a bit though - 
much better, though quite similar.

>Please insult me some more.

Naw, I wouldn't do that. :)
I should rephrase my statement, in a more verbose way:
If you see someone coming out of a 356 or early 911, there's a good chance that that 
person is an enthusiast, and a fairly knowledgable Porsche fan.
If you see someone coming out of a Ferrari Dino (a friend of mine just sold his '72, 
leaving him with only his '69... Whatta car! Factory knock-off wheels, Daytona seats, 
etc, etc... Beeeeeeoooteeefooool.) or a 250GT, chances are that it's an enthusiast and a 
knowledgable Ferrari fan.

However, if you see someone coming out of a 944, there is a far less chance that they 
are an enthusiast. Ditto for a 308. The cars were marketed more towards the young, 
affluent type as something to drive to work, rather than a sports car to blast down the 
back roads. And, not to be a snob, but I hate the idea of a sports car being driven exactly 
the same way that a luxury car or family care would be driven.

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 95 16:18:31 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Fred's Heads


Fred-

Sounds like you have the cylinders installed, and the cam 
towers all mounted on the heads.  Now you want to bolt 'em 
together.  You believe the left bank has the cam correctly 
placed for #1 to be at TDC, and I assume, although you 
haven't said it, that you believe the right hand cam is aligned 
such that it is in the position it should be when #1 is at TDC.  
Lot of believing and assuming going on here.

One way to see if things are roughly correct is to check the 
position of the indents on the ends of the camshafts.  Both 
ought to be pointing approximately straight up when the 
heads are positioned for mounting.  If they pass that test, you 
ought to be OK.  It means #1 and #4 are set properly, and all 
the rest then fall into place.

Then you can do as you state, put #1 at TDC and mount the 
heads.  For peace of mind, before you mount them, you might 
want to look at those  cylinders whose valves are extended at the 
moment, and  check that the corresponding piston is somewhere 
down in the bore where it won't hit the valves.  It should be.

I don't remember this part exactly, but on my engine (don't know 
if they're all this way) there wasn't enough span in the chains to,

1) slip them over the camshafts once the heads were bolted down,

2) or slip them over the sprocket and get the sprocket on once the 
heads were bolted down, or,

3) both of the above.  

So just be sure you check this part before you compress those nice 
new headgaskets. :-) Also, tighten the headbolts progressively and 
give the cam a turn after each tightening sequence.  If the cam 
binds, try another sequence.

 -Bob Spindel



P.S.  I sent this to the group at large just in
case I'm all screwed up.  One of us would be enough...


------------------------------

I don't have the exact dates for the Watkins Glen dates. Perhaps I'll give them a 
call and get a brochure. Actually, I've seen brochures at local hotels, maybe I'll 
grab one there. Either way, I'll find out.
And to answer the other questions:
Yes, you can camp anywhere you like. (I stuffed the 914 full of camping stuff and 
stayed in the "woods" by the back straight. They start qualifying early-early - it 
was great to awaken to the sounds of racing motors at 7:30am! I swear, I could 
LIVE there. :)
I dunno about showers. I figure I can go one night without a shower - not like I 
was sweating, it was COLD there! (And me with no heater! Brr.)
As for cars, not TOO many Ferraris. There was a 275 last year, a 250LM the 
year before, and plenty of 308s, 328s, Testarossas, etc just driving around. There 
are a ZILLION Porsches, almost all 356s. Tons of MGs... A couple Aston Martins. 
Lots of weird old hard-to-identify stuff. I have a zillion pictures, a couple of 
which are on the computer - I plan on putting this year's pictures on Photo CD 
as well as print, so I can make JPeGs out of 'em and distribute them.
Anyways, Watkins Glen is the only "real" sports car track I've been to, but from 
what I've seen on the boob tube, it's definetely one of the nicer ones. I find it 
quite beautiful... And a nice drive for me. (About two hours of back roads.)

>BTW, any info on the big Porsche swap meet in PA?  

I don't know anything about them, except what others have told me.


- --

| "General Lido" '85 Dodge Shelby Charger                   -Groucho Marx |

part you want to visit and what your main interests are (apart from german
metal).

the Alfa factory museum in Arese. They're both worthwhile.

If you send some more specific information, I could maybe help better.

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 12:06:57 +1100 (EST)

Subject: Movie Porsches

I am surprised no one has mentioned No Man's Land (1987), with
Charlie Sheen and D.B. Sweeney. The whole film revolves around
stealing Porsches and driving them fast. Lots of detail on
how to steal them, if you are into that sort of thing.

Oh, it is an okay movie, with a story really about a young
cop seduced by the criminal lifestyle. Worth watching if you
haven't seen it.

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 20:43:11 -0500
From: "Paul F. Lyman" <lyman@bnlls1.nsls.bnl.gov>
Subject: Subject:  Memory Flashes


Hi, all,

    My favorite flashing incident happened on a backroad of NH (which we were 
just informed has a law against it, BTW).  I was driving my beat up ol' '76 
Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce  (i.e., an Alfetta GT for non-'76 models).  Going
down a sleepy road on my way to a conference on Lake Winnipisauke (sp?), when
I started noticing an inordinate number of Alfa Spyders going the other way.
Started wondering what was going on.  Then, around a curve came a MINT '59 (?)
Alfa Guilia -- and HE flashed ME!!!  I was thrilled!  Never did find out what
the Alfa "swarm" was about, though.
    Of course, this was the same trip that I discovered how thoughtful Italian
engineering can be.  Upon departing said sleepy backwoods NH town, discovered
that the engine would not start because the A/C compressor had seized.  Well,
I'll just cut the belt, I thought.  Nope!  In Milan they put the A/C where the
alternator should be, and piggyback the alternator off of the A/C pulley!!
Took a little while to rip out the A/C, remount the alternator in its rightful
place (which mounts to an exhaust stud!!), and finally to convince the auto
parts store (for replacement belt) that my car did NOT have A/C :^)  
   Do you think we P-philes could start a flashing fad?  Might ruin us 911
driver's high-beam switches, though :^(   At least the 914 guys got the sturdier
VW switch!

Paul Lyman
'82 911SC Targa  
ex-'76 Alfa Romeo Sprint Veloce rustbucket

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 23:06:25 -0500 (EST)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: 911 cam timing

We did a good bit of dyno testing many years ago at AutoThority (when 
they did that sort of thing.) 

First, the general rule of thumb is that advancing the cam timing helps 
low-end, retarding the cam timing accentuates the top-end. SC's, although 
always supplied with the same cams, went through several different cam 
timing specs.

One other note: the factory typically sets cam timing in the middle of 
the published "acceptable" range. After the chains break-in, they have 
stretched a bit and retarded the cam timing.

Anyway, yes, advancing the cams will help mid-range performance. Not  
a great deal, but some. No numbers for you, but I can say I talked to many 
people who had it done and felt it was worthwhile. We usually shot for 
1.55mm.

Larry Bershtein

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 22:01:14 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: your mail

>I can beat that.  In my old 914, if you left your foot on the brake pedal

Geeze, *WHAT* am I thinking of... I sent Jeff a note about my old
Nash that required you to hold the foot on the brake to start it,
but forgot *CLEAN* about the true Car From Hell -- The Chasemobile!

This is (was? never know...) a Saab 99 of dubious vintage that had a
special hole crafted in the dash directly in front of the passenger's
left shoulder. The job of the passenger was to peer through the hole from
time to time to see if the car had caught fire yet, and if so, to
blow out the flame by exhaling rapidly and frequently through same said
hole...

The owner, despite being a good friend of mine and *way* high up on
the genius scale, never seemed interested in a fix. He continued to live
with this "work-around" until he finished grad school and passed the car
on to his brother who was just entering grad school at the same hallowed
institution. Best of my knowlege, the car never got fixed.

No, Dave Barry had *NOTHING* to do with this, despite a vague similarity
in overall outlook, and living in reasonable proximity to the owner's 
parents...

Stan

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 22:22:28 -0600
From: mcerny@sam.neosoft.com (Michael Cerny)
Subject: New Porsche Enthusiasts


I'm not so sure that there has to be a difference between buyers of new
Porsches and owners of old Porsches.    

I just bought my first Porsche (new) this week, and must say that I'm
really looking forward to some on-the-road cameraderie.  Before buying the
Porsche, I had a 94 RX-7 (which I still enjoy), but there is something
different about a Porsche.  From the time you walk into the dealership you
realize that there more to Porsches than other cars -- there's a history
and a level of craftsmenship that you just don't see anywhere else.  

- --Mike

>
>Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 12:50:29 -0800 (PST)

>of exclusivity, which mitigates against admitting marque camaraderie.

Most PCA regions which are close to "race tracks" have porsche time 
trials, driving schools. These are the best for learning to drive YOUR 
car.

I would start with a autocross school first and a couple of atuocross 
them move on up to the race track events. 

The race tracks can be a little intimidating the first time out.

Date: 17 Feb 95 23:32:50 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Leakdown tester

There was a thread here over the past week re leakdown testers.
 
Aircraft Spruce and Specialty sells a pressure-type leakdown tester (not the
Mity-Vac kind), $49.95, with an 18 mm plug adapter. A 14 mm plug adapter is
another $8.30.
 
Pete



------------------------------

Date: 17 Feb 95 23:32:52 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Battery acid protectant

Also while browsing through the Aircraft Spruce and Specialty catalog, I
found something they call "battery cable guard. Forms a thin protective
coating that will neutralize battery acid on all treated areas. It is an
excellent way to clean the battery, hold down straps, and all metal parts
you want to protect including cables, clamps, box, and posts. Excellent for
aluminum battery boxes." 4 oz can $4.95, 7.5 oz. $8.95, 16 oz. $14.95.
 
Pete

Back in the '60s you had to be careful to catch the eye of oncoming drivers;
otherwise, they tended to fixate on the 356 to the extent that they drifted
over into your lane!  I've taken to the shoulder a few times to avoid being
sideswiped (or hit head-on).  Flashing them usually broke the trance.

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 01:32:07 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Flashing

Greetings:

For 914 owners who are looking for that "different sort of flash",  you know,
the one that sets you apart from all those "normal" 914 flashers, try pulling
the switch out and back in as fast as you can.
If you do it just right you will raise and lower just one headlight instead
of both effectively winking at the oncoming p-car.  It takes a bit of
practice to be able to do it right every time, but the look on the flashees
face as he passes is well worth the effort.

;;; pm9146@aol.com

Pat Moyle

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 00:38:22 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: 912E #1 update&corvair pwrd 914?

>doesn't know its history, he bought it with the shop some eight years 
>ago.  He thinks it might be an original 914/6 because of its early build 
>date (11/69) and its uplevel interior and tougher looking suspension.  
>His question and mine...how do you tell a 914/4 from a 914/6?  Are the 
>VIN #s different?  Suspensions?  Any info would be helpful.
>Jay Karolyi

Jay,

According to 'Das Book' 13312 1969 914.4's were made and 2668 914.6's were made.

The serial numbers were:

914.4:  4702900001-4702913312
914.6:  9140430001-9140432668

If the number is between 91423300010-9142330020 then call me :-O

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 21:26:45 -0500
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: RE: PCA vs PCX vs List

Hi all,

It seems that the driving force behind being affiliated with PCA(X) is
economic.

The Tax benefits of becoming a Non-Profit organization are worthy of
considerations. But do we have to be under Porsche Club of America, AG or
whatever? 

Why not start our own Porsche special interest group? There are many Porsche
Clubs out there like Porsche Owners Club, 356 Registry, 914 Owners
Associations etc. that have Non-Profit Tax Status. We could start the first
Porschephiles Club or some other applicable name. 

In California, most PCA regions are Non-Profit Corporations. They are treated
individually as Non-Profit entities by the government. All income has to
follow the Non-Profit guidelines of the Fed & State, but that's it! As long
as the purpose stated behind the Non-Profit application is accepted and
adhered to by the club, you are treated as a non-profit group.

Some of the discussion has raised concerns over geographical boundaries and
P-Car ownership. Creating our own Porsche Enthusiasts Club would let us
decide how the club is operated, dues and set own membership guidelines.

I think there are some very creative folks on this list. If we wanted to
pursue this avenue we need to accumulate the Non-Profit laws for each state
of the US to determine which one has the best opportunities for our group.
Merchandising considerations would be determined by the Non-Profit law we
would be under. 

In California, some PCA regions are having difficulties with the State
Non-Profit Authorities over Member vs. Non-Member income. One of the reasons
we are having these problems, is the way PCA is structured. Regions are
separately governed entities under a large umbrella. Other car clubs are not
encountering the same problems because there membership is "Under" one
governing body.

Don't get me wrong, I have been a member of PCA for many years. I enjoy PCA
and have been very active in the local region (Orange Coast Region) for over
15 years. I would support an EFR region as a Dual member, if we felt this was
our best alternative.

That is my $0.10 (inflation). I understand the reasons for wanting to
affiliate with PCA. But I also think it may be prudent to explore becoming a
separate Non-Profit club.


Bev Frohm
70 911E Tangerine Targa    (Show & Touring car)
74 914 2.0 - butt ugly at the moment (race and daily driver)
86 Freckles the Calico Cat
89 Elmer the six toed tear (named after the glue cause those extra toes stick
to everything!)

Date: 17 Feb 95 18:49:13 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Re: My first driving event


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Re: My first driving event
Date: 1995-02-17 20:38
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

James Eley wrote:

>I'm about to enter my first driving event.  I'm very interested in any
>advice anyone would like to offer.  I'll be driving my brand-new, heavily
>financed 968 at Texas World Speedway in a "high-speed driver education
>program".  I understand other cars will be on the track at the same time
>(although it's not racing - things are carefully monitored).  I'm really
>excited, but also a little nervous.  Any comments ?

First off, follow the advice Ben Evans gave you -- the pre-event tech will
check most  of the safety items too.  And secondly, relax a bit.  TWS is a
very safe track as tracks go.  If we even hold the event (not NEAR enough
registered drivers right now) I'll be one of the instructors and Sally will
be doing laps in our "new" '84.

Just as a small example of how safe TWS is, I was instructing there a year
or so back and we exited the course at about 80 mph (not on purpose, mind
you) -- I just told the driver (as calmly as one can when siting in their
own p_ss) to drive straight and slow down e-a-s-y (which we did), there was
no damage to the car at all as TWS has lots of runout room on most all
corners.  This was with VERY spirited driving on the advanced student's
part, and I don't think you should worry too much about it.  Most all the
instructors up there WILL NOT let you get in over your head (I know I
won't).

What makes this an even cuter story, is that Sally was my student and it was
OUR car she was driving...

You'll have a blast.  I'd also highly suggest you come out to some of our
autocrosses which will teach you the same skills but at slower and safer
speeds.  (in fact *I* think it should be a prerequisite of high speed event
attendance)...

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 21:53:09 -0500
From: Beverly514@aol.com
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1164 Tue F...

>BTW, I called our Mystery Accountant "Ken" in my advice because

>frame mind to offer advice to an X400459, so I used "Ken"
>instead, apologies to any other Kens out there in e-space.	>X400459

FYI, I looked up X400459's profile and his name is listed as Rich.

Rich's curt message was not called for, he would have received much better
responses if he had been polite. It was obivously out of frustration and to a
newcomer this list can be a bit intimidating.

In time, you get to know the personalities and take things in stride. What is
difficult for newcomer's, is that it takes a couple month's to become
"involved". I have heard the same complaint from new member's of a PCA
region. "The people are cliquish". They are not, but that is the apperance.

If you are a newcomer to the list, Be Patient. 
If you feel your questions have not been heard - Be Polite! 
Curt messages will yeild curt messages.

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 23:06:25 -0500 (EST)
From: "Lawrence D. Bershtein" <lbershte@nova.umuc.edu>
Subject: 911 cam timing

We did a good bit of dyno testing many years ago at AutoThority (when 
they did that sort of thing.) 

First, the general rule of thumb is that advancing the cam timing helps 
low-end, retarding the cam timing accentuates the top-end. SC's, although 
always supplied with the same cams, went through several different cam 
timing specs.

One other note: the factory typically sets cam timing in the middle of 
the published "acceptable" range. After the chains break-in, they have 
stretched a bit and retarded the cam timing.

Anyway, yes, advancing the cams will help mid-range performance. Not  
a great deal, but some. No numbers for you, but I can say I talked to many 
people who had it done and felt it was worthwhile. We usually shot for 
1.55mm.

Larry Bershtein

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 22:01:14 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: your mail

>I can beat that.  In my old 914, if you left your foot on the brake pedal
>while you turned the ignition off, the car would continue to run.  It would
>die as soon as you took your foot off the pedal.

Geeze, *WHAT* am I thinking of... I sent Jeff a note about my old
Nash that required you to hold the foot on the brake to start it,
but forgot *CLEAN* about the true Car From Hell -- The Chasemobile!

This is (was? never know...) a Saab 99 of dubious vintage that had a
special hole crafted in the dash directly in front of the passenger's
left shoulder. The job of the passenger was to peer through the hole from
time to time to see if the car had caught fire yet, and if so, to
blow out the flame by exhaling rapidly and frequently through same said
hole...

The owner, despite being a good friend of mine and *way* high up on
the genius scale, never seemed interested in a fix. He continued to live
with this "work-around" until he finished grad school and passed the car
on to his brother who was just entering grad school at the same hallowed
institution. Best of my knowlege, the car never got fixed.

No, Dave Barry had *NOTHING* to do with this, despite a vague similarity
in overall outlook, and living in reasonable proximity to the owner's 
parents...

Stan

Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 22:22:28 -0600
From: mcerny@sam.neosoft.com (Michael Cerny)
Subject: New Porsche Enthusiasts


I'm not so sure that there has to be a difference between buyers of new
Porsches and owners of old Porsches.    

I just bought my first Porsche (new) this week, and must say that I'm
really looking forward to some on-the-road cameraderie.  Before buying the
Porsche, I had a 94 RX-7 (which I still enjoy), but there is something
different about a Porsche.  From the time you walk into the dealership you
realize that there more to Porsches than other cars -- there's a history
and a level of craftsmenship that you just don't see anywhere else.  

- --Mike

>
>Date: Fri, 17 Feb 1995 12:50:29 -0800 (PST)
>From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
>Subject: Re: Greeting other Porsches
>
>I think it's a difference between Porsche enthusiasts who pride
>themselves on their older cars, on upgrading them for performance
>and/or preserving them for concours, and people who buy new Porsches
>for any number of reasons, including the desire to show the world that
>they can afford them.  Buyers of expensive cars often do so in pursuit
>of exclusivity, which mitigates against admitting marque camaraderie.  
>
>This reflects (appropriate word) on a problem PCA has had in
>recruiting members among buyers of new Porsches--or more precisely,
>people who buy new Porsches who have never owned a Porsche before.  It
>has also made the relationship between Porsche dealers and PCA regions
>often less than salutary, as their respective goals have diverged.
>
>Steve Gilbert
>San Joaquin Region, PCA
>steveng@csufresno.edu

Most PCA regions which are close to "race tracks" have porsche time 
trials, driving schools. These are the best for learning to drive YOUR 
car.

I would start with a autocross school first and a couple of atuocross 
them move on up to the race track events. 

The race tracks can be a little intimidating the first time out.

fact that I can flash the lights in my Cherokee in the same fashion
does kind of dilute the uniqueness of the gesture.

Date: 17 Feb 95 23:32:50 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Leakdown tester

There was a thread here over the past week re leakdown testers.
 
Aircraft Spruce and Specialty sells a pressure-type leakdown tester (not the
Mity-Vac kind), $49.95, with an 18 mm plug adapter. A 14 mm plug adapter is
another $8.30.
 
Pete



------------------------------

Date: 17 Feb 95 23:32:52 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Battery acid protectant

Also while browsing through the Aircraft Spruce and Specialty catalog, I
found something they call "battery cable guard. Forms a thin protective
coating that will neutralize battery acid on all treated areas. It is an
excellent way to clean the battery, hold down straps, and all metal parts
you want to protect including cables, clamps, box, and posts. Excellent for
aluminum battery boxes." 4 oz can $4.95, 7.5 oz. $8.95, 16 oz. $14.95.
 
Pete

Subject: Re: Flashing

Back in the '60s you had to be careful to catch the eye of oncoming drivers;
otherwise, they tended to fixate on the 356 to the extent that they drifted
over into your lane!  I've taken to the shoulder a few times to avoid being
sideswiped (or hit head-on).  Flashing them usually broke the trance.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 01:32:07 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Flashing

Greetings:

For 914 owners who are looking for that "different sort of flash",  you know,
the one that sets you apart from all those "normal" 914 flashers, try pulling
the switch out and back in as fast as you can.
If you do it just right you will raise and lower just one headlight instead
of both effectively winking at the oncoming p-car.  It takes a bit of
practice to be able to do it right every time, but the look on the flashees
face as he passes is well worth the effort.

;;; pm9146@aol.com

Pat Moyle

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 00:38:22 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: 912E #1 update&corvair pwrd 914?

>doesn't know its history, he bought it with the shop some eight years 
>ago.  He thinks it might be an original 914/6 because of its early build 
>date (11/69) and its uplevel interior and tougher looking suspension.  
>His question and mine...how do you tell a 914/4 from a 914/6?  Are the 
>VIN #s different?  Suspensions?  Any info would be helpful.
>Jay Karolyi

Jay,

According to 'Das Book' 13312 1969 914.4's were made and 2668 914.6's were made.

The serial numbers were:

914.4:  4702900001-4702913312
914.6:  9140430001-9140432668

If the number is between 91423300010-9142330020 then call me :-O

Porschephiles #1180                         Sat Feb 18 02:00:09 CST 1995
Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 02:46:59 -0500
From: MAESTRO132@aol.com
Subject: Re: Sodium Thrills

Dear John:
       My most vivid memory of Sodium fires was a training film I saw when I
was at Oak Ridge National Laboratory, circa 1968 (the film must have been
made in the '50's.) A 1955 Chevy pick u p truck backs to the top of a cliff
overlooking a water-filled quarry. Two figure emerge, unhook the  tailgate
and push a chunk of sodium about a cubic foot or two over the edge of the
quarry. The  sodium block accelerates  as Newton doth state and splashes into
the water. A one or two second pause. Followed by a DRAMATIC EXPLOSION Yellow
flames big plumes of water, etc. Smaller chunks of sodium land outside the
plume and produce secondary explosions. More yellow flame, white smoke etc.
     A rather vivid demonstration- far removed from the cute little pops one
gets from the chunk of sodium from inside an Ate 3048 Sodium-filled exhaust
valve when dropped into the sink.

KEEP THE 356/912 FAITH!
The Maestro

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 95 09:51:44 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: Safety, ABS, Air Bags etc.


Text item: Text_1

Chris was asking about the intro. date of alleged safety features, if the 89 C4 
I test drove last year was truly representative of the model it did not have air
bags, it did have ABS. 
Now to start a flame session: who in their right mind would want either?
The safest restraint you can have is a FIXED length seat belt properly adjusted 
and WORN. It can be tested every time you drive the car and can be visually 
inspected, you know it will work when you need it and you don't have to worry 
about it working when you don't need it. Air Bags are a totally unnecessary 
government imposition on those of us who take care and precautions, shades of 
Big Brother and over regulation. If they would leave well alone Darwin's Theory 
would prevail.
ABS is similar in that it adds an unknown quantity of failure modes with unknown
effects and unknown failure rates. As one who has to evaluate all of these 
factors on an almost daily basis for commercial airline equipment its easy to 
get paranoid about it but things that ain't there don't break, pun intended. 
Unless racing you should never be in the position of having to be at the limit 
of braking. If you are, you have failed to read the road and or the situation, 
and are not driving in the defensive mode needed to be a good citizen, i.e. like
most ignorant, selfish, inconsiderate and intolerant louts you get around these 
parts. Strong letter to follow........
If you are racing you probably have enough skill to do better than ABS any way.
Seriously there are several good books on driving skills, one of the best being 
Paul Frere's Sports Car and Competition Driving, recently updated and re issued 
I believe.
Bottom line save your money for something useful and quit believing all of these
TV ads.
One of the reasons I bought an 86 was because it DIDN'T have ABS and Bags, 
though I do confess I am still using the inertia reel belts. However they are 
testable and inspectable for every pre-flight.
Have fun, observe and drive safely.

neil_nw_walker@ae.ge.com


------------------------------

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 95 09:51:09 EST
From: Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B <smtplink%Neil_NW_Walker_at_EVEN__2100B@ccmail.ae.ge.com>
Subject: Swedes and Old Fashioned Courtesy


Text item: Text_1

Reference Ben's and Pete's recent postings. Swedes (vegie kind) are known here 
as Rudebegas or some such spelling. Do not know derivation but it does cause 
confusion when trying to buy vegies.
Yeah I've driven TR6s, one was quite thrilling as it was one of the development 
cars for the Lucas fuel injection system, which if my memory is good was the 
precursor of the Bosche CIS. Car had much more power than standard machine but 
you had to carry a hammer in the tool kit as the fuel pump would quit at 
inappropriate moments, very easy to get sideways even in the dry when pump 
worked.
If my memory is correct Bosche took (i.e. licensed) the mechanical system from 
Lucas and Lucas later took the electronic from Bosche. There were many ties 
between the Companies dating back to the mid thirties.
Many people used to acknowledge the driver of a similar vehicle be it MGA/MGA 
TR/TR Morgan/Morgan or whatever but you dont see it any more. Lorry (truck) 
drivers always gave lots of information to other drivers too, like flashing 
lights for speed traps or to tell you it was clear to overtake, I suppose the CB
radio did away with that.
Nostalgia..............

neil_nw_walker@ae.ge.com

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 10:54:56 -0500 (EST)
From: Richard Hollander <ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us>
Subject: Re: Safety, ABS, Air Bags etc.

I've an '87 951 and it came with dual airbags, ABS, and a limited slip 
differential. I believe at the time it was the only car in the world that 
offered such safety features, which, believe it or not, are still not 
available on such "sports cars" as Ferraris and Lamborghinis, not to 
mention Aston Martin. Yet another milestone for Porsche.


RickSH
ricksh@bcfreenet.seflin.lib.fl.us

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 16:32:40 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: 912E #1 update&corvair pwrd 914?

Jay,
You said:

>His question and mine...how do you tell a 914/4 from a 914/6?  Are the 
>VIN #s different?  Suspensions?  Any info would be helpful.

914/6 serial numbers begin "914x43xxxx". 914/4 numbers begin with
"47xxxxxxx".  The first x in the 6 serial number is the last digit of the
model year, ie. 0 for 1970 or 1 for 1971.

914/6's also had five bolt wheels and vented front disks.  Many 4's have had
this done so this method of telling them apart is not as good.

A firend of mine built two Corvair powered 914's.  Had reverse cams in them
so they would run backwards.  Had 40 IDA Webers like early 911's.  Both
burned to the ground because of carb fires, at the same location on the same
highway after he had been to the same parts store! Eerie!  He gave up and
bought a pristine 914/6 instead.  Eventually sold it because he kept having
nightmares about IT burning to the ground.

Jon Lowe
jonlowe@aol.com

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 16:50:00 -0500
From: JonLowe@aol.com
Subject: Re: Movie Porsches

In a recent message, RickSH said:

>"No Man's Land" is the GREATEST of all Porsche 
>flicks because the whole movie revolves around them! Though the stars are 
>mainly ass-engined Porsches and not 28s or 44s, it's nevertheless the 
>ultimate Porsche film. 

At the risk of a flame war, NOT!  Rent, or better yet, BUY Steve McQueen's
"LeMans".  This is the ultimate heart pounding Porshcephile flick with
Porsches in their natural element, the race track.  Porsche vs. Ferrari, and
Steve in a Porsche 917 at LeMans: what could be better?!! And while the film
revolves around Porsche 917's, there are 911's and the winning 914/6 Sonauto
car from 1970. For the ultimate videophile, there is even a laser disk
version in widescreen format. All other Porsche films pale in comparison. And
yes, I also own "No Man's Land".

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 19:17:43 -0500
From: jfoster@rohmhaas.com (Jim Foster)
Subject: Re: Safety, ABS, Air Bags etc.

At 09:51 AM 2/18/95 EST, Neil NW Walker trolled for flames:
>
Seatbelt discussion deleted. 

>ABS is similar in that it adds an unknown quantity of failure modes with
unknown
>effects and unknown failure rates. As one who has to evaluate all of these 
>factors on an almost daily basis for commercial airline equipment its easy to 
>get paranoid about it but things that ain't there don't break, pun intended. 
>Unless racing you should never be in the position of having to be at the limit 
>of braking. If you are, you have failed to read the road and or the situation, 
>and are not driving in the defensive mode needed to be a good citizen, i.e.
like
>most ignorant, selfish, inconsiderate and intolerant louts you get around
these 
>parts. Strong letter to follow........
>If you are racing you probably have enough skill to do better than ABS any way.

It's my understanding that ABS will fail in such a way that while you may
lose the anti-lock, your normal braking won't be affected.  Does anyone know
if this isn't correct?

As for never being in a position of being at the limit of braking, have you
ever driven in a Northeast Winter?  Have you ever hit "black ice?"  It's
possible for one side of the car to have adequate traction while the other
side has far less.  This is an example of where ABS will probably do you
more good than being a professional driver.  The ABS will be able to cycle
the brakes on half the car far faster than you could ever pump them.
- --
Jim Foster - jfoster@rohmhaas.com        (215) 592-2446 (voice) 592-2369 (FAX)
"Being on a Beemer and not having a wave returned by a                   944S2
Sportster is like having a clipper ship's hailing not                  DoD 142
returned by an orphaned New Jersey solid waste barge." -OTL      '91 K100RS16V

chrome bumpers rather than the big, black, rubber (ugly IMO) safety bumpers 
found on the `75-6's.  Were the chrome ones only on original cars until `72? 
 I can never remember.

She was Rockford's lawyer.  The character later "upgraded" to an SL Mercedes 
of undetermined model number.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 18 Feb 1995 21:36:42 -0800 (PST)
From: Bryan Clingman <bryanc@slip.net>
Subject: Re: Need advise on Driving Schools

> I had the pleasure of reading the information sent to P-files regarding the
> Russell Driving School, and I got "pumped up" enough to send for the Russell
> Brochures.

I didn't see the stuff sent to P-files about Russell, But I did attend
the school last December.  I recommend the school if you are interested
in open-wheel racing, heck even if you aren't, I had a blast.  The basic
course takes place in an older Formula Ford (2 liter Pinto engine) car. 
The car weights about 900 pounds and has a resonable power to weight
ratio.

The first day of the course involves getting suited up, then you get to
practice heel-toe downshifting (an art in itself, much easier to do in a
914 than a Forumla Ford IMO) and brakeing.  Day two begins with
cornering exercises followed by lapping in the afternoon.  Day three is
purely lapping.  You are allowed to pass other cars in certain sections
of the course (the longer straights).  If your class is good, you get to
drive the Formula Russell Cars (similar car, with slicks, wings and lots
more power) for your last lapping session.

If you do go, you will probably notice several things when you get back
into your Porsche:

1.  My "nimble" 914 felt like a extended cab longbed pickup when I got back
into it.  This feeling continued for almost 2 weeks.

2.  I appreciated even more the "race breeding" in my 914 (i.e. pedal
setup, drivers position, steering position, brakes (yes even 914 brakes).

3.  I can't wait to go back for the Advanced Course...(or I put money
down on a 911)

  --Bryan Clingman
    bryanc@slip.net

  95 914 2.0

p.s. Regarding your question, I think there is a school that uses Porsches.
try a copy of Racer magazine.

Porschephiles #1182                         Mon Feb 20 02:00:05 CST 1995
Date: Feb 19, 1995 04:18:05
From: gwong2@uranus.calstatela.edu (Gene Wong 10-06-92)
Subject: 911 Engine Removal

Hello, Porscephiles;
    Hi, all!  I'm attempting to remove the engine out of my 1983 Euro-spec
911 Targa but experiencing trouble with getting the car high enough for yhe
engine to be removed.  I'm not even sure where to put the jackstands to
support the rear.  My jackstands are almost at maximum height
when placed under the torsion bar ends that stick out on either side of the
brackets on the arm side.  The _floor jack_ is also nearly at max height when
jacking under the engine with a 2 x 4 and I still need the car higher in order
to clear the engine (possibly 6 more inches or a little more). I was wondering
how some of you out there have been removing your engines.  Is there another
place to put the jackstands (and floor jack) that does not require as much
height? Also, is it hard to separate the engine from the transmission (how
is this accomplished)?  Any help would be greatly appreciated!  So far, I
have put the car back down on the ground and all that is left is to get the
car high enough and remove the mount bolts.
                            Thanks,
                             Gene

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 1995 09:18:51 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 911 Engine Removal

After your car is at max height with jackstands take the jack and get a large
board such as a 2" x 6". Put that board under the floorpan of your car just
forward of the transmission and across the width of the car. Put your jack on
another board so that it is high enough to jack up the board that you have
across the car. Raise the car enough to drag out the engine. Obviously the
car will come off the jack stand during this procedure and that is OK.
Make sure you have a helper to observe and help steady the engine.
We just did this in the sands of Sebring during the Club Race weekend so it's
pretty fresh in my mind.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
9:01 am

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 1995 09:18:52 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: Safety, ABS, Air Bags etc.


>Reponse to Neil who doesn't think ABS or airbags are necessary if you are a
"good driver."

Neil,
You have just got to be kidding. You can be the best driver in the world
(ever read about notable world class drivers wrecking their street cars) and
the potential for a mishap is always there. Do you slow down at every cross
street and check to make sure no one is running a light, stop sign, etc ? Did
you ever have anyone fall asleep and cross a median strip in front of you?
These thing can and do happen and you are going to get walloped, I don't care
who you are.
Secondly seat belts are fine but in a high speed mishap you are going to be
seriously injured whether you are wearing them or not. Trust me on this I
spent quite a bit of time in emergency rooms during my college years. Seat
belt injuries can be severe, but certainly not as severe as not wearing them.
Head and leg trauma, as well as thoracic damage are common.
Seat belts combined with air bags have a much greater safety margin. It
doesn't take a genius to figure out why.
ABS is the greatest. Why do you think that modern race cars use this system?
I am sure race drivers can threshold brake very well but the driver with ABS
has a clear advantage both on the course and on the street. Worst case
scenario is that the ABS will fail in which case you have normal brakes.
Please re think your position on these matters

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
9:13 am

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 1995 09:47:46 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: re;airbags,abs

I agree with you that airbags are a "big brother" intrusion on our lives, one
unfortuneate side effect for us sports car owners is the lack of easily
transferable steering wheels at a moderate price.

However I totally disagree with you concerning abs, which I have in my 90
944S2 and feel it is a great improvement over non-=abs in most circumstances.
 In autocrossing it is far superior to non-abs cars to such an extent that we
in the Northeast Region of PCA refer to courses as abs and non-abs favored
courses, and I'm sure it is true most everywhere else.  There is no question
that the abs can threshold brake better and more consistantly than 99% of the
drivers.  But when it comes to track driving the jury is still out on the
effectiveness of abs,  although it will help you to not lock a wheel when
hard braking, this aspect is not as critical on a track as it is at an
autocross, plus most people are more conservative on the track (probably due
to the hard walls around them) so they do not threshold brake quite as often
or as deeply.  Now the one unknown and a hot topic here in the Northeast area
of the country, is how does an abs equipped car react in a spinning situation
where the car is traveling in a rearward direction?  Commonly held theory to
lock the brakes does not work (abs works in reverse too.), so what do you do
to slow the car down?  Currently a number of regions and the people at the
local BMW club are investigating this quandry. Once my car comes out of
storage I may do some experimentation to see if there is a safe and controllab
le way to slow a spinning car on the track.


                           Steve

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 1995 10:11:07 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re : Airbags

>Air Bags are a totally unnecessary government imposition on those of us who
>take care and precautions, shades of Big Brother and over regulation. If
they >would leave well alone Darwin's Theory would prevail.

I read in Autoweek that airbags are not "totally" unnecessary, but there
aren't exactly a panacea either.  Airbags don't increase the survivability of
an accident much over the use of seatbelts alone (from the NHTSA numbers -
not my opinion).  In fact the article made mention of the fact that airbags
had even been *responsible* for deaths in accidents that should have been
survivable in a few cases.

Airbags are designed, basically, for head-on collisions.  I have to believe
that
most head-on collisions are avoidable.

FWIW, I don't like "passive" seatbelts either, nor do I believe that man-made
CFCs are causing global warming, etc, blah blah blah, yadda yadda yadda...:>)

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 95 21:46:07 +0100
From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: car stories....

Paul,

  |           for the guidance everyone gives!  Sometime ago I "inherited" what
  |           is a shell and frame of a 1957 356A.  The car's body and frame 
  |           are in excellent condition, it's been in storage for about 20+

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 95 16:08:57 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Addition to the pcar family??

> Hey,

> wants to look "cute".  I know, not a great reason to buy a 
> Porsche, but what the heck?

> new timing belts, etc., supposedly good condition.  $3850.
> 
> Am I an idiot, or what?  Aside from the usual motor mounts,
> water pump, etc, - is there anything specific to the '87s
> or 924Ss in particular that I should look for??
> 
> TIA, 
> 
> Mike Dayton
> '76 Euro 911

Hi, Mike,

In 1987 Porsche decided to redesign the oil/water intercooler near the air
filter, resulting in failures of the O-ring.  Keep an eye out for black scum
in your coolant reservoir or brown foam in your oil.

No other unusual problem areas...stay away from the automatic...

On the other hand, you may want to hold out for a 1988 model, 15 more
horsepower, and you may be able to locate one of the special edition cars 
(no sunroof, windup windows, lighter and quicker) which are autocrosser's
delights...

Oh, and, keep my number handy...  :-)


- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 1995 16:35:22 -0500
From: Jon50g@aol.com
Subject: RE:944S stalling out

The first reply>
..............................................................................
......................
If your engine runs fine when cold but has a problem warm, I'd
look for something temperature related.  This could be an injector
o-ring or the intake manifold gasket.  You can test both for vacuum
leaks by dribbling tap water on them.  If, when you dribble it at a
particular place, the engine note changes, or you hear or see the
water being sucked into the intake, you've found a problem.

Could be an O2 sensor; they get slow with age.  However, if after
about three minutes of driving from dead cold, you do not have an
idle problem, I think the O2 sensor is probably not to blame.  That
is, if the problem doesn't surface until long after the cat has lit off
and the DME has started running closed loop, it is not the closed
loop that is causing the problem.
..............................................................................
......................

Thank you, Kevin, for the reply.  I tried these tests and am not sure what
I've found, but would like to share observations.

The car is up on stands after a 20min. test session.  From dead cold, with
the 02 sensor partially unscrewed (no exhaust leaking), I started the car.
 The 02 was then removed, no change in engine operation as far as I could tell
. I placed it back in and tried the same 15min (and some 2000-3000rpm idling)
later, no change in engine operation now either.  Has the car failed the O2
test?  Was I listening for the right audible changes (i.e. idle change,stumble
,etc)?  This problem does manifest itself after 3+ minutes.  Boosch engine
management isn't my forte and I would need elaboration on when "cat. lit off"
and "DME closed loop" occur. 
The water test, performed with fish tank tubing and a bucket, was negative.

The big observation comes at the 11th minute and 15th minute of operation.
 At the 11th, the car chugs/stumbles and flushes itself slightly over 1000rpm
and then settles back down to a nice steady 1000.  At the 15th, it
chuged/stumbled and stalled dead from idle.  Regular maintenance has been
performed properly (I thought for a minute it could be particle(s) in the
fuel system, but the filter is fresh).

I've heard of the O2 test before, but thought it not applicable here because
it usually leads to other performance problems such as poor throttle response
at the gas peddle.  That is not when this problem is occurring.  Am I wrong
in this assumption?

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 95 18:06:07 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: RE:944S stalling out

Hi, Jon

Removing the O2 sensor from the loop does not mean to remove it physically
from the exhaust system. It means to disconnect the electrical connection to
the DME.  In this case, the connection is a plug (about the size of a
jalapeno pepper) located near the firewall at the top of the motor.

Try the same tests with the sensor installed in the exhaust system, but with
the connection removed.

Of course, it could be one of the temperature sensors with a dead spot at
some point, which is causing the stumbling.

The last thing to be said is that the factory service manual contains a
detailed diagnosis and list of symptoms that might assist you in your quest.
If you're going to be working on your on 944, I HIGHLY recommend the
acquisition of the factory manual. (Porsche Factory Manual - there is no
substitute...)

Lastly, about your fuel filter being new and therefore good.  It was about 2
years ago when I finally found ($$$) a fuel filter had been clogged by a bad
tank of gas that kept my getting enough fuel at medium to high rpms.  The
fuel filter was 3 months old, the gas let me cruise home for 60 miles until
the symptoms occurred.

All that I am trying to point out is that you cannot make any assumptions
that a part is good until you have tested it.  Even then, you cannot always
be sure...

Good luck,

- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 95 19:06:58 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Flashing

> Here in NH flashing is also illegal. Years back I
> had ample opportunity to read those little sheets with
> all the offenses and the fines that they so nicely give
> you when you get a ticket.

This sounds like a Freedom of Speech issue.  Years ago, I read a 
front-page article in the Hartford (Connecticut, USA) Courant about a 
guy who got a ticket for light flashing.  The court offered to drop the 
charge, but he persisted in order to force a judgement and thus a legal 
precedent.  He won, and in his argument, made reference to the earlier 
days when Paul Revere used lanterns in the Old North Church to warn of 
approaching British.  (Hope I recall my history fact right).

I've flashed & been tagged by Massachusetts cops a fair amount.  I 
usually win the court fight, but it depends on the judge.  Best not to 
play the game...

		Jim

Date: Sun, 19 Feb 1995 21:52:22 -0500
From: X400459@aol.com
Subject: Re: 1978 911 SC

I bought an 85 Targa this summer. In searching for the car, I extensively
searched for a 911 sc as well as a Carrera. The earliest car I saw was an 80
Coupe. The guy wanted 16k for it. I looked at several 81's and 82's at around
17k and an 83 cabriolet at 22k (this car was in a couple of really serious
accidents--didn't pass muster). If the car is as you say--it sounds like a
very competitively priced  car to me. Be sure to check whether there is a
chain tensioner upgrade. Have it checked out by a mechanic and, when driving
it, be on the watch for worn syncromesh in 1st and 2nd gears. Also, theres a
"pop off box" that needs a kit. One of the other guys with more tech
knowledge can tell you more about it--not sure I understand it. Oh yeah, a
leak down test is mandatory when being checked out mechanically. And, by the
way, I love my Targa, the top goes thru the car wash with just a trickle on
inside of the passenger window. And you can't beat the wind and air for the
price compared to a cabriolet.

Rich Brown aka x400459@aol.com
85 911 Targa, black w/tail (wounded)
84 Saab Turbo, black (wounded)
86 Puegot, silver (pronounced pew  got, running again)
2 standard poodles (still in the dog house)

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 02:10:05 -0500
From: Mdch01@aol.com
Subject: 931 Fuel pump riddle.

Hi Porschephiles.
I am experiencing some weird problmes with my 924 Turbo - here is a
chronology of the events:
When I turn on the ignition and the pumps cycle on to pressurize the system,
I get a strange 'rattle' from the fuel pump area (near the tank).  This has
been the case since I bought the car several years ago.  When I start the
engine, I can still hear a noise from the back of the car.  I checked the
system pressure and it proved to be within spec - and my in-dash air/fuel
ratio guage shows full rich at wide open throttle.  I assumed therefore that
all was OK with the pump.
Today, the car started jerking when I accelerated.  The car would eventually
only go about 10MPH.  The 'rattle' from the back seemed to have intensified.
 I had the car towed home and installed a pump from my brothers 1979 924.
 This solved the jerking problem - BUT after driving a few miles, the 'rattle'
 from the back (either from one of the two pumps or the fuel accumulator) had
returned (!!!) - even with the enw pump.  I know that the noise is not coming
from the in-tank pump because I disconnected it and the noise remained.  Has
anyone ever experienced this?  
BTW, when I bought the car, the fuel accumulator had been removed (bypassed)
and I replaced it with a 2nd hand unit from "Best-Deal."  

Thnaks for your advice -
MIKE

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 95 10:12:49 PST
From: mwc@lubrizol.com
Subject: Airbags - personal testimony


To those who question the usefulness of airbags: you're crazy!

Last November I was driving my 1985 Ford Tempo equipped with
an airbag (yes, '85 Tempo).  I was on the Columbus beltway approaching
a "cross-merge".  I needed to exit the highway right beyond an on-ramp.

Traffic was moderate, the road was lighted but dark at 7:45 pm; 
I looked back to make sure no one was merging on, when I looked forward, 
the car in front of me jammed the brakes and almost lost it.  His back end 
came out about 20 degrees and his front end took a serious dive.

I jammed the brakes and veered right onto the shoulder instinctively to
avoid him.  I thought I probably had room behind him, but veered right.

A split second later I found out why he jammed his brakes.  He was
also merging off to the right and was going to cut across the painted "V"
from the on-ramp, when at the last second he saw a parked car!

My attention was on his car, I didn't even see the parked car when I veered 
right I hit the parked car square at 35-45 mph.

After a loud pop, I realized what had happened.  I didn't hear any
squishy sounds and felt okay.  Jumped out of the car and was fine.

I admit the seat belt protected me from serious injury, but the airbag kept me
from whipping my head, kept me from being bruised by the seat belt alone,
kept me from going forward more than a couple inches off the seat,
and did a good job of making my wire rimmed glasses a pair of sport goggles!
Without the airbag, I could have suffered a neck injury, perhaps some
bruised ribs.

I just couldn't believe I was in such a serious accident and wasn't injured.
Maybe my accident could have been avoided, but then again, that's why
they're called accidents.  If a $1000 option is going to save me from injury
(especially during the few times I don't wear my seat belt), I call that 
CHEAP insurance.

Alive, Using all 4,

Matt Carpenter
1984 928S
1988 Saab 9000 turbo
E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 10:52:50 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Addition to the P-Car Family??

Mike Dayton says, "Aside from the usual motor mounts, water pump, etc, - is
there anything specific to the '87s or 924Ss in particular that I should look
for??"
 
Mike, your wife has good taste.

Look at the 924/944/968 FAQ for "things to look out for".  In particular,
check to see that it has the modified seals in the oil cooler.  If it has,
ask whether or not the lower bearings were also replaced (they should have
been).  Coolant in the oil can ACCELERATE bearing wear.

By the way, there were 500 of the Special Edition cars in 1988.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S (the Special Edition, M030)
1992 Isuzu Trooper

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 10:46:02 -0500 (EST)
From: randy@sensor.com (Randy Kirby)
Subject: Re: removing window tint

> 
> Can someone please tell me how to remove window tint. I am especially
> concerned with the rear window defrost lines. The tint is just to dark..
>                                                          THANKS,
>                                                              Philip


About a month ago I removed the "drug dealer" tinting from my Mercedes. It
was quite easy and only took about an hour. All you need is a spray bottle
full of ammonia, a razor blade and paper towels. 

On the roll-up windows, roll 'em down an inch or two to expose top corner of
tinting, get under it with the razor to lift it slightly, then spray a bit of
ammonia at where the tint is beginning to peel away and pull. If you're lucky,
the sheet will not rip. When you've got it pulled down as far as it will go,
roll the window back up and pull it the rest of the way off.

For the other windows, just find a corner, lift, spray, pull, spray, pull...

I tried to be especially careful with the defroster elements, pulling the
film off parallel to the lines and had no problems. 

Good luck!

  Randy Kirby
  sensor!randy@encore.com
  Boca Raton, FL
  Still looking for a '90 C2 Cab...

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 10:14:44 -0600
From: Pete Klager <pete.klager@medtronic.com>
Subject:  914 Horn Help - Thanks!

Thanks to everyone who responded to my horn help question.

From your answers, I learned that the cut-off wire is supposed to go to a spade connector on the
metal ring on the horn pad.  (Note:  '70 and '71 914s use a different design with some sort of
finger contact).  I also learned that there is supposed to be a rubber boot on which the horn pad
pivots - something I never knew I was supposed to have.  No wonder my horn pad is loose and
rattles on the steering wheel.

I will be ordering a new rubber horn boot and making up a spade connector splice soon.

Thanks again,

Pete Klager
'75 914  1.8L

and some other stuff to drive to work

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 09:24:23 -0700
From: mhatch@utg.org (Mark Hatch)
Subject: Pointer to OEM undercoating on early 70's 911

Hi all!


Does anybody know where I can purchase some of the original undercoat that
was used during the early 70's.  This stuff was sprayed on the lower rocker
panels and around the lips of the fendors. It was also used in the around
the gas tank up front and in the fender wells. This stuff is tuff! The only
reference I could find to it was a vague description of it being a PVC
based undercoating (in the DIY Porsche Restoration Book). I checked with
the local Porsche dealer and he looked at me as if I had two heads (human,
not 911)...

Thanks!

mark
73'911 T Targa (CIS)

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 08:24:48 -0800
From: KimKnapp@ix.netcom.com (Maynard Knapp)
Subject: Re: Airbags - personal testimony

You wrote: 

>
>
>To those who question the usefulness of airbags: you're crazy!
>
>Last November I was driving my 1985 Ford Tempo equipped with
>an airbag (yes, '85 Tempo).  I was on the Columbus beltway approaching
>a "cross-merge".  I needed to exit the highway right beyond an on-ramp.
>
>Traffic was moderate, the road was lighted but dark at 7:45 pm; 
>I looked back to make sure no one was merging on, when I looked 
forward, 
>the car in front of me jammed the brakes and almost lost it.  His back 
end 
>came out about 20 degrees and his front end took a serious dive.
>
>I jammed the brakes and veered right onto the shoulder instinctively to
>avoid him.  I thought I probably had room behind him, but veered right.
>
>A split second later I found out why he jammed his brakes.  He was
>also merging off to the right and was going to cut across the painted 
"V"
>from the on-ramp, when at the last second he saw a parked car!
>
>My attention was on his car, I didn't even see the parked car when I 
veered 
>right I hit the parked car square at 35-45 mph.
>
>After a loud pop, I realized what had happened.  I didn't hear any
>squishy sounds and felt okay.  Jumped out of the car and was fine.
>
>I admit the seat belt protected me from serious injury, but the airbag 
kept me
>from whipping my head, kept me from being bruised by the seat belt 
alone,
>kept me from going forward more than a couple inches off the seat,
>and did a good job of making my wire rimmed glasses a pair of sport 
goggles!
>Without the airbag, I could have suffered a neck injury, perhaps some
>bruised ribs.
>
>I just couldn't believe I was in such a serious accident and wasn't 
injured.
>Maybe my accident could have been avoided, but then again, that's why
>they're called accidents.  If a $1000 option is going to save me from 
injury
>(especially during the few times I don't wear my seat belt), I call 
that 
>CHEAP insurance.
>
>Alive, Using all 4,
>
>Matt Carpenter
>1984 928S
>1988 Saab 9000 turbo
>E-mail: mwc@lubrizol.com
>
>
>
Matt,
	We are all glad that you came out of the accident unscratched. I 
don't think anyone doubts how effective the airbag is. I think the 
problem is that they are not, in fact, optional and people are getting 
tired of the gov't making decisions for them.
		Kim
