Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 12:01:40 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Airbags and ABS

Your points about "unnecessary" safety devices are dubious at best, for,
although what you write may be appropriate for you, I and the majority of
people on this list unfortunately dear old Aunt Minnie and millions like her
do not necessarily approach the task of driving with the same mind set, and
when she gets into a wreck lets hope an airbag saves her both for her sake
and for ours. Why?, because we are the ones that indirectly absorb the
additional costs of her extended hospitalization (due to lack of protection
in the vehicle) through increased insurance premiums. 

It's the same as the idiots, like Garey Busey, who refuse to wear helmets
when riding bikes because it "their freedom" not to do so. Well fine - but I
just hope he makes sure that he can afford to pay ALL the additional costs
for reconstructive surgery and life support after he smashes his skull on the
pavement 'cos I want no pay no part of "his freedom".

In this state (AZ), insurance companies severely reduce payouts on accidents
where they can prove that injuries were increased in severity by the lack of
seat belt use. But still you see idiots driving around without them on. ( I
wonder if these same idiots are on their way to the airport, where they will
board a plane and buckle up without a murmur?)

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 16:25:01 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: flashing and waving

On Fri, 17 Feb 1995, Ed Mellinger wrote:
> Someone once observed a "flashing" incident while I was piloting, um, a
> different brand of german metal, and remarked "just lift two fingers

Waving 2 fingers is not considered polite in the UK.

This dates back to the 100 years war with france, if an english bowman 
was captured by the french, they cut of his two fingers so that he could 
not draw his bow.

In subsequent battles english archers would always raise 2 fingers to the 
opponent in a gesture of defiance.




+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 09:37:25 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: RE: Rockford Files & Bumbers

>>The 914 in "The Rockford Files" was (if memory serves) orange rather than 
>>red (one of us needs to adjust our set) and a `74 or earlier since it had 
>>chrome bumpers rather than the big, black, rubber (ugly IMO) safety bumpers 
>>found on the `75-6's.  Were the chrome ones only on original cars until `72? 
>>I can never remember.
>
>I've been trying to find this out my self for my 914 restoration and continue to 
>be confused in this area.

According to the 914 Restorer's Guide to Authenticity...
Front bumpers:
1970-'72: Painted bumpers, standard. Chrome bumpers optional.
1973-'74: Matte black bumper, standard. Rubber bumper guards, USA.
1975-'76: Revised bumper (the big one), and bumper guards for California and 
Maryland.

Rear:
1970-'72: Painted bumpers, standard. Chrome bumpers optional.
1973: Matte black bumper standard.
1974: Rubber bumper guards, USA.
1975-'76: Revised bumper (the big one), and bumper guards for California and 
Maryland.

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 13:12:48 +0500
From: timmins@warthog.us.udel.edu (Steve Timmins)
Subject: EuroProducts Strikes Again! (long)

The following are statements of fact.  Interpret it as you will.

On January 30, I ordered two pairs of manual factory C2 mirrors from
EuroProducts for $269 each, plus misc. for a total of $607.  They said
they were in inventory and would go out UPS Ground that day.  Florida
to DE is 2 days usually.

On February 7 I called back to see if my order had shipped.  Talking to
Mark, he said he had some problems getting the mirrors and would look
into it and call back.  When asked why he said he had them in hand, he
said he had done no such thing.

On February 8, I called back again, and was informed that the C2 manual
mirrors were no longer available and that he could get the electric
version for $369.  I said I would check around for manual and let him know if I wanted the electric, but until them to put the order on hold.  That was acceptable.

I then called The Racer's Group and talked to Kevin, who said he coul d
sell the C2 manuals for $269 and showed 6 pairs in inventory.  He said
it might take a few days to get the order out.  I also ordered an oil
cooler and some brake ducts for a total of $688.00

Still on February 8 I called EuroProducts and taked to Mark, cancelling the entirety of my order.  He said that was fine.

On February 17 I received my C2 mirrors from Racer's Group, along with other items.

Today I talked to Discover Card who said there was a charge January 30 to my card for 
$607 from EuroProducts.


I called Mark at EuroProdiucts to see if my account had been credited.  He said he was sure it had been and he would call me back.

About a year ago I ordered some Headers from EuroProducts.  I
specifically asked if the lower valve covers could be removed with the
headersd in place.  I ewas told they used these headers all the time
and that there was plenty of clearance.  I was quite adamant that they
must fit, and allow easy accress for valve adj. because I had had
problems with other headers.   No problem I was told.

When I received the headers, I gently bolted them up, being careful not
to scratch them, using my own new gaskets and nuts.  Sure enough it was
impossible to remove the valve covers with the headers installed.

I called europroducts to explain the problem to them.  Mark said "we
don't take returns on installed parts" and indicate that it was a
common problem, and I'd just have to remove the headers when I needed
to adjust the valves.  He refused to allow return and said they were
special orders even though he claimed to have them in stock when I
ordered them.

I called discover and explained the situation to them.  They suggested
I attempt to return them, and to include an explaination and shipping
receipt in a letter to them, and to CC: europroducts.  That way even if
the headers were refused I could prove returning them in good faith.

About 2 weeks later I got an apologetic call from Mark, who said he was
sorry for the misunderstanding, and saying he was very soryrry, bklah
blah blah, and how they would hate to lose a good customer, and wouls
I please accept 6 oil filters free as a token of apology.  I told him I
didn't particularly want any free oil filters and that I woud not be
conducting business with them in the future. He said he was sending
them anyway.  I told hom to suit himself.

Two days later I recieved the oil filters.

>>>>>>personal comment follows:

I should have known better.  I figured they had made an honest mistake
and perhaps they wern't such bad guys afterall.  Now I get to hash it
out again.  That'll teach me!











------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 17:17:33 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Swedes and Old Fashioned Courtesy

On Sat, 18 Feb 1995, Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B wrote:
> Yeah I've driven TR6s, one was quite thrilling as it was one of the development 
> cars for the Lucas fuel injection system, which if my memory is good was the 

The Lucas mechanical system was used for many years on formula 1 cars - 
did 160k miles on 2 TR's with only one fuel injection failure, when the 
injector drive sheared. 

The fuel pump uses used to play up in summer, they got hot - you stopped 
 - the fuel vaporised in the pump, and you couldn't restart. We solved that 
prob by wrapping a length of fuel line round the pump motor, so fuel 
returning to the tank from the relief valve passed around the pump 
cooling it down.

The TR 2.5 ltr used to give 29 mpg (Imperial) = 36 us mpg driven with a 
lead foot it dropped to 22 mpg and pulled 27 mph per 1000 revs 

The tthing that I liked most was the overdrive, far better than 5 speed 
boxes, nice to have a gear change on a finger switch you could sit in 3rd 
o/d waiting for a gap in traffic then click and go

+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

I think it is a typo for Daytona.  There is no track in Dayton, OH or any
other Dayton that I know of. 917 coupes ran at Daytona in '70 and '71 before
they were outlawed.

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 12:32:47 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: 914 chrome bumpers

As I recall, chrome bumpers on the 914 through 1974 were part of the
"appearance group," which included vinyl-covered rollbar and console.
The '74 limited edition white/orange and black/yellow had the gauges,
but no vinyl and painted bumpers.  Other 914s had black bumpers.
Maybe they were body-colored in earlier years--I forget.

Steve Gilbert
steveng@csufresno.edu

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 95 16:12:38 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Euro 911/930 turn signal indicator

You've got a bad ground on that side's turn signal bulb.  The current 
is seeking ground, and it's finding it by bridging backwards through 
the front parking light bulb.  I see this on old Audi's all the time.

		Jim

> From: Stan Hanks  <stan@tta.com>

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 14:14:24 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Rebuilt 914 High Idle Question

I have a question concerning a 914 that's idling high ('74 2.0, stock)

All my hoses are new and correspond with Fred Pack's "914 Hose Layout" of
January '95. The engine has <2,000 miles on new rings, exhaust valve
guides, and lots of little parts, including injectors.  The ignition system
is in good shape and was timed to 27deg BTDC @ 3500 rpm. Vacuum advance and
retard both work properly. I used silicone only under the throttle body
(necessary) -- all other air intake gaskets were done "dry". It runs very
nicely, BUT

The idle is too high, and cannot be adjusted by the idle adjust screw (it's
already all the way in).  Once the engine is warm, it idles no lower than
1100 rpm. The aux air valve works properly, and is shut closed once the
motor's warmed up. Turning the CO mixture screw has little effect - it
drops a wee bit on both extremes of the range.

I disconnected each and every hose and tested it for vacuum or pressure.
The idle didn't change when any of them were plugged, except for the line
at the crankcase breather "valve" next to the oil filler cap.  This line,
when plugged, caused the idle to drop way down, to a point where it seems
"right", and could be adjusted by the idle air screw.  I can feel little
"putt-putts" coming out of the valve if I put my finger over it. 
Strangely, I feel very little air being sucked _into_ the crankcase
breather lines on the hose between the air cleaner and the junction/flame
trap.

Did I fail to seal the intake tracts properly when I re-assembled this
motor, or is there something else going on here?

Any help appreciated. I would like to fix this to avoid any CA smog hassles
come smog-check time.


 


 ________________________________________
|  Andrew E. Kalman     aek@netcom.com   |
|       standard disclaimers apply       |
 ________________________________________

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 17:37:56 -0500 (EST)

Greetings Porsche Dwellers,
	I stopped by VWs ETC recently, who's owner that bought my 
912E and proceeded to total it :^( .  He has a stripped out dirt brown '77 
911S (like T*d's...AAAAHHHH!!!) with straight front end that he plans to 
"clip in" eventually.  I  REALLY regret selling this vehicle, and I hope 
you folks can forgive me, my finances were hellish but the car deserved 
better...
	Anyway he has a bunch of basket case 914s lying around, the most 
interesting is one that I thought was a 914/6.  It has fender flares 
which are fiberglass and had an opposed six in it.  I asked about it and 
it turns out someone had slapped a CORVAIR engine in it!!!???  Is this 
conversion common and/or fast?  The car is rusted to death but you can 
tell someone once spent a lot of money on it, like leather upholstery, 
WIDE minilite style wheels, wild looking suspension, etc.  The shop owner 
doesn't know its history, he bought it with the shop some eight years 
ago.  He thinks it might be an original 914/6 because of its early build 
date (11/69) and its uplevel interior and tougher looking suspension.  
His question and mine...how do you tell a 914/4 from a 914/6?  Are the 
VIN #s different?  Suspensions?  Any info would be helpful.

Here's to Tom Cruise, awesome 928's, and beautiful women! 

Jay Karolyi

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 95 15:09:00 PST
From: "Lai, Hubert" <hl@msmail.orsil.ubc.ca>
Subject: 944 Noisy Half-Shaft?


My 1983 944 has recently developed an unusual noise that I find quite 
disconcerting.  It is a pronounced "clicking" that varies with speed.  It is 
coming from the rear of the car.  This is *not* the same "whining" sound 
that I heard when my wheel bearings needed replacement.

At first, I thought that there was a nail in my right rear tire.  The noise 
sure sounded like that.  However, I pulled the wheels off the car and 
inspected them.  Nothing in the tires.

I then thought that maybe the brake shroud or something had been bent and 
was contacting the wheel as it rotated.  Both rear brake shrouds appeared to 
be clear of the wheels though.  For good measure, I bent them so that they 
were perfectly aligned.  No change in noise.  I inspected the wheels and 
wheel wells closely to see if *anything* could be hitting the rear hubs or 
wheels.  I could see nothing.

I am now mystified as to what is causing the noise.  It is intermittent, 
which has foiled my attempts to crawl around the back of the car to really 
localize it when I hear it.  Regrettably, I usually drive alone, which adds 
to the difficulty.  However, the noise is not so intermittent that I can't 
hear it at least once or twice a day.

One thing I have noticed is that the noise only seems to occur when I am 
accelerating.  The noise seems to be more pronounced when I accelerate 
around a curve, though it doesn't seem to matter which way the curve goes 
and I can still get the noise when travelling in a straight line.

The noise is not dependent on which gear I am in.  I have managed to produce 
it in both 2nd gear and 3rd gear.  (I have an automatic transmission -- no 
flames, please.)

The car seems to be functioning fine, but for this very worrisome and 
noticeable noise.  I have exhausted my store of ideas.  Does anyone have any 
idea what this could be?  I hate to bring it to my mechanic when I have no 
guarantee of even being able to reproduce the noise for him.  Thanks muchly 
in advance...

Hubert Lai
hl@orsil.ubc.ca
1983 944 (Gemini Metallic)

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 95 18:29:23 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Noisy Half-Shaft?

> 
> My 1983 944 has recently developed an unusual noise that I find quite 
> disconcerting.  It is a pronounced "clicking" that varies with speed.  It is 
> coming from the rear of the car.  This is *not* the same "whining" sound 
> that I heard when my wheel bearings needed replacement.

Hi, Hubert,

I would guess that one of your CV joints is starting to show it age of 12
years and has gotten a bit sloppy.  What you hear is one of the ball
bearings slopping around in there...

If you haven't done it recently, now would be a good time to disassemble
each of the CV joints, clean them and re-lube with a good molybdenum grease.

That's probably the problem...

Good luck,

- --

George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 19:05:38 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 Noisy CV Joint 

Herbert writes...

<My 1983 944 has recently developed an unusual noise that I find quite 
disconcerting.  It is a pronounced "clicking" that varies with speed.  It is 
coming from the rear of the car.  This is *not* the same "whining" sound 
that I heard when my wheel bearings needed replacement.>

You almost certainly have a bad CV joint. This is not a major problem and can
be fixed by the average home mechanic. Look for some deals on parts. It is
usually easier and sometimes cheaper to replace the whole axle with both
joints in place. A loud clicking under acceleration is a dead giveaway.
Sometimes they click because they have been run dry and they can be re packed
with grease although it has been my experience that once they are audible
they are shot.
Many times they are dry because the boot is cracked. It is not worth
replacing the boot is the joint has been run while dry. A new CV joint is
under $100 and that includes the boot.
I have an axle with a good joint in place if you need it. Price would be $50
without shipping

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
6:58 pm

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 19:37:51 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: Re; Ignition wires

Hartje;

          Why in the world are you replacing all the ignition wires on you
944, this isn't a chevy or honda, as with all German cars there are 3 pieces
to each wire (2 ends and a solid core wire) which never go bad in all 4
cylinders.  If you have a problem in one cylinder just ohm the wire, find the
bad end or cable and replace just the defective one.  Experience has shown,
that short of abuse to the wires they last a very long time.

                        Steve

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 95 11:22:37 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: Turn signal prolem resolution

Hi,
Thanks to everyone who helped me solve the turn signal problem. 
It seems that quite a few Porschephiles are experiencing similar
symptoms, so here is a summary of what I learned.

If everything is working properly, only one of the turn signal
indicators on the dash board should blink, i.e. only the left
arrow for a left turn signal etc. When both arrows blink, this is
not a bug, but a safety feature which was specifically put in place
to alert the driver that the turn signals aren't drawing the 
expected amount of current. 

It seems that the turn signal housings and lenses aren't sealed all
that great, and the metal reflector / bulb sockets easily get
corroded. If there isn't a more obvious problem like a bulb being
totally out, you should take out all four bulbs (or 6 in the case of
euro cars) and clean the contacts. But more likely you will find that
the ground wire is to blame. On my car, it connects directly to the
metal of the reflector, without a good copper contact.

If you bought your car used, you may also find that the previous
owner did not replace bulbs with the required wattage. In my case
('82 930) I need 21W bulbs. Curiously, stores like Auto Palace with
a large selection of bulbs only list the application for a bulb 
(e.g. turn signal, parking light) and its socket code (something like
1073), but nowhere on the package or the bulb itself does it mention
how many watts it is supposed to have. So you have to look up the
codes, and in my case the code 1073 is indeed a 12V 21W bulb with 
regular big socket.

The turn signal flasher relay is usually not the culprit. In fact if
it is working as described it is working properly, and you should
really double-check the bulbs and the contacts (especially the ground
wire) before you order a new relay. 

I say usually, because in my case it actually was the problem. When
reading the maintenance records of my car, I found that the workshop 
had previously replaced the relay with a used one at no charge. So I
checked it out, and found that it was made by Hella, but wasn't the
right type that is supposed to be there. The "safety feature" I 
described above requires a 4-prong relay. The unit I found in my car
was missing the connector labelled "c", which is exactly the one that
makes the safety feature work. When I got the correct relay (at a 
cost of $36.95) my turn signal indicators finally started indicating!

Boy, that was a lot of work just to make sure that the correct
arrow lights up. But I guess having the "safety feature" now enabled
makes it worthwhile.  

Ray
Euro '82 930	(which I am getting to know better by the minute)
'92 Harley	(hybernating)
2 Toyotas	(soaking up road salt)

//-----------------------------------------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 21:04:25 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: OEM Undercoating - early Pcars

Mark Hatch, et al:

I was told, some 20 years ago, that Porsche was using a 3M Product called
BODY SHUTZ.  I've used it myself a bunch of times on my old Pcars with lots
of success.  It stays resillient, but dries to a non-tacky state in about an
hour.  It is paintable when cured, though not necessary in most cases.

I've used it for my '73 T's fender wells and bellypan in an unpainted state -
it does not pick up and hold stones, and is easy to clean (if you're into
that!)

I've also used it on my concours '72 914.  The fender wells have been sprayed
over with factory color, with a perfect look.  I've alos redone my rocker
panels with it, and left them unpainted.  I was careful, and got a perfect
match to the original finish, and its very easy to maintain - you just wash
it.  Takes hits from stones with no chipping.

The product comes in either aerosol cans, or liquid.  If you plan to spray
the liquid on, you'll need a special air gun, available from 3M very
inexpensively (I got mine from them for $15 - 20 years ago).

I still am unsure as to whether this stuff was "really" the factory applied co
mpound, but do know that 3M products were in heavy use by Porsche during that
era.

I'm cetain that I have just opened a can of worms here, and that others will
remember differently.  Flame On!

Pat Garvey

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 20 Feb 1995 21:23:33 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Need Help in Lowering 911SC.

Subj:	Need Help in Lowering 911SC.
Date:	95-02-19 21:46:37 EST
From: NPIBob@aol.com
To: Porschephiles@tta.com

I have been told that lowering the front suspension on a 911SC is rather
easily done.

Does anyone have a set of step-by-step instructions on how this can be done ?

Thanks in advance.

Bob Dubay 
NPIBob@aol.com
1980SC Triple Black
1978SC Petrol Blue
============================================

Bob:

     You didn't say how much you wanted to lower it, and wether or not you
were going to lower the rear as well.  The front can easily be lowered by
turning the 10mm adjusting screws found at the rear of each front torsion bar
tube. I believe that 1 turn lowers the car between 1/4 - 1/2 of an inch.
 Make sure that you do each side the same amount.  If you run out of travel,
you will have to turn the entire adjuster.  Let me know.  That is the good
news.  The bad news is that it will change your toe setting and you will have
to get the car re-aligned.  Also, if you lower the front more than 1 inch,
you will need to get a bump steer spacer kit to raise the steering rack.
 This will negate the increased bump steer that will result form the
lowering.

     The rear is another story.  It involves removing and turning the rear
torsion bars with respect to the spring plates, and weight balancing and
completely re-aligning the car.  That is best left to a professional shop. 

Larry Herman
HermanHome@aol.com
84 911 Carrera-Club Racer

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 00:22:28 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: Porsche Undercoating

The question was raised as to matching Porsche OEM undercoating:

The match for that "pebble finish" super tough coating is Wurth SKS Stonegard
or "body schutz".  This is a water based elastomer compound that may be applie
d with either the Wurth Schutz Gun or "dappled" onto the surface with a
brush.  The easiest way to match the OEM finish is to use the gun, but with
patience and little artistic flair, you can achieve excellent results with a
small stiff brush and a larger soft brush.  The brush technique involves
"spattering" the honey like consistancy SKS with the stiff brush.  Dip the
brush into the liquid and fan the bristles with your finger to fling it onto
the surface.  Then using the end stiff bristles, dab it to the proper "bumpy
texture" using up and down strokes.  The up stroke will tend to create (pull)
bumps and the down will meld the bumps together.  When it has been dappled to
your satisfaction, dip the softer brush in water and smooth out any rough
areas and match the OEM texture.  This is somewhat of an artistic adventure,
so developing your technique on on your Yugo may be prudent.

Correct application involves thoroughly cleaning the area to covered with a
quality degreaser  or pre-paint cleaner to remove all loose rust,
undercoating, wax, dirt and grease.  The surface must be completely dry.  Appl
y the SKS and allow the dry.  It changes color as it dries and may be painted
in 4-5 hours (but 24 is better).  When dry, clean again with a pre-paint
cleaner, apply primer and then paint. It does not have to be painted if you
so choose.  Available colors are beige, black or gray.  The finished product
will be a super tough, flexible protective coating that helps prevent rust
and is very chip resistant.  The water base allows easy clean up, until it
dries.  Once is has dried, about the only way to remove it it to blast it
off. It seems to be impervious to almost anything.  So, clean off any "slops"
before they set. 

The directions warn against freezing.  Heed this warning.  Do not allow the
bottle to get below 32.  You will have a big rubber baseball floating inside
the bottle.  This is experience talking!  Anyone want two cases of baseballs
in bottles?

Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specialties, Inc.
Distributors of Porsche Care Products
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 01:38:40 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: 944 Noisy Half-Shaft?

If the wear on the joints is not excessive you can extend the life of them by
swapping them over. But you have to be very careful to get the swap right. 

To do it, you move them over left side to right side and right side to left
side WITHOUT turning them end for end ie: The inbord end of the left shaft
becomes the outboard end of the right shaft.

By doing this, the loading on the bearing surfaces in the races is reversed,
(the ones that were torquing clockwise are now torquing anti-clockwise) and
the loading will be on an, as yet, unused area.
  

------------------------------

Date: 21 Feb 95 00:23:06 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porschephiles #1183 Mon Feb 20 15:40:55

OEM Undercoating
 
Mark Hatch asked about the OEM PVC undercoating. Wuerth (Wu:rth to be
correct, with umlauts, or just plain Wurth to the unwashed) sells several
different products that will probably work just fine. Their SKS Stoneguard
is a latex-based product that goes on to look like the stuff you describe,
and there are also some other products. Wu"rth is hard to find, they
normally sell only to garages, not paint and body supply stores. Get 800
directory assistance, find their 800 number, call there, find who is their
jobber in your area.
 
Stoddard also sells Wu"rth products.
 
Pete

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 08:42:10 -0500
From: Bob356@aol.com
Subject: Re: Air Compressors

Pat Garvey says, "I'm finally at the point where I would really benefit me
with this Porsche thing to purchase a decent air compressor.  Given the
parameters below, what are the groups views/plugs/hates with specific brands
and models...."

Pat, before buying a compressor, you need to know *almost* specifically where
you will be using it and for what: in the garage, at the track, for impact
tools, spray guns, or just filling your tires?  The demands of each of these
vary (measured in cubic feet per minute, and pressure), and your satisfaction
will depend upon the proper choice.

Having said that, my choice is the Emglo model AM78-HC4V compressor.  It is a
compact, electric 1.5 hp unit with two tanks, delivering 4.1 cfm at 100 psi,
and regulated to operate at 80-125 psi.  It sells at discount for about $310,
complete with gages and regulator.  Emglo makes compressors in a variety of
styles and outputs, ranging from 0.75 hp ($300) to 5 hp ($770) to 8 hp
($1200) to 11 hp ($2000).

Budget some additional money for hoses (I have found two 50-ft lengths of
hose about right, but YMMV), fittings, and tools.

Emglo is a brand commonly used by contractors, and that's what first
attracted me to it.  It's very well-made, and most of the discount-house
brands pale in comparison.  Folks who use these things to make their living
also say to shy away from oil-less compressors.

Where to buy?  Look up one of the woodworking magazines (like Fine
Woodworking or Fine Homebuilding) and check out the ads.  Great discounts are
available on all brands, and shipping is usually free.  Yes, FREE.

Good luck.

Bob Joyce
1965 356SC
1988 924S
1992 Isuzu Trooper




------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 09:07:42 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Engine Rebuild for 914/6, to 2.2E


Dear Dan,

If you only plan on reving your engine to 6,500 RPM, you will never have a
problem. You won't even have a problem with 7,500 RPM. If you balance
everything before you reassemble it.

"E" pistons and cams will make a great engine for your 914-6. If you are
going to all the troube to build your engine, it will be well worth balancing
the rotating assembly, i.e. crank, rods, flywheel pistons and pressure plate
and you will have no reason to fear 7,500 RPM! To have this work done, I
would recommend Competition Engineering. Their phone number is 619-379-3879.
Tell them I sent you and they can help you with anything you need.

Sean

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 09:07:54 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 status


Dear Stephen and Alan,

All 914 impellors (fans) were interchangeable and all replacements are marked
ony with a 0. To check 0 and timing marks simply remove the impellor and
measure it moving to the passenger side from 0 (TDC).

The 1.8 mark 7.5 degrees BTDC is 14.6mm from 0.
The 1.7, 2.0 mark 27 degrees BTDC is 52.5mm from 0.

You can measure any mark you have to determine the other.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 09:08:06 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Fuel Line Recall Program ?


Dear Craig,

<I was just flipping throught the pages of my Automotion catalog and came
across 
a Tech Tip indicating a fuel line recall program for 914s still being active.
 
I'm not sure if the fuel lines in my car have been upgraded, but does any one

know for sure if this program is still on going ?  I'm very sure many of us
914 
owners would like an answer on this one.>



Automotion catalog? They have a tech tip about 914 fuel line recall? What
page?

The fuel line recall (HO campaign) for 914 vehicles has long ago expired - 20
years was the limit. It consisted of the following operation.
     1. Replace cloth braided injector elbows with the heavy duty rubber
covered type. Install appropriate smoothe hose clamps.
     2. Replace upper cloth braided fuel lines with the heavy duty rubber
covered type.
     3. Replace large and small injector seals.
     4. Clean batter tray and battery area.
     5. Install newer style larger batter cover on battery and secure with
holding band.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 09:08:25 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Switch 1.8 fi to 2.0 engine?


<I have a 1.8 that runs great with F.I.
Everyone says that the 2.0 is better with F.I. and I have webbers on the 2.0,
Can I switch the 1.8 fuel injection to the 2.0?> 

<Or should I just sell my 1974 1.8 with a recent re-build in excellent
running
condition?>

Dear Rich,

You can certainly install 1.8 fuel injection on a 2.0 engine, just use the
2.0 intake runners. Since the 912E was manufactured with a 914 2.0 engine
with AFC 1.8 fuel injection, we know the factory approved the application. A
trick we have done in the past is to use the 1.8 system but install the 912E
control unit, airflow meter and injectors.

The AFC system is basically what all modern Porsches use and is superior to
the old D-Jetronic/MPC system. Although we always advocate keeping the 914 as
stock as possible, if you do not have a 2.0 injection system to install, the
1.8 system is the next best thing and far better than carburation.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 09:08:32 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Horn Help?


<At some point, a previous owner had installed an aftermarket steering wheel
on my 914.  It was
later replaced with the original.  Unfortunately, I am missing some pieces
inside the steering
wheel for the horn contact.  If I remove the center section of the steering
wheel, I see a hole at
the edge of the center hub that has the horn wire in it.  The wire is cut off
flush with the hub.  There
is a stamped steel ring attached to the hub to which the center section
clips.  This ring has a
hole in it which is aligned with the hole in the hub where the cut wire is.
 Something is apparently
supposed to go in this hole and attach to the horn wire in order for the horn
to work.
Does anyone know what piece(s) am I missing?>


Dear Pete,

Your 1975 914 does not use the hole in the steering wheel. '70-'71 model 914s
used the hole for a horn contact stalk, but this was superceded in 1972 to a
wire which clipped to the back of the horn butterfly via a contact plate.
This plate had a built-in male clip which easily broke. We repair this piece
with a special rivit and clip as the part is not available without the
purchase of the complete hub/butterfly assembly.

So, to repair your assembly, extend the wire by passing the hole and install
a female clip. Clip this to the butterfly contact plate, make sure the horn
boot is firmly planted in the middle of the plate and gently clip the
butterfly to the steering wheel turning it clockwise. (We always install it
with the ignition switch turned to "on" in case we accidently pinch and
ground the horn contact wire.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 07:15:45 -0700
From: "    John Jones" <J.Jones@az05.bull.com>
Subject: Re: Porschephiles #1179 Sat Feb 18 01:21:59 CST 1995

I think you are aware but just in case I got this digest 4 times.

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 09:17:36 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: 914 Speedo Cable Failures


Dear Stan:

You wrote:
<Fellow PCA member with 74 914 has had the speedo cable break about 1 to 2
inches inside the cable housing just forward of the angle drive.  This is the
third occurance, at the same place.  Previous fixes included:  new angle
drive unit, 2 new speedo cable units plus the original (to him-had the car 6
months), and he had speedo completely rebuilt.  All done by a repair shop, so
he tells me.  Claims there are no binding turns in the cable.  First and
subsequent failures gave no warning, no noise, no needle wobble, etc.>  

<I have replaced the entire assembly from angle drive to the speedo on my 73
914 and had the speedo head rebuilt, but have not seen or heard of repeat
failures after replacing all that.  Any thoughts?>



914 speedometer cables fail most often from engine heat melting the
protective cover. The other possibility is the speedometer head locking and
shapping the cable at the head. Other than those failures the cables last a
long time.

Common speedometer related failures are as folows:
     1. Rear angle drive
     2. Rear housing expansion bolt loosening and stacked drive gear failure
     3. Cable breaking or melting (a melted cble can make the speedometer
needle bounce.)
     4. Cable not routed smoothly (the speedometer needle will bounce or the
cable will snap prematurely)
     5. Speedometer head failure (usually the odometer stops turning first)

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 09:17:29 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Alloy wheel paint was Re: 914 lube points? (long - sorry)


Dear Nate,

 <Thank you very much for the detailed and helpful response!  Do you
have a part number or description of the Wurth wheel paint you mentioned
(Pedrinni alloys)?  Or is this just a standard stuff that was used on
all similar wheels at the time?  If I'm gonna do it, I may as well do it
right (esp. after your comments about the rarity of these wheels!)>


The Wurth wheel paint (metallic silver) is fairly expensive (about $14.00 for
13.5 ounces), but is the perfect color. It is made in Germany and says it is
abrasion resistant. If you cannot find it, we can sell it to you.

Secondly, a factory 914 oil temp gauge was available in four varieties.:
     1. 914-6 combination gas gauge oil temp gauge, orange and red temp scale
silver center button
     2. Early '74 914 gas gauge/oil temp gauge black and white scale silver
center dial
     3. Late '74-'76 914 gas gauge/oil temp gauge black and white scale black
center button
    4. Small '73-'76 appearance group center console temp gauge '73-'74
scale:  larger red area '75-'76 scale:  smaller red area

All of the gauges with the exception of the 914-6 were optional. '73-'76
models were prewired from the engine bay main harness in front of the battery
to the center tunnel next to the shifter. Installing any of these gauges in
your 914 is easy with the appropriate send unit and plate in the bottom of
the engine block.

George Hussey

Date: 21 Feb 95 06:27:54 PST
From: "Jessen, Scott -" <SJJE@chevron.com>
Subject: Are 7s&8s legal in SCCA stock?


From: Jessen, Scott - SJJE
To:  OPEN ADDRESSING SERVI-OPENADDR
Subject:  Are 7s&8s legal in SCCA stock?
Date: 1995-02-21 08:21
Priority:

- ------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Chris Bennet asks:

>I know you guys hate answering these questions but
>on the off chance you already researched this I'll
>ask anyway:

No we don't hate answering these, heck that's what we're here for (to ask
and answer each other's questions -- and make fun of T*d, tell stories,
etc., etc.)

>My 911 has the 6? & 7 inch 16" Fuchs.  Mostly for appearance
>reasons I'm considering getting a couple of 8" wheels i.e.
>I'd have 7" on front, 8" onback, plus two cool hose reels <g>.
>[I'd probably be sticking with the 205/225 widths.]
>Q: Is this enough to bump me out of SCCA Solo II stock class or
>   was this a somewhat obscure option for the '86 Carrera ?

Although the *optional* 6&7 x16" alloys are the more popular wheel for the
Carreras (seems like they almost all came with them), the 15x7 & 8 were a
standard size and you would have no problems in SCCA stock class running
them.  This is, of course, as long as we're talking either factory wheels or
aftermarket wheels within .25" of factory offset *AND* as long as it's the
15" wheels and not 16 x 7&8s]]  Any width tire may be used in SCCA stock.
 You will also benefit from a reduction in overall diameter with the 15"
combo (versus your 16s) so the car will feel a little quicker and more
responsive -- 'course your speedo will read high....

I would suggest 225/50/15 on front and rear (versus the 205 you were
planning to use on front).  Oh, and of course if you are planning on running
a soft compound tire, run the BFG R1 -- set your pressures for AX around 26
psi rear and 20 psi front (hot), go at least 5 psi higher for the street.

I'd keep the 16s and run street tires on them -- you can swap them out
before and after events....

 -Scott Jessen
sjje@chevron.com
ASP 911

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 09:50:52 -0500 (EST)
From: Ujjal Bansel <ujj@server.chem.ufl.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 Noisy Half-Shaft?



On Mon, 20 Feb 1995, George Beuselinck wrote:
> > 
> > My 1983 944 has recently developed an unusual noise that I find quite 
> > disconcerting.  It is a pronounced "clicking" that varies with speed.  It is 
> > coming from the rear of the car.  This is *not* the same "whining" sound 
> > that I heard when my wheel bearings needed replacement.
> 
> Hi, Hubert,
> 
> I would guess that one of your CV joints is starting to show it age of 12
> years and has gotten a bit sloppy.  What you hear is one of the ball
> bearings slopping around in there...
> 
> If you haven't done it recently, now would be a good time to disassemble
> each of the CV joints, clean them and re-lube with a good molybdenum grease.
> 
> That's probably the problem...
> 
> Good luck,
> 
> --
> 
> George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
> 944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
> 1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593
> 


Hi, 

I had this same problem. If you decide to relube those CV joints (which 
isn't a hard job), you might want to consider switching the right half 
shaft assembly with the left on and vice versa. I did this on my 85 944 
and the clicking went away. Do this only if the CV's are symmetrical. 
I found out that one of my sleeves that held the bearings were worn. By 
switching the whole shaft, the bearing no longer puts force on the worn 
part of the sleeve when I accelerate (unless I go in reverse). It's like 
I have a brand new CV joint:)  Hope this helps.

Ujjal Bansel

'85 944
(167k miles and no more clicks)

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 95 08:55:33 CST
From: wchutt@alex.monsanto.com (Bill C Hutton)
Subject: Re: .Battery mats in older 911s

Bill wrote:

- -----------------------------------------------
"My question is:  Has anybody install these Battery Mats in their
earlier vintage 911?  An I wasting my time when there is a better
alternative?  Is one approach is to move to a single, nonvented
battery, setup secured outside of the battery boxes?"
- -------------------------------------------------

Why not just take good care of your battery trays (and batteries) and
leave things like they are? 

A 30 minute treatment every 6 months will keep them in good shape for a
long time. If it ain't broke don't fix it. My battery trays/front pan
are also in excellent condition. I plan to keep this area well
maintained and make sure the batteries are not defective or over
charged.


**********************************************************************
W.C. Hutton, Monsanto Company, Corporate Research

wchutt@monsanto.com, 314 537 6021  1971 911E coupe

This message does not necessarily reflect the views of Monsanto Company
or, now that I think of it, anyone else.

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 9:34:52 -0600 (CST)
From: Ross Stites <STITES@cacdvax.cacd.rockwell.com>
Subject: Re: 944 Ignition Wires


>Hartje;
>
>          Why in the world are you replacing all the ignition wires on you
>944, this isn't a chevy or honda, as with all German cars there are 3 pieces
>to each wire (2 ends and a solid core wire) which never go bad in all 4
>cylinders.  If you have a problem in one cylinder just ohm the wire, find the
>bad end or cable and replace just the defective one.  Experience has shown,
>that short of abuse to the wires they last a very long time.
>
>                        Steve

Steve,

I'm having to replace all of my wires because the heat off my engine
has baked the insulation around the wires.  Now they put on a very 
pretty light show when the engine is running:)  My wires have not
been abused or mistreated.  They've just deteriated due to normal 
wear and tear.

Ross
'87 951

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 13:47:24 -0500
From: "John C. C. White" <jccw@ilab.mitre.org>
Subject: Re:  Re[2]: K&N Air Filter: Does it affect brake booster (long)

Good answer! Upon reflection, it is pretty clear that the supercharger
shouldn't be in a state to provide greater than atmospheric pressure
at the same time the brake booster wants vacuum.

On the other hand, I'm old enough to remember vacuum-powered windshield
wipers; try THOSE on your supercharged machine!
>>
>>     John,
>>     
>>     Here is the answer to your "manifold vacuum on supercharged and 
>>     turbocharged engines" question.  This is a two part answer.
>>     
>>     1.  Cars with superchargers and turbochargers still have manifold 
>>     vacuum!  From idle up to part throttle (light load) the manifold 
>>     pressure is still lower than atmospheric pressure.  In other words 
>>     there is still a vacuum signal.  As RPM and engine load increase, the 
>>     manifold pressure increases beyond atmospheric pressure.  If you don't 
>>     believe this, take a drive in someone's car who has a Manifold 
>>     Absolute Pressure (MAP) gauge.
>>     
>>     2.  All power brake systems utilize a check ball to prevent vacuum 
>>     leakage during low manifold vacuum conditions (full throttle or engine 
>>     off).  The system is designed to allow 2 or 3 vacuum assisted 
>>     depressions of the brake peddle after the engine has been turned off.
>>     
>>     Put these two items together and you can see how a power brake system 
>>     will continue to operate in a turbocharged or supercharged 
>>     environment.
>>     
>>     Feel free to post this if you think folks would like to read it.
>>     
>>     Bill Elwell
>>     
>>______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
>>Subject: RE: K&N Air Filter: Does it affect brake booster (long)
>>Author:  "John C. C. White" <jccw@babypuss.mitre.org> at INTERNET
>>Date:    2/9/95 3:05 PM
>>     
>>OK, but what if the engine is supercharged? Seems like the only vacuum 
>>to be found then is the ported vacuum, which must be pretty weak.
>>     
>>-John White-
>>'84 928S (non-supercharged)
>>     
>>     
>>
 -John White-


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1187                         Tue Feb 21 17:37:06 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 13:53:47 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: Jacking/raising a 944

I had the old sheet metal kind. two cylinders, one fits inside the other,
with a pin to adjust the height, and four legs for balance. The top had a
flat plate welded on with turned up "ears". I sawed off the ears leaving
the plate on the end and put the biggest socket head bolt on which still
fit inside the jack point doughnuts. the result looks like the commercial
plate that I bought.

I haven't seen the sheet metal stands available recently. they all appear
to be cast.

ok?

doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories
86 951
85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 13:54:15 -0500
From: CarcareSp@aol.com
Subject: 944 vs 928 Oil Filter

Does anyone know the internal specifications of the 928 Oil Filter PNA#
928-107-201-05 vs the 944 Oil Filter PNA# 944-107-201-90?  The 928 filter has
the same OD and ID gasket, the same inlet ID/ thread, a longer can (I assume
additional filtration area) and a different pattern of oil return openings.
Is the internal relief valve setting the same?  What are the differences in
flow characteristics? 
Are there any hidden negatives?

I am thinking of substituting the 928 filter on my track 86 944 Turbo.  

Reason 1:  The longer can will make installation/removal easier.  

Reason 2:  The increased filtration (this is an assumption)  is not a bad
thing, especially for an engine run at red line a significant percentage of
it's life.

I appreciate any assistance and/or other options in this area.

Larry Reynolds
Car Care Specailties, Inc.
Distributors of Quality Porsche Care Products
Phone (201) 796-8300
Fax (201) 791-9743
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 95 14:06 EST
From: "Barton P. Chambers"  <bartonc@mailhost.annap.infi.net>
Subject: ALL HANDS - Open question to EFR members

John  writes: 
> Gentlemen: 
 
> Somewhere along the path from $15 to helpout Stan to $100 for patron-class 
> membership I have lost the thread. 

> It seems like the type A personality types have taken over ('I can pledge 
> more than you can...').  I have no problem with $15 to keep things going but 
> when the ante gets up to the $50 to $100 area I would like to have more 
> specific information on who made the decision and on what basis.  This is 
> especially so if this is to be a region based upon member participation in 
> the decision- making processes.

Hi John, and New members of the Group (who are wondering what all this talk of
money for a free list is all about...)

Your points are good, and are taken in the constructive manner offered.

In the meantime, re Type-A personalities.  Hey!  watch yo' mouth!  I
resemble that remark!  (whack)  (thank you, I needed that.)  What I meant
to say; and what I have said all along; and what *Stan* has said, is:

*Nobody* has to contribute anything.  We are trying to acquire the funds
to build the infastructure to ensure the survival of Porschephiles
independent of any member.  It's not a type-a personality thing at all.
Folks who have pledged $100 are those who have recognized the high
capital cost of accomplishing this, and who have the means to contribute
more.

I don't have firm figures for the costs, and that doesn't bother me a
bit. I do know that Stan has made the service available to the group,
using the capital resources that he depends upon to earn his daily bread,
and is begining to feel the strain.

Why?  Well, Porschephiles has steadily grown to a membership of *OVER*
1200 members, generating traffic of more than 68,000 messages per month.
This volume of traffic is eating a significant chunk of Stan's T-1
service.  Not to put too fine a point of this, this eats into Stan's
livelihood, and, amigos, that ain't right.  We owe Stan an inestimable
debt of gratitude.  The very least we can do to show it is to take as
much of the capital burden upon ourselves as possible.

So where do the suggested contribution numbers come from?  Can you say "Rectal 
Data?"  It is my sense that a Student should be able to afford $15.  If a 
poor starving Stoont can cough up $15, it isn't far out of line for a Working 
person, who can afford both a love of Porsches and access to the 'net, to be 
able to pony up $50.  If you want to do more, then $100 seemed like a nice, 
tidy round number.

I don't think it's anal-retentive to recognize those who dig deeper.  I
have assured all that no one's name or contribution level will be
published *unless* they instruct me to do so.  NOBODY *HAS* TO CONTRIBUTE
ANYTHING!

I also know (I've been investigating the costs of becoming a Service
provider on the 'net, and) it's not cheap.  Last week's InfoWorld has a
comparison of two ppackage servers, one from BBN, and the other a Sun
Netra.  We're looking at $7-10K just for the box and software.  I don't
believe that Mailing list Software was in those figures, but I do know
that they do *not* include T-1 service.  As we determine what the blivid
(5 lbs in a 3 lb bag) of stuff totals out to be, you will be advised.

But this is *not* some anal-retentive thing working here (well, that's my
story and I'm stickin' with it...), but an attempt to offer *guidance*
that has been requested.  Frequently.

So what If you don't send anything?  You're *still* a Porschephile, with
all the privilidges and rights pertaining thereto.  As long as the
service survives...

If you want to ensure the survival of this organization, and I sure as
hell do, then send what you can.  Many folks have asked what would be
appropriate to send, and I've tried to offer guidelines.

So What do you get out of this?  How about a nice shiny *Number*,
reflecting the order in which I receive your check?  How about
*Satisfaction* that you've been part of one of the *great* happenings on
the 'net?

Finally, the "membership" issue.  Within 30 days from last Friday, we must
apply to the IRS for Non-Profit Organization status.  (tick...tick...tick)
I'm the guy in the barrel here.  We need to decide what kind of an orgainztion
we will be.  Here, again, you can be a PORSCHEPHILE and not join any more
organizations.  Many of us would like to be the Electronic Frontier Region
of PCA, but this is not universal.  Most of the Non-US folks are not interested
in affiliating with PCA, and that's no problem either.

Everyone *Can* send a donation; *NOBODY* has to!  Everybody can Join (whatever
orgainzation we decide); aganin, *NOBODY* has to...there is enough interest in
the EFR business that we *can* go that route if required to keep my butt out
of the [deleted] grasp of the IRS.  

Finally, for you good souls who want to contribute:  The bank folks would rather
that you send the checks to me, made out to

  for deposit to "Porschephiles" Acct #3933150532

My address is:

Custodian "Porschephiles"
c/o Bart Chambers
1270 Lavall Drive
Davidsonville, MD  21035
(410) 721-2989

If you wish to call me, please do so prior 8:30 PM EST.

***Please send me an Email with your address, ck number and amt.*** 
This will be private unless you wish to send it to 'philes yourself:

We are grateful any and all donations.

Cheers

Bart Chambers
Custodian, Porschephiles
Wife, Varmint, Porsche, etc.

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 14:29:46 -0500
From: Dr914@aol.com
Subject: Re: Rebuilt 914 High Idle Question


Dear Andrew,

You seemed to have solved your own problem! The '73-'74 2.0 PCV valve is bad.
The oil filler installed PCV should not pass crank case breath unless pushed
open by excessive crankcase pressure. Either you have tremendous blowby (not
likely) or a bad PCV valve. Simple replacement of the valve should solve your
problem.

George Hussey

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 95 11:04:56 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: Diff between SC and Carrera ?

| From: Bill Ataras  <Bill_Ataras@ccm.jf.intel.com>
|
|      Can someone explain ?

In early Porsches, Carrera denoted the top of the line model.
There was a 356 Carrera and from 73 to 76 or 77 there was a
911 Carrera as top of the line. In 78, all 911s were called SC,
for Super Carrera, and featured full galvanization of the body
and a 3.0 litre motor. In 84 the 911 was relabelled the Carrera
with the 3.2 litre motronic engine.

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 11:46:53 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: Safety, ABS, Air Bags etc.

Neil NW Walker at EVEN_2100B wrote:
: Now to start a flame session: who in their right mind would want
: either?  The safest restraint you can have is a FIXED length seat belt
: properly adjusted and WORN. 

Agreed!  More fools should wear seat belts, whether fixed or not.


: Air Bags are a totally unnecessary government imposition on those
: of us who take care and precautions, shades of Big Brother and over
: regulation. 

I disagree vehemently.  As a firefighter, I know at least two people
who owe their lives to airbags: one, driving a Volvo, left the roadway
and Teed a Jersey barrier at 65mph.  Walked away.  The other was in a
Honda Del Sol and was hit head-on by a Detroit Iron driver (who was
rear-ended himself).  Result: Unbelted driver of Detroit Iron killed,
belted passenger seriously injured.  Del Sol driver, belted behind
airbag, cut by glass on hands and walked away.

This is anecdotal, obviously.  But airbags have a place, and crash
statistics will bear out their save rates.  I've personally seen many
people injured severely, even while properly secured behind belts.
High speed collisions involve HUGE amounts of energy compared to our
little bodies' strength.  I saw a driver literally cut in half by his
shoulder belt, and others with nasty head and neck injuries, all
preventable in an airbag car.

*I* find it obnoxious that many new cars still don't have the bags
available (even optionally) on both front seats.  And I DESPISE those
automatic track belts that cause people to forget the lap belt (and
insult those of us who always belt up anyway).


: Unless racing you
: should never be in the position of having to be at the limit of
: braking. If you are, you have failed to read the road and or the
: situation, and are not driving in the defensive mode needed to be a
: good citizen

This is incredibly arrogant and unrealistic.  
Why have brakes at all?  If we all drove as well as you claim to, we'd
have time to downshift to avoid a collision every time!  Alas, I do
not live in the land of universally predictable drivers, slow animals,
and hazard-free roads.

It's a pretty simple engineering exercise to see that technological
advances like ABS and airbags save lives, and that the lives lost to
device failure is minicscule in comparison.  I'd be happy to have 'em.


 -mike  (scraped up one too many...)

------------------------------

Date: 21 Feb 1995 11:45:20 U
From: "John Lucas (GRC)" <John_Lucas_#l#GRC#r#@cpqm.saic.com>
Subject: Re: 84 928 speedo problem

 Reply to:     RE>>84 928 speedo problem

Peter, 

You wrote:
> I saw your message on Porschephiles about the pinted circuit foil on the
> back of the instrument cluster on the '84 928.  I'm having a problem with

... snip ...
> My speedo and odometer and tripmeter are all lifeless for the first 10
> minutes of almost every drive.  Most of the time, eventually they kick in.
> But sometimes they stay dead the whole drive and sometimes (rarely) they
> operate from beginning to end.  When it does start to move, the needle
> jumps erratically around from 0 to the current speed and back for a few
> minutes and eventually settles down.
>
> Does that sound familiar?


Your symptoms are almost identical to the ones I observed on my car.
I became convinced that something was loose somewhere because
I would jiggle the circuit connector that plugs into the foil on the bottom
of the instrument cluster while driving and often could revive the speedo 
for a short time. However, I was not able to find the real problem until
I dismantled the entire instrument cluster and began following the circuit
with an ohm meter.  Finding the loose rivet was simply a matter of luck!!!
(I happened to be looking at the meter just when I pressed on the rivet!)

First, an additional test you should perform:  Does your auto speed control
function properly, even when the speedo is dead?  Looking at the circuit
diagrams in the Porsche manual will show that the cruise control input 
comes from the speedo circuit (i.e., from the magnetic sensor on the tranny).
 
If the cruise control works and the speedo doesn't, you've isolated the 
problem to the speedo.  If the cruise control also doesn't work, your
problem may be in the sensor, the sensor wire, or the circuit connection
on the bottom of the instrument cluster. (I can't be positive if the wire 
from the sensor branches to the cruise control at the plug on the 
edge of the foil (I think it does) or if it branches closer to the speedo
connector).

There are two connectors on the bottom of the instrument cluster, one
to the left of the steering column and one to the right.  I don't remember
without looking at my manuals which connector has the speed sensor
wire and which pin it is, but I vaguely remember fumbling around with
the left one while driving on Pacific Coast Highway between Santa
Barbara and LA one day (while simultaneously cussing out the "genius"
who designed their electrical connectors -- you would think Porsche 
could do a better design than Nissan! *sigh*).  

If you do need to take the instrument cluster out, it is a very easy process
but you do need the Porsche manuals.  In order to test, you'll want the
circuit diagrams and then, to take the cluster out, you'll need to know
where the 4 bolts are and how to take the switches apart (must do before
removing the cluster).  Do you have the manuals?

A hint:  you have to remove the steering wheel; nowhere in the manual
do they tell you how to get the horn pad off.  If your steering wheel is
like mine, the horn pad (with the 928 stamped on it) PULLS off -- under-
neath are two springs which fit into two detents punched into the 
steering wheel frame.  Simple brute force is needed to pull the edges
of the springs out of the detent in which they are wedged.  The reverse
is also true -- when putting it back together, a solid hit with the side or
flat of your hand is required to seat it properly (otherwise the horn 
won't toot!).

A warning -- disconnect the battery before doing this project.  First, 
if you don't, your horn will go off the minute you start trying to take
the wheel off.  Second, you could fry something if you leave the 
battery connected and accidently touch live wires.  (not to mention
starting the car if you are really unlucky!).

Let me know how you're doing ...  I doubt if you're in the LA area,
but if you are, I'd be willing to help if you get stuck.

Good luck!

John
'84 928S

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 95 15:11:41 PST
From: pasha@hal.com (James Pasha)
Subject: 924/944 Factory Ignition Harnesses


In answer to a couple of posts, the following is characteristic of 924/944
factory ignition harnesses:

After about 5 years, the outer insulation material starts break down in the
wires. This will eventually lead to arcing and other detrimental ignition
behavior.

When this occurs, you have a few choices. You may buy new. You may replace
the one that is bad with a mickey-mouse solution (I have seen many). You may
repair the bad wire correctly.

To do the last, I usually do one wire at a time. I have found that most 
solid wire (actually stranded but copper wire rather than carbon core) will 
work. To repair, I UNSCREW the wire from each end. A factory wire has a
cup receptacle on each wire end that has a threaded end. I remove the old 
wire from the end by carefully cutting the copper wire out. I remove all 
material from the cup, then carefully drill a small hole into the base.
The hole drilling is a little tricky, but patience will reward you with
a small, clean hole. I then cut new wire to the same length as the old, 
stripping 1/4" of insulation from the wire. I insert the wire, then solder
the wire to the cup. If you use some discretion when soldering, you should 
have a clean joint with minimal solder. When both ends are done, put some 
dialectric lubricant on the wire and cup, then rethread and carefully 
tighten each end. Re-install the wire, go to the next. Just to be on the 
safe side, I scrounge extra wires for the ends, just in case I break one.

Total cost = $12 for Accel black copper core wire.

One other tip: pull the plastic cover off the coil. Remove the coil lead and inspect the coil connector for green corrosion. Clean the connector with 
electrical contact cleaner, scrubbing with a q-tip until the green grunge
is gone. Check all connections on the distributor cap for the same, then the 
spark plug ends. Resistance is about 5K ohms for the entire lead and end.

Jim Pasha

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 15:54:14 -0800
From: billv@macaw.retix.com (Bill Van Bibber's account)
Subject: Re: 928 parts needed

Bob Writes:

>Bill,
>
>        Sorry to hear that!  It just spontaneously broke in two?  I hope the 
>valves and pistons didn't hit!

>Bob

Hey Bob!!

Well,I'm not sure if it spontaneously broke in two; the fact is I had been 
working on that part of the engine the last month.  I took apart the front
part of the engine to get to all the seals in the engine that were leaking oil
and replaced alot of gaskets too!  I torqued everything correctly and
reinstalled all the loose pieces and fired it up.  I let it get warm and than
set the timing.  I stopped it and checked for leaks; NONE!!!  I was so happy!
This was on Saturday Afternoon.  I then drove it to my girlfriends house and
tinkered a little more and of course,l GLOATED that it no longer leaked oil!
I then drove it home and raced it around town.  Checked all the belts; A-ok.
I deemed it ready for its maiden voyage (this month) to Santa Monica and left 
early this morning at 1:30 AM.  I stopped and got food for me in Carlsbad but
did not turn off the car.  I poped the hood and heard a little slapping of
the timing belt.  I thought to myself, "The belt is finally starting to loosen
up.  I'll tighten it in Santa Monica."  With those words I was Doomed.  I drove
all the way to Long Beach when I felt a slight surging and I was loosing power,
and then, Silence.  I'm still coasting, so I de-clutch and change down, but
the engine isn't picking up.  I try the starter.  It turned, but didn't
catch either.  I coast to a stop at the Atlantic Ave Exit in Long Beach right
next to a call box, and even next to a guard rail and cement island
under a bridge (in case it rains).  I get out and pop the hood, thinking that
it is a loose belt that jumped it tracks, and , wrongly, thinking it'll take a 
couple o'minutes to fix.  Lo and behold, the belt is not loose, but correctly 
tensioned but the cam sprocket (left side) doesn't look right.  I take the bolt
out of the sproket and watch in awe as the sprocket falls into my hands.  I'm
still optimistic, for about .000001 x 10to the 9 second, thinking that it just
slipped it's Woodruff key.  And then I notice the little brass distributor
drive gear.  And I start laughing!  It's 3:30 AM on a tuesday morning, I'm in
Long Beach on I405 30 minutes from my apartment in Santa Monica or 1 1/2 hours
from my aprtment in San Diego and my "just fixed" car just took the dump of its
life and I'm laughing!  I pack up my tools and head to the call box to wake up
my Alfa friend Craig.  He comes over and we use his AAA card to call a tow
truck.  I tell the tow truck driver, "Take me to Santa Monica, please".  We 
load up, thank Craig and head North with me talking about racing and buring
928's to the ground and the tow truck driver picking my brain re: L-jetronic
FI on his 280Z.  What a night!  I don't know what happened.  The bolt didn't
loosen (until I took it off; it, of course, was already beginning to loosen
as the camshaft had sheared and was wearing against itself) and the belt wasn't
tight; certainly not tight enough to break a camshaft! (" Gee Rocky, Don't
know my own strength!")  and the engine wasn't revving over 2600 (75-ish mph)
all night.  It broke right at the last bearing support on the outside of the
head.  So, WHEN did it break?

Anyway, I need another camshaft that only has two ends and not 4.

later,
bill


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 16:40:36 -0800
From: Larry_Wilson@macnexus.org (Larry Wilson)
Subject: Porsche Burgers



Here's something of international interest.

Last night my wife and I had a hamburger at a Burger King located at the
Casa Grande off-ramp off Interstate 10 between Phoenix and Tucson. Inside
were large reproductions of about 10 factory Porsche posters, all with
glass, matted and framed, and signed and numbered 114 of 500 by "Steinger"
plus the 917 Poster by Dave Marek (former member of Sacramento Valley
Region, PCA and now big-time Principal Designer for Honda R&D in
Torrance).

Except for the Marek poster, all had the official Porsche name in extended
lettering at the bottom and said, "Printed in Germany." Several were 911 and
917 posters and one showed Dan Gurney in the flat-eight F-1 car.

When the lady behind the counter asked for my order I said, "all the
posters," but she said they weren't for sale. All were very securely
attached  to the wall.

Stop in for a burger if you're in the neighborhood.

Larry Wilson
larry_wilson@macnexus.org

Date: 21 Feb 95 20:41:37 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsches on TV

>In the the airport thriller on last night, the plane lands on a
>runway being used for autocrossing -- and one of the autoX cars is a
>nice bright yellow 356 Cabriolet.
 
I didn't watch the airport thriller, since I already know how it turned
out. This incident really happened, I don't know if they made that clear or
not. That includes the slalom on the abandoned (sort of) airfield. I was
working at Porsche when somebody brought in the Stuttgarter Zeitung or
whatever with a picture of this emergency-landed plane, with a 911 autocrossing
in front of it. If I remember right, the plane was Canadian (one of my
Canadian friends at Porsche would say "that explains it") and they put X
liters of fuel in instead of X gallons, or pounds, or some conversion-factor
problem like that.
 
Another reason to avoide Airbusii.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 21 Feb 95 20:41:35 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Air compressors

 
What kind to get -- the biggest damn compressor you can afford. The ultimate
would be a 2 stage 60 gallon job, big enough to run EVERYTHING. I have the
next best, a single stage 5 hp 60 gallon, which is plenty for most home shop
jobs. I can use a real spray gun with it too. Mine is a DeVilbiss, about
$400.
 
You rally need a 5 hp job for spraying and air grinders. Smaller compressors
will work for intermittent things like impact wrenches.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: 21 Feb 95 20:41:42 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Obstructing Justice

 
100,000 more cops on the street. Right. Does anybody with two gray cells
still wired together honestly believe that these are going to "reduce
crime"? F--k, no, they're going to be writing tickets while for the
dispatcher to send them to the occasional crime.
 
We don't have a problem catching criminals. We have a problem with the
lawyers, judges, and jails not being able to put these people away for the
specified amount of time when they ARE caught. So what are we supposed to do
if/when these 100,000 "peace officers" start bringing in more of same?
 
POLICE ARE TAX COLLECTORS. End of soapbox oratory.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 95 20:43 EST
From: Jay Ellis <0007142347@mcimail.com>
Subject: Re: Squeaky  944

>Does anyone know the cure for squeaky brakes on an 89 944? The brakes
>are virtually brand new. I get a vicious squeal when I just touch
>them. If I lean into them they don't squeak (sometimes).

This always happens to me when I put on Cool Carbons for the track. Do you
know what kind of brake pads you're using?  If they're new and you don't
want to replace them, you might want to try a set of anti-squeal backing
plates which stick to the back of the pads to reduce movement.  They're
available for about $20 from Vehicle Craft, Inc. at 201-366-7800.

Jay Ellis
7142347@mcimail.com
'87 951
'89 Feline Tigger
'92 Feline Grisabella

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 18:22:28 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)
Subject: Re: 1971 911T Questions

>Hi Gang:
>
>I'm new in the group...
>
Hi Eric, and welcome!
>
>I have a couple questions regarding my new purchase, a 1971 911T.
>The car was well maintained. I purchased it with records dating back to
>1978. I >found the original tool kit in the front trunk.  About all that
>was left in it was >the original fan belt and the tool for securing the
>pulley whilst changing it.  >Does anybody know what came standard in that
>kit?  Or... is there a book regarding >restoration type issue that would
>answer this question?
>
My '71T didn't come with a tool kit. The previous owner has it in her
garage somewhere but she has been unable to find it!  There is a wonderful
reference book available for the early 91 that will answer all of your
questions and more. It's By Dr. Brett Johnson and it's called, "The 911 &
912 Porsche.  A Restorer's Guide To Authenticity."  I highly recommend this
book, it's cheap (relatively) and filled with pictures and facts regarding
the pre '74 911 and 912.
>
>I am having the car repainted and I would like to put the S front spoiler on at
>this time.  Were these an option on this year?  I have read that they were.
>
The spoiler was standard on the '72S and optional on the other '72 models.
To the best of my knowlege, they were not available for a '71 911.  I do
like the look of the spoiler though.
>
>Based on the previous S spoiler question you may have gathered that I like a
>little more aggressive look.  The car came with the Fuchs alloys (14's).  I'll
>be needing new tires for the summer.  How far can we go? I was looking at
>190/60/14's.  Any tire experts out there?
>
I just went through this tire wheel thing with my '71T.  I've always
thought that the 14's looked small.  Anyway, 190's should fit fine though
the 60 series may make the tire well look somewhat anemic in addition to
giving you a fairly large speedometer error.  If you like an aggressive
look, my recommendation would be to go with 205/60x15 or 205/65x15 on 6x15
Fuchs on the rear and either the same or a 195/60 or 65x15 on the front.
I've tried 6x16 and 7x16 on the back of mine and they just don't "look"
right to me though 205x16's will work.

The standard (optional) Fuchs on a '71T were 6x15 with 185/70VR15's all
around.  Good luck finding those!
>
>And finally, this may seem really stupid, but... what is the "Appearance
>Group"?
>I've seen mention of it while looking for Deco trim parts but I've never really
>had an explanation.  From what I gather it's slightly wider trim (which I have)
>and rubber trim caps on the chrome bumper extensions (which I also have).  Is
>this right?  Is there more?
>
This is correct, I also believe that the apperance group included the "S"
instruments which were not standard on the "T".

Hope this helps,

Regards,

Dave Sens
Santa Barbara, California
'71 911T Coupe
"I'm not sure we understand everything we know about this".

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 95 19:11:59 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re:Ignition Wires


Will Hartje asked why 944 ignition wires cost so much.  Without
being to flip about it, I think the answer is that anything
associated with the Porsche name costs "so much."  I don't see
any reason why you, Will, can't buy a hunk of 'regular car'
ignition wire and use that, or buy a set if you can't get it
by the foot and cut it to suit your needs.  That's what I'd
do.

Bob Spindel

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 95 19:18:46 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re:Need Help in Lowering 911SC


There's a little pamphlet written by Ray Scruggs on alignment
methods for the 911.  It's advertised in the Classified section
of Pano, and sells for somewhere around $10.  Buy it.  It's
really quite good.  Armed with it you can do an entire alignment,
including lowering, camber, toe, and so on, in your home.  It'll
take you longer than a pro shop, but at least when you're done
you'll lnow more about your car, and you'll know it's been done
right.  Have you ever wondered if the alignment gear at your local
shop is calibrated?  by whom? when?

If you're serious about lowering and proper alignment, it'll be
the best $10 you spent.

Bob Spindel

P.S.  Tell him I sent you!  I thought he did a great job with his
booklet and wrote to tell him so.  If you tell him, it'll be another
compliment.

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 95 23:47:39 +0000
From: Ray@arkay.MV.COM
Subject: Re: Turbo water injection


Hi all,
Someone recently asked about pros /cons of injection systems for
turbos. While I don't have any firsthand knowledge, I have been
following a discussion about this in the internet newsgroup
rec.autos.sport.tech. Basically, it was mentioned that water 
injection reduces probability of destructive detonation, helps
absorbe excess heat, and in the process the generated steam adds
torque due to the additional pressure exerted onto the piston by
the expanding steam.

Of the disadvantages that were noted, the danger of internal engine
corrosion was the one that alarmed me most. In fact the idea of an
engine rusting inside out bothered me so much that I forgot any
other problems they mentioned.

Re-reading Bruce Anderson's book ("Porsche 911 Performance Handbook")
I noticed that he mentioned another way to increase safe boost limits
is the use of an additional fuel injection system to enrich the
mixture at high boost levels. Unfortunately, the company mentioned
in the book no longer makes any such devices, but EBS Engine Builders
Supply mentioned on the phone that they have something like that. I
asked them for specifics but probably didn't sound ready to plunk
down tremendous amounts of cash so they haven't sent me anything yet.

While I realize that I have a lot to learn before I attempt such
performance improvements, I am very curious about anything that 
makes higher turbo boost safe or at least less dangerous. Larger
intercoolers are also of interest.

My 930 has adjustable turbo boost, all the way up to 1.5 bar, but   
Bruce's picture of the melted piston is very vividly in my mind
anytime I am tempted to reach behind the driver's seat to touch the
forbidden tap of instant pleasure. 

Another thing that is very much on my mind is the previous owner's
repair bill totalling $7000 in parts, labor, and machine shop costs
for rebuilding the engine after a "mysterious loss of power".

Ray (Former Boston city dweller transplanted to NH boonies)
'82 Euro 930 		(the primary subject of my attention)
'92 Harley		(hibernating)
'83 and '88 Toyotas 	(soaking up road salt)


//----------------------------------------------------------------
