Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 00:07:29 -0600
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Garage sale continues

The BIG stuff is gone -- cars, etc. And there is some stuff still pending
like the 914 EFI and a few other items, so, if you think we have a "deal"
or there's something not on the list that you're wondering about, send me
a note... I lost a LOT of pending stuff in a disk crash a few weeks ago.

The warehouse sale continues, more parts being uncovered every day...
Prices do include shipping, unless otherwise specified.

356
- ---

One set T6 B wheels with crest hubcaps. These are painted wheels, not
chrome, and have only factory paint on them. Stored for 15+ years, 
$100 plus shipping.

912/early 911
- -------------

1 *NEW* 912 throwout bearing, $90. (NLA sent wrong one)

Full set of instruments (clock, gas gauge, temp gauge, 120 MPH speedo,
12V electric tach), $150. Tach useful for those 356 12 volt conversions.

1 set core 912 calipers. Rusted, ugly -- possibly can be rebuilt. $40
  plus shipping.

1 set rear bumper guards, not cherry but not bad, $50.

1 flywheel, usable as is, $100 plus shipping. Will toss in pressure plate,
  clutch disk in unknown condition.(look OK, but???)

2 starters, $50 each plus shipping. (this is NOT a set, can be split up)

1 shifter assembly, 5-speed style with aftermarket walnut shift knob, $50.

1 fuel pump, C/912 style, works, doesn't leak, $70.

Driver side door, super-cherry condition, just back from the body shop 
where it got the full treatment, in primer, $200 plus shipping.

Decent set of low-back seats, $100 plus shipping.

914
- ---

NOS seat belts for  cars with "late style"  ('73-6). Only as a set, 
$150 the pair.

1 windshield washer bottle, $20.

1 complete headlight assembly, $75.

1 headlight bucket and ring assembly, $40.

2 headlight motors, $100 each.

1 spare tire hold-down including part that welds to pan, $20.

Stan

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 21 Feb 1995 18:03:09 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: Forbes magazine ASAP

> >      Can anyone post a history ..
>
> What I *CAN* provide is a tracking of the total volume of mail ...

I should have been clearer: that's the total volume of mail that *EACH 
SUBSCRIBER* gets. For those who get picky, the "real" total
volume is

	(n+4)*V + (C*n * X) where

	n is the number of subscribers (the plus four accounts for the
	  original incoming note, the archival copy, the copy that goes
	  to the digest, and the one that goes to the test account that
	  keeps  me posted as to whether or not this stuff is "getting out")
	V is the volume from the previous note
	C is some multiplier for how many addresses generate some
	  sort of "error message", currently about 0.23
	X is the average size of the error message generated, 
	  currently about 30k (lots of stupid mailers return 
	  digests)

Not counted: retransmissions due to network or system failures, mis-queueing
or other problems.

Implications: this little system is *SMOKING*... On average, there are 
3 MBytes *A DAY* of admin mail that has to be processed. Fortunately, 
I have that pretty well automated, but it still takes time. So, add it
all up, and see what you get. Imagine trying to run that on a 28.8 dialup
modem...

Stan

basically perfect.  The question is, since we can use PML to establish an
average price for an average '82 928, what price premium do you think should
be added to the above car to reflect the value of limited edition, very low
miles, and perfect condition?

Thanks for you help!

Porsche Enthusiast=92s on the Information Super Highway
by Bev Frohm


There is a list for Porsche enthusiasts on the Internet. Many of you may
already know about this list, but for those of you who do not - Here=92s =
the
skinny.

The list is called Porschephiles, cute name, and it is like using an E-Ma=
il
service.  Approximately 1,000 =93Subscribe=94 to the list and there is no=
 fee to
=93Subscribe=94.  Most of the mail is sent to one Internet =93address=94,=
 this is
then forwarded to everyone that subscribes to Porschephiles. =


I have been =93Subscribing=94 to the list for the last couple months. The=
re is a
lot of volume as far as mail goes. Some of the people who frequently repl=
y to
questions are professional, who know there stuff, others are individuals =
like
the rest of us. Given that, there is a wealth of knowledge subscribing to=

Porshephiles, but you have to use common sense when taking someone=92s ad=
vice. =


To subscribe to Porschephiles you must have Internet access. For example,=
 if
you have a modem using America on Line, Prodigy, or Compuserve you can
subscribe. Although there is no fee to subscribe to Porschephiles, some
services may charge for Internet mail. For example, America on Line does =
not
charge a fee for any outgoing or incoming Internet mail, but Prodigy does=
=2E
Make sure you know the fee base for Internet use, you do not want any
unexpected surprises on your next bill.

To subscribe to Porschephiles, send a polite request with your Internet
address to:
Porschephiles-request@tta.com =


Soon you will receive a reply with the Rules for being a Subscriber or Me=
mber
of Porschephiles. I would suggest that you send an additional request to
start receiving the =93Digest=94 form of Porschephiles once you are a mem=
ber.
This takes all the mail coming in to the main address, Porschephiles@tta.=
com,
 and puts them  into one large file. I like the =93Digest=94 version, but=
 make
your own choice. =


If you  have any questions, send me an E-Mail to either:
Beverly.Frohm@conner.com		Work E-Mail Address
Beverly514@AOL.com		America on Line address

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 01:58:55 -0500
From: RICK9142@aol.com
Subject: 914's

Recently I had a problem with my 74 914 2.0's windshield leaking during heavy
rain.  I was afraid it would cost a ton to reseal the windshield, since no
one could guarantee they wouldn't break it.  Then my mechanic suggested just
having the trim resealed--it was alot cheaper and my car is as dry as a bone.

hope this helps
Rick9142@aol.com

Dave Krich was looking for a 914 mechanic in the San Diego area. I don't

slalom, and ask around. Or just go to a slalom and ask around. (Oh, join
anyway). The next one is March 4, at Jack Murphy Stadium, southeast lot.

around).

Date: Mon, 13 Feb 1995 16:30:52 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: 911 FAQ (1/2) [LONG]

        Response on this has been overwhelming--so it goes to the
whole list.  My mailer can't deal with the whole thing, so it's in
two big parts.  The original author tells me:

>Oh, BTW, I'm now sbscribed to Porschephiles from my account at netcom:
>
>        wadeg@netcom.com

 - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

>Date: Mon, 12 Dec 94 16:46:57 PST
>From: wade@nb.rockwell.com (Wade Guthrie)
>Subject: [LONG] Vestigal 911 FAQ
>
>I've been compiling information for a 911 FAQ.  I realize that I'm not
>the most qualified to do so, but I needed a lot of the information that
>I ended-up placing here.  Hopefully, I can flesh-out the stuff in here
>with the help of the Porshcephiles.
>
>Among the places where I know enough to realize I need extra help:
>
>       - When (and on what models) was the tea-tray rear wing (and,
>         for that matter, the other rear wings) used?
>
>       - I need all the information on the more recent models.
>
>       - What are the options I didn't mention?
>
>Well, at any rate, here's what I have so far.
>
>
>- --
>Q. What's a 911?
>A. Yikes.  Okay, in 1964 Porsche announced the 901, a model based on
>the venerable 356 model.  The car, which was renamed 911 because Peugeot
>had a copyright on all 3-digit car model numbers with a zero in the
>middle, has continued to become, arguably, the most popular car ever
>produced by Porsche.  The car had (and continues to have) a six cylendar
>opposed engine.  The body of the car was designed by Ferdinand "Butzi"
>Porsche (Ferry's son) while the engine was designed by Ferdinand Piech
>(Dr. Porsche's nephew).
>
>- --
>Q. Which 911 Should I Get?
>A. The standard answer is "get the newest 911 you can afford".
>Unfortunately, it's more complicated than that.  I had occasion to meet
>Joe Rusz (sp?) once; his answer to this question was simply "if you can
>afford it, get one with Motronic Fuel Injection" (those'd be the ones
>built in 84 and after).
>
>You really have to decide for yourself what you want.  Many feel that
>one exception to the 'newest you can afford' rule is the middle year
>cars (1973 through 1977) due to their short engine life span (circa 50K
>miles).  Others (like myself) prefer the early mechanically injected
>cars (light and sparcely appointed with quick, torquey engines) over
>the newer 911SC (with their air conditioning, electric windows, and
>bullet-proof engine).
>
>Hopefully, the information in this document will help you decide.
>
>- --
>Q. What are the differences between the various 911s?
>A. There's *lots* of differences:
>
>First, there are numerous of body styles:
>
>       Coupe           4 seats (well, 2 and a couple postage
>                       stamps) and a hard roof.  You know. . .
>                       a COUPE
>
>       Targa           Like a coupe, but with a roll bar and a
>                       removable top.  The earlier targas had
>                       soft rear windows, but the later ones
>                       had glass.
>
>       Cabriolet       A full-on convertable.
>
>       Speedster       A version of convertable, but with a
>                       short windshield and a fiberglass tonneau
>                       (the 356 speedster was different, but we're
>                       talking about 911s here).
>
>
>There are several trim and tune options:
>
>       T, E, S         The early years (the latest any of these
>                       were produced was 1977) cars in touring,
>                       injected and super (also fuel injected)
>                       states of tune.
>
>       Carrera         For the earlier cars, this was the quickest
>                       standard customer car.  After 1983, the Carrera
>                       was the standard customer car.
>
>       SC              This was the standard car (there was also the
>                       turbo for some of theses years) between 1978
>                       and 1983.
>
>       H, N            Rare models: Homologation (20 made in 1973) and
>                       a Euro model in 1976.
>
>       L               The one-year replacement for the 911S in the US.
>
>       R, RS, RSR      911 in race trim.  These cars are always rare
>                       and expensive.
>
>       Turbo           This one is, well, turbo charged.
>
>
>And, finally, there are the various changes over the different model
>years.  Major Eras Include (the names are, partly, my own):
>
>    - 1964-1968 short wheel base (SWB, 2211 mm to be exact).  In
>      contrast, the long wheel base (LWB) is 2268 mm long.
>
>    - 1968-1973 early power.  These 2.0, 2.2, and 2.4 liter 911s
>      (my personal favorite) saw either mechanical fuel injection
>      or carburators.
>
>    - 1974-1977 middle-year 911s.  These cars had the 2.7 liter
>      engines that had a notoriously short life span.  This is
>      the beginning of the crash bumpers (with the accordian
>      sections at the edges) and K-Jetronic fuel injection.
>
>    - 1978-1983 911SC.  These 3.0 liter SCs are powerful,
>      luxurious, and nearly bullet-proof.
>
>    - 1984-1989 Motronic Carreras.  Like the 911SC, but with a
>      3.2 liter engine and Motronic fuel injection.
>
>    - 1989-1993 964 (original 911 Carrera 2/4).  These cars have
>      the one-piece, all body color bumpers and the engine cover
>      that raises at 50 MPH to form a wing.
>
>    - 1993-today 993 (today's 911)
>
>Note: Years given are model year.  The model years start in August
>or September of the previous year (example 1972 model year starts
>in September of 1971).  Much of the research for this document has
>been clouded by research materials not specifying whether they
>discussed calendar year or model year.
>
>More specific differences are given in the following (big) table.
>This table contains the following headings:
>
>    -Model / disp      Model / Displacement (in Liters)
>    -ind'n             Induction
>    -0-60              0-60 MPH in Seconds
>    -HP                        Horsepower (DIN)
>    -top spd           Top speed in miles per hour
>    -weight            Weight in pounds
>
>== General Recognition 1964-1968 =============================================
>
>    1968 and earlier cars have a shorter wheelbase than the 911s built in 1969
>    and after (recognition hint: the tortion bar tubes are right next
>    to the SWB cars' rear wheel well -- there's a gap in the LWB cars).
>    Other accoutrements of the SWB cars are:
>
>       - glass lens covered headlights,
>       - exterior door handles that opened via an exposed push-button
>         (rather than the flying-buttress protection or trigger of
>         later years),
>       - no side marker reflectors,
>       - Hella 128 fog lights mounted through the bottom half of the
>         front bumper,
>       - a vertical structural strip running under the rear engine
>         grille,
>       - sunroof models during these years had a drain slot above the
>         rain gutter above the back side windows,
>
>    And, in the interior:
>       - chrome instrument bezels with green lettering,
>       - ceiling-mounted rear-view mirror (1968 was as well, but
>         it was break-away type)
>       - a one piece under-dash knee guard,
>       - pleated door pockets, and
>       - push-buttons to open the doors from the inside.
>
>    Until 1971, non-S models had silver painted slotted steel wheels;
>    S models had Fuchs alloy wheels.
>
>    911s before the 1967 model year had the '911' designation
>    diagonally across the lower right corner of the engine cover and
>    the PORSCHE script in one piece (well, actually it was two pieces,
>    but it looked like one) on the bottom.
>
>
>== 1964 2.0 liter=============================================================
>
> -Model / disp---ind'n---0-60----HP------top spd-weight---------------------
> 911 2.0       Solexes 8.8     130     .       2380
>
>- -- Recognition Tips -------------------------------------------------------
>The 1964 cars have no rocker-panel trim and and no model designation on
>the engine lid or on the dash.  Supporting clues are that 1966 and earlier
>911s have wooden dash trim and open A-frame window cranks.
>
>- -- Notes/Options ----------------------------------------------------------
>There were four 901 prototypes produced (serial numbers 13326, 13327,
>13328, and 13330).  Porsche went on to build 125 first year (1964) 901
>cars.
>
>
>== 1965 2.0 liter=============================================================
>
> -Model / disp---ind'n---0-60----HP------top spd-weight---------------------
> 911 2.0       Solexes 8.8     130     .       2380
>
>- -- Recognition Tips -------------------------------------------------------
>These cars look nearly identical to the 1966 cars.  The things that
>separate these cars from the 1966s is in the interior.  The 1965 cars have
>no wrap-around knee guard, aluminum backing on the wood dash trim, or
>rubber shift boot (I think they were leather).
>
>Both years are similar in that they have the rocker panel trim (this is
>not found on the 1964 cars), wooden dash trim, and open A-frame window
>cranks.
>
>- -- Notes/Options ----------------------------------------------------------
>A four speed transmission became standard mid-model year.  Options:
>    - sunroof.
>    - tinted windshield
>    - enamel porsche crest on wheels
>    - chrome plated steel wheels
>    - gasoline heater (LHD models only)
>    - ambient temperature gauge
>    - driver's side vanity mirror on sun visor
>    - recaro or ferrari seats (actually, both are made by recaro)
>    - leather seats
>    - headrests
>
>== 1966 2.0 liter ============================================================
>
> -Model / disp---ind'n---0-60----HP------top spd-weight---------------------
> 911 2.0       carb    8.8     130     130     2207
> 911S 2.0      carb    8.1     160     140     2207
>
>- -- Recognition Tips -------------------------------------------------------
>These cars look nearly identical to the 1965 cars.  The things that
>separate these cars from the 1966s is in the interior (see the 1965
>description).  Of course, if the car is an 'S' model, it has to be
>a 1966 or later.
>
>US models have all chrome vertical bumper guards (standard equipment) --
>911S bumper guards are all rubber.
>
>- -- Notes/Options ----------------------------------------------------------
>Weber carbs replace Solex mid-model year.  S model introduced mid-
>model year.  Fuchs wheels introduced.  Targa (with soft rear window)
>introduced.  911 introduced in US.  Options:
>    - sunroof.
>    - tinted windshield
>    - enamel porsche crest on wheels
>    - chrome plated steel wheels
>    - gasoline heater (standard on S-models) (LHD models only)
>    - ambient temperature gauge
>    - driver's side vanity mirror on sun visor
>    - recaro or ferrari seats (actually, both are made by recaro)
>    - leather seats
>    - headrests
>
>== 1967 2.0 liter ============================================================
>
> -Model / disp---ind'n---0-60----HP------top spd-weight---------------------
> 911 2.0       Webers  .       130     .       .
> 911S 2.0      Webers  8.1     160     140     2314
> 911R 2.0      Webers  .       210     .       1810
>
>- -- Recognition Tips -------------------------------------------------------
>The window cranks on 1967 cars are of the covered A-frame type but had
>a hard plastic knob.
>
>US Models have chrome vertical bumper guards with a rubber strip
>(standard) -- 911S bumper guards are all rubber.  The bases for the
>switches on the dash go from black to chrome and the dash is matte black
>(S model had basket weave vinyl).
>
>- -- Notes/Options ----------------------------------------------------------
>Only 20 911Rs were made.
>Options:
>    - Rear window wiper optional from this model year on (on Targas,
>      too?).
>    - tinted windshield
>    - rear-window defroster (vertical wires)
>    - sunroof.
>    - sportomatic (introduced in 1967)
>    - enamel porsche crest on steel wheels
>    - chrome plated steel wheels
>    - Fuchs alloys on non-S models
>    - 100 liter fuel tank
>    - gasoline heater (standard on S-models) (LHD models only)
>    - ambient temperature gauge
>    - leather covered steering wheel (standard on S-models)
>    - driver's side vanity mirror on sun visor
>    - leather seats
>    - headrests
>    - recaro sport seats (available in leather, vinyl, vinyl with
>      with corduroy, or vinyl with hound's tooth inserts).
>
>== General Recognition 1968-1973 =============================================
>
>    Side marker reflectors appear in 1968 (tacked-on side reflector) --
>    in 1969 and later, the reflectors are incorporated into the turn
>    indicators.  1968 and later 911s have the model designation mounted
>    horisontally centered on the engine cover (the hood?).  The covered
>    headlight is replaced with a rim bezel over a sealed beam headlight
>    (US) or a lens covering bulbs (non-US).  Inside, the window cranks
>    are one-piece with a soft vinyl knob.  The door pockets under the
>    arm rests are vinyl-covered hard cardboard.
>
>    1969 is the first year of long wheelbase 911s; these came with
>    flared fender arches; also, the targas come with glass rear windows.
>
>    The 911s between 1969 and 1973 used a 2 battery system.
>
>    From 1970 on, the doors opened via trigger-type door handles.  The
>    under-dash knee guard is a two-piece (with room for the ash tray in
>    between) unit during this time period.
>
>    1969 and later, the rear-view mirror is mounted to the windshield.
>
>== 1968 (A Model) 2.0 Liter ==================================================
>
> -Model / disp---ind'n---0-60----HP------top spd-weight---------------------
> 911 2.0       .               130     .       2207
> 911T 2.0      Webers          110     .       2185
> 911L 2.0      .               130     .       2314
> 911E 2.0      mfi             130     .       2185
> 911S 2.0 euro mfi             160     140     2132
>
>- -- Recognition Tips -------------------------------------------------------
>Matte black wiper arms.  US Models have chrome vertical bumper guards with
>a rubber strip (standard) -- 911S bumper guards are all rubber.  S Models
>have chrome vertical bumper guards with a rubber strip.  Knobs on the dash
>are now rubber covered.
>
>1968 US models only, 911s had tacked-on rectangular side reflectors in
>front and back.  Two-piece dash pad (1968 only).  Matte black dash (S
>and L models had basket weave or elephant hide vinyl).  Rear-view mirror
>is break-away and ceiling-mounted.
>
>- -- Notes/Options ----------------------------------------------------------
>A very few targas had glass rear windows at the end of the model year.
>Options:
>    - sunroof.
>    - Sportomatic transmission (1968-1971)
>    - tinted windshield
>    - rear-window defroster (vertical wires)
>    - a chrome bar (optionally with leather rubber covering)
>      connecting the top of the rear vertical bumper guards (where
>      bumper guards exist).
>    - a 3-piece stainless steel muffler skirt (hanging below the
>      rear of the car)
>    - enamel porsche crest on steel wheels
>    - chrome plated steel wheels
>    - Fuchs alloys on non-S models
>    - 100 liter fuel tank
>    - gasoline heater (LHD models only)
>    - ambient temperature gauge
>    - leather covered steering wheel (standard on S-models)
>    - leather seats
>    - headrests
>    - recaro sport seats (available in leather, vinyl, vinyl with
>      with corduroy, or vinyl with hound's tooth inserts) are
>      available on non-US cars.
>
>== 1969 (B Model) 2.0 Liter ==================================================
>
> -Model / disp---ind'n---0-60----HP------top spd-weight---------------------
> 911T 2.0      Webers  10.2    110     125     2250
> 911E 2.0      mfi     .       140     .       .
> 911S 2.0      mfi     8.0     170     170     2250
>
>- -- Recognition Tips -------------------------------------------------------
>First year of long wheelbase 911s; these came with flared fender arches.
>Dash was basket weave vinyl (1969-1971).  If it's a LWB car with push-
>button outside door handles, it's a 1969.
>
>- -- Notes/Options ----------------------------------------------------------
>All new forced air ventillation system.  Heated rear window standard.
>Targa had glass rear window.  911T came in an normal and 'Lux'
>configurations.  911T has all chrome bumper guards (rubber strip is an
>option); 911E and S have all rubber bumper guards.  After 1968, side
>marker reflecters were incorporated into the turn-signal indicator.
>Options:
>
>    - Hydropneumatic struts on S model.
>    - Hella 169 fog lights (not available in US)
>    - sunroof.
>    - tinted windshield
>    - Sportomatic transmission (1968-1971)
>    - aluminum wheel arch mouldings (E and S models)
>    - sportomatic, 5 speed (T and E models)
>    - rear-window defroster (horisontal wires)
>    - a chrome bar (optionally with leather rubber covering)
>      connecting the top of the rear vertical bumper guards (where
>      bumper guards exist).
>    - a 3-piece stainless steel muffler skirt (hanging below the
>      rear of the car)
>    - 10-spoke cast magnesium wheel (on T model only)
>    - chrome plated steel wheels
>    - 100 liter gas tank (non-US models only)
>    - gasoline heater (LHD models only)
>    - electric antenna
>    - leather seats
>    - headrests
>    - vinyl and leather door coverings
>    - vinyl, leather, (and cloth?) sport seats
>    - electric windows
>
>
>= 1970 (C Model) 2.2 Liter ===================================================
>
> -Model / disp---ind'n---0-60----HP------top spd-weight---------------------
> 911T 2.2      carb    .       125     127     2250
> 911E 2.2      mfi     .       155     .       .
> 911S 2.2      mfi     .       180     143     2250
>
>- -- Recognition Tips -------------------------------------------------------
>First year of trigger-type door handles.  '2.2' badge on engine grille.
>Dash was basket weave vinyl (1969-1971).  1967-1970 glove boxes used a key
>lock which was mounted over the glove box, but offset toward the center
>of the car.
>
>- -- Notes/Options ----------------------------------------------------------
>Underfloor areas galvanized with PVC undercoat.  911T has all chrome bumper
>guards (rubber strip is an option); 911E and S have all rubber bumper
>guards.  Options:
>
>    - Hella 169 fog lights (not available in US)
>    - Limited slip differential optional.
>    - sunroof
>    - Sportomatic transmission (1968-1971)
>    - tinted windshield
>    - aluminum wheel arch mouldings (E and S models)
>    - rear-window defroster (horisontal wires)
>    - a chrome bar (optionally with leather rubber covering)
>      connecting the top of the rear vertical bumper guards (where
>      bumper guards exist).
>    - a 3-piece stainless steel muffler skirt (hanging below the
>      rear of the car)
>    - 10-spoke cast magnesium wheel (on T model only)
>    - chrome plated steel wheels
>    - 100 liter gas tank (non-US models only)
>    - gasoline heater (LHD models only)
>    - Bosch hydro-dynamic struts (on T and S models only)
>    - electric antenna
>    - leather seats
>    - headrests
>    - vinyl and leather door coverings
>    - vinyl, leather, (and cloth?) sport seats
>    - electric windows
>
>
>== 1971 2.2 liter ============================================================
>
> -Model / disp---ind'n---0-60----HP------top spd-weight---------------------
> 911T 2.2      Web/Zen .       125     .       .
> 911E 2.2      mfi     .       155     .       .
> 911S 2.2      mfi     .       180     .       .
> 911 racing    mfi     .       270     .       .
>
>- -- Recognition Tips -------------------------------------------------------
>Dash was basket weave vinyl (1969-1971).  In 1971, the glove box lock was
>mounted in a twist knob that appeared centered over the glove box.
>
>- -- Notes/Options ----------------------------------------------------------
>911T has all chrome bumper guards (rubber strip is an option); 911E and S
>have all rubber bumper guards.  Options:
>
>    - Hella 169 fog lights (not available in US)
>    - tinted windshield
>    - Sportomatic transmission (1968-1971)
>    - heated windshild (this year only)
>    - sunroof.
>    - aluminum wheel arch mouldings (E and S models)
>    - rear-window defroster (horisontal wires)
>    - a 3-piece stainless steel muffler skirt (hanging below the
>      rear of the car)
>    - 10-spoke cast magnesium wheel (on T model only)
>    - chrome plated steel wheels
>    - gasoline heater (LHD models only)
>    - electric antenna
>    - leather seats
>    - headrests
>    - vinyl and leather door coverings
>    - vinyl, leather, (and cloth?) sport seats (standard on S model)
>    - electric windows
>

[continued...]

Date: 21 Feb 95 12:59:48 -0800
From: Daryl Savage (Exchange) <daryls@microsoft.com>
Subject: New Rotors on a '78 930

My normal track car is a '78 930 with S4 calipers up front and
the 930 fronts on the rear axles...

well, its time for new rotors (they'r stock) and i am wondering 
how hard this is going to be.

also, the rotors on '78 to '80 930's are different (and more $$) then
the later models.  I've heard they are *better* but am curious
as to why (floating?  huh?).

i run Pagid's on the track and being as they are scarce
(esp in this odd arrangement) i'm wondering if i am gonna
have to toss my last pair (which have one sesson's wear)
due to mating issues, etc...  same question for my street 
pads too...

the car is not lightened, pretty highly modified (ie: higher then
normal top speeds) and is not babied on the track.   the pucker
factor coming into the first turn off the straight is pretty tight at 
165 to 185 mph so i'd like (ahem) to do the right thing wrt the
brakes...

thoughts?  ideas?  experiences?

thx

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 09:00:29 -0500 (EST)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: WANTED: 912, 914, 924

I'm bored and want something Porsche-style to fix up. What I'm looking 
for is as follows: Any 912, 914, or 924. Wrecked, damged, or whatever 
(but still having a good body otherwise). Minor rust is acceptable, but 
as always, not preferred. I would like it running, but top condition is 
not expected (ie. if it sounds bad and all, but at least has some life in 
it to rebuild... it's good)

What I wanna do to it: Have it painted, replace all the interior things, 
all the little exterior things (lenses, bulbs, etc.) new muffler system, 
etc. It should be in all aspects: a project car.

Oh, as for the color, it doesn't matter too much, but I'd like to keep it 
original, and would rather not have silver.

As far as price goes, I'd like to keep it under $1000, so somewhere in 
the range of $400-$1000 is good for me. I fully intend to spend $1500+ on 
getting it up and running, then maybe $1000 more after that. (In what 
I've seen, this sounds reasonably realistic)

Summarized:
912, 914, 924
Running preferred, but not necessary.
Minor rust acceptable (ie. can't put your fist through the closed door)
Fav'rite colors (well, hell, I don't expect to get 'em, but can't hurt):
Blues, Reds, Greens, Yellows
under $1000

If you have something like this sitting in your yard, just quietly 
awaiting death, or have one that you lost interest in... e-mail me at: 
cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu

Thank you muchly!
Derek Cahill

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 09:07:45 CST
From: wpcostel@porsche.aud.alcatel.com (William Costello)
Subject: Re: 86 Carrera shifting (revised)

I had the same problem with my 86 911 Carrera until I changed the transmission
fluid a few weeks ago. I used SWEPCO gear lube that I got from Zims. Now I
can shift in the 3k RPM range. Its not always perfect, but its a whole lot
better that it was before.

W.P. Costello

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 09:04:20 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Re: $$$

> Thanks for taking the initiative (and heat) on this one.  The
> common perspective is that INTERNET is FREE.  If you believe that,

...then I have this bridge you should look at. 8{)

You know, that just *BAFFLES* me.... Even back in The Old Days, you
had to have this majik $30k/year "grant" from someone on the DARPA
approved list, payable to the Defence Communications Agency -- and
that was for a crummy 9.6k leased line!

The Internet has  *NEVER* been free -- it's just that there are a lot
of people who have put significant pieces of their own budgets into making 
it look that way.  Ditto for Usenet -- I used to spend about $2k/month 
from my research budget on dial and leased line services passing bits 
from seismo (east coast) to lbl-csam (west coast) -- and as a by-product, 
bringing good connectivity to Texas -- as part of the backbone 
when things like that still mattered. That was $24k/year I could have
done something else with, like hire another half of a tech or support
part of another research project. Nope, I did it because it was the
"right thing to do".

The big change going on now is that for the first time, end users are
starting to see those costs. The total numbers are HUGE - my sources say
that all of the internet service providers will spend something like
$120 million this year on buying services (leased line, dial-up, access
to the backbone, etc) that will let them be in business. That doesn't
even include the hardware and staff costs (for which I've seen no estimates)!!

Stan

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 11:15:34 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Roll Cages

Greetings:

While I have had no personal experience with the Race-Tech roll cage, I have
installed a number of Safety Devices Cages in Porsches and a few Autopower
cages in other SCCA showroom stock cars.  From the sounds of it, the Race
Tech cage is similiar to the S, D., for which you weld in nut plates to
structural portions of the chassis (I.E. door sills etc).
The Autopower cages I have dealt with mount directly to the floor with
reinforcing plates bolted under the floor forming a sandwich of the floor
pan.  IMHO the first method is far superior, using the structure of the
chassis to absorb the impact of a rollover rather than just the pan.  It also
is a great chassis stiffening device for open cars such as 914s and targas.
 Why spen big$s on suspension upgrades if the effectiveness of the upgrade is
being partially absorbed in chassis twist?
Lastly, all of the above was theory until the 1993 SCCA runoffs when a
showroom stock car rolled voilently punching the Autopower cage through the
floor.  I can't tell you the brand of car and I was not there but I had
several friends in SS classes at that event who relayed this information to
me.  My understanding is that the driver was injured as a result of the
failure.  Keep in mind the cage itself did not fail, the mounting system was
inadequate and the roll over protection system failed.
My feeling is that safety is prime when driving track whether it be drivers
ed or wheel to wheel.  Why try to save a few (even a few hundred) bucks and a
few hours installation time on a product just to perhaps "meet the rules".
 You've already spent the money for the best car, protect yourself with the
best cage.  Go with the Race-Tech (or Safety Devices who as a matter of
interest is owned by Matter, who provide the factory cages for Cup cars etc.)

Keep the shiny side up

Pat Moyle

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 11:15:26 -0500
From: PM9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Steward at Sebring

Phil et al:

I wasn't going to post this to the list originally but the question has been
asked a couple of times.
At Sebring, the Chief Steward (moi) started hearing more and more reports
from workers, (primarily tech and pit & grid) about being treated rudely by
drivers and crew members.  Combing this with what I felt was a higher degree
of rude driving for this type of event, Sunday morning I turned my normally
mild mannered hat around and addressed the group at the driver's meeting in
my best Chief Stewards voice.  The summary of what I said was that these
workers donate their time, at their own expense to make events like this
possible, and give the drivers a place to play.  That there wasn't a person
in the room who had the right to verbally abuse a worker no matter how
frustrated they were and if it happened again the offending party would be on
the trailer.  If they had a problem they could discuss it with me or the
National Tech Steward in a conversational tone of voice and we would get it
handled.  Turned my hat around and got on with the rest of the meeting.
Normally this isn't a problem.  Maybe there's something in the Florida water.
 (ready to duck flames)

Normally mild mannerly yours

Pat Moyle

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 08:24:07 TZ
From: Jim Harriger <jimharr@microsoft.com>
Subject: today's 928 electrical puzzle


	This past weekend, i did the oil change, tune-up thing on 'The Pig'
('79 928).  Two rather interesting occurances were observed:

	i decided to try spark plugs other than Bosch Platinums, since it seems
like the Platinums' perfomance drops off after a few thousand miles, a slight
roughness in the 1/8 to 1/4 throttle, light load regime.  so i bought 
Champions.
well, driving the car to work yesterday with the Champions in it was a rude
awakening; it ran worse at light load! at heavy throttle, it runs real 
good, but
at light throttle, light load, it misses like crazy. i went home last 
night, regapped
the plugs down a notch (from the specified 0.71mm to 0.63mm) and drove it
up and down the road- no change. so i cleaned the old Bosch's up, and re-gapped
them to 0.71mm and put them back in- not great, but about like they 
were before.
hmm. are the Champions just shit, or did i get the wrong plugs for my car? the
Bosch's are  WR8DP and the Champions are RN11YC.

	also, on the way to work yesterday, the 'ENGINE OIL' light began flashing,
followed immediately by a sharp rise in heart rate and BP (mine, not 
the car's!).
some research indicated that this is a low oil level warning. hmm, i thought i
put the normal 8 qts. back in, check it, its OK. so i start looking at 
the sensor.
ah, look, a broken wire! ok, fix that, take it for a drive. now the oil 
warning light
only flashes going up a hill, or accelerating. go home read the manual 
some more.
OK, the central warning brain is only supposed to care about the oil 
level sensor
when the key is on and the engine 'stationary' (german for 'not 
running'?). so, i
conclude that the central warning box is confused about when the engine 
is running.
i pull the dead pedal, and look at the connectors. well, lookee there, 
there's a
connecter backed out of the connector block. i put it back and go to 
bed. driving
to work this am proves that the problem still exists. what i'm 
concluding is that
the wire to the sensor has been broken a long time (perhaps by the previous
owner, in response to symptoms like i'm seeing)?  $64 question: does anyone
know how the central warning system brain knows whether or not the engine is
running? could all of this be caused by the classic 'bad ground'?

	thanks for any ideas you might have.


						jim harriger
						'79 928 Mochabraun

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 09:32:19 -0800 (PST)
From: David Sanderson <biom@unixg.ubc.ca>
Subject: Corner weighting

I have access to a sophisticated force measuring device and this weekend 
will record the force under each wheel on my 1977 911S. To properly 
corner-weight a car I understand that the gas tank should be full and 
the driver in the car. Has anyone else had experience at this? I realize 
that if the weights are outside spec it will be more work to set up. 
Thanks in advance.

David J. Sanderson, Ph.D.                 (604)-822-4361 VOICE
UBC Biomechanics Laboratory               (604)-822-6842 FAX
biom@unixg.ubc.ca


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 17:30:46 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: Cost of running the list

On Wed, 22 Feb 1995, Stan Hanks wrote:

> $120 million this year on buying services (leased line, dial-up, access
> to the backbone, etc) that will let them be in business. That doesn't
> even include the hardware and staff costs (for which I've seen no estimates)!!

Stan 

Think of a number then multiply it by 10

The revenue that British Telecom alone make from bandwidth sales to 
internet users exceeds 120m dollars. then there are all the other 
suppliers...

Currently we all scrounge bandwidth from our employers or whoever. Sooner 
or later our employers will wise up and start putting traffic monitors on 
the LANs so that they can start charging individual depts. When that 
happens the boss will start looking at how he can cut his dept spend - 
before you know it cisco will bring out routers that can be programmed to 
reject packets to http servers etc etc....

So I guess there is some sort of trade off on how big you can let any 
list grow, there may also be be some natural limit. If a list gets too 
big, the number of posts grows, and the number of broadcasts grows, so 
you have a square law working.

If the list gets too big, then the postings each user receives gets 
beyond what he can view in a lunch break, at this point, I guess some 
users will start to un-subscribe.

For me I think the limit is probably close right now, I scan the list and 
dump unread all the posts on certain categories ( apart from those with 
obvious entertainment value), and that still takes half hour.

I think from the above it is fairly clear that a 5000 member list would 
be impossible, so you may need to think about splitting the list into 
model specific lists, perhaps 911, 914/944/928, 356/C912/914, and general 
interest -
for me I could then subscribe to 944 and general, and expect to get 30 
mails per day. 

This should half the bandwidth requirement, but obviously would need 
slightly more administration.

Perhaps there would then be scope for someone taking over running one of 
these sub-lists on another server.

Another possible way forward - lots of work for Stan, would be to make it 
possible to register a limitted group interest, so that pfilers could 
register interest groups, and then postings could be given the 
appropriate subject and distributed as reqd, I haven't played with elm, 
so I am unsure how much work is involved.

Which ever way you decide to go Stan, you have my thanks for the great 
work you have done.



+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 12:40:45 -0500 (EST)

What about the connectors? Is there any thing special with the spark plug 
wire and distributor cap connectors? Maybe that's why they cost so much.

By the way, I bought some Accel wires, cut off the original connectors, and 
with the help of my brother, soldered the connectors onto the Accel 
wires. The car runs much smoother now.

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 11:17:21 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re: compressor size to buy

    For years I swore I did most my painting with a 3.5 hp Speedaire. In 
   fact (since it finally died) it was only 2.5hp ! Fully okay for impact
   wrenches, painting, and light sanding. 

    If you are going to run a Sandblaster (or probably a beadblaster) even
   5hp isn't enough to really keep going. But I replaced my 2.5hp with
   a Craftsman 6hp; the price is great ($399), and I like the direct drive
   (no more slipping belts). Also it is oiless so I don't have oil mixing
   when I paint. It also does a pretty good job of keeping up with an inline
   sander. 

    I really don't know what a big tank gives you except that its a pain to 
    move. For any continous use (sandblasting or sanding) the compressor is
    going to run all the time anyway. Two stage supposedly only gives you 
    higher pressure, not higher thru-put (I've heard both ways...) and you
    just don't need over 100psi....
     
    I do suggest 230 volt operation at 4hp and above. Makes for better starts
    and fewer blown fuses.  I'd be really tempted to buy the Craftsman
    4hp 115/230 volt model (only $299 !),  and have something I could
    transport if needed. I got the 6hp expecting to combine with my 60gallon 
    5hp Campbell Hausfield (or Puma or whatever Taiwanese model at the
    "other" shop) when sandblasting.

                  Lee A.

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 10:04:27 PST

Subject: Re: Corner weighting

>
	Hi Dave,

I had my 84 911 aligned by a san jose shop. I told him my weight and filled
the tank to 3/4 full. In my opinion, this set up so far gave me the best
compromise for the riding I do. The car now feels excellent and handles
much better. It has been lowered about 1". I have adjustable spring plates
which made balancing much easier. The corners are now within 20 lbs from each
other according to the shop.

Hope this helps....

Ehab.


 
> I have access to a sophisticated force measuring device and this weekend 
> will record the force under each wheel on my 1977 911S. To properly 
> corner-weight a car I understand that the gas tank should be full and 
> the driver in the car. Has anyone else had experience at this? I realize 
> that if the weights are outside spec it will be more work to set up. 
> Thanks in advance.

Dave,

You're probably going to find that a heat range 3 plug is what you need.
But the only way to be sure is to run the car, and look for the heat line
on the electrode.

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 10:50:23 PST
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: re: compressor size to buy

Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com says:
> 
>     I really don't know what a big tank gives you except that its a pain to 
>     move. For any continous use (sandblasting or sanding) the compressor is
>     going to run all the time anyway. Two stage supposedly only gives you 
>     higher pressure, not higher thru-put (I've heard both ways...) and you
>     just don't need over 100psi....

What the bigger tank and higher pressure give you is a longer cycle between
runs of the compressor.  Its pure physics.  If you are using 4 cfm at 60 psi,
and you have either 60 gal of air at 120 psi or 100 gal of air at 160 psi,
which one do you think is going to take longer to drain?

FWIW I had a 5 hp single stage 60 gal, and up graded to a horizontal 120
gallon 10 hp 2 stage last year (bought used from garage that went out of
busines).  Now I hardly ever get the compressor to run except when starting
out or when running a DA sander (takes 9.8 cfm at 90 psi)

- -- 
Miq Millman   mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com	  503 642 6139   (Aloha site)
AL4-55  Intel, 5200 NE Elam Young Parkway, Hillsboro, OR 97124-6497
See also miq@teleport.com

------------------------------


Porschephiles #1190                         Wed Feb 22 16:51:54 CST 1995
Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 14:04:26 EST
From: fwk@hogpa.ho.att.com
Subject: re: compressor size to buy

>...
>    going to run all the time anyway. Two stage supposedly only gives you 
>    higher pressure, not higher thru-put (I've heard both ways...) and you
>    just don't need over 100psi....
>     
>    I do suggest 230 volt operation at 4hp and above. Makes for better starts
>    and fewer blown fuses.  I'd be really tempted to buy the Craftsman
>    4hp 115/230 volt model (only $299 !),  and have something I could
>    transport if needed. I got the 6hp expecting to combine with my 60gallon 
>    5hp Campbell Hausfield (or Puma or whatever Taiwanese model at the
>    "other" shop) when sandblasting.

What you really want to look at is CFM of air at a given pressure, 90 psi
being frequently specified and a useful value. This has been beaten to
death in many other forums, but "4 HP" motors running off 115 V. lines
is simply not realistic. The high HP values come from creative specification
approaches. I haven't heard of anyone finding a way to distort CFM values
yet. 

230 V. operation is definitely a good idea, for anything above perhaps
1 or 1.5 HP.

From my observation of CFM values at 90 PSI, 2-stage compressors do
in fact produce more air at a given HP rating (if you think you have
found a HP rating you are willing to believe).

A larger tank is nice if you expect to do jobs where the air flow needs
exceed the compressor output. Sandblasting is a possible example. The
larger tank then allows a longer "operate" period before you wait for
the compressor to catch up. If you buy a relatively high CFM compressor
this may not be a big issue, but most (all?) of those come with a big
tank anyway.

I would also look for a good brand name as an indication of the expected
life of the compressor unit itself, although I'm mot sure that the
better names aren't now buying "cheap" compressor heads for their
lower cost models.

An ASME tank is nice, if that helps you sleep better at night.

Frank Kerfoot
fwk@hogpa.att.com

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 13:41:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Corner weighting


>To properly corner-weight a car I understand that the gas tank should be 
full and
>the driver in the car.

When aligning or corner weighting, you ideally want the car in the
condition it will be run.  So that means driver in the car, and preferably
nothing in the cubbies/trunk which you would remove when running
it.  If you like to autocross on vapors, align/CW the car with an empty
tank.  If you do track events with a full tank of gas in the morning and
not much left by 5PM, align/CW with a half tank.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 15:09:17 -0500
From: noorder@btg.com
Subject: Re: Compressor size

On Feb 22, 11:17am Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com writes:
>     For years I swore I did most my painting with a 3.5 hp Speedaire. In 
>    fact (since it finally died) it was only 2.5hp ! Fully okay for impact
>    wrenches, painting, and light sanding. 
> 
>     If you are going to run a Sandblaster (or probably a beadblaster) even
>    5hp isn't enough to really keep going. But I replaced my 2.5hp with
>    a Craftsman 6hp; the price is great ($399), and I like the direct drive
>    (no more slipping belts). Also it is oiless so I don't have oil mixing
>    when I paint. It also does a pretty good job of keeping up with an inline
>    sander. 

Having spend alot of time evaluating compressors [thinking about
sandblasting] beware of the 'rated' HP of these units.  The number
you are really interested in is how many cubic feet per minute (CFM)
that a given unit can pump.

You can get a cheap 5HP compressor for < $400, but it will
pump less then 10CFM.  If you do lots of DA sanding or use a die
grinder with wire wheel to remove LOTS of rust - this really isn't
enough ;-( (experience).  On the other hand you can get a 5 HP that pumps
15+ CFM, but it will run you more then $800 or so.

> 
>     I really don't know what a big tank gives you except that its a pain to 
>     move. For any continous use (sandblasting or sanding) the compressor is
>     going to run all the time anyway. Two stage supposedly only gives you 
>     higher pressure, not higher thru-put (I've heard both ways...) and you
>     just don't need over 100psi....

The big tank is usefull for 'reserve' pressure.  Ideally the 
compresser will be able to keep the tank up to pressure even when you
are working - so you never get below operating pressure.

If you are doing high-volume work I would suggest the two stage units
as they pump lots more air.  The compressor I would love to have
is a 7.5 HP 2 stage compress with 80 gallon tank that pumps 22 CFM
per minute.  That I won't be able to get ahead off - NEVER!  The
rating on 2 stage compressors usually is at a higher CFM, which is
what you really want, but not necessarily - so check the numbers.

If your compressor can keep the tank at 175 psi instead of 125psi
you have LOTS more air in the tank waiting to get used.  Very 
important!

>      
>     I do suggest 230 volt operation at 4hp and above. Makes for better starts
>     and fewer blown fuses.  I'd be really tempted to buy the Craftsman
>     4hp 115/230 volt model (only $299 !),  and have something I could
>     transport if needed. I got the 6hp expecting to combine with my 60gallon 
>     5hp Campbell Hausfield (or Puma or whatever Taiwanese model at the
>     "other" shop) when sandblasting.

Yup - The 220 volt compressor are lots cheaper to run, and in fact
the larger compressors (15+ CFM) can suck up to 30 Amps of 220 Volt.
Big motors :-)

Right now I am dong what Lee is - hooking up two smaller compressors
to drive all the air tools: impact guns, da sander, die grinder,
tire changer, etc.  And I spend too much time waiting for the compressor
to spool up :-(.

> 
>                   Lee A.      
> 

Hope this helps.

BTW - don't forget to drain your compressors.  My latest acquisition
had three gallons of water in the tank - unbelievable!


Alex Noordergraaf [noorder@btg.com]

'73 914 (no engine) [being stripped the old fashioned way - wire wheel :-)]
'73 914 2.0 [lurking under car cover]
[three complete 914s in boxes in the garage (back yard actually :-)]
'88 Honda CRX Si [SCCA DS/S4]
'90 Toyota MR2 [SCCA CS/S3 and SSB (maybe)]

Date: 22 Feb 95 11:57:34 -0500
From: mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Subject: re: Obstructing Justice

>100,000 more cops on the street. Right. Does anybody with two gray cells
>still wired together honestly believe that these are going to "reduce
>crime"? F--k, no, they're going to be writing tickets while for the
>dispatcher to send them to the occasional crime.
> 
>We don't have a problem catching criminals. We have a problem with the
>lawyers, judges, and jails not being able to put these people away for the
>specified amount of time when they ARE caught. So what are we supposed to do
>if/when these 100,000 "peace officers" start bringing in more of same?
> 
>POLICE ARE TAX COLLECTORS. End of soapbox oratory.
> 
>Pete

First, don't worry about 100,000.  There is only funding for about 25,000.
And that number goes down 20% a year until they're gone.  But anyway,
what you do about lack of jail space for real criminals is you eliminate
'consensual crimes' which jail non-violent non-criminals.  By far the most
important is to get rid of all drug laws.  Some 18 year-old caught with
some arbitrary amount of a drug gets a 'mandatory minimum' while people
who commit the drive by shootings can name names and get off or get a 
light sentence.
Drug prohibition doesn't work and when the prices go up for the illegal
material, you get businesses operating outside the law who have to have
their own enforcement.  Besides, it's immoral to tell people what they
can and can't put in their bodies as long as they're not harming others.

Mark A. Skala
mvmas@mvujc.att.com
Disclaimer: I have not ever used any illegal drugs, nor do I advocate
doing so, however I do not subscribe to the belief that it is okay to
force others not to.

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 17:22:14 GMT
From: jcp@mi.leeds.ac.uk
Subject: Re: Porsches on TV

On Feb 22, 10:37am, Peter Albrecht wrote:
> Subject: Porsches on TV
>
> I said >another reason to avoid Airbusii.
>
> Lou Nicotra pointed out that it was a 757.
>
> I know the plane that did the emergency landing was a Boeing, but Airbus,
> Airbusses, Airbusii, aw, hell, more than one Airbus, every one I've ever
> been in looks like it was built by Eurosocialists who don't care anymore. I
> should have made clear that I figure this sort of conversion factor mistake
> becomes even more likely with things like these committee-built state
> sponsored airliners. And I just don't trust fly-by-wire. (Doesn't Lucas have
> a hand in all this? Would you trust an airplane with Lucas electrics? Didn't
> the new Denver airport get a high-tech baggage handling system built by a
> British company, and it doesn't work?)
>
> Pete
>
>
>-- End of excerpt from Peter Albrecht

What is this Europhobic rubbish doing in the Porschephiles mailing list,
especially with the title "Porsches on TV"?
May I remind you that Porsche cars are made in Germany, Europe?

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 13:02:38 -0800 (PST)
From: steven_gilbert@csufresno.edu (Steven Gilbert)
Subject: Re: Rear View mirror adhesive


It depends on what year mirror.  The later ones ('78 on?) have a round
metal disk, which uses the standard Loctite mirror adhesive (take the
mirror off and sand the disk before attempting to attach).

The earlier ones have a black adhesive pad.  You can do as I did when
I didn't know better--take it to a glass shop; they'll sand the
trapezoidal surface to flat, bare metal and use the above adhesive.  Or you
can get a replacement adhesive pad (Tweeks, Stoddard, etc.--I like
Stoddard because they don't pad their shipping charges).

Or you can update your mirror to the later type.  That's a more
expensive solution.

BTW, I have a spare pad and mirror just in case the same thing happens
again, or if I have to replace my windshield.

Steve Gilbert
Fresno, CA
steveng@csufresno.edu
> 
> 
> Does anyone know what type of adhesive should be used to reattach 
> a 911 rear view mirror to the windshield?  It was quite a shock 
> when it fell off while driving last night.
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Brooks Esser
> esserb@hpcc01.corp.hp.com
> 
> 


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 13:06:24 PST
From: steve@pyramid.com (Stephen Chan)
Subject: Re: Rear View mirror adhesive


> Does anyone know what type of adhesive should be used to reattach 
> a 911 rear view mirror to the windshield?  It was quite a shock 
> when it fell off while driving last night.
> 

I had tried a number of adhesives without much success for my '81 911.
Then I decided to ask the dealer if they carry the adhesive strip that
attaches the rear view mirror to the windshield.  Indeed they do, and
it only cost a couple of bucks.

Steve  
'81 911SC Coupe Platinum Metallic
'81 911SC Widebody Coupe Black (Still in the shop but almost finished!)  

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 16:00:58 -0500
From: pjwales@magicnet.magicnet.net (Peter Wales)
Subject: Re: Corner weighting

I assume that you are corner weighting a car to race it. If not, you will
have adjustable SPRINGS to set the corner weiights with.

We used to do this on a race car and it is done as it was meant to be driven
so we put half a tank of gas and a weight equivalent to the driver in it.
Then we adjusted the suspension so that the cornerweights side to side were
equal. This is done by raising and lowering collars on screw threads on the
suspension which raised and or lowered the corner. This adjusted the weight.

Hope it helps

Peter Wales

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 13:58:13 TZ
From: Eric Brown (SYS) <ericb@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Compressor size

| From:  <noorder@btg.com>
|
| BTW - don't forget to drain your compressors.  My latest acquisition
| had three gallons of water in the tank - unbelievable!

It had been a while since I had drained mine, so I moved it to the
center of the shop and opened the petcock. Egads, the dirty,
brown water just kept coming out. So, before the puddle got too
big, I shut the petcock and wheeled the thing outside to finish
the job.

If you have a stationary compressor, or just like gadgets, you
can get an automatic drain valve for your compressor. That way
you won't forget to drain it.

BTW, is it PC to use the term petcock? Does it conotate a rooster
you are fond of? <vbg>

    Eric

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 17:19:53 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: strange but true electrical stories


I used to have a Mercedes that would turn it's own brake lights
on and off at random, whether the car was occupied or not. My
wife was watching the random blinking from the living room window 
one time and decided that the car was posessed. It took me a 
loonnnng time to track down the problem, and I finally found it 
with a short detector made by KD and dumb luck. It turned out to 
be a cut in the wiring harness above the driver's window - 
probably caused by a slip of the knife when Fritz installed the 
headliner after too much of that vending machine Pils. It wasn't 
apparent by looking at the skinned wires why there should be a 
problem - transient electropositronical transmigrography perhaps - 
but I taped it up and the problem went away.

Reid



------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 95 14:25:31 PST
From: "SRAMACHA.US.ORACLE.COM" <SRAMACHA@us.oracle.com>
Subject: first autocross


Hi everybody, 
 
         Just thought I would let everybody know that I took part in my 
first autocross last saturday organized by the Golden Gate Region PCA. 
Boy! Did I have a blast. 
         There were about 60 cars - mostly 911's and 914's, one RS, one 
930, one 928 and two 944's. Initially I felt a little odd 'coz I looked 
like the most unprepared( for the autoX)  guy while others had their 
track-only cars or atleast track tires  and me with  my 215-60-HR 15 
RE-71 road  tires .  My  best  time  was  43  seconds  ( a 5  second 
improvement over my worst ie first run) and almost everybody was doing 
40 secs with some people doing 37 secs. I discovered a completly new 
driving experience though I an not anywhere near mastering driving at 
the limits. I thought driving at the limit was driving with the tires 
squealing. I have also enrolled in the 2 day drivers ed & autoX school 
in May. 
          Now for the reason for my 43+ second runs:SABOTAGE!! Someone 
switched my accelerator and brake pedals and put a cone-attracting 
magnet under my bumper ;-).  
 
Sreelal 
'84 944 
 
ps: Was there anyone else form the list at the event?

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 14:42:29 -0700
From: stephenk@synopsys.com (Stephen Keller)
Subject: Re: strange but true electrical stories

The funniest auto electrical glitch around here was a former co-worker's
Jaguar sedan.  It had electric side mirrors that would wink if you shut the
driver side door a little to hard.  The mirror would auto-adjust until it
hit its limit switch and then return to its normal position, then back to
the limit, then to normal and so on until the owner finally saw it and
wandered out to open and shut the door.  On a sunny day, it looked like the
car was winking.  I think the car was sensitive about having its doors slammed.

Stph

Date: 22 Feb 95 17:43:10 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsches on TV

Peter Diffey writes
>The airbus is a fine and wonderful plane unfortunately some parts were
>designed in countries that have rather different ideas about ergonomics.
 
Yeah. Countries populated by double amputee midgets (oops, sorry,
"vertically challenged nonopods") who like sitting in rows
of 20. Must be one of those evolutions of the third-world tour bus, which
is only 2 meters long but 30 meters wide because they all want to sit up
front with the driver.
 
Every Airbus I've ever been in (and there have been a few) struck me as
being the airborne version of the Yugo. Or, to put it in Western European
terms, the Mini Metro or Renault 5 or Ford Fiesta or Fiat Panda or... or...
Yes! I've got it! The Goggomobil!
 
I might accept the Airbus if 1) they put more engines on it (yeah, I know,
the new Boeings are doing the same thing) and 2) they stopped trying to
stack passengers like cordwood in interiors built by low-bid contractors. As
far as I'm concerned, there is nothing to beat a 747 for long hauls, and a
737/57/67 for domestic flights. IMHO. YMMV. FBI/KGB. UNESCO. Etc. The Airbus
(any one of them ) and McDonnell-Douglas DC-10/MD-11 could have a showdown to
decide worst big airplane honors.
 
Pacers, BTW, are now collectors' items. One, because there are nearly none
left alive in the wild (and there's a reason); two, because of the movie
"Wayne's World." The Flying Fishbowl lives! Besides, doesn't it share
parts with the 924 (running, ducking...)
 
Is the conveyor at DIA a German design? I heard BAE, thought "British
Aerospace." OK, so it's German. Germans probably mess up just as often as
the British but are better at covering it up (better at following boss'
orders to shut up and deny...) The British just own up to it
and figure they'll "muddle through" somehow. My next door neighbor used to
work for a British boss who was very proud of the fact that no project he
ever worked on went into production (missles/aerospace).
 
Peter D, come home to America, all is forgiven...
 
Pete

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 14:57:32 -0800
From: winders@support.apple.com (Scott Winders)
Subject: Re: first autocross

>Hi everybody,
>
>         Just thought I would let everybody know that I took part in my
>first autocross last saturday organized by the Golden Gate Region PCA.
>Boy! Did I have a blast.
>         There were about 60 cars - mostly 911's and 914's, one RS, one
>930, one 928 and two 944's. Initially I felt a little odd 'coz I looked
>like the most unprepared( for the autoX)  guy while others had their
>track-only cars or atleast track tires  and me with  my 215-60-HR 15
>RE-71 road  tires .  My  best  time  was  43  seconds  ( a 5  second
>improvement over my worst ie first run) and almost everybody was doing
>40 secs with some people doing 37 secs. I discovered a completly new
>driving experience though I an not anywhere near mastering driving at
>the limits. I thought driving at the limit was driving with the tires
>squealing. I have also enrolled in the 2 day drivers ed & autoX school
>in May.
>          Now for the reason for my 43+ second runs:SABOTAGE!! Someone
>switched my accelerator and brake pedals and put a cone-attracting
>magnet under my bumper ;-).
.
.
.
>ps: Was there anyone else form the list at the event?

Sreelal,

I was there. I drive a silver '78 911SC Targa with a '77 Turbo tail. I ran
in the "odd" run group (1st  to run).

Henry Watts and I battled it out for the TTOD 911 honors. In fact no other
911 was within a second of us. My first run of the day was with a student
(Hank has me teaching already) so I took it easy. It was cold out and the
course was dirty. It felt like I had tires made out of concrete!!  There
was no turn-in at all. This I attributed to shortness of the course (no
time for the tires to warm), the cool weather, and dirty track (I was the
third car out). I did a 37.7xx. My next run, without the student, was a
little faster 37.6xx, but I hit a cone. Still had no turn-in and the tires
we still cold to the touch. Hank was only a little faster with a lower
37.6xx and with a cone like me.

Thank God the sun came out!! My next run came after lunch. The course had
warmed up and been cleaned off. My first run was a 36.5xx with no cones.
Hank went out and beat my time with a 35.8xx. My next run I did a 35.7xx
(the tires were warming up). Hank then did a 35.5xx. I did not have high
hopes of matching this time. For my last run, I did a 35.4xx. They tried
to give me a cone but it was from my practice lap so the 35.4xx stood.

Before my last run, Hank and had discussed him taking my car out if I did
not beat his time. He decided to take my car anyway...I was somewhat
suprised by this decision. Hank also had a cold....

Scott Winders
winders@support.apple.com

'78 911SC Targa, Silver (Current daily driver and autox weapon)
'74 911 Coupe, White (Project car and soon to be time trial and autox
                      weapon)

My '72 T came to me 7 years ago with some kind of ugly white adhesive
spread out on the window, about 5 times the amount needed, and the 
mirror stuck to it.  I've trimmed off the excess, and the mirror still
holds just fine.  I don't know what it was.  I'd think epoxy would 
work as well...

I would like to point out that the United States of America already 
has the highest incarceration rate among first world countries.
(Id est, ratio of imprisoned citizens to free citizens.)
How much higher would this figure go with such a "cuff-em-and-stuff-em"
approach?  In the Land of the Free?

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 19:53:00 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Re: Painted to match 914 bumpers

Mike Willis wrote that painted bumpers for 914's were only available on the
Special Edition cars.  Incorrect, as painted to match bumpers were standard
equipment from 1970 through 1972 (maybe '73 also, but don't remember).  My
'72 was "appearance grouped" by the dealer - painted bumpers replaced with
chrome, foglights added, carpet upgraded, and 5 1/2 inch steel wheels in
place of 4 1/2's.  Tires were also upsized, and vinyl panels and trim pieces
added.  Seemed high, at $300, at the time, but price a good chrom bumper
today!

Pat Garvey

------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 17:06:45 -0800 (PST)
From: Mike Weihman <mikew@cougar.sr.hp.com>
Subject: Re: strange but true electrical stories

Well, the funniest automotive glitch I've seen is on my very own
931...

When it rains, and I try to adjust the driver side electric mirror, it
only moves in one axis (up/down) no matter which way I move the
joystick!  

I imagine that water in the mirror is shorting something out, but I
have not been irritated enough to open it up yet to find out.

 -mike  '80 931 fire engine red

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 18:53:36 -0600
From: darling@simlab.arc.nasa.gov (Dave Darling)
Subject: Re: first autocross

>You didn't finish your statement about Hank taking your car out!  Did you
>win or did the unthinkable take place (Hank beat you in your own car)?

        Unthinkable?  Heck, everyone was impressed that Hank used to beat
Scott by *only* a half-second in Scott's own car!
        Myself, I'm floored (and envious) that someone could, in their first
race of their second season, beat Watts and the Elf!  Regardless of the car
that they were driving!
        I guess Hank can take consolation in the fact that he wasn't beat
by a rookie.   >;->
        Once again, "WOW!"

- --DD

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 20:57:42 -0500
From: SLR944@aol.com
Subject: re;944 wheels

Bruce; Yes you can use "phone dial" wheels on your 84 944 but only from an
83-86 944, in 87 the 944 wheel changed offset.  You can also use fuchs wheels
from a 911 up to 89, there are plenty of them around for prices in the
$100-250 range depending on condition, phone dials are even cheaper.

                       Steve

ps if you are interested in some fuchs, drop me a line at slr944@aol.com and
I can connect you with a friend who has numerous wheels for sale.

Date: 22 Feb 95 22:00:43 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsches on TV

 
Christian Pret objects to
>Europhobic rubbish.
 
I'm allowed to say anything "Europhobic" I want, as I carry an EC passport.
I still think Europeans can't build airplanes for squat -- uh, "merde."
Cars, yes. Airplanes, no; they were invented in the U.S. and the best ones
are still built here. If/when the U.S. is no longer able to build world class
airplanes, it will indicate a larger problem and it will be time to leave,
maybe for Australia or someplace new.
 
(Later) Funny that this subject should come up at just this time. Today
France asked that some U.S. diplomats be expelled on charges of industrial
espionage. The U.S. media reports that for two years, the French have been
looking for a way to retaliate for some French nationals being expelled for
espionage in the U.S. aerospace industry, particulary commercial airliners.
And that there is a continuing French industrial espionage campaign to steal
U.S. high tech trade secrets. Whether all these charges and countercharges
are true or not, I don't know. I'm just repeating what the idiot box in the
living room says. If this is true, perhaps theft is the sincerest form of
approval for America's aerospace and high tech capability.
 
Pete

------------------------------

Date: 22 Feb 95 22:00:56 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Strange but true electrical stories

 
While I was at Rodent Track, we had a Sterling (British copy of Acura
Legend, but with Lucasbits or equivalent thrown in for good measure). With
the radio turned off (CLICKED off, not just with volume down), you could
hear the last selected radio station in the left door speaker, keeping time
with the turn signal when the left turn signal was turned on. But not the
right turn signal.
 
I once saw a 924 in the Porsche parking lot with some sort of electrical
problem. Car locked, key out of ignition, owner already at work, the car
would continuously raise and lower its headlights. Up, down. Up, down. Until
they found the owner, and he pulled the fuse.
 
One of my favorite non-electrical problems was a one-year test of a Saab
(900? 9000?) at Rodent Track. It went through three transmissions in less
than a year. The last straw was when somebody went for the shift lever, the
shift knob disconnected itself from the shaft, and the reverse lockout
spring sent it sailing out through the open sunroof, never to be seen again.
At that point they gave the car back. Saab never could make decent
transmissions (personal experience with Saab 97/Sonnett confirms this).
 
There. Have I offended enough people for one day? Good. Flames keep my
heating bill down; California houses aren't insulated very well.
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 20:21:04 -0700
From: mhatch@utg.org (Mark Hatch)
Subject: Air Compressors

Althought this might have been said by someone else...


There is a difference between oil-less and oil compressors. Oil-less are
lower maintenance and do not require a separate filter before your spray
gun (but unless you live in Arizona you will need a filter anyway to get
rid of the condensation). However, oil-less require overhauls sooner than
those that use oil (assuming you remember to keep them filled with oil...).
I have also been told (no experience here) that having a compressor that
takes oil reduces the amount of oil you need to feed your air tools to
prevent them from wearing out. Every air tool that I have has a separate
oil feeder between the compressor and the tool to ensure that the tools are
lubricated.


I ended up buying a sears 6hp compressor oil-less (the largest you can run
on 220) and still regret that I didn't get a bigger one! When ever I use my
DA sander the compressor is on continuously! If you look for the Craftsmans
days you can get an extra 10-15% which helps to put a bigger compressor in
your garage!

mark

Date: Wed, 22 Feb 1995 19:43:37 -0800 (PST)
From: mpl@netcom.com (Mike Lommatzsch)
Subject: Re: Original Steering Wheel & Weber Question

Hi Rich -

You didn't mention what kind of Weber carb's you had, but if they are 
anything like mine (40IDF's) then those tubes sticking out of the top are 
called "emulsion tubes".  The tubes hold the main jet (bottom pointed 
piece towards intakes manifolds) and the air correction jet (hidden 
inside the top of the tube after you remove emulsion tube holder which is 
just a tight fit like the main jet.  The emulsion tube is set by the 
situation of the use of the carbs (generally) and then the jets are 
adjusted per situation as needed (like altitude/temperature/humidity).  
Aagain, this is very basic information and is not to be taken as final as 
all different cars and situations require different jets, emulsion tubes 
or air correction jets.  BTW, the idle jet is located elsewhere in the 
carburetor.

If I'm wrong with this I am sure someone will correct you and me!

For more information about the Weber carbs I suggest you purchase the 
Haynes book on Weber Carburetors.

Mike Lommatzsch

PCA-LPR/SVR/GGR
SCCA-SFR/RR

snipe....

> WEBER QUESTION: what are the tubes that stick out of the top of the carbs in

> only 2 on each carb? The Webers in question are on a '67 911.
>
> Rich Lambert

> '89 Carrera Targa

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 00:09:25 -0500
From: Tedd9146@aol.com
Subject: Re: Air comp thread bare...

Alex commented:

>  Yup - The 220 volt compressor are lots cheaper to run, and in fact
>  the larger compressors (15+ CFM) can suck up to 30 Amps of 220 Volt.
>  Big motors :-)

I'm probably running behine in the posts on "the philes", and somebody
smarter than me (99% out there?) correct me if I'm wrong, but the equations
E=IR and P=EI comes to mind.  You'll probably not notice much difference in
your electric bill by using 220V. 
     P = Power used measured in watts (usually billed in kWs)
     E = Electromative force (voltage)
     I = Current (amps) If you check the spec tag on the electric motor of
the comp (or whatever else) you'll in most cases see that you'll use the same
'wattage'. The 220 gear usually runs on half the amperage  of running the
same equipment on 115.  Equated (is that a real word?) out, the billed
wattage will be , for all praticle purposes, the same. A 220 unit will
probably "spool" up easier and maybe be a little more efficient (maybe also
because they're usually more expensive they'll last longer), but again for
the price differential of the original prices (115 vs 220) cost of operation
is generally the same. 

I do concur that the CFM or SCFM is of major concern. If you're going to use
high volume air consuming tools, it's really necessary to purchase probably
 at LEAST a 10CFM machine. I weld for an occupation (Don't tell my MOM. She
thinks I'm a piano player in a Whore house.) and I do need at least decent
air delivery for even the basic tools I use (I.E. - die grinders. bead
blaster , etc.)

I hope any of this can be of any help.

((   Hi Pat  8-)    )) 

Tedd 
 '70  914-6 Recently revitalized, almost like Sean talked about
                  (still 2.0 L, but w/E "stuff")(Future reserves heavily
burdened -
                   i.e. - plastic will smoke for awhile!!!)      
 '70  911T (sell?)
 '84 944 (SO's cruiser)
 '85 Porsche "Astro van"(?) Pulls the 'six' when we can borrow a trailer or
    
                                           when I build one!)

case brought against Lucas for this, can't remember the outcome.

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 8:54:42 -0500 (EST)
From: Pat Roberson <root@patrick.mdn.com>
Subject: RE: Hydraulic fluid- sealer...


>	This a special request to the large majority of Porsche
>	owners that also own Audis.  I have heard of a sealant
>	alcohol base fluid that can be used in the hydraulic steering
>	pump.  My pump is starting to leak at the seams.  This
>	sealant fluid expands the O rings to reseal the case. I have
>	yet to be able to find the name and where it can be
>	purchases.  Any help out there would be appreciated.  
>	Paul Zanussi


Paul, I have a 5000CST and had the same problem with the hyd pump, 
leaking around the o-ring seals.  I would not recommed adding anything
to the mineral based fluid.  If you can, take the time to replace the 
O-rings.  It is relativly simple and the kit is about $30.00 at the
dealer.  I have heard of some lower cost kits via mail order.

My $.02 worth.

Pat Roberson

'72S Targa
'79SC
'86 5000CST (w/191k miles and original hyd pump)

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 10:48:37 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Rear View mirror adhesive

Most mirrors clamp (with a little locking screw) onto a little U shaped block
that glues directly to the glass. If yours is like this you can get the glue
(Mirror Adhesive) at any auto parts store, it comes as a two-part mixture.

Be careful that you replace the base corectly, it is bevelled, the wider
surface goes away from the glass.

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 11:08:55 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: re: compressor size to buy

>     I really don't know what a big tank gives you except that its a pain to 
>     move. For any continous use (sandblasting or sanding) the compressor is
>     going to run all the time anyway.

The big tank gives you a more consistent feed pressure. High volume in the
feed lines also helps in that regard (1-1/2" pipes). The converse is that
it takes longer to come up to pressure.

> Two stage supposedly only gives you 
>     higher pressure, not higher thru-put (I've heard both ways...) and you
>     just don't need over 100psi....

I've had to crank the pressure up to 125 at times to get enough effect from
the impact wrench. Naturally, I realize that the wrench is rated at 90psi and
this will shorten its life...

>     I do suggest 230 volt operation at 4hp and above.

Unless you cheat (like by using an illegal circuit breaker) you can't
get more than 2.5 hp from a 110 volt line.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com
