Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 11:22:37 -0500 (EST)
From: Jay Karolyi <jkarolyi@southern.edu>
Subject: 924s & Pacers?  I think not...

Greetings Porsche dwellers,
	Responding to Pete's idea about 924 and Pacers sharing parts, I 
think he's a bit confused.  First of all, the "parts" (meaning engine) 
referred to are found in either a '77 or '78 Gremlin or Concorde, not the 
Pacer.  According to my research, AMC used the original Audi carbureted  
engine, which is what Porsche BASED its design on.  The engine was 
significantly reworked for the 924 and as I understand it NO parts are 
interchangeable.  I looked at an Audi engined Gremlin once, and while 
some things looked familiar, like the timing belt cover, everything else 
looked much different than my 924.  If I'm wrong about this please let me 
know.

Jay Karolyi
'77 Lima bean green 924  NC plate  NOSBST2T

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 17:51:41 +0100
From: Pierre Fournet-fayard <fournet@ilm.loria.fr>
Subject: Air cooled motors: why ?



Maybe this has already been discussed many times.  If so, simply ignore
this mail.

`What are the main advantages of air cooling a motor ?'

My opinion is that:
 - it's easier to design,
 - it increases power since there's no water pump to move,
 - it reduces the weight.

If so, why don't we see more air-cooled cars ?

Is there a *big* default with this design I forget ?
... like an erractic fuel consumption because the motor is not running at
a constant temperature ?


Pierre F-F.
`a good process is a dead process'

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 11:53:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: spark plugs


Ed,

>what's a "heat line"?

On the top electrode, that is the L-shaped one, you'll notice a change
in the colour/deposits on it about half way down.  That's the heat line.

Kevin

means.  He's a good instructor, and *really* knows how to organize a
school.

their *own* car!  So beating him and his "race" car (the Elf, pictured on

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 12:37:47 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Air cooled motors: why ?

> `What are the main advantages of air cooling a motor ?'
> My opinion is that:
> - it's easier to design,

It isn't. Not really. You still have to worry about most of the
same issues, and the thermodynamic analysis is no less complex.
The parts count may be lower, and you don't have to design coolant
galleys, but you have to design air flow, shrouding, thermostats, etc.

> - it increases power since there's no water pump to move,

But there's more air flow needed, so you need a bigger (more power-depleting)
fan.

> - it reduces the weight.

Maybe. You don't have the coolant and you don't have the radiator, but
you have to put fins on the cylinders, and the oil cooler has to be
more effective.

> If so, why don't we see more air-cooled cars ?
> Is there a *big* default with this design I forget ?

Noise is an issue in air-cooled vs. water-cooled motorcycles -
the two-strokes that I used to love are now all water-cooled 
primarily for this reason. Specific power vs. cooling capacity
also appears to have its limitations.


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 10:26:30 -0800
From: jeffk914@ix.netcom.com (Jeff Kyle)
Subject: Re:Ignition Wires

>Will Hartje asked why 944 ignition wires cost so much.  Without
>being to flip about it, I think the answer is that anything
>associated with the Porsche name costs "so much."  I don't see
>any reason why you, Will, can't buy a hunk of 'regular car'
>ignition wire and use that, or buy a set if you can't get it
>by the foot and cut it to suit your needs.  That's what I'd
>do.

There is a difference between generic parts and factory parts, 
often a huge difference. If you get the factory part, you know it's 
gonna be the right part for the right car, not a part for a totally 
different car adapted to work on your car. German cars are often 
set up quite different from American cars, and a lot of wear items 
rarely, if ever, need replacing on German cars (ie, spark plug 
wires, radiator hoses, etc.)
I think if you guys would check into it, you'd find that your dealer 
is not as outrageous as you might think on a lot of stuff - in fact, 
I've compared a lot of dealer prices to prices from aftermarket 
Porsche supply houses, and in the majority of the ones I checked, 
the dealer retail was less - something, significantly less.

Anyways, to make a long post short, you get what you pay for.

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 13:33:49 -0500
From: HSpiva@aol.com
Subject: Odd shifting 86 Carrera

Like Mike, I also have been having trouble with shifting my 86 Carrera in
gears 1 & 2. 
I bought the car with 112,xxx miles on it, and figured it was the synchros.
When my clutch failed, I had the dealership [big mistake I now know] take a
look in the tranny and prepare to replace the sychros. As I plan to autocross
the car, I wanted a tranny in top condition. The repair order called for
replacing gears 1-3 and reverse. ARGH. The service rep said they could just
replace the "dog teeth" pre-gears for much less, and it would essentially be
the same. I said OK and after over $3K [not counting the clutch cable I had
to replace later], 4K miles and six months, it still shifts roughly.

I brought it back in and they said that they found metal shavings at the
drain plug, and I probably need the new gears anyway! Also the "dog teeth"
were not Porsche parts, so the usual warranty is null and void. When I
protested, the threw around the word "abuse".

The car simply does not shift smoothly and consistantly. I never shift into
1st without going thru 2nd and only while stopped, yet sometimes I cannot get
into 1st and other times its 2nd. Periodically, when upshifting, I need lots
of force to shift into second. 

Another mechanic seems to think it is the shifter. I had Porsche install a
short shift kit with the tranny work, but I feel no difference. I think I
have been screwed. I plan on writing PCNA and cc'ing Excellence, PCA and the
local newspaper. I plan on getting this examined more closely, but am
rightfully short on funds.
Any advice?

The dealership is Crescent City Motors in New Orleans. Stay away from their
service dept. at all costs.

Here comes the torch.  I'm sure that most know that the Tiptronic is very 
similar to the electronic transmisions currently used in Formula 1 racing where 
gears can be changed with the flip of a stearing wheel mounted switch.  Granted 
that the Porsche Tiptronic has two modes - automatic and manual (by wire) 
shifting.  I have not personaly experienced this machine but have been told by 
those that have, that there is greater control going into and coming out of 
turns, not to mention the additional safety of shifting with both hands on the 
wheel.  If anyone can, Porsche will redefine "sports car".

Craig Z.

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 13:54:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: Air cooled motors: why ?


In addition to what John L. mentions, I'm aware of a couple of other
limitations.  First has to do with emissions and mileage.  Apparently
there are limits in an air-cooled engine.  I am not sure what the reasons
are for these, but suspect they may have to do with component
temperatures (limit comression ratios?).

The second is multi-valving.  You cannot multi-valve an air cooled
engine.

It also seems true that a loss of air cooling has much quicker and
fatal consequences than, say, a water pump failure.  If you throw a
fan belt in a 911, esp. at the track, bad things happen very quickly.
Perhaps this is simply a 911 quirk.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 13:39:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Have '86 944  overheating any suggestions plz


Rodger,

You probably don't need all those expensive parts.  You mention that
your car has started running hot.  Did you perform (or have performed)
any significant service to the car recently?  If so, perhaps something
there explains the problem -- perhaps the coolant was changed but not
fully bled.

If not, the first thing to do is check the coolant thermostat, which inserts 
into
the neck of your water pump.  They do fail with age, and are straightforward
to replace.  You can take the old one out, check it with a pot of water
and cooking thermometer on your stove.  But as a practical matter, get
a new one, pop it in, and be done with it.  They're cheap.

What happens when the thermostat fails is that it does not open (enough),
allowing coolant running through the engine to circulate through the
radiator.  During warm-up, the radiator is bypassed so that the coolant
isn't cooled, which speeds up the process of bring the whole engine into
its ideal operating temperature range.

(911's do the same thing with their oil thermostat, bypassing the cooling
loop or radiator.  And 944 Turbos have an oil thermostat built into their
oil filter base.  Both of these guys also fail.  However, unless you have
been clever enough to fit an oil temp sender and gauge to your car,
you might never know about a failure with a 944 Turbo.  I had a case
last winter where my oil thermostat failed open, and my oil temp would
never get above 120F, even after a long drive.  Putting my hand on the
warm oil radiator convinced me of what was wrong.)

In replacing the coolant thermostat, you'll have to know which version
of the water pump you have in your car.  The newer pumps take a
different spacing rubber ring.  This is covered in a tech bulletin which is
reprinted in the EuroSelect catalog.

You mention pricing and sources.  I would avoid EuroSelect rebuilt pumps
if it comes to that.  I had my hands on one a few months ago, and it looks
like a real piece of shit.  They go so far (such as that is) as to spray 
paint
it silver to make it look swell.  It ain't.  Sell your old one back to 
Porsche.
Last time I checked they were paying $100 for cores, regardless of whether
you bought a new part from them.

Radiators can get clogged and fail.  I don't have any personal experience
with that sort of failure; they seem to last pretty well if you change the
coolant annually.

Sorry for rattling on so long.  Massive build going on in another window,
and time on my hands...

Kevin Gross

------------------------------

Date: 23 Feb 95 14:31:25 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Porsche Aircraft Engine and Airplanes

 
Oooh, I must have really rattled Martin Walker. Enough flames to not only
heat the house but also to dry the fresh spot paint repair on the 356.
 
>why did the wwii best us single engine fighter p51 (which was shit until
>the d model) use a british (rolls) engine and why was it STILL outrun by
>the british equivalent the spit?
 
Roger A. Freeman, "Mustang at War," p. 20-21: "Flight tests in Britain
showed that war equipped and loaded, the Mustang I [with your despised
Allison engine, I might add] could consistently attain a top speed of 375
mph at 15,000 feet, 35 mph faster than the RAF's standard low/medium
altitude fighter of the day, the Spitfire V. The Mustang was heavier than
the Spitfire V -- around 8600 lbs. loaded as against 6,900 lbs... above
15,000 ft, the Mustang fell away due to lack of any supercharging on the
Allison."  "During February [1942] they were pitted against the RAF
Spitfires and other types in comparison tests from which the Mustang emerged
with a great deal of credit and little in default. The report rated the
aircraft with a high standard of manufacture with good servicing
facilities." [From what I've read, the Spitfire was a kludge by comparison.]
"Its four hour endurance was about double that of the Spitfire or other
contemporary single-engine fighters." "In comparison tests the Mustang
proved faster than the Spitfire VB in level flight up to 20,000 feet."
 
p. 52: "This design study credited the Merlin 61-powered version of the
Mustang with a performance equal to, or better than, a Spitfire using the
same engine."  p. 53: "Manufacture of the Merlin in the USA had been
arranged during 1940 and by 1942 this engine was in full production at the
Packard factory in Detroit." The P51 did not use a Rolls-Royce engine; it
used a mass produced, American-built engine of Rolls-Royce DESIGN.
 
>why did the raf laugh at the 8th air-force
 
I don't know. Too much gin in their tonic?
 
>because the b-17 was a shit airplane until very late in the war. it's had a
>pitifully small payload - infact it carried more weight in defensive
>payload (bullits) then it carried in bombs !
 
The USAAF carried that many, uh, "bullits" because they usually had to fight
their way TO the target, and then BACK again, in daylight. RAF Bomber Command
had no such problem: go at night, when you can't find the radar-equipped enemy
fighters anyway until his tracers find YOU -- hope the radar flak doesn't
get you, dump your bombs in the general vicinity of a large city, and go home.
 
Lancaster I bomb load -- max 18,000 lbs., service ceiling 22,000 ft.
Lancaster II bomb load -- max. 14,000 lbs. Service ceiling 18,500 ft.
B17 E&F -- 8000 lbs. Service ceiling unknown but top speed is at 25,000 ft.
B17G as of Sept. 43 (NOT that "late in the war"), 16,000 lbs., service
ceiling 35,600 ft; the B-17G could operate at 25,000 ft for 6 hours.
The 8th AF routinely flew up around 30,000 ft.
 
There is a big difference between carrying bombs to the mid-teens, nearly
unopposed, at night, and carrying them to more than twice that altitude, in
daylight, against an entire hostile air force full of FW190s and Bf109Gs,
where pilots with over 100 kills were not unusual. Most USAAF crews did not
survive to their 25th mission, winding up in POW camps. Many RAF crews
survived an entire war of night missions.
 
But if you want to play hardball, with equipment of the same era,
B29 -- 16,000 lbs over longer distances, or any nukes you happen to have...
 
Whittle -- Very nice but he kilt hisself in his own device and the Me-262
went into service sooner. Everybody got jets at about the same time,
 
Geez, Martin, you shouldn't get so emotional about these things. Your
spelling and punctuation goes all to hell. Veddy unBritish, you know...
 
<g>
 
Pete
 


------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 14:45:28 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: Air cooled motors: why ?

> In addition to what John L. mentions, I'm aware of a couple of other
> limitations.  First has to do with emissions and mileage.  Apparently
> there are limits in an air-cooled engine.  I am not sure what the reasons
> are for these, but suspect they may have to do with component
> temperatures (limit comression ratios?).

Component temps is part of it. You can't run lean-burn on an engine
for which the latent heat of vaporization of the (richer) fuel has already
been taken into account in designing the cooling system.

> It also seems true that a loss of air cooling has much quicker and
> fatal consequences than, say, a water pump failure.  If you throw a
> fan belt in a 911, esp. at the track, bad things happen very quickly.
> Perhaps this is simply a 911 quirk.

No, that's a generic air cooled quirk. Water cooled engines can boil off
a fair bit of coolant before the temperature starts to soar. Air cooled
engines can't boil anything (except maybe the oil, in which case "too late").


- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 14:53:31 EST
From: sdandeka@chipcom.com (Shirish Dandekar)
Subject: 911 Test Drive

This past weekend I had the opportunity to test drive a couple of 911s.
I test drove 86, 87 and 89 model years. I found the 86 to be extremely
dificult to shift. When I was down shifting I kept missing the gears.
The car had only 26K miles on it. I had no trouble with the 87 or 89.

I read that Porsche changed to the G50 transmission in 87, but I didn't
think it would make that big a difference. Are the pre-87 transmission
prone to failure at such a low mileage? Since that test drive I've been
focusing on 87 thru 89 911s. However, there seem to be alot more 84-86 
avalable. Was this just an isolated case or are the 915 transmissions
less reliable than the G50s?

	-RISH-

> headliner after too much of that vending machine Pils...
 
ha ha ha
pretty funny Reid.
 
Strangest auto electrical problem I have dealt with was while
installing an aftermarket tape deck/radio in my RX-7 and trying
to get the automatic antenna to work. When I first hooked
it up, it would go down when I turned the radio on, and it would
go up when I turned the radio off. Finally fixed it by installing
a relay and changing the polarity of the signal from the radio
to the antenna.

2 weeks, so my rebuild is stalled until I get back.

Valve adjusting screws 
rocker bushings
Camshaft timing gears 
Intermediate shaft gear(s)?
 
What should I look for on my cams to see if they're ok?

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 14:53:52 -0600 (CST)
From: "Dr. Keith Kenitzer" <kenitkw@ndlc.occ.uky.edu>
Subject: Original Steering Wheel?

According to The 911 &912 Porsche, A Restorer's Guide To Authenticity:

The standard steering wheel on 912s was a black plastic-rimmed wheel, 
described as hard rubber and Ebonite in subsequent versions.  Also 
available as an option was a wood wheel similar to the standard 911 
wheel.  All wheels had four spokes and were 400 mm in diameter.  They 
were available in a "projecting hub" version.  Also available with a 
rectangular "butterfly" horn ring.  For more info check out the reference 
listed above.

My '66 912 has an aftermarket steering wheel, a Racemark.  It is a THICK 
leather covered wheel.  I like it a lot and when I finally restore my car 
it will be one of the few aftermarket items that I will include on the car.

Hope that helps.

Keith Kenitzer
'66 912 (disabled)

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 15:53:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Odd shifting 86 Carrera


HSpiva,

Couple of bits of info.  First is that in the 911 gear boxes, the dog gears
are indeed replaceable separately from (and much cheaper than) the
main gear.  However, the separate dogs are *not* available from PCNA,
only in the aftermarket.  That the dealer offered you this path is pretty
progressive, I'd say.  Most wouldn't, although perhaps with the arrival
and acceptance of the EuroSelect line, dealerships may nowadays be
a little less dogmatic about non-factory parts.

I can understand them mentioning the word "abuse" if they found metal
in the drain.  Dog teeth don't fall off by themselves.

A short shift kit won't help.  In fact, it will hurt because the shorter 
throw
gives you less "dynamic range," for wont of a better term, in which to
feel the transmission engaging and disengaging.  I personally find the
gating of the 915 really close, and it doesn't surprise me that it people
mis-shift them as often as they seem to.

You may indeed have a shift linkage problem.  However, I can't imagine
not feeling the problem from the get-go after the original rebuild.  Did it
shift poorly right away, or was there a deterioration over time?

Hope this helps,

Kevin Gross

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 16:36:00 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Have '86 944 overheating ...

How recently have you flushed your system?

 Do you run with distilled water in it?

Here in Arizona, where summer heat is a potential problem I run with
distilled water and Red Line "Water Wetter". Anti -freeze not only stops
water from freezing, it reduces you cooling system's capacity to cool the
engine.

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 13:48:05 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Who's Hank Watts

Re: Who's Hank Watts?

If you can remember back to Franz Klammer's amazing downhill run in the
'76 Winter Olympics -- staying *right at the very limit* for most of the
run and seemingly beyond for parts of it -- you will have an idea of 
Hank's style.  Yeah I know... all racers do that... but seldom is it as
obvious even to the casual observer... or to the clock.  My tour of
Sears Point in his '83 cab at 115 mph remains deeply etched in my mind!

Plus as indicated he's a genuinely nice guy.  Say, how come he's not on
here to defend himself against all this deification?

 -Ed

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 15:34:32 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: re; 924s and Pacers 


>Subject: 924s & Pacers?  I think not...

>Greetings Porsche dwellers,
>        Responding to Pete's idea about 924 and Pacers sharing parts, I
>think he's a bit confused.  First of all, the "parts" (meaning engine)
>referred to are found in either a '77 or '78 Gremlin or Concorde, not the
>Pacer.  According to my research, AMC used the original Audi carbureted
>engine, which is what Porsche BASED its design on.  The engine was
>significantly reworked for the 924 and as I understand it NO parts are
>interchangeable.  I looked at an Audi engined Gremlin once, and while
>some things looked familiar, like the timing belt cover, everything else
>looked much different than my 924.  If I'm wrong about this please let me
>know.

>Jay Karolyi
>'77 Lima bean green 924  NC plate  NOSBST2T 

    AMC referred to this as a "Porsche" motor, not an Audi. In Gremlin
  tune it sported something like 80hp versus Porsches' 95hp. I've got both
  a 924 and a Gremlin engine in my garage (oh boy...). They are the same
  motor, the differences are in the fuel (single Holley 2 barrel, something 
  like 250 cfm I think)  for the Gremlin and ignition (Electronic for 
  Porsche). The plumbing around it is different, of course, and the Porsche
  includes a very beautfifully made cast-aluminum oil pan and valve cover 
  (both deep drawn steel on the Gremlin).

     The head differs in that Porsche taps the intakes for the fuel injectors.
  If you could find a 20-some millimeter tap you could convert the Gremlin
  head to a Porsche 924 head. Adapting the Gemlin carb and intake to the
  Porsche is possible but difficult, since the 924 mounted the engine at
  a 40' angle and the Gremlin sat straight up, the Gremlin intake will list
  out of the top of your hood.

     You can usually find parts cheaper if you quote the Gremlin application
   instead of the 924, of course. These are impressively stout motors on the
   bottom end, though, they look like they could have delivered some high RPM.

     The real bummer is that this was the -small- motor for the Gremlin.
  Its more likely that the Gremlin next to you at a stoplight has a 
  6-cylinder, so don't get cocky and race for pink slips.... :)

            Lee A. derelict '77 924 and other twisted wreckage...




------------------------------

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 16:55:52 -0500
From: BLenoble@aol.com
Subject: Should I Purchase this car?

I have an opportunity to purchase a 911 at a very good price. This car
started life as a '78 SC, and has been converted to 84+ Carerra specs. This
included the motor being updated to 3.2l with pressure fed cam chain tens.
When the engine was rebuilt, the head was ported and polished, and the
catalytic converter was removed. The rubber clutch has also been updated. I
don't know if the car has CIS, DME, or carbs.

The body was modified by adding a Carerra rear spoiler. The car has Carerra
Fuchs wheels, with Turbo tie rods and Turbo brakes. The suspension was also
upgraded, but I'm not exactly sure how. What are turbo tie rods?

The car was originally brown, but was repainted red some time ago. The paint
is in poor condition and definately needs to be repainted. The interior also
needs some work. It has some old Recaro cloth seats that have faded and have
some rips. The headliner is also coming down.

I can buy the car for about $10,000. What would a good paint job cost? how
about the interior work? Should I buy new seats, or get the Recaros
reupholstered? Also, in NY the emissions are tested. I ssume this means that
I will have to have a catalytic converter installed. How much is this?

One final question. I am selling my 86 944. I was originally going to
purchase a 944 S2 or Turbo S. How would the 911 compare in performance? This
car is not going to be my daily ride, so I am unconcerned with ride quality,
driving in bad weather conditions, etc. Which car would be faster on the
track, easier to drive, etc? 

Thanks in advance.

Barry Lenoble
BLenoble@AOL.COM

86 944 (For sale!)
Nothing clever to add here

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 13:56:48 PST
From: Miq Millman <mmillman@ptdcs2.intel.com>
Subject: SWB suspension setups

Background:
I started to get some work done on my '66 911S, I wanted to raise up the rear
a bit (3/4"), get the front end a bit level (the drivers side is about 1"
higher) and put in a decent alignment in it.  

Everything is stock in the car, and the rear torsion bars were resting
against the top of the bushing mounts.  (IE I need to replace them)

Since I'm going to have to disassemble the whole thing, now is a good time to
change to bigger bars.  Stock has 19mm front and 22mm rear I believe.  This
car is mainly to bomb around on back roads and take to an occaisional
driver's event.  I'd prefer performance to comfort. 

Questions:

What is a good size rear tube to put in?  Should I go for the 23mm out of the
73-77?  25mm?  Because the car is a short wheel base, I don't want to go too
stiff, or I'll end up feeling like the teacup ride at Disneyland.

Does anyone have the specs on the 67 911R?  what was used in those?

How about a recommended size for the anti-sway bar?  It doesn't have one in
the back right now.   

If I add one, should I change the front?  if so to what size?

Shocks are yellow/orange Koni sports in the rear, Boge with Koni inserts in the
front (grey)

Last question, has anyone tried to put the turbo-tie rods on a pre 67?  will
this work?  I have both a set of originals and a set of turbo tie rods, both
unused.  I remember that this is a good thing to do, but not the reasons
behind it.

Thanks for the quick (hopefully) help in advance

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 17:21:14 -0500
From: NeilK356@aol.com
Subject: Carrera 4 vs other AWD cars

Hi,

A couple of months ago there was a discussion of whether a Carrera 2 or 4
would be better in the snow. Well in the Feb. 10 issue of the German car
magazine, Auto, motor und Sport, there was a comparison test of 4 wheel drive
cars in the snow. They tested the Audi A8 4.2, Porsche Carrera 4, Range
Rover, Subaru Impreza and the Golf VR6 Synchro. The Carrera 4 came in last in
acceleration tests on snow: 0-30/kmh (3.3 sec) and 0-60/kmh (7.8 sec), but
first in braking. In acceleration tests on snow, they could spin the rear
wheels while the front tires didn't move. The testers complained that not
enough torque was being transferred to the front wheels and thought that
there was a problem with the viscous coupling but in subsequent tests with 2
other Carrera 4 the same thing happened. Auto, Motor und Sport spoke to the
head of development at Porsche, Horst Marchart who said, "Traction wasn't our
utmost priority in our all-wheel drive concept, but rather first class
handling." Which means that they wanted to avoid the understeer that plagued
the early Carrera 4. Their conclusion was that the Carrera 4 is an excellent
all-wheel drive car on dry and wet surfaces but on snow it handles more like
a rear wheel drive car. The authors also thought that the Carrera 4 was
probably oriented too much towards good handling rather than traction.

I'd take a Carrera 4 any day. I don't think poor traction in snow is too big
a problem for people who can afford the car in the first place. They can just
take out the Suburban or the Range Rover.

brings to mind the strangest flash I ever saw:

I was in Houston a few years ago, near downtown on Westheimer, when I
pulled up to a red light next to an old battered car full of skinheads.
They were all very agitated and wildly gesticulating toward me. I looked
straight ahead and ignored them until the light changed. At the next light,
I ended up behind a couple of carloads of foreigners in BMWs with
diplomatic plates. Now they were stuck next to the skinheads. The skinheads
couldn't seem to get their attention, and next thing I knew, a couple of
them were mooning the diplomats, with their cheeks pressed against
the windows.

I drove a tiptronic 968 before I bought my six-speed.  I really liked it.  
The real problem was that 4 forward gears in the tiptronic was not enough.  
It's a nice transmission though - very smooth.  It's also $3000 more than 
the six-speed. The six-speed, BTW, is *wonderful*.

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 21:06:48 -0500
From: MLBDayton@aol.com
Subject: Re :  915s vs G50s

>This past weekend I had the opportunity to test drive a couple of 911s.
>I test drove 86, 87 and 89 model years. I found the 86 to be extremely
>dificult to shift. When I was down shifting I kept missing the gears.
>The car had only 26K miles on it. I had no trouble with the 87 or 89.

Everyone's perception of "difficult shifting" is probably a little different,
but I would not write off all pre-G50 cars unless you find that every 915
equipped car you test drive is "difficult to shift".  I myself have only
driven
a couple of 915-equipped cars that were "difficult" and these were obviously
the result of abuse.

>I read that Porsche changed to the G50 transmission in 87, but I didn't
>think it would make that big a difference. Are the pre-87 transmission
>prone to failure at such a low mileage? Since that test drive I've been
>focusing on 87 thru 89 911s. However, there seem to be alot more 84-86 
>avalable. Was this just an isolated case or are the 915 transmissions
>less reliable than the G50s?

On the contrary, I thought the 915s were pretty stout.  FWIW, my *very*
limited experience driving a car with a G50 led me to believe that it wasn't
*that* much better than the 915s.

Mike Dayton
'76 Euro 911

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 21:43:25 -0500
From: Mrmojo911@aol.com
Subject: 915s vs G50s

Second Mike Dayton's opinion on 915 comparison toG50. I had an 84 911 with
915, and now drive an 88 with G50. Can't say I notice a lot of difference in
the shift action (neither difficult ), but the hydraulic clutch with the G50
is certainly an improvement, especially if you do a lot of urban driving. The
G50 is supposedly a stronger design, but probably hasn't been around long
enough for reliability judgments.

Charles Broome <Mr mojo911@aol.com>

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 22:11:54 EST
From: "Rick Dill" <dill1@watson.ibm.com>
Subject: British .. American  how things happen

Before we entirely condem British cars, one needs to look at some
of the reasons.  The Jaguar engine design was dictated by a rule
taxed the area of the pistons and not the displacement.  The result
was (and I think still is) very tall engines that have higher piston
speeds than almost anything around.  They also had a lot of kit cars
(i.e. Lotus 7) because the tax was lower.  Also, motorcycles were
taxed at lower rate than cars which gave us the Morgan 3-wheeler
among other things.

For those of you with machine shops (all good Porschephiles have
them, don't they), does your lathe use Morse tapers.  Do you
know why the different numbered sizes won't plug more or less
into a long tapered hole.  The design called for something like
5/8" taper per foot, but the first ones made were not accurate.
Since reproduction was initially done by hand fitting each size
has a unique taper.

No one gets it all right.  The Japanese produced a lot or very
little cars because of tax reasons.  It probably made sense.  I
once saw a Caddy coming down a little street in Kyoto.  People
had to move things back from the road to let it pass.

Rick Dill
63-356B ... waiting for the snow to be gone

------------------------------

If "flush" is a verb used in conjunction with your car,  you don't own a
Porsche.  

1. What percentage of the cooling of an "air cooled" 911 is carried out by
the fluid medium of oil?
2. Oil ( Mobil 1) is $ 5.00 per quart.  The 911 takes 12 quarts per change
(oil FLUSH, if you prefer).  Now that works out to $ 60.00 and should be done
four times a year.  Lets see, that's a minimum of      $ 240.00 worth of
coolant per year. 
3. Anti-freeze is $ 6.00 per gallon.  Flush once a year and you have blown
 $12.00.
4. "Evolution tends to improve the species... those who do not conform to
their current environment will expire. ... There are numerous branches... that
 are doomed to failure due to design flaws" Dr. John Howell, Sr.,  commenting
upon the failure of several branches of early man.  
6. Porsche will fluid cool the next generation of 911 heads.  Do I hear a
flushette?
7. Can you say "trailing throttle oversteer".

The above are not necessarily the opinions of the management and in fact we
refuse to confirm or deny the existence of the below.

Larry Reynolds
86 944 Turbo Tracker
90 944S2 Cabrio Waxer
Car Care Specialties, Inc.
E-mail carcaresp@aol.com

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 1995 21:54:05 -0600
From: trevs944@mixcom.com (Trevor Sadler)
Subject: Re:Ignition Wires

At 10:26 am 2/23/95, Jeff Kyle wrote:
>There is a difference between generic parts and factory parts,
>often a huge difference. If you get the factory part, you know it's
>gonna be the right part for the right car, not a part for a totally
>different car adapted to work on your car. German cars are often
>set up quite different from American cars, and a lot of wear items
>rarely, if ever, need replacing on German cars (ie, spark plug
>wires, radiator hoses, etc.)
>I think if you guys would check into it, you'd find that your dealer
>is not as outrageous as you might think on a lot of stuff - in fact,
>I've compared a lot of dealer prices to prices from aftermarket
>Porsche supply houses, and in the majority of the ones I checked,
>the dealer retail was less - something, significantly less.
>
>Anyways, to make a long post short, you get what you pay for.

I will agree with you on this but only to an extent. Any high quality wire
that is well shielded will get energy from point "a" to point "b". There
are certain applications (ignition wires, other high power wires, audio
interconnects, speaker cable) where is it benificial to have good low
oxygen copper that has a good jacket on it. The upper end of the Accel line
of ignition wires seem to be of good quality, and when used with OEM
connectors, I can't see why they wouldn't work (please correct me if i'm
wrong).

On the other hand, I agree that you should not use the $10/set bargain
ignition wires from Wall Mart. The good Accel wires are about $50/set,
which isn't bad compared to the OEM wire sets ...

just my $.02 worth !!!

trev.

Trevor Sadler
Recording Engineer/Producer

'90 Mitsi Eclipse Turbo - "Red Bill"
'93 S.O. unit - "Denise"
'94 Child unit - "Emma"

Pat, 
with all due respect. I agree that drivers shouldn't abuse corner workers,
but I get equally miffed at Stewards who are more regularly than not
suggesting all of the things that "will put you on the trailer for the
weekend".  Lets forget about this power stuff and get on with having good
clean fun. To suggest that habits should change is ok, but to suggest that
someone should go on the trailer for suggesting that a corner worker wan't
doing their job (I am only guessing at the reason) shouldn't be a reason for
the "ultimate" penalty.  Lets not forget that the corner workers are doing it
volunatrily too and the Drivers are paying for the track, the track time
and..., and... etc. Driving is serious stuff and this is supposed to be
racing (I think) and not one at a time "after you...please...thank you"
autocrossing. 

Sorry about going on, but I am concerned that one of the biggest problems
with PCA racing is attitude at the organizer.  I have raced in a lot of
venues and nowhere, yes, nowhere, is there such a sense of officiousness as
at the PCA races I have attended (Second Creek was a pleasant exception).

Date: 23 Feb 95 23:24:33 EST
From: "Eric S. Shea" <73633.1772@compuserve.com>
Subject: Early Parts Available

Hi Gang:

Thanks for your many helpful replys to 71 T Questions.  It seemed that I got
quite a few responses from my trailer "66 911 - Parting Out".  So heres some
information for those of you interested.

I purchased a 66 911 to restore and drive.  The car was a very solid vehicle but
needed its share of TLC.  It was a Texas and Florida car all its life (where
it still rests today in many assorted pieces).  The pan and general
superstructure are in great shape.  The previous owner decided he was going to
race it and did some "interesting"  suspension mods.  1). Bumping up the
suspension pick-up points on the drivers side.  2) Arc welding a steel bar
across the shock towers.  I guess he was going to show those who didnt make
bars for the earlier upper shock mounts??  The car has a roll bar welded into
place and SC flares spot welded on the rear.  The suspension pan has now been
replaced and the shock towers have been put back to original condition (went to
PAR and MIGGED some out of an early car there)  The shell has been acid dipped
and is ready for final body prep and paint.  Theres plenty of parts that go
along with it.  Heres a partial list:

66 911 Shell (acid dipped, no rust) $800,  2.0 Engine 901/05 $1,700, 901
Transmission $600, 2.0/2.2 Headers w/Exhaust $150, BW Rocker Panels (new) $250,
S Front Bumper $100, 66 Rear Bumpers $100, AIR RS Front Bumper (new) $175, AIR
IROC Rear Bumper (new) $175, AIR Carrera Tail (new) $200, 70 Left Front Fender
$200, 70 Right Front Fender $200, Complete 66 Front Suspension $300, Competition
Spring Plates $200, 6 & 7x15 Alloys w/tires $400, Recaro Seats $300, 1971 914
$700  BUYER PAYS SHIPPING.

Ive got all kinds of parts for this car.  Let me know if you need anything.

Date: 23 Feb 1995 08:13:06 U
From: "Nans Kunz" <Nans_Kunz@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: classifieds on line

 2/23/95       7:55 AM        Subject:    classifieds on line

FYI,
For those of you who are shopping for Porsches, Porsche stuff, or just want to
do a price check the San Jose Mercury News (South San Francisco Bay  area) 
publishes parts of their daily newspaper on the Web.  This includes the
classified ads that have a search feature built in.  The other day I put in
the key word Porsche and it came up with 36 matches out of about 9,980 ads.
The URL is:  http://www.sjmercury.com/

Nans Kunz
'86 951 daily driver


------------------------------

Date: 23 Feb 1995 07:27:13 U
From: "Nans Kunz" <Nans_Kunz@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: RE- air compressor size

 2/23/95       6:46 AM        Subject:    RE: air compressor size

Due to the high volume, I only have time to skim digests so I didn't get a
chance to see the original posting of this topic.  However, since I am on my
second compressor I may be able to contribute.  I apologize if this has been
already beat to death.
IMHO an air compressor is one of those tools that you don't realize how
valuable they are until you have one.  Even if you just use it to blow things
off and pump up tires a small air compressor is worth having.  The first air
compressor I bought was just a little 3/4 horsepower with an 8 gallon tank. 
It met most of my needs (blowing, tires, impact tools, occasional painting and
occasional sanding).  The main reason that I upgraded to a bigger compressor
was the peak pressure was only 90psi and there seemed to be a big difference
in the capability of the impact tools as the pressure dropped off.  
When I upgraded, I went to a 2 hp Campbell Hausfield direct drive that goes up
to 125 psi, and delivers 6.3 SCFM at 90 psi.  The reasons were:
1) size, space in my garage is very limited, bigger would have hard to
accommodate.
2) electrical power, 2 hp appeared to be the largest you can plug into 110V,
and I didn't want to have to wire a 230V outlet
3) cost,  obviously  larger would be more expensive.  I think I paid around
$200 dollars. 
Anyway, that was several years ago and I have been very happy with it.  It can
even  keep up with my sander (at about 60 psi).
Nans Kunz
'86 951 daily driver in the carpool lane

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 16:47:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: Re: Air cooled motors: why ?


>OK, now you guys have me worried.  What are the fatal symptoms when I am
>tooling along and the fan belt breaks.  Also, is it easily detectable from
>in the drivers seat so that I can hit the breaks and save myself from
>"bad things" ?  Additionally what are the "bad things" ?

There's an alternator light which comes on when the fan belt fails.  It
is basically invisible to any driving 'hors combat' at a track, but is a 
little
easier to see on the street.

The bad things are, broadly speaking, internal engine damage of many
possible sorts.

K.

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 14:47 PST
From: tfrazer@sonic.net (Thomas Frazer)
Subject: Re: To Tip(ronic) or not?


>(We'll see if this generates any flames.)
Here comes...

>There is no such thing as a sports car with an automatic transmission.

I would certainly consider a Ferrari F1 car a sports car.  I had the
pleasure of driving a C2 with a Tip and it was an absolute blast. The wider
gearing of the 4 speed automatic puts the 993 tiptronic a nearly 1 sec.
disadvantage in 0-60mph versus the 6 speed.  But the real world advantage
in being able to preselect your exit gear should make you a bit faster.
There is also something to be said for moving the lever to D when in a
nasty traffic jam.
Just my $0.02

Tom Frazer
'64 356SC
'91 Audi 200 quattro wagonfromhell
other stuff

	The pilot of this particular 757 gets a F for pre-flight planning, and a
A for in-flight emergency procedures.  He is/was an active glider pilot, and
"just did a normal glider landing".  In a modern jetliner, that has a Lift/Drag
ration of a brick.  With all kinds of passengers on board.  On an ex-airfield
that had people using it for picnics, autocrosses, etc, etc.  Amazing.

baggage system designed and built by BAE (can't remember what the acronym stands
for) and modified and tested by Rapistan.  The baggage system has been working well
for some time now, and you will soon be able to pass through the world's newest
large airport.

	And no, I'm not trusting *my* luggage to the baggage system, but I haven't
done that for 20 years, regardless of which airport I'm at...

Date: Thu, 23 Feb 95 17:20:56 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Porsches on TV

> Pete, I was really with you until you put that slash after the "737"!  The
> 757/767s are undoubtedly the most uncomfortable planes flying.  Boeing has
> just taken ANOTHER inch out of seat width and shortened seat pitch still
[...]

That's funny, I just had 4 flights last week on a 767, 737, Airbus 320, 
and something else.  The Airbus had a really hacked-looking multi-panel 
riveted cover over the engine hanger pod (sorry for improper 
terminology) and some poor fitting slats (paint scraped off main wing 
in spots), but the Recaro seats and interior noise level & panel design 
were pretty good compared to _older_ 7xx's.

The 767 was by far my favorite, as they've drastically cut one of the 
subjectively loudest sounds - the HVAC system.  Lighted seat controls 
and really cool avionics were appreciated too.  Most interestingly, the 
plane's response to turbulence feels a lot better to the seat of my 
pants, as the normal vertical (tension inducing) motions seemed to be 
converted to lateral wiggling, something I can tolerate much better.

All this is completely subjective of course.  I love flying but hate 
being out of control and not knowing what's going on (OK, OK - I admit 
it - I need to be in the cockpit sliding that baby around, just as I do 
in my 951 on the ground!).

		Jim

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 01:03:15 -0500
From: Member5265@aol.com
Subject: 944 TURBO MODS ;mechanic help ?

I have a 1988 944T with the following modifications : level ride height.
 bilstein shocks. strut brace. autothority stage 2 chips with the banjo nut
for extra boost. replaced air box with k & n cone filter. dumped the cat.
converter. 5'' supertrapp stainless exhaust and a modified MFS. 

I have noticed quite a bit of white smoke lately under full thottle
acceleration. Also,  my Bosch platinums seem to have a dry, sootie, black (
carbon? ) residue on the lower one or two threads and the base of the plug.
There is none on the electrode or ceramic tower, they seem to be burning
properly. All of this started after I decreased the tension on the ' barn
door ' in the MFS. I loosened the spring about 8 clicks and noticed that when
I pushed and then released the accel. pedal the RPMs dropped to a very
unconfortable level before the idle stabilizer brought them back to normal.
So I backed off to 3 clicks and curred the problem.

My question is this.  Is it possible that the black plug buildup is occurring
while idleing and that my "quickness" under instant accelleration has indeed
increased with no potentially harmful side effects ?  I know I am creating A
slightly richer mixture by fooling the mfs into thinking that more air is
flowing initially therfore send more fuel.  

Also what do you think about the supertrapp ? It sure sounds good but do you
think I am giving up HP ? Especially low-end. I have tried to use enough
diffusers to increase backpressure from the open exhaust mode.  

Any help or coments is appreciated ( with the exception of my spelling ).
                                     Philip in BHM, AL

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 01:08:03 -0500
From: jbradb@access.mountain.net (J Brad Bellotte)
Subject: For the Airheads and Geeks

This is a question for all the Airheads, Geeks, and people with too much
free time:

A friend and I were having this discussion the other day,  a car is shaped
similar to the wing of an airplane.  I suppose a 944 would be the closest
P-model.  The question then is, how fast would one have to drive to
overcome the weight and drag to become airborn?  We may have to assume that
the front spoiler has been removed and the underside of the car is smooth,
to allow clean airflow, but is this possible to calculate?

I suppose a 928 in Reverse may be a more ideal airfoil, but I don't think
that we could find the cd for a car in reverse.

If this can be calculated, does anyone have enough free time to calculate
it for the different models and post them in order of lift off speed?

J Brad Bellotte

Hey Nate,
Could  you shoot another onw to the list for me.

All this talk of british cars has made me wish to share something. I have
been doing an internship (work for free) at a restoration place that
specializes in Brit metal. I get to learn to paint weld wet sand wire
rebuild . . . on other peoples cars before I do it to mine. First I think
the work for free thing is going to save me a ton of money ince my auto
habits lean towards the classics. Two its been wonderful working Healeys
and MGs. I swear the MGA might just be the prettiest car I have ever seen.
This was when it was parked next to an E-type both of them finished. If
Asked to choose I might just have picked the A.

Second thing I have learned about brit cars is They go together hard, but
come apart easy. It takes days to wire the damn things so blinkers work but
only minutes for them to fail. The P-car 914 by comparison seems to come
apart slow and go togther fairly easily.
Nick

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 09:15:27 -0500
From: dougie@physics.att.com (doug dykaar)
Subject: Re: For the Airheads and Geeks

the problem is not so much lift, as ground effects. a car on the ground has
very different aerodynamics than a car that is already airborne due to the
behavior of air under the car. the real serious F1 teams use rolling road
wind tunnels. as an example, I heard of a pantera that crested a hill at
135mph, and got airborne. made that pesky transition from car to wing. even
those Nascar bricks tended to "loft" before they got air brakes.


doug dykaar
AT&T Bell Laboratories

85 535i
94 850 turbo wagon
groucho the cat

On Thu, 23 Feb 1995 CarcareSp@aol.com wrote:

> 1. What percentage of the cooling of an "air cooled" 911 is carried out by
> the fluid medium of oil?
A little bit, but the oil is also for lubrication.

> 2. Oil ( Mobil 1) is $ 5.00 per quart.  The 911 takes 12 quarts per change
> (oil FLUSH, if you prefer).  Now that works out to $ 60.00 and should be done
> four times a year.  Lets see, that's a minimum of      $ 240.00 worth of
> coolant per year. 
Okay, but then if it's $240 for coolant, then you need no lubricant. Now, 
where do you get this 4 times a year bit? As I recall, synthetic (Mobil 1 
or whatever you prefer) needs changing only twice if even that each year. 
And while we go at new math, Mobil 1 is only $3.50/qt. (here anyways). 
So, for synthetics, the new cost is:
12*2*3.50=$84
If you decide to go with dino juice (which should be changed 4 times a year):
12*4*.90=$43.2

> 3. Anti-freeze is $ 6.00 per gallon.  Flush once a year and you have blown
>  $12.00.
Okay, I'll stick with the $6/gal. Now, you are supposed to change twice 
though, so now you're at $24.

3a. Oil for my water box is the same price as for a Porsche (but the 
water box only needs 5 qts per change)
Synthetics:
5*2*3.5=$35
5*4*.90=$18

So to recap all the math here:
	Porsche Air-Cooled			Wasserboxer
	------------------			-----------
AntiFrz        $0				    $24
DinoJc	       $43.20				    $18
	------------------			-----------
	       $43.20				    $42

Hm. $1.20 more for the Porsche... not a bad deal...

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 95 00:30:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: RE:944S stalling out


Hi  Chris,

The simplest way to take the O2 sensor out of play is to unplug it.  There
is a three-connector plug for it at the back of the fuel rail, underneath 
the
black plastic fuel rail cover and in a white plastic clip.  The DME realizes
that it is unplugged (in fact, simply not electrically available), and runs
"open loop."

Which brings us to your second question.  A system runs "closed loop"
when its output is sampled (fed back) and used to affect the transfer
function.  In the case of a DME, the O2 sensor is used to fine tune the
amount of fuel injected per cycle.  It runs "open loop" when the feedback
path is disabled, ie, opened.

Regarding "lights off," both the catalytic converter and the O2 sensor
work properly only when at operating temperature.  This is why the O2
sensor is ignored by the DME for the first few minutes of operation.  (I
forget exaclt how long.  Depends in part on whether it is an early, single-
wire unit vs. a later three-wire unit.  The later ones have an electric 
heater,
which is the reason for the extra two wires.)

I don't think there's anything wrong with your temperature sensors.  They
rarely go bad.  When I say "temperature related," what I mean is
something which is for some reason affected  by engine temperature.
Warming up the engine can in some cases open up a vacuumleak, in
other cases close it up.  Depends on the faulty piece.

Happy hunting.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 95 00:36:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 Radiator Hose #


Pierre,

>One of them is a lower radiator hose for my 944 85/2 non-turbo, the
>old part # was 944-106-237-02 and I received a 944-106-237-05 instead.

No, you've been given the wrong part.  the .05 is for cars up to MY85, and
is as you observe shorter.  You want the .07 part (944.106.237.07), which
is appropriate for MY85.5 and later non-turbo 944's.

I don't know about the .02 version.  If that was what was stamped on the
old hose, ignore it.  Porsche (or their manufacturers) mislabel hoses all
the time, for some reason.

Kevin

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 10:54:43 -0500
From: RobVial@aol.com
Subject: Re: Wanted: 944 S2 Cab

Last year I bought a 944S2 coupe in Houston.  I went to both dealerships and
searched the paper and Sports Car Trader for about a year before I found the
right one.  

I found mine in the Chronicle Classifieds and the desription seemed to good
to be true.  I took a day off of work, saw the car and brought it to Don
McGill Porsche to have it checked out.  Best 50 bucks you'll ever spend.
 They caught everything like the front and back bumper had been repainted
(wreck?).  I even checked the service records because the car had been
serviced there.

I paid $13,800 for a 1989 S2 with 69,000 miles on it.  No oil leaks, motor
mounts is good shape, new clutch, just had the 60,000 mile ($$$) scheduled
maintenance.  I thought it was a steal.  Convertibles run $10,000 more than
the coupes new but I suspect you could get one for about $5,000 more than a
used coupe.

Give Gerry Reel a call at Don McGill (713-493-1000).  He works the used lot
there.  Tell him what you're looking for and he will call you periodically to
let you know if he has found something.  He aslo lets you test drive anything
on the lot.

Good luck.

Rob

1991 Lumina (Company car.  Never washed.)

Menelaos,

The Autocross version, the BFG R1 226 compound, is no longer available.
The 230 compound is a very nice tire that is better (faster) than any
version of the Yokohama RS tire. I used the Yokohama RS II (autocross
compound) tire last year and switched to the BFG R1 230 compound this
year. I can already tell that it is a much faster tire. My local
competition has to worry a little bit more this year ;-).

Get the BFG R1 230 compound, you will be happy you did.

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 10:02:20 -0500 (EST)
From: "Martin C. Walker,EP,x2517" <martinw@eapi.com>
Subject: For the Airheads and Geeks

  >A friend and I were having this discussion the other day,  a car is shaped
  >similar to the wing of an airplane.  I suppose a 944 would be the closest
  >P-model.  The question then is, how fast would one have to drive to
  >overcome the weight and drag to become airborn?  We may have to assume that
  >the front spoiler has been removed and the underside of the car is smooth,
  >to allow clean airflow, but is this possible to calculate?

If the car is designed properly you will never get airborne !

Cars may in fact have an airfoil shape, but unlike an airplane wing
where the low pressure side is on top (sucking the airplane into the
sky), on a car the low pressure SHOULD form underneath  sucking the
car to the ground.  The faster the bigger the suck (said the actress
to the bishop :-)).

if it were not this way the faster you drove the more uncontrollable
the car would get since there would be less downforce with all the
various problems associated.

bart can tell you how to get a corvette airborne though !

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 01:09:41 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Re: Fan belt breaks ... now what ? (Air cooled motors: why)

Richard Hocking nervously said:

>OK, now you guys have me worried.  What are the fatal symptoms when I am
>tooling along and the fan belt breaks.  Also, is it easily detectable from
>in the drivers seat so that I can hit the breaks and save myself from
>"bad things" ?  Additionally what are the "bad things" ?
>

Richard,

The immediate fatal symptoms are:

(1) The alternator light comes on (same belt as fan)
(2) The temp guage starts climbing at an <unbelievable> rate.
(3) Bad things possible: warped heads, engine seizure, more ...

If you turn off ignition as soon as your brain is able to process the 
information you probably will save the day. Be careful as you coast out of 
traffic and pull over safely.

I'm not sure of newer 911's lock the steering wheel with the ignition off so 
you might want to check that first.

The experience:

Being an electronics geek I had designed an 'exclusive or' circuit (XOR) 
that drives a piezoelectric buzzer between the oil light and alternator 
light. That geekness saved me that day. (I might not have noticed the 
'idiot' light soon enough!)

For non techies an XOR circuit can be designed with just a few diodes so 
that if either light (but NOT both; so that when you turn the ignition on 
the warning does'nt sound) shines you'll be alerted. Costs just a few $$ 
with Radio Shack parts, and easy to install too.

If you check on the belt regularly though this should not be such a concern.

Chris Jungmann                                   jungmann@swcp.com
Software Development                             Voice: 505-275-6566
Northern Systems, Inc.                           Fax:   203-373-0880
                                                 BBS:   203-373-0881

                       you never know what it will drag in:-)

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 11:13:36 +0100
From: Pierre Fournet-fayard <fournet@ilm.loria.fr>
Subject: Re: For the Airheads and Geeks (long, sorry)


You wrote:
>A friend and I were having this discussion the other day,  a car is shaped
>similar to the wing of an airplane.  I suppose a 944 would be the closest
>P-model.  The question then is, how fast would one have to drive to
>overcome the weight and drag to become airborn?

Well.  I don't know where to find it, but there are some very important
quantities called Cx, Cy, Cz (may be the names are different in US) that
describe the car in aerodynamic terms.  Usually, only Cx is given.
It's around 0.30 .
(axis x is the horizontal one, y is lateral and z is vertical)

For instance, the Cx quantity allows you to compute the aerodynamic force
in the horizontal direction.

Fx = 0.5 x Sx x Cx x U^2 x p

where U is the car's speed in meters per seconds,
p is the density of air in kg per m^3 (around 1.3),
Sx is the suface exposed to the air in m^2 (try to imagine the
shadow of your car if you stands just in front of it, it's the surface
the wind will `see').

The force is in newtons (N).

You drive at 130 km/h (36 m/s), with a Cx=0.30, and a Sx=1.5 m^2:
Fx = 0.5 x 1.5 x 0.30 x 36^2 x 1.3 = 380 N

The aerodynamic power is P = Fx x U = 13650 W = 20 hp
(remember it's at a constant speed and there are some other power
losses like tires.  In fact, you need more power to run at 130 km/h)

>I suppose a 928 in Reverse may be a more ideal airfoil, but I don't think
>that we could find the cd for a car in reverse.

After the rear tiny wheels, here comes the reversed race flying car :-))

>If this can be calculated, does anyone have enough free time to calculate
>it for the different models and post them in order of lift off speed?

Back to the problem of changing a 928 to an airplane.

Yes, you're right.  Some cars used to have a negative Cz.  It simply means
that their road holding decreased if the speed was getting higher.

That doesn't happens if the car is well designed (like a P' one).  I'm
told that the duck tail increased the weight of 40 kilos more at 130 km/h
(take it as a typical value, not a factory one).

If you want to transform your car in a plane, you will have to measure what is
Sz x Cz.  If Sz x Cz is negative, it'll mean that the more the speend grows, the
less the car will weight.

The is the car mass is M (in kilos), it weights g x M newtons.

The speed to reach will be as

Fz = 0.5 x SCz x U^2 x p = g x M

so U = sqrt ( (g x M x 2) / (SCz x p) ).

But it's not easy to measured the SzCz quantity and very hard to computed
(excepted you have very precised plans and the right program to do it).

May be the best to do is to ask directly PCNA or the factory to obtain
those figures.


That's all for today, you can leave school.  Thanks for coming.

Pierre F-F.


NB : I don't want to start an aerodynamic flame war, but I'm not
     sure that Fz depends of Sz.  But it doesn't matter as you'll measure
     the product SzCz when you test a car.

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 15:01:05 -0500 (EST)

------------------------------

Date: 24 Feb 95 10:33:00 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Air cooled motors

 
>Has anyone informed the Japanese of this fact? 4-valve per cylinder
>air-coold motorcycles are quite common.
 
But not 4V Porsches. No room for the valve gear and the fins. One or the
other, not both. 4V Porsche heads have until now required water cooling.
Yes, I know, there's an aftermarket maker of air cooled 4V heads. I'm not a
gamblin' man and if Porsche says they can't do it, I don't think the
aftermarket can.
 
Pete

Steve,
	Actually, I have one of each (flusher and airhead), and I like 
the 911 best. But it has nothing at all to do with air cooling vs water 
cooling. Seems silly to make a decision on what car to buy based solely 
on what type of engine it has (air cooled or not), the end result is 
what is important (otherwise, I would buy a Mazda RX7 with the GREAT 
rotary engine. Uh, oh, any RX7 owners out there, do not send flames. I 
have owned several over the years and like them a lot, too!).

	Jeff,
	Sorry to reply to your message, I missed the original

Keith,
	I drove both when I was looking at the C2's back in '91 and was 
not impressed. This is a ver personal preference type of thing, though, 
and I would highly recommend getting your dealer to let you drive both 
for more than a spin around the block. BTW, I love my 993 Cab (with 6 
speed). You will probably rarely use 6th in the USA, but it is a great 
gearbox and very enjoyable. The only way I would consider the Tiptronic 
is if you are driving a lot of miles every day in heavy traffic. In that 
case, sports car or not, I prefer an automatic. Lucky I don't live in LA 
:-).
		Kim

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 08:19:27 -0500
From: Mike.Worland@DANA.COM
Subject: RE:Only lawnmowers are air cooled



You wrote...

>If "flush" is a verb used in conjunction with your car,  you don't own a
>Porsche.

>1. What percentage of the cooling of an "air cooled" 911 is carried out by
>the fluid medium of oil?
>2. Oil ( Mobil 1) is $ 5.00 per quart.  The 911 takes 12 quarts per change
>(oil FLUSH, if you prefer).  Now that works out to $ 60.00 and should be
done
>four times a year.  Lets see, that's a minimum of      $ 240.00 worth of
>coolant per year.
>3. Anti-freeze is $ 6.00 per gallon.  Flush once a year and you have blown
 >$12.00.
>4. "Evolution tends to improve the species... those who do not conform to
>their current environment will expire. ... There are numerous branches...
that
> are doomed to failure due to design flaws" Dr. John Howell, Sr.,
 commenting
>upon the failure of several branches of early man.
>6. Porsche will fluid cool the next generation of 911 heads.  Do I hear a
>flushette?
>7. Can you say "trailing throttle oversteer".

>The above are not necessarily the opinions of the management and in fact we
>refuse to confirm or deny the existence of the below.

Well Larry... You obviously try very hard every day to find a way to make
yourself feel better by putting others down. Generally when this is the case
the person providing all the rationalization is really uncomfortable with
the situation they are in. I think you should spend your energy on more
rewarding things, since none of the 911 owners think two-bits about your
rationale.  As far as the cost to 'flush' our cooling systems, we don't
care!!!! If we couldn't afford our cars we would sell them. We simply have
decided that we very much like all of the characteristics of our 911's, that
is why we bought them. That is why people STILL buy them today!!!!

When sideways, stay on the gas and deal with it. (my motto)

Mike

I would have to agree - that would be a great sight. It would 
also scare the s**t out of me, as Rob Yasek can attest first

that can lead to a quick thinning of the species. We lost some
B-52s early in the 'Nam goat-rope just because of that. They
then developed the trail formation that got away from the 
problem.

Herb Myers

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 14:33:04 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: RE: Air cooled motors: why ?

>From: dkelly@tomcat1.tbe.com (David Kelly)
>Subject: Re: Air cooled motors: why ?

>Jeff Kyle said:
>> The second is multi-valving.  You cannot multi-valve an air cooled
>> engine.

>Has anyone informed the Japanese of this fact? 4-valve per cylinder
>air-cooled motorcycles are quite common.


Well, they're not -that- common. It's primarilly an Itallian thing, the
germans (BMW) have finally joined the 4-valve air-cooled crowd. Although
there are some american made engines that fit the bill, but they're more 
custom racing built engines and are not easilly available to the public.

just my $.02 worth...

 -Josh

Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

jah@slc.slac.stanford.edu

namely ME. So don't go suing the DOE, they don't care...

> I have always believed in keeping your mouth shut 

Don't worry, you're not alone.  In fact, many, if not the majority, doubltless
believe in keeping my mouth shut... (just imagine their disappointment...)
 
> A little background for your edification.  Car Care Specialties, Inc. is my
> company.  We are distributors (and retailers) of quality car care products
> and safety equipment for the Porsche, BMW, Mercedes and Ferrari markets.  We
> run and/or supply several club "goodie stores" and also conduct numerous

> offer a 10% discount to any member of  Porschephiles.  I did not want to 
> blast this out and step on one or more of the unwritten rules and/or offend
> anyone. 

Let me restate my admiration for your restraint.  One of these days, I'm gonna
have to take some lessons in that arcane craft m'self...

> I have received several inquires and have forwarded packages to
> those who asked.  If you wish to inform the list of the above, please feel 
> free to do so.  All they have to do is write "Porschephiles Special Discount" 
> on the bottom line of the order form and take the 10% discount (or mention
> Porschephiles on phone orders).
 
> Our business is built upon service to our customers.  We provide technical
> expertise and if we don't know the answer, we have the sources that do.  I 
> will not sell a product unless I have used it and know what it will or will 
> not do. Our customers come first and if they are not happy with a purchase, 
> we will take it back.   

Well, Larry, you've been such a gentleman about this, and you seem to reflect 
those noble qualities one expects from a pfellow Porschephile, I have no choice
but to incur the wrath of the group by letting everyone else in on this 
discussion, given the permission.

> I have been on the net since 2/12/95.  Several people suggested that I get
> on, as there were questions for which they felt I could provide answers.  So,
> I bought the modem and the software and joined Porschephiles.  The
> discussions have been very interesting and I hope that the few tidbits that I
> threw into the ring were helpful, but I still do not have a solid feeling as
> to the "rules".  So with that in mind, I leave the CCS price list/discount
> promotion or lack thereof in your eminently capable hands.

If only the wisdom manifested in your courteous message, that of keeping one's
mouth shut and risking the danger of being thought a fool rather than opening

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 18:07:28 -0800 (PST)
From: aa@mda.ca (Adrian Alleyne)
Subject: RE: Tiptronic vs 6-speed

>>(We'll see if this generates any flames.)

>>There is no such thing as a sports car with an automatic
>>transmission.

Afterburner on full blast for this one, As mentioned in a few
postings, F1 racing has had semi-auto boxes since 1990 [Ferrari].
Since its introduction practically all teams have switched, due to
the performance advantages.

The only reason I believe that the current tiptronic S 993 is
approx 1 sec slower in the 0-60 time vs the 6-speed is that the
tiptronic has only four gears which don't have suitable ratios for
producing a faster 0-60 time.

Personally I can't wait for a 6-speed tiptronic S [selector on the
wheel] based transmission.  Under braking and acceleration at
Track and AutoX events, I'm sure that a 6-speed tiptronic will be
smoother and quicker than a manual.

Tiptronic S is just the type of high-tech improvement I expect
from Porsche to keep them ahead of the competition and at the
leading (bleeding edge).

>>Craig Z.
>>If anyone can, Porsche will redefine "sports car".

I for one fully agree.

I would like to hear comments from any philes who have driven
(raced) a 911/968/993 tiptronic at a track or AutoX event.

Here's a quote from a recent article on the New 1995 Jordon
Formula 1 car:

"As far as the transmission is concerned, the 195 features a new 7
speed longitudinal gearbox. With the torque reduction in the
engines - which are 3 litre units this year - this enables us to
use a narrower rev band. That in turn enables Peugeot to increase
power at the peak end of the range. Another factor which
influenced our decision to go for a 7 speed box is the use of the
hydroelectronic [semi-auto] gearchange. It's so fast that you
really don't pay a penalty any more by having 7 gears.  It
currently takes about 25 milliseconds to change gear - that
equates to about 0.15 seconds to go from 1st to 7th. That's faster
than we used to be able to change one gear in 1991 when the boxes
were operated manually!"

Adrian.
'86 951 (5-speed)

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 18:35:55 -0800

You betcha! It's been run officially... Seven (?) times, I think. It's always run by 
Brock Yates, Car & Driver columnist and all-around nutty guy. He wrote the 
screenplay before the movie before it was hacked into a stupid psuedo-car movie 
that glorified drinking and driving and general idiocy. (Hint: Run, don't walk, to 
your video store and rent The Gumball Rally. Terrific movie, predated the 
Cannonball Run movie, and is a real ball - especially near the end, with a 
Daytona Spyder and a 427 Cobra racing side-by-side in the aquaducts of Los 
Angeles... And to the best of my knowledge, all the cars were REAL cars.

The first one that includes several competitors was won by Brock and Dan 
Gurney in a Ferrari Daytona coupe. I recommend picking up Brock's book, 
Sunday Driver, and giving it a read - the last section involves the Cannonball.

Brock's a neat guy - I've ALMOST met him several times, and have been down to 
his bar, The Cannonball Pub, in sleepy Wyoming, New York. (A real one-horse 
town, except for his bar, with the big Ferrari sign out front, and tons of auto 
goodies all over the inside of the place.)

Anyways, I'd be willing to bet that it's been run unofficially quite a number of 
times. It's just too appealing an idea to sit for so long without having been done.

Date: 24 Feb 95 22:41:34 EST
From: CLINTON OWEN <74547.3121@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 Overheating

I have an early '83 944 with 145k miles and have probably had most of the
possible problems with the cooling system (and most of the other systems).  The
temperature gage should normally read at around the 3/4 mark after the car is
warmed up, and hardly ever vary from whatever spot your car thinks is normal.
You may reach the edge of the "Yellow Zone" under extreme conditions such as
prolonged idling with the A/C on in 90+ weather, or driving up mountain roads
with a luggage rack and two bikes on top and the A/C on.

You should check that both electric fans are running when the temperature switch
turns them on.  If one fan fails you will never notice it unless you check them
by letting the car idle until you reach the turn on point.  They normally don't
run at all if the car is moving unless the A/C is on.  I have seen a used car
for sale with only one fan working which overheated during the test drive.

There is one relay which controls the fans during normal conditions and a
separate one which turns them on whenever the A/C is switched on.  Either of
these relays can keep the fans off. If your A/C will not work at all this relay
is a likely culprit.

The fan switch in the radiator can fail either open or shut.  If the fans won't
run under normal hot idling conditions but switch on when you turn on the A/C
this switch is not closing (or the wire is broken). If the fans start as soon as
you start the car (A/C not on) the fan switch is stuck shut.  This also leads to
the deadest battery you have ever seen, because one fan will continue to run in
the "cool down" mode even after the key is removed.

If your car overheats but the radiator remains cold (the fans may or may not
run) your thermostat is stuck shut or the radiator is blocked.  The thermostat
bypasses water around the radiator until the engine is hot, so the hot water may
never get to the fan switch, but you will see a normal reading on the gage.

I made the mistake of putting stop leak in my car once to correct a small leak.
Within 2 miles it had turned into a gusher, as the top tank separated from the
core.

The water pump usually goes by leaking or bearing failure, rarely by loss of
pumping action.  The pump is the cheap part, the shop labor to replace it is
about 6 hours (it took me 12 in my own garage) the special belt tool p9201 is
required, as all of the belts have to come off.

Hope some of this helps, Clint Owen

'83 944

------------------------------

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 95 23:30:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 TURBO MODS ;mechanic help ?


>I have noticed quite a bit of white smoke lately under full thottle
>acceleration.

Ruh roh, Rorge.  Head gasket is what I would expect.

>Also,  my Bosch platinums seem to have a dry, sootie, black (
>carbon? ) residue on the lower one or two threads and the base of the plug.
>There is none on the electrode or ceramic tower, they seem to be burning
>properly.

Normal.  The plug runs cooler at its threads than on the tip, and does
not self-clean of combustion debris.

>All of this started after I decreased the tension on the ' barn
>door ' in the MFS. I loosened the spring about 8 clicks and noticed that 
when
>I pushed and then released the accel. pedal the RPMs dropped to a very
>unconfortable level before the idle stabilizer brought them back to normal.
>So I backed off to 3 clicks and curred the problem.

Yes, this is what happens.  You have adjusted the springing of
the barn door, which affects it both on accel and on decel.  The system
is damped by both the spring and by a pocket of air behind the other leg
of the right-angled barn door.  Bosch set the spring to the right tension;
you changed it.

Kevin Gross

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 21:54:32 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re: For the Airheads and Geeks

>A friend and I were having this discussion the other day,  a car is 
>shaped similar to the wing of an airplane.  I suppose a 944 would be 
>the closest P-model.  The question then is, how fast would one have to 
>drive to overcome the weight and drag to become airborn?

I guess it depends on the car.  I have personally seen a VW bug skip 
across hard-packed sand at 100 miles per hour or so like a rock skipping 
over water.  Distance between the take-off and landing points (judging 
from the tracks left in the sand) was about 25 feet.

Of course, cars don't have to be wing-shaped to get airborne.  Even 
high-downforce race cars will fly (once) if they crest a hill at speed 
and get a little air underneath.

 -Andy

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 22:31:38 -0800 (PST)
From: JAH@SLC.SLAC.STANFORD.EDU
Subject: Re: For the Airheads and Geeks

>It is often claimed that Indy cars and Formula 1 cars could (theoretically)
>run upside down on the ceiling if you could get thenm up there, in other
>words the develop (at speed) more than their own weight in downforce.

I can't give all the exact numbers, but I had the opportuninty to get some
interesting anecdotes from an Indy car driver and owner.
He was in the process of selling his '73 914, a formula ford with 4 wheel
sets and spare engine, -and- his indy car (with full spares of everything
of course). It turns out that the car he was selling (one he competed in
for a number of years) was big-Als car in 1982. His comments were
interesting to say the least. First off, he said driving the car was SCARY.
And he gave a great explanation as to why Indy cars fly off the track so
fast if they get sideways. He described his car as such: The car has 1000lb
coil springs in order to counteract the 1800lbs of downforce that the car
generates at speed (-think about it-). Now if the car gets sideways, the
downforce INSTANTLY disapears, and that 1000lbs will literally launch the
car into the air, not far but far enough to loose all traction, and the
rest is simple newtonian mechanics. He said that had happened to him once
where it happened so fast that he didn't even know what happened, he just
saw flying hay bails all of a sudden. Yikes!

I didn't get to drive it, but I did get to sit in it. 

 -Josh

Joshua Hadler				'74 914 2.0L CS -> CSP

Stanford Linear Accelerator Center

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 1995 23:00:00 -0800 (PST)
From: Dan Brown <dbrown@acme.csusb.edu>
Subject: Re: Have '86 944 overheating ...

On Thu, 23 Feb 1995 WHartje@aol.com wrote:

> distilled water and Red Line "Water Wetter". Anti -freeze not only stops
> water from freezing, it reduces you cooling system's capacity to cool the
> engine. 

	I don't think this is correct.  My chemistry is a bit hazy, but I 
don't think that current antifreeze has much effect on the specific heat 
capacity of the coolant.  However, it significantly raises the boiling point.

	In the owner's manual for my '62 Cadillac, it says to use 
antifreeze in the winter and water in the summer.  For anything newer, 
the manual says to keep antifreeze/coolant year-round.  My guess is 
there's been a big change in antifreeze between 1962 and 1977+.

Date: Fri, 24 Feb 95 10:11:22 EDT
From: "Ola d'Aulaire" <Ola.d'Aulaire@f1020.n141.z1.fidonet.org>
Subject: speedo calibration


I have a 1986 944 Turbo with 90k miles on it,in excellent condition.  Only problem is that from day one, the speedometer and the odometer have registered almost exactly 10% too fast.  Dealers and independent mechanics have consistently told me there's nothing they can do to recalibrate, and that this is within a "normal" error range.  I tend to feel otherwise.  My tires are Yokohama AVS A+4, 205/55VR16 on fronts and 225/50VR16 on rears.  Anybody have any insight if it's possible to make the speedo more accurate?   (I live in the Danbury CT area, with not a speedometer shop in sight.)

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 1995 07:43:19 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: Motor Mount Horror/all 944   

Just received a Technical Bulletin straight from Porsche. 
Once again they have an updated engine mount for all 944 series cars. They
include 924S, 944/S/S2/T. all years. 
The new mount # 951 375 042 04, supersedes the former version, 951 375 042
05. In a startling reversal it is no longer a hydraulic unit, but is spring
loaded. It is longer than the old mount thereby eliminating the 4mm spacer
used in the old model (on the right side). 
This mount is applicable to either side of the engine. They are also saying
that you can mix and match so you need not replace both mounts at the same
time. They are also a bit pricey although I don't have the exact numbers. I
do know that they are more expensive than the supersceeded part.(surprize)
BTW you don't have to have a vibration problem to need a new mount. The
factory would have you replace mounts if the engine oil pan drops below the
lowest point of the front crossmember. Something about not tearing out your
oil pan if you encounter an obstacle.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:18 am
