Date: Sat, 25 Feb 1995 07:12:15 -0600
From: cowan@sccsi.com (Ken Rentiers)
Subject: RE: Tiptronic vs 6-speed

Adrian writes:

>Here's a quote from a recent article on the New 1995 Jordon
>Formula 1 car:
>
>"As far as the transmission is concerned, the 195 features a new 7
>speed longitudinal gearbox. With the torque reduction in the
>engines - which are 3 litre units this year - this enables us to
>use a narrower rev band. That in turn enables Peugeot to increase
>power at the peak end of the range. Another factor which
>influenced our decision to go for a 7 speed box is the use of the
>hydroelectronic [semi-auto] gearchange. It's so fast that you
>really don't pay a penalty any more by having 7 gears.  It
>currently takes about 25 milliseconds to change gear - that
>equates to about 0.15 seconds to go from 1st to 7th. That's faster
>than we used to be able to change one gear in 1991 when the boxes
>were operated manually!"


Porsche is playing with a similar system (EKS), already available in some
of the RUF tuner cars. An article by Bruce Anderson in a recent issue of
Excellence extols the virtues of this unit. EKS is distinct from  the Tipo
in being an electronically shifted traditional gearbox (hydroelectronic
[semi-auto] gearchange) as opposed to the torque converter-type slushbox we
all are familiar with.

Once you can shift *right now* by wire it's a short trip from the stick to
a button on the steering wheel.

 -ken-
'91 C4

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 1995 09:32:20 -0600
From: fhess@free.org (Fred L Hess)
Subject: Trans mounts and more..

   The rebuild project is coming along fine. The majority of the top end
stuff came Friday. The p&c are installed. I also bought new tensioners.
From what I can tell and have read there are 3 varieties of mechanical
tensioners (not including the oil fed). What they sent me was part
#930.105.053.00 (turbo's?). From what I understand these tensioners are
smaller and hence, I also got spacers. To be on the "safe" side I bought
the clips that fit above them in case they fail. I assume that installing
the saftey clips is a good idea, comments? Today I will be removing the
rocker arms from the cam housings and (hopefully!) mounting those. I do
have to comment that there is nothing tooo overwhelming in this job as
long as one takes one thing at a time (an has the *BEST* tech suport
known to man..Porschephiles ;-) and handles the logistics of the outside
work.                                              

   Looking ahead to a compleation date of April 1st, I did notice a few
items that need to be attend to. The oil tank and associated lines will
be cleaned,I am going to rebuild the Webbers (or at least the excelerator
pumps), and I was looking at the trans mounts. Most of the trans mounts
I have seen are the same type as the motor mounts. On this '66 they are not.
I haven't looked into availability yet but, it looks as if they are pressed
in. Anyone familiar with these? Are they still available? 


          
Fred L Hess

Date: 25 Feb 95 11:40:19 EST
From: Peter Albrecht <76416.167@compuserve.com>
Subject: Carrera

Trond says
>The little village of Carrera is placed in the Alps, I don't know if
>Switzerland or Germany or Austria
 
Carrera is in Graubuenden (or Grisons), Switzerland. It has about 2 people
and 200 cows. I think everybody who buys a Carrera notices this little dot
on the big map of Switzerland (won't appear on small maps) and decides to go
there to photograph car in front of city (sort of) limits sign. (If anybody
is looking for it, it's on the Swiss road 67, between Bonaduz and Ilanz, on
the south side of the upper Rhine valley (the Rhine is only a creek at this
point), a few miles south of the bigger town of Flims which is on the other
side of the Rhine and which gets more traffic on its wider road. What little
traffic is on the 67 often has to stop while herds of cattle are driven
along -- not across, along -- the road.) So of course I had to go there too.
While doing this, I noticed that the farmer whose farm is
right behind the city limit sign was watching all this, apparently confused.
Now this poor rustic has probably seen dozens of Porsches stop in front of
his barn, people get out, take pictures of car and his barn, and drive off
without explanation. I felt it was time for one. I called out to him that my
car is a Carrera, just like his town. "Oh........ Ja." And looking past
him, over his shoulder, what is peeking out of his barn? The nose end of a
Porsche tractor. I said "I see you are a Porsche driver too." There was a
moment of silence, THE FARMER TURNED AROUND, LOOKED AT THE TRACTOR, TURNED
BACK, and said "Oh.......Ja."
 
True story.
 
I think the remote village of Carrera suffers from excessive inbreeding, or
lack of television, or both.
 
Pete

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 1995 08:58:43 -0800

Heck, I'll go one further than that - not even station wagons should have 
them! :)

I enjoy driving... And the whole point of driving sports cars is to get closer 
to the driving experience, not to be removed from it, as with luxury cars. 
(It goes without saying that I hate everything that luxury cars stand for.)

I've promised myself that I'll never own a car with an automatic. The 
advantages of a stick are far too great, plus it's s much more fun... Besides, 
who wants to be seen with a wimp-shift? :)

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 1995 14:25:23 -0500
From: NannW@aol.com
Subject: Cleveland

Sreelal:

I grew up in Ohio, and spent the first eighteen years of my life in a town
about 60 miles east of Cleveland - right on Lake Erie.
For sure, the winters can be cold, and snowy.  Cleveland is influenced big
time by what is going on in Canada.  However, it is still agreat place to
live - the people are, for the most part, very friendly,genuine, and
outgoing, with no pretense.

You can transfer your membership to the Northern Ohio Region by contacting
Ruth Harte in the executive office (phone no. 702-933-9200) in Alexandria,
VA.  She is listed in the back of the Panorama.

Also, for your information, the current membership contact in the Northern
Ohio Region is Larry Katz, in Beachwood, Ohio.  His phone number is
216-581-9050.  He cannot transfer your membership, but should be able to get
you on their newsletter mailing list sooner, and can also let you know about
events/meetings going on in the area right away.

Another great advantage to being in Ohio is that you will have the
opportunity to drive on the Mid-Ohio sports car track in Lexington (Mid-Ohio
Region track).  What else could a Porsche driver ask for.

By the way, there are companies that specialize in transporting cars - check
the yellow pages in your area.

Enjoy, and good luck!

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 95 14:40:06 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: Re: Have '86 944 overheating ...

> > distilled water and Red Line "Water Wetter". Anti -freeze not only stops
> > water from freezing, it reduces you cooling system's capacity to cool the
> > engine.
>
> 	I don't think this is correct.  My chemistry is a bit hazy, but I
> don't think that current antifreeze has much effect on the specific heat
> capacity of the coolant.  However, it significantly raises the boiling point.

Actually this is true.  Antifreeze conducts heat more slowly than 
water.  It raises the boiling point but doesn't get the heat out of the 
block/head as fast as pure water.

Suggested best solution is to slightly reduce the antifreeze 
concentration during summer.

		Jim

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 95 14:45:48 TZ
From: Jim Selders <jimseld@microsoft.com>
Subject: RE: 944 TURBO MODS ;mechanic help ?

> >I have noticed quite a bit of white smoke lately under full thottle
> >acceleration.
>
> Ruh roh, Rorge.  Head gasket is what I would expect.
>
> >Also,  my Bosch platinums seem to have a dry, sootie, black (
> >carbon? ) residue on the lower one or two threads and the base of the plug.
> >There is none on the electrode or ceramic tower, they seem to be burning
> >properly.
[...]
If this is on a 951 as the email header indicates, another possibility 
is turbo center bearing failure.  This would produce white (oil) smoke 
in the exhaust and might, depending on the leak, get into the intake 
tract and coat your spark plugs especially on their cool parts.

Pull the ducting between the turbo outlet and the intercooler and check 
it for oil.  If it's nicely coated inside, you have a good bit of evidence.

		Jim

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 1995 15:48:51 -0500
From: PerryS7342@aol.com
Subject: Re: Airplanes.....(forever)

Bart:

Shame on you for passing on "second-hand" war stories to these
kids....(Trond, Ben, Martin, Hugh, etc, etc, etc, following Pete's posting
and spirited defense).

..The "f****er* on my tail was a Messerschmitt!" was a popular WWII joke.
 Same vintage as "Yanks....oversexed and over here".

..Fokker was and still is a Dutch Company with WWI designs like the D-VII.

..Hurricanes (not Spitfires) were the primary contributor to the Battle of
Britain.  Spits not available in quantities.  Although Hurricane was not a
"great" fighter aircraft, the heroics of RAF pilots and short fuel duration
of German fighters over target helped.

..B-17s dropped over 80 percent  of the tonnage on occupied Europe and
Germany from English-based bomber aircraft.  Also took over 85 percent of
bomber/crew losses.  Lancasters, Sterlings, etc never got the night fighter
attention commensurate with daytime "precision" bombing raids.

..North American P-51 originally designed for British..US Army Air Corps tried
 in ground attack role as A-36.  Never a great air combat aircraft until the
later versions replaced the RR Merlins with Allisons.

..Both US and allies and Russians recruited German Scientists.  US Contingent
worked at White Sand Missile Range before later move to Huntsville (Werner in
fact was the first to coin the term to girls in Juarez..."But I am a Rocket
Scientist").  Chrysler, out of gratitude, made his brother Magnus Chief of
Quality Control in the 60's and he was able to accelerate deterioration of
 their already abysmal quality.

..God Bless the Marines and their combat spirit..when it comes to business,
however, the Army and AF periodically try to save them from themselves and
the Navy.  They had "egg on face" at the original US flight demo of the
Harrier AV8-A which  had to be "scrubbed" when they didn't have the UK spec
"rather than MIL or NATO" fuel and lubricants to impress the invited crowd.
(BTW Soviet aircraft were designed to use MIL and NATO fuel and lubes)


..Finally (to get on a Porsche thread), Porsche DID NOT design the production
version of the WWII Tiger tank.  They built two prototypes and lost the
production contract to Henschel.  As I've mentioned before, Porsche has a
history of difficulty in translating innovative and advanced designs into
volume production.  (and yes, the Porsche design did become the Jagdpanzer
"Ferdinand"  Tank Destroyer,  encumbered by poor battlefield reliabilty).

Enough said..

Perry

BTW, Pete, I don't mind 2-hour or less trips in the Airbus...very quiet and
relatively comfortable except for the cabin compartment doors which swing
into the aisle.    

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 1995 15:54:10 -0500
From: PJZabo@aol.com
Subject: Re: Air cooled motors: why ?

You neglected to mention emissions restrictions.  Since the operating
temperature is more erratic with air cooled engines it is harder to tune the
engine for peak power and emissions, although this fact is being made less
relevant with the more advanced electronic engine management systems that
have been developed.

By the way, as any 911 driver such as myself knows, some of the air cooled
cars out there are also really oil cooled. Hence the 12 quart 911 oil change
and long piping runs to the fender mounted cooler or loop.  Suzuki actually
advertised their original GSX motorcycles as air/oil cooled since they added
an second oil pump that operated at higher pressures to direct greater
volumes of cooling oil to the undersides of the pistons in these motorcycles.

------------------------------

Date: Sat, 25 Feb 95 16:13:56      
From: tt911@ibm.net
Subject: Re: Steward at Sebring

I like to see this subject drop soon, but Mr. Kitchak completely mis-stated the
nature of the problem Pat was addressing. The incidents that occurred at this event
were alot more serious then some car driver telling a corner worker that they did not 
do their job right (which no driver should do anyway unless they are willing to go out
on the corners work a few weekends themself).
 
It was more on the lines of a driver who was refusing to follow our safety
requirements and then deciding it was time to threaten the steward physically and 
verbally throw about every four letter word at him. This was not the only time this 
has happen at an event. I been at events were "the finger" has been given to a 
Chief Steward, to corner workers and to other drivers. Only a very, very, small
percent of the drivers have been a problem, but it has been growing a bit so the
threat to put them on the trailer is need before it gets out of hand.

If Mr. Kitchak feels that PCA Club Racing is a bit too "officious"
then so be it, nobody is forced to attend these events, but judging
by the growth in the number of drivers and events in the last two years I 
think that this feeling is not widely held. I think that most of the drivers 
like the ideal that we have a 13/13 rule and that it is enforced so that
the crash-n-burn type drivers are discouraged from attending/continuing these races. 
PCA Club racing was started to allow the Porsche owner who had no racing experience 
a chance to take his P-car out and race it in a some what controlled environment 
(sort of an oxymoron but we try). If after a while they want more challenges or 
competition then there are other venues to try out and I think we will see this
year some PCAers that started racing in Club Racing doing very well in IMSA. 

Yes I like to see alot more lightening up going on in PCA Club Racing but I think a there
a few more drivers that need to then stewards. 

Tom Tauscher

AIRBAGS -- I used to think that they were cash-flow enhancers until I	     
heard a report on ESPN (Speedweek?  Whichever has Derek Daly) that F1      
is looking into air bags as a method of reducing head injuries.  The      
current problem is the ballistic pillow doesn't deploy fast enough.

     Adding insult to injury.  Impact, whiplash, boot-to-the-head.  :P

AUTO TRANS in Sports Cars/Race Cars -- The current issue of Racer magazine   
   says that clutchless trannies could become a necessity in F1 cars.       
They claim that braking systems could reach the point of requiring a      
double-wide pedal that would be applied with both feet.

BROCK YATES -- Assuming you can find it (I don't remember which issue it's   
   in) there was a letter to the editor of C&D a couple years ago from the   
   Chief of Police in Redondo Beach, CA.  Seems one of his officers caught   
   Mr. Yates driving 90mph through the city streets of RB.  Had in the car   
   a passenger, one Dan Gurney.  Most of the letter is a transcript of the   
   interview/interogation of Mr. Yates.  It's hillarious.  Either Yates      
wrote it himself or the Police Chief has a great sense of humor.

     I believe the issue had an AC Cobra on the cover (if that helps.)

Later,

>cooled plants since the mid 80s till water cooling became the rave.  That's
>also when they started to cover every square inch of their bikes with plastic
>to hide the invariable array of pipes, hoses, radiators, etc. that go with
>the flushers.

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 1995 11:19:35 -0800
From: fastfwd@ix.netcom.com (Andrew Warren)
Subject: Re:  balancing act

Maria Duryee (hbeng032@huey.csun.edu) wrote:

>my question is, do i balance the tires with the wheels on the car 
>or off? does it matter?

Maria:

Balancing tires ON the car would allow out-of-balance components like 
brake discs, hubs, etc. to be compensated for, but since those pieces 
are usually well-balanced already, you should get good results even if 
the tires are balanced off the car.

Just make sure that the guy doing the balancing is running the machine 
at the "high" speed, and ask him to put the weights on the front AND 
back of the wheel.

In my part of the world, the number of shops that'll even do on-the-car 
spin-balancing has dwindled to just one (Clarence Brown Alignment, in 
case any other San Diegans care), which makes this a moot point anyway.

 -Andy


- -- 
Andrew Warren - fastfwd@ix.netcom.com
Fast Forward Engineering, Vista, California

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 1995 15:19:49 -0500
From: PORSCHEFAN@aol.com
Subject: Sticky Stuff

Porsche used (at least during the early '70's) a sticky, putty-like compound
for weathersealing areas where insignia studs protruded through metalwork.
 It usually was a seal at the base of a speed not fastener. It was usually
gray or black. 

Does anyone know what this stuff was, and where it is available?  The
particular application I'm thinking of is where the "914" emblem fastened to
the area between the taillights.

Pat Garvey

------------------------------

Date: 26 Feb 95 13:54:45 EST
From: Kim Knapp <73477.1132@compuserve.com>
Subject: Re: Re : Auto vs manual

	I don't know. I made a mistake thinking that way ("manual transmission in
every car I own"). Then I bought a BMW 733 back in '88 (?) with a manual. The
car was a pain! The problem was that it had no power (for the weight) at low
rpm, so you had to always start out with lots of revs and slipping of clutch.
Then when I traded it, I got nothing for it, because no one else in the world
wanted a manual 733. Now I stick with manual in light sports cars (like the 911)
and automatic in everything else.
			Kim


------------------------------

Does anyone know if there were ever Heated seats made that would fit my 1984
944?
Maybe for later Cabriolets?  My roommate's '92 Golf Cabriolet has heated seats,
and they're the clear cat's ___ for our winter conditions.  <Welcome to
Saskatchewan: temp as high as +35C in the summer, low as -45C in the winter>

I'd also love to hear of anyone's stories on how 944's stand up (or don't) in
extreme cold situations.  I just acquired my car, and plan to use it year-round.
Am now trying to figure out what kind of engine heater I can install -- have had
a lot of local input, but none from anyone who could call themselves a Porsche
expert.  I'm told there is no available factory block heater, as there
supposedly is for the 928.

Richard Kovach
1984 944

Date: 26 Feb 95 14:34:11 EST
From: Richard Kovach <76253.1567@compuserve.com>
Subject: RE: Overheating 944

I believe I've read several times that having adequate antifreeze in
your engine coolant is critical even in summer, because of all of
the corrosion-inhibitors.  And that this is even more important
for aluminum and aluminum-alloy blocks/heads/etc.  If this is not
true, I'd sure like to know (and why).

As far as the overheating, unless this is a common problem with
your model of car, I would say that running on straight water
or something like that is trying to fix the symptom without fixing
the real problem.  Which, like many things in life, is usually just
asking for more (and more serious?) trouble later...  

In the automotive context, I learned this the hard way with a
pre-built kit car that I won in a lottery -- and spent 3 years trying
to get straight, before finally selling it for < 1/2 what it should've
been worth if it had been built properly to begin with.  Not that I'm
complaining, it did give me some fun, a lot of lessons, and a few
grand in the bank!!!  (lately spent acquiring my own 944)

Richard Kovach
1984 944


------------------------------

Date: 26 Feb 95 14:34:16 EST
From: Richard Kovach <76253.1567@compuserve.com>
Subject: Mine's an Auto (for now?)

Now put those flamers away, ok?...

My recently-acquired 944 is, much to many peoples' chagrin, an automatic!  And I
must say for myself that I still consider it a Sports car, much more so that
other sports cars I have had the pleasure to own (which all had manual boxes).
But the real reason I bought it was a combination of being impressed with the
driveability of it AND the fact that it was about 2/3 the price of any
reasonable-condition manual models on the market.  I certainly wouldn't choose
the auto for same price/condition, but I do really like it (sure makes city
driving a lot easier!)

So how about we direct all this negative energy on automatics to a POSITIVE
purpose, and explore what all it would take to convert my 1984 auto 944 to a
manual transmission?  Besides the obvious transmission change, clutch, shifter &
linkage, etc. what else?  different axles?  different torque tube? any welding
required for pedal/shifter installations???  

Ok, you're thinking if he's stupid enough to drive a 944 in -40C weather, he's
stupid enough to try anything.  And you're right!  But I have a pretty good
history of succeeding at things that "everyone" says is impossible.  So I am
seriously interested in this, particularly if the automatic ever decides to give
up the ghost, and would really appreciate any advice.

Richard Kovach
1984 944 (automatic, for now...)

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 95 19:16:55 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 Heated Seats available??

> Does anyone know if there were ever Heated seats made that would fit my 1984
> 944?

Yes, the 1985/2-1991 seats from 944s will fit (with a couple of minor
modifications) in your 84 944.  Some of those seats came with heat as an
additional cost option.  All of the North America cars came with power
cables to both of the seats, so you will need the cables also.

The alterations to the 86 seats are minimal:

1) You will have to remove the seat belt receptacle from the new style seat.
You should continue to use the seat belt receptacle mounted on your
transmission tunnel, inasmuch as it will provide more strength.

2) Whereas the 85/2-91 seats are mounted in the 85/2 -91 cars with six
mounting bolts, you will only use the forward 4 points in your 84 (that's
because you only have four mounting points...) That's also why you should
not use the seat mounted seatbelt receptacle...

I would suggest that you use ignition switched power to power the heated
seats, otherwise you might end up with a dead battery because you forgot to
turn off the heat...

BTW, they work great in my 83... 

> Maybe for later Cabriolets?  My roommate's '92 Golf Cabriolet has heated seat
> and they're the clear cat's ___ for our winter conditions.  <Welcome to
> Saskatchewan: temp as high as +35C in the summer, low as -45C in the winter>
> I'd also love to hear of anyone's stories on how 944's stand up (or don't) in
> extreme cold situations.  I just acquired my car, and plan to use it year-rou
> Am now trying to figure out what kind of engine heater I can install -- have 
> a lot of local input, but none from anyone who could call themselves a Porsch
> expert.  I'm told there is no available factory block heater, as there
> supposedly is for the 928.

No experience with the kind of cold you will experience, but a block heater
would help.  There are some that bolt to the outside of the oil pan, also
some that heat the coolant and circulate it.  That would help heat the oil
through the oil-coolant intercooler. 
Either type might help.

I have dismantled several 944 engines with more than 200,000 miles (that's
300,000 km in metric) motors that show no cylinder wall wear at all.  In my
opinion, with frequent oil and filter changes, you might be able to get
500,000 miles out of one of these engines, before you have to tear down the
bottom end...
- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ mhv.net
E-Mail: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net

------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 95 19:29:05 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Mine's an Auto (for now?)

> Now put those flamers away, ok?...
> 
> My recently-acquired 944 is, much to many peoples' chagrin, an automatic!  An
> must say for myself that I still consider it a Sports car, much more so that
> other sports cars I have had the pleasure to own (which all had manual boxes)
> But the real reason I bought it was a combination of being impressed with the
> driveability of it AND the fact that it was about 2/3 the price of any
> reasonable-condition manual models on the market.  I certainly wouldn't choos
> the auto for same price/condition, but I do really like it (sure makes city
> driving a lot easier!)

The real proof is going head to head at an autocross or track event. An
automatic 944 will never have a chance against an equivalent manual trans
944.  You just lose too much power due to the inefficiencies of the auto...

> 
> So how about we direct all this negative energy on automatics to a POSITIVE
> purpose, and explore what all it would take to convert my 1984 auto 944 to a
> manual transmission?  Besides the obvious transmission change, clutch, shifte
> linkage, etc. what else?  different axles?  different torque tube? any weldin
> required for pedal/shifter installations???  

When your 944 started as a bare chassis, Dr. Porsche had no idea what kind
of 944 it was going to end up as (i.e. whether automatic or standard...)
So, all that you need to make your car a manual trans 944 is the following:

1) Manual transmission
2) Manual transmission torque tube
3) Manual transmission bell housing
4) Manual transmission flywheel
5) clutch (pressure plate, clutch, throwout bearing, pilot bearing)
6) Clutch slave cylinder and hoses
7) Clutch master cylinder
8) Clutch pedal assembly and mounting hardware
9) Shifter assembly, shift knob and linkage
10) Connections to backup lights.

The good news is, the CV joints and halfshafts are the same.

The bad news is, you will pay $3000 to $4000 US to make this conversion. In
our neck of the woods, that is almost more than what your car is worth
(assuming average mileage of 70,000 to 80,000 miles)...

On the other hand, the likely failures of your car are:
1) The oil seal between the 90W and the atf goes tits up and mixes the two,
causing lots of damage.
2) the Rubber center damper breaks and leaves you stranded with a dead car.

> 
> Ok, you're thinking if he's stupid enough to drive a 944 in -40C weather, he'
> stupid enough to try anything.  And you're right!  But I have a pretty good
> history of succeeding at things that "everyone" says is impossible.  So I am
> seriously interested in this, particularly if the automatic ever decides to g

Take pictures of the conversion.  I want to read the article in Panorama...
(Man tries the improbable. Spends a fortune. Has a normal car now...)
- --
George Beuselinck, user of the UniBoard System @ mhv.net
E-Mail: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net

for their Nationals, similar to your Porsche Parade.  I can get you the
address from any of the clubs over here, just let me know which state you
would like to join. I am a member of Porsche Car Club of Queensland, and
although small, 120 members, we still enjoy all the comradeship (mateship)
that all other clubs enjoy. The Victorian club is our biggest with approx.
350 members, then NSW with 250 members, also South Australia, Canberra, and
Western Australia.  There is also a 356 Registery with I believe over 100
members as well.

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 1995 19:42:25 -0500
From: cseko@inasec.ca (Craig Seko)
Subject: Winter 944's (was: 944 Heated Seats available??)

First of all, I gotta admit I store my car, but I have put it away as late
as December and brought it out as mid-February...

>Does anyone know if there were ever Heated seats made that would fit my 1984
>944?

Yes, heated seats were a factory option for 944's, though I'm not sure if
they were for all years. No doubt they're not cheap, but you can ask fellow
p-philer George B. (George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net) if he has a pair for
sale. A simpler solution would be to go to Canadian Tire and get the heated
seat covers that plug into a cigarette lighter. They're ugly, and not that
cheap ($40 each?), but, boy, are they nice :)

>Saskatchewan: temp as high as +35C in the summer, low as -45C in the winter>

Yeah, but its a *dry* cold...<grin> here in Ottawa we have a *wet* cold.
Believe me, there *is* a difference. You'll find the AC marginal in the
summer as well, but it doesn't matter :)

>I'd also love to hear of anyone's stories on how 944's stand up (or don't) in
>extreme cold situations.  I just acquired my car, and plan to use it
year-round.

The heater works *very* nicely. Steel rims would be a good plan, together
with a second set of tires... high-performance summer tires just don't grip
that well when it is cold, even with lots of tread.

It would be *really* nice if your car has the optional limited slip
differential, otherwise watch for oversteer. The car is quite good in snow,
compared to something like a BMW, for instance.

Keep the snow clear of the roof/hatch. A snow/ice dam can build up in the
gap between the hatch glass and roof, rendering the hatch un-openable. The
same goes for the headlight raising/lowering mechanism. Expect the "hold the
thing up" struts in the engine compartment and rear hatch to stop "holding
up" in the cold, but start working again in the spring.

The front fenderwells can store an amazing amount of gunk, so make sure to
clean them out regularly during the spring.

I have heard from the local dealer (though I have no proof) that
high-pressure gas shocks such as Bilsteins will blow their seals in very
cold conditions. I do know my front struts are *very* noisy over bumps when
it is cold out.

I don't know if you have power steering, but the power steering system will
complain *very* loudly if you aren't *very* gentle with the steering wheel
in the morning.

>Am now trying to figure out what kind of engine heater I can install --
have had

Well, I just had a quick look at my engine (conveniently located in my
kitchen), and there isn't any obvious place to to put a block heater. You
could probably get by with a battery blanket and synthetic oil (*and*
synthetic gear oil). There isn't really a good location for an in-line
heater-hose heater, but one might be crammed in somewhere. The lower rad
hose doesn't have parallel walls, so a heater spliced in there probably
can't be found, and using the upper hose isn't usually recommended. I don't
like dipstick heaters, and I don't think they can be sold anymore, anyway.
There is a second plug on the oil pan, which may take a heater <shrug>, but
as I recall the type of heater that "sticks on" the oil pan is the one the
local dealer installs.

I'd start with the synthetic oil and a battery blanket and see if that's enough.


Craig.

- --- <: snip! ;> ---
+ Craig Seko in Ottawa, the second coldest national capital in the world! +
| Personal'n'Porsche mail: cseko@inasec.ca  Work mail: sekocet@statcan.ca |
+ Usual opinion disclaimer :) I speak only for myself. Live free or die.  +

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 95 21:14:06 TZ

An interesting note about 928's that I learned while on a factory tour 
in 1986: 928's chassis are actually different for manual vs. automatic 
transmission.  The auto car has a bigger "hump" between the rear seats.

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 1995 21:38:23 -0500
From: HermanHome@aol.com
Subject: Re: Overheating 944

From: 76253.1567@compuserve.com (Richard Kovach)
To: porschephiles@tta.com (Porschephiles)

>I believe I've read several times that having adequate antifreeze in
>your engine coolant is critical even in summer, because of all of
>the corrosion-inhibitors.  And that this is even more important
>for aluminum and aluminum-alloy blocks/heads/etc.  If this is not
>true, I'd sure like to know (and why).

>As far as the overheating, unless this is a common problem with
>your model of car, I would say that running on straight water
>or something like that is trying to fix the symptom without fixing
>the real problem.  Which, like many things in life, is usually just
>asking for more (and more serious?) trouble later...  

>Richard Kovach
1984 944

Richard, it is extremely important to use antifreeze with corrosion
inhibitors ALL OF THE TIME!  Pure water has no lubricants for the water pump
bearings and seals (an expensive replacement in a 944) and will promote
corrosion of all internal parts.  Additionally, antifreeze mixed with water
has better thermal properties than plain water.  It will provide better
cooling!  I know that for a fact because as a lad I filled the cooling system
in my Triumph GT6 with water, and didn't get very far before the temperature
gauge went into the red.  Refilled with the proper mixture (along with the
required heckling of my father...I told you so!) it once again ran fine.
 Finally, antifreeze will retain it's "anti-freezing" properties
indefinately, but the corrsion and lubrication properties break down rather qu
ickly.  If you don't change it every year or two, you may want to add
corrosion inhibitors.

Larry Herman
Ambler, PA
HermanHome@aol.com
'84 911 Carrera-Club Racer


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 1995 22:24:58 -0500
From: Jon50g@aol.com
Subject: Re: Should I Purchase this car?

Barry writes,
..............................................................................
........................
I have an opportunity to purchase a 911 at a very good price. This car
started life as a '78 SC, and has been converted to 84+ Carerra specs. This
included the motor being updated to 3.2l with pressure fed cam chain tens.
 When the engine was rebuilt, the head was ported and polished, and the
catalytic converter was removed. The rubber clutch has also been updated. I
don't know if the car has CIS, DME, or carbs.

He also mentions it's: priced at $10.000, has turbo tie rods?, needs paint
and interior work and is being compared to a 951 or 944S2 for track purposes.
..............................................................................
.....................

Barry,

 I'm not sure whether anyone else made an attempt at offering you any advice
on this broad question, so I thought I would take a shot. I know your
feelings about buying the 911.  I'm close to being in the same position of
switching from water to air cooled in the garage.

  The price from what you mentioned, (I'll guesstimate the milage at 80,000),
doesn't seem like a steel.  Watching carefully here in the Boston area an SC w
/that mi, in that described condition, would probably be on the market a long
time and fetch maybe $8-11k.  I say that because, even though 911 buyers are
typicly wise and savvy, the market tends to discount cars that have had major
custom work like this one.

  When looking at a car that has been reworked such as this one you can't be
too careful.  Think about:

 -  Who did the work and your relationship w/ them.  Many others won't touch a
911 w/that work, or they'll spend time ($$$) figuring it out.
 -  It's really not a carrera.  It may have the power, but I doubt somebody
would spend all the money to actually replicate one.  Car & Driver in '83
quoted Porsche saying  75-85% of all the engine parts for the carrera had
changed..
 -  It's probably carburated which can be a good reliable conversion if thats
what the mechanic was going for. 
 -  A lot of if's.

  Tie rods are part of a cars steering system.  Turbo tie rod conversions on
911's are popular because most who do it would testify about an improvement
in steering feel and response.  All SC's and, I think, most Carrera's until
the late '80s came without power steering.  This readily increases the
steering feel.  Turbo tie rods make that much of an improvement.

  Sorry to be the bearer of bad tiddings, but the paint and interior work
could easily run in the $1000's, and catalytic converters are'nt cheap
either.  I haven't priced out one for a 911 lately, but look in the mid $100's
 minimum.

  On the track you'll find the 951 clearly fastest with that 911and the S2
dicing it out if your lucky and the mechanic is worth his salt.  Everyone
will tell you the 944 platform is easier to drive then the 911.  This comes
down to weight distribution and a couple other things.  It's about even in
the 944.  The 911 with its engine in back can behave like a pendulum, heavier
rear end swinging out.  The 911's rear tires also want to steer you into a
turn the harder you give them gas and, conversly, out from a turn when you
lift:(.  Its suspension geometry is such that with gas (i.e. rear end squat),
the rear tires toe in more.  Since the weight is on the outside tire, it will
contribute to the direction you are steering in.  Hence, the term "throttle
steer".  I've never done this at the limit of adhesion in a 911, but it
sounds too exciting to pass up.

Wishing you the best, 

Chris Woodward
944S

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 1995 23:56:59 -0500
From: YoramGuy@aol.com
Subject: Re: balancing act

On Feb 25 Maria Duryee wrote:
<<i'm having a real vibration problem  at 70+ mph in my 1970 911T...my
mechanic says i need to balance the tires.....my question is, do I balance
the tires with the wheels on the car or off? does it matter?
thanks for your help....>>

This is a good one.
On one hand balancing the wheels off the car obviously does not balance the
hub/disk rotating mass.  On the other hand, as far as I know, there is no
good way to perform dynamic balancing (weight imbalance about the tire center
plane, not about its axis) on the car.  From my experience, the tire and rim
imbalance usually far exceeds any hub/disk imbalance, and a good and well
calibrated off-vehicle dynamic balancer is much more sensitive and accurate
than an on-vehicle balancer.
My vote?  Off-vehicle.  Use on-car balancer as a first-order diagnostic.
Warning #1:  Very often, tire balancers in the "mainstream' shops are out of
calibration and/or operators are inept or careless, and it takes patience and
determination to come back or go elsewhere to get it right.  But there are
few things more satisfying than the smoothness from perfectly balanced
wheels...
Warning #2:  Quite often certain aftermarket tires will have roundness or
stiffness non-uniformity substantially outside OE tire specs.  This results
in vibration that cannot be eliminated by any amount or method of balancing.
 In my own experience, Goodyear and Pirelli can be quite bad in this regard,
and the Japanese (Bridgestone, Yokohama) are predictably consistently among
the best, as is Michelin.
Warning #3:  All the above assumes the trivial (and usually easiest to check)
condition that the rims are perfectly straight and round...

Yoram Guy, Ann Arbor, MI.
...Still Looking for an '87 Carrera Coupe...


------------------------------

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 1995 22:15:22 -0700
From: jungmann@swcp.com (Kit Jungmann)
Subject: Fan Belt Audio Warning w/ Radio Shack Parts


Well after receiving a few inquiries about the 'XOR' oil/charge warning 
circuit I thought I'd better pull out the plans I drew up back in 1985. The 
good news is I kept records and found two designs. The bad news is I don't 
have Radio Shack part numbers.

The parts list is as follows:

        4 - diodes                       (almost any will work)
        (instead of diodes use a simple low current rectifier!)
        1 - 12V pievoelectric buzzer    (get lowest current model!)

NOTE:   Instead of 4 diodes you should use a 'rectifier' (this is a device 
which has two input connections and two output connections and no matter the 
polarity of the input always gives the same current direction at the output)

Connections are as such:
- ------------------------

(Arrows within brackets [ |<- ] indicate direction of current flow and match 
'diode' symbols. Asterisks '*' indicate connections)


OIL LAMP (+)       >---*--[ |<- ]------*------>>---   (+)
                       |               |                         
   (INPUT)             ---[ ->| ]---   |      (OUPUT)       PIEZO WARNING
                                   |   |                        BUZZER
CHARGE LAMP  (+)   >---*--[ ->| ]--*---|------>>---   (-)
                       |               | 
                       ---[ |<- ]-------

Here's the logic behind the design:

When any lamp is on there is (+) voltage at that connection. The other lamp 
(off) acts as a ground (-) connection (through the light bulb filament). The 
rectifier makes sure that the piezo element gets the proper polarity 
regardless of which lamp is on and which is off.

If both lamps should be lit (ignition on, engine off) then there will be no 
current flow because the rectifier is getting two (+) input voltages with no 
ground (-) to create current flow.

Make sure you use a <LOW CURRENT> (as in small) piezo buzzer ONLY because a 
larger unit will create current flow through the light bulbs. I won't get 
into details about that here.

When you build the unit you will have two wires leading to a black box 
containing the rectifier circuit and piezo buzzer. Installation is simple. 
Connect one wire to of each warning lamp wires. Does not matter which. 

I installed this in my 69-912 back in 1985. The simple circuit has operated 
reliably since then, and saved me once. (too stupid to check fan belt 
regularly?).

The nice thing about the low current piezo element is that it will make a 
faint sound when idling at low RPM when the charge lamp will be dimly lit. 
The system also acts as a 'stall warning' which fellow aviators will 
appreciate!-)

I also designed an transistor driven model (can I have the GOTWA 'Geek of 
the week award') that did not have the low current limitations mention 
above. I never built this unit but have the plans if anyone is interested.


Chris Jungmann                                   jungmann@swcp.com
Software Development                             Voice: 505-275-6566
Northern Systems, Inc.                           Fax:   203-373-0880
                                                 BBS:   203-373-0881
My mother always said: Life is like a cat,
                       you never know what it will drag in:-)

Porschephiles #1200                         Mon Feb 27 02:00:06 CST 1995
Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 01:05:16 -0500

Subject: Thanks from PML and to Stan

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 02:10 EST
From: Jay Ellis <0007142347@mcimail.com>
Subject: 951 CV Axle

When under my p-car this morning, I noticed some transmission oil leakage 
at the point where the right side CV axle attaches to the transmission
housing. Also, as I moved the axle up and down I could feel more play in
this axle as compared to the left side, and could see the CV joint
separating slightly from the housing.  Not having seen the transmission 
with the axle removed,  I'm guessing that there's a bad seal of some type
inside (or flush with) the transmission housing.  Any suggestions?  Thanks. 


Jay Ellis
7142347@mcimail.com
'87 951
'89 Feline Tigger
'92 Feline Grisabella

late 85 radiator and oil filters). Their service, delivery time and price was
excellent.
	I took a chance with them without knowing if they were reliable or not;  I
assumed  that, big ads in "Excellence Magazine" reflect serious people. But I
can do a lot of silly things for $100 in saving (after customs, delivery
charges and exchange rate CAN->US $).
	Most of the time I must rely rely on mail-order vendor for my parts need
(since the prices in Montreal area are outrageously high........not enough
competition)
	I would be interested (and maybe some other list-member) to read more about
recommended / avoided mail-order vendor appering in magazine ads
("Excellence" is the only one that I know. Any other???). ....Unless is has
been covered in past months ..... i'm new to this list u-know.

Date: 27 Feb 1995 04:13:01 GMT
From: vezp@eureka.qc.ca (Pierre Vezina)
Subject: Re: 944 Rear Hatch


	I'm not sure if someone answered your request , I quickly scanned my unread
mail without finding any reply to rear hatch (maybe I missed it). Wowww... I
think I can answer my first Porschephile message. 

	I have a 85/2 Coupe 944 which had exactly the same problem with the rear
hatch. The top portion of the frame was slowly coming off the glass and while
running
on the highway the whole thing was squeeking and grinding like hell.
	I went to my favorite Porsche dealer which gave me two options :

	1) change the rear hatch ............around $2000  .......nahhh

	2) leave the car there a couple of days in order to rebuild the rear hatch
	    (done by a sub-contractor which come to take the hatch, rebuild it,
	   and the dealer reinstall everything......for around $600 ... sounds great
	   compare to #1 but ...............nahhhh 

	I choose #3 options which is:
	
 I was able to obtain the name of the sub-contractor fixing the rear hatch 
for the Porsche dealer  .......... interesting!!!!!
	
  I told the dealer that I will think about it and I called the day after the
glass shop.

	The shop charge me $120 , "YES".... one hundred and twenty dollars (tax
included) to do the following things:
	1) remove the hatch
	2) separate the glass frame from the glass
	3) clean the glass (the black area where the frame attach to the glass), 	  
 apply a new black coating (the old one was pealing off)
	4) Glue the glass and the frame together
	5) Reinstall and readjust the hatch

	I was in heaven , they kept the car 1 1/2 day for the job (time for coating
and glue to dry). The job was professional .... OK if you look cose enough
you'll see some
imperfections but less important that the difference in price.

	I that time I was in LA area. If you're in that area I can give you the name
,
 it was a shop specialized in glass installation. Sniff Sniff now i'm back in
Montreal Canada area and the car is sitting in my garage on jackstand
patiently waiting for the hot season
	
		Pierre Vezina
		vezp@eureka.qc.ca
		85/2 Black 944 Coupe
		89 Civic SI (wife's car)
		yellow cat
		no dog

Date: Sun, 26 Feb 95 23:35:26 PST
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: Drivers with Suspended Licenses


Here's some food for thought next time you find yourself surrounded by freeway 
traffic at 70 mph . . . 
 
The March/April issue of Motorland, the California State Automobile 
Association magazine, in an article entitle "Driving with a Suspended License? 
You could lose your car!" notes that the California DMV estimates there are 
720,000 people in California driving with suspended licenses and almost one 
million "drivers" who have never bothered to get a license . . . in California 
alone! 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com) 
1962 356B Super90 Cabriolet

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 04:03:53 -0600 (CST)
From: stan@tta.com (Stan Hanks)
Subject: Status on The Fund, Electronic Frontier Region, Etc.

Phellow Porschephiles:

Lots of discussion has occurred over the last several days, and I think
it's very, very important to let you all know what's going on behind the
scenes. In part because it's just the right thing to do, in part because
we need your continued participation.

There are two things happening in parallel, both of which may interest you.
We are establishing a non-profit foundation to support the perpetual
operation of the Porschephiles mailing list, it's enhancement and further
promotion. And we are investigating methods of gaining closer ties to 
the Porsche Club of America, PCNA, and Porsche AG.

Porschephiles Foundation
- ------------------------

Thanks to the tireless efforts Bart Chambers, instigated on by Fred Pack's 
initial efforts to raise the money to have the group buy my race car, we 
have a bank account, contributions banked, misc. paperwork flowing back and
forth, and have work underway to get this thing formalized.  This leads
of course to the inevitable discussion of how formalized, and in what form.

There has been discussion of running this as a membership organization,
with annual dues, and voting, and all that sort of thing. While that
certainly has merit, should be done if that's what enough of you want,
there are some significant problems with that approach. The organization
then has a fiduciary responsibility to do a certain style of accrual 
accounting and manage its funds so that n/12ths of a member's dues can be
refunded if they resign in the middle of their "year", and this has to slide
in a manner that lets every member have their own annual date. You have 
to conform to other specific practices regarding the decision making process,
you have to have annual meetings, and a pile of other stuff.

Since I was president of the Sun Users Group for the last 4 years, and a
director for the 6 preceeding that, I've had up close and personal experience 
with governance of large non-profit membership organizations. We can do it, 
but that may note be what best serves the group. So, I ask, how about a model 
that works more like Public Television?

With a Porschephiles Foundation, you can send in your "suggested" annual 
"membership", you can send in more, or if you're in a place to do so, you can 
become a "sponsor". Or, you can do nothing and just sit back and just watch 
the list roll past. There is no obligation, no funny accounting, nothing that 
adds to the cost of running the organization, or the headache for either you 
or me.

There would be a board of governors, initially selected by the members and 
self-renewing following that. There would be the usual non-profit organization 
safeguards to ensure that those charged with running the show weren't 
profiting from it. There would be recall and petition proceedures, but no 
unnecessary political bullshit that would get in the way of the primary 
objective: running the list in a high quality manner, keeping the bills paid, 
having enhancements made, and ensuring that there's aways a place for 
Porschephiles to hang out that's free of constraint and free of charge. Very 
much like we  have now, in fact, but with the involvement of some additional 
people and a much-needed influx of cash.

So, barring disaster, massive member dissent, or acts of Ferry, that's what is 
going to happen. Watch your mail for the initial proposed slate of governors, 
and further details on the formation of this entity.

Comments, offers to help (pro bono legal and accounting services are 
especially solicited), criticisms, etc should *ALL* be sent to the following 
address:
		comments@tta.com

and *NOT* sent to the list as a whole. Open discussion on the list is OK, but 
try to keep the "yeah, me too" and other items that do not add to a greater 
understanding the issues to a minimum.

This leads to the next issue:

Affiliation with PCA, PCNA, PAG
- -------------------------------

Like it or not, most of the Porsches on the road are in North America. Like it 
or not, most of the members of this list are in North America. Consequently, 
there is a distinct North American bias to this whole process. And like it or 
not, I'm a white male of Northern European extraction, to boot. It's not PC, 
but if that's important to you, you can kiss my ass anyway.

The upshot of that is that affiliation with PCA gains maximum benefit for all 
of the members of the list from a perspective of access to technical 
resources, access to the free use of certain intellectual property (the crest, 
the name "Porsche", and several other *minor* things), and exposure to a mass 
of potential members which have something significant to add (there are over 
34,000 members of the PCA; there are but 1200 of us. if you assume the usual 
PCA 10% rule holds, where roughly 10% of the membership of the organization 
actually *DOES* anything, we're still short 2000 members...). Plus, even if we 
don't actually affiliate with PCA, its' very, very wise to not have them as 
our opponent in other discussions with PCNA and PAG. So that's the direction 
this conversation is going to head. It does not preclude additional 
affiliation with PCNA or PAG, it's just a starting point.

Note that if we are organized as a non-profit foundation, that we don't need 
some of the benefits of affiliation with PCA. We can, and should, do that on 
our own. However, this PCA thing has to be explored.

There are some very, very key issues that were raised in the last couple of 
weeks. First on the list is the requirement that a region conform to the 
general bylaws of the PCA and the PCA requirement that you actually own a car 
before you an join. Second is the fact that PCA regions are typically defined 
by ZIP codes, and we're going to break that rather badly. Third is the world-
based nature of the list, with a lot of significant and valuable international 
members, and a very, very real potential to expand overseas with only a very 
little encouragement. These need to be resolved as part of the process and the 
matter needs to be brought to the attention of those people who have indicated 
that they want to be part of this.

For the roughly 200 people that sent me notes saying that you'd like to be 
either founding members or affiliate members of the Electronic Frontier Region 
of the PCA, you'll be getting a note early next week with a confirmation and 
some further questions that need to be addressed. This matter will not be 
dropped or allowed to slide; it will proceed in parallel with the 
establishment of the foundation. You will also be added to a separate mailing 
list so that we can keep traffic about the list formation off of the main list 
so as not to detract from its primary value -- being, as someone from PCNA 
recently put it "absolutely the best technical resource available for any 
Porsche owner."

Summary
- -------

Things are happening. You'll be seeing updates from time to time, and your
input is certainly welcome. Watch this space!

Stan Hanks
Porschephiles ListMeister

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 07:32:09 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951 CV Axle

> When under my p-car this morning, I noticed some transmission oil leakage 
> at the point where the right side CV axle attaches to the transmission
> housing. Also, as I moved the axle up and down I could feel more play in
> this axle as compared to the left side, and could see the CV joint
> separating slightly from the housing.  Not having seen the transmission 
> with the axle removed,  I'm guessing that there's a bad seal of some type
> inside (or flush with) the transmission housing.  Any suggestions?  Thanks. 
> 

Hi, Jay,

Yes, most likely cause is the flange seal. Simple to replace:

1) disconnect half shaft from trans.

2) locate 6 mm allen bolt in center of flange, undo.

3) remove flange.  Note location of seal.

4) pull oil seal.

Installation is reverse of removal (learned that from haynes manuals...)


- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 10:14:19 -0500 (EST)
From: Joseph Tzougrakis <jtzougra@acad.bryant.edu>
Subject: Re: 944 Heated Seats available??

  I have only owned my '86 944 for a few months, but the heater is just 
awful.  I have the knob turned to 30 degrees celcius (which should work 
out to be 90 degrees) and the fan on full blast all the time and its 
been a mild winter.  On days when the temperature is in the teens or 
lower, I have to drive with a winter jacket on.  I have vented the 
cooling system to make sure there are no air bubbles, but think the main 
problem is that the car never gets warm.  The thermostat stays around 1/4 
all the time and won't climb any higher unless I'm in heavy traffic.  944 
turbos run a lot hotter and have much more effective heating.

Sounds like you need a new thermostat, or your thermostat has been replaced
with one that opens at a lower temperature...

Replace it with the stock one and you will have no complaints about the
amount of heat that your system will generate...

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 13:02:52 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: speedo calibration


Manufacturer seem to set speedo's => 10% fast, this saves them from legal 
probs where some idiot gets clocked for speeding then blames the 
manufacturer.

I have checked the calibration on several cars over the years, all 
running with std tyres, the worse was 11% fast, the best 5%

The odo is usually reasonably accurate though.

I checked each car by running at 60mph indicated for distances of 5 miles 
using the motorway mile posts as markers, each car was checked at least 
twice.

Why you may ask this interest in speedo calibration - boredom, stuck in 
heavy traffic....

| From   : Peter Diffey         |

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 09:19:58 PST
From: sean@scifi.ucsf.EDU (Sean Steinman)
Subject: Re: Re *#@^&% Rear Panel

Jim (All)
Believe it or not, there are mounting points for recoil belt already in place.
The mounting blocks are actually reinforced as well. I guess those guys in
Germany had some future insight(although I think that recoil belts were 
available everywhere except the US in '69. Go figure?) The parts book actually
shows recoil belts for this early model. Just thought you'd be interested.
Sean
69 912
Zero & Maddog: 8 Legs of Terror!

Subject: wierd wheels

Hi P-car p-eople:
I have question that you 356 experts may be able to help me with.  My '64
SC coupe was delivered in Italy and has Campagnolo magnesieum alloy wheels.
They appear to be the correct vintage for the car.  They require spacers
on the rear wheels and there is  very little room between the fender and
the tire edge, but there has never been any tire/body contact.  They look
good to my eye, but there's a big difference between these wheels and the
original equipment.  Since I'm selling the car these wheels could be a
strike against the car's value so I'm considering getting steel wheels and
selling these campy wheels seperately.  Does anyone have any idea where I
can get a value for these anomolies?  Is anyone interested in them (The
extra contact patch sure helps the cornering...)?  Anyone have a guess what
car they could have originally come on?

Thanks in advance,

Tom

Date:         Mon, 27 Feb 95 12:56:48 EST
From: Archie <SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU>
Subject:      914 Idle

In a continuing effort to ensure excellence from my P-car, I ask the following
questions.  First to establish an index for comparison.  I recently tuned my
914 (1972 June manuf.date) replacing at the time plugs, points, plug wires,
hoses, etc. except the rubber hose running from the cylinder heads to the
flashback valve.  Since the tune-up the RPMs at idle no matter how cold the
engine never idles over 1200.  Usually after warm up the RPMs hover around the
800 level.
   Now the questions.  Since the weather has warmed up, after a run of 20-30
minutes at highway speeds, the RPMs drop at idle to about 300.  Yesterday after
a 30 minute drive, my P-car cut completely off at a traffic light.  The RPMs
dropped to 0.  It did it a second time at the next light.  The engine would
run normal if you keep a little accelerator pedal on when stopped.

Everything else seems normal and the engine does not indicate excessive
heating.

Any recommendations and/or suggestions welcomed.

(In Eastern NC yesterday, the temperature was 71 F and wonderful with the
top off!)

Archie T. Smith
East Carolina University
Department of Sociology, Brewster A-412
Greenville, NC 27858 (919) 328-6147
Bitnet: SOASMITH@ECUVM1 Internet: SOASMITH@ECUVM.CIS.ECU.EDU

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 10:14:32 PST
From: Tom Medeiros <tomm@hpsadqh.sr.hp.com>
Subject: It's alive!! It's alive!!

Well, after 15 months of waiting for parts, money for parts, cleaning
parts, reassembling parts and just plain futzing around, the beast
has roared to life.  What an incredible feeling watching instrumentation
that had not worked or been turned on in over 13 years flicker to life.

The engine only took a few seconds of cranking before it caught and when
it did the whole house shook.  Scared the hell out of my wife, she came
running out to the garage thinking we were having an earthquake.  Once
the engine warmed and settled in a bit, it ran quite nice.

I already put about 20 miles on it this weekend.  In spite of bad tires,
tired suspension, a pair of tired carbs that I may replace, and lots
of other "little" things that still need to be done, it made an otherwise
bad week come to a very good end.  I think I had a smile on my face
the whole weekend.

It started on Saturday morning, and as I got so rapped up in tuning it
that I forgot completely about breakfast, lunch or dinner.  That
fact didn't hit me until I was slamming down a couple of celebratory
cold ones with my buddies and they hit pretty fast.  Oh well, it was all
worth it.

Of course, there are some minor flaws.  It tends to leak about 2 or 3
tablespoons of oil (what else!) after a drive.  Appears to be coming
from the pully end crankshaft seal.  I figured I installed this wrong
or something.  I've already ordered a new one to replace before I drive
it anymore.  Anyone have any idea how this would have happened?
Also a little backfiring, seems to be coming from cylinder 5.  I'm
guessing carbs being its so hard holding a steady idle.  Seems to
fluctuate between 850 and 1100.  The only gauge that seems to not work
is the oil level gauge.  Is this typical?

Those problems aside, I'm a happy camper.  First ever Porsche rebuild
and it RUNS!!  Even the wife had a big grin on her test ride.

Tom 1970 911T (vroom!!)


------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 10:28:22 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: Re: Idiot Light Audio

Regarding adding audio to idiot lights, Chris Jungmann wrote:

> 
> I installed this in my 69-912 back in 1985. The simple circuit has operated 
> reliably since then, and saved me once. (too stupid to check fan belt 
> regularly?).
> 

Shucks, there goes my Geek of the Week award... I was going to describe
a similar circuit I installed in my '83 SC in 1989, but Chris did it
quicker and better.  Anyway mine has also operated without adverse side
effects; no fanbelt or oilpump failures to report but it DID catch a
failed voltage regulator (indicated only by a dimly glowing alternator
light that I never would've noticed) just as I was about to head down
one of those "next services 87 miles" desert roads...  
This circuit is a fun simple project if you like to add little personal
techno-gadgets to your car.

 -Ed
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 11:23:00 PST

Hi April,

I had the same experience with my 73 targa.  It had sat in a pile of leave 
for 10 years, and even though it was it was somewhat sheltered, targa that 
it was, moisture crept in and the black interior was grey with mildew.

I was able to remove it quite easily with alternating applications of 
alcohol and simple green.  A good vinyl product to use after cleaning is Der 
Vinyl Stuff.

              Recent major service professionally done (10/94; 1500 miles ago):
                  - New water pump, hoses
                  - New timing, balance belts;  New rollers
                  - Clean & repack CV joints (old boots were not yet ruptured)
                  - Brake system bleed & refill
                  - New motor mounts (both sides)
                  - New balance seal, balance shaft housing
                  - New rear shocks (Koni sport)
                  - New transmission fluid (Swepco 201)
              Synthetic oil changes every 3000 miles

              kept in L.A. for most of its life (5 years).  The car is now
              in Salt Lake City, Utah.  It has been stored during the winter
              months while in Salt Lake, and never operated in snowy or road-salt
              conditions. 

              The car has been well-maintained throughout its life, and has
              never been wrecked or damaged.  It has never been raced, and has
              had no performance chips or other aftermarket performance mods
              installed.  It is in exceptionally good condition, both mechanically
              and cosmetically.  Right now the car needs nothing.  Probably the 
              next things which will require attention are the A008P tires, which
              appear to have about 5000 miles of useful life left.

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 11:51:29 -0800 (PST)
From: allanh@handmadesw.com (Allan N. Hessenflow)
Subject: Re: HELP:  Moldy interior - ugh -

I've had the same problem (not with a drivable car, as I don't store
them so they don't stay damp, but with a project car I'm working on
extremely slowly).  It was easy to clean up; I let it dry out first
and then just cleaned the leather with Lexol (it was only really growing
on the leather).  Just wiping it with anything would have probably
worked as well; by the time the car was reasonably dry the mold was all
dead and just brushed off, making quite a cloud.  I hope there's nothing
there that's too harmful to inhale...  Anyway, it does take a little
while to clean out all the little seams, but it's not difficult.

allan

- -- 
Allan N. Hessenflow     allanh@handmadesw.com

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 14:28:14 -0600 (CST)

Subject: Re: HELP:  Moldy interior - ugh -

Go to your friendly neighborhood VW Dealer (who,if he's like mine,
is neither particularly friendly nor particularly close to my neighborhood).
There purchase one each "All Purpose Cleaner". Key indicators here is it's
a plactic (white/clear) bottle with a yellow lable and black letters 
so identifying it.

I have *NO* idea what is in this stuff, but it cleans tar and nicotine
residue, mold, mildew, paint oxidization, and a ton of other crap (including
most species of bird, but that's another story...)

Stan

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 16:40:29 -0500
From: WHartje@aol.com
Subject: Re: Have '86 944 overheating ...

>> > distilled water and Red Line "Water Wetter". Anti -freeze not only stops
>> > water from freezing, it reduces you cooling system's capacity to cool
the
>> > engine.
>>
>> 	I don't think this is correct.  My chemistry is a bit hazy, but I
>> don't think that current antifreeze has much effect on the specific heat
>> capacity of the coolant.  However, it significantly raises the boiling
point.
>
>Actually this is true.  Antifreeze conducts heat more slowly than 
>water.  It raises the boiling point but doesn't get the heat out of the 
>block/head as fast as pure water.

 - That is why the term "coolant" is a total mismoner for anti-freeze, it
makes you run hotter, not colder. Water Wetter has the opposite effect, it
dissipates the heat quicker but I don't believe it gives you any improvement
in coolant boiling temperature therefore as Jim Seld says, the addition of a
small amount of anti-freeze may be necessary if you system has tendency to
boil over..

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 13:35:57 -0800 (PST)
From: allanh@handmadesw.com (Allan N. Hessenflow)
Subject: Re: HELP:  Moldy interior - ugh -

Tracy M Nelson wrote:
> Actually, inhaling the mold spores *can* be pretty harmful.  Mold likes to
> grow in warm, moist, dark places -- like the inside of your lungs.  A good
> friend of mine is an industrial safety manager, and *refused* to ride in
> her husband's '67 Charger which we "revived" after several years in a barn.
> 
> Of course, *we* rode around in it quite a bit and never had any problem, but...

The inside of ones lungs certainly qualify as warm, moist, dark places
(although the inside of my car where the mold grew couldn't have been
described as warm), but they also have an immune system that my car lacks.
Anyway, I didn't have any ill effects - at least not that I attributed to
that...  Of course I was outdoors and probably didn't actually inhale any
significant amount.

allan

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 17:03:27 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 951 CV Axle

> > 
> > Yes, most likely cause is the flange seal. Simple to replace:
> > 
> 
> Hi George
> 
> Is it possible that the bearing is worn, and hence enlargening the seal
> hole, or do you generally find that the seals wear long before the
> bearing? 

Yes, this happens, but most likely the seal first. Replace the (cheap) seal
before getting into the (more expensive) bearing...

> 
> The reason I ask is that I have noticed a slight seapage on my trans and 
> decided ( from past experience with other types of car ) that I would 
> live with it rather than go and find a bigger problem.
> 
> Next obvious question, if the bearing is worn, how hard are they to replace?

Not too bad. Probably needs a bearing puller. I haven't done mine yet, so
can't say...

> 
> I have also got slight dry scrape noise on my trans hich appears to be at 
> engine speed, it is present in all gears and seems to vary directly with 
> revs. When the car is at rest in neutral, the noise is present, but stops 
> when I depress the clutch. I had figured that this is probably the input 
> bearing. Any comment on what that can be, and the best cure.

Most likely input shaft bearing... "They all do that..."

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 17:47:31 EST
From: 27-Feb-1995 1744 <olson_r@cho000.dnet.ge.com>
Subject: 944 black smoke problem

Hi Porschephilers,

 I've been living with a black smoke problem on my 84 944 since
 I bought it last November, and am ready now to get serious about
 finding out the cause and fixing it.  Here's what I know:

  - Under heavy acceleration, the exhaust looks fine up to 3500rpm,
    at which point it becomes very black (as if it's running VERY rich).
    When the rpm drops back down, the black smoke clears.  The tailpipe,
    and even some of the close-by paint, are very sooty.  
  - The engine idles rough (probably why the previous owner set
    the idle speed to 1100rpm).  Above 1200rpm the engine smooths
    out nicely.  The idle roughness mostly disappears as the car
    warms up, but never is quite right.
  - I replaced the oxygen sensor, and a quick checked showed it
    oscillating at idle between .4v and 1.0v or so, at about
    a 2 second interval.  Seemed about right to me.
  - I had the CO adjusted.  It was a little rich, but easily adjusted
    to spec.  Anyway, neither the black smoke nor the idle improved.
  - I assume (maybe wrongly) that my oil-burn problem is not related.
    I go thru 1 qt per 600 miles, have high (20%) leakdown on one
    cylinder, but NO visible bluish smoke.  Of course, when the black
    smoke is present, I probably wouldn't see anything else,
    but at lower RPMs the exhaust is clean.  This oil-burn
    is obvious a serious matter in itself, but I'd like to fix the
    'easy' ones before going after that one.
  
 So . . . 
    - what should I check next?
    - if this car has had a black smoke problem for years, are
      exhaust system components, such as the catalytic converter,
      likely to be clogged?


Thanks for any help,

Ron Olson (olson_r@cho.ge.com)

------------------------------

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 95 15:14:56 PST
From: spindel@anchor.apl.washington.edu (Bob Spindel)
Subject: Re: It's Alive!


Tom-

Hey!  Wonderful news!  Great feeling , too, isn't it?  
Congratulations!

The one other really great thing is that everytime you get in that 
car from now on, every time you turn the key and it sputters to 
life, you'll get a bit of the same feeling you did last weekend.

On the oil leak near the pulley, check the "front cover".  Make 
sure that's not where the leak is coming from.  The surface has to 
be reasonably flat.  On the oil gauge, apparently they never 
quite operate pefectly.  On my '72 it's easy to see why.  I don't 
know if that's true in a '70.  If you peer down the oil filler tube 
while the engine is running you can see oil gushing about, 
sloshing andslushing, so to speak. The oil level sender is an arm 
and float, like the float ball in a toilet hopper, and there's no way 
it can stay at a reasonably constant level with all that oil moving 
this way and that.
Further, there is considerable expansion as the oil heats up, and 
it significantly changes the reading of the gauge.  You may not 
have gotten it warmed up enough in your 20 miles of total 
maiden voyages.

Anyway, thems are minor things.  You have the big one under 
control!


Bob Spindel
'72 911E (Restored and running!)

Date: Mon, 27 Feb 1995 20:19:04 -0700
From: Steve "THRUD" Cook <steve@prism.nmt.edu>
Subject: 944 Motor Mount repair questions.


Howdy.

------------------------------

Date: 28 Feb 95 00:48:17 EST
From: Clinton Owen <74547.3121@compuserve.com>
Subject: 944 Not Warming Up

Joseph, Try this simple test: while your car is cold, i.e. not driven for at
least an hour, turn the key to the on position without starting the engine (make
sure the A/C control knob is off) then check to see if the electric fans are
running.  If they are that is your problem, as they should normally only run
during prolonged idling, which is the only time your car starts to heat up.
There is a separate relay in the Air Conditioning system which switches the fans
on whenever you switch on the A/C.  This relay can force the fans to run all the
time.  The normal fan switch in the radiator will do the same thing and also
keep one fan running at a slower speed even with the key out, if it is stuck in
the shut position, my car has this very problem right now.

83 944


------------------------------


Porschephiles #1203                         Tue Feb 28 11:34:19 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 11:13:45 +0100
From: Trond Vidar Olsen <Trond.Vidar.Olsen@hrp.no>
Subject: The Empirical formula of Oil filter exchanges.. :) 

Hiall,

Thus not strictly Porsche related I'd like to share some interesting
gatherings.

My daily driver, the 'olde F**d' has been the testing bed for a new
'low tech' series of Engine Maintenance routines.

First:
When should I change Oil and filter and how to determine this?
**************************************************************
Data:

After 0 kilometer with new filter and oil, the oil lamp goes off
almost immideatly after engine starts.

After 5000 kilometer I have about 2 seconds delay before the oil light
goes off. 

After 15000 kilometer (Yes, I'm cheap... ;) I'm up to almost 4 seconds
before the lamp goes off...start to get intimidating.

The change of oil and filter at this moment brings down the delay to
almost 0 again.  

I've run the 0-15000 km 'data gathering' twice, and the pattern was
similar in both 'tests'.
(..I used electric engine heater in the wintertime, so the temperature
range from which I started the engine shouldn't have a delta over 10
degrees Celsius.)

Advice;
If you under (~constant outdoor temperatures) notice an increase in
delay of oil lamp going off, change oil! (You should assure that the
engine temperature is similar in test cases though.)

*********************************************************************
Fuel consumption versus mileage with the new air filter:

Two tests were run, in the first I had no significant increase in
fuel consumption from 0 to 15000 kilometres. This was Spring to early
winter kilometres. (Mostly long nice weather weekend trips)

In the second test I noticed about 4 % increase in fuel consumption
from 0 to 1000 kilometres, from there up to 15000 kilometres I got a
whopping 35 % increase. 

Advice?

Due to the random factor of weather there was no pattern from the two
tests I could use, therefore;

Inspect Air filter at least every 5000 kilometres (3500 miles), if
dirty replace.

*******************************************************************
Spotted in San Jose Mercury News (WWW)

PORSCHE '65 356SC Cpe. nd some wrk $6500 867-4094

*******************************************************************

cheerio,
Trond V.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 12:08:42 +0000 (GMT)
From: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: AM Radio in 944

On 28 Feb 1995, Pierre Vezina wrote:

> 
> 	I can't receive any AM radio signal in my 85/2 944. I have a CD Alpine
> Stereo

AM signals are far more prone to interference, so bad connections tend to 
have more effect on AM signals - so check that the antenna coax is pushed 
fully home, also check the connections to the pre-amp and the windshield 
antenna itself.

It is possible that the pre-amp is not even powered, if you live in an 
area with good FM coverage, the FM signals probably get through even 
without the antenna plugged in.


+-------------------------------+
| From   : Peter Diffey         |
+-------------------------------+

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 13:43:41 +0100
From: kevinh@hasler.ascom.ch (Kevin Holden)

> Phellow Porschephiles:

> There has been discussion of running this as a membership organization,
> with annual dues, and voting, and all that sort of thing. While that
> certainly has merit, should be done if that's what enough of you want,
> there are some significant problems with that approach.

Not least of which is that membership would sink to a fraction of what it
currently is - not many people who subscribe to the Internet seem to be
prepared to pay for anything, regardless of quality. Whilst a reduction
in membership would be advantageous in some ways (like, I could read it all!)
I wonder if porschephiles would suffer because of it? 


> With a Porschephiles Foundation, you can send in your "suggested" annual 
> "membership", you can send in more, or if you're in a place to do so, you can 
> become a "sponsor". Or, you can do nothing and just sit back and just watch 
> the list roll past. There is no obligation, no funny accounting, nothing that 
> adds to the cost of running the organization, or the headache for either you 
> or me.

I suspect you'd get a small regular core of people financing the thing and
most people sitting back doing sweet FA.   

> This leads to the next issue:
> 
> Affiliation with PCA, PCNA, PAG
> - -------------------------------
> 
> Like it or not, most of the Porsches on the road are in North America. Like it 
> or not, most of the members of this list are in North America. Consequently, 
> there is a distinct North American bias to this whole process.

But will it continue that way? I suspect the biggest internet growth
areas are outside the US(?), will the balance of membership change in the future?
What percentage of membership is non US, about 5-10% I suspect. Why not register with
PAG as a separate entity - a worldwide electronic medium or whatever phrase
you like?

> There are some very, very key issues that were raised in the last couple of 
> weeks. First on the list is the requirement that a region conform to the 
> general bylaws of the PCA and the PCA requirement that you actually own a car 
> before you an join.

PCGB allow, I think, up to 10% of membership to be porscheless, isn't that a better
example to follow (if possible).

> list so that we can keep traffic about the list formation off of the main list 
> so as not to detract from its primary value -- being, as someone from PCNA 
> recently put it "absolutely the best technical resource available for any 
> Porsche owner."

Whilst it's currently the best technical resource currently available -  with a bit
of improvement/investment (eg links to PCNA, and other clubs eg. PCGB, trouble-shooters,
factory manuals, on-line workshop manuals (inevitable at some point, surely?), sales 
info (to satisfy sales-critters)  etc etc it could be rather interesting.

Kevin - day dreaming again...
