Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 09:31:48 -0400
From: cbt@eduplus.ca (Stephen Davies)

> I'd also love to hear of anyone's stories on how 944's stand up (or don't) in
>extreme cold situations. I just acquired my car, and plan to use it
>year-round. Am now trying to figure out what kind of engine heater I can
>install -- have had a lot of local input, but none from anyone who could call
>themselves a Porsche expert. I'm told there is no available factory block
>heater, as there supposedly is for the 928.

I had an '86 944 in Fort McMurray, AB for a couple of years. I had an oil
pan heater installed (at Eurasia, Edmonton) and a Canadian Tire battery
blanket. This was good for starts in -28 C or warmer. Beyond that I just
waited for the next "warm front". No other major cold related problems.

I've moved back to the relative warmth of Halifax and no longer have to
worry about heating accessories. ( just more car washes !)

Stephen Davies, 1988 944 Turbo S



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 09:31:40 -0400
From: cbt@eduplus.ca (Stephen Davies)
Subject: 944 in cold


>I'd also love to hear of anyone's stories on how 944's stand up (or don't) in
>extreme cold situations. I just acquired my car, and plan to use it
>year-round. Am now trying to figure out what kind of engine heater I can
>install -- have had a lot of local input, but none from anyone who could call
>themselves a Porsche expert. I'm told there is no available factory block
>heater, as there supposedly is for the 928.

I spent 5 years in Fort McMurray, AB, 3 winters with my 944. I had Eurasia
(Edmonton) install a oil pan heater and Canadian tire installed a battery
blanket. With both turned on for a couple of hours, I was able to start the
car in about -28 C or warmer. Below that I just left it until a "warm
front" appeared. I had the car outside so if you have a garage you should
do better. Other than starting I had no major cold related related
problems, except for a small brake fluid leak at the master cylinder that
cleared up with warmer weather.

I have returned to the relative warmth of Halifax and fortunately no longer
need the aformentioned heating equipment.(just more car washes !)

Date:    p 25 Feb 95 12:16:38 EST
From: Tracy_Meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov
Subject: 944 wheel repair question

Hello All;

Friday was a bad day in Greenbelt.  On the way to work someone decided to change 
lanes right into the side of my '89 951.  Mostly only sheet metal damage.  He 
got the right door and rear quarter panel.  As a result of the contact, both 
rear wheel lips were scraped up.  The hubs seem fine.  The left wheel got it 
worse as the back end was pinned between the curb on the median strip and the 
other car.

The body shop (Elite Autohaus is Jessup, Maryland) said the wheels could be 
repaired by putting them on a device similar to a brake lathe.  They use a place 
called Wheel Works to do the work.  Has anybody had experience with this type of 
repair to forged alloys?  Will they be weaker as a result of the repair? 
Obviously I would rather have new wheels, but how do I explain to the insurance 
adjuster the need for strong wheels at 130mph at Summit Point?  Thanks in 
advance.

Tracy Meyer
tracy_meyer@ccmail.gsfc.nasa.gov

I notice that lots of discerning beer drinkers are commenting
on the merits of Adnams. Was it not Adnams that won the Great
British Beer Festival last year? I think so. I regret that
I was unable to obtain a sample, despite many visits last summer 
to this excellent annual event. I did however quaff many pints
from many breweries, including the awesome Summer Lightning
from the Hop Back Brewery. I can recommend this event to the
thirsty multitudes. For those who consider that beer should
be made from rice, pasturised, filtered, refrigerated, served
using gas dispensers and have "no aftertaste", I feel only pity,
and not much at that. Just my .02 pints worth!

Can I claim the record for the most beer ever transported in
a 911? I brought back ~120 litres from Belgium quite recently,
with driver and passenger on board AND luggage. Beat that if you 
can pcar people.

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 09:25:15 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 wheel repair question

> Hello All;
> 
> The body shop (Elite Autohaus is Jessup, Maryland) said the wheels could be 
> repaired by putting them on a device similar to a brake lathe.  They use a pl
> called Wheel Works to do the work.  Has anybody had experience with this type
> repair to forged alloys?  Will they be weaker as a result of the repair? 
> Obviously I would rather have new wheels, but how do I explain to the insuran
> adjuster the need for strong wheels at 130mph at Summit Point?  Thanks in 
> advance.
> 

There are several places that advertise in Pano that do this kind of work.

The effect on wheel strength would be a function of how much metal is
removed, and from where it is removed...

Probably not enough metal will be removed to affect the strength of your
forged wheels...  If the gouges are deep enough for you to be worried about
this, junk them and buy some new ones or even some used ones...

Good luck

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 09:41:40 -0500 (EST)
From: Derek Cahill <cahilld@freenet.scri.fsu.edu>
Subject: Re: What color is the inside of 911 taillight housings?

Well, the 73 911T we have out in the garage has black 'trim' around the 
lights. As age has taken its toll, I recently repainted 3 of the four 
lenses (the fourth one I dropped on the floor and had to replace... hint 
in working with those: don't drop 'em, they are $60-$90 through mail 
order... I got lucky and found the correct one at a swap meet)

Anyways, from what I know, depending on whether or not your car has the 
'Euro' look or not, it could be black or it could be chrome. They should 
all match AND they should match your horn grille (which also came in 
black or chrome)
See what you've got and make it all match up.
 -Derek Cahill

Date: 28 Feb 1995 07:10:06 U
From: "Nans Kunz" <Nans_Kunz@qmgate.arc.nasa.gov>
Subject: Tire Balancing

 2/28/95       6:47 AM        Subject:    Tire Balancing

Does anyone know anything about "Accu-balancing" ?  Yesterday, I went to a
local Wheel Works to have a flat fixed for free on my Maxima, and they talked
me into this new "state of the art" tire truing procedure.  The procedure
involves turning the tire slowly with a load applied to it, then buffing
(grinding) of the so called high spots based on the flexing.  When the buffing
is complete, they do a regular spin balance.   Is this a worth while procedure
or just another way to separate a customer from his/her money?  ($12/tire).
My free flat repair (screw in the tire) ended up costing $48.
Nans Kunz
'86 951 daily driver
'89 Maxima with accu-balanced tires (wife's daily driver)
'92 Explorer skimobile

- ---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 09:24:24 -0500 (EST)
From: ROBERT DUCKWORTH <gp310ad@prism.gatech.edu>
To: Peter Diffey <pete@suppdbg.suppdb.bt.co.uk>
Subject: Re: AM Radio in 944

> 
> On 28 Feb 1995, Pierre Vezina wrote:
> 
> > 
> > 	I can't receive any AM radio signal in my 85/2 944. I have a CD Alpine
> > Stereo

You might want to check for an adjustment to match the antenna to the radio.
Usually a small coil or cap accessible through a hole near the antenna
jack on the radio. This is not an issue with factory radios as they are 
already set up for the antenna config. of the car. Aftermarket, esp. older
units are a different story.
 -bob

Date: 28 Feb 1995 10:53:57 GMT
From: cbennet@lmcorp.com (Chris Bennet)
Subject: Re: Speedo calibration


For what it's worth, I saw an indicated 165mph on my stock '86 951 twice.
[With standard size Comp T/A tires.]
IF the car was at its factory claimed top speed,
AND the factory claimed top speed is 152mph,
The error (at this speed at least) would be a wopping 8.5%.
  
My Carrera seems to be very optimistic in the speedo department also.

  Personally, I would much rather have a speedo that was right
on the money.  Probably the law suit factor at work.  [Notice that
I didn't say anything bad about lawyers.<g>]

 vrooom,
  Chris
  cbennet@lmcorp.com

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 11:27:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 wheel repair question


Tracy,

If your damage is limited to the inner or outer "lips" as you call
them, I think that taking a little metal off would probably not be
a real problem.

For more serious repair (straightening, welding), Porsche's answer
would be a resounding no.  I am pretty sure that tech bulletins to
that effect exist, and presenting them to your adjuster should
be all that s/he needs to OK new rims.

If you have scraped or scuffed the anodized surface of the Design
90 style wheel, it cannot to my knowledge be restored.

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 11:33:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: Goodwill Claims


Randy,

My understanding has been that PCNA area rep's each work with
a goodwill budget, allowing them to take care of the kinds of situation
you describe.

(Locally, Clair Porsche working with our rep did a number of things for
my car when it had come out of warranty -- great guys, very happy with
them and the work they did.)

Kevin

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 09:56:41 -0700
From: mhatch@utg.org (Mark Hatch)
Subject: Re: color is the inside of 911

Thanks!

BTW: What is a "RC" store?

Sounds like the way to do it. Did you have to supplement the self-adhesive
at all?

mark


>Hi, Mark,
>
>>I am restoring my 73 911T and have reached the point where I am restoring
>>the taillight housings. The previous owner at painted the inside with
>>"chrome" paint. Unfortunately, he did not prepare the surface well, so I
>>had to strip it.
>
>>As I stripped the inside of the housings, it appeared that some parts were
>>actually white. Is this true? Are there some parts that are suppose to have
>>a "chrome" finish?
>
>When we restored my '70 911E Targa, we noticed a similar problem with the
>"chrome" fiinished having worn off. The white underneath is the color of the
>plastic housing. This white plastic housing was somehow chromed. It is a
>rather shoddy detail. We did ot like any of the chrome paints we saw. None
>would give the reflective quality of chrome. The lights are not as
>"brilliant" and when dealing with tail lights, I want someone to see them.
>Finding "good" used replacement housings are difficult, most suffer from the
>same affliction. New housing replacements are expensive.
>
>One day while browsing through the local RC store, I found some adhesive
>backed chrome sheeting. It would reflect about the same as the chrome
>plating. The only trick would be to apply it to the housing that did not look
>like a third grader did the job. Our first attempt was on one of our "other"
>cars and discovered you have to have a good template cut first. You also have
>to insure that the housings are clean of grease/dirt and any loose plating
>has been removed.
>
>Once we applied this to one of the 911 taillight housings, we made a test for
>brightness. If the result was going to be no better than the paint, we would
>have to dive into the ol' checking account for new housings. I was very
>pleased with how bright the tail lights were. In fact, they had not been that
>bright for quite some time.
>
>The chrome sheeting has been on the housings now for approx. two years. I
>checked them about two months ago and was pleased they are still in good
>shape.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 11:51:00 EST
From: Kevin Gross <keving@mesa.com>
Subject: RE: 944 black smoke problem


Ron,

I would begin by doing the following.  Pack up your spark plug wrench
and go for a drive.  Find a road which isn't too busy, run the car up to
the point at which it is making the black smoke, then immediately shut
down the engine, park the car, and pull each of the four plugs.  You
want to find out whether the problem is common to all cylinders or is
specific to one, perhaps the one with the high leak down.

Let's assume it's common.  If you have unburnt fuel, it will be because
you either have too much fuel, too little spark, or a compression
problem.  You know that compression is OK on three cylinders, so
eliminate that for the time being.

Too much fuel could come from a bad air flow meter or perhaps an
injector which is hanging up.  I posted something in the past few weeks
regarding checking the AFM: check its output signal as you sweep
its barn door from limit to limit.  Injectors are a little harder to check,
but you can pull the rail, run the fuel pump with the coil disconnected,
and get a qualitative idea of their comparative output.  I think Probst
covers this is his book -- worth reading.

Too little spark could result from a bad coil, wires, plugs, and a number
of other sources.  Check the battery voltage at RPM and the alternator
output.  Check the coil impedences and the wire impedences, including
the wire from the coil to the cap.  Check the cap and rotor while you're
at it.

If you run way rich, unburnt fuel will get burnt within the rather hot 
catalytic
converter, and that will indeed met it.  Also, if you dump too much fuel
into a cylinder, it will wash the cylinder's walls of lubrication, which 
will
lead to damaging the rings and the wall surface.  Perhaps this is why
you have bad leak-down on one of your cylinders.

Kevin

------------------------------

availble is the BFG 230 (competition) tire.  This tire is still more
competitive then the current generation Yokohama tire (RS-II).

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 09:50:35 PST
From: "Michael Hodos" <MHODOS@us.oracle.com>
Subject: More on Drivers with Suspended Licenses


- --Boundary-7178196-0-0

Jim: 
 
Initially there is both a written and a practical driver's test. 
 
Once the practical test is taken successfully, only the written test is 
required until you're 60 or so.  In addition, if you establish a perfect 
driving record you can renew every other time without taking the written test. 
 The license is good for 4 years. 
 
Far from perfect, but by and large my experience has been the Califiornians 
are pretty good drivers . . . at least on the freeways that I travel routinely. 
 
The two biggest sins I've been noticing of late: following other cars far to 
closely for the speed and changing lanes/turning without signalling. 
 
The latter is especially onerous given the fact that the CHP recently made it 
known that something like 90% of the accidents on California roads and 
freeways  are the result of drivers failing to signal their intentions! 
 
Michael Hodos (mhodos@us.oracle.com) 
 
1962 356B Super90 Cabriolet

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 09:51:32 -0800 (PST)
From: scokelly@netcom.com (Scott Kelly)
Subject: Re: 944 Motor Mount repair questions.

Steve,

I am not a professional mechanic, but over the past 6 years I have
replaced probably 4 sets of motor mounts.  My technic may not
be the recommended method, but it worked great those 4 times.

I don't have any advise on the Automation "kit" as I have
always purchased just the regular 944 turbo motor mount.  I do
not know what else Automation would put in the kit.

Oh well, here is what I do:

1) Jack front of car and support with jack stands.

2) Unbolt existing mounts.

3) Use engine lift (or hoist rig or in my case my dad's fork
   lift and a chain) to lift the engine off the motor mounts.
   I lifted from both engine hooks (front & back).  The lifting
   is the tricky part.  Lift too high and you might damage the
   exhaust system/headers, etc.

4) Once you lift high enough to remove old mounts, insert new ones.
   You will find they are taller and you will probably have to
   lift the engine some more.  You will also have to twist & turn &
   crowbar the things in place - but it can be done.  Make sure they
   are inserted the right way.

5) Lower engine & tighten bolts.

Other things to try:
  ? Do one side at a time, lifting only one side???
  ? Disconnecting exhaust system to prevent damage.
  ? Lift engine from underneath.

Good luck,

Scott Kelly (scokelly@netcom.com)
85.5 944
95   C220

Maintain for Mom & friend
86   944
83   944

Actively looking to buy:
89-91 C2 or C4 (<$34,000)

Porschephiles #1204                         Tue Feb 28 15:07:34 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 12:58:20 EST
From: connerst@pwfl.com (Steve Conner 407-796-5968)
Subject: Re: 914 Idle

Archie T. Smith wrote:

>   Now the questions.  Since the weather has warmed up, after a run of 20-30
>minutes at highway speeds, the RPMs drop at idle to about 300.  Yesterday >after
>a 30 minute drive, my P-car cut completely off at a traffic light.  The RPMs
>dropped to 0.  It did it a second time at the next light.  The engine would
>run normal if you keep a little accelerator pedal on when stopped.


I own a 1980 931, but I experienced the same problem you described.  The problem turned out to be a crack in the air hose between the air flow sensor and the turbo inlet.  This caused the engine to run lean and cut out at idle.  

I would check all hoses.  Even with this leak, I readjusted the mixture ratio to correct the problem until I got a new hose.


Steve Conner
'80 931

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 12:09:04 -0600 (CST)
From: Menelaos Karamichalis <mnk@wuerl.wustl.edu>
Subject: SUMMARY: BFG Comp T/A R1

This is logn overdue, but here it is: I got a number of responses from
helpful individuals.  These responses gave me some hints as to what the
part numbers meant on the data sheets I got from BFG.  In the beginning I
did not understand what 230 and 226 meant and how the numbers tied into
the Comp T/A R1, but crosschecking with the data sheets made it very
obvious (thus I learned something new!!) 230 is the competition (Road Race
in BFGtalk) R1 tire.  226 is the autocross R1 tire.  The data sheets that
were mailed on Feb 15, 1995 listed only 11 sizes of the R1 226 type left in
current stock, compared to 21 sizes of the R1 230 type.  Basically, as fellow
Porschephilers pointed out, the R1 226 type has been discontinued, only what
is left over is available. 

The data sheets also mention the BFG R1 204 Competition (BFGtalk again) 
type. None of the responses I got mentioned this tire, so I cannot offer 
information on this one.

So to sum it up: forget the BFG R1 226 unless what is in stock fits your
car.  Get the BFG R1 230 which seems to have impressed a lot of drivers.

Here are the responses I received(thanks guys!)
__________
From: noorder@btg.com
I would strongly suggest that you become a Team TA member if you
are going to be doing any racing on BFG's.  It is free and you will
get a monthly newsletter, be eligible for close-outs on tires,
get discounts from some vendors, etc.  Call (800) RACE-BFG and
they will be happy to sign you up.

The BFG 226 (autocross) has indead been discontinued.  The only tire
availble is the BFG 230 (competition) tire.  This tire is still more
competitive then the current generation Yokohama tire (RS-II).
__________
From: Michael Willis <mswillis@ix.netcom.com>
My understand is that the autox version has been discontued.
__________
From: Mike Lommatzsch <mpl@netcom.com>
Menelaos -

Forget about the autocross compound tire for now.  I t is no longer 
available from BFG as they are sticking to their 230 tire for the 
expected victories.

___________
From: Scott Winders <winders@support.apple.com>
Menelaos,

The Autocross version, the BFG R1 226 compound, is no longer available.
The 230 compound is a very nice tire that is better (faster) than any
version of the Yokohama RS tire. I used the Yokohama RS II (autocross
compound) tire last year and switched to the BFG R1 230 compound this
year. I can already tell that it is a much faster tire. My local
competition has to worry a little bit more this year ;-).

Get the BFG R1 230 compound, you will be happy you did.
__________

I hope that someone will benefit from this.

'93 Red-White Miyata Five-12

Kevin, you're the one who made a blanket inaccurate statement
to the list that multi-valving was NOT POSSIBLE
for air cooled motors.  I only corrected the statement
based on experience outside the Porsche realm.

A 1 liter 4 valve 150hp motorcycle powerplant is hardly
as you say "what can be made to work".   It IS pretty
darn good engineering. 

From my observations, the list membership as
a whole acknowledges the cross over engineering from 
other fields including motorcycles, aircraft, etc.
The same laws of physics apply to all vehicles.

Your reference to kitchen appliances, and chain saws was
an un-called-for exageration.

No one knows it all, that's why we have a list.  Just limit
your comments to that which you know, or accept correction
like man.

FLAME OFF

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 11:08:11 -0800
From: aek@netcom.com (Andrew Kalman)
Subject: Tire Mounting Advice Sought

I'd like some advice on tire mounting ...

In the past I've had my tires mounted at Dinan (the BMW tuners), but their
machine grips the inside "back" of the wheel in such a way to leave
permanent little dimple marks, as if one took an automatic center punch to
the wheel. They claim "that's just how the machine works." To their credit,
I do end up with well-balanced wheels, but I find it hard to believe that
it's physically necessary to dig into aluminum wheels in order to mount
tires on them.

I've never seen any marks on aluminum wheels from the factory.  Can anyone
recommend a particular brand of wheel-mounting machine that does not mar
the wheel?  I'm concerned with 15"-18" wheels, 6"-9" widths.

Also, any recommendations for tire mounting places in the San Francisco Bay
Area?

Thanks,

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 14:09:37 -0500
From: David944@aol.com
Subject: Good Will Claim by Porsche YES!

Randy-

I own a 84 944 with a power sunroof.  The electric motor went two years ago,
taking the cable with it.  I brought it to the dealer and found that Porsche
had 'updated' the part, and I needed some significant modifications made to
my roof mount, plus parts, we were talking $1500+.

I called Porsche North America and spoke to Hank???, sorry, can't remember
his name.  Said that I had been through the water pump upgrade, the engine mou
nt thing a couple of times, and felt that I had lived through more than my
share of payments for components that should have been designed correctly the
first time.  He aggreed, and Porsche payed for all the parts and split the
labor.  I am the original owner, but the question never came up.

He did comment, that being nice and friendly on the phone put me in a very
small minority of callers, and it did contribute to his helping me out on this
 one.

David944@aol.com

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 14:14:33 -0500 (EST)
From: RINGNALDA@kcgl1.eng.ohio-state.edu
Subject: 944 idle problem

I have a 86 1/2 944 which has just been cured from 8 bent valves after 
spitting the timing belt tensioner out.  After completing this job and with 
much anticipation as to other noises which may (or may not) appear upon 
turning the ignition key, I found with much relief that the engine sounds 
great.  However even though it starts without pushing the accelerator down, it 
will not keep running, in fact it dies as soon as it catches.  The only way I 
can keep it running is by putting the gas pedal right down on the floor, and 
keeping it running at sensible rpm by manipulating the pedal, however this is 
accompanied by backfiring (occasionally)
	Things checked are:
inputs to the computer (seem all OK)
plugs (black & sooty) seem running rich
Timing of crank vs cam & balance shafts (all OK)
fuel pressure (seems OK)

	Has anyone ever had this type of problem before, and is there an 
additional control unit for the idle control valve on this model?  If so where 
is it hidden?

	Thanks,   Jan Ringnalda

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 11:25:51 PST
From: Ed Mellinger <meed@mbari.org>
Subject: 911 Hidden Mold

Hi Folks -

Speaking of moldy cars... last year I made the mistake of rinsing some
salt spray off my 911, using a spray gun, while the engine was idling
and the heater was on.  I believe that some water got sucked into the
fan and pumped thru the heat exchangers and into the heater ducts,
because during the following couple of weeks I began to notice the smell
of Something Growing whenever I had the heat on.  Not a totally awful
smell, just a wet-dog sort of smell, annoying and embarrassing but not
life threatening.  *However* it has not gone away with the passage of
time, or rather, it comes back whenever the weather's damp.

I theorize that some kind of single-celled life form (er, I HOPE it's
single celled!) has colonized the heater ducts that are built into the
frame rails.  Whatever it is seems to survive extended runs with the
heater on full blast, which is pretty hot ("dammit, Scotty, more power!"
"Thot's ooll she's got, Cap'n!").  

Has anyone else ever experienced this?  Does anyone know of a
fumigant/deodorant that might be pumped thru the ducts to wipe out this
life form?  Things like this must happen to you folks in the Southeast
occasionally...

As for the rest of you: DON'T wash your 911 with the engine running and
the heater on, or if you do, drive far enough to dry out the ducts.

 -Ed Mellinger
meed@mbari.org
'83 911SC   with a friendly tail-wagging sort of aroma in winter :-)

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 14:42:00 PST
From: Browning David <BrowningD@rnd1.indy.tce.com>
Subject: RE: 944 idle problem


     I had a similar phenomenon with my Rabbit the other day.  I was 
checking some wiring and started the car up and basically the same thing 
happened.  Poor idle, backfiring...I found that the control plug to the 
frequency valve (CIS K-jetronic) came off.  I have a 944 and know the 
systems are different, but some similar control scheme could be causing the 
same problems.  On my car the frequency valve basically adjusts the amount 
of fuel sent to the injectors, which is controlled by the black box.  Maybe 
it could be even a disconnected O2 sensor (I think that might make it run 
rich--I'd have to think about it--but you said you checked that.)  I've been 
in the process of trying to fix a low mpg problem in the Rabbit so I've done 
a little studying mainly from the Probst book and my Bentley manuals.

If Kirk S. sees this maybe he can lend a theory or two.  (We are EE's that 
work together and have been soaking up as much knowledge as possible in this 
area.)

Good luck,
David B.
89 944 2.7
81 Rabbit

   I have a 86 1/2 944 which has just been cured from 8 bent valves after
   spitting the timing belt tensioner out.  After completing this job and 
with
   much anticipation as to other noises which may (or may not) appear upon
   turning the ignition key, I found with much relief that the engine sounds 

   great.  However even though it starts without pushing the accelerator 
down,
   it
   will not keep running, in fact it dies as soon as it catches.  The only 
way I
   can keep it running is by putting the gas pedal right down on the floor, 
and
   keeping it running at sensible rpm by manipulating the pedal, however 
this is
   accompanied by backfiring (occasionally)
           Things checked are:
   inputs to the computer (seem all OK)
   plugs (black & sooty) seem running rich
   Timing of crank vs cam & balance shafts (all OK)
   fuel pressure (seems OK)

           Has anyone ever had this type of problem before, and is there an
   additional control unit for the idle control valve on this model?  If so
   where
   is it hidden?

           Thanks,   Jan Ringnalda

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 14:48:30 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: 944 idle problem

> I have a 86 1/2 944 which has just been cured from 8 bent valves after 
> spitting the timing belt tensioner out.  After completing this job and with 
> much anticipation as to other noises which may (or may not) appear upon 
> turning the ignition key, I found with much relief that the engine sounds 
> great.  However even though it starts without pushing the accelerator down, i
> will not keep running, in fact it dies as soon as it catches.  The only way I
> can keep it running is by putting the gas pedal right down on the floor, and 
> keeping it running at sensible rpm by manipulating the pedal, however this is
> accompanied by backfiring (occasionally)
> 	Things checked are:
> inputs to the computer (seem all OK)
> plugs (black & sooty) seem running rich
> Timing of crank vs cam & balance shafts (all OK)
> fuel pressure (seems OK)
> 

My friend,

You have a large vacuum leak.

Look to make sure that the large (3/4 inch diameter) hose is connected at
the bottom of the intake manifold (near the back of the air filter
housing...)

Otherwise, look for some disconnected hose.

You have the classic symptoms of a good-sized leak...

Good luck
- --
George Beuselinck, georgeb@mhv.net
944 Ecology, Purveyors of Used Porsche 944 Parts
172 Hardenburgh Road, Ulster Park, NY  12487
1-800-ALL-P944 / (914) 658-9593

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 13:53:44 -0600 (CST)
From: mjt@adc.com (Mike J Tietel)
Subject: Re: RE; motorcycles, was multi valve

> 
> Your reference to kitchen appliances, and chain saws was
> an un-called-for exageration.
> 
> No one knows it all, that's why we have a list.  Just limit
> your comments to that which you know, or accept correction
> like man.

One could argue that (on a Porsche mailing list) references to
motorcycles are irrelevant.

Kevin's point is that the differences in the design parameters
for automobiles vs motorcycles vs lawnmowers vs chain saws
(ad infinitum) are *not* insignificant.  (Consider that motorcycles
don't have to worry about heating a passenger compartment, engine
cooling vs bodywork, etc.)  So... what works for a motorcycle may
not work for an automobile.

If Porsche's engineers say that 4V air-cooled engines won't work
in an *automobile*, I'm inclined to believe them.  What specific
engineering data do *you* have that refutes their claim *for
automobiles*.

Now, lighten up!!!  And take your medication tomorrow.  ;-)

- -- 
mike
mjt@adc.com

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 15:01:02 -0500 (EST)
From: len@library.mt.att.com
Subject: dying 944...

Jan writes:

 have a 86 1/2 944 which has just been cured from 8 bent valves after 
spitting the timing belt tensioner out.  After completing this job and with 
much anticipation as to other noises which may (or may not) appear upon 
turning the ignition key, I found with much relief that the engine sounds 
great.  However even though it starts without pushing the accelerator down, it 
will not keep running, in fact it dies as soon as it catches.  The only way I 
can keep it running is by putting the gas pedal right down on the floor, and 
keeping it running at sensible rpm by manipulating the pedal, however this is 
accompanied by backfiring (occasionally)
	Things checked are:
inputs to the computer (seem all OK)
plugs (black & sooty) seem running rich
Timing of crank vs cam & balance shafts (all OK)
fuel pressure (seems OK)

	Has anyone ever had this type of problem before, and is there an 
additional control unit for the idle control valve on this model?  If so where 
is it hidden?

	Thanks,   Jan Ringnalda
=======================
Jan, have you re-connected all hoses? Sounds like you might have a vacuum
leak somewhere that is confusing the air meter.

There a number of hoses running under the intake manifold, providing vacuum to
the brake booster, charcoal canister, etc. 

Also, did you plug any of the intake manifold tubes? 

And BTW, sorry to hear about your valves! I bent two of mine some time ago...

Lou Nicotra

Hi Mark,

An "RC" store is a Radio Control store. Usually a hobby shop will specialize
in various types of sport. In our case, we like radio controlled cars.

sheets. We did not have to enhance the adhesive at all. The product is made
to withstand some abuse from the RC cars and buggies.

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 12:54:10 PST

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 14:37:41 CST
From: Lee=Atkinson%Portable%PCPD=Hou@bangate.compaq.com
Subject: What good is Plastigauge ?


    This might sound like a question even a novice could answer, but what is
  the real use for Plastigauge ?  I -think- I've used it, but....it doesn't
  seem to make sense that bearings are available in sizes of 10/1000 over
  and Plastigauge looks for clearances of 1-4/1000s...
       
   * It seems like if you use it to measure clearances while taking the
        engine apart, you're checking against worn bearings. Even if
        the Plastigauge deforms within spec it might be too tight with
        new bearings.
   * It seems like it would work if you have a set of new, standard
        size bearings and want to know if you can use them again. But how
        many times would you have a new, standard set to compare to ?
   *  Most the literature I've seen suggests you use it on re-assembly,
      at which time you've presumably already mike'd and ground your crank
      and bought new bearings. If clearance is off, does this suggest
      regrinding the crank and matching new bearings ?  
            
      How are you supposed to use the stuff ? Maybe to jibe with your
     micrometer measurement of the journal itself ? Or is it the only real
     way to measure crank to bearing clearances with torqued caps ?
       
         -  Lee A (just curious)....

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 16:17:11 EST
From: lupienj@wal.hp.com (John Lupien)
Subject: Re: What good is Plastigauge ?

>     This might sound like a question even a novice could answer, but what is
>   the real use for Plastigauge ?  I -think- I've used it, but....it doesn't
>   seem to make sense that bearings are available in sizes of 10/1000 over
>   and Plastigauge looks for clearances of 1-4/1000s...

Right - you aren't supposed to use an oversized bearing on a stock journal.
You have to get the clearance right. That's where the plastiguage comes in.

>    * It seems like if you use it to measure clearances while taking the
>         engine apart, you're checking against worn bearings. Even if
>         the Plastigauge deforms within spec it might be too tight with
>         new bearings.

Right enough. You use it on the actual pieces that you plan to use "from here
on". It seems pretty foolish to go through all the effort of the dissassembly
and reassembly of your precious engine without replacing any and all wear
items such as bearings, rings, etc.

>    * It seems like it would work if you have a set of new, standard
>         size bearings and want to know if you can use them again. 

What do you mean "again"? Are these "new, used standard sized bearings"?
No such thing.

>    *  Most the literature I've seen suggests you use it on re-assembly,
>       at which time you've presumably already mike'd and ground your crank
>       and bought new bearings. If clearance is off, does this suggest
>       regrinding the crank and matching new bearings ?  

Absolutely. Or maybe it suggests that you made some other kind of mistake.
It's kind of a safety net...

- -- 
- ---
John R. Lupien
lupienj@wal.hp.com

a lane change on the interstate.  I think they were just picking on him, 
he was 16, driving my fathers 944 Cab at the time.  He has also been 
pulled over for excessive acceleration and separately for revving his 
engine.  He got a lecture from the state cop on why it was dangerous and 
bla bla bla.  The cop then started asking him about the car.

The one that take sthe cake, is what happened when he was driving his 
3000GT VR4 at about 2:30 AM in Clarksburg, he had just finished 
lifeguarding for a YMCA special event (i.e. being a good citizen) and was 
on his was home.  The cop pulled him over, came up to the window, and 
explaine, "Son do you realize that you were going 24 in a 25 mph zone?"

I forgot to mention that all of the above happened in West Virginia.

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 13:27:12 PST
From: Greg DesBrisay <gd@kuma>
Subject: Re: 912 Parts needed 



> Here is a list of some things I need for my 65/66 Porsche 912
> If anybody can help please give me a shout.  Also who is best to use for 
> mailorder.. I know about Tweeks and Performance Products.  Who else is 
> out there..These guys seem really high..especially Tweeks
> Thanks baggett@ix.netcom.com


I really like Stoddard for mail-order 912 parts.  Great service, good
prices, very competent salesfolks, and their parts are almost always
in stock for quick delivery!

	Stoddard	
	Willoughby, OH
	800-342-1414 or 216-951-1040 

For good used parts, Porsche Heaven is a really great outfit.  Lots of
others on this have come to same conclusion too.

	Parts Heaven
	1680 W. Winton, Hayward, CA
	510-782-0354 (-0358 fax) 

Also, don't forget to try your local Porsche dealer!  You'll be
surprised at how many parts for these old cars are still available
directly from Porsche at reasonable prices (Stoddard is in fact a
Porsche dealer, but they carry parts from other manufacturers too when
the Porsche part is not available).


> Engine Work		1	1000	1000	

Is your engine work estimate for rebuilding the engine?? If so, the
estimate is a bit low.  The cost of new pistons and cylinders alone
will be around $1000.  Plan on about $2000 for a rebuild, $3000 if
someone else does the entire rebuild for you.

Hope this helps!
You'll love your 912 when you're done!

Greg DesBrisay
'67 912

Porschephiles #1205                         Tue Feb 28 21:27:09 CST 1995
Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 16:24:29 -0500
From: Jerry944T@aol.com
Subject: 944 motor mounts/ important

Just received a Technical Bulletin straight from Porsche. 
Once again they have an UPDATED engine mount for all 944 series cars. They
include 924S, 944/S/S2/T. all years. 
The new mount # 951 375 042 04, supersedes the former version, 951 375 042
05. In a startling reversal it is no longer a hydraulic unit, but is spring
loaded. It is longer than the old mount thereby eliminating the 4mm spacer
used in the old model (on the right side). 
This mount is applicable to either side of the engine. They are also saying
that you can mix and match so you need not replace both mounts at the same
time. They are also a bit pricey although I don't have the exact numbers. I
do know that they are more expensive than the supersceeded part.(surprize)
BTW you don't have to have a vibration problem to need a new mount. The
factory would have you replace mounts if the engine oil pan drops below the
lowest point of the front crossmember. Something about not tearing out your
oil pan if you encounter an obstacle.

Regards,
Jerry
89 944turbo S black (track Car)
89 944turbo S Glacier Blue
Muffy & Portia,  the cats
7:18 am

reached by phone on 1-800-590-7770, or on email on Roddhot@aol.com.
	Thought this info may be useful for others trying to run a prestigious 
car on an economic budget...

I just bought a '76 914 2.0L.  Here are the good things about it:

 - 71K original miles (as far as I can tell), 2 previous owners
 - original lime green color, been repainted
 - very straight body with minimal rust
 - nice interior, 1 minor tear on the driver seat
 - runs strong, no leaks
 - all the little things (lights, switches, handles...) work

The bads:

 - Riviera rims gotta go.  For unknown reasons, I never liked 'em.
 - not an Appearance Group
 - I need a 3 car garage, or more :-)

The neutrals: (I'm not sure if it a good thing or not)

 - rear fenders pulled ever so slightly to accommodate
  wider tires.  Currently has 195/60s but with room to 
  spare for 205/60s.

Needed repairs:

 - needs muffler
 - front end vibrate a bit, probably tires off balance or 
  needs new rubber joints???
 - brake job
 - needs antennae and stereo
 - add the Appearance Group stuff
 - replace wheels

before I start my barrage of questions.

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 16:42:56 EST
From: reid_zeigler@Merck.Com (Reid Zeigler)
Subject: re: what good is Plastigauge?



I agree with John Lupien, it's just a safety net. It's also the
only way to make sure the bearings are what they say they are.
The chances of having mismarked or out of spec bearing shells 
is probably about nothing, but as the man says "do you feel lucky?"

One BIG word of caution: Rod bolts aren't reusable after they've
been torqued down so you have to use the old bolts when you check
clearances "at torque" with the plastigauge.

It's just one of those things I do, like writing down torque
readings on an engine diagram as I do them -- so I can sleep
at night - or drive 100+ mph without getting ulcers.

Reid



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 18:20:42 -0400
From: cbt@eduplus.ca (Stephen Davies)
Subject: Heating problems

The heat in my 951 S has the nasty habit of disappearing when I come to a
stop and the revs drop. It is normally fine at driving speeds though it
seems to take a little bit longer than usual. My local dealer recently
replaced a thermostat near the turbo to know avail. He now thinks that the
heater core could be gummed up. Could this be the problem?

Also, he says that a heater core is not covered under the 1 year dealer
purchase of used vehicle warranty. Does anyone have reason to doubt this ?

Stephen Davies
1988 944 Turbo S
  



------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 17:50:55 US/Eastern
From: George.Beuselinck@bbs.mhv.net (George Beuselinck)
Subject: Re: Heating problems

> The heat in my 951 S has the nasty habit of disappearing when I come to a
> stop and the revs drop. It is normally fine at driving speeds though it
> seems to take a little bit longer than usual. My local dealer recently
> replaced a thermostat near the turbo to know avail. He now thinks that the
> heater core could be gummed up. Could this be the problem?

A couple of questions:

1) Does the temperature gauge follow these fluctuations?

2) Have you checked the heater valve (located near the waterpump) that is
operated by a vacuum diaphragm (controls the flow of coolant to the heater
core...)

Heater core is probably not the problem... More likely the wrong thermostat
(located inside the waterpump.) I would remove and test the thermostat
first, or just replace with the proper new one...

Of course, in Canada, your kilometerage may vary.

> 
> Also, he says that a heater core is not covered under the 1 year dealer
> purchase of used vehicle warranty. Does anyone have reason to doubt this ?

One question: What does your *written* copy of the warranty say?

If it specifically states that it does or does not cover the heater core,
then that is the case.  If not, then PCNA's lawyers have not done their
job...


> 
> Stephen Davies
> 1988 944 Turbo S
>   
> 
>

Stahlflexes... Remember them?) Anyways, I'm 
debating either going sticking with a 195/50/15 and 
going with a Comp T/A ZR tire, or moving to a 
205/60/15, with an AVS Intermediate tire. Right now 
it seems like there'd be plenty of room between the 
tires and the fenders, but then the 50-series barely 
go into the fenders. (That's one of my problems, they 
just look too small!)

Any suggestions or thoughts? Thanks much.

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 18:06:13 -0800
From: davesens@rain.org (Dave Sens)

>The two biggest sins I've been noticing of late: following other cars far to
>closely for the speed and changing lanes/turning without signalling.

No kidding, I see this routinely here in Santa Barbara County where traffic
can generally be considered light to moderate.  Seems that my poor little
911 attracts it's share of tailgaiters.  At 70 mph, I've had people follow
me so closely that I can't even see any space between our two cars!  The
worst violators are drivers of "Sport Utillity Vehicles".  I guess they
figure that if the need to stop rapidly occurs, they'll just launch off the
back of my 911!
>
>The latter is especially onerous given the fact that the CHP recently made it
>known that something like 90% of the accidents on California roads and
>freeways  are the result of drivers failing to signal their intentions!
>
Interesting since I estimate that over 90% of law enforcemnt officers (CHP
included) fail to use their signals at *any* time.  This is particularly
troublesome considering that these people are supposed to be "professional"
drivers.  They set a poor example.

When I was a kid, driving seemed a joy in California.  Drivers were
generally polite and they generally signaled their intentions.  I remember
my dad complaining about lack of signaling and rude drivers on our summer
trips outside of California.  Now the is the norm throughout the country
rather than the exception.

But, what can you do?

Regards,

Dave Sens

------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 95 19:18:54 PST
From: John Wright <jpw@hpsadlb.sr.hp.com>
Subject: 911 rear defogger check

>Date: Wed, 25 Jan 95 12:47:29 EST
>From: jplawrence@goodyear.com (John P Lawrence)
>Subject: Re: re:rear window defogger

>>Hi Vol, I have a two stage that doesn't work. Could you or someone else out
>>there in the p-world detail how to test the circuits? Would love to have the
>>defogger working this winter!
>>
>I have the same problem with my '80 911SC. Have replaced fuses and relay
>with no success. Also interested in any forthcoming advice on this subject.

Below are some thoughts on checking the 911 rear defogger operation.
It took me a while to get around to it.

There should be enough information here to help test defogger elements
at swap meets/salvage yards.

For a lot of people it will be "been there, done that".

It's long, so here is a short summary. 

  From the engine compartment, make some resistance measurements, 
  calculate estimated power, measure voltage drop across relay contacts 
  to verify relay is ok, measure supply current and verify actual power
  is close to calculated power.

  There is also a procedure to probe for single "opens" in defogger grids
  if you want to attempt a repair.

This discussion assumes you have access to a digital multimeter (DMM). 

For around USD 100 you will get an autoranging DMM with 10A current range, 
0.1 ohm resolution, digital display and fast responding analog bar graph.
I own one of these and it has worked well for the 10 years I've had it.

If you don't want to get a high quality DMM, than an inexpensive DMM
might be adequate.

You CAN get a bare bones Chinese import 3 1/2 digit DMM with 10A current
measuring range, 5 DC ranges from 200mv to 1000 VDC, and 0.1 ohm resolution
for USD 15.00.  

This does NOT have the analog bar graph, auto ranging, sensitive AC 
voltage/AC current measurements or continuity beeper of the higher priced
DMMs.

The import DMM is likely not as mechanically/electrically rugged as
the more expensive DMM, but it is about 1/8th the price.

I keep the Chinese import DMM in my "swap meet" backpack (along with my
Chinese vernier calipers). 

Most of the defogger troubleshooting is done from the engine compartment,
since this is where the defogger relay, fuse and wiring harness originate.

A nominal 12 volt battery voltage is used in the discussion. 

For power calculations, I ignored voltage drops in supply leads, relay
contacts and connectors.

There is no +/- accuracy range on the measurements here.  These are to be 
regarded as characteristic measurements, not EXACT values.

But a typical decent DMM will resolve to 0.1 ohms on the 300 ohm range with an 
absolute accuracy of +/- (0.2 ohms + 0.7% of reading).

I used my USA "name brand" DMM for the measurements listed here.

Extrapolate to other than 69/72 years at your own risk.

911 rear defogger background information:

  The single heat defogger (69 911T coupe at least) has 9 elements and is
  rated at 100 watts (according to the 69/70 parts manual).

  The dual heat defoggers on 911's are split into three sections, and the
  wiring has the top + bottom as the 150 watt section and the middle
  as the 100 watt section.  Also according to the 72/73 911 parts manual.
  So this totals to 250 watts.

  The German language section of the 72/73 parts manual lists the
  rear Targa window at 300 watts.  

  Same part number, same electrical system as the USA version.

  Maybe the German rating is spec'ed at 13.8 volts (running voltage) and 
  the US at 12.6 volts (battery voltage), since this mathematically
  accounts for the difference.

  Essentially the "dual" heat defogger has 3 elements in the top section
                                           9                 middle
                                           7                 bottom

  This is true of both the coupe and Targa, at least for the two Targa
  glasses and one dual element coupe I looked at.

  The dual heat elements are electrically connected like this
  
                 |___________________________________|
            1    |___________________________________|
          _______|___________________________________|
          |       ___________________________________|  3
          |      |___________________________________|____
          |      |___________________________________|   |
          |  2   |___________________________________|   |
    +12V  |  ____|___________________________________|   |
          |      |___________________________________|___|
          |      |___________________________________|   |
          |      |___________________________________|   |
          |      |___________________________________|   |
          |       ___________________________________|   |
          |      |___________________________________|   |
          |      |___________________________________|   |
          |      |___________________________________|   |
          |      |___________________________________|___|___
          |      |___________________________________|       |
    +12V__|______|___________________________________|       V


  The 72T I have has a three position (off, halfway, fully out) switch.

  An illustration in the shop manual diagrams the dual section defogger
  this way

  +12V _____ 25A fuse ____4__| |_______2____><____100 watt element_______
                             | |  |                                     |
                                  |___| |_1_><____150 watt element______|3
                                      | |                               |
                                                                        V

  The single heat defogger element

  +12V _____ 25A fuse _______| |_____><____100 watt element____________
                             | |                                       | 
                                                                       V
  The  | | = relay contacts controlled by defogger switch.

  For the dual heat elements, this relay is a special rectangular shaped
  relay in the engine compartment.

  For the single heat elements, this relay is one of the "round" relays
  that is common on the 911.  It is also in the engine compartment.

       >< = defogger wiring connector inside engine compartment.

       |
       V  = ground lug on left side of engine compartment.

  First off, I'm skeptical the defogger 150 watt element is actually 150 watts.

  If each element is the same length (approx. true for a coupe rear window) 
  and has approximately the same cross-sectional area, I'd expect each segment
  have the same resistance and dissipate about the same power, so the center
  section of 9 elements would be about 9/10 the power of the top + bottom
  combined.  This would put the top + bottom at 100 watts * 10/9 = 111 watts,
  not 150.

  Maybe the top/bottom elements are thicker/wider than the middle elements.  

  The measurements I made on a USED coupe window indicate the center dissipates
  about the SAME power as the top + bottom combined.  

I. DMM Ohmmeter check with NO voltage to the defogger.

  1. Unplug the defogger connector in the left side of the engine compartment.

  2. Now measure the resistance from each of the exposed defogger connector
     pins TO the GROUND BOLT behind the Bosch CDI (1972 911T). 
     A new defogger should read about 1.44ohms on the 100watt section and 0.96
     ohms on the 150watt element.

     This is from the formula R = (V^2)/power  = 144/power.

  My experience is that defoggers tend to have scratched open segments or 
  be burned out so you won't get numbers close to the factory fresh values.

  This corresponds to measuring the resistance from 1 to 3 and 2 to 3
  in the above diagram.

  You are measuring 

        R          +  R                + R
        +12v lead     heating element    ground return

  After you make the measurement, you can calculate the approx. power your
  defogger grid will produce by

       Power = (V^2)/R  = 144/R

  I measured my spare "swap meet" three section coupe defogger window 
  (out of car) and came up with

            4.3 ohms for the top section of 3 elements
            1.5              middle         9 elements
            2.2              bottom         7 elements

  If you measure the window in the car, the top and bottom should measure
  a parallel resistance of ~ 1.5 ohms.

  I subtracted the DMM lead resistance (~0.2 ohms) from the actual readings 
  for the above chart.

  This corresponds (at 12 volts) to

           33.5 watts for the top
           96 watts for the middle section
           65 watts for the bottom

  So top + bottom totals 98.5 watts and top + bottom + middle = ~195 watts.

  These values correspond fairly well with the expected power levels, with 
  the top + bottom being low (stated 150, expected 111 watts, and ohmmeter
  measurement indicated a calculated 96).

  When I did this on my installed 72T Targa window, I measured

     2.7 ohms for one section
     3.5 ohms for the other section

     The parallel resistance of the two sections is 1.52 ohms,
     calculating to 7.89A (95 watts) with both sections on.

     So it runs at less than half rated power.

  3. Now measure the resistance from one of the exposed defogger connector
     pins TO the other defogger connector pin.  This should be slightly lower
     than the SUM of the readings in step 2, since you are measuring the series
     resistance of both elements without returning through the ground lead.

     You are measuring:

        R           +  R                  + R                 + R
        +12v lead1     heating element1     heating element2    +12v lead2

     The difference between the this reading and the SUM of step 2 should
     approximate twice the resistance of the defogger ground return lead,
     since the ground return lead resistance is included in BOTH of the
     step 2 readings.

     When I did this I measured 6.1 ohms.  The sum of the two step 2 readings
     was 6.2 ohms.  Given the stated accuracy of the ohmmeter of +-0.2ohms,
     one can't determine the actual ground resistance with any accuracy.

     But, it did not measure at any significant resistance.
     
     If the sum of the step 2 readings is much higher than step 3, than 
     you have a poor/open ground connection.

  This resistance check could be made as part of a pre-purchase inspection
  and be done fairly quickly.

  If the grid measures at a high resistance, on to step II to see if the
  defogger grid is itself bad.

II. Resistance Measurements at defogger grid itself INSIDE the car

  Purpose of the test:

    See if the resistance readings at the defogger grid agree with
    the ones taken from the engine defogger connector.  This will
    let you know if the defogger grid is OK, but the wiring harness
    leading to it is not.

  Power to the defogger is OFF.

  This can be skipped if I. gives decent results.

  With the DMM in ohms mode, probe at one ground tab (USA passenger
  side of window) and the +12 supply lead at the USA drivers side of the
  window at each of the two sections (middle, upper+lower) and record the
  readings. 

  With the window in the car, the top and bottom elements are in parallel,
  so you can't read them independently unless you unplug the jumper wire
  inside the window gasket.  If you do measure a different number while 
  probing at the top and bottom, then the jumper wire connecting the
  two sections is not making a good contact.

  The resistance measurements should be somewhat less than the values 
  measured from the engine compartment since you're not measuring the 
  supply leads.  
    
  If you get a large difference in resistance measurements, you have
  a bad connection to +12volt supply lead(s).

  Check that the slide on terminals in the rear window gasket are not 
  corroded and are firmly in position.

III. Supply voltage to defogger connector checking.

  The purpose of the test is to see if the defogger grid is getting
  12 volts thru the defogger relays/defogger switch.

  It won't be necessary to have the car running to do this test,
  as a new defogger at full power would take about 4 hours to
  completely discharge an 80 amp-hour battery.

  The ignition switch must be in the ON position for the defogger to get 
  power.

  1. Slightly separate the defogger connector in the engine compartment so
     a DMM probe can touch the contacts while they are powered.
       
  2. Turn the defogger switch to the half on position, and measure
     the voltage from the connector terminal to the ground lug (on
     the left side of the engine compartment).  One of the connectors
     should read around 12 volts.

     Check the contact drop across the relay by measuring from the defogger
     fuse to the connector terminal.  It should be low, (I measured 
     ~0.35 volts for the 72T defogger relay) and is a low value because 
     a closed relay contact should drop near zero volts.

     This corresponds to measuring the voltage drop across 2-4 in the
     above diagram.

     If this is a high voltage, either the relay is not being activated
     by the defogger switch or is defective.  You may want to remove the 
     relay from the socket and check for corrosion on the relay terminals.

  3. Pull the switch to the full out position, and measure the voltage
     at the other connector terminal.  It should be ~12 volts.  

     Check the contact drop as before.

     This corresponds to measuring the voltage drop across 1-4 in the
     above diagram.
   
  4. If you're not getting 12 volts, check the following:

        1. Corroded defogger fuse contacts
        2. Fatigued defogger fuse contacts
        3. Bad defogger fuse (25A is the installed value)
        4. Corrosion in the defogger relay socket
        5. Corrosion on the defogger relay terminals
        6. Bad defogger relay 
        7. Bad defogger switch
        8. Connector inside engine compartment is corroded.
     
     If the defogger fuse is blown and a new one fails, the
     rear window defogger wiring may be installed incorrectly and
     shorting to chassis.  A body shop that re-installed my Targa
     window did this.
     
     In general, a good fuse or contact should drop near zero volts
     during operation.  So the DMM can be used in volts mode
     to check for unexpected voltage drops across components 
     (fuses, switch contacts, relay contacts, and connectors ) that should
     not drop any significant voltage. 

     Relay activation can be tested by listening for a mechanical click
     as the defogger switch is activated or the relay can be removed
     and the activation voltage read with the DMM from the exposed
     socket.

IV. Power to defogger grid measurement.

  If you want to, you can determine the power developed by your
  defogger grid using the current measuring mode of your DMM.

  Since you have measured the resistance of the elements can calculate
  the power they develop by the formula I^2 * R.

     or

  Calculate the power by 12 * I.

  The current is measured in two stages since many DMM's do not measure 
  greater than 10A.

  The 150Watt element should take 12.5A max
      100watt element should take  8.33 A max

  I'm assuming the 12.5A will not actually occur, both because most
  tested defoggers will be somewhat worn out and/or because the defogger grid
  is stated optimistically.

  1. Remove the 25A defogger fuse in the engine compartment.
     Insert the DMM (in DC current mode) in place of the fuse.

  2. Unplug the dual element defogger and re-insert it such that
     only ONE connector is active.

               O_____O  <-- one half of connector assembly
                \
                 \
                  \ 
                   O    <-- other half of connector assembly

     This is done to avoid overloading the DMM with 
     the combined 12.5A + 8.33A.

  3. Now activate the defogger switch with the DMM
     in DC current mode.  Pull the defogger switch fully out since
     this activates BOTH elements.

     Measure the current.

  4. Now unplug the connector and re-insert to activate the other
     element,  repeat the measurement for the other element.

  The available power is = 12 * sum of current measured.

  It should correspond fairly well with the power calculated
  from V^2/(resistance) measured above.
     
  There WILL be a difference because there is a voltage drop across
  the defogger relay contacts and the DMM leads.

  BE SURE TO TAKE THE DIGITAL MULTIMETER OUT OF CURRENT MODE AFTER THIS
  MEASUREMENT, otherwise you may try to measure volts sometime later 
  and put an effective short circuit across the device under test since
  the DMM is still in current measurement mode.   The DMM appears as 
  a high impedance during voltage measurements but as a low impedance 
  during current measurements.

  Re-connect the defogger connector.

V. Determining bad defogger individual elements assuming the defogger is
   getting 12 volts and everything else is ok.

  DMM IS IN MEASURE VOLTS MODE.

  Power is applied to the defogger for this test.

  The voltmeter negative lead is connected to the ground side of the
  grid (USA passenger side)

  This is assuming the positive end of the defogger is at +12,
  and the ground end is near 0 volts.

  If you want to check that individual elements are working, carefully 
  probe the voltage at the center of the window at each element.  If it is 
  about 6 volts, then the individual element is complete and likely to be
  uniform.  

  It may be uniformly worn, but this will spot opens.  If the voltage at the
  center is 12 volts then there is an open on the ground (earth) half of the
  element.

  Be careful not to scratch the defogger grid and cause an open. You might
  want to use a rounded tip probe to avoid this problem.

  If the voltage at the center is 0 volts then there is an open on the + side
  of the individual grid.  An unstable measurement could be multiple
  opens on either side of the center.

  If the individual element has a SINGLE open, you can use the DMM
  to probe for the open position, since the open will indicate +12v on one
  side and zero on the other side of the open.

  You may be able to repair a small break with conductive paint.

 
John Wright   jpw@sr.hp.com


------------------------------

Date: Tue, 28 Feb 1995 22:38:46 -0500
From: Zunknown@aol.com
Subject: 944 Motor Mounts 

OK, does anybody out there have the definitive answer to the question; What
is the latest 944 motor mount?

JerryT's message this past weekend aroused my curiosity....do the latest
mounts really have springs in them instead of fluid?

I've been gathering what info I can for the past 2 days (still lots of work
to do), and have found this:

 -The 951 375 042 04 mount, which is supposed to be the latest supercession
has been in the Porsche price book for at least a year. 

 -The Euroselect catalog contains a memo describing how the then new "04"
mount has superceded the "05". The "04" has a 4mm thicker flange which
eliminates the need for spacers/washers. This 4mm thicker flange also
contains threaded holes which eliminates the need for bolts AND nuts...just
thread the bolts into the flange.

 -Most of the mounts on the market now are "04"s, but there may be some "05"s
left out there somewhere (are they the ones on "special"?).

The question remains; what about the spring? Is there really a spring inside
the "04" mount? If not, what IS inside an "04"? (I heard somewhere they are
solid).

I'll keep researching, but can anyone else shed some light on this?

>to make a signal (outside of an crash situation)?  I don't go around

>getting a ticket for this.  Of course, I seldom see the cops signalling
>either.  Might be a cause and effect here...

I was once sitting in a left turn only lane in Kingman, Arizona when one of 
the county mounties pulled in behind me.  The green arrow came up and I 
proceeded to turn.  Immediately the cop turns on his lights and pulls me 
over.  He walks up and asks if I knew why he was pulling me over.  I had no 
idea.  He then proceeded to tell me I failed to signal my turn.  What 
complete bullsh*t.  I finally managed to talk him down to a warning.  I 
think he was just hassling me because I had out of state plates.

Albert Hsu  '82 911SC
